title: Wilson and Byrne Ask More Gasoline
description: While officials of the Federal Energy Office in Washington worked feverishly yesterday to preoare March gasoline alloca tion for every sate, the Governors of New York and New Jersey continued to press thel Government for more gasoline.

title: Gasoline Shortage ...
description: President Nixon told the nation this week that he had personally observed long gasoline lines, but his subsequent comments indicate a failure to understand the ordeal to which a deepening gas shortage is subjecting millions of Americans. His announced intention to veto the emergency energy bill suggests nothing to the contrary.

title: Off Off Broadway Shows
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to a show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers

title: Selassie, to Placate Army, Appoints a New Premier
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Friday, March 1Emperor Haile Selassie appointed a new Premier yesterday in an attempt to placate mutinous army troops, but it appeared that the almost absolute authority that he had exercised for more than half a century had been deeply eroded.

title: PRICES FAIL AGAIN ON COMMODITIES
description: A sharp break in commodity prices that began late Wednesday continued yesterday. Most basic raw materials prices closed at or near their daily permissible downward hints again.

title: Output and Stocks of Gasoline Reported Almost Equal to 1973
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 28 (UN)  As Americans waited in line for gasoline, the Amencan Petroleum Institute reported today that gasoline production and gasoline stocks in the United States last week were almost the same as a year ago  and crude oil stocks were higher.

title: Missing Wilt on Special Job for Boss
The Mexican Steak Didn't Fight Back Enough
description: Confine me without food until I settle on one national cuisine as my exclusive source of nourishment for the rest of my life, and I would probably starve to death trying to choose between Chinese and Mexican after discarding French with relief, North American with reluctance, and Italian con sentimento molto profondo.

title: GROMYKO WARNS ARABS ON UNITY
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 28Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, stressing the need for greater SovietArab solidarity, warned Arab states today to be wary of Israeli tricks and maneuvers to split the Arabs and retain their territory.

title: Guerrillas in Lebanon Jails Reported on Hunger Strike
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Feb. 33 (AP)About 150 Palestinian guerrillas have gone on a hunger strike in Lebanese prisons, demanding trial or immediate release, guerrilla sources reported today.

title: Stage: Hume Cronyn Dances Through Coward in Two Keys
description: Sir Noel Coward's astonishing talent to amuse is giving New York its newest gift, a final posthumous premiere. It is called Noel Coward in Two Keys. It opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater and will be around

title: U.S. Office Assesses Use Of RevenueSharing Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 More than 60 per cent of all Federal general revenuesharing funds that have thus far been spent by thousands of state and local governments have been used for education, public safety and transportation, the Office of Revenue Sharing reported today.

title: Mrs. Paul Chavchavadze Dies; Russian Princess Was an Artist
description: HYANNIS, Mass, Feb. 28Mrs Paul Chavchavadze, the former Princess Nina of Russia, who was an artist, died yesterday in Cape Cod Hospital, after a short illness. She was 72 years old and had lived in Wellfleet since 1939.

title: Cochrans Dominant In Slalom
description: WILMINGTON. N.Y., Feb. 28Cochran was the name of the game again today as two members of that famous ski racing family sped to impressive triumphs in the United States giant slalom championships on Whiteface Mountain.

title: Monitoring Government
description: One of the constructive developments of recent years has been the upsurge in the number of publicinterest law firms, legal defense funds and citizens' organizations concerned with the functioning of government as it is supposed to function. They have been variously inspired by Ralph Nader's crusading, by the legal services section of the antipoverty program, by the civil rights and environmental movements.

title: Bridgehampton: The Sounds and the Silences
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N. Y Most of us who live more or less in solitude deserve a place of our own, outside the house, to visit when the gloom of home deepens with the early dark, where we can remain as private as we desire, lifting the veils of silence whenever we want to That place for me is a saloon named Bobby Van's, an angular structure on Main Street with dark paneling, Tiffany lamps and old fans suspended from an undistinguished ceiling, a long mahogany bar, and from the back the flickering of candles on small booths and tables covered with red tablecloths This is a village of dogs, big country dogs with melancholy faces who roam about unencumberedall honored local personalities and it is indicative of the notability of Bobby Van's that they always come in packs and scratch on the front door, wanting to be let inside

title: 2 TELL HOW BROWN SAID HE GOT PISTOL
description: Two detectives testified yesterday that Henry S Brown, on trial in the murder of two policemen, told them he had gotten a slain officer's resolver front a man who admitted killing Officers Gregory P Foster and Rocco W Laurie two years ago in the Last Village

title: Trudeau Budget a Record; Special Programs Stressed
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 28Prune Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government proposed today a record spending program of more than $22billion for the fiscal year 1975 beginning April 1.

title: A Queens Prosecutor Is Indicted With 10 Others on Drug Charges
description: A 31yearold lawyer who was an assistant district attorney in Queens until last Monday and 10 other persons have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of having conspired to sell cocaine, hashish and phencychdine worth $680,000.

description: ROME, Feb 28  Italy's Treasury Minister, Ugo La Malta, resigned tonight in a dispute oer ways to fight inflation, making it almost impossible for Premier Mariano Rumor's centerleft Government to stay in power.

description: One year after rumblings of consumer discontent that prompted boycotts and demonstrations over rising food costs, the family grocery bill is higher than ever. An Associated Press market basket survey shows that the prices are 16 per cent: above the level of last March

title: Gotcha Squad Harassing By State Police Is Alleged

title: January's Loss Up For Penn Central; Higher Costs Cited
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday that the carrier had a net loss on a fully accrued basis of $34.21million in January compared with a deficit of $23 1million in the 1973 month.

title: Rozelle Is Wary Of Strike

title: New Jersey Briefs

Named by a Federal grand jury in the sevencount indictment were Joseph Orlando, 40 years old, of Floral Park, Queens, former assistant vice president and principal loan officer of the Middlesex County Bank; Seymour Kaplan, 45, of Freeport, L. I.; Theodore Demagistris, 48, of Yonkers; Benjamin Cohen, 55, of Great Neck, L. I. and Edward Dicicco, of Staten Island

title: TV: An Incisive Study of Living Costs on Today
description: The National Broadcasting Company's Today show shifted its focus somewhat yesterday morning and improved considerably its scope. The entire program, Up, Up and Away, was a broad examination of the high cost ofliving. That is two hours, from 7 A M. to 9 Well, minus breaks for local and national news and for the usual numbing barrage of commercials, it's closer to one hour but let's not get into that aspect of the format this time around1973, to January, 1974, consumer prices rose 9.4 per cent. In an attempt to cope, people actually ate less last year, Mr. McGee noted, but wound up paying more anyway. And, of course, since they patriotically cut back on gas and electricity use, the utility companies have accelerated demands for rate increases.

title: Advertising: Bouncing Glare

title: Death Penalty Put in Bill To Curb Plane Hijacking

title: The Age Of Greed
description: LONDON, Feb 28A strange quiet has fallen on Britain now. The battle of personalities in the constituencies is over and the battle for the solvency of the nation has begun. Everything looks the samea busy traffic in the streets, the almond trees, the daffodils and the crocuses blooming in the bright green parks  but somehow everybody senses that the future will be different.

Excuse me, whispered the blond woman, dragging two small children through the carpeted office, are you with the Historical Society?William C Loud leaned against his office desk, a Louis XIV reproduction, smiled gently and shook his head No, he replied softly, I'm just trying to run a business here.

title: Closing the School Gap
description: When the City University adopted its policy of open admission, success of the program depended inevitably on the effectiveness of remedial instruction. The obvious, but usually unspoken, question was why such remedial efforts should have had to be delayed until the college years. Could there be any doubt that it would be pedagogically and socially more desirable to teach the necessary proficiency in reading, mathematics and other areas during the normal twelve years of school rather than by way of a crash program in college?

title: State Is Planning to Construct Nuclear Plant on Hudson by '82
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28The State Power Authority announced today that it had decided to build a nuclear power plant along the Hudson River at either. Athens or Cemeton, in Greene County, by 1982.

title: Screen: Solas's 'Lucia'
description: At last we're privileged to see Humberto Solas's "Lucia," completed in 1969, when the director was 26; it opened at the First Avenue Screening Room on Tuesday. Spanning nearly 70 years of Cuban history, this extraordinary movie focuses on three generations of women whose lives reflect the society around them.The first section of the movie is set in 1895, when the Cuban nationalists were warring against the Spanish rule. Lucia (Raquel Revuelta), an aristocrat with ruffles at her throat, has a brother in the rebel army. Since so many men are being killed off, she doubts that she'll ever marry. But she falls violently in love with a stranger who claims to be apolitical, and elopes with him even though he's married. As they ride toward the coffee plantation where the rebels are hidden, troops hired by the Spanish gallop out of the hills, her lover throws her off his horse, and she realizes that he was simply using her to discover the nationalist' secret headquarters. Many are killed, including her brother, and she later stabs her betrayer to death.Some differ sharply in their responses to the three parts of "Lucia." I found this section lushly overacted  almost in the style of silent movies. The women have been directed to flutter and squeal until they appear like a parody of winsome maidenhood. Operatic music throbs whenever the lovers' eyes meet, and the enthusiastic battle scene seems straight out of one of our Westerns: It's odd that a Cuban film maker should have used such mossy capitalistic models. The men fight with a gleeful gusto that's almost amusing, and what comes through is the glory of war, not its tragedy  although that's probably not what Mr. Solas intended.'Lucia, 1933" is far more successful. This Lucia, a delicate, discontented daughter of the middle class, flees her parents' world of canasta parties and posh country houses and takes off with Aldo, a young revolutionary, who's involved in the overthrow of the dictator Gerardo Machado. But the new rgime is as rotten as the old one. Disgusted, Aldo tries to revive the revolutionand is shot dead.The vulnerable young woman who dwells with loss and change is admirably played by Eslinda Nunez, who can ring the changes from intense happiness to misery, and conveys fragility even when shouting at her mother or working, wan and pregnant, in a cigar factory. The street scenes, with everyone running and bleeding and weeping, distill all the confusion of urban warfare, the uncertainty of who did what to whom. The weaknesses are the images of corruption (an unconvincing orgy) and the fact that the revolutionary's character is inadequately developed. Since he lacks any dimension beyond his political beliefs, the impact of his death is lessened.The final episode, "Lucia, 196 ," is absolutely splendid, and reveals Mr. Solas's vast talent for comedy. The third Lucia (Adela Legra) is a stunning young field workeras robust as the last Lucia was frail. Newly wed to a beguiling hulk (Adolfo Llaurado), she revels in their long days of sexual clowning (In "Lucia, 1895," sex was made to appear very threatening, and desire almost unbearable.) But the husband won't let Lucia return to work or even leave their house. As he nails up the windows so that other men won't see her, she complains that she's no longer allowed to look at her own mother.Well-wishers warn the man that he's betraying the revolution through his machismo and his possessiveness; he replies that he's the revolution. Lucia is told that a wife is not a slave, that her husband must learn that times have changed. When he insists on total obedience, it's remarked that he's behaving as his father did, and according to his prerevolutionary upbringing.Wretchedly divided, she leaves and goes back to the fields. There's a hilarious scene when he orders her home, chases her and is himself chased by her female co-workers, who surround and hold him while he and Lucia yell with fury. Daft about each other, they're unable to separate or to agree about her way of life, and as the movie ends they are still fighting between embraces The whole picture stresses thatalthough many women haven't yet won the most ordinary kinds of freedomthe present is far superior to the past I wish that "Lucia, 196 . ." might be seen by all the sexes: it's the best discussion of equality (and inequality) I've seen on screen, and the clashes are clarified by comedy.

title: MRS. JEAN POLETTI IS DEAD IN FLORIDA
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla, Feb. 28Mrs. Jean Ellis Poletti, a former president of the New York State League of Women Voters, a pioneer in what became the United States Committee for UNICEF, and the wife of Charles Poletti, a former Governor of New York, died yesterday in Naples Community Hospital. She lived here since 1966 and spent summers in Elizabethtown, N. Y.

description: Two detectives testified yesterday that Henry S. Brown, on trial in the murder of two policemen, told them he had gotten a slain officer's revolver from a man who admitted killing Officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie two years ago in the East Village.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Avery Fisher Hall, 2

title: New Governor Appointed In Argentine Revolt Area
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28The revolt by rightwing policemen in Crdoba, the second largest city in Argentina, continued tonight after a new governor assumed office in the province.

title: THOMAS M. CURRAN
description: BOSTON, Feb 28 (AP)Thomas M Curran, a former Jesuit priest who became newspaper editor after he left that order, died yesterday He was 47 years old.

title: I.R.S. Says Many in Area Err in Government's Favor
description: Thousands of taxpayers in the New York metropolitan area who have already filed their Federal tax returns have made arithmetical errors causing them to overcharge themselves, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday.

title: Weary Britons Watch the Vote Coming In
description: LONDON, Feb 28Rain in Scotland, snow in Devon, but none of this upsidedown weather kept the British from pressing in large numbers into schools, churches, improvised booths and vn a pub or two after a most peculiar and upsidedown election campaign.

title: Screen: Pedestrian
Music: Direct Approach of Schippers
description: One of the nice things about Carnegie Hall's Festival of Visiting Orchestras is the chance it gives us to hear orchestras from around the country. On Wednesday night It was the turn of the Cincinnati Symphony, conducted by Thomas Schippers. The soloist was Shirley Verrett, who sang Mozart and Wagner. The orchestra was heard in Mozart's Cosl fan tutte Overture and the Brahms Second Symphony.

title: Special State Jury to Hear Oil PriceFixing Charges
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that the Appellate Division had agreed to his request for a special grand jury to hear charges involving alleged criminal activities in the petroleum industry. He said the jury would be empancled on March 11

title: World's Species Termed Being Depleted
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 The world's diverse species of mammals and birds are becoming extinct at a rate of about one a year, representing what seems an irreversible biological impoverishment of the earth, it was reported at a twoday symposium on endangered species that ended here today.

title: AMERICAN EXPORT SETS A LOAN PACT
description: A revised bank loan agreement has been negotiated by American Export Industries, Inc, subject to the closing on or before March 8 of the company's sale of its terminal facilities in Staten Island to the City of Nets York, among other conditions

title: P.S.C. GIVES CON ED RATE RISE OF 12.3%
description: ALBANY, Feb 28The Public Service Commission approved today a $174.7million, or 12 3 per cent, interim electricity rate increase for the Consolidated Edison Company At the same time it ordered an independent management study of the company answerable directly to the commission.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  United States monetary reserves rose by $187million in January, largely reflecting a repayment to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Aid for Officers' Survivors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill yesterday that would award a $50,000 death benefit to the surN ivors of public safety officers killed in line of duty The lump sum payments would go to the beneficiaries of policemen firemen and other law enforcement officers

description: Mayor Beanie is planning to name a threemember mediation panel soon to assist negotiators for the Transit Authority and bus and subway employes in working out a new contract before their present agreement expires at midnight March 31

Brasco had called him in May, 1968, demanding to know why the post office had canceled a trucking contract with a Bronx concern headed by a reputed Mafia captain.

description: CAIRO, Feb 28 (AP)Eight Arab guerrillas accused of killing the American Ambassador to the Sudan, his aide and a Belgian diplomat have confessed to the killings and will be brought to trial in the Sudan on Saturday, diplomatic sources said

They said that Chinese officials appeared eager to reassure them that the current doctrinal campaign would not affect China's policy of improved relations with the West

title: Nixon Aide Resigning
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) A Cambridge. Mass, man who has been an advance man for President Nixon during the Presidential campaign and on several world trips is leaving the White House in midMarch Jack D'Arcy, 30 years old, will return to the banking business.

title: Marines Held in Rifle Theft
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb 28 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investstigation said today that 12 of 17 rifles stolen from a Marine Corps base had been recovered and the four Marine suspected had seen arrested.

title: FARM PRICES UP BY 1.5% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) Prices of raw farm products rose 1.5 per cent from Jan. 15 to Feb 15, moving closer to the record level set last summer, the Agriculture Department said today.

description: BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP)Ross Brooks tied the National Hockey League record for the most consecutive victories by a goalie, and Phil Esposito reached another milestone with his 450th and 451st career goals tonight in an 81 Boston Bruins victory over the Detroit Red Wings

title: Democrats Settle Damage Suit Against G.O.P. for $775,000
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 28 (UPI) The Democratic National Committee agreed today to settle for $775,000 its $6 4million civil damage suit against the Committee for the Reelection of the President over the breakin at its Watergate headquarters here on June 17, 1972.

title: JURY IS SELECTED AM SEQUESTERED IN MITCHELL CASE
description: A jury of eight men and four women was selected and sequestered, yesterday for the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, clearing the way for what is expected to be a series of major indictments today in Watergaterelated scandals.The indictments have been held up pending isolation of the jurors to avoid prejudicing them in the historic trial of the former Attorney General and the former Secretary of Commerce.

description: Good, oldfashioned AlkaSeltzer, whose safety and effectiveness is currently under study at the Food and Drug Administration, is going to have a sister product called AlkaSeltzer Without Aspirin. It's the aspirin that has been held as being possibly hazardous to ulcer sufferers.

description: ALBANY, Feb 28 (UPI)Phantom or flybynight funeral establishment will find it harder to do business under new State Health Department regulations that went Into effect today.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $813million, up 4 per cent from the year earlier 8780million. Total retail store sales were about $8 811billion, virtually unchanged from last year's $8 853billion.

title: Recital
description: Stephen Bishop, the Americanborn pianist who has lived in London for the last 15 years, served notice right away in his recital at Hunter College Playhouse on Wednesday night that he prizes individuality. He went at Bath's Prelude and Fugue in C sharp minor from the second book of The WellTempered Clavier in a highly personal style, steerMg completely away from the antiseptic objectivity that some Bach specialists believe best suits such music.

title: Additional Rises in Prices Of Gasoline Set for Today
description: Getty Oul, Cities Service and Standard Oil of California said yesterday they were raising the wholesale price of gasoline, effective today The increases, ranging from less than a penny to more than 5 cents a gallon, will be passed on directly to motorists.

description: A Traffic Department survey released yesterday verified what garage and parking lot operators have known for weeks: The number of vehicles entering the city has dropped sharply.

I, Feb 27  Textron, Inc, the former textile concern that became a pioneer in American corporate doiversification, was host here today to a soviet trade official who plays a key role in the much dis cussed transfer of technology between the United States and the Soviet Union

description: NEWARK, Feb. 28  Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was pictured at his Federal fraud trial today as either a peddler of political influence or a scapegoat for an ambitious company official.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb 28Attorneys for President Nixon have concluded that the Constitution requires not only a finding of criminal conduct but also criminal acts of a very serious nature to provide grounds for impeaching a President.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Feb 1 on the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, The New York Times quoted the Rev Leighton Ford, an evangelist who is the brotherInlaw of the Rev Billy Graham, as praising a talk by President Nixon at the breakfast Mr Ford's praise was directed at a prior speech given by Senator Harold Hughes of Iowa

title: VW WEIGHS LAYOFF OF 126,000 WORKERS
description: LONDON, Feb 28(AP) Volkswagen may have to lay off temporarily 126.000 workers in six plants tor 10 or 11 days in April because of sagging sales to the United States, its chairman, Rudolf Leiding, said today.

title: Grote Is 3d Victim of Mets' Iron Monster
description: ST PETERSBURG, Fla, Feb. 28The New York Mets will not bat against live pitching until tomorrow, but they still showed their legend. ary talent for mayhem today when Jerry Grote was struck on the left elbow  by a pitching machine.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. Feb 28When the Yankees' infielders and outfielders report for their first spring workouts tomorrow, they may be surprised to find that Graig Nettles has been here all week. Some may be surprised to find out he's here at all.

title: 2Hour Allowance for Rescue Gives Osprey Sailing Victory
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 28 The race committee today announced a new winner of the MiamiNassau ocean race, which concluded here on Tuesday Osprey was named the overall winner after she had been Riven a credit of two hours in her time allowance because of her rescue of the crew of Wimoweh, which had foundered off Great Isaac Light last Monday night

title: House Panel Rejects Nixon Plan For Federal Officials' Pay Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 28 Prospects for enactment of President Nixon's proposed 22 5 per cant, threeyear pay increase for members of Congress, the Judiciary and other top Federal officials diminished rapidly today as the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee voted to reject the entire pay package

title: NO MEETING HELD ON CULTURAL AIDE
description: Contrary to an impression given by Mayor Beame's office, the city's fivemember Board of Ethics did not meet to discuss the propriety of Irving Goldman's appointment as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. Only the board's counsel and one of its members reviewed the case, hte counsel, S. Stanley Kreutzer, confirmed yesterday.

title: Dr. Frank FremontSmith Dies; Mental Health Leader Was 78
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Feb 28 Dr. Frank FremontSmith, former president of the World Federation for Mental Health, who was prominent in psychiatry and medical philanthropy, died yesterday at the Parkview Nursing Home. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: S.E.C. AND TREASURY OPPOSE STOCK CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 28The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Treasury Department have advised the Senate Securities Subcommittee of their strong opposition to giving the S E C. mandatory Dower to ban or restrict trading in listed securities off the floor of national stock exchanges.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A report issued today by a Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee called for suspension of a plan to base a navy aircraft earner near Athens until the Greek Government takes irreversible steps toward a free electoral process.

title: A Queens Prosecutor Indicted on Drug Charges
description: A 31 yearold lawyer who was an assistant district attorney in Queens until last Monday and 10 other persons have been Indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of having conspired to sell cocaine, hashish and phencyclidine worth 680,000.

title: D.C. HEALTH STUDY SCORES DIAGNOSES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The most basic medical problems of children in the nation's capital are poorly diagnosed and inadequately treated, a study released today has concluded.

description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's second largest international oil company, after the Exxon Corporation, announced yesterday a 153 per cent increase in 1973 earnings, to $1.78billion from $704million in 1972.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 28Minor White, the American photographer, was once described by an admiring colleague as teacher, critic, publisher, theoretician, proselytizer and house mother for a large portion of the community of serious photographers. All that, of course, in addition to being photographer of classic eminence in his own right.

title: Stars Top Rockets On Balanced Drive
Loss of Ford's Seat in Election Laid to a Revolt Against Nixon

title: Merce Cunningham Likes a Risk in Career
description: Just when it appeared that Merce Cunningham was throwing in the towel, he was really taking up the cudgel. After 25 years of activity that has gained him an international reputation as dance's chief iconoclast. Mr. Cunningham has radically reordered the priorities of his artistic career.

description: OLD BRIDGE, Feb. 28Marie and Michelle Treeon, the 4yearold twins released from Babies Hospital on Valentine's Day after undergoing corrective heart surgery, celebrated the beginning of their third week at home today with a brisk ride on their new yellow bicycles.

title: Educational TV Hopes to Make Math Less Abstract and Far More Palatable
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 23 I want you to guess something about your body, said the teacher. Which is bigger, your head or your waist? That was an easy one for Jonathan Persons, a chubby 9yearold from Boston's black ghetto of Roxbury, who jumped up swinging his 30inch waist, clearly bigger than his 20inch head. But the choice was not so obvious for many or the other children, and a tape measure had to be used to see if they had guessed right.

description: ORLANDO, Fla, Feb. 28 (UPI)Jack Ewing scored his first holeInone today in posting a 67 for a share of the firstround lead of the $150,000 Citrus open, and Arnold Palmer fought back from a triple bogey with two eagles to finish one stroke back.

description: As you can see, said Pegi Pearson, gesturing toward some simply framed abstract works, I want to get back to painting

title: One for All and All for Alma Mater
description: When they asked Sam Snead what mysterious motivation could keep a man of 61 traipsing around the world in unremitting competition with golfers almost 40 years younger, he replied with simple candor The money. What is true of the old Slammer does not necessarily apply to all performers in the International Track Association's barnstorming animal act Or so one is forced to conclude when a professional of Jim Rvun's eminence turns in a halfmile clocking of 1 minute 56 seconds, for pay That might have beaten most undergraduates 70 years ago but it would not qualify a runner for this weekend's renewal of the I C 4A indoor championships (That's the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America, which will be evacily half as old as the United States of America in the bicentennial year of 1976)

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOTAL RECALL, Pat Cooper, who was once a kid and, luckily for us, remembers it all, is reminiscing these evenings at Jimmy's, the big restaurantwatering hole at 33 West 52d Street (7578484). Mr. Cooper's lookback on an ItalianAmerican childhood erupts, in a goodhumoredit really does get the deep laughsmonologue during which he goes over what was, what is and how. He has a good ear for language and a good mouth for using it, and even it you're familiar with his general themes and style, you'll listen as though it were all fresh. He's in the 52d Street Room of this threefloor emporium, sharing the bill with Cathy Carlson, a comely and powerfulvoiced singer.

title: Chase Renewing Bid for Dial Financial
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the holding company of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said yesterday it was filing a new application with the Federal Reserve Board to acquire the Dial Financial Corporation, a consumer loan company. Chase's l973 request for permission to acquire Dial was denied by the Federal Reserve Board in January. The new application includes commitments to provide important additional public benefits, Chase said.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1News conference:

title: Meskill Signs Bill Putting End To the 6.5% Utility Sales Tae
description: HARTFORD, March 1Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today signed a law eliminating Connecticut's 6.5 per cent sales tax from utility bills.

title: For U. S. Support of a Rhodesian Settlement
description: WASHINGTONThere can be an early settlement in Rhodesia if we encourage it. There might be a lasting settlement in Rhodesia if we support it. There will probably be a war in Rhodesia, if we stand aside. If war comes, we will be greatly affected.

title: Nets Spoil Return of Wilt, Rout Q's
Police Shoot Kearny Man In MistakenIdentity Case
description: KEARNY, March 1 (UPI)A Kearny man incorrectly thought to be a fugitive was shot in the head after the man tried to run down two Federal narcotics agents, the police said today.

title: After Suspense of Investigation, Rules of the Courtroom Now Come Into Play
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 For all the drama of the Watergate grand jury's announcement today, for all the daybyday buildup of suspense, it is only an indictment. It will take months to turn the indictment into anything moremonths of legal motions and jury selection and trial, months of battling in the courtroom.

title: British Pound Plunges
description: The value of the British pound fell 1.85 cents and prices of stocks went down 24 points in hectic trading in London yesterday in reaction to the setback for Britain's Conservative Government. Details on Page 41.

title: Hartnett I.C.4A Threat; U.S.Soviet Meet Today
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 1John Hartnett never appears like he's running fast enough to record a 3:54.7 Outdoor mile or 8:26.6 indoor twomile, his surprising achievements within the list year in track and field.

title: Arraignment Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The arraignment of a Texas lawyer, Jake Jacobsen, who is charged with lying about milk producers' political contributions, was postponed today until March 15. Mr. Jacobsen was an aide to President Johnson but switched to a quiet fundraising role for President Nixon in the 1972 campaign.

title: Idea Offered by Doctor To Prevent Earthquakes
description: WASHINGTON, March 1A New York physician with oil and mining interests has invented a method designed to prevent earthquakes and other disturbances in the earths crust caused by the removal of things underneath. Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson was granted Patent 3,793,839 this week for the devices and procedures to be used. Patent applications have been filed in all oilproducing countries.

title: Dash Feels White House Won't Interfere in Trials
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 2 (AP)  Samuel Dash, chief counsel for the Senate Watergate Committee, said today that he was confident there would be no White House interference in trials or sentencing of seven former top Presidential aides indicted on obstruction of justice charges.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Of the holdouts, Celerino Sanchez is the most mysterious. He's still in Mexico and hasn't been heard from Gabe Paul doesn't think he's too far apart with Bobby Mercer, but, he said, That's a matter of opinion sometimes. Sam McDowell missed his second straight workout with a virus. Otto Velez, the first Yankee to sign last winter, failed to show for the first session and no one knew why. . . . Jerry Kenney, who was traded to Cleveland last year, is back with the Yankees. He arrived In camp with a BandAid on his forehead, the result of an encounter with a bedpost in his motel room.

title: JUVENILES' CENTER OPENED IN WARREN
description: MANSFIELD TOWNSHIP March 1After five months of construction delays, Warrer County's juvenile center, Warren Acres, opened its doors today with only tentative approval from the state.

title: Gimbel Brothers Profit Drops; A Decline of 17.6% Is Shown
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., the big department store chain now owned by the Brown and Williamson Tobacco Corporation, reported yesterday a 17.6 per cent drop in earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31. It was the first time in the history of Gimbels that drop was shown in the Christmas shopping period when all retailers do their greatest volurne of business.

title: Nixon Urges Quick Trials, Cautions on Prejudgment
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 President Nixon expressed the lope today that trials arising gut of the new Watergate iniictments will move quickly to a just conclusion. He also cautioned the nation to remember that the accused are presumed innocent unless proved guilty.

title: Zero Growth Rate Forecast for U. S. In O.E.C.D. Report
description: BRUSSELS, March 1A confidential, report drawn up by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development predicts that the United States economy is headed for a zero growth rate in 1974 and a 7.75 per cent inflation rate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET MINISTERS SEEK TO HEAL RIFT
description: BONN, March 1The foreign ministers of France and West Germany agreed tonight to try to repair the disunity of the European Common Market at a ministerial meeting in Brussels on Monday.

title: Braves Top Celtics for 2d in Row
description: BUFFALO, March 1 (UPI) The Buffalo Braved, led by Bob McAdoo's 31, points, battered the Boston Celtics, 11094, tonight for their second straight victory over the Atlantic Division leaders in the National Basketball Association.

title: Balk Line Experiments No Joy to Met Pitchers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1One year after the debut of the designated hitter, baseball found a new controversy today in the experimental balk line.

title: Telephone Calls for Five Cents Betoken Bygone Era Upstate
description: CHATHAM, N.Y., March 1  Deposit 5 cents, please. The operator's voice and the message have been confusing and surprising strangers who use telephone booths in this pocket of rural New York close to the Massachusetts border.

title: Ford Flies to Phoenix, Appeals To Republicans to Assist Party,
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1Vice President Ford flew into Phoenix today to implore fellow Republicans to retain their faith in their party and halt a threatened Congressional sweep by liberal Democrats.

title: Charges of Nixon Misconduct Inferred By Lawyers Analyzing Action of Jury
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Federal grand juries issue reports rather than indictments so rarely that today's action by the Watergate grand jury prompted widespread discussion among lawyers and politicians of its potential meaning for President Nixon.

title: FRENCH MAY BUY NATIONAL KINNEY
description: Warner Communications, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the sale of 5 million of its 6 million commonshare holding in the National Kinney Corporation. There are 9.5 million common shares of National Kinney outstanding.

title: I.R.S. WILL GIVE UP DATA ON REPORTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Internal Revenue Service decided today to surrender the home telephone records of David E. Rosenbaum, a New York Times reporter, without conceding any wrongdoing in obtaining the records.

title: BOBBY TIMMONS, 38, JALL PIANIST, DEAD
description: Bobby Timmons, a jazz pianist, vibraharpist and composer, died yesterday in St. Vincent's hospital. He was 38 years old.

title: BRASCO TRIAL OFF; DEFENDANT IS ILL
description: The corruption  conspiracy trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco and his uncle, Joseph Brasco, was adjourned yesterday morning after the latter suffered what appeared to be a stroke.

title: Heard Up By Stroke In Orlando
Music: From Boulez's Favorite Era
description: Pierre Boulez started his program with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening with an early 19thcentury piece. Then he veered abruptly into the century he knows and loves best. The 19thcentury work was Schubert's Overture in the Italian Style, that agreeable bit of Rossinian fluff composed in 1817. Then came Bela Bartk's Piano Concerto No. 1 of 1927, three movements from Berg's Lyric Suite of 1926 and both of Ravel's Daphnis and Chlo Suites of 1912.

title: No Win in Britain
description: Britain's election has generated the worst possible result: no real winner, the certainty of minority government and exacerbation of the problems that that government must face.

title: Tocks I. Squatters Offered Food, Clothes and Land
description: DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa., March 1Offers of land, food, clothing, blankets and legal aid today poured in to help 65 young men and women and their children who were evicted early Wednesday by Federal marshals from homes on Federal land near the site of the proposed Tocks Island Dam on the Delaware River.

title: February Auto Output Off 34.3% From '73
description: DETROIT, March 1 (UPI) United States automakers reported today that they built 562,286 cars in February, down 34.3 per cent from a year ago and the worst February since 1970 as they continued to cut back on production of the slowselling big cars.

title: Leonhardt Quits Board of Directors At Beker Concern
description: Announcing his resignation as a director of Beker Industries Corporation, W. S. Leonhardt, president of Commercial Solvents Corporation, said yesterday he had been completely unaware of Beker's plans to make a tender offer for 26 per cent of his company's common stock.

title: Plan Bus Campaigning
description: MEDFORD, Ore., March 1 (UPI)Representative John Dellenback, Republican of Oregon, has forsaken his car in his campaign for reelection. Mr. Dellenback said yesterday that he would use Greyhound buses instead of his car because of the gasoline shortage.

title: Drunk Driving and Death
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa (AP)Kaiser Matazi, 55 years old, was fined $300 for driving a hearse while drunk.

title: January Deficit Off a Bit as Cost of Fuel Soars
description: With a fuel bill of $18.3million in January, $8.6million higher than in the same month last year, Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a January deficit of $7.6million.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AllHours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: SALES INCREASE AT CHAIN STORES
description: Chainstore sales rose sharply in January as 33 of the country's major retailers showed an average gain of 13.9 per cent over the 1973 level.

title: Higher Pay Floor
description: President Nixon has taken a needed initiative toward breaking the long deadlock between the White House and Congress that has condemned millions of the working poor to a statutory wage floor grossly inadequate to protect their living standards against the inroads of inflation.

title: Jobless Picture Unchanged In Major Cities, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  The number of major cities with substantial unemployment of 6 per cent or more remained at 33 in February for the fourth consecutive month, the Labor Department said today.

title: Republic Housing Plans To Cut Mobile Home Units
description: The Republic Housing Corporation, Dallas, plans to discontinue operations at three of its four mobilehome manufacturing plants, it was announced yesterday.

title: Haywood's Play Wins
description: DETROIT, March 1 (UPI) Spencer Haywood's 3point play with 37 seconds to go gave the Seattle Supersonics a 105103 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight. It was Detroit's fourth straight loss.

title: Okker Outlasts Estep
description: MIAMI, March 1 (AP) Tom Okker outlasted Mike Estep, 76, 67, 76, in a grueling quarterfinal match of a W. C. T. tournament tonight. Estep, from Dallas, could not hold a 65 lead in the third set.

title: France Announces a Smaller Cabinet With No Fresh Faces
description: PARIS, March 1A new, smaller French Cabinet was named today, but despite several shifts of posts there were no fresh faces.

title: Plea for Damages Denied In Campaign Mail Dispute
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 1 (AP)Representative Bob Wilson, Republican of California, used his Congressional franking privilege by mailing newsletters during his 1972 campaign at taxpayers' expense, a Federkl District Court judge has ruled.

title: Stage: CSC's Revengers Tragedy
description: Cyril Tourneur The R??vengers Tragedy is perhaps one of the few oversung Jacobean classics. The authorship of the play is, of course, in doubt, and that is almost the only certain thing we know about it. At times it has been attributed to Thomas Middleton, John Webster or John Marston. But Tourneur is as good a label to put on it as any other. Although its moral attitude is almost reversed, it makes a fair companion piece for Tourneur's weaker The Atheist's Tragedy.

title: Mayer Tops Amritraj at Net, 75,62
description: PARAMUS, N.J., March 1 Sandy Mayer of Wayne upheld his No. 2 seeding with a firstround victory, but Karl Meiler of West Germany was upset in the $20,000 Garcia tennis tournament at Bergen Community College tonight.

title: RED ONION SOLOISTS ENLIVEN JAZZ TUNES
description: A fiveman variant of the Red Onion Jazz Band, a group that has been playing off and on around New York for 20 years, began one of its infrequent steady engagements this week at Barney Google's, 225 East 86th Street. The group, which will be there Tuesday evenings throughout March, is made up of two regular Red OnionsBob Thompson on drums and Hank Ross on piano  and three occasional ones (Billy Barnes, cornetist; Jim Lawyer, banjo picker, and Jacques Kernen, clarinetist and soprano saxophonist), along with Natalie Lamb, who usually sings with the Onions.

title: British Betting Chain Expects New Election
description: LONDON, March 1 (AP)Ladbroke's, one of Britain's biggest betting chains, opened a new book on the next British election today while results were still coming in on the current one.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: I.R.S. Delays Silvercup Foreclosure

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 2, 1974

title: 60Dash to Rosenberg
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 1Manny Rosenberg of Valley Stream Central won the state's fastest flit 60yard, dash competition of the season last night in the Nassau County South Shore scholastic indoor track championships at the Hofstra University field house. Rosenberg clocked 6.2, seconds as all five medalists ran 6.5 or faster. Uniondale scored 31 points to win the team title.

title: HARRISON, STARR PLAN A U.S. TOUR
description: Two former Beatles, Georg Harrison and Ringo Starr, wil make a 25concert tour cover ing 12 to 15 American cities late this fall, sources close tc the tour confirmed yesterday in Los Angeles.

title: Hospital in Brooklyn Gave Its Business to 4 on Board
description: The Community Hospital of Brooklyn, gave almost $57,000 worth of legal, insurance and electrical business to four members of its board of directors in 1972, a state study has disclosed.

title: Witness Testifies Gross Arranged Tax CoverUp
description: NEWARK, March 1  A textile company owner testified in Federal Court today that Nelson G. Gross had arranged an income tax coverup for a $2,000 contribution he gave to Mr. Gross's unscuccessful 1970 campaign for the United Senate.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: States' Rights Issue Is Holding Up a Federal Program to Protect Coastlines
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 1  The Federal Government's first big venture into controlling land use, a program to protect the nation's ocean and inland coastlines, is proving a slow and touchy thing to implement.

title: MITCHELL JUDGE HALTS TRIAL HERE
description: Federal Judge Lee P. Gagliar. di abruptly suspended yesterday the conspiracyperjury trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans for what he called apparent excesses by the chief Government prosecutor in his opening statement.

title: Paper Stirs a Dispute by Hiring Convict
description: WILMINGTON, Del.,  When a newspaper here recently hired a convicted murderer as a columnist, it explained the move as an attempt to focus public attention on the problems of crime and corrections.

title: SALES INCREASE AT CHAIN STORES
description: Chainstore sales rose sharply in January as 33 of the :ountry's major retailers showed an average gain of 13.9 per cent over the 1973 level.

title: Warning by Rockefeller
description: SEASIDE, Ore., March 1 (UPI) Former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York warned today that efforts to hound President Nixon out of office could cause lasting damage to the Presidency.

title: Broadcast Industry Backs Challenge to Florida Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  The broadcasting industry sided with newspapers today in a Supreme Court case challenging Florida's free reply law for political candidates.

title: The Scene in Sirica's Court: A Historic 13 Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, March 1At 10 A.M. today, Judge John J. Sirica was sitting in his chambers, reminiscing about his 16 years on the bench, whiling away the time until he could put a black robe over his gray suit and walk into Courtroom 2 to preside over history.

title: Britain's Vote: A Result but Not a Decision
description: LONDON, March 1The crowds gathered quietly outside 10 Downing Street all day today in scenes reminiscent of World War II. The country, crippled by economic disruption, was faced with political crisis.

title: Percentage Drops
description: Stocks with the largest per Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Penn Defeats Columbia For 5th Ivy Title, 9065
description: Pennsylvania won its fifth consecutive Ivy League basketball title and clinched a National Collegiate tournament invitation by defeating Columbia, 9065, last night at University Gym.

title: Study Implies Big Bad Wolf Really Isn't
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 The wolfthat supposedly savage creature that did Grandmother in and sought to do the same to Little Red Riding Hoodis developing a growing reputation as a gentle, loving animal, sensitive and even moody.

title: Declines Shown on Amex and OTC
County Officials Confused By Revised Juvenile Law
description: TRENTON, March 1  Juvenile authorities in New Jersey's 21 counties encountered what was described as total confusion as the state's new juvenile code was put into effect today.

title: Consumer Group Plans Childrn's T Festival
description: An international festival of children's television, featuring programs from the United States and 10 foreign countries, will be held at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Pers forming Arts in Washington, March 31 to April 2. It will be part of the annual threeday conference of Action for Children's Television (ACT), a national consumeraction group, which has its headquarters in Newtonville, Mass.

title: Mackell Case Goes to Jury After a Call for Mistrial
description: The state's case against Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, went to the jury yesterday, seven weeks after the trial began. He Is accused, along with two former aides of conspiring to block investigation of a $4.4million getrichquick scheme, In which members of his staff invested money.

title: Wuppertal Soccer Victor
description: WUPPERTAL, West Germany, March 1 (UPI)S. V. Wuppertal defeated Rotweiss Essen, 20, today in a West German First Division soccer game.

title: People in Sports
description: Rick Barry equaled a National Basketball Association record yesterday when he was fined $1,000 for making bodily contact with a referee.

title: State of the Courts
description: The State of the Judiciary address delivered to the Legislature in Albany by Chief Judge Breitel of the Court of Appeals represents a historic first for New York.

title: Rhodesia Hangs 2 Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 1 (Reuters)  Two blacks were hanged in Salisbury jail today for alleged guerrilla attacks in Rhodesia.

title: Republicans Shun Carolina Contest For Seat of Ervin
description: RALEIGH, N. C. March 1  North Carolina Republicans, who had planned a major drive for the United States Senate seat being vacated this year by Sam J. Ervin Jr., a Democrat, wound up with a virtual unknown as their likely nominee when the filing deadline for May 7 party primaries passed Monday.

title: Cost Council Approved Rise of 5%  Hoechst Plans Move on Polyester
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had increased prices for a wide variety of steel products in accordance with new Cost of Living Council rules. The increases were initially scheduled for Jan. 1 and Feb. 16, but were delayed by the council.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Page

title: RED CROSS VISITS 65 ISRAELI P.O.W.'S
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 1 Israeli prisoners held by Syria, long the focus of a dispute that prevented trooppullback negotiations, received their first visit from Red Cross inspectors today.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: LONDON, March 1 (UPI)The dollar retreated slightly on the European money markets today after a firm opening but at the close it was higher everywhere from yesterday's, closing levels.

title: Lion of Judah
description: Because of his long rule, his courageous resistance to Fascist Italy in 1935 and his role of leadership in the Organization of African Unity, Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia commands great international respect. At home, however, his efforts to cope with the necessity of economic and social advance in a largely feudal society have had considerably less success.

title: Maheu Lawyer Promises Proof of Gift to Humphrey
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 Robert A. Maheu's lawyer promised in court today to submit proof that $50,000 worth of $100 bills from Howard Hughes was delivered to then Vice President Humphrey in a limousine at the Century Plaza Hotel here during the summer of 1968.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Feb. 23 totaled an estimated 16.4 billion tonmiles, 3.6 per cent above the comesponding week last year. Carloadings in the same period totaled 518,593 cars, 2.5 per cent above last year.

title: Business Briefs
description: OAKBROOK, Ill., March 1 (Reuters)The Bunker Ramo Corporation filed a suit today in United States District Court charging the International Business Machines Corporation with seven counts of patent infringement.

title: Art: Realistic Nudes of Jillian Denby
description: Realism in the visual arts is a paradoxical phenomenon. One can never be entirely certain whether it is the socalled truththe fidelity to appearancesthat compels attention or the artifice employed in creating an illusion. Some realists seem to place the emphasis on the most literal verisimilitude, whereas others place it on style, form and technique. Whatever the emphasis, however, we are sooner or later left with questions of esthetics rather than questions about life, though lifelike appearances may be rendered with an impressive meticulousness.

title: Frederick Piket, 71, Dies; Published Liturgical Music
description: Frederick Piket, composer, conductor and music publisher, died Thursday of cancer in Boulevard Hospital, Long Island City, Queens. He was 71 years old and lived at 3323 Clearview Expressway in Bayside, Queens.

title: Ashe, Dibbs Win
description: BARCELONA, Spain, March 1 (UPI)Arthur Ashe and Eddie Dibbs advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis indoor circuit tournament today.

title: People and Business
description: Last October, when Cyrus S. Eaton Sr., the 90yearold Cleveland financier, was replaced as chairman of the Chessie System, Inc., he was critical of his successor and others  charging that they got handsome salary increases, bonuses and employment contracts along with their new titles.

title: Legislators Vote Raise
description: HARTFORD, March 1 (UPI)The Connecticut appropriations committee, of the General Assembly has voted 6 to 4 to draft a bill giving Connecticut lawmakers a $6,000ayear pay rise. The increase would bring legislators' compensation to $25,000 for a twoyear term, including expenses.

title: Plane Averts Crash
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP)A trans worm Airlines 707 jetliner flying from San Francisco with 80 persons aboard made a safe emergency landing here last night after firemen sprayed a cushon of foam for fear that the nose gear war not operating.

title: Rothko Art Value Disputed in Court
description: The true monetary value of Mark Rothko paintings was argued yesterday in Surrogate Cout, where the late painter's laughter, Kate, seeks to have executors who sold 100 of the works for $1.8million discharged and the contract rescinded.

title: Campus Notes
description: Robert Hanford, a 22yearold Ithica College senior, began working with puppets as a hobby two years ago. Now he teaches a threecredit course in puppetry to his classmates at the college.

title: Nixon Urges Quick Trials, Cautions on Prejudgment
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 President Nixon expressed the hope today that trials arising out of the new Watergate indictments will move quickly to a just conclusion. He also cautioned the nation to remember that the accused are presumed innocent unless proved guilty.

title: PRUDENTIAL SHOWS OPERATIONS GAINS
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the world's largest insurer, reported new highs in virtually all areas of its operations.

title: Market Pace:
description: When the specialist in Geon Industries was faced on Feb. 22 with an Influx of sell orders in the shares of that foreigncar replacement parts company, trading was delayed while officials of the American Stock Exchange sought a possible explanation from Geon's management for the selling.

title: Death Penalty Backed
description: DENVER, March 1 (UPI) The Colorado Senate passed a measure yesterday that would return the death penalty to the state, providing residents concur in the November elections. The vote was 26 to 6.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 12yearold runaway Korean orphan who had worked as a maid in Miami since leaving her home in Beachwood, N. J., almost two months ago was flown home yesterday with a private detective hired by her foster parents, Army Sgt. Frank Carpenter and his Koreanborn wife, Sun Yen.

title: Notes on People
description: The post of United States Chief of Protocol, which has been vacant since June, 1972, was finally filled yesterday when President Nixon elevated Marion H. Smoak, who has been serving as acting chief, to the top job.

title: STATE TOLD TO GIVE ABORTION RULES
description: TRENTON, March 1  After Iseveral days of bureaucratic delay, State Attorney General William F. Hyland today ordered the State Department of Health to make public proposed regu lations that would govern abortions performed in New Jersey after the 12th week of pregnancy.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second end third, the third end fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Akzona Unit Is Expanding
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., March 1 (UPI)Akzona, Inc., said today its Armira subsidiary, the former Armour Leather Company would build a large factory near Asheville to make Xylee, a manmade material for shoe uppers. The unit will employ about 200 persons. Xylee is a poromeric or breathing plastic and is presently made in Europe by Enka Glantztoff, which like Akzona is a member of Azo, N.V. group.

title: GENERAL BOOKS HEAD RESIGNS FROM HOLT
description: Aaron Asher has resigned, effective yesterday, as a vice president of Holt, Rinehart and Winston, the publishing house, books department. He said he would remain in publishing but did not yet know where.

title: MANGEL STORES TO FILE PETITION
description: The Mangel Stores Corporation, which operates the Shoppers Fair discount stores and the Mangel's women's apparel shops, said yesterday that its board had authorized the filing of a petition for voluntary bankruptcy under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The petition is expected to be filed in a Federal court on Monday.

title: Its Official: Lyle and Murcer Hold Out
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1While four Yankees, including Bobby Murcer and Sparky Lyle, became official holdouts today, Ron Blomberg became one of the most eager Yankees to begin working out, arriving at Fort Lauderdale Stadium at 8:15 this morning. He didn't have his new hair weave on his head, but within half an hour, he had his favorite bat in his hands.

title: The Pop Life
description: Cheech and ChongRichard (Cheecharrone) Marin and Tommy Chong  are the pop life's hottest comedy team now, with three gold albums and a talent for interpreting the counterculture view of the world with tongueincheek skits.

title: Printers Union to Appeal Strike Ban Reinstatement
description: Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6, said yesterday that he had asked the union's attorney to seek a review by the United States Supreme Court of a court ruling in New York earlier this week reinstating a permanent nostrike injunction against typographical employes at The New York Times.

title: 2 YUGOSLAVS TOED THEY CAN'T TRAVEL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 Two Yugoslav dissidents, one of them a former Vice President of that country, have reported to the annual meeting of the American Association, for the Advancement of Science here that they would not be able to attend. They attributed this to their Government's suppression of their right to travel and express nonconformist views.

title: Father and Son in Business: From ManBoy to ManMan
description: BOSTON  A little more than four years ago, Gerald (Gerry) Slavin, a young graduate of CarnegieMellon University, became the first official S.O.B.

title: Tams Set Back Squires
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 1 (AP)Wilbert Jones and Glen Combs each scored 18 points to lead the Memphis Tams to a 10895 A.B.A. victory over Virginia tonight.

title: JOHN LEWIS ROACH
description: John Lewis Roach, a noted breeder of dogs in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday at his home, 303 Knollwood Avenue, Douglaston, Queens. He was 92 years old.

title: DUDLEY MOORE ACTS AS JAZZ PIANIST TOO
description: Dudley Moore has been moonlighting this week from his regular work of being wryly comical with Peter Cook in Good Evening at the Plymouth Theater to play jazz at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street.

title: YORKERS STUDIES FUEL ALLOTMENT
description: YONKERS, March 1  The City of Yonkers said today that it had surveyed its gasoline dealers and concluded that it was not getting its share of gasoline supplies, although demand had increased because of a population increase.

title: Miracle Worker
description: It was in the fall of 1969. Black and white student leaders were facing each other in open hostility at a national meeting in Washington, and the mood had reached the brink of violence. A tall black man rose from the sidelines. Frustrated? he asked, pointing to the angry black youths. Yes, I'm frustrated, too. . . And these are my children. When Dr. Lucius Pitts, then president of Miles College in Birmingham, Ala., sat down, the combination of a preacher's emotion and a philosopher's reason had miraculously established peace.

title: Gold Rush Beginning at Canadian Banks
description: TORONTO, Feb. 28People are lining up early at the gold windows of Canada's banks these days, eager to buy and sell as the world market price races up and down.

title: Fedders Limits Its Output
description: EDISON, N.J., March 1 (UPI) The Fedders Company, maker of air conditioners, announced today it was abandoning the manufacture of kitchen ranges and refrigerators and had set aside a reserve of $15million to cover costs of liquidating the operation.

title: ALBERT HIRST, 87, LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: Albert Hirst, a lifeinsurance lawyer who wrote the text of the state's landmark Comprehensive Exemption Law, which exempted annuities and life and disability insurance benefits from attachment by creditors, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: Highs and Lows New York Stock Exchange
description: NEW HIGHS3

title: WINE TALK
description: The winetasting as a social event has become popuPar in recent years. Wines are uncorked, an assortment of cheeses is offered, the conversation is casual, lighthearted, and hopefully an enlightening time is had by all.

title: MOST TOY PRICES OFF FROM CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Cost of Living Council removed wageandprice controls today from most children's toys other than bicycles.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesBenny Rodriguez, 120 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Jose Sanchez, 119 pounds, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: A Guide to the Perplexed Parent
description: LONDONFor a century or more parents have been bombarded with advice about how to bring up their children. Doctors, nurses, teachers and divines have purveyed their admonitory wares; and in recent decades they have been joined by psychologists and psychoanalysts. But were we to collect all this good advice and inspect it, what should we find? Little more, I'm afraid, than a cacophony of contradiction. To every thesis there would be antithesis.

title: Roncallo and 4 Nassau Officials Plead Not Guilty on Kickbacks
description: Representative Angelo D. Roncallo and four Nassau County officials pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of participating in a kickback scheme to extort money from a Long Island contractor for the benefit of the Republican party.

title: Sports Today

title: Sun Lamps and High Ceilings Help Russians Overcome Long Arctic Night

title: Harvard Defeats Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, March 1 Harvard scored 11 straight points early in the first half and went on to defeat Yale, 8765, in an Ivy League game tonight. Lou Silver scored 20 points to lead Harvard to its 11th victory in 23 games. The Crimson are now 9.4 in the league. Silver, a junior from Merrick, L. I., led. all rebounders with 10.

title: MITCHELL JUDGE HALTS TRIAL HERE
description: Federal Judge Lee P. Gagliardi abruptly suspended yesterday the conspiracyperjury trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans for what he called apparent excesses by the chief Government prosecutor in his opening statement.

title: About the Knicks . . .
description: Earl Monroe, playing his seventh pro season, needs 12 points to reach the 10,000point plateau. . . . Bill Bradley performed in his 500th regularseason game. . . . Speaking of the KnickCapital rivalry, Walt Frazier said: We have played them so often that they know our plays better than we do. Mike Riordan told them most of our plays after was traded. Monroe didn't have to tell us the Bullets' plays. They had only oneand it was him. He brought it with him to New York.

title: CON ED ASSAILED ON RATE INCREASE
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday criticized as extremely unfair to consumers the $174.7million interim electricity rate increase approved by the Public Service Commission for the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Hartnett I.C.4A Threat; U.S.Soviet Meet Today
description: MOSCOW, March 1  A young American indoor track team, missing many standout stars of past international competition, ran through a light warmup this afternoon for a oneday dual meet tomorrow with the Soviet Union.

title: About the Mets . . .
description: After swinging against machines for two days, the Mets finally took batting practice against pitchers. What did, you see out there? Yogi Berra was asked. Nobody got hurt, he replied with relief.... Willie Mays, overdue in camp, telephoned that he was heading. South at last for his new job as special: Coach. But Ted Martinez was still hiding in the Dominican Republic, where he has been playing all winter... Dr. Kenneth Donaldson, an internist from New York, arrived and began the annual physical examinations of all 43 men in camp.... Dr. Peter LaMotte also arrived for a few days' visit. He has turned over his duties as team physician to Dr. James Parkes and is now devoting his time to building a hospital at Hilton Head, S.C.

title: Brilliant Staging But Indecisive Result
description: LONDONNo one can complain the British election was not scrupulous and impeccable. Harold Wilson, Labor party leader and relative gainer in this important, if damnednearrun thing, put it with sobriety when he said the campaign had been fought with great fairness and with very great seriousness.

title: Rebellious Argentine Police Free Governor and Aides
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, March 1Crdoba's Governor, Deputy Governor and 80 of their aides and supporters who had been taken prisoner in a rightwing police revolt that began on Wednesday were released tonight.

title: Mayer Tops Amritraj at Net, 75, 62
description: PARAMUS, N.J., March 1 Sandy Mayer of Wayne upheld his No. 2 seeding with a firstround victory, but Karl Meiler of West Germany was upset in the $20,000 Garcia tennis tournament at Bergen Community College tonight. Sandy Mayer of Wayne upheld his No. 2 seeding with a firstround victory, but Karl Meiler of West Germany was upset in the $20,000 Garcia tennis tournament at Bergen Community College tonight.

title: POSTAL CHIEF WARNS OF NEW RATE RISE

title: Heath, Trailing Labor Party In Britain, Declines to Resign
description: LONDON, March 1Prime Minister Heath, deprived of his majority in Parliament by Britain's voters, declined to resign tonight. His action raised the prospect that Mr. Heath's Conservatives, outnumbered by the Labor party in the House of Commons, would try to remain in power.

title: LAWYER REINSTATED BY MARYLAND COURT
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 1 (UPI)Maryland's highest court ordered Maurice L. Braverman reinstated as a lawyer today, ruling that his expulsion from the legal profession 19 years ago for activities as a Communist party member and lawyer was largely political in nature.

title: Windows of Bus Smashed
description: A band of 20 to 30 disorderly youths smashed all the windows of a city bus in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, authorities said. The youths forced the driver and 15 passengers to leave the bus at Livonia and Saratoga Avenues, and then broke all the windows.

title: N.J. Harness Meet Opens at Freehold
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., March 1 The sulkies and horses returned to New Jersey for the 1974 harness racing season as the Atlantic CityatFreehold Raceway meeting opened today. Golden Acres Farm's Dr. Julius Jubilee, with 22yearold Billy Breshahan driving, won the Neptune Pace, defeating Riceland Flame and Butlers Waverley.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Government lifted today its sevenmonth ban on 13 brands of aerosol spray adhesives that it no longer fears as public health menaces.

title: Pasta Price Rise Rejected
description: ROME, March 1 (AP)The Italian Interministerial Price Committee rejected today requests from pasta makers for retail price increases. The prices have been subject to a price freeze since last July. In December, however, the committee approved price increases of up to 30 per cent.

title: N.Y.R.A. to Fete Centenarian at Aqueduct Today
description: Sam Johnson was 100 years old yesterday. Hardly a routine attainment, and the New York Racing Association is not about to let the occasion go unnoticed. In case the question arises as to what connection the N.Y.R.A. has with the centenarian the answer is obvious. Sam Johnson has been a race track personality most of his life and in recognition of that fact, Jack Krumpe, the president of the N.Y.R.A., will include Sam in today's activities at Aqueduct Race Track.

title: Eureka! Here's the Answer!
description: New York is a great place for passing laws, against parking, for instance, or jaywalking, or blowing horns. From time to time widely publicized but brief campaigns are undertaken to make people obey them. A total stranger from a far place, studying the restrictive and threatening signs on our lampposts, might think the city a kind of police state until he noticed all the cars variously standing, parking and doubleparking in blithe disregard of the stern warnings.

title: Film:'Ace Eli and Rodger of the Skies' r
description: The place is rural Kansas, and the time is midsummer in the early nineteen-twenties, not long after the Great War.Eli (Cliff Robertson), a barn storming pilot who has the emotional make-up of an 11-year-old, and Rodger (Eric Shea), his 11-year-old son who possesses the wisdom of the ancients, set off to see the world, which means flying all the way to San Willow. To Eli, San Willow seems to be as fabled as Xanadu and quite as remote."Ace Eli and Rodger of the Skies," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is about the adventures of Rodger and Eli getting from nowhere to nowhere. Eli, a killer with the ladies at first, always leaves them unsatisfied. He seems to have a sex problem. Rodger spends a lot of his time getting his dad out of scrapes. He also drinks, smokes and goes to sleep at night crying for his mom, who was killed in a plane crash with Eli.It's difficult to determine just what sort of movie the makers of "Ace Eli and Rodger of the Skies" had in mind when they began it. Americana? Comedy? Drama? A psychological study of the Oedipal relationship?Little Rodger really does have a problem with his father, whose girlfriends he loves, whose whores he pays off and whom, at the very end, he comforts when a particularly bitchy woman has walked out on Eli saying that he was lousy in bed. "I love you," says Rodger, cradling his weeping dad.The production appears to have been expensive. The aerial photography is lovely, and the performances are O.K., but the movie is such a mess of unexplored moods and loose ends that it makes the later, similar "Paper Moon" look like a masterpiece.The film, which was made three years ago, is being shown here in a version that the original producers, writer and director so disapprove of that they took their names off it. The names included in the credit box above for those contributions appear on the screen and are fictitious. For the record, "Ace Eli" was actually produced by Robert Fryer and James Cresson, written by Claudia Ann Salter and directed by John Erman.

title: Six Burckhardt Films Celebrate City Nostalgically
description: New York, which, in the case of the 59-year-old Swiss-born photographer and film maker Rudy Burckhardt, consists of only Manhattan and Queens, was a wonderful town. And it is nostalgically celebrated in the collection of six of his short subjects made from 1939 through 1967 that is being shown at the Film Forum. Mr. Burckhardt, whose New York photographs have been lauded in one-man shows, now illustrates that he is equally artistic in his movie documentations of our town's people and places.In the silent, 7-minute "Pursuit of Happiness," shots of hurrying mid-Manhattan crowds focus on not only now-quaint 1939 hair, dress and suit styles but also a variety of faces that ironically mock the film's title. And it sets the tone for subsequent subjects such as the 20-minute "The Climate of New York" (1949) and the 15-minute "Under the Brooklyn Bridge" (1955), the best of the lot in this observer's view."Climate," which takes its subtitles from the poetry of Mr. Burckhardt's friend, the poet and dance critic Edwin Denby, courses among empty lots and children and their elders enjoying a quiet Sunday in Astoria, through subways, to buildings at dusk in Manhattan, with perceptive, stark clarity that beautifully preserves the past. Just as sharp and memorable are the vignettes of the demolition of an ancient warehouse juxtaposed against scenes of nude boys swimming and diving from decayed piers in the blighted areas of "Under the Brooklyn Bridge."Although it is out of step with the rest, the 1964 "Miracle on the B.M.T." (the Independent, really), provides a swift tour of subways and streets while it concentrates on a threadbare romantic comedy about a lonely boy and a girl, played by Red and Mimi Grooms.However, "Eastside Summer" (1958) is a fond continuation of "Climate" in its unadorned portraiture of the tenements, shops and the largely Hispanic population of Avenues A, B and C. The past and present haven't changed much here or in the 1967 "Square Times" and its garish, sleezy Times Square night life."Rudy Burckhardt's New York" has not been previously shown theatrically, says the Film Forum management. But it is informative and fascinating visual history that deserves public recognition.
