title: METALS OFF AGAIN IN COMMODITIES
description: After two days of generally sharp price declines, commodity futures prices moved in both directions yesterdaymost metals dropped further, while major grains turned up.

title: Heath, Trailing Labor Party In Britain, Declines to Resign
description: LONDON, March 1Prime Minister Heath, deprived of his majority in Parliament by Britain's voters, declined to resign tonight. His action raised the prospect that Mr. Heath's Conservatives, outnumbered by the Labor party in the House of Commons, would try to remain in power.

title: Poor Families' Possible Impact On Congress Elections Studied
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Joint Center for Political Studies reported today that oneffth of the nation's Congressional districts were populated by significant numbers of poor families who could have an impact on Congressional elections.

title: Morris Nemet, 80, Dies; Operated Nemet Motors
description: Morris M. Nemet, who retired in 1963 as an international automobile dealer and distributor, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He was 80 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACOSS

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
Books of The Times
description: THE DEVIL'S DECADE. By Claud Cockburn. Illustrated. 256 pages. Mason & Lipscomb. $8.95.The devil's decade was the nineteenthirties and Claud Cockburn was one of its prophets. Without honor, apparently. But now he is something of a cult figure among the left. He writes for the British satirical magazine Private Eye, where first encountered him. Back in the thirties he was a topflight foreign correspondent for The Times of London, until the paper had a falling out with him over his political views and Mr. Cockburn went on to a paper more congenial to his social WeltanschauungThe Daily Worker. Later he ran a oneman radical sheet called The Week, which was stanchly antiHitler. (He coined the term the Cliveden set.)

title: Colonels Win 4th in Row
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., March 1 (UPI)Artis Gilmore scored 28 points, took 29 rebounds and blocked six shots for the Kentucky Colonels tonight as they extended their winning streak to four games with a 10893 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Akzona Unit Is Expanding
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., March 1 (UPI)Akzona, Inc., said today its Armira subsidiary, the former Armour Leather Company; would build a large factory near Asheville to make Xylee, a manmade material for shoe uppers. The unit will employ about 200 persons. Xylee is a poromeric or breathing plastic and is presently made in Europe by Enka Glantztoff which like Akzona is a member of Azo, N.V. group.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Cavaliers Down 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (UPI)Austin Carr and Len Wilkens combined for 50 points tonight to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 11093 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers. It was Cleveland's third triumph in a row and fourth in five games against the 76ers.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Chance of showers later today, tonight. Milder tomorrow. Temp range: today 3646; Friday 4349. Additional details on Page 62.

title: The Political Impact
description: WASHINGTON, March 1More than a year and half after the apprehension of a bugging squad inside the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee, the judicial branch of the Government has pointed the finger of accusation at the four men who were then President Nixon's closest advisers and raised questions about the veracity of the President himself. Accusations have been hurled at these men for months by politicians, the news media, commentators and Watergate witnesses. But those charges did not have behind them the weight of a grand jury of ordinary men and women, presumably impartial and dispassionate and they were not couched in the precise and yet frighteningly blunt language of indictment.

title: Roman and Urtain Draw
description: MADRID, March 1 (UPI) Joe King Roman of Puerto Rico and Jose Manuel (Urtain) Ibar of the Basque district of Spain fought to an eightround draw tonight in a heayyweight bout.

title: BARNARD CLOSING LACK DORM AREA
description: An allblack section in a don mitory at Barnard College that has existed since 1969 for black students who wanted it is scheduled to be eliminated at the end of the current school year, despite the protests of 18 black women who live there.

title: 15 Are Reported Arrested In Gunfight in Chile Capital
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 1 (Reuters)Soldiers arrested 15 people after a gunbattle here at dawn yesterday, the Government announced today.

title: Rail Rate Rise Sought
description: The nation's railroads said yesterday they planned to file an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase freight rates by an additional 0.2 per cent, effective about March 16. The increase would help cover added costs of the railroad retirement tax.

title: ALFRED SCHWABACHER
description: Alfred Schwabacher, who retired in 1939 as president and general manager of the Rudolf Mosse Company, which published the newspaper Berliner Tageblatt until 1936, died Thursday at Doctors Hospital. His age was 94, and he lived at 91 Central Park West.

title: MRS. PAUL D. CORBETT
description: Mrs. Eileen Pepall Corbett, wife of Paul D. Corbett, president of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., book publishers, died yesterday in SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research.. She was 58 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PROVIDENCE, R,I., March 1Brown held off a strong Dartmouth challenge after building a 20point second half lead and defeated the Big Green, 8373, tonight in the Providence Civic Center.

title: New Jersey Sports End of a Mat Era
description: RANDOLPH TOWNSHIP, March 1It was a long time oming.

title: TwoWay Radios in Taxis To Help City Fight Crime
description: The city officially began a program yesterday to put on the streets thousands of cruising taxicab drivers trained in the observation and reporting of crime and who are in radio. communication with the police.

title: City Bank Pares Prime Rate % to 8%
description: The First National City Bank, perhaps pushing a little faster than previously to lower interest rates, decided yesterday to cut to 8 per cent from 8 per cent its prime interest rate on corporate loans, effective Monday. The prime rate is the level commercial banks charge their large corporate borrowers.

title: People in Sports Barry Ties Costly Mark In N.B.A.$1,000 Fine
description: Rick Barry equaled a National Basketball Association record yesterday when he was fined $1,000 for making bodily contact with a referee.

title: D. E. LeVine Weds Barbara A. Grande
description: The marriage of Barbara Ann Grande, a fashion model, to David Eliot LeVine, executive director of the Dramatists Guild, Inc., took place here yesterday afternoon. Civil Court Judge Harry W. Davis performed the ceremony at his chambers.

title: The Scene in Sirica's Court: A Historic 13 Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, March 1At 10 A.M. today, Judge John J. Sirica was sitting in his chambers, reminiscing about his 16 years on the bench, whiling away the time until he could put a black robe over his gray suit and walk into Courtroom 2 to preside over history.

title: KOTARO TANAKA, JAPANESE JURIST
description: TOKYO, March 1 (Reuters) Kotaro Tanaka, former chief justice of the Supreme Court of Japan and a former judge of the International Court of Justice in The Hague, the Netherlands, died of a heart attack in a Tokyo hospital today. He was 83 years old.

title: Recordings
description: THERE'S a new Nozze di Figaro on the market. Well, it's not exactly new and it's not exactly on the market, and therein lies its interest.

title: BROWN TRIAL HELD TOPSY TURVY ONE
description: The prosecution is coming to the end of its case against Henry S. Brown, accused slayer of two policemen in the East Village two years ago, in what lawyers call a trial by elimination.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Court Backs Aid to Widow Who Sold Home for Funeral
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 2 (AP)When her husband died last year, Rosa Owens, 85 years old, had to sell her home for $1,050 to pay for the funeral.

title: CORRUPTION CHARGE DENIED BY SIHANOUK
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk has denied a charge made last month by President Lon Nol's Government in Cambodia that the nation's corruption had been bequeathed to us by the former regime of the nowexiled Cambodian leader.

title: Elizabeth Smith And C. P. Crow, Editors, Marry
description: Miss Elizabeth Venture Smith, a senior editor at New York magazine, was married here yesterday afternoon to Charles Patrick Crow, an editor at The New Yorker.

title: Son to Mrs. B. J. Shapiro
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs, B. James Shapiro of New York on Feb. 5 in the LyingIn Hospital. The child, the couple's second son, is named Bryan Jason.

title: Alison Weigel Engaged to Frank Hain
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 2Mr. and Mrs. H. Bourke Weigel of Pocantico Hills here and Saranac Lake have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Ann Weigel, to Frank L. Hain, son of Mrs. Marjorie L. Hain of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Frank Hain.

title: Platform Tennis to Start Friday
description: More than 100 teams will converge on the home of platform tennis, the Fox Meadow Tennis Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., next Friday for the men's national doubles tournament.

title: Makeup The idea this spring is to look unmadeup.
description: PASTEL makeup is coming onstrong for spring, in pale tones for blondes, richer shades for brunettes and blacks. The idea is to look unmadeup, even if it takes 10 beauty products to do it. Start with the eyes, this page. Maybelline PowderTwist comes in a colorcoded case containing powder shadow that is transferred to a PillowWand applicator with two twists of the cap. $1.50 each in Just Turquoise, Misty Teal, Really Yellow, True Blue, Fresh Violet and Rich Pewter. On the fingernails, Helena Rubinstein's Strong & Icy polish in Rose Quartz Ice ($2). Peaches and green from Charles Revson's Ultima II collection are used to achieve a soft, romantic look, opposite page, first column. Chris Royer was made up by Benjamin Moss, who used as a foundation the C.H.R. Face Makeup System in Soft Beige ($16.50) with Tawny Peach Blushing Creme ($5) and Sultry Peach Super Luscious Lipstick ($3.50). Deep Green Creme Liner ($4.50) and Pistachio Patina Shadow ($4.50) accent her eyes. See Chris in full face on following page.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Republic of Korea and Poland were inadvertently omitted from the Documents Chart (Where to Get Information Before You Go) in last week's Travel Section. The listings should have read as follows:

title: Letters: Pointers On Pints
description: That was a charming, or as the Irish would sad, a grand piece by Edwin Miller on Irish pubs, The Irish Pub Is a Great Equalizer (Travel Section, Feb. 17), but there was a tiny bit of confusion about a pint and a glass of Guinness, or any beer. A glass is a halfpint. If you want a pint, you ask for pint. If you want a halfpint, you ask for a glassnever for a halfpint. Incidentally, many pubs will not serve pint to a female customer; it somehow seems unladylike.

title: I Want it anyway
description: IS it a plot?

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt seemed like a fine idea at the time. But the National Commission on Industrial Peace, formed by President Nixon to help labor and management find ways to resolve their disputes, has never gotten very far off the ground.

title: TwoYear College To Open
description: MERRICK, L. L.A new twoyear college, which will offer an innovative program in music technology, is now accepting applications for its first class, which will begin in September.

title: News of the Screen
description: Sammy Glick, the heelhero of Budd Schulberg's celebrated 1941 novel, What Makes Sammy Run?, finally appears to be nearing Hollywood, the major scene of his sleazy triumphs. The book, which has been on and off the schedules of producers for more than 20 years, looks as though it will make it as a movie at last, reports the author happily.

title: John W. Murchison Dies; Oil Millionaire's Brother
description: SAN ANTONIO Tex, March 2 (AP)  John W. Murchison, brother of the man who founded the Murchison oil and banking fortune, died Thursday in a Dallas hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Where Artists Gather to Talk of Their Work and Frolic, Too
description: KLOSTERS, SwitzerlandWasn't it glorious today, Marian Shaw told a friend at her cocktail party. I wish the weather were like this in December when there aren't any people on the slopes. Of course, there are people in Klosters in December, but not nearly so many as now in the high season. They are the perms members of the international set who establish themselves as permanent winter (and sometimes summer) residents of this Alpine resort.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Classicists are fond of saying that the learning and literature of the ancient Greeks and Romans are relevant to 20thcentury concerns. Indeed, we give names like Gemini and Apollo to our space ventures, classical imagery weaves in and out of much modern literature and art, and we even drive Mercury and Electra automobiles, mounted on Atlas tires.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Freehold Winner Is Butlers Prince
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., March 2 Butlers Prince, under a smart drive by Albert Jean Van Paelt, 41yearold New Egypt, N.J., resident, won the $7,000 Billy Direct Preferred pace at Freehold Raceway this afternoon. In second place, 2 lengths back, was Sterlings Glamour. Chinco Dane was third.

title: Why Truck Makers Can't Catch Up
description: George J. Agamemnon has learned the hard way about the boom in truck production. He is still waiting for many of the 60 tractors and 200 trailers he ordered last spring when his company, Burlington Industries, deciled to convert its fleet from leased trucks to companyowned vehicles.

title: Broadcast License Opposed Over Ties to Newspapers
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  The Justice Department, which is trying to break up newspaperbroadcasting combinations in Des Moines and St. Louis, has extended the effort to the MinneapolisSt. Paul area.

title: Leslie Perry Plans Bridal
description: WEYMOUTH, Mass., March 2  Mrs. John R. Perry has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Leslie Christine Perry, to Robert Philip Blank of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Blank of New Rochelle, N. Y.Miss Peny, daughter also of the late Mr. Perry, and her fianc will be married here in June.

title: Miss Jan Theil, Designer,Wed
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., March 2  Miss Jan Louise Theil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon S. Theil of Scarsdale, was married here this morning to J. Paul Westerlund, son of Mrs. John E. Westerlund of Scarsdale and Center Harbor, N. H., and the late Mr. Westerlund. The Rev. Warren Ernest performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Tax Withholding Upheld
description: CONCORD, N.H., March 2 (UPI)The New Hampshire Supreme Court upheld this week the right of the State Tax Commission to withhold income taxes from Maine residents who earned money in New Hampshire.

title: Denres, $14.40, Scores
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., March 2 (AP)Denres captured the openingday feature at Finger Lakes race track today. The winner paid $14.40 and was timed in 1:01 15 for the five furlongs.

title: Nets Lose To Squires; Kenon Hurt
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 2  The New York Nets, playing what Coach Kevin Loughery called only nine minutes of real basketball, were upset by the Virginia Squires, 106101, tonight at the Hampton Roads Coliseum.

title: The Last Word
description: Solzhenitsyn as a Media Creature

title: All Visits Middle East
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2 (UPI)Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion, arrived in Beirut today for a threeday visit. He will later visit the Persian Gulf states of Abu Dhabi and Qatar as well as Egypt and Libya.

title: Miss Nylex Helps Catamaran's Image
description: The catamaran with the airplane wing instead of a sail took a significant step toward respectability in February when Australia's Miss Nylex successfully defended the Little America's Cup against a challenge by New Zealand's Miss Stars. Miss Nylex, which carried a solid aerofoil instead of the conventional sheet sail, beat Miss Stars in all four races of the International Catamaran Sailing Championship for C Class catamarans on Port Phillip Bay, near Melbourne.

title: MACKELL IS GUILTY ALONG WITH AIDES IN QUEENS SWINDLE
description: Thomas J. Mackell, the for mer Queens District Attorney, and two former aides were found guilty yesterday of blocking the prosecution of the operator of a $4.4million fastmoney scheme in which hundred of Queens residents and members of Mr. Mackell's staff invested money.

title: GUERRILLA LEADER OUSTED IN CYPRUS
description: ATHENS, March 2The man named by the late Gen. George Grivas to succeed him as chief of the Cyprus militants seeking union with Greece was seized in a commandostyle coup and shipped back to Greece this week. There are indications that he is under arrest.

title: Tennis, anytime
description: CHERYL REPP rides, skates, skis (and water skis), swims, plays paddle tennis and squash, but tennis is her love. She plays Saturdays and Sundays and at least one night week, in addition to teaching tennis once a week at a boys club in Harlem. Cheryl says she never finished college because she spent all her time riding. Instead she went to secretarial school, then went to work at Ogilvy & Mather, the advertising agency, as a secretary. In four years, she has worked up to junior account executive.

title: 2 ON 5TH AVE. GET $300,000 IN GEMS
description: Two armed men robbed a Fifth Avenue jewelry shop near 57th Street yesterday morning, gathering up a window display of diamond necklaces and other gems valued at $300,000, and hen exploding a teargas canister to cover their escape.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Following is the text of a letter prompted by an article that appeared in this section on Feb. 3. To Tin EDITOR: The Sunday Jersey section presented a discussion of New Jersey schoolboard candidates and why they run. While the examples given were admirable, all seemed rather traditional and narrow.

title: Confusion Rules in 5 of 6 Races in Brooklyn
description: Chaos and confusion that is how many politicians describe the current maneuvering for five of Brooklyn's six seats in Congress.

title: Mark Whalen to Wed Miss Hudson, a Nurse
description: WEST NYACK, N. Y., March 2Miss Margaret Ann Hudson and Mark Whalen will be married April 21 in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Nanuet.

title: What's Doing in ARIZONA
description: ADJUST YOUR KALEIDOSCOPE The spectrum of things to see and do in Arizona is dazzling. Around April 1 you can view flowering prickly pear, cholla cactus and yucca in the desert...or you can go skiing in the White Mountains, 120 miles west of Phoenix. The Tourist Division of the Arizona Department of Economic Planning and Development (DEPAD), 1645 West Jefferson Street, Phoenix, Ariz. 85007 (phone 2715638) offers brochures on almodt every area of the state. If they don't have the information they will refer you to the appropriate agency.

title: Pays $6.40 at Gulfstream
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 2LeRoy Jolley is the bright, witty and caustic son of Moody Jolley, who is just plain caustic. Father and son go different ways each summer, but in the winter they stable together and train together in Floridaeach with his own set of horses in Barn C at Hialeah. LeRoy has 20 horses, Moody has six.

title: Admiral Says Ehrlichman Asked His Confession in Spying Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Senate testimony released today disclosed that a Navy admiral and his assistant were given lie detector tests in a 1971 investigation of leaks of secret documents.

title: Sales Drop In Vacation Homes Seen; Sellers Act
description: The vacationhome industry, apprehensive that the gasoline shortage might sharply reduce the number of potential buyers, has undertaken major shift in marketing and advertising techniques on the eve of its spring and summer selling season.

title: Nixon Record to Be an Issue on the Island
description: President Nixon is not a candidate this year but it is already clear that he will be a major issue in six Long Island Congressional races this November.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Weather: Partly sunny, mild today; cloudy tonight. Showers tomorrow. Temp. range: today 3852. Saturday 3641. Additional details on Page 59.

title: LIBERAL SUPPORT COURTED BY HEATH
description: LONDON, March 2Prime Minister Heath moved today to win the support of the Liberal party in an attempt to remain in power despite the severe setback in the general election.

title: Photography
description: OUR French photographers are having first American showings in a small exhibition at the French Cultural Services, 972 Fifth Avenue. The photographers, all under 30, are illustrative of a growing trend in France towards photography for the sake of personal expression as distinct from commercial or journalistic photography, a trend that is finding hearty support from the Bibliotheque Nationale and its Curator of. Photography, JeanClaude Lemagny, who selected this show.

title: The Floundering British Economy
description: LONDONThe financial reins of Britain have passed into uncertain hands at a critical moment for the British economy following the election defeat of the Conservative majority led by Prime Minister Heath.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Stamps
description: THE Universal Postal Union is 100 years old. It has attained an age reached by few other international organizations, and has done so without tinging declarations, largely unfulfilled, and despite two global conflicts and other woes during the troubled century of its existence.

title: Homestead Project Seeking To Halt Decay in the Cities
description: TRENTONHomesteading, a word that evokes tableaus of pioneers, wagon trains and sodbusters, has come to New Jersey's troubled urban centers. There, once again, property is being made available to those willing and capable of improving it.

title: Black Children, White Dreams
description: Jules Henry's great study of modern families, Pathways to Madness, was written for children, he said, in the hope that it will help reduce the misery in their lives. Henry's compassion_ for the people he studiedand for their tormentors: husbands, wives, sons, daughters  was unmistakable both in the nature and style of his work and in his tremendous sensitivity to his subjects rigid conceptions of the family and social system that was making life a hell for its members. Throughout, one could feel Henry's assumption that he himself might well have been one of them, that none of us is free of the kinds of problems they have.

title: Of a certain ageand important
description: WHEN I go to my closet in the morning and come up with, a nice black dress and pearls, I feel I've failed fot the day, says Evelyn Cunningham.This doesn't happen very often, because Mrs. Cunningham is one of those women who get a kick out of clothes. She likes to do the unexpected. When I'm going to a meeting of heavy thinkers who I know are going to wear sincere clothes, I'll get into my wildest Pucci, she says. When I know everybody's going to come sequinned, I really love to underdress.She sums it up: I love to be different.Hardly a flibbertigibbet, Mrs. Cunningham has a serious role in the world's work. As special assistant to the Governor, she has been and will continue to serve as an ombudsperson for Mr. Rockefeller, dealing with problems of minorities, housing, drug addiction, transportation, even the arts. She is also director of the Women's Unit of New York State. What she calls her twoheaded job (representing women and blacks) takes her to Washington, Albany, all around the country as a matter of fact for seminars, confer. ences and committee meetings, but her desk is in Rockefeller's New York City headquarterswhere she was the first woman to show up for work wearing pants a few years ago.All the girls wanted to get started wearing them, but they worried about what the Governor would say, so I volunteered. I told them, I'm the black one, no one wants to offend me.

title: A Collection of Collections
description: Once when I was compiling a humor anthology, an addled permissions editor addressed a letter to me as Veronica Geng, Human Anthologist. I was grateful for the tribute. I prefer an anthology that has been put together by a human; a fearful lot of them look like mechanical gimmicks designed to recycle useless old literary standbys in marketable new combinations. Twenty Great Stories About Angst, A TreasureTrove of OutofCopyright Poems. True, an anthologist is a kind of engineer, manipulating length and balance and theme and what's available at the right price. But finally his duty is to come down adamantly on the side of what he likes; and it is the quirkiness or beauty of his vision that makes his book interesting.

title: What's New in Theater?
description: TOTAL ECLIPSE, The Chel sea Theater Center of Brooklyn's production of Christopher Hampton's play, got 2 favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Probst, WNBCRadio), 6 mixed (Watt, News; Crittenden, Bergen Record Glover, AP; Feingold, Vitlage Voice; Simon, New York; Clurman, Nation) and 5 unfavorable reviews (Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear, Wallach, Newsday; A. Klein, WNYCRadio; Stasio, Cue).

title: King Says Nepal Can Avoid BigPower Dominance
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, March 1 The King of Nepal says that he is convinced that his small, landlocker Himalayan nation has carved out a delicate role that successfully avoids the dominance or the displeasure of his surrounding neighbors, India and China.

title: DR. SAUL FREEDMAN
description: PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 2Dr. Saul Freedman, a member of the general surgical staff of the United Hospital since 1945, died there of a coronary thrombosis last evening. He was 74 years old and lived at 341 Westchester Avenue.

title: I love to sing And I love to drink Scotch. lost people would rather hear me drink Scotch.
description: WHEN THEY ASKED ME to write this article, they said to be sure and mention Teacher's Scotch, but not to drag it in, make it sound natural. Well, I just mentioned it, and that sounded natural. It sounded so natural I'll mention it againTeacher's Scotch.

title: Chess:
description: A curious struggle takes place within me whenever I play chess, Alexander Alekhine said. A struggle between fantasy on one side and sheer prudence on the other. You see, too much fancy, or too much fantasy, is not so good. It must be tamed by good, cold sense. The two pull in opposite directions. Yet they must both be gratified.

title: Miss Waldron Plans Nuptials
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., March 2Mr. and Mrs. William J. Waldron Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Waldron, to Thomas Patrick Fallon Jr., an operations research analyst at Manufacturers Hanover Trust in New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fallon of the Bromic, New York.

title: THEATER OPENINGS
description: ULYSSES IN NIGHTTOWN Zero Mostel acts Joyce's Leopold Bloom in a revival of the 1958 play which is currently previewing at the Winter Garden.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2: Right Now: Justices of the New York State Supreme Court, Burton B. Roberts, Jawn A. Sandifer and Andrew R. Tyler, Channel 9, 9:30 A.M.

title: Bernadette Skerry to Be a Bride
description: TUXEDO, N. Y., March 2Mrs. Ann Skerry has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bernadette Ann Skerry, to Patrick Ambrose King of Spring Lake, N. J.

title: ETHIOPIA'S ARMY RELAXES ITS BOLD
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 2  The army largely withdrew from the streets of Addis Ababa today and it seemed increasingly likely that the military would accept Endalkachew Makonnen as the new Premier.

title: A wandering Dutchman finds his koan but not satori
description: And that was why I had come, to visit an old Japanese gentleman who ridiculed everything I said or could say; and to sit still for fifteen hours a day on a mat, for seven days on end, while the monks whacked me on the back with a fourfobtlong lath made of strong wood. So writes Janwillem van de Wetering, a wandering Dutchman, in a memoir of his wits'end state of mind just before Rohatsu, the most strenuous week of meditation in the Japanese Zen monastery where he had lived and trained for over a year. He dreaded the week of weeks because, even on an ordinary day, his stiff thigh muscles made sitting in the halflotus position an agony, because he couldn't help falling asleep and toppling over during meditation, and because the morning interview with the master fiercely demanding an answer to his koanthe paradoxical knot every Zen student is given to untieleft his mind a blank.

title: State Planning Study of Windmill Power
description: TRENTON  The Energy Study Commission, a legislative agency, will undertake soon a feasibility study of a plan to generate electrical power for New Jersey by erecting 300 sets of windpills along, the coastline.

title: Road Safety Called Problem of Insurers
description: TRENTONAsserting that long delays could be averted and tax money saved, a West Orange Councilman has initiated a campaign to make New Jersey's automobileinsurance companies assume responsibility for safety improvements on the state's roads.

title: Mrs. Steinberg Has Son
description: NORWALK, Conn., March 2 A son was born Feb. 17 to Mr. and Mrs. Harold I. Steinberg at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. Mr. Steinberg is a partner in the accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. Mrs. Steinberg is the former Miss Rosalie Bornze. The child has been named Daniel Martin.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: In the newest version of a game called Playing With Other People's Money, retail chains (including some of the country's largest) have recently slowed down their payments to their suripliers. Their apparent purpose is to make shortterm investments before they put the back into circulation.

title: Molloy Wins Catholic H.S. Track Title
description: Archbishop Molloy had only two individual winners but scored in 9 of the 15 events yesterday to capture the team title in the 47th annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Blue notes
description: ACROSS

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Use Skill, Not Elbows and Sticks
description: To the Editor:

title: Even Some Losers Emerge as Winners in Baseball's New Arbitration Procedure
description: FT. LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2  For perhaps the first time since the players and their owners agreed that four balls were a walk and three strikes were a strikeout, the two sides generally agree on something else: Salary arbitration is a worthwhile and beneficial procedure for the game.

title: Luba Levisky Wed To Dr. S. J. Marx
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Miss Luba Levisky and Dr. Stephen J. Marx were married here this evening by Cantor David Benedict of Temple Israel in Lawrence, L. I., at the Madison Hotel.

title: North Stars Victimized
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 2Told they'd have to play doordie hockey tonight to stay in the fight for a playoff spot, the Minnesota North Stars obeyedbut died anyway, 31, at the hands of the New York Rangers, who won their sixth in a row.

title: There Is Plenty of Wheat, These Farmers Insist
description: SIDNEY, Neb., March 2 There is not much that makes folks in these parts any angrier than the notion that the United States is about to run out of wheator fall so short that a familysize loaf of bread may soon cost a dollar.

title: The Nation
description: There was more gas at the pumps last week and the lines were shorter; the winter was receding and nobody had gone cold. President Nixon congratulated the nation on its cooperation and publicly promised there would be no gas rationing.

title: Oil Industry vs. Public
description: The House of Representatives provided a startling rebuff to the oil industry last week by passing and sending to President Nixon for signature the emergency energy bill, which the oil companies thought they had already killed. But Mr. Nixon has repeated his promise to veto the bill, apparently in the expectation that there will be no Congressional override. Yet he might be surprised, for Congress is well aware of public anger over the mess the Government has made of the oil problem.

title: JUDICIAL GROUPS SPLIT ON REFORM
description: The centuryold issue of court reformdramatized last week by Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel in his speech to the Legislaturehas split the state's lawmakers, political leaders, judges, major bar associations and goodgovernment groups into at least half a dozen factions.

title: Conservative Alumni Act to Alter Princeton Image
description: PRINCETONAs the clamor of student activism at Princeton University mellows to a whisper, the school's administration id turning its ear to a new wave of protests.

title: He Wanted a More Open White House, Didn't Get It
description: WASHINGTONWhen H. R. Hildeman and John D. Ehrlichman were forced but of the Government last spring because they had, beep implicated in the Watergate scandals, there were predictions that not for a long time would two Presidential assistants accumulate so much power. Yet an official in a position to know observed recently that Mr. Haldeman's successor as chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., had turned out to be Haldeman and Ehrlichman rolled into one.

title: Tizna, $17.60, Triumphs By a Neck at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 2  Another Chileanbred invader, Tizna, stole the $100,000 Santa Margarita Handicap today from retiring Convenience and 10 other fillies and mares at Santa Anita Park.

title: U.S. Urges New ArmsTalk Approach
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The United States has proposed to the Soviet Union a new negotiating approach on strategic arms that would seek to establish broad working principles and at first avoid details and mac numbers, according to diplomats and American officials.

title: More time is spent acquiring information than evaluating it
description: It is hard to imagine what A. J. Liebling would have made of all this. For almost two decades after World War II, in his commentaries on The Wayward Press, Liebling tried to show how our perception of the world was being damaged by the carelessness of reporters and, more often, by the prejudices of publishers. Now, 10 years after his death, dissident reporters hold soulsearching conventions in his name, and here we have a publisher, of all people, invoking Liebling's celebrated maxim, Freedom of the press is guaranteed only to those who own one.

title: Actress/designer from England
description: PAULINE CONBOY, a talented English import, divides her life between acting and designing. She worked as a designer in London before coming to the United States six years ago. She eventually opened a boutique in Seattle. Then the acting bug bit. After working with a repertory company, she came to New York to study with Uta Hagen. I did some film and TV work, she says, and between roles started designing for friends. I'm now marketing some of my clothes under the label Perils. Her first line is underwear (and she insists on calling it underwear rather than loungewear or lingerie). I'm trying to bring back the 30's idea of underwear, Pauline says, to make a woman feel beautifulbut I'm retaining the practicality of+modern fabrics.

title: Down with platforms
description: IF highstepping shoe designers have anything to say about the matter, those monster shoes with heavy platforms are going, going, gone. What are these designers suggesting to replace the clunkies? Sandals. And more sandalsfrom sporty to dressy, from very bare to bare only in back. Heels are getting higher, too, to go with the kneelength and longer skirts that women, are supposed to be ready for. Whether women are also ready for the return of pointed toes is debatable, but pointed toes are on the scene. Colors? Neutrals, of course. All those bone, fawn, taupe and luggage shades along with a new idea in neutrals: spring green.

title: AGNES GERAGHTY, SWIMMER, 67, DIES
description: Mrs. Agnes Geraghty McAndrews, who from 1924 to 1930 held world's records for the women's breaststroke from 50 yards to 400 meters, died Friday in the South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, L. I, She was 67 years old and lived at 831 Barth Drive, Baldwin, L. I.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: FIRST NATIONAL CITY BANK lowered its prime lending rate to 8 per cent, effective Monday .... Gold closed in London Friday at $166.50 an ounce after touching $184 on Wednesday .... United States trade surplus in January was $643.8million, vs. $859.6million In December .... Leading economic indicators, were up 2 per cent in January vs. a decline of 2.7 per cent In December .... Prices of raw farm products rose 1.5 per cent from Jan. 15 to Feb. 15.

title: Islanders Lose, 52, To Leafs
description: TORONTO, March 2 (UP) Tim Ecclestone scored a pair of goals and Dave Keon and Norm Ullman registered their 20th goals to pace the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 52 victory over the New York Islanders tonight.

title: Imperious Oil Image Out West
description: SAN FRANCISCOThere is one place in the world where the dignity of Queen Victoria's era mingles with the frenzy of King Faisal's. That place is the headquarters of the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: Mary A. Alexandre, a Teacher, Betrothed to Carl R. Gebauer
description: MANHASSET, L. I., March 2Miss Mary Ann Alexandre, teacher of English in the Massapequa public school district, and Carl Robert Gebauer, who is studying for a master's degree in education at Hofstra University, plan to be married in September.

title: 68,417 SEEK JOBS AS SANITATIONMEN
description: A large number of people turned out yesterday for Civil Service examinations for a few sanitationmen's jobs sought by 163,039 applicants, a record.

title: Griffin Accepts Award
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 2, (UPI)  Archie Griffin, Ohio State's allAmerican tailback, was presented The Chicago Tribune's silver football award today as the most valuable player in the Big Ten for the 1973 season.

title: Farm Union to Defy Court In Gallo Boycott Picketing
description: KEENE, Calif., March 2 (AP) The United Farm Workers of America will defy a court ban on mass picketing at liquor stores in its boycott of Gallo wines, the union president, Cesar Chavez, says.

title: Book Ends
description: Found. Whatever became of Edward Anderson? That question was raised recently in favorable review by Pauline Kael of Robert Altman's movie Thieves Like Us, based on a novel called Thieves Like Us by Edward Anderson. The novel (reviewed here Feb. 10) is a small classic of the thirties, about little people's dreams, and how they chase them and inevitably fail Avon brought out a paperback edition without copyright because the copyright had not been renewed and further Edward Anderson had disappeared from sight. After the Kael review, however, he turned upor rather his son Rader Anderson did, Edward Anderson died in September, 1969, at the age of 63 The bare facts of his life provided by Rader Anderson, an opera singer, sketch out something of a prototypical thirties writer. There were the newspaper jobs10 cities in Texas, Arkansas and Oklahomathen a stint as a deckhand, then writing crime and prizefight stories for the pulps. (He had been a professional fighter briefly.) His first novel, Hungry Men, about men on the bum, was published in 1935. This was followed in 1937 by Thieves Like Us, which was the cowinner of the DoubledayDoran Story Magazine award as the best novel of the year. The reviews were laudatory, and one reviewer compared Anderson to Faulkner and Hemingway. The remainder of his life Anderson bounced around from one newspaper to another and worked as a scriptwriter for MGM in 1941. The family wandered a good seal but often returned to Weatherford, Tex., where Anderson was born. His last newspaper job was in Quero, Tex. He never published another book after Thieves Like Us. Those, as we said, are the bare facts.

title: Salesmen Given OddEven Exemption
description: ALBANY, March 2The State Emergency Fuel Office announced today that salesmen who use their private cars extensively for business could get exemptions from the mandatory oddeven system of gasoline sales.

title: Visions of Hoover Haunt the Cloakrooms
description: WASHINGTONThis is not going to be an ordinary midterm election year. First, there is Watergate, and the developments in that seemingly bottomless scandal last week insured that it will be in the forefront of voters' minds right up through election day in November. The trials the seven new defendants will require, in the view of the prosecutor, three or four months, and will probably begin in late summer.

title: Solzhenitsyn Invited to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (Reuters)Aleksandr I. Solzenitsyn, the expelled Soviet author, has been invited by the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations to make a lecture tour of the United States, it was announced today.

title: Notes: Youth Fares Live In Canada
description: AIRLINE youth fares, the discount rates under which young Amercans have been flying high, wide and cheaply for more than decade, will finally expire next June after suffering a long, lingering illness. International youth fares met their doom last Jan. 1, and when the domestic youth diieounts are completely phased out in June, it will mark the end of an era, perhaps the beginning of the end of a freewheeling lifestyle, too.

title: PALESTINE RELIEF IS SHORT OF FUNDS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2The United Nations relief program for Palestinians says it will be forced to reduce educational services for 260,000 refugee children unless government contributions are increased soon to cover a $12million deficit.

title: Death with dignity
description: For a good part of my adult life, I've speculated on how would most prefer to die. There are only two good choices. One is to get hit by lightning on the golf course and the other is to freeze to death while camping in the Yukon. The advantage of lightning is that death is unexpected and instantaneous and the golf course setting allegedly most pleasant. Death by freezing has the virtue of being preceded by drowsiness, euphoria and then sleep; that sounds very accepable.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 3, 1974

title: First of all a poet
description: His style was the common English style, i.e., variations of rhymed tetrameter, though he also wrote sonnets, including some splendid ones, ballades and other poems in fixed forms, as well as many in free forms. His diction was as natural and contemporary, not to say vulgar, as anyone could wish. But his syntax was what set him apart. The word order of his poems is often strange: full of inversions, complex parallelisms, ellipses. In his best poems they work, producing not only lucidity of meaning, rhythmic intensity and a personal voice, but also a kind of plain gracefulness which is the first appeal of his writing. Without attempting musicality in verse, which he would have deprecated, Goodman nevertheless wrote songs, the songs of words, and this is his greatest distinction as a poet.

title: Court Coach Named
description: TAMPA, Fla, March 2 (UPI)Bill Gibson, the University of Virginia coach, was named today the head basketball coach at the University of South Florida.

title: Historic Meeting House
description: BOSTON, March 2 (AP)The Friends Meeting House on Quaker Highway in Uxbridge, built between 1770 and 1776, has been certified by the National Park Service as eligible for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: A Russian Nationalist Looks to the Past
description: PARIS, March 2Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, in his 15,000word letter to the rulers of the Soviet Union, reveals himself to the bottom of his soul as a Russian, not a Soviet, nationalist. The document, as made available in its original version before modifications by the author, is messianic, patriotic, utopian and religious in tone; antidemocratic, antiWestern, a rejection of the alien, corrupting world outside the borders of mother Russia, holy Russia.

title: Letters
description: Bons of Abrahams and Ishmael

title: Celtics 10448 Victor
description: One of Coach Red Holzman's homely old saying about life in the National Basketball Association hit the mark last night as the Knicks suffered a costly 10488 loss to the Boston Celtics before a capacity crowd of 19,694 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Linda or Tatum Oscar Winners?
description: GOOD grief. It's Linda Blair versus Tatum O'Neal as the top contenders for the Oscar as best supporting actress of 1973, a contest that Variety has already labeled the battle of the babes. Meanwhile, it should be pointed out that there is absolutely no truth in the rumor that a lot of Tatum O'Neal's salty dialogue in Paper Moon was dubbed by Ali MacGraw, that a New York actress (was it Colleen Dewhurst?) doubled for Miss O'Neal in some of the long shots and that she's really 39 and Ryan O'Neal's older sister, not daughter. Some people will believe anything.

title: In Queens Political Wars, a Mood of Detente
description: The usually voluble Matthew J. Troy Jr., Democratic leader of Queens, had to for words the other grope For Councilman Troy, who thrives on political turbulence, is flabbergasted by the political peace that has erupted in the three Congressional Districts hi his Iii I can't believe It. There isn't a single Congressional fight in sight in Queens, he said. The organization doesn't seem to have any problems in any of these races. I never had anything like this before.

title: Sussex Aged Get Hot Meals
description: HOPATCONGAs the result of a nutrition program that was begun here recently, more than 100 elderly persons in this Sussex County community and its environs are assured of one hot meal five days a week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his article U. S. Faces Recession in Housing Production [Feb. 17], Albert A. Walsh, the president of the National Realty Committee, stated that fuel costs for apartment houses had risen 200 to 300 per cent during the last 12 months.

title: The Crisis of Democracy
description: LONDON, March 2The world is now being run by Communist governments that rule by fear and force and by nonCommunist governments that do not have the confidence of the majority of their people.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 2 (Reuters)Mike Quarry, an American lightheavweight contender, lost a narrow decision to South Africa's Pierre Fourie in a 10round bout tonight. Fourie gained points because of superior infighting despite the handicap of a bad gash above the left eye suffered early in the ninth round.

title: Gas for Salesmen
description: Salesmen who use their private cars for business were granted exemptions from the oddeven system of gasoline sales in New York State, and it was announced that other groups would be considered for exemptions. Page 43.

title: Why Do Homosexuals Want to Bust Busting?
description: WHEN my meter was a young womas taking sourses in fashion design at Cooper Union in the early thirties, she was waited by her another of two things to stay out of Chinatown because of the Tong Wars, and always to carry a hatpin in her purse in Greenwich Village. The hatpin, she was told, was a special precautionary measure to protect her against the men in lavender with green carnations who might kidnap her and make her perform illicit acts with lascivious creatures of her own sex.

title: Miss Susan Homer And a Flier Marry
description: Miss Susan Northrup Homer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin N. Homer of Metamora, Micb., formerly of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday morning to Leonard Ernest Loudenslager In St. George's Parish, BermudaThe. bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs: Harold Loudenslager of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Business Declining At Newark Airport
description: NEWARKThis city has a spanking, new international airport where its old one once stood, but airline passengers apparently are not taking advantage of it.

title: Friends, movies and women, made and unmade
description: Reviewers often praise writers for taking big risks. Usually they mean an author has pushed his abstruse or idiosyncratic perceptions to the breaking point, or has tackled a difficult and unpopular theme, or has experimented with technique, hoping to open new areas of experience. But there is another, equally noble form of risktaking that is seldom acclaimed or even recognized. It involves turning the telescope around, sharpening the picture by contracting it, concentrating on precise, irreducible images of life and death, on marginal characters, basic emotions, essential acts.

title: Houston Golfers Wni
description: LAREDO, Tex. March (AP)Houston won the team competition and Tom Jones of Oklahoma State captured the individual crown today in the 23d annual Border Olympics intercollegiate golf tournament. Houston won the 72hole tournament with 1,146 strokes 12 fewer than runnerup Oklahoma State Jones.

title: March
description: If March has a dubious reputationand it doesit is not wholly without reason. There is a hint of madness in the mere mention of the March hare. Dark deeds are somehow inherent in the Ides of March. There is March mud, there are March floods, there are the winds March. And there is the lionandlamb tradition.

title: O'Hara Art Sustained Him
description: WHEN Frank O'Hara died at the age of 40 in 1966  after having been hit by a jeep in a bizarre accident on Fire Island  America lost one of her finest modern poets. And, in the same moment, a fascinating chapter in the cultural history of New York City carne to an end. Neither of these facts was widely apparent at the time. Since the publication of O'Hara's Collected Poems in 1971, the first has been gaining currency. Now, with a show at the Whitney Museum, a stab has been made at establithing the second.

title: Africans Have Second Thoughts On Arab Tie as Oil Prices Soar
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 27A columnist in Fraternit Matin, the local newspaper, questioned the wisdom of black African nations in siding with the Arabs on the Middle East conflict in exchange for the promise of an Arab oil boycott against Rhodesia, Portugal and South Africa. Similar ideas have been heard in several parts of black Africa in recent weeks.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: ENABLING the user to shoot pictures at second intervalsmuch faster than would be possible with an ordinary manual camerathe new Topcon Super DM is the first 35mm single lens reflex camera that comes with a motorized electric film advance mechanism as standard equipment. Called the Auto Winder, this motorized unit is attached to the body of the DM with a single screw so that the owner can easily remove it at any time if he prefers to use the camera manually.

title: Columbia Loses Finale In Old Gym to Princeton
description: Seventyfour years of college basketball came to an end in Columbia's Uniirersity Hall last night and this final season in the old building was not a happy one.

title: Fashionable without fads
description: JUDY DI SPALTRO, left, shown hefe with Cheryl Repp, virtually lives in pants. At least during the day when she's running after her two dughters, 5yearold Danielle and 3yearold Kristin. But she likes to wear skirts for dinner Parties in fact, whenever she and her husband go out in the evening. I love clothes, she says. I can't imagine not reading fashion magazine. I don't follow every fad, but I She choose the things that are right for me. She applies the same philosophy to decorating her hom. She and her husband, Joseph, both New Yorkers, recently moved into an old stone house in Larchtnont. They want to furnish it with contemporary pieces that won't be out of date in a few years. They both like the openness of suburban living, although Judy, who studied art in Rome and worked as an illustrator, is disappointed that she can't find a local art school.

title: Mary Ruddy Is Bride Of John W. Diercksen
description: March 2Miss Mary L. Ruddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ruddy, was married here at noon today to John W. Diercksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Diercksen of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television, programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Food
description: For those who fancy fish and seafood (and pity those who don't), there is nothing more gratifying to the senses of taste and wellbeing than a pipinghot fish soup.

title: MIGRANTS SUFFER IN FUEL SHORTAGE
description: A United States Department of Labor manpower project survey in south Texas indicates that the fuel shortage may keep 63 per cent of the migrant farm workers from traveling north this season to harvest the nation's crops.

title: LBJ Grove
description: A city of memorials can so easily take on the dreary quality of a necropolis that it is a relief to contemplate a monument that will instead heighten the sense of life. That should be precisely the cheerful effect of the proposed Washington tribute to President Lyndon B. Johnsonnot a thing of stony grandeur but a simple grove of white pines and flowers and a single inscribed rock from Texas.

title: City Digs Out From a Mountain Of Rent Protests
description: Two years after the inception of the computer rent program for controlled apartments, the system's protest mechanism remains a sore point with tenants, landlords and municipal bureaucrats.

title: Persia Campbell, 75, Economist And Consumer Advocate, Dead
description: Dr. Persia Campbell, a director of the Consumers Union and emeritus professor of economics at Queens College, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens, following a stroke suffered last Sunday. She was 75 years old and lived at 13727 Geranium Avenue, Flushing.

title: The Great American Auto Conversion
description: DETROITWhile the Ford Motor Company was overhauling its Wayne assembly plant, just west of here, David Anyan kept an eye on how the work was going by dashing about in a golf cart.

title: Joplin Ragtime Used To Pleasing Effect By Choreoconcerts
description: Given the raging popularity of ragtime music, it is inevitable that beginning choreographers will design dances around Scott Joplin's lilting tunes. What is not inevitable is that they will do it well. Jerry and Sara Pearson managed so ably in their first try that one eagerly looks forward to further pieces. Magnetic Rag was shown in the Choreoconcerts Workshop series Thursday evening at the Washington Square Methodist Church.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA TO CONFER IN U.S. Aides Say Kissinger Is to Meet Separately With Teams in Washington
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 2 American officials said today that Israel and Syria had agreed to send delegations to Washington later this month to continue independent discussions with Secretary of State Kissinger on achieving a separation of forces in the Golan Heights area.

title: L.I. Cool To City Plan For Busing In Schools
description: New York City had a message last week for Long Island. The city, seeing the percentage of minority youngsters in its public schools steadily increasing as whites moved to the suburbs, let it be known that the future of integration might depend on cooperation by the suburbs.

title: Dr. Harvey Lester Weds Elaine Zeldin
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., March 2Miss Elaine Zeldin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zeldin of East Hampton, was married here this evening to Dr. Harvey Lester, a dentist in practice in East Hampton and son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Lester of Brooklyn.

title: FUND ON NEEDIEST ENDS 62D APPEAL
description: The 82d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest with contributions totaling $1,015,742.30 from 10,208 donors.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Connecticut Cats Tolls For CarPool Riders
description: HARTFORD, March 2 (AP) Cars with three or more passengers will qualify for reduced tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike beginning March. 15.

title: Storefront a Base For Christian Aid
description: Mrs. Janine Laks, of 849 Carroll Street, who is Jewish, recently arrived with a neighbor at a nearby storefront called Christian Help in Park Slope (CHIPS), 219 Sixth Avenue, to offer her services.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Letter Is Published in Paris
description: PARIS. March 2 (UPI)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's Pads publishers today put on sale his letter to the Soviet leaders.

title: PABLO ELVIRA SHOWS PROMISE AS GERMONT
description: The New York City Opera has acquired a new baritone whose pleasing voice and smooth singing make him a welcome addition and suggest that he might develop into a more imposing perormer. His name is Pablo Elvira, and he made his debut with the company yesterday afternoon as the elder Germont in Verdi's La Traviata.

title: Princeton Unveils Play by Lawrence
description: PRINCETONAn allbutforgotten play by D. H. Lawrence will have its American premiere at McCarter Theater here Thursday.

title: NOTAX LIST ROSE FOR RICK IN 1972
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The number of highincome individuals who pay no Federal income tax is growing again, according to a report made public today by Senator Walter F, Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota.

title: 5 Arab Terrorists Who Struck in Rome Go to Cairo for Trial
description: KUWAIT, March 2  Five Palestinian extremists who killed 32 persons during a firebomb attack at Rome airport and a hijacking last December were flown to Cairo today under the responsibility of the Palestine Liberation Organization, official sources said.

title: More Makeup
description: GETTING down to the basics, here are some of the new cosmetics for spring that the manufacturers hope women will be adding to their already overflowing makeup kits. Among them, a creamy lipstick, a blusher that squeezes out like toothpaste, and pale pink nail polish to blend with all the soft colors of spring clothes.

title: Anna Aims to be the Next Margaret Rutherford
description: HAT ever happened to Anna Russell? That question has been frequently asked in musical circles ever since she disappeared from the American scene six yeters ago. Well, lots of things have been happening to her in her native Australia, where she has been alive and well all this time. And to prove that she still exists, she is going to give a concert in Avery Fisher Hall next Sunday afternoon. It may be a farewell performance by this very fuany lady, who can make Wagrier's Ring sound like something Woody Allen dreamed up, and then again it not. She talked, a bit about the interim years a few days ago, looking slimmer and grayer than she used to but possessing the same formidable energy and the same penetrating voice.

title: In Defense of Policies Whose Success Is Being Eroded
description: These are excerpts from School Chancellor Irving Anker's report on Programs and Problems Affect. ing Integration of the New York City Public Schools.

title: Kiri Did It All With A Bit of Maori Pride
description: WHEN Kiri Te Kanawa stepped out for a solo curtain call following her unexpected Met debut last month as Desdemona, the earshattering uproar that erupted was accompanied by cascading confetti sent down from the balcony by opera freaks who shredded their programs to bits in a spontaneous and supreme gesture of welcome. The fetching New Zealand soprano (pronounce her name Kihtee TuhKONawa) also bowled over the critics who were unanimously enthusiastic about what may be one of the great voices of our time, a voice as international as the Met itself, and acting that was touching and invariably believable.

title: F.B.I. IS PUZZLED IN HEARST INQUIRY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2The kidnappers of Patricia Hearst continued their puzzling silence today even though the free food for the poor program they demanded has been put into full operation.

title: 220Yard Mark Set
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, March 2 (UPI)Carl Lawson sped to a world best indoor mark in the 220yard dash tonight at the United States Track and Field Federation Intermountain championships, Winning in 21: 1 seconds. Lawson, a Jamaican Olympian who is a senior at Idaho State, clipped a tenth of a second from John Carlos's fiveyear old record.

title: N.F.L. Players Seeking Change in Rozelle Rule
description: CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI) A militant stand against the National Football League's Rozelle Rule and for higher salaries was expected from the N.F.L. Players Association convention that opens tomorrow.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 36762 Tickets maiching the number van $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or fast four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and., second digits, the second end third, the third and fourth the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: *King George Inn, 181 Mount Bethel Road (Somerset County Route 527), Mount Bethel. (201) 6470410.

title: Ash, Malek, O'Neill, Zarb & Co.: Not household names but their power is great, and growing
description: WASHINGTON. During the past few months the great superstructure of Presidential government that Richard Nixon built has slowly collapsed: a landslide here, a cavein there, leaving billows of dust to hover over the ruins. Through the haze, however, it is possible to discern some remaining promontories that have become more important to the President and to the Government, whatever its shape and leadership may be in the months ahead.

title: Hanoi: Rebuilding and Caution
description: Jean Vincent, of Agence FrancePresse, who first went to Indochina in 1945 as a French soldier, is now one of the few Western correspondents in Hanoi. During the war, travel by correspondents was restricted. Now, the restrictions have been eased and Mr. Vincent has been able to inspect reconstruction efforts at first hand. This article was not subject to censorship.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MESA, Ariz., Feb. 28As the Oakland A's new manager, Alvin Dark will need to be an optical contortionist. He'll have to keep one eye not only open but looking over his shoulder for orders from Charles O. Finley while he keeps his other eye closed to the escapades of his players. In training camp here, he's already condoned the symbol of both potential predicamentsthe players' mustaches. This team won the World Series twice with mustaches, Dark says. I'll only try to control the things I have control of.

title: Douglaston Mall Hearing Scheduled
description: The city's Board of Standards and Appeals will meet on March 19 to hear arguments for and against a plan to build a shopping mall along Northern Boulevard between 244th and 247th Streets in the Douglaston section of Queens.

title: A Gas Station Owner Describes His Position: In the Middle
description: Norman Reichbach is coowner of a Getty station just north of the Bronx Yonkers city line, and thus a frontline soldier in the fuel battle. From last April through January, the effects of the battle have closed an estimated 1,000 gas stations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticutdouble the normal fatality rate. Moreover, thousands of other stations have curtailed their hours sharply, reducing income and wages; layoffs in the region have been estimated as high as 15 to 20 per cent.

title: Beame Submits 22 Bills Aimed At Ending Abuse of Consumers
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he had submitted to the  Legislature 22 bills designed to eliminate a wide range of consumer abuses, including what was termed outdated fairtrade laws and excessive sales taxes.

title: Bossert Hotel Asks A Facility for Aged
description: The owner of the Bossert Hotel has filed with the city for a senior home permit to turn half of his Brooklyn Heights establishment into a facility for the elderly.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Georgia Bass
Women have stopped taking dictation
description: THIS spring, Fashion dictates ... Remember that voice? It had the ring of silken authority, if not naked truth. Occasionally it snapped Off with your hat! or Down with your hem! It told you when sequins were a must have, and when they were a nono; it said you would never look together without separates or natural without false lashes. And best of all, it promised that you could be really something in a little black nothing.

title: Hart Says Administration Undermines Privacy Right
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Senator Philip A. Hart of Michigan speaking on behalf of the Democratic majority in Congress, accused the Nixon Administration today of unprecedented efforts to undermine the American people's right to privacy.

title: The Region
description: The compelling logic that urban ghettos hold for school integrationthat races cannot be mixed where there is only one race availablehas led the New York City Board of Education to propose, gently and indirectly, what seems certain to become a matter of continuing discussion. The board has suggested that the same logic requires that the school districts in the city's immediate suburbs, Nassau and Westchester, participate in an exchange of pupils to achieve integration.

title: Balancing the National Interest With Private Interests
description: The oil executive was almost apoplectic. Good God, he said, do you know that the Government is telling us how much we have to pay for crude oil, where we can refine it, who we have to sell our products to, what we can charge our customers, and how much profit we can make? It's unbelievable!

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AllHours Given In Daylight Saving Times

title: Who Won and What It's Worth
description: LONDON  The European Community was the only significant victor in the confused British elections. Prime Minister Heath, who called the needless vote, was heavily battered although he still clings to office by his fingernails. Harold Wilson's Labor party got relatively more seats than votes while the resurgent. Liberals did just the reverse: they zoomed in the ballot boxes but have very few M.P.'s

title: Concert: Webern's Rarefied World
description: About 10 years ago the music of Anton Webern was played all over. New Yorkin the big halls as well as at small avantgarde groupings. Since then he has faded a bit. The younger composers are not that interested in his kind of serial composition, though of course he has remained one of the more potent influences of the century.

title: Town Hall May Sue North Hills On Zoning
description: NORM HILLS, LL  The Town of North Hempstead is expected to take legal action within the next two weeks against a luxury condominfum here, in what is believed to be the first suit by a towen against one of tts own viliages on ecological grounds.

title: The Black Man in Search of His Own Soul
description: ALL along the route taken by his brilliant ritual drama, The Great MacDaddy, playwright Paul Carter Harrison deftly places ghost figures and mythic demons from the history of black American folklore. Such legends as Shine and Stagolee, each representing a sector of our black emotional territory, tour latterday AfroChristian mythology.

title: Jan de Wilde to Wed Miss Cockerill
description: MANHASSET, L. I., March 2Miss Cathryn Grace Cockerill, who is studying for a Ph.D. in Asian history at Princeton University, and Jan de Wilde, a Foreign Service officer in Washington, whose last post was Nha Trang, Vietnam, plan to marry this summer.

title: School secretary and parttime model
description: JAN LAMBERTA gave up a 10year career as a model to raise a family. Later on, when her daughters were in school, she went back to work, this time as a school secretary at P.S. 144 in Forest Hills, Queens. She chose the job so my working hours would coincide with their school hours. The girls are grown now and in her free time she has gone back to modeling. Her new career started about a year ago when she walked into Lane Bryant's. A store executive saw her and asked if she would model in a fashion show. These days her modeling is just for fun. Her school job gives her plenty of vacation Aime so that she and her husband, William, can travel to Florida, Europe or any other place that strikes their fancy.

title: SOVIET EMIGRANTS SAID TO DECREASE
description: MOSCOW, March 2The rate of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union dropped off considerably in the first two months of this year, according to Western diplomatic sources.

title: Home Improvement
description: OF all the projects that doityourselfers tackle, one of the simplest to complete successfully, and one that almost always produces gratifying results, is the installation of a new floor covering of resilient tile (asphalt, vinylasbestos or solid vinyl.)

title: CHANGE IS SENSE IN SYRIANS' VIE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 2 A sense that a settlement the long conflict with Israel now inevitable appears to emerging here, despite tough terms laid down peace and the continuing cm bursts of antiIsraeli feeling.

title: After 22 Seasons, Mays Is Stranger
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2It feels strange, man, Willie Mays said on his first day in uniform as a coach. Strange. Nothing to do. You come to spring training, and got nothing to do.

title: Aqueduct Payoff $27.80
description: Making his way through the middle of the field in the homestretch, Noble Michael of the Edgehill Farm won the 73d running of the Swift, for 3yearolds, at Aqueduct yesterday. The outcome was a surprise to the crowd of 32,524, for Noble Michael was an outsider, and he returned $27.80, $10.60 and $6.20 for $2 across the board.

title: Patronizing Remarks by Men. Anger Women at a U.N. Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1Women participants in a United Nations conference on population complained today that they had been humiliated by male speakers whose remarks they found patronizing, insulting and uninformed.

title: Cured Cancer Patients Find Job Bars
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Three and a half years ago, Mary Smith underwent cancer surgery. The operation was apparently successful, as she has been symptomfree ever since. But there was one side effect not mentioned in the textbooks: Mary Smith has been unable to find a permanent job.

title: Museum Is Small on Budget, Big on History
description: BAYVILLE, L.I.The Bayville Historical Museum has an extensive photograph collection commemorating the significant events of the small village. But, there are no photos of the village trustees drinking a champagne toast to salute the museum's recent first anniversary. The museum budget leaves no room for a bottle of the bubbly, not even a domestic label.

title: Indiana Trackmen Retain Big Ten Title With Depth
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., March 2 (UPI)Indiana University captured only one first place but still managed to win the 64th Big Ten indoor track and field championship today for the second year in a row.

title: Design: Three years ago it was a toy factory
description: When painter Jack Ceglic bought this 40by100foot loft for $14,000 three years ago, it was a toy factory. The tin ceilings were the color of an elephant's hide and the walls had not been painted for 30 years. But he moved in anyway, living in a shell with a toilet and a sink. The big story is that he renovated the loft with a minimum of trauma and a budget of $10,000. How? By keeping everything simple. He ran new plumbing lines alqng side the old ones, positioned dividers (for a bathroom and closet) within the existing sprinkler system, followed building codes to the letter, kept carpentry (expensive) to a minimum. Paint was the chief medium that transformed the factory into all the things I neededa kitchen, a bathroom, a place to sleep, a place to work.

title: Nuptials Held for Blair BageTeg
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 2  Miss Blair BageTeg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William BageTeg of Farmington, Conn., and Cornish, Me., was married here this morning to Stuart Carlton Werner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar C. Werner of New York and Southbury, Conn.

title: Only $7.50 a Day And 35 Miles Away With One Hitch
description: IN these days of runaway prices, where can you go for only $7.50 a day and stay in a resort in the hills 35 miles from New York City with room, three meals a day and, depending on the season, your choice of iceskating, tobogganing, hiking, tennis (four courts), swimming (pool or lake), boating, canoeing, golf, bicycling, archery, shuffleboard, boccie, horseshoes, volleyball, badminton, PingPong, handball, dance instruction andnearby skiing, bowling, rollerskating and horseback riding?

description: WOODBURY  When I first ran for sheriff here in Gloucester County, John Hunt recalled with a hearty laugh last week, some people who were against me said that my election would put a gunslinger into office. They even called meThe Fastest Gun in the East.

title: Passive Laos Students Become Force for Coalition
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 25Encouraged by the activism of their counterparts in South Korea and Thailand, the longpassive students of Laos have begun to command attention as a new force in national affairs.

description: MIAMI BEACH, March 2The Israel Bond Organization opened a campaign today to sell $1billion in Israeli bonds this year and announced an initial sale of $178,133,000.

title: Mrs. Dougherty Is Remarried

The Rev. Richard Bailey of All Saints Episcopal Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Preston Coleman Townsend.

title: Neurosis as imprisonment in the past, psychedelics as release into the present
description: Reading the protocols of psychedelic research sessions usually becomes tedious very quickly. Streams of consciousness carry a lot of flotEam and jetsam. But Claudio Naranjo's report on the experimental work he did in 196566 in his native Chile, using four lesserknown psychedelics as occasional adjuncts to psychotherapy, is a trip through an enchanted wood, from which one emerges elated, stirred up and slightly glazeddangerously ready to start redeeming the world, though not exactly sure how to start. In short, this is a seductive book, and therefore difficult to assess fairly.

title: Mrs. John Y. Dater, 78, Dies; Naturalist and Ornithologist
description: RAMSEY, N. J., March 2Mrs. Eleanor Gott Dater, a naturalist and ornithologist, died yesterday at her home, 259 Grove Street. Her age was 78.

title: Expensive Threads
description: AMERICAN business has developed an epidemic affliction in recent months. It's called shortagesandhigher prices, and the apparel industry is no more immune than the oil induitry or She food industry. And the American consumer, far from trying to cure the disease by starving it, appears ready to nurture it by continuing to buy, except for occasional revolts like the meat botcott.

description: A large number of applicants turned out yesterday for Civil Service examinations for a, few sanitationmen's jobs sought by 163,039 people, a record.

description: When commodity traders are asked to explain sharp price increases, the answer often is one of the oldest adages in the trade: The best Mire for high prices is high prices.
