description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me, March 2  Miss Damaris Hunneman of London, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dexter Hunneman Jr., was married here at noon today to Ronald James Fletcher, also of London. He is the son of Mrs. A. Ronan Nelson of Ardulussa, Isle of Jura, Scotland, and the late R. G. Fletcher.

title: Suffolk Symphony Settlement Expected
description: Negotiators in the Suffolk Symphony dispute that forced the cancellation of a concert last weekend report that they appear to be on the verge of a settlement.

title: Judith Kozak Plans Bridal
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 2Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kozak of East Brunswick and Seaside Park have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Eileen Kozak, to Richard Carey Morgan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Morgan of Tucson, Ariz.

title: Is Opera a Luxury for TV?
description: THIS week's most unusual, intriguing and fascinating slice of television is being presented tomorTow night at 8 o'clock on publicTV's WNET Opera Theater. It's called Riad, La Cubana, a vaudeville with musk composed by Hans Werner Henze. Thiehoted composer, whose Fifth Symphony was commissioned by the New York Philharmonic for the opening of Lincoln Colter, created Rachel for television and, more specifically, for American television, which he feels can provide a broader audience spectrum for serious music than TV.

title: As for Owen Marshall, There Oughtta Be a Law!
description: I'VE always been a Marcus Welby fan. Dr. Welby genuinely cares about each of his patients, and he's terrific at helping them work out their problems. What a doctor Actually, though, I have to admit that it's not his medical skill that keeps me watching. My favorite shows are the ones where the patients' problems are more complicated psychologically than medically miscarriages, alcoholism, sterility. That's Marcus Welby at his best.

title: Soviet '60 Feeler Toward Kennedys Told in Documents
description: WALTHAM, Mass., March (AP)Soviet diplomats bypassed the State Department and made their first contact with Presidentelect John F. Kennedy in 1960 through his brother Robert, according to documents recently made public.

title: Miss Longstreet to Wed
description: SEA GIRT, N. J., March 2Mr. and Mrs. William Carl Longstreet Jr., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cathleen Anne Longstreet, to Robert Stoneham Lacey, son of Judge Frederick Bernard Lacey of the United States District Court and Mrs. Lacey of Glen Ridge and Sea Girt. Miss Longstreet and her fianc are seniors at Arizona State University. Her father is a realtor and insurer in Sea Girt. An Aug. 10 wedding is planned.

title: FORD SAYS PANEL SHOULD GET DATA
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2Vice President Ford said today that the contents of a secret report compiled by a Federal grand jury in the Watergate case should be submitted to the House Judiciary Committee, which is considering impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Stockbroker and Pianist Turn to Pottery
description: BRIDGEHAMPIDN, L. I.Wendy and Dick Engel do not believe in doing things halfheartedly. So three years ago, when they decided to leave Manhattan and their careershe was a stockbroker and she was a concert pianist and teacherto bebecome professional potters here, they also decided to travel through Europe in search of knowledge to perfect their art.

title: Catherine Nixon to Be Wed June 22
description: ROSEMONT, Pa., March 2 Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. A. Nixon of Rosemont and King's Hill, St. Croix, V. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Agnes Nixon, to Paul George Chicos, son of Mrs. Peter G. Chicos of Belmont, Mass., and the late Mr. Chicos. The wedding is planned for June 22 in Villanova.

title: $30,000 Frees a Kidnapped Baker
description: SANFORD, Fla., March 2 (UPI)  A baker kidnapped Thursday night by two men wearing ski masks was released unharmed early today after his son paid a $30,000 ransom.

title: Safety Act Is Expected to Force Closing of 500 Small Coal Mines on March 30
description: WASHINGTON, March 2A longdelayed requirement of the 1969 Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act is expected to force the closing of more than 500 small coal mines at the end of this month with a loss of about 5 per cent of the nation's coal production, Government officials said today.

title: Dance
description: MURRAY LOUIS and the Gemini of the Alwin Nikolais are dance world. Although for years Louis was Nikolais's student end later his principal dancer, and although for mime time the Louis Company was merely another name for the Nikolais company with different Choreography, the twin nature of their achievement has always been apparent. And Ns happy and generous relaettenship (how rare to find Ow statists with such true its for cooperation and collaboration) has even survived the existence of completely Separate companies. Yet they are still thought of affectionately as Nik and Murray, and maybe their companies are not so separate as at first appears.

title: Lawyer Is Fiance Of Linda Masters
description: WOODBURY, L. I., March 2Dr. Stanley Masters, an ophthalmologist, and Mrs. Masters have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Sue Masters, to Robert Lewis Barrows, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Barrows of St. Paul. The father of the future bridegroom is a partner in the law firm of Leonard, Street & Deinard in Minneapolis.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 2Army courts handed down prison sentences ranging from three to 15 years today to two South Korean politicians and 10 university students for advocating constitutional reforms.

title: Cherry Hill Wants Place on the Map
description: CHERRY HILL  This sprawling Camden County community of 27 square miles discovered last week that it had no official map and that it could not be found on most of the maps issued by the major gasoline companies. The news, spread by civic leaders, the police and longtime residents, came as something of a surprise. There has been such remarkable residential and commercial growth here in the last decade that many people felt that the township had achieved a statewide reputation and was no longer identified as a suburb of Philadelphia, a 10minute drive across the Delaware.

title: ...And Mrs. Viorst Wore Her Skin
description: I've always been willing to follow the dictates of fashion. Whatever it's told me to do I have gladly obeyed. I've been, in my bangles and scarves, a Sant'Angelo gypsy. I've been, in my feathers and headbands, an Indian maid. I've put on bleached jeans and no bra when they said go be groovy. I've put on a shift by Courreges when they said go be staid.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TuesdayNew Jersey Association of Corvair Enthusiasts monthly meeting at Riverview Inn, Route 202, Northbranch, N.J., 7:30 P.M. Information: Ed Connolly, phone (201)3355300.

title: Fuel Shortage Drastically Altering Pattern of Highway Travels
description: GERONIMO, Ariz.The nation's energy shortage, which has left motorists at the other end of the fuelallocation pipeline, is drastically altering traditional American highway travel patterns.

title: LETTER FROM TOKYO
description: Many Japanese have lately been recalling the old chronicles that told of men and countries whose glory faded in the space of a dream. The recent period of Japanese glory, from 1969 to 1973, when it seemed that a small, distant country would overtake the giants of the West, lasted somewhat longer than a dream, but it has ended with dramatic suddenness. The same people who only a few months ago.were talking and acting if the future held unlimited possibilities of economic expansion now gloomily announce, not without a touch of masochism, that they live in a .country completely at the mercy of others survival.

title: Gardens
description: OXALIS bloom well in bright light or under fluorescent light. Suddenly, this dainty blooming plant has become more popular than ever.

title: Volunteers Guide Consumers Through Complaint Red Tape
description: MOUNT OLIVE TOWNSHIP  A distraught woman barged into the local office of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: Violence Goes On in Argentine City Held by Police
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, March 2This embattled industrial city awoke today from a third night of shootings and bomblings with two rival governors, a labor movement split between rightists and leftists and a rebellious rightwing police force in control of the city, the Government House and the broadcasting stations.

title: Murcer, Yankees Agree To Record High Contract
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2First he gorged himself with a dinner of imported caviar, stone crabs and broiled pompano. Then Bobby Murcer stuffed his wallet with the highest salary the Yankees have paid in their glorious 72year history.

title: Firemen's Union Votes to Assess Nonstrikers $125 to Pay Fines
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association has voted to impose $125 assessments on firemen who stayed at their posts during the union's Nov. 6 strike and to divide the money among firemen who were fined $125 after the illegal walkout.

title: U.S. Indictments Due in Sale Of Tickets Stolen From Airlines
description: Federal indictments are expected to be handed up this week following a lengthy investigation into the multimilliondollar traffic in stolen airline tickets, Government sources said yesterday.

title: Michigan Tech, Boston U. Hockey Playoff Favorites
description: Every sport hat a second season and college hockey's is now at hand. Playoffs in all major conferences will be held this week, with the four best teams moving on to the eliminations of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. In the East, most observers feel Boston University, with a 197, wonlost record, is the team with the fewest weaknesses, while some are picking fastclosing Harvard. A seasonlong leader, New Hampshire, has the record (237), but few have placed the Wildcats in the favorite's role.

title: The Transit Dilemma
description: It is far too early to celebrate as accomplished fact what may be only a temporary trend, but the gasoline shortage seems to be returning passengert to public transit all over the country. Yet, in New York, which already had 40 per cent of the nation's transit riders, the gains were minimal and probably would be wiped out if, as seems likely, the fare has to be increased later in the year.

title: The Reckoning
description: The men who exercised power in Richard Nixons White House have now been formally accused, by a grand jury of ordinary citizens, of what constitutes the most corrupt conspiracy in the history of American government: the attempt to hide the true meaning of the Watergate burglary by destroying evidence, lying to investigators, buying silence with hutdreds of thousand of dollars and offers of clemency that only the President could grant.

title: Tennis Players Skeptical On City Courts Projects
description: With the publicparks outdoor tennis season starting next month, Parks Administrator Ed Weisl Jr. has come out of his bomb shelter to voice assurances that the courts will be in shape.

title: Lawyer to Wed Faye Polayes
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., March 2Miss Faye Marion Polayes, who is in her first year at the New York University Law School, plans to be married in August to Jonathan J. Silbermann, an N.Y.U. law graduate and lawyer with the New York firm of Finley, Kumble, Heine, Underberg & Grutman.

title: HERBERT S. FRIEDER
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2Herbert S. Frieder, president of S. Frieder & Sons, cigar manufacturer, and a director of the Cigar Institute of America, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old and lived in Melrose. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1924.

title: LehmanFive Faces Evers For Crown
description: Brooklyn College's basketball title hopes in the City University of New York tournament were snuffed out a second and last time, 8870, by Lehman College of the Bronx yesterday.

title: Miss Leah Siegel Will Wed June 18
description: CHICAGO, March 2Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Siegel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leah Siegel of Brooklyn, New York, to Martin Goldman of Kew Gardens, Queens, New York, an assistant district attorney for Queens County. He is the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Saul Goldman of Brighton, Mass.

title: The Indictments
description: The Watergate indictments are an occasion for sorrow mingled with pride. It is sad that a grand jury working with the Watergate special prosecutor believes there sufficient evidence of wrongdoing to bring criminal indictments against seven individuals, including a former member of the Cabinet and three men who were the most influential members of the President's staff.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Coach Norm Van Brocklin, after the Atlanta Falcons signed Gerald Tinker, who shares the world record of 9.1 seconds for the 100yard dash: Tinker is the first man we've ever had who can run like he can. We'll have to draw our pass patterns on longer paper.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The annual report as a literary form may be the American corporation's only indigenous contribution to world literature. Certainly it is our most prolific contribution.

title: She works in politics
description: MEDORA COOPER has to dress conservatively for Board of Estimate meetings, but in the evening she likes to dress freaky. The meetings are part of her job as assistant to Wilbert Tatum, deputy Borough President of Manhattan, who was recently appointed Mayor Beame's liaison to the clothing industry. The best part of her work, Medora says, is being able to help blacks and Puerto Ricans who get tangled in housing and welfare red tape. A political science major at Amherst who went on to study economics and government at the London School of Economics, Medora got involved in practical politics when she was living in Alabama.

title: Lamb Is Springing Into Season on American Dinner Tables
description: Regardless of weather or folk lore, March is not ushered in by a lion, but by a lamb, a spring lamb, to be precise.

title: An objectionable correlative
description: T. S. Eliot has always been a snare for biographers. While he lived, his personal elusiveness was as notorious as the difficulty of his poetry, and memoirists were often driven to metaphor to convey something of his fascination. For Clive Bell, Eliot was a planetary figure, much sought and hardly to be found; for Marianne Moore, a master of the anonymous...the cat who could never be caught. Auden saw a fireraising grandmother and a 12yearold boy inside the ceremonious churchwarden; and Cecil Day Lewis spoke of a playful, austere presence who slips into my mind/Like a most elegant allusion clinching an argument. As the years went by, the Eliot enigma appeared to be one of the poet's most artful creations, product not only of a self conscious esthetic requiring the continual extinction of personality, but of the fiercest, most deeplyrooted psychological compulsions.

title: City Digs Out From a Mountain Of Rent Protests
description: Two years after the inception of the computer rent program for controlled apartments, the system's protest mechanism remains a sore point with tenants, landlords and municipal bureaucrats.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONShould a state legislator who is a lawyer, and whose clients include people in the banking industry, serve on a legislative committee that handles banking bills? Should a legislator who is a contractor serve on a committee that considers major state construction contracts?

title: Jane Pittman Fulfilled My Deepest Expectations
description: Reviewing The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman on Feb. 10, Stephanie Harrington expressed her disappointment in the highly praised CBS drama. Jane Pittman, wrote Mrs. Harrington, contained nothing about black history that I, at least, had not learned in public school or from television newscasts and documentaries. In the article that follows, black poet Nikki Giovanni takes an opposing view.

title: Richardson Whitfield Schell To Marry Jennifer Almquist
description: WARREN, Conn., March 2 Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Almquist have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jennifer Almquist, to Richardson Whitfield Schell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Charles Schell Jr. of Chicago.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Miss Kujawski, Law Librarian, Plans Nuptials
description: ATLANTA, March 2Miss Jolynn Powell Kujawski, librarian with the Philadelphia law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, and Donald Edward McFadyen, who expects to receive an M.B.A. degree in May from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, will be married May 18 in Christ Episcopal Church, Philadelphia.

title: An Oil Sheikh's Paradise: the World's Fanciest Gift Shop
description: BESIDES being one of the handsomest stores in London, Asprey's is probably the last place on earth where you can still buy a set of motherofpearl caviar spreaders. That may be of only marginal interest to the average tourist, but for those who wince at the thought of metal coming into contact with sturgeons roe it is no trifling matter.

title: No. 1 Cyclist Finds Peril In the Birds
description: More than II Pazzo, the Mad One, the thing that scares Kenny Roberts are the birds. There he is, coming out of the 31degree banked turn at 170 miles an hour and his bike is in the air, the wind so cold that even under two pairs of gloves his fingers will freeze, and he knows he's going to drift 10 feet off his original line. That much he can handle.

title: Thoeni Wing World Cup Giant Slalorr
description: VOSS, Norway, March 2 (AP)  Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, double world skiing champion, won a World Cup giant slalom race today and improved his position in a bid for a fourth straight victory in the overall Cup standing.

title: Tales from the Closet
description: SHERLOCK HOLMES once drew an accurate picture of a man's domestic life from a glance at the man's shoes. The clues offered by what a woman wears are just as revealing, but, as several studies have shown, they are often much more deceptive.

title: The lace of evolution
description: NAIROBI. Fifty years ago, when the scientific world was convinced that Asia was the birthplace of man, a young British adventurer named Louis Leakey told hie.Cambridge dons he would go on a hunch to look for early man fossils in Africa. They scoffed, and Leakey was not much heard from for another 35 years. Whilebig foundations like the Carnegie and the Rockefeller poured vast sums into explorations in places like Java and Peking, Leakey worked patiently in the dusty gorges andhillsides of East Africa. At first alone, later with his wife, Mary, and son Richard, he struggled along on shoestring budgets, much the money out of his own pocket, in search of the evidence he was convinced had to be there. In 1959 the Leakeys finally scored, turning up the virtually complete skull of a previously unknown form of extinct man. And since their first big find, this remarkable family has revolutionized our understanding of where man came from.

title: Realty Panel Is Ordered To Bar Interest Conflict
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Real Estate Commission has been ordered to halt the practice whereby its members have been receiving advance funds from developers for expenses incurred in carrying out the inspection of outofstate lands being offered for sale in New Jersey.

title: RULING IS ISSUED ON BRASCO TAPES
description: Federal District Judge Inzer B. Wyaft ruled yesterday that the Government had destroyed dication tapes of an interview with is Prosecution witness in the corruption conspiracy trial of Representative Frank J. Braseb in the normal course of bussiness and had not acted improperly in so doing.

title: Michal Herridge Bride of Navy Officer
description: Miss Michal Troy Herridge was married here yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Comdr. Gray Hildebrand Rusk of the Naval Reserve Medical Corps. The Rev. John Mellon performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: DAYAN'S FOLLOWING TO SUPPORT PREMIER
description: TEL AVIV, March 2 (AP) Premier Golda Meir won vital votes for her planned minority cabinet tonight when Defense Minister Moshe Dayan's political followers decided to support it.

title: Music in Review
description: Miss Ludwig Sings Lieder Favorites

title: Met Is Given $1Million In U.S. Matching Funds
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which this season faced its worst financial crisis since the Depression, will receive $1million in matching funds from the National Endowment for the Arts. The money, which is not earmarked for any specific purpose and which will be used for operating expenses, is the largest grant of its kind to be given by the national arts group.

title: TWO SINGERS SHARE GRANNY SPOTLIGHT
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2 (AP) Killing Me Softly With His Song, a ballad about the emotional impact of music, was named record of the year tonight at the recording industry's 16th annual Grammy Awards, giving singer Roberta Flack her second such honor in two years. iMss Flack, also accepted a gold statuette for best female pop performance, also a repeat award for her.

title: Brooklyn Professor Finds Lost Music
description: A major 19thcentury musical work by a black composer received its first American performance last week  thanks to a longneglected book and a Brooklyn College professor's perseverence.

title: Growing up
description: IT hit me the day Camilla came home from the third grade and announced she had been studying The Adventures of Margo Polo. Already the woman was sprouting from the Brearley school uniform along with her legs. Now she's Camilla instead of Cammy, and out of uniform, but still a curious bundle of fluff and steel. Just when I think she's combing the fashion ads for thinnerlooking jeans, she'll look up from The Times and ask me to explain puts and calls. She reads the financial pages every day for her economics course at Barnard.

title: Hart Again Elected Head Of American Horse Shows
description: Albert E. Hart Jr. of New York has been elected president of the American Horse Shows Association for the 15th consecutive year, making him one of the most durable leaders of the nation's sports organizations.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodaySiberian Husky Club of Greater New York's specialty match; MidIsland Shopping Mall, Hicksville, L.I.; entries from 10:30 A.M.; judging 12:30 P.M

title: Point of View
description: There are many unanswered questions about the causes, nature, propagation, containment, general behavior and prevention of fires and smoke in our built environment. As a nation, we lack authoritative criteria and proven information to tell designers, code officials, legislators, owners, insurance companies and other decision makers what combination of fire safety measures is better than another or how to achieve a given level of safety at the lowest cost.

title: Fiona Wilson Fiancee Of Francois T. Balogh
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 2Miss Fiona Fraser Wilson, a granddaughter of the late Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin of New York, plans to be married April 13 to Francois Tibor Balogh.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Love makes the world go round, and maybe it will do something for the banking business too. At least that seems to be the hope of a new series of checks.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE CASE WORKER, by George KohnId. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95.) A social worker's daily rounds bring him into despairing touch with a variety of poor people who are etched with a preternatural clarity.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Cross currents affected the stock market last week, rippling through such major groups as the oils, golds and nonferrous metals.

title: Jumpers Needs To Settle Down
description: No problem is insoluble given a big enough plastic bag, Brian Bedford proposes, with a deeply satisfied smirk, in the current Kennedy Center production of Tom Stoppard's Jumpers. What the good people who have mounted this American production of Jumpers will now have to do is find a big enough plastic Vag. Someone's got to stuff the play's crochety, cerebral, freeassociation whimsies into a single, sealable theatrical container.

title: Nixon Near Low Point in Survey, With 27% Expressing Approval
description: The public's approval of President Nixon's performance in office remain near its low point to date in the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Only a Handful Will Make It
description: DON'T be surprised, Mother and Dad, if your son/daughter, the fine arts student, announces she's/he's taking courses in carpentry and plumbing. In at least one school, the an Francisco Art Institute, that's what they're planning to offer this fallto supplement such conventional fare as Drawing and Painting.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The Sound of Tokyo Music
description: WEST ORANGE  When the Tokyo String Quartet performs tonight at the Y.M.Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey, Leonard Shiman will settle back in his seat to enjoy what he calls a conversation conducted in civilized tones.

title: Inflation Hurting Small Shops
description: ROCHELLE PARKFor the last four and a half years, the Rochelle Cleaning Center and the Colonial Cleaners, which are situated opposite each other on busy Rochelle Avenue, have been in such fierce competition that the owners of the two drycleaning establishments were barely on speaking terms.

title: Stringer
description: Ward Just is an admirable journalist (Newsweek, The Reporter, The Washington Post) who has written books about the U.S. Army and the war in Vietnam; he is also the author of a previous novel and a tollection of stories. His second novel, Stringer, brings these interests together into a tale of military adventure in Vietnam.

title: Mrs. Nina Peabody Married to Dr. Thomas Ippolito
description: WILTON, Conn., March 2 Mrs. Nina Havemeyer Coogan Peabody, widow of Charles M. Peabody, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Thomas Leonard Ippolito, a widower of East Norwalk. The ceremony was performed in Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Joseph Cantillon.

title: FENNIMORE HEARD IN A PIANO RECITAL
description: Joseph Fennimore, who founded an adventuresome series called Hear America First in 1972, appeared in a benefit piano recital for the series yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was by no means exclusively American, and it can't have made much moneythe intimate hall was far from full. But it turned out to be a most enjoyable affair, even so.

title: Kunstler Works Untiringly on Latest Cause
description: ST. PAUL, March 2  William Kunstler, his spectacles glinting like a comb in his graying hair, declined to have a cocktail and instead took up a menu and asked, What is a porterhouse steak?

title: Sheila Kane Is Engaged to Ensign
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 2Frank R. Kane, Washington correspondent for The Blade of Toledo, Ohio, and Mrs. Kane have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Mitchell Kane, to Ens. Powell Alexander Fraser Jr., U.S.N., son of Dr. and Mrs. Fraser of Bristol, Tenn., where his father is president of King College.

title: The need for a science of limits
description: Lewis Mumford, Theodore Roszak, and Jacques Ellul, preachers against technology, make provocative bedtime reading, but little more than that, primarily because they fail to take account of the psychological reality principle of technology  that contemporary man cannot and will not live without technology. So writes Daniel Callahan (director of the Institute of Society, Ethics and the Life Sciences) toward the end of his book Had that sentence been the first in the book, the reader might have been led to expect that Callahan  firmly cognizant of man's irreversible commitment to technology; determined not merely to preach against technology would provide more than merely more provocative bedtime reading. One might even expect answers to the many questions that so exercise Munrford, Roszak and Ellul and with which they provoke their readers.

title: Deborah Sturm Engaged
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., March 2 Miss Deborah Anne Sturm, who expects to graduate in June from BaldwinWallace College, plans to be married Aug. 31 to Frank Lynn Fox Jr., a BaldwinWallace graduate studying law at Toledo University. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Sturm have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fox of Sandusky, Ohio.

title: THE DINER CIRCLE LAMPOONS NIXON
description: The Inner Circle, an organization of New York political writers, held its annual lampoon show and dinner last night, thrusting its satirical lances at President Nixon, Vice President Ford, Mayor Beame and former Mayor John V. Lindsay, among others.

title: Red Smith
description: When Harry Ruby, the songwriter, died in California last week the obituary bestowed the title of world's greatest baseball fan on the composer of Three Little Words, Who's Sorry Now? Baby Face and many other hits. The obit didn't tell the half of it. Harry Ruby felt deeply about music, yet given his choice of composing Beethoven's Third or ripping a line drive over second like Bill Dickey, he would have suited up on the spot. He loved the piano, but would infinitely rather have been Pete Rose than Artur Rubinstein.

title: Sarah Churchill Paintings To Appear as Lithographs
description: ENGLISHTOWN  Her father was perhaps the most famous Sunday painter in the Western world. And so it was only natural that his daughter, Sarah Churchill, also would take up painting as a hobby.

title: Providence Turns Back St. John's
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 2Providence College is going to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament again while St. John's University is going to the National Invitation Tournament againa fortunate happenstance for the Redmen.

title: Julia E. Connolly Wed to Kevin Hayden
description: Miss Julia Elizabeth Connolly was married yesterday morning in St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, to Kevin John Hayden. The ceremony was concelebrated by the Rev. Eugene O'Hara, the Rev. J. Edward O'Brien and Abbot Edmund, president of Belmont (N. C.) Abbey College, of which the bridegroom is a graduate.

title: U.N. UNIT BIDS CHILE FREE 5 PRISONERS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1  The Commission on Human Rights called today on Chile's ruling military junta to release five leading political prisoners and allow them to leave the country.

title: Robin Poses Is Bride
description: HARRISON, N. Y., March 2  Miss Robin Poses, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Poses of Yonkers, was married here this evening to Robert W. Markell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Markell of New Rochelle. Rabbi Amiel Wohi performed the ceremony at the Willow Ridge Country Club. The bride is an assistant media buyer for Doubleday & Co., the publishers, in New York.

title: Lynne H. Gorman to Be Bride Of John F. Berentson in May
description: CHICAGO, March 2Miss Lynne H. Gorman, a merchandising editor for Glamour magazine in New York, and John Franklin Berentson, chief operating officer of Formont Associates, a New York company in video merchandising on cable television, plan to be married here in May.

title: Saigon: U. S. Advice Still a Factor
description: SAIGON, South VietnamThe bitter years of American soldiers fighting and dying in South Vietnam are fading into the pages of history. But an important American presence still fuels one side as Vietnamese continue to kill Vietnamese a year after the Paris peace accords.

title: The World
description: Secretary of State Kissinger has resumed his shuttle diplomacy, composed of equal parts speed, secrecy and persuasion, with the goal of separating Israeli and Syrian forces on the Golan Heights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Loses Tax Plea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (UPI)Tax Assessor Joseph E. Tinney has declined to grant a tax exemption to a church that featured an art exhibit on lovemaking. Mr. Tinney said this week that the art exhibit of the Genesis Church and Ecumenical Center reflects commercial aspects because admission was charged and, therefore, the collections was not tax deductible.

title: The Arabs' Goal: A Theater That Speaks for Arabs
description: JUST a month before the ArabIsraeli war I was on the way to Iran to attend a Third World Theater Festival and Conference where, it turned out, the Arabs were predominant and the Israelis, although invited, conspicuously absent. Worried about hijacking but never giving the possibility of war a thought, I was looking forward to the event and to meeting Arab, Asian and African artists and, seeing their productions.

title: Election Blow in Ulster
description: One of the risks Prime Minister Heath took in calling last week's British election was the possibility that a divisive campaign would undermine the painfully constructed machinery for ProtestantCatholic powersharing and cooperation in Northern Ireland. The results confirm the forebodings: Protestant extremists, bitterly opposed to sharing power with Catholics, won, eleven of Ulster's twelve seats in the House of Commons.

title: Smith Defeats Ramirez, Meets Newcombe Today
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Mar. 2Stan Smith, probably the busiest athlete of the week, won a hardfought semifinal from Raul Ramirez today, 63, 4.6, 64, to set up a second straight final against John Newcombe in the Blue Group of the World Championship Tennis circuit.

title: Yarborough Eyes Auto or Senate Race
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., March 2Gale Yarborough will start from the pole tomorrow in the $98,075 Carolina 500, which proves a Republican can run well, in 1974.

title: Bouttier Regains Title
description: PARIS, March 2 (UPI) JeanClaude Bouttier of France regained the European middleweight title tonight, battering Elio Calcabrini of Italy until the referee stopped the scheduled 15round fight in the 12th round.

title: THE INNER CIRCLE LAMPOONS NIXON
description: The Inner Circle, an organization of New York political writers, held its annual lampoon show and dinner last night, thrusting its satirical lances at President Nixon, Vice President Ford, Mayor Beame and former Mayor John V. Lindsay, among others.

title: A LAGAL QUESTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The Watergate grand jurors concluded that President Nixon was involved in the Watergate coverup and they decided a month or more ago to urge the courts to turn over their conclusions and evidence to the House impeachment inquiry, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Pilot Finds Luge Racing Bigger Test Than Flying
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.You can't beat this sport, said Dave LeBoutillier, a Trans World Airlines pilot, who had finished almost at the end of the 41man field at the recent international luge racing twoday test program at this Adirondack resort. It has everything.

title: News Summary and Index
Texan on List of Enemies Says He Forgives Nixon
description: Stanley Marsh 3d, one of 490 persons whose name appeared on a White House enemies list, says he has forgiven President Nixon and has taken a poll to find out how many others on the list will do the same.

title: Old Bomb Kills 3 in Japan
description: NAHA, Okinawa, March (AP)Two construction workers and a child were killed and at least 20 persons injured today when a buried World War II bomb exploded near a kindergarten, the police said.

title: For Elderly, Sunday Is Loneliest Day
description: HACKENSACKThere is the widow who wanders through the aisles of the local supermarket. And then there is the one who holds animated conversations with the television set.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Bill Russell, the onetime great center, and Kareem AbdulJabbar, his present counterpart, will visit Madison Square Garden this weekRussell as coach of the Seattle Supersonics, who play the New York Knicks Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. and AbdulJabbar to lead the Milwaukee Bucks against the Knicks Saturday at 8 P.M.

title: Dance
description: Merce Cunningham and his dance company reappeared at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night to give the first of two performances. Well, nowadays Mr. Cunningham tends to call his performances events, which are numbered consecutively. Thus Brooklyn was seeing Events Number 89 and 90.

title: New England as it was
description: A dozen years ago, Eric Sloane published a short illustrated narrative of a year in the life of a New England boy, based on a diary in Sloane's possession. Almost everyone interested in Americana is likely to know something of Sloane's long interest in early American wooden tools. For him, as for any good archeologist, it was a natural step from the study of implements and artifacts of a vanished time, to the study of the way life was lived in pioneer settlements, where those artifacts were found. The fact that author Sloane is even better known as artist Sloane, painter and illustrator, has caused his works to be as dependent on

title: Ideas & Trends
description: As a kind of antidote to the new math, an educational television series on mathematics has been developed that stresses everyday skills such as estimation and measurement.

title: Prestigious Awards Won by 2 in Suffolk
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. Two young people from Eastern Long Island have been awarded the prestigious Marshall Scholarships for advanced study in Britain.

title: ITALY'S PREMIER, RESIGNS IN RIFF
description: ROME, March 2 Premier, Mariano Rumor's Government, Italy's 35th in 30 years, resigned today following the collapse of the centerleft coalition on which it was based.

title: Margot Thayer Fiancee of Robert Rice
description: CONVENT STATION, N. J., March 2Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Thayer Jr. have made known the engafement of their daughter, Miss Margot Jeanne Thayer, to Robert William Rice, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rives Rice of Houston, formerly of Somerset.

title: The Triumph of Money and Power
description: WASHINGTONThe United States Government secretly decided last month to resume aid to the small Central African country of Burundi despite official intelligence confirming that ethnic genocide by the Burundian regime continued to take thousands in 1973.

title: Harvard Outswims Yale, Earns Title
description: NEW HAVEN, March 2The Harvard swimming team clinched its first outright Eastern Intercollegiate Swim League title since 196162 and finished undefeated for the first time since that season with a 9122 victory over Yale today.

title: Gov. Docking of Kansas Will Not Seek Reelection
description: TOPEKA, Kan., March 2 (AP)  Robert B. Docking, fourterm Democratic Governor of this normally Republican state, said tonight he would not seek reelection this fall.

title: Iowa Gymnasts Triumph
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 2 (UPI)Iowa, paced by Carl Walin in the allround competition, established a Big Ten Conference gymnastics scoring record today in winning the team championship. Iowa had 329 points Michigan, the 1973 titleholder, was second with 322.20.

title: QUESTIONS
description: The questions appearing this column are asked and answered by readers in exchange of gardening knowledge. If you have question or answer, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be published. Please include stamped return envelope.

title: A ShoelaceTying Machine and Other Wonders of the Inventors Fair
description: SPEP right this way, ladies and gentlemenl Walk right into the greatest gadget show on earth. It's the 65th running, from April 27 to May 12, of the famous, nutty, lovable and occasionally amazing Councours Lepine the huge inventors show that is a delightful part of each year's sprawling Paris Fair in Parc des Expositions at the Porte de Versailles. There you'll see a couple hundred bricoleurs, that notorious breed of oldtime French puttrers, tinkerers, idea men and occasional geniuses who make a virtual life's philosophy of systeme D, the D standing for debrouillard, the character who always finds a way, his own way, of doing whatever has to be done, no matter how many jars of glue, rolls of baling wire, hairpins or rubber bands it takes.

title: Mary H. Gram Will Be a Bride; Nuptials in April
description: Mrs. Carl W. Gram of New York and East Hampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Harvey Gram, to Francis Hopkinson Van Deventer Jr., son of Mr. Van Deventer of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. David S. Henkel of Greenwich and Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Numismatics
description: THE word exonumia has reached the Promised Land. It has been accepted for inclusion in the MerriamWebster International Dictionary. Exomile, as readers of this column have witnessed, has gained increasing recognition in the hobby as a term that enfolds the various kinds of medals, advertising storecards, good  for tokens and paper chits, political badges and a great range of other numismatic material that flourishes just outside the boundaries of oftidal governmentissue coins and paper money.

title: VETERANS' GROUP ENDS 19DAY SITIN
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2Disabled Vietnam veterans ended a prolonged hunger strike today after meetting Donald E. Johnson, heed of the Veterans Administration.

title: Rego Park Apartment Proposal Approved
description: Community Board 6 in Queens has given conditional approval to plans for a highrise luxury condominiurn, office building, commercial and parking complex that has been proposed for the Rego Park section.

title: Twixt Upset By Neck in Forge 'Cap
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., March 2 (UPI)Fairway Flyer overtook heavilyfavored Twixt near the finish at Garden State Park today to in the $28,875 Valley Forge Handicap for fillies and mares.

title: Payments Awaiting Blind and Disabled
description: HACKENSACKFreeholder Thomas J. Costa has urged elderly blind and disabled persons in Bergen County to check with the Social Security Administration in order to determine if they are eligible for additional payments.

title: St. Peter's Team Doctor Is Mom to the Players
description: We're having a running love affair, said Jerene Robbins about herself and the male athletes at St. Peter's College in Jersey City. Some of them write me letters, send me valentines and even invite me to the prom.

title: Solzhenitsyn Asks Kremlin To Abandon Communism And Split Up Soviet Union
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Russian dissident writer, addressed a long letter to the Soviet leaders last fall, asking them to abandon Communism as an alien, unworkable political philosophy, dismantle the Soviet Union and focus on developing, Russia proper as a separate state.

title: New Murder Trial Sought
description: ERIE, Pa., March 2 (AP)Albert Pass, convicted of murder in the Yablonski family slayings, has requested a new trial. A panel of Erie County judges will consider the motion next Thursday, according to President Judge Edward H. Carney.

title: HERMANN G. PLACE, AN INDUSTRIALIST
description: Hermann G. Place, former president and board chairman of the General Precision Equipment Corporation (now part of the Singer Company), died yesterday in Millbrook, N.Y., where he lived. His age was 79.

title: Brooklyn Falconer's Pleasure Soars
description: Out in the Marine Pad section of Brooklyn, not far from the marshy shore of Jamaica Bay, William McGrath carries on an ancient sport that dates back at least to Pliny anti Aristotle.

title: Chris Evert Mrs. King Both Upset
description: CHICAGO, March 2 (AP)Rosemary Casals of San Francisco and Virginia Wade of Britain, scored upset victories today in the semifinals of the $50,000 women's tennis tournament.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Postwar Aid

title: Superstar Kyle Rote Jr.: Unusual Young Athlete
description: Right now, he is the league. He is big, strong, blond and generous. He is cleancut, modest and mildmannered. Money and titles are not allimportant to him. He would like to be a minister of some sort, or at least be an example to others, He is currently studying theology and nays an athlete has a greater minisdry than a preacher. He feels he has a mission and an obligation to youngsters. His favorite story is about a French prisoner who requested a delay in his release so that he could play in the prison soccer final.

title: At home in three worlds
description: AFEW years ago, Ruth Siegel and her family chartered a converted minesweeper for a Mediterranean cruise. During the trip, a mishap occurred. Somehow, somewhere at sea, their dinghy floated away. Reaching Cannes, they had no way to get ashore. Mrs. Siegel reacted with typical practicality. She dove over the side and made her entrance into Cannes in a wet swimsuit.

title: AROUND THE
description: Prune grapevines, fruit trees, shads trees, evergreens and summerflowering shrubs. ... Avoid foot traffic on wet soggy lawns. ... Take power mowers and tractors for sharpening and servicing, if needed. ... Finish seed orders and mail promptly. ... Repair fences and gates.

title: Our Airports Are Socifugal, Not Sociopetal, And It's An Outrage!
description: AIRPORT terminals should rank high on any list of socially destructive 4n buildings. They are precast concrete testimonials to the school or architecture which critics have called the New Brutalism. From the exterior, most airports are impressive, but you wouldn't, want to live around one or spend much time inside. In addition, airports are beingrecognized as a source. of air pollution and harmful noise, but I will leave these topics to those more qualified in the natural sciences and concentrate instead on the human environment inside the airport.

title: Be a Good Neighbor
description: Pursuant to a long tradition and an official proclamation by Mayor Beame, March is Red Cross month  the time of the year when the voluntary agency appeals to New Yorkers to provide some of the funds needed to continue its services.

title: Flower Show to Open Saturday
description: MORRISTOWNThe gasoline shortage is not expected to diminish attendance at the eighth annual New Jersey Flower and Garden Club Show, which opens at the National Guard Armory next Saturday and continues through May 17.

title: Problems Delay Quarter Horse Track
description: YAPHANK, L. I., March 2 There will be no quarter horse racing on Long Island this spring or this summer. Perhaps in the fall, then? Well, maybe.

title: Steer Sold for $40,000
description: HOUSTON, March 2 (AP) The grand champion steer of the Houston Fat Stock Show was auctioned today for $40,000 to a group of Houston businessmen. The high bid was made by Tommy Vaughn, a Houston car dealer and president of the show, who represented the group of about 30 buyers.

title: Silver as an Art Shown at Adelphi
description: GARDEN CITY, L. LDavid Berg, New York lawyer and art enthusiast, decided some years ago that he wanted to decorate his apartment with antique furniture. Once he had started his project, he felt he ought to accessorize his place similarly.

title: Mackell Still Eligible For $26,000 Pension
description: Despite his conviction yesterday on charges of conspiracy, hindering prosecution and official misconduct, Thomas J. Mackell is entitled to continue to receive his pension of more than $26,000 a year for his 30 years as a policeman, State Senator and Queens District Attorney.

title: A Spanish Anarchist, 26, Is Executed by Garroting
description: MADRID, March 2  A 26yearold Catalonian anarchist was executed today by garroting despite widespread appeals to Generalissimo Francisco Franco for clemency.

title: Seymore Triumphs In Bowling
description: MIAMI, March 2 (AP)Alex Seymore, in his fifth full season on the Professional Bowlers Association tour, made his debut in the winner's circle today in an $80,000 tournament in Miami.

title: About the Mets...
description: The American League played the National in St. Petersburg's 18th annual oldtimers game for the March of Dimes. It was 60 years ago after the St. Louis Browns had pitched the first spring training camp on the Gulf Coast.... The Mets were represented by Yogi Berra, Ralph Kiner and five coaches: Eddie Yost, Rube Walker, Joe Pignatano, Billy Connors and Phil Cavarretta .... The Mets are still running the fastest workouts in the area: two hours, half as long as the Philadelphia Phillies at Clearwater. The reason: the Mets' world revolves around their pitchers, who are limited to five minutes each on the mound for batting practice.... Still missing: Ted Martinez, the utility infielder, somewhere in the Dominican Republic. We max have to send a scout to find him, said Bob Scheffing, the general manager in charge of wayward travelers.

title: 4 Arrested at Jack in Box
description: Four Queens teenagers have been arrested on charges of threatening John English, the manager of the Jack in the Box restaurant in Hollis. The arrests on Friday were not connected with the incident on Feb. 15 when a group of youths caused several thousand dollars worth of damage to the restaurant. Two girls, 15 and 17 years old, and two 15yearold boys were charged with loitering and harassment in the restaurant, the police reported.

title: TEACHER SEIZED ON DRUG CHARGE
description: A 25yearold Trenton substitute teacher has been charged with encouraging about 20 high school students to smoke marijuana in a classroom potparty by locking the door, rolling the windows up and the shades down and providing instruction on cigaretterolling for those who needed to know.

title: Julie S. Short Engaged To Marry Pike Talbert
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 2The engagement of Miss Julie Sayre Short to William Pike Talbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Talbert of New York, has been announcd by her father, Marion Lewis Lovell Short of Lexington. The prospective bride also is a daughter of the late Mrs. Julia Allen Short of Philadelphia.

title: French Accuse 3 Corsicans Of $12Million Wine Fraud
description: AJACCIO, Corsica, March 2 (UPI)The French Government has charged three Corsican winemakers with making $12million in illegal profits by marketing artificial wine composed of sulfuric acid, glycerin and sugar.

title: '74 Patrick Trophy Goes to Murdoch
description: For his 11 years as a Ranger and 27 years as Yale's hockey coach, Murray Murdoch will receive the 1974 Lester Patrick Trophy for his contributions to the sport in the United States.

title: Resorts and Hotels Find Weekend Business Cut by the Fuel Shortage
description: An American traditionthe overnight weekend automobile jaunthas become a vanishing tradition in much of the countryvictim of vanishing gasoline.

title: S.O.R.C.Honors to Hood Robin Too II
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, March 2Ted Hood is the king of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

title: Jersey Pilot Is Killed
description: PATUXENT NAVAL AIR STATION, Md., March 3 (UPI)An Air Force pilot was killed today when his jet fighter crashed into the sea during a training flight over Chesapeake Bay. A spokesman at McGuire Air Force Base identified the victim as 2nd Lieut. Robert H. Drosendanl. 25 years old, of Westfield, N. J.

title: Recital
description: Helen Harbison's choice and arrangement of works for her cello recital Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall seemed, at times, to have been made almost in hope of distracting attention from her, performances. What with piano and harpsichord Moving, problems of tape synchronization (in Divadovsky's Synchronisms No. 3) and the inclusion of three Ramau pieces that emphasized flute and, harpsichord, it was difficult to remember that the purpose of the evening was a cello recital.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The second season in New. Jersey high school basketball starts today as 350 schools begin play in the 56th annual state interscholastic athletic association tournament

title: NELSON FRANK, 68, EXLABOR REPORTER
description: Nelson Frank, a labor reporter for the New York WorldTelegram from 1944 to 1954 who frequently wrote of Communist inflitration and espionage and covered Congressional investigations into them, died yesterday in Park West Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 107 University Place.

title: Byrne and His Family Move Into Mansion
description: PRINCETON, March 3 (UPI)Governor Byrne and his family have officially moved into the Governor's mansion.

title: ETHYL TO MAKE A BID FOR ALL VCA STOCK
description: The Ethyl Corporation said yesterday it planned to make a cash tender offer of $17.50 a common share for all VCA corporation stock. The offer would involve some $80million.

title: NORTH BRUNSWICK MOVES ON BUSING
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK TOWNSHIP, March, 3The school board here has taken another step in its long effort to end the busing of its nearly 600 white highschool students from this community to the racially troubled New Brunswick High School by cutting $422,000 from the township's proposed $8.1million 197475 school budget.

title: Excerpts From Text On Primacy of Pontiff
description: Following are excerpts from the text of, the conclusions of the Ministry and the Church Universal: Differing Attitudes Toward Papal Primacy, which was published yesterday by a joint commission of Lutheran and Roman Catholic scholars:

title: Clinton Dominates Relays
description: Clinton won four events yesterday in the first Bronx schoolboy indoor relay carnival at the Kingsbridge Armory. Clinton captured the 440, 880, mile and freshman 880 events. Other winners were John F. Kennedy in the distance medley and Columbus in the twomile.

title: Woodcock Says Outlook For 1974 Jobs Is Bleak
description: This year will be one of the worst years for unemployment since World War II, labor leader Leonard Woodcock predicted this weekend. The Nixon Administration's forecast of 5 per cent to 6 per cent joblessless, said the president of the United Auto Workers, is much too optimistic.

title: Warranty Plan Protects Homeowners
description: NEWARK, March 3The estate's building industry has offered to be a testing ground for a new warranty program designed to protect homeowners against faulty worksmanship and defects in materials.

title: U.S. Reports BuildUp by Hanoi in South
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28There has been an extensive buildup in men and equipment by the North Vietnamese in South Vietnam, according to Air Force photos and other information, and it is causing concern in the Pentagon.

title: MEDICAID ABUSES ALLEGED IN BRONX
description: A community group has charged that private health centers in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx were continuing to take advantage of Medicaid patients despite an agreement signed jest August to halt certain practices the community found questionable.

title: Many Workers Still Face Health Peril Despite Law
description: The recent discovery of fatal liver cancer among vinyl chloride workers has focused renewed attention of government, labor, industry and medicine on the thousands of known, suspected and as yet unsuspected health hazards that face 60 million working Americans.

title: The Calley Disgrace
description: Where crime and justice are concerned, the mind instinctively seeks for uniformity. But uniformity of treatment is the attribute that has been singularly lacking in the case of Lieutenant William L. Calley Jr. Instead of bringing to trial before the same courtmartial all officers and enlisted men who were in any way involved in the My Lai massacre in South Vietnam 1968, the Army held different trials before different panels of officers serving as judges.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Mood Music for Kissinger
description: BONN, March 3  As the Jordanian Arab Army Band marched past Secretary of State Kissinger before his departure from Amman this afternoon, a member of the Kissinger party shook his head and said: It's crazy, isn't it? An Arab king honoring a JewishAmerican official, with his Britishstyle band playing its Scottish bagpipes to a desert background.

title: Guatemalans Vote, Without Turbulence, For New President
description: GUATEMALA, March 3  Some 700,000 Guatemalans voted in apparent tranquillity but with little overt enthusiasm today for a new President from among three military candidates.

title: JOAN MILLER TROUPE OFFERS A DANCE BILL
description: Joan Miller's lithe jumps and turns show a genuine joy in moving, but her creative reach does not extend beyond a short phrase or two. There, are moments when her works seize attention, but over all they tend to wear out their welcome before they are finished. Her new Thoroughfare, presented at Clark Center on Saturday night, has its pretty bits, but it scatters its thrust in endless entrances and exits.

title: Scientists Still Divided On Setting Growth Limit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3Two years after the celebrated Club of Rome report saying that unbridled growth would bring the world to catastrophe, the scientific community is still fragmented on what limits to growth are desirable or possible.

title: London Strike Diverted Britons to Turkish Jet
description: LONDON, March 3 (Reuters) A strike of ground staff at London's Heathrow Airport diverted many British passengers to the Turkish Airlines DC10 that crashed near Paris today, a spokesman for British Airways said.

title: Budgetary Storm Signal
description: Mayor Beame's order to department heads to cut back on spending because of rising costs Sand declining revenues is a warning of serious budgetary storms ahead.

title: Kissinger in Bonn for Talks About Mideast and Europe
description: BONN, March 3Secretary of State Kissinger began consultations on the Middle East and on EuropeanAmerican relations with Foreign Minister Walter Scheel tonight after a fiveandahalfhour flight from Amman, Jordan.

title: Muskle Campaigns in Ohio
description: CINCINNATI, March 3 (UPI) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, the last in a long series of top Democrats and Republicans campaigning for Congressional candidates here, spoke here today for Thomas Luken.

title: JOSEPH C. THOMSON, LAWYER, 76, IS DEAD
description: Joseph C. Thomson, who retired in 1965 as senior partner of the New York law firm of Thomson & McGinty, died Saturday in Doctor's Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 840 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Egypt Urges Arab Talks On Easing Oil Embargo
description: CAIRO, March 3Egypt has proposed that the oil ministers of Arab oilproducing countries meet in Tripoli, Libya, next Sunday to consider, among other things, the easing of their oil embargo against the United States.

title: Events Today
description: BACH'S ST. JOHN PASSION, Tully Hell, 7:30.

title: TRUCKERS WARN OF A NEW STRIKE
description: LOS ANGELES, March 3It has gone vitually unnoticed, but another nationwide truckere' strike has been scheduled.

title: LANGUAGE STIRS NEW QUEBEC ISSUE
description: MONTREAL, March 3When an immigrant comes to Montreal from a country where the people speak neither French nor English, what should be the language of his children's education?

title: When It's Time to Walk Away from a Lie
description: I kind of thought so, Pop. I'm so glad you told me. My 12yearold daughter spoke these words when shared with her, and with my 9yearold son, the meaning of homosexuality and revealed that I'm gay.

title: Shipping/Mails AllHours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mall Ships

title: Fern Helscher Dies at 73; Press Agent for Ted Shawn
description: Fern Helscher, wellknown dance publicity woman in the nineteenthirties and forties, died yesterday on a flight to New York after a threeweek tour of West Africa and the Indian. Ocean islands with friends. She was 73 years old. Miss Helscher had been under treatment for cancer in recent months.

title: Bullets Win, 9893, Despite a Cold Spell
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 3 (AP) The Capital Bullets went the final 5 minutes 19 seconds without a field goal tonight, but managed to hang on for a 9893 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. Elvin Hayes led the victors with 25 points:

title: Hearst Pleads With Kidnappers
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., March 3  month after the abduction of his daughter and 10 days since the last message from the kidnappers, Randolph A. Hearst made a new appeal today for some word from 20yearold Patricia Hearst.

title: Elisabeth Houghton, Trustee Of Hirshhorn Museum, Dies
description: Elisabeth Houghton of Washington, a former, member of the board of governors of the American Red Cross who was appointed in 1971 by President Nixon as a trustee of the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, died Saturday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

title: PRINTERS CUT OFF NOSTRIKE ACCORD
description: Typographical Union No. 6 announced yesterday that it had sent telegrams to The New York Times and The Daily News terminating its agreement not to strike or interfere with production at the two papers.

title: Child Patients Not Wanted by Parents Pose Problem for Psychiatric Hospital
description: A 12yearold boy sits in the cheerful therapy room, his eyes cast down, his voice a monotone, as he talks about his ordeal. He has been waiting for more weeks than he can remember to leave the Queens Children's Hospital.

title: Keansburg to Vote Tomorrow On BoroughGovernment Form
description: KEANSBURG, March 3Voters in this Monmouth County municipality on the Raritan Bay will be asked to decide on Tuesday whether the borough should abandon its 48yearold government and adopt a plan under New Jersey's Optional Municipal Charter Law.

title: LAWMAKERS MEET PUBLIC IN ESSEX
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 3Five state lawmakers from Essex County stated their position on publicly financed political campaigns, unrestricted meetings of legislative committees, creation of a safe Congressional district for Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. and other issues at a forum here today sponsored by Common Cause, the citizens' advocate group.

title: U.S. Won't Insist on Numerical Parity in Arms Talks With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States would not insist upon strict numerical equality with the Soviet Union in any future armscontrol agreement limiting the strategic arsenals of the two nations.

title: Mason: New $100,000 Yankee
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3And now from the people who brought you Hank Aaron, Willie McCovey, Billy Williams, Cleon Jones, Amos Otis and Tommie Agee comesfanfare of trumpets Jim Mason. Jim Mason?

title: Parkway Section to Close
description: The northbound lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway between 79th and 96th Streets will be closed at 10 A.M. today to enable work crews to make roadway repairs. The parkway section is expected to be closed for three days, according to the City Transportation Administration.

title: Productive Papp Follows the Writers' Lead
description: One New York critic recently made a reference to the ailing New York Shakespeare Festival. Joseph Papp, the combative producer of the Shakespeare Festival, called the writer and said, Maybe you're ailing, but I'm not ailing. We've never been more alive and active.Despite mixed reviews on most of his recent productions, business has been good, and Mr. Papp's enthusiasm and productivity are unflaggingdowntown at the Public Theater and uptown at Lincoln Center.

title: MARKET TURMOIL EXPECTED ABROAD
description: LONDON, March 3 A period of turmoil is in prospect, for the foreign exchange markets, all over Europe due to widespread economic uncertainties engendered by the political deadlock in Britain and the fall of the Italian Government.

title: 4 GRAMMYS GIVEN TO STEVIE WONDER
description: Stevie Wonder, the singer, won four Grammys Saturday night for his recordings during 1973. The presentation ceremonies of the record industry's annual awards were held at the Hollywood Paladium and were televised nationally by the columbia Broadcasting System.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Pate 31

title: Mayor Beams Asserts Crises Make Days Longer
description: Mayor Beame said last night that his two months as Mayor had teen perhaps the most enlightening 60 days in my entire life.

title: COMMUNISTS GAIN FROM INDIAN VOTE
description: NEW DELHI, March 3Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is ready to lean heavily on Communist support in the aftermath of the narrow election victories by her ruling Congress party in two key Indian states.

title: TV: An Operatic Rachel, La Cabana
description: Tonight's offering on WNET Opera Theater, at 8 P.M., is the world premiere of, a vaudeville with music Composed by Hans Werner Henze and once subtitled a cruel and obacene vaudeville, it's called Rachel la Cubana. The libretto, written by Hans Magnus Enzenberger and translated by Meli Mandel, is based on the novel La Cancin de Rachel, written in 1969 by Miguel,Barnet, a Cuban. Barnet, a Cuban.

title: Sabres Outscore Islanders' Harris, 43
description: BUFFALO, March 3 (AP)Powerplay goals by Rick Martin and Gil Perreault in the final period tonight rallied the Buffalo Sabres to a 43 National Hockey League victory over the New York Islanders.

title: Utility Regulators Ask Curb On Use of Phone Records,
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissions urged telephone companies to require a court order before keeping secret from a customer the word that his tollcall records had been turned over to a government agency.

title: Petty Wins, Laps Carolina 500 Field
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., March 3In a setting resembling a church picnic, Richard Petty won the $98,075 Carolina 500 todaya race that turned out about as exciting as a church picnic, and just as predictable.

title: Kennan Says Europe Brought Disunity on Itself
description: WASHINGTON, March 3If Western Europeans insist on suicidal course of disunity, they should learn to recognize this as the product of their own choice, not as something forced upon them by the Russians and the Americans, George F. Kennan says in an article in the current issue of Foreign Policy.

title: LINDSAY IS BLAMED IN HEALTH CARE DROP
description: Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, the city's Health Services Administrator, said yesterday that the quality of the city's health services had declined under the Lindsay administration.

title: Brooklyn Museum Pickets Seek Union
description: Professional, technical and administrative employes of the Brooklyn Museum marched with picket signs in front of the museum yesterday to elicit public support in their effort to win union ??.

title: City Court Title Won by Lehman
Egypt Hails, Soviet as a Sturdy Friend
description: CAIRO, March 3  Egypt's Governmentcontrolled newspapers today gave high praise to the Soviet Union as the Arabs' sturdiest and most consistent friend.

title: Western Europe Falters
description: PARIS, March 3A plague of political troubles has swept the European democracies, leaving most governments weakened and some countries without effective government at all. A few months after the Common Market's nine members pledged to speak with a single voice and develop a harmonious European identity, Britain, Italy and Belgium are without governments and without much prospect of achieving the solid political consent needed to make representative democracy work effectively.

title: Wacky Packs: For Many Children, It's Like Collecting Antiques
description: It's a preteenagers paradise these days at just about every candy store in town. At lunchtime and after school youngsters pile In at such places as Riefner's Stationery Store, 1488 York Avenue (at 78th Street), to snap up its sixth series of Wacky Packages, those phenomenally popular putdowns on advertising.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3And now from the people who brought you Hank Aaron, Willie McCovey, Billy Williams, Cleon Jones, Amos Otis and Tommie Agee comesfanfare of trumpets Jim Mason, Jim Mason?

title: Home for the V.P.
description: For decades, there has been desultory discussion of the need to provide the Vice President with an official residence. Traditionally, this idea has been advanced, as specific step that could be taken to upgrade the office of Vice President and enhance its dignity.

title: Baltimore Teachers Reach Tentative Accord on Strike
description: BALTIMORE, March 3 (AP) An agreement has been reached that is expected to end a monthlong strike by the city's 8,600 teachers, according to William Usery Jr. director of the Federal Mediation and Con??liation Service.

description: JERUSALEM; March 3Premier Golda Meir stunned her party and the country tonight by announcing that she was giving up her fiveweek effort to form a new coalition government.

title: Use of Task Forces and Informers Helps Increase Drug Prosecutions
description: On the night of Feb. 17, 1971, a task force of narcotics agents on a Federal investigation arrived in the neighborhood of Christine's Luncheonette in East Harlem accompanied by a paid informer, Agent 0036, also known as Boom Boom, who was carrying $16,500 in buy money.

title: Connecticut Hearing Is Set On Dropping Rail Routes
description: Opposing views of federal and Connecticut transportation officials op the viability of 25 per cent of the state's rail freight trackage will collide headon at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing March 11 in Connecticut.nous report from Washington, Commissioner Joseph B. Burns said that it would be thoroughly scrutinized before we determine to give up a single inch of a rail freight line. He added: The current energy crisis makes the need to preserve our existing rail ?? even more demanding.

title: Nixon and Congress Are Scored By Connally Over Leadership
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 3 (UPI)  Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally said today that neither President Nixon nor Congress was providing the nation with the type of leadership the American people wanted.

title: ARABS HIJACK JET, FREE 102, BURN IT
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 3Two gunmen who identified themselves as members of an Arab youth organization hijacked a British Airways jetliner with 102 persons aboard aboard today, forced it to land outside Amsterdam and then set it afire after allowing all the passengers and crew members to flee.

title: Democrats Seek an Upset in Congressional Election in California Tomorrow
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 3  Telephones have been ringing in private homes along the coast and on farmlands in California's 13th Congressional District, in shakeroofed ranch homes in wealthy Santa Barbara suburbs and sunbaked field huts on the edge of Ventura's avocado farms.

title: Police in Indianapolis Accused of Graft and Other Wrongdoing in 6Month Inquiry by Paper
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 3Shortly after announcing his candidacy for the Senate Republican nomination, Mayor Richard G. Lugar finds his city's high repute marred by allegations of widespread corruption in the city's police department.

title: BURNS IS PARK TO YIELD RALLY
description: Last Tuesday, Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testified before the SenateHouse Joint Economic Committee and pointedly addressed himself to the matter of inflation. His remarks sparked what several money market participants called a yield rally. The rally continued through the close of trading last Friday, with Government issues particularly reflecting its course. Prices were marked down; yields or rates edged ahead.

title: Newcombe Beats Smith In JohnStan Net Show
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 3John Newcombe's powerful service Overcame some impressive reflexes flashed by Stan Smith today in a 62, 46, 64 victory on a chilly, windy and occasionally rainy court at LaCoste Hotel and Spa.

title: Personal Finance
description: Carrental companies all over the country are trying to convince local municipalities to collect parking fines from the customers who rented the cars so that the companies themselves will not be faced with fines, now running into millions of dollars every year.

title: Bridge: Underleading an Ace Proves Disastrous Most of Time
description: Good players on opening lead against a suit contract hardly ever underlead aces. And when they do take such a risky action the ensuing disasters probably outnumber, the occasional brilliant successes. One problem is that the underleader frequently deceives his unfortunate partner, as on the diagramed deal from a recent Canadian tournament. It was reported by Frank Vine of Hamilton, Ont.

title: Gros Take's Slalom, Gets Cup Lead
description: VOSS, Norway, March 3 (AP)  Piero Gros of Italy moved into the lead in the overall World Cup ski standings today by winning a special slalom race.

title: Anthony Petrocelli Dies at 78; Founded Men's Clothing Firm
description: Anthony Petrocelli, founder and designer of Petrocelli Clothes, who was credited with introducing Roman styling in men's apparel, died Saturday at Lone Island JewishHillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park. He was 78 years old and lived in Westbury, L.I.

title: Marco Polo Is Best of Pekingese
description: Norman Cacciatore, a real estate appraiser for the Highway State Department of Alabama, can appraise specialty shows as well as land.

title: F.B.I. CHECKS THREAT MADE TO GOVERNORS
description: BOSTON, March 3 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today it was handling reports of letters sent to five New England Governors by the kidnappers of Patricia Hearst, the newspaper heiress.

title: Armed Rightists Patrol Argentine City
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, March 3As the sun sets and the midsummer heat dissipates under a breeze from the nearby Jeep stationwagon drives up to the intersection of Avenida Colon and General Paz.

title: LEVITT CHALLENGES A $66MILLION LEASE
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt has questioned a state plan to lease office space in a proposed hotel complex that would face the new Albany Mall, when for the same price, according to Mr. Levitt, the state could own the building.

title: Bapkers Optimistic On Money Markets
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Leading American bankers are now confident that the world's money markets will be able to handle without excessive strain, for this year and probably longer, the 350billion financial burden resulting from the huge increase in the price of oil.

title: Western Europe Falters
description: PARIS, March 3A plague of political troubles has swept the European democracies, leaving most governments weakened and some countries without effective government at all. A few months after the Common Market's nine members pledged to speak with a single voice and develop a harmonious European identity, Britain, Italy and Belgium are without governments and without much prospect of achieving the solid political consent needed to make representative democracy work effectively.

title: SABATO V. SORDILLO, NEUROSURGEON, DIES
description: Dr. Sabato Vincent Sordillo, chief neurosurgeon of the Catholic Medical Center of Queens, died Wednesday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 66 Malba Drive, Malba, Queens.

title: Theater: Musical Sextet at the Bijou

description: If you don't know what B.O.A.C. stands for, then over 30 years of the British Overseas Airways Corporation advertising hasn't paid off. But at the headquarters of the Governmentowned carrier here they're betting that you do so they'll be taking a lot of pains to also let you know that they're changing the name on April 1.

title: Many Workers Still Face Health Peril Despite Law
description: The recent discovery of fatal liver cancer among vinyl chloride workers has focused renewed attention of government, labor, industry and medicine on the thousands of known, suspected and as yet unsuspected health hazards that face 60 million working Americans.

description: The stock ticker goes tick, tick, tick. The tensions mount. The big deals roll in. And then it is lunch time, and many jittery Wall Street executives eat a stale hero sandwich at their desks because, as everyone on Wall Street knows, Time is Money.

No penalties were assessed against the 26yearold infielder, who grinned sheepishly and explained: No visa. He played 60 games in Caribbean winter ball and arrived in midJune shape . . Only three other Mets played ball in the islands this winter: Felix Milian, Craig Swan and Bob Apodaca . . . Another, George Theodore, played in Venezuela for a month to test his dislocated hip. Except for one appearance as a pinchhitter in September, he hadn't played since July 7, when he collided with Don Hahn in the outfield in the most spectacular of the Mets' many injuries in their strange summer.

description: Charles F. Pukhafer, who retired in 1950 as a vice president of what is now the Chase Manhattan Bank, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 2 Uxbridge Road in Scarsdale, N.Y.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court is expected to decide this week, possibly tomorrow, what to do with a sealed report handed down to him on Friday by one of the Watergate grand juries, wellplaced sources said today.

description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 3 (UPI)Turkish airline sources said tonight that five passengers on the Turkish Airlines plane that crashed north of Paris might have been guerrillas carrying bombs that exploded in flight.

description: The Rev. James A. McNamara, since 1966 pastor of Mary Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church, 1395 East 56th Street, Brooklyn, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

title: Hearst Extortion Case
description: SAN DIEGO, March 3 (UPI) Samuel Lee McGraw, 24 years old, was in custody today, suspected of trying to extort $10,000 from the Randolph A. Hearst family, thee Federal Bureau of Investigation, said. He was arrested in his downtown area hotel room yesterday.

title: MARION MEYER DREW
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 3 (AP)Marion Meyer Drew, an astrologer who wrote a column on astrology for the old New York World and later for The. New York Daily News from 1943 to 1949, died today in Vassar Brothers Hospital. She was 84 years old.

description: INTELLECTUAL SKYWRITING, Literary Politics and The New York Review of Books. By Philip Nobile. 312 pages. Charterhouse. $7.96.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court is expected to decide this week, possibly tomorrow, what to do with a sealed report handed down to him on Friday by one of the Watergate grand juries, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Pad, Pencil And Pacers Beat Nets
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 3 A legal pad and a pencil in the hands of Freddie Lewis were the modest tools today with which the Indiana Pacers took away a 20point halftime lead from the New York Nets and then leapfrogged over them to win by nearly the same margin, 12099.

description: PARIS, March 3  A Turkish jumbo jet plunged into a forest 26 miles northeast of here today, killing all 345 persons aboard. It was the worst air disaster in history.
