description: HOWARD CITY, Mich., March 3 (AP)The former Mayor of Cadillac, his wife and two grandchildren were killed today when their singleengine plane crashed near here. The victims were identified as Ronald Wilson, 55 years old; his wife, Joyce; 52, and two grandchildren, aged 9 and 5, sons of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Harcourt, also of Cadillac.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3The men driven from power by the Watergate scandal are generally having as little success as President Nixon in putting the past behind them.

title: SSC&B Agency Expertise Is Dixie's Cap of Tea
description: It should come as no surprise that SSC&B, with all of the cup expertise it has acquired with Lipton's tea and Cup a Soup, had, no trouble beating out 14 other agencies and landing the Dixie cup account. description: CAIRO, March 3Egypt has proposed that the oil ministers of Arab oilprothicing countries meet in Tripoli, Libya next Sunday to consider, among other things, the easing of their nil embargo, against the United States.

description: Andr Watts, who is younger than 30, approaches the keyboard with an elegant gravity, suggesting that his mastery is already a foregone conclusion. and it is clear that a broad and enthusiastic public has accepted him at that value: Avery Fisher Hall, was filled for his recital yesterday afternoon, and the stage was overflowing, too.

title: Woman Wins in a Walk
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 3  The first woman to compete in an I.C. 4A track and field championship turned up a winner today when her two top male rivals were disqualified for form violations in the last 50 yards.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EARLY PASSION J. S. Bach was a deadline composer who turned out music with the speed of a Tin Pan Alley man at work in the Brill Building. For a while he wrote a new cantata for every Sunday. Back in 1723, he did a rush job on the Passion According to St. John, because he expected to be appointed cantor of St. Thomas in Leipzig. The appointment was delayed, and so was the Passion, which was first performed in Leipzig on Good Friday, April 7, 1724.

title: Cameroon Keepsakes, Once Link To Past, Now a Lure for Greedy
description: BAMENDA, CameroonIt is near the end of the dry season in Cameroon. The leaves wear gloves of dust. The, sky is heavy with Harmattan the vast, annual dust storm that sweeps in from the Sahara across all of West, Africa. People are drying fresh mudblocks for the spring rains.

title: Patinka Kopec Wed To Dr. Jay Selman
description: The Lincoln Square Synagogue was the setting here at noon yesterday for the marriage of Miss Patinka Kopec, violist and violinist, to Dr. Jay Edward Selman, an interne in pediatrics at Jacobi HospitalAlbert Einstein College of Medicine Hospital, the Bronx.

title: The Profit System and America's Growth
description: WARREN, MichAs a nation we have launched ourselves on a most ambitious social agenda. We want to achieve even higher standards of education, health, and wellbeing for all our people. We want to abolish poverty. We want to rebuild our cities. We want to preserve and restore the beauty of our great resources; our land, our waters, and our skies. We want to give every Americanof whatever color, religion, Or backgroundan equal opportunity to become all he is capable of becoming. We aim for full employment, and even morethe full opportunity for everyone to participate in all that America has to offer.

title: A Quote That Never Was
description: WASHINGTON  Something struck me as fishy about the central count of the Watergate indictment, the perjury charge intended to link the President with the coverup conspiracy.

description: Federal legislation requiring a nationwide 55 mileanhour speed limit took effect today and an Associated Press survey showed that the states had complied with the law.

title: About New York Mayors Change, but the Show Goes On
description: The three Jet linemen each looked 8 feet tall, and the man in back of them was only 5 feet 2. Let's say hello to Broadway Abe, the three Jets sang, and the man in back stuck out his head, and in a voice somewhere between a cry and a chant, sang, That's Broadway and Chambers. The old trouper from the University Settlement House had struck again, and somewhere in the balcony Mary Beame was feeling better.

title: Retrogression in Spain
description: The revival of executions with political overtones in Spain and the evident decision to exile a Roman Catholic bishop for advocating greater freedom for Basques are actions of a nervous, uncertain Government. Generalissimo Franco has accepted a dubious argument in believing that the death by garroting of a young anarchist accused of killing a policeman will deter the growing political protest against repression and brutality.

title: Red Smith
description: Secretariat, the most publicized lover since Casanova or, anyway, Joe Namath, has a date this week with a bit of fluff who has been looking forward to the occasion since Nov. 6. That autumn day, when the big red colt was to make his race track valedictory with a ceremonious appearance at Aqueduct, his mail included a postcard signed Fiji. It read: I can't wait.

description: Byron Janis attributes it to extrasensory perception, In 1967 the pianist played a hunch that led him to two lost Chopin manuscripts in France, the waltzes Op. 18 and Op. 70, No. 1. About a year ago, he discovered different versions of the same two waltzes, also in the composer's hand and hitherto unknown to musicologists, at Yale University. Mr. Janis performed both the Yale manuscripts for the first time in New York yesterday afternoon at his Carnegie Hall recital.

description: ALBANY, March 3Like touts watching the morning line, politicians are following with interest the progress of a race track bill that would create a new source of revenue for financing new tracks.

description: Rases of $14,000 a year for the members Writhe city's Board of Estimate have been held up pending review by the Federal Colt of Living Council.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HAROLD A. NEHRBAS
description: Harold A. Nehrbas, who retired a partner in Parrish & Co. stockbrokers, in 1970, died Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 81 years old and formerly lived in Huntington, L.I.

title: Chaotic Culture
description: Cultural affairs in the Beame administration promise to be an oddly mixed bag. On the same day that City Hall announced a badly needed study of the city's cultural policies, it also made an appointment of a Commissioner of Cultural Affairs that has appalled the cultural community.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 5, 1974

title: NEWS INDEX
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Richardson and Magruder Reported Writing Books
description: Elliot L. Richardson has begun work on a book about the Watergate scandals and other national topics, and there were unconfirmed reports yesterday that Jeb Stuart Magruder had contracted to write an auto biographical book dealing largely with Watergate.

title: Contract Awards
description: AlsthomSogerca, the nuclear engineering branch of Compagnie Gneral d'Electricit (C.G.E.), said yesterday, it had received an order from Electricit de France, the state power company, to build two 995,000kilowtt nuclear power reactors. A preliminary agreement between the two was announced last December covering eight reactors using the General Electric Companys b'oilingwater reactors Total value of the contract is $700million.

title: Grace Unit Plans Rise in Packaging Film Prices
description: The Cryovac division of W. R. Grace & Co., announced yesterday that it would increase its price by a range of 15 per cent to 20 per cent for all laminated packaging films for meat, cheese and other products, beginning April 1. Prices for certain groundbeef packaging films will be increased by 8 per cent.

title: MRS. MEIR SHIFTS STAND AND AGREES TO FORM COALITION
description: JERUSALEM, March 4Premier Golda Meir reversed herself today and agreedunder pressure from her Labor party colleaguesto try to form a new coalition cabinet in the next 48 hours. Premier Golda Meir reversed herself today and agreedunder pressure from her Labor party colleaguesto try to form a new coalition cabinet in the next 48 hours.

title: No Sounds of Basketball Fixes Today, Says Hero of '51 Scandal
description: A third major college basketball fixing scandal is not likely, according to Junius Kellogg, the courageous player who exposed the first big betting coup in the sport 23 years ago. Kellogg said yesterday, You would pick it up in the streets if there was anything going to happen. And, I haven't heard.

title: Other Energy News
description: Additional articles on energy appear on Page 35 and in Business/Finance, starting on Page 43.

title: SUPER CARRIERS MAY BE DOOMED
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  If Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has his way, the Navy is building the last of the billiondollar aircraft carriers that have become the pride of the fleet.

title: Foreign Bank Venture Set
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 (UPI)  The Bank of America has agreed with British and French shareholders in its Jointventure, merchant  banking houses in London and Paris to consolidate the enterprises in a new Luxembourg corporation to be called Bank of America International, S.A. PierrePaul Schweitzer will be chairman of, the new company.

title: HEARING BY SIRICA ON JURY'S REPORT IS SET TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Chief Judge John J. Sirica today set a hearing for Wednesday to hear arguments by all interested counsel on what is to be done with a sealed grand jury report believed to bear on President Nixon's possible role in the Watergate coverup. Chief Judge John J. Sirica today set a hearing for Wednesday to hear arguments by all interested counsel on what is to be done with a sealed grand jury report believed to bear on President Nixon's possible role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Gold Panning Title Won
description: ROSAMOND, Calif., March (UPI)  A northern Nevada housewife panned eight shiny gold nuggets in 19.6 seconds and won the woman's gold panning title yesterday. The winner was Mrs. Marie Bertles, of Fallon, Nev.

title: MEXICO'S TOP PARTY MARKS ANNIVERSARY
description: MEXICO CITY, March 4 (AP)Mexico's major political force, the Institutional Revolutionary party, celebrated its 45th anniversary today with a membership of more than 6 million.

title: SEWERSYSTEM FOE NOW WITHOUT WATER
description: HACKETTSTOWN, March 4  Mrs. Anne Soudrs, the 56yearold widow who has been jailed twice for her refusal to connect to the local sewer system here, had her water supply shut off today. She thus faces possible eviction for lack of sanitary facilities, if the local health board so rules.

title: Kissinger and Europe
description: PARIS, March 4  Secretary of State Kissinger met with Europe's senior diplomats in Brussels today for a second time,, gesture to show that he has accepted longstanding complaints about America's failure to consult with Europe in the last five turbulent years, The first time Mr. Kissinger made a formal trip to the capital of the European Community was last December, for the annual meeting of the North Atlantie Treaty Organization.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Hearing on Proposed Landmarks Slated

title: Dave Anderson
description: At the start of the Seattle Supersonics' season, the fine for a player arriving late at a team function, such as a practice or a bus departure, was $1 a minute, a standard levy for many pro basketball teams. But soon, Bill Russell, the new general manager and coach, realized that a few players were casually ignoring the virtue of promptness. He increased the fine to $100 a minute. The previous offenders no longer are casual.

title: Yanks Put Pressure On Clarke
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4Horace Clarke succeeded Bobby Richardson as the Yankees' second baseman in 1967, and some people have wanted the Yankees to find someone to replace Clarke ever since. This year, one trade rumor has it, the replacement will be Dave Nelson. Or, according to another report, it could be Steve Braun.

title: New U.S. Envoy in Soviet Signals Diplomatic Change
description: MOSCOW, March 4President Nixon assured the Soviet leadership today that nothing Was more important this year than a new agreement with Moscow to limit the arms race and pledged to spare no effort to achieve that objective.

title: Huge Toll Reported in Niger
description: OSLO, Norway, March 4 (Reuters)More than a quarter of the four million people of Niger are dying of starvation, a Norwegian Red Cross official said today.

title: Spanish Students Riot in Two Cities
description: MADRID, March 4University students clashed with the police in Madrid and Barcelona today after demonstrating against the execution of a young Catalonian anarchist.

title: 17Acre Holy Land in Waterbury Nearly Finished
description: WATERBURY, Conn., March 4The first thing to build, John Greco thought 18 years ago, was the city of Bethlehem as it appeared in Biblical times. From there he could progress through the Old and New Testaments, creating out of cement and stone and bits of junk a 17acre religious theme park here on a windswept hilltop overlooking the industrial Naugatuck Valley.

title: Harassed School Officials Feel Authority Is Waning
description: The American school superintendent, long the benevolent ruler whose word was law, has become a harried, embattled figure of waning authority for whom the ledger book has grown as vital as the textbook.

title: Milwaukee Journal Honored
description: DENVER, March 4 (UPI) The Milwaukee Journal was named today as winner of the William Allen White Foundation's 1974 editorial excellence citation. The paper's editorials during 1973 were judged by the Inland Daily Press Association as those best exemplifying the standards of the late editor.

title: On the Unmaking of Presidents
description: WASHINGTONThere has been great deal of confusion about how we are going to celebrate our upcoming bicentennial year. All of this could have been avoided if only the House Judiciary Committee staff report on Constitutional Grounds for Presidential Impeachment could have been written at the same time as the Constitution. There would be no confusion at all today, because there would he no bicentennial.

title: Formal Bankruptcy Action Is Filed by Mangel Stores
description: The Mangel Stores Corporation, which operates Shoppers Fair discount stores and Mangel apparel shops, formally filed a petition yesterday for an arrangement under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: People and Business
description: Michel C. Bergerac, president of ITT Europe, Inc., has been named a corporate executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the company, announced yesterday.

title: John L. Gets Ring Name By Accident
description: The name, actually, was a complete accident, said John L. Sullivan, the middleweight from Olympia, Wash. and the second man in 78 years to take that name into the ring. My father named me John and my sister named me Lee. It wasn't until later that they realized what they had done.

title: Rate Freeze Ends For Car Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) The Cost of Living Council today ended its freeze on auto insurance rates, apparently taking the view that rates will increase despite a reduction in traffic accidents because of the gasoline shortage.

title: C. J. BURCKHARDT, HISTORIAN, 82, DIES
description: GENEVA, March 4Dr. Carl J. Burckhardt, Swiss diplomat, historian and author, died last night in a hospital here at the age of 82.

title: Soviet Truck Project Spurs U.S. Business
description: The Kama River truck plant, biggest Soviet industrial project of the current detente era, has begun to have a tangible effect on economic life in the United States by providing sizable portions of the business of some American companies.

title: Haldeman Says He Did Nothing Illegal or Improper
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4 (UPI)H.R. Haldeman declared himself not guilty in the Watergate scandals today but said it Was obvious some things were wrong.

title: The Too Final Penalty
description: In approving the Administration's bill to restore the death penalty, the Senate Judiciary Committee has succumbed to President Nixon's appeal thus to attack crime without pity. The Supreme Court argues on the contrary, that the death penalty constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment.

title: MilkProduct Imports Set
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) lamation today permitting importation of an additional 150 million pounds of nonfat dry milk products before next June 30.

title: HOUSING WEIGHED AT MORGAN ESTATE
description: ASHAROKEN. L. I. March 4Residents of this tiny village overlooking Long Island Sound just above Northport met tonight to consider a proposal that could double the community's population and alter the local ecology. The meeting adjourned without voting any recommendation.

title: Republicans in House Say Conspiracy Could Justify an Impeachment Drive
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Several senior Republican members of the House Judicialary Committee, who have taken the position that a President may be impeached only for serious violations of criminal laws, said today that they would regard conspiring to obstruct justice as such a serious violation.

title: Defenders Advance In National Curling
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y. March 4 (AP)  Massachusetts, the defending champion, got off to a weak start today in the first round of the United States curling championships, edging Connecticut, 109, in an extra end.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Europe's Nine Offer Arabs A Broad Cooperation Plan
description: BRUSSELS, March 4The nine European Common Market countries made a joint offer of longterm economic, technical and cultural cooperation to the Arab world today.

title: LETTER SOFTENED BY SOLZEHNITISYN
description: PARIS, March 4Examination of Aleksandr I. Solzenistyn's 13,000word letter to the Soviet leadership shows that he deleted and softened some denunciations of Western democracy between the time he wrote it last September and the time he published it this weekend.

title: JOHN C. PHILLIPS
description: POALI, Pa., March 4  John C. Phillips, vice president in charge of corporate planning for Ina Corporation, a holding company for insurance and real estate, died Saturday in Paoli Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: JAEWORSKI OPPOSES NEW PLEA FOR HUNT
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)Special Watergate prosecutor Leon Jaworski asserted today that E. Howard Hunt Jr. could neither prove nor justify his role in the Watergate breakin on grounds of national security.

title: GENTILITY STRESSED BY LAURS ON CELLO
description: There is an unassuming gentility in the playing of Janis Laurs, a young Australian cellist (of Latvian descent), that helped parts of his debut program Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall but hindered others.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO the Editor:

title: Judger Scores in Florida
$117MILLIO PAID FOR SHALE TRACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)The Interior Department announced today that it had accepted a $117.5million bid from a consortium headed by the Atlantic Richfield Company to mine oil shale in western Colorado.

title: Manila Assures Foreign Press That Freedom Is Unimpeded
description: MANILA, March 4 (AP) The Government declared today that international news agencies and, foreign newsmen shall have unimpeded freedom in working in the Philippines.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
About the Yankees:
description: Celerino Sanchez, the other Yankee holdout, is on his way to camp, according to Tal Smith, the executive vice president.... Sam McDowell has been hospitalized while recuperating from a flu attack and an upper respiratory infection. The pitcher said his fever had broken and he was much improved. He hopes to be out of the hospital in a day or two.... Mickey Mantle, special instructor, arrived and immediately went to work helping Bill Virdon in the manager's outfield drills. That's the best outfield workout I've ever seen, said Mantle.... Whitey Ford, pitching instructor, planned to do a lot of homework and draw his plans for the first few exhibition games, which begin Friday. His problems are compounded by two B games scheduled this weekend.

title: No Article
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: PARLEYS IN ITALY ON PREMIER OPEN
description: ROME, March 4President Gibvanni Leone began formal consultations with political leaders today before designating a Premier for Italy's next Cabinet.

title: 100,000 Deaths in Africa Linked to Drought Neglect
description: WASHINGTON, March 4A newly published study of relief efforts by the United States Government and international agencies for the victims of last year's drought in West Africa has charged that gross neglect and outright failures contributed to the deaths of more than 100,000 people.

title: Business Briefs
description: HelpWanted Index Off for 3d Month

description: ACROSS

title: Rivals See Green After Her Victory
description: The jokes came first, then the skepticism. Now, having established her credentials as a firstclass athlete, Ellen Minkow finds male jealousy has joined the wolves' whistles.

title: Market Finishes Mixed As the Dow Climbs 1.26
description: Political uncertainties abroad caused the stock market to finish mixed yesterday as many investors stayed on the sidelines, in the slowest trading in two weeks.

title: State Views Oil Port Plan As Bringing New Pollution
description: TRENTON, March 4  The Byrne administration warned today that a state operated degpwater oil port off New Jersey would add to pollution and overindustrialization without easing the state's fuel shortage or adding any significant tax revenues to the state treasury.

title: They Recognize Jewelry and Call Out, Mahie
description: Joyce Susskind wears it*because she hates being a slave to jewelrythe kind your insurance company insists you keep in a bank vault, that is.

title: Filion Keeps Winning as Yonkers Opens
description: YONKERS, March 4Perhaps it was the impact of Yonkers Raceway's opening night that moved Herve Filion to dispense some French  Canadian philosophy tonight:

title: SIMON ASKS CURBS ON TAXFREE FUEL
description: Facing a threatened lawsuit from Pan American World Airways, the Federal Energy Office moved yesterday to place imported, dutyfree jet fuel used by international airlines under Federal price and allocation controls for the first time.

title: Year Later: Supermarket Prices Up 28.7%
description: WHIPPANY, N. J.  Last March, food prices in one survey showed an increase of more than 21 per cent in 18 months, and shoppers around the country were angered, bitter and voluble about foodprice rises in general. The meat boycott of last April was one manifestation of that anger, directed then at supermarkets.

title: GEORGE E. BLAIR
description: George Edward Blair, who retired in 1955 as a national advertising salesman for The New York Times after 23 years of service, died at his home Friday at Eastbourne, England. He was 76 years old and had lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Soviet Writer Berates Officials on Solzhenitsyn Exile
description: MOSCOW, March 4Roy A. Medvedev, the dissident Marxist historian, declared today that the forced exile of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn represented a moral defeat for those in power who were neither willing nor able to answer his accusation about Soviet repressions and who did not dare to put him on trial, even in secret.

title: Market Place: Market Refuses To Tip Its Hand
description: There's a theory on Wall Street that the stock market often shows its hand in January. If the popular averages turn up, that has been taken as a good sign over the last quartercentury that stock prices will finish higher for the year. If the averages tumble, that is regarded as a bad omen.

title: U.S. Safety Agency Will. Set Standards For Television Sets
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) The United States Consumes Product Safety Commission an nounced today that it plannec to develop mandatory safety standards for television sets which are suspected of causing hundreds of house fires with many injuries and deaths each year.

title: Mideast Jitters
description: Neither the nervousness of the Israeli leadership nor the jockeying for influence by various Arab governments can obscure the essential point that the belligerents in the Middle East are moving, step by step, toward the brink of a political settlement that no one would have thought possible just a few months ago.

title: Woes Loom In Economy Of Finland
description: HELSNKI, Finland, Feb. 25Few Finns seem to be aware of it in their happy pursuits of consumer goods in the crowded and richly stocked stores, but their country is caught in an economic squeeze that has caused its leaders to recall the dire days, of the late forties and early fifties.

title: HOME SALES GAINAFTER RATES RISE
description: TRENTON, March 4Stath Banking Commissioner Richard F. Schaub told the Assembly Banking and Insurance Committee today that New Jersey'shigher 8 per cent home mortgage rate had revitalized the sagging real estate market.

title: PrimeTime Programing Is a Show in Itself
description: At 8 o'clock tonight, barring catastrophe, 45million of the 66.2million households in the continental United States that enjoy the blessing of television (only 2.1million do not) will be watching it.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Spanish Students Riot in Two Cities
description: MADRID, March 4University students clashed with the police in Madrid and Barcelona today after demonstrating against the execution of a young Catalonian anarchist.

title: Beame Swears in 2 Aides
description: John J. Walsh was sworn in yesterday as a $34,024ayear member of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals. At a City Hall ceremony, Mayor Beame also swore in Aldo R. Benedetto as director of the Office of Staten Island Development, a $32,726 post. Both appointments had been announced earlier.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We have received from a friend, Carl Sontheimer of Greenwich, Conn., a fascinating extract from an old manual called La Cuisine Pratique, published by the Cordon Bleu in Paris in 1903.

title: Pound Eases in Money Transactions
description: LONDON, March 4  The British pound weakened sharply against the United States dollar this morning and then rebounded in the afternoon to close with fractional losses as the financial community awaited a resolution of Britain's political deadlock.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The New York Rangers hockey club will offer a limited number of mezzanine tickets for the Stanley Cupplayoffs at Madison Square Garden. They will be offered in strips of two seats for each of five home games for $57.50 per pair.

title: Muskie Impeachment View
description: NORMAL, Ill., March 4 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, says a President can be impeached for political wrongdoing. Speaking last night at Illinois State University, Mr. Muskie said the act of impeachment gives the people the right to remove the President for a great political offense.

title: International Harvester Deal
description: CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) The International Harvester Company announced today it had signed an $8.5million contract with Traktor export Moscow for the sale of 39 pay loaders, part and attachments to the Soviet Union.

title: MAILORDER HOUSES ARE TARGET OF F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion said today that two large mailorder houses, Montgomery Ward and Spiegel, may have treated their customers unfairly by suing for unpaid bills it courts sometimes situated up to 1,000 miles from where the cus. tomers lived.

title: New Book Bridges Gap in Black History
description: The outsized book resembles a scrapbook, but one, according to Bill Cosby's introduction, that would have been put together by a 300yearold black man who had decided, oh, say when he was about 10, to keep a scrapbooka record of what it was like for himself in these United States.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Ranger Playoff Tickets Available

title: Opposition Seems Victor in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, March. 4  A general representing the opposition appears to have scored a clear victory over two other military candidates in Guatemala's presidential election yesterday, but the Government has so far refused to concede defeat publicly.

title: People in Sports
description: Before retiring from boxing to spread the faith of Islam, Muhammad All wants a final fight against George Foreman, the heavyweight champion.

title: Gourt Bars War Objector From Benefits of G.I. Bill
description: WHINGTON, March. 4A conscientious objector who chase two years of civilian serylbe rather than be drafted into the armed forces is not eligible for veterans' educational benefits, the Supremen Court ruled today.

title: A Report Says New Laws Are Needed To Cover Colleges' Labor Negotiations
description: DENVER, March 4Predicting coatinued heavy growth in the unionization of college faculties, the umbrella education agency for the states warns in a new report that unless laws are written quickly to cover the special nature of collective bargaining on the campus, the very roots of higher education may be brutally ?? up.

title: High Court Backs CableTV Systems in 2 Fee Cases
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 The Supreme Court handed, down two decisions today that were likely to save operators of cabletelevision systems substantial amounts of money.

title: Advertising: How Money Works
description: The curse of wealth is a very real thing. Why, even having a discretionary income is full of problems.

title: Paris Critics Hail Malle's Chefd'Oeuvre
description: PARIS, Feb. 27Local film critics who have seldom been tempted of late to apply the term of masterpiece to a French movie, are nearly unanimous in their description of La combe, Lucien as a chefd'oeuvre. Louis Malle's new film tells the story of a more than ordinarily obtuse peasant boy in Nazioccupied France. Because he is sick of his job in an old peoples' home, because his father is a war prisoner and his mother has taken up with the landlord, because he has a certain juvenile penchant for violence, because a Resistance member turns him down and he has a flat tire while bicycling back tb town, Lacombe lands up in the German police, swaggering, torturing, killing.

title: 100,000 Deaths in Africa Linked to Drought Neglect
description: WASHINGTON, March 4A newly published study of relief efforts by the United States Government and international agencies for the victims of last year's drought in West Africa has charged that gross neglect and outright failures contributed to the deaths of more than 100,000 people.

title: Rail Labor Terms U.S. Plan Useless
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Railroad labor regards the Department of Transportation's recent proposals for restructuring the Penn Central and six other major bankrupt railroads in the Northeast and Midwest as useless.

title: Books of The Times
description: PROM REVERENCE TO RAPE: The Treatment of Women in the Movies. By Molly Haskell. 388 pages. Illustrated. Halt, Rinehart and Winston. $10.

title: Police Decline to Link Murders Of 2 Girls Who Were Strangled
description: TOMS RIVER, March 4The police declined to say today whether they were searching for a link between the murder of 18yearold Cynthia Leslie, whose body was found here yesterday in a wooded area just a few blocks from the central business district, and the still unsolved slaying of 14  year  old Suzanne Garden five weeks ago.

title: First Black School, 6 Others Gain N.I.T.
description: Maryland Eastern Shore, snubbed by the National Collegiate Athletic Assocaition and a comparative basketball unknown despite the best wonlost record in the nation (261), was one of seven teams selected yesterday to the National Invitation Tournament. Formerly known as Maryland State, and noted as a track and football power, Maryland Eastern Shore is the first predorqinately black college to be chosen in the 37year history of the N.I.T.

title: Trial of Nixon's Doctor On Tax Charges Starts
description: Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, osteopathic physician to President Nixon, former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, went on trial in Federal Court here yesterday on income tax evasion charges.

title: Highs and Lows New York Stock Exchange
description: NEW HIGHS6

title: About the Knicks:
description: Willis Reed, hoping to return to the lineup in week; worked out yesterday with the team at Pace. He continued to confine himself to running exercises and a bit of shooting.... Tom Riker and Dick Barnett, the assistant coach, missed the drill because of flu. Danny Whelan, the trainer, ran the practice in Barnett's place.

title: Harassed School Officials Feel Authority Is Waning
Bucks, Fatigued, Turn Back Kings
description: MILWAUKEE, March 4 (UPI)The Milwaukee Bucks, weary after playing six games in six days, had all they could handle tonight in a 109103 victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings in the National Basketball Association.

title: HEARST CAPTORS STILL ARE SILENT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 There was no response today to a plea by Patricia Hearst's parents that the kidnapped girl be permitted to write to her family, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent said.

title: Gross Trial Told $44,000 For Cahill Was Disguised
description: NEWARK, March 4  A publicrelations specialist said in Federal Court here today that more than $44,000 in political contributions was funneled through her company to finance the successful gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill in 1969.

title: KISSINGER IS BACK FROM THE MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Secretary of State Kissinger returned tonight from an eightday trip to the Middle East and Europe, refusing to predict whether his diplomatic efforts would lead to a lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
CocaCola Sales and Net Are at Record for Year and 4th Quarter
Business Records
description: Chapter XI petition for an arraoement by: MANGEL STORES CORPORATION, doing business as Shoppers Fair, Mangels and Polly Perrey, operates a chain for ladles, apparel shops and discount department stores, at 115 W. 18th St., N.Y. Business organized in Delaware. Signed by Joseph H. Lamm, president. Liabilities $28,867,000, assets $50,370,000. In statement of affairs the payroll alone amounts to $1,700,000. The debtor has a business of approximately $126,000,000 and employs 3,500. An equity of machinery and equipment approximately $7.257,000. Accounts receivable $9,501,000 and an Inventory of $21,343,000.
