title: Mitchell Mistrial Denied; Lawyers Start on Defense
description: A defense motion for a mistrial was denied yesterday in Federal District. Court here, and then lawyers for John W. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans made opening statements in Which they depicted the two as men of high character who had devoted their lives to public service.

title: AnchovyFishing Ban Ends Today in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, March 4 (UPI) The Peruvian Government will lift tomorrow its yearlong ban on anchovy fishing.

title: Armored Car Is Stolen
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 4 (Reuters)An armored car, believed to contain as much as $500,000, was stolen here today as it was left unattended in front of a local bank, the police said.

title: EDWARD L. ROSENBAUM
description: NEWARK, March 4Edward L. Rosenbaum, a former director lof the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, who retired last year as head of RosenbaumSchwartz Associates, a company agency at 680 Fifth Avenue, New York, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. His age was 68 and he lived in Palm Beach.

title: Text of the Proposal by the Europeans
description: BRUSSELS, March 4Following, in an unofficial translation from the French, is the text of a proposal issued to day by the Common Marfeet countries on cooperation with the Arab nations.

title: Impeachment Doubted By a Top Nixon Aide
description: DETROIT, March 4 (AR)The top woman in the Nixon Administration said today the President would not be impeached and will regain, inch by inch, percentage point by percentage point, the confidence of the American people. The top woman in the Nixon Administration said today the President would not be impeached and will regain, inch by inch, percentage point by percentage point, the confidence of the American people.

title: About the Mets:
description: The Mets held their breath when Cleon Jones ?? a pitch off his left foot in batting practice and hit the dirt. He is still nursing a chronic case of sore feet anyway, and wears tennis shoes in camp except when he switches to baseball spikes for batting. The left fielder, soon to try becoming a center fielder, picked himself up, swung and missed at the next pitch and sighed: I'm trying. ... Yogi Berra said he might sfart Benny Ayala in the outfield Saturday against St. Louis in another experiment. The 23yearold rookie from Puerto Rico hasn't played tripleA ball yet, but will get a shot at making the varsity. ... Willie Mays, leading the search for a center fielder, was tutoring two of his pupils, Jones and Ed Kranepool, who plays first base and left field. All three were conducting the classin right field. ... Despite the vacancy in center, General Manager Bob Scheffing maintains, this is the Mets' most set team in recent years. Next: 162 games to find out how set.

title: Gov. Wilson Virtually Endorsed By Amiable State Labor Leaders
description: ALBANY, March 4Governor Wilson and leaders of organized labor in the state exchanged warm compliments today as the union leaders, in town to lobby for their legislative programs, made it clear that the Governor hardly needed to lobby for their support.

title: C.I.A.HEAD SAYS BOOK BREACHES SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)  William Colby, director of Central Intelligence, testified today that the manuscript of a book about the C.I.A. contained security breaches which are very serious indeed.

title: Summary of Actions by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: MRS. MEIR SHIFTS STAND AND AGREES TO FORM COALITION
description: JERUSALEM, March 4 Premier Golda Meir reversec herself today and agreedunder pressure from her Laboi party colleaguesto try to form a new coalition cabinet in the next 48 hours.

title: Arab Oil Output Cut May Be Vital
description: KUWAIT, March 4  If the Arab oil producers lift their embargo on the United States, as now seems possible, this move would have little effect on world oil prices unless it were accompanied by the restoration of Arab production cutbacks.

title: IT'S SPRING AGAIN OR SO IT SEEMED
description: The day began muggy and gray yesterday, but the sun broke through by 3 P.M., pushing temperatures to a record high of 70 degrees at 3:45. It was a day for shirtsleeve ice skating in Central Park and thoughts about the equinox.

title: Senate Bars 2 Compromises on Pay Rise for Congress and Federal Officials
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Senate rejected by wide margins today two attempts to compromise a proposed 22.5 per cent, threeyear pay increase for Congress, the judiciary and other top Federal officials.

title: Multinational Morals
description: The dinosaur died out, they say, because it had a peasized brain. Could the gargantuan oil corporations expire for the same reason?

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: MILLER COUNTY, Ga.Hard by meandering Spring Creek in fields that would soon be planted to peanuts or corn, we searched for signs of nomadic hunters who had been there thousands of years before the time of Christ.

title: U.S. Reviewing Past Problems of DC10
description: Federal officials began an urgent reexamination yesterday of previous troubles encountered by DC10 jumbo jets.

title: Chess: He Who Loses Should Not Hesitate to Try, Try Again
News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 5, 1974

title: ROTHKO EXECUTOR ON STAND AGAIN
description: The lawyer for the Mark Rothko Foundation yesterday joined the retinue of lawyer trying to break down the account of one of the late painter's executors that he had opposed a contract for the sale and consignment of all of Mr. Rothko's paintings to Marlborough Gallery.

title: Excerpts From Sakharov's Foreword
description: MOSCOW, March 4Following are excerpts from material written by Andrei D. Sakharov as a foreword to a forthcoming collection of his statements to be published in the United States by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. The material has circulated here, reaching Western newsmen.

title: Baby Dies as Boat Capsizes
description: MONROE, La., March 4 (AP) An excursion boat with some 35 persons aboard capsized on a canal in cityowned park yesterday, spilling the passengers into the water and drowning a baby. Most of the passengers swam ashore safely. The body of Rebecca Simmerling, 17 months old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Simmerling of Ruston, was recovered from water about five feet deep.

title: New 9Mile Bridge Spans Rio's Bay
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4 (AP)Brazil opened a $232million bridge across Rio de Janeiros Guanabara Bay today. It was described as the largest structural complex in bridgebuilding history.

title: WILLIAM GREENFIELD
description: MIAMI, March 4  William Greenfield, founder and chairman of the Federal Distributing Corporation of New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old and lived also at 40 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A suit seeking to force state and county agencies pay for special schooling for handicapped children New Jersey was filed in Mercer County Superior Court by the Education Law Center, a publicinterest educational law firm based in Newark. Paul L. Tractenberg, director of the center, said the suit represented the family of an autistic and schizophrenic boy from Berlin in Camden County and the family of a neurologically impaired highschool girl from Montclair in Essex County.

title: HEARING Y SIRICA ON JURY'S REPORT IS SET TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Chief Judge John J. Sirica today set a hearing for Wednesday to ]tear arguments by all interested counsel on what is to be done with a sealed grand jury report believed to bear on President Nixon's, possible role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Dayton Upsets Irish Five
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 4 (UPI)The Dayton Flyers, with a record home crowd of 13,528 chanting Goodby Irish, we hate to see you go in the background, upset secondranked Notre Dame, 9782, tonight.

title: Rangers Renew Drive to Tie Canadiens For 2d at Garden Tomorrow Night
description: Keep your fingers crossed, Ranger fans, tomorrow nights the night when the club just might catch the Montreal Canadiens and tie them for second place in the National Hockey League East. The two teams meet at Madison Square Garden in the first of a pair of homeandhome games; they will play again Saturday at the Forum in Montreal.

title: Erik Hillman Plays A Schumann Rarity In His Piano Debut
description: The rarity on Erik Hillman's piano recital program Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was Schumann's Bunte Bltter (Op. 99). This is a collection of 14 salon pieces composed between 1836 and 1849, and they aren't often performed these days. Sviatoslav Richter offered the complete set a few years ago, and other pianists occasionally play some of the individual pieces.

title: Montoya Is Showing He Belongs In Big Time Here as a Jockey
description: When Daryl Montoya hit the New York circuit as a jockey last fall, he was an unknown quantity to most fans here. True, he had performed creditably at Liberty Bell in Philadelphia, but his achievements there were hardly noticed by the regular patrons of the New York Racing Association tracks.

title: Mexican Wins Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4 Juan De Villafranca, a sophomore from the University of Mexico, won the national intercollegiate Class A squash racquets championship yesterday by beating Glenn Whitman of Harvard, 1511, 1614, 1614.

title: Bank Sets Singapore Unit
description: SINGAPORT, March 4 (Reuters)  The Monetary Authority of Singapore have granted the Chemical Bank permission to open an offshore branch here. The bank said the branch would deal primarily in the Asian currency and foreignexchange markets. Operations are expected to begin within three months.

title: Brooklyn Laundry Mark Is Gone After 80 Years
description: To many Brooklyn residents, the sight of the dark green Pilgrim Laundry truck was as much a part of the borough as were Ebbets Field, Ebinger's Bakery or the Rheingold Brewery. But the truck, its sides emblazoned with a portrait of a bold pilgrim poised on a rocky shore, musket in hand, is no longer seen making its rounds of neighborhood homes.

title: U.S. Steel Increases Prices By Level Less Than 5.5%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yesterday that it was increasing prices by less than 5.5 per cent on a variety of iron and steel products.

title: GASOLINE TIEUPS FADE IN CITY AREA, BUT COULD RETURN
description: For the first time in months, no lines were reported at gasoline stations in the metropolitan area yesterday. But Federal land state officials and dealers warned against overoptimism, saying the lines could recur in the middle of the month.

title: Bridge, Only 2 Metropolitan Players Rate in Top 50 for Last Year
description: A generation ago New York and Philadelphia dominated the world of American bridge. A few players from the Midwest and California were knocking at the door, but it seemed unlikely that they would be admitted to the East Coast coterie that provided America's world championship representatives.

title: Nixon Recommends Raises In Disabled Veterans' Funds
description: President Nixon recommended today a 12 per cent increase in veterans disability payments and a 14 per cent increase in payments to the dependents of disabled veterans.

title: 2,000 Here Cheer Davits And Contribute $250,000
description: About 2,000 Republicans applauded Senator Jacob K. Javits's 18 years in the Senate last night, contributed at least $250,000 to his reelection campaign and comparisonshopped four Presidential possibilities who spoke at the Javits fundraising dinner.

title: A Year Later: Prices in Supermarket 28.7% Higher
SOLVENTS SEEKS TENDERS REPORT
description: The Commercial so?? Corporation said yesterday it had engaged Georgeson & Co., a leading stockholderrelations concern, to solicit rejections of the tender offer made by Baker Industries. Georgeson will also handle distributions of company statements about the tender offer. A spokesman for Commercial Solvents said that William S. Leonhardt, president of the company, was shocked by the Beker offer. Though a director of Beker, a Commercial Solvents customer, Mr. Leonhardt reportedly had no knowledge of the tender offer and had not been invited to any Beker meetings where it was discussed. He resigned last week as a Beker director almost immediately after the tender offer became known.

title: Feeding the Fire
description: Even by the antipublic standards long characteristic of the domineering unions that represent New York City public employes, the current leadership of the Uniformed Firefighters Association is notable for its arrogance and obtuseness.

title: Southeastern Stock Exchange in Its Debut
description: MIAMI, March 4At 10 A.M., with a traditional ring of a bell, the Southeastern Stock Exchange, a division of Philadelphia's PBW stock exchange, opened for business here today.

title: Poor Arthur, Too Old to Start Over
description: WASHINGTON, March 4If you are a Republican politician, good form requires you to exhibit delirious happiness each time President Nixon says he will never quit.

title: 2 Democratic Mavericks to Vie For Right to Oppose Schweiker
description: PITTSBURGH, March 4Herbert S. Denenberg, the Pennsylvania Commissioner of Insurance, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate, setting the stage for what may become one of this state's classic primary elections.

title: CAUTION IS VOICED ON SANK REFORMS
description: Bankers were cautious yesterday in reacting to proposal, made over the weekend for extensive reform to banking institutions in New York State. In general, savings bankers seemed happier with the report  by State Superintendent Harry W. Albright Jr.than commercial bankers, particularly the smaller banks upstate. It quickly became apparent that the proposals face tough going.

title: Brown Trial Closed To Public to Protect Frightened Witness
description: Spectators and reporters were barred yesterday afternoon at the murder trial of Henry S. Brown, and the courtroom doors were locked during the testimony of an unidentified witness.

title: George Gallowhur, 69, Dies; Founder of Skol Company
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 4 George Gallowhur, who in the nineteentwenties in the Austrian Alps developed Skol suntan lotion, and later founded the Skol Company in New York, died Friday in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 69 years old and lived here and in Reading, Vt.

title: Many Medical Students Avoid Primary Health Fields
description: DALLAS, March 3Russell W.H. Kridell, the former president of the Student American Medical Association which met here this weekend, is certain he will be a doctor in another year. Exactly what kind is not clear to him.

title: BEAME HAS HOPES FOR 35CENT FARE
description: Mayor Beame held out hope yesterday that the 35cent transit fare could be saved un til the end of December, 1975, with continuing Federal subsidies, if the necessary legislation was forthcoming.

title: GROSS TRIAL HEARS OF DISGUISED $44,000
description: NEWARK, March 4A publicrelations specialist, testifying in the Federal fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross, said today that more than $44,000 in political contributions was illegally funneled through her company to finance the successful gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill in 1969.

title: Congress Holding Hearings on Largest Desalting Plant
description: Proposed measures that bear critically on the future of the Southwest and on the United States' relations with Mexico have reached the stage of Congressional hearings in Washington already being done on a limited scale by the use of a computer to avoid overirrigation of participating farms.

title: Mitchell Mistrial Denied; Lawyers Start on Defense
description: A defense motion for a mis, trial was denied, yesterday it Federal District Court here, and then lawyers for John W. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stang made opening statements in which they depicted the two as men of high character who had devoted their lives to public service.

title: Brasco's Uncle Gets Mistrial; Case Severed From Nephew's
description: A mistrial was declared for Joseph Brasco and his case was severed from that of his nephew, Representative Frank J. Brasco, in Federal Court here yesterday.

title: One Dead in Cafe Accident
description: CHELSEA, Mass., March 4 (AP)One man was killed and two were injured when part of the cement facing on a caf toppled to the sidewalk, according to the Chelsea police. Dead was Dominque Matys, 53 years old, of Chelsea.

title: FRANCIS REED DIES; CORPORATE LAWYER
description: Francis C. Reed, a specialist in corporate law and partner the law firm of Hughes, Hubbard & Reed, 1 Wall Street, died yesterday at his home in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J. His age was 70.

title: Giant Step
description: Campaign money is at the root of so many of the Nixon Administration scandalsboth the buying of Government favor with campaign contributions or their extortion on pain of disfavorthat national sentiment has swung sharply toward public financing of the election process. Congress gives increasing signs of readiness to respond to this pressure for change; the problem is how to get quick action on reforms that will prove effective, not harmful.

title: U.C.L.A. Places 2 On AllStar Five
description: U.C.L.A., the giant of college basketball, may have more trouble in its effort to repeat as the regularseason national champion, but it proved yesterday it still has a firm grip on the individual talent pool. The Bruins placed two playersBill Walton and Keith Wilkeson the 197374 United Press International allAmerica majorcollege team.

title: 2,000 Here Cheer Javits And Contribute $250,000
description: About 2,000 Republicans applauded Senator Jacob K. Jay its's 18 years in the Senate last night, contributed at least $250,000 to his reelection campaign and comparisonshopped four Presidential possibilities who spoke at the Javits fundraising dinner.

title: Rates Are Erratic in Money and Credit Markets
2 Weicker Nephews Saved In Plane Crash Fatal to 5
description: GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Colo., March 4 (UPI)Rescuers today reached the wreckage of an aircraft carrying seven persons and found two young boys alive. Five persons were killed.

title: SCHOOL UNIT BARS USING ETHNIC DATA
description: The president of a Queen school board said yesterda that his district had been informed it would not be eligibl for special Federal grants unless it provided ethnic dat about teachers and other stal members.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MOVEMENTS Dr. Benito Ortolani, who is a theater professor at City University, became a Japanesetheater buff somewhere along the line. He was thoroughly taken with the body movements the Japanese are so expert at. Tonight at 8, he will tell all about it in a lecturedemonstration at Japan House. 333 East 47th Street (8321155), relating theater movements and gestures of Kabuki and Noh to Shinto rituals and shamanism. He'll be accompanied by two performers who will illustrate the points. Admission: $1.50.

title: Finns Give Young Politicians a Vote of Confidence
description: HELSINKI, Finland,  A day after UIf Sundqvist celebrated his 27th birthday, he was sworn in as Finland's Minister of Education. Now that he has turned 29, he still considers himself a radical social Democrat in political principle but says that he has been changed by ministerial experience.

title: Adolph Gottlieb, Abstractionist, Dies
description: Adolph Gottlieb, a founder of the New York School of abstract expressionism and major figure in American art for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived and worked in studios at 380 West Broadway and in East Hampton, L.I.

title: TEACHERS REJECT BID FOR BALTIMORE PACT
description: BALTIMORE, March 4Striking Baltimore teachers defied their leadership today by rejecting a proposed settlement of their month old strike by 74 votes.

title: 2 Killed in Dayton Holdup
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 4 (AP) Two young bandits fleeing a Jewelry store holdup today shot and killed a Dayton civil rights leader and a police sergeant, the polie reported. The dead were identified as W. Sumpter McIntosh, 52 years old, and Sgt. William K. Mortimer, 43. The police said three, unidentified young men were arrested, including the suspected driver of a getaway car.

title: Chase Renames Vienna Unit
description: VIENNA, March 4  The Chase Manhattan Group today renamed its Austrian subsidiary, Oesterreichische Kommerzialbank, A.G. It will now be known as Chase Manhattan Bank (Austria), A.G. Chase owns 74.5 per cent of the bank, with the remaining 25.5 per cent controlled by Girozentrale und Bank der Oesterrelchischen Sparkassen, A.G.

title: WILSON IS PRIME MINISTER AS HEATH FAILS IN EFFORT TO WIN LIBERALS' SUPPORT
description: LONDON, March 4Edward Heath, his party defeated last week by Britain's voters, tonight gave up his effort to hold onto power, and Harold Wilson took over as Prime Minister.

title: Downing Street Resident Again
description: LONDON, March 4In 1965, when Harold Wilson had been Prime Minister for a Tear, a Mend came into, his office and congratulated him for having survived so long despite the thinness of the Labor party's fourseat majority in the House of Commons.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Bob Lester's career got off to a late start for a high school basketball player. But in just one year of varsity competition as a senior, he was a standout performer for Newark Central and later at Montclair State College.

title: Senators to Hear Buzhardt On Reported Snooping Ring
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., President Nixon's White House counsel, will testify Thursday in the Senate Armed Services Committee's investigation of alleged military spying on the White House. J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., President Nixon's White House counsel, will testify Thursday in the Senate Armed Services Committee's investigation of alleged military spying on the White House.

title: Meat Cutters Ratify Pact With CostofLiving Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP)  A threeyear contract has been overwhelmingly accepted by union meat cutters. The pact ratified yesterday by the 4,800member Amalmated Meat Cutter and Butcher Workmen provides for an 8 per cent pay rise  about $20 the first year  and four per cent rises the second and third years. Also included is a costof living hike in the last two years.

title: HARVEY STONE, 61, COMEDIAN, DEAD
description: Harvey Stone, a nightclub comedian and actor, died yesterday in his sleep on the Cunard ship Queen Elizabeth 2 in the Bahamas, according to word from the company to the Lambs Club, of which he was a longtime member. He was 61 years old And had spent much of his time in the last year as a cruise entertainer.

title: JERSEY PLANS SUIT ON ITS ALLOTMENT
description: TRENTON, March 4  New Jersey announced today that it would sue the Federal Energy Office and the major oil companies this week in an effort to what it called its equitabgele share of gasoline.

title: Ballet: Norwegian National Company
description: The Norwegian National Ballet made the first appearance in its fairly long United States tour Saturday night at the Walt Whitman Hall of Brooklyn College. As a cardcarrying Scandinavian lover, I bid it official welcome. As a simple friend of ScandinaviaI ask it why? Was this journey necessary?

title: SONG DEBUT IS MADE BY EMILY MARUOKA
description: Emily Franklin Maruoka, music teacher at Taft High School in New York, made her formal solo debut Sunday at Town Hall in a modest but appealing program of songs by Schubert, Handel and various American composers.

title: No Sounds of Basketball Fixes Today, Says Hero of 51' Scandal
description: A third major college basketball fixing scandal is not likely, according to Junius Kellogg, the courageous player who exposed the first big betting coup in the sport 23 years ago. Kellogg said yesterday, day, You would pick it up in the streets if there was anything going to happen. And I haven't heard.

title: MRS. HAROLD WILLIAMS
description: PAWLING, N. Y., March 4 Mrs. Gertrude Hassall Williams, wife of Harold Williams, who founded and headed the Lumelite Corporation here, which became a division of RichardsonMerrell, Inc., in 1963, died Saturday at her home on North Quaker Hill. She was 80 years old.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Adm. Rea to Command The Coast Guard Here
description: Rear Adm. William F. Rea 3d has been nominated by President Nixon to head the Coast Guard's Atlantic Area and Third District commands here, with the rank of vice admiral.

title: A Step Short of Impeaching
description: The muddled and dangerous political situations in Britain and Israel should be a caution to those who have been glibly promoting the idea of parliamentary government in the United States. On the other hand, the criminal indictment of four men who were once Richard Nixon's closest personal and political aidesnot to mention all the other Nixon men implicated by indictment or guilty pleas raises again the troublesome question of accountability in American Government.

title: FRANK WILCOX DIES; CHARACTER ACTOR, 66
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4 (AP) Frank Wilcox, a character actor who appeared in more than 150 movies and played such varied television roles as Mr. Brewster in the Beverly Hillbillies and Elliot Ness' boss in The Untouchables, died Sunday at his suburban home. His age was 66.

title: Fernandez Beats Seeley on Points
description: Jose Fernandez of Santo Domingo won a unanimous 10round decision over Walter Seeley of Sayville, L. I., in the feature bout at the Felt Forum last night.

title: Stage: 2 Poignant Characters in Irwin's Sea Horse
description: At the Circle Repertory Theater, quality is getting to be customary. First there was Lanford Wilson's The Hot I Baltimore, then Mark Medoff's When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder? and now James Irwin's The Sea Horse, which opened Sunday at the Circle, 2307 Broadway, at 83d Street.

title: Renewed Warnings Issued on Overuse Of Antibiotic Drugs
description: Renewed warnings against the overuse of antibiotics and the toll this practice can take on health and pocketbook  have been issued in a series of commentaries published in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: RHEINGOLD'S FATE IS UP TO 4 UNIONS
description: The board of directors of Chock Full O'Nuts authorized its chairman, William Black, yesterday to proceed with arrangements for the acquisition of Rheingold Breweries from Pepsico.

title: Handicapped Drivers Win Exemption After 3Hour Midday Traffic Jam
description: New York State's oddeven gasoline sales program ran into trouble again yesterday.

title: Europe's Nine Offer ArabsA Broad Cooperation Plan
description: BRUSSELS, March 4he nine European Common Market countries made a joint offer of longterm economic, technical and cultural cooperation to the Arab world today.

title: Hopes for Cyprus
description: Cyprus is not a habitual source of good news. The GreekTurkish clash on this Mediterranean island is rivaled only by the nearby ArabIsraeli dispute as a burial ground for peace plans that aborted, compromise formulas that lost their promise, and wouldbe peacemakers who went home in disillusionment.

title: Inactivity a Mixed Blessing for B52 Pilots in Thailand
description: U TAPHAO AIRFIELD, Thailand, March 1Boredom has apparently replaced wartime tension among the nearly 7,000 American airmen here who still lily and service the B52 bombers that were once the awesome tools of United States policy Southeast Asia.

title: A HighRise Project Contested in Boston
description: BOSTON, March 4  This city's longestsitting urban renewal egg is about to be hatched, amid heated debate over whether it will produce a phoenix or an albatross.

title: Mets Agree: Win More in 1974 or Else
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4One month before the start of the baseball season, the New York Mets took stock today and decided that it would take fewer injuries and more victories this year to repeat their minor miracle of 1973.

title: GASOLINE TIEUPS FADE IN CITY AREA, BUT COULD RETURN
description: For the first time in months no lines were reported at gasoline stations in the metropolitan area yesterday. But Federal and state officials and dealers warned against over optimism, saying the lines could recur in the middle of the month.

title: IT'S SPRING AGAIN OR SO IT SEEMED
description: The day began muggy and gray yesterday, but the sun broke through by 3 P.M., pushing temperatures to a record high of 70 degrees at 3:45. It was a day for shirtsleeve ice skating in Central Park and thoughts about the equinox.

title: Ethiopia Army Units Warn of Action Against Selassie
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 4  Leaflets dropped over Addis Ababa today said that some military units would take action unless Emperor Haile Selassie made sweeping political, economic and social changes, but it was not immediately clear how large the forces involved were.

title: Administration Asks Power of Retaliation in Trade
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 The Nixon Administration asked the Senate Finance Committee today for unambiguous authority to retaliate with trade measures against nations imposing illegal or unreasonable restraints on exports of raw materials in short supply.

title: A 3NATION PANEL SIFTS PARIS CRASH
description: PARIS, March 24  American aviation experts joined French and Turkish teams today ininvestigating whether the Turkish jetliner that crashed near Paris yesterday killing all 346 persons aboard could have been blown up by a bomb or brought down by mechanical failure.

title: Notes on People
description: In Washington, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas delivered a setback to the plans of Dr. S. I. Biwakawa, of the semanticist and former president of San Francisco State College, to seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. Justice Douglas denied a request by Dr. Hayakawa for a stay of a California Supreme Court ruling that Dr. Hayakawa, who switched from the Democratic to the Republican party late last year, failed to meet the requirements of a state law that says a candidate in a primary must have been a member of his party for three months and a member of no other party for an additional fine months before filing time.

title: Feminist Psychotherapy: Seeking to Redefine Healthy Woman
description: Only a decade or so ago there were as many mem as women receiving psychiatric care. Today, many more relief from their emotional problems and, according to a number of feminist psychowomen than men are seeking relief from their emotional problems and, according to a therapists, the women are being ill advised by traditionbound professionals in the field.

title: BENEFITS AWARDED IN MATERNITY CASE
description: The State Division of Human Rights yesterday ordered Syracuse hospital to pay workmen's compensation benefits to a former woman employe for sixweek period when she took maternity leave in the fall of 1972.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Troop Separation Is Completed at Suez
description: TEL AVIV, March 4 (AP)The separation of forces along the Suez Canal front was complated ahead of schedule today.

title: A BALLOT CHANGE SOUGHT IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 4  The State Senate gave swift and unanimous approval today to a measure that would move the state legislative elections from the bottom of the ballot up ahead of local and judicial contests to attract greater voter interest.

title: Mistaken Identity Cited In Shooting of Teacher
description: Federal drug agents were seeking a fugitive who is charged with participation in five murders and the sale of cocaine when a 25yearold Kearny, N.J., teacher was shot last Thursday night by an agent in a mistakenidentity case, Federal spokesman said yesterday.

title: A OneStation Town Runs Out of Gas
description: CAROGA LAKE, N. Y.Clayton Shutts closed down his Texaco station on Nick Stoner Road for the last nine days of 1973 and four days last month. He had run out of gas, and when he runs out of gas, so does Caroga Lake.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WILLCOX & GIBBS makes styrene dunnage beige for shipping (WGAMEX)Advt.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: MILLER COUNTY, Ga.Hard by meandering, Spring Creek in fields that would soon be planted to peanuts or corn, we searched for signs of nomadic hunters who had been there thousands of years before the time of Christ.

title: SELLING WEAKENS PRECIOUS METALS
Nilsson Hurt in Fall at Dress Rehearsal
description: Birgit Nilsson fell yesterday and dislocated her shoulder during a dress rehearsal of Gtterdmmerung at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Hoffmann of E. Germany Leads Figure Skating
description: MUNICH, Germany, March 5 (UPI)  Jan Hoffmann of East Germany, carving figures with the precision of a computer, took a slender lead over two Soviet Union skaters after the men's compulsory program in the world figure skating championships today and left the star American skater, Gordon McKellen, with only an outside chance for the title.

title: Houston's Architecture: Pop and Freewheeling
description: HOUSTONJust down the road from the Astrodome, this city's celebrated sports stadium, is a Texaco gas station. It does not have the square, boxy look of most gas stations; instead, it is round and has a low domejust like the Astrodome's.

title: CHINESE CAMPAIGN AIMED AT BOSSES
description: HONG KONG, March 5Wall posters in Chinese factories are denouncing once again the evil tendency to offer overtime payments and other material incentives to workers to stimulate higher production.

title: GROSS IS LINKED TO PERJURY COUNT
description: NEWARK, March 5The general attorney for the Grand Union Corporation testified today that Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was the source of an account concocted to disguise a $5,000 contribution to former Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign as a business expense.

title: Doctors Hospital Ends Obstetrics Department
description: Doctors Hospital, a voluntary institution on the upper East Side, has discontinued its obstetrics department because of what an official called low utilization and a large deficit.

title: Suit Naming Mony Mortgage Dismissed by Court Here
description: The $4billion Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York said yesterday that a suit filed against the company, its real estate investment trust, Mony Mortgage Investors and the trust's 10 trustees has been dismissed by the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court.

title: HIDING NIXON FEE LAID TO DR. RILAND
description: The Federal Government charged yesterday that Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, an osteopathic physician here, had secretly funneled fees for treating President Nixon and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller into private savings accounts to avoid listing them as income.

title: Mitchell Is Linked To Vesco by Sears
description: The Government started yesterday to get to the core of its case against John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, with the first testimony linking former Attorney General Mitchell to Robert L. Vesco, the financier who is now a fugitive.

title: BRITISH PROPOSING 35% FOR MINERS, TWICE HEATH'S BID
TORE STRESSES ALUMINUM ROLE
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 5President Ahmed Sekou Tour today urged underdeveloped countries that produce bauxite the base material for aluminumto develop capacity for producing aluminum itself and thereby increase their incomes at least 15 times.

title: A Family Squabble
description: PARIS, March 5The relations be tween the United States and France have taken a nasty turn. It is not primarily that their policies are different, which is understandable and even natural, but that they are beginning to personalize their differences, and blame them on Henry Kissinger or Michel Jobert or Georges Pompidou.

title: Money
description: Tuesday, March 5, 1974

title: $250,000 Grant to Aid Filming of Two Stories
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)A $250,000 grant to the Center for Understanding Media, in New York, for the filming of two American short stories was announced today by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Nixon Message Will Urge Limits on Campaign Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) President Nixon has rejected the idea of public financing of campaigns for Federal office and will ask Congress on Friday to limit individual campaign contributions and bar direct donations by big labor or big business, a White House official said today.

title: Cornell, Boston U. Advance in Hockey
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 5Cornell, the defending hockey champion in the Eastern College Athletic Conference, beat St. Lawrence, 53, tonight in the first round of the conference tournament.

title: BERLINGER NOTES WELFARE SAYINGS
description: The State Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, estimated yesterday that more than $7.6million had been saved statewide as a result of the ending or reduction of welfare grants in 3,047 cases investigated by his office.

title: Nixon Portrait Is Lost And Recovered at Duke
description: DURHAM, N.C., March 5. (UPI)A painting of President Nixon posing against a stone wall, reported missing from Mr. Nixon's old law school at Duke University yesterday morning, was found undamaged this afternoon. The portrait was found stuffed beneath loose ceiling tiles in a secondflood classroom at the Law School building by securty personnel, a spokesman said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 5 (UPI)Stax Records and Charles O. Finley said today they had almost completed an agreement for Finley to sell his Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association to the blacksoul music company. Finley's reported asking price was $1million. The Tams have the worst record in pro basketball.

title: Cards Floated Off Shore of L.I. In Project Opposing Oil Drilling
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 5 A group of Long Island and university officials flew over the South Shores early this morning and dropped thousands of specially marked cards from their helicopters in a project designed to dissuade the Federal Government and oil companies from engaging in offshore oil exploration.

title: Screvane Named Head of OTB
description: Paul R. Screvane became president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation yesterday.

title: Cuban Deal Pressed
description: Opposition members of the Canadian Parliament are demanding that the Government take steps to assure that an $18million sale of Canadian locomotives goes through in spite of United States opposition. Page 55.

title: Boycott Is Sought Over Abortion Drug
description: BOSTON, March 5  The medical staff of Boston's largest Roman Catholic hospital, St. Elizabeth's, has recommended that the hospital should boycott Upjohn Company products when possible because of the company's production of a drug that is used to induce abortions.

title: Notes on People
description: Jarl Heileman, managing director of the publishing company holding first Fin nish rights to The Gulag Ar. chipelago 19181956, by the Russian exile Aleicsandr I. Solzhenitsyn, said in Helsinki that the board of directors decided unanimously not to publish the book. The reason, said Mr. Heileman, is that it has become a political question rather than a literary question in Finland. The Finns are sensitive about anything that could disturb relations with the Soviet Union, which looms on their small country's eastern frontier.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, March 5, 1974

title: People in Sports
description: Otto Graham, onetime ace quarterback with the Cleveland Browns and athletic director at the United States Coast Guard Academy since 1970, was named yesterday as the New London, Conn., institution's head football coach, succeeding Tad Schroeder. Graham also will continue as athletic director.

title: Peron Wins Senate Approval For a TakeOver of Province
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 5After a heated debate until the early morning hours, the Argentine Senate gave its approval today to President Juan D. Pern's request that he be allowed to appoint a federal oftidal to replace the deposed leftwing Peronist governor of Crdoba.

title: JURY PANELS CALLED IN 2 POLICE SLAYINGS
description: Prospective jurors return today to state Supreme court here for possible duty in the trial of five persons accused in the ambush slaying of two police officers at a Harlem housing project in 1971. The five are believed to be members of the alleged Black Liberation Army.

title: RODINO PANEL BIDS LAWYERS OBTAIN GRAND JURY DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The House Judiciary Committee directed its lawyers today to obtain a sealed grand jury report on President Nixon's possible, role in the Watergate coverup and to determine by Thursday if the White House would supply evidence for use in an impeachment inquiry.

title: PARNASSUS TO FOCUS ON AMERICAN POETS
description: The current fallwinter issue of Parnassus, the twiceyearly magazine devoted solely to reviews of poetry and edited by Herbert Leibowitz, will be published March 15.

title: Knicks Given Tablets In Meningitis Case
description: After last night's victory over Seattle, the Knicks and five sports writers were given medication to combat a possible exposure to meningitis.

title: European Football
description: By Reuters

title: Rangers Seek 8th in Row And Chance to Tie for 2d
description: Golden Opportunity, in the form of the Montreal Canadiens, presents itself tonight at 7:35 when the New York Rangers take the ice at Madison Square Garden. With a victory, the Rangers can tie Montreal for second place.

title: Manufacturers Set $11Billion For 4thQuarter Plant Outlays
description: The nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers set aside a total of $11.35billion for improvement of plant and equipment in the fourth quarter of 1973, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: ARABS DENY PLOT TO KILL KISSINGER
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 5 (Reuters)  Reports from Washington of a plot to assassinate Secretary of State Kissinger during his visit to Damascus last week were denied by official sources here today.

title: State Seeks Improved TV Coverage; Wants New York Station to Shift Base
description: TRENTON, March 5  New Jersey officials asked today that the Federal Communications Commission find a way to assure better television service for the state, even if it meant moving one or two New York stations to New Jersey.

title: Corporations Release Reports Covering Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: RRecord

title: A DOUBLE DEFENSE OF NIXON DRAFTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 5White House lawyers are preparing a twopronged defense against the implication in last Friday's grand jury indictments that President Nixon may not have opposed hush money payments to the Watergate defendants.

title: Bravo!
description: Announcement of a one million dollar matching grant to the Metropolitan Opera from a greatly enriched National Endowment for the Arts marks a stunning breakthrough in public support for cultural activities this country. To the Met, caught in what its board chairman has described as a life and death financial crisis, this transfusion of funds far exceeding any previous governmental assistance offers a new lease on life.

title: Virgin Isle Hilton Closing
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, March 5 (AP)Hilton International Company has announced the closing of the Virgin Isle Hilton by March 31.

title: A DOUBLE DEFENSE OF NIXON DRAFTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 White House lawyers are preparing a twopronged defense against the implication in last Friday's grand jury indictments that President Nixon may not have opposed hush money payments to the Watergate defendants.

title: A Cut of 3.5Billion In Pentagon Budget Called Senate Aim
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that the Senate Defense Appropriation's Subcommittee would try to cut 53.5billion from next year's record $85.6billion defense budget.

title: Pro Transactions
description: DETROIT (NFC)Traded Mei Farr, running back, to Houston for future draft choice.

title: POWER COMPANY ASKS 23% RISE
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company, which is New Jersey's second largest utility company, asked state officials yesterday, for authority to increase its rates an average of 23.5 per cent.

title: Players Cite N.F.L. Flaw In Pensions
description: CHICAGO, March 5 (AP)The National Football League Players Association described today as totally inadequate benefits under the pension fund for widows of former players and for totally disabled former players.

title: Hope Is Seen for Easing Of Oil Curb at Arab Talks
description: KUWAIT, March 5The meeting of Arab oil ministers to be held in Libya Sunday holds out strong prospects for a relaxation of Arab oil restrictions, including the embargo against the United States, according to Arab diplomatic sources. against the United States, according to Arab diplomatic sources.

title: Assembly Is Urged to Allow Domestics To Organize and Bargain Collectively
description: ALBANY, March 5  The Assembly was asked today and the virtual enslavement of thousands of household workers by allowing maids and other domestic employes to form unions and bargain collectively for better working conditions.

title: Oil Price Deregulation
description: SANTA FE, N. M., March (AP)The Western Governors Conference has called for gradual deregulation of oil and natural gas prices at the wellhead and full energy production in every state with untapped resources. The statement, released yesterday, said energy should be distributed to all states according to their need.

title: Brooklyn Museum Names Six To Begin Search for a Director
description: Six members of the Brooklyn Museum's governing committee have been named to a committee to find a permanent director for the museum. Two more members, representing the curatorial and nonprofessional staffs, are expected to be chosen this week.

title: Peter Schell, ExMinister Of Interior of Hungary, 75
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 5 Peter Paul Schell, who was Minister of the Interior of Hungary when the Nazis took over in 1943, died at his home here on Sunday. He was 75 years old and lived at 71 Myrtle Avenue.

title: LEGISLATORS GET SPECIAL GASOLINE
description: During the gasoline shortage, New York State legislators have been getting a special supply from a state agency on Sundays, when most service stations are closed to the public.

title: NILSSON UNSURE OF SINGING FRIDAY
description: Birgit Nilsson, who is recuperating from a shoulder dislocation suffered during a dress rehearsal of Gtterdmmerung on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera Rouse, said yesterday from her bed in Roosevelt Hospital that she was coming along. But the soprano is still not sure whether she will be able to sing Brnnhilde on Friday in the premiere of the Metropolitan's new production of the Wagner work.

title: Store Center and Tenants Sign Anticompetition Order
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Federal Trade Commission announced today that a large regional shopping center and Ilwo of its major tenants had agreed not to enforce anticompetitive provisions in their lease.

title: Model Cities Workers Demonstrate at City Hall to Protest Job Cuts
description: Several hundred Model Cities workers and representatives of private antipoverty agencies demonstrated at City Hall yesterday to protest the imminent cutback of 3,871 federallyfinanced jobs in Harlem, the South Bronx and the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Joint Tax Panel Expected to Ask What Nixon Knew About Claims
description: WASHINGTON, March 5President Nixon appeared today to be headed for a possible confrontation with Congress over his tax returns.

title: WAVE OF BOMBS HIT NORTHERN IRELAND
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 5 (AP)A wave of terrorist bombs hit Belfast and three other Northern Ireland cities today.

title: PROF. HELEN VILJOEN OF QUEENS COLLEGE
description: Dr. Helen Gill Viljoen, who retired in 1965 as professor of English at Queens College, died on Monday at her home in Flushing, Queens. She was 75 years old and lived at 16710 Crocheron Avenue.

title: Drivers Delay Strike Over New Trot Rules
description: Although angered by stiffer penalties threatened by the State Racing and Wagering Board for infractions, drivers at Yonkers Raceway decided last night shortly before posttime to compete.

title: 2 More Named in Attempt On Police Officers' Lives
description: Two new defendants were named yesterday in an indictment involving the attempted ambush murder of two police officers in Queens last year.

title: Nora Post Displays Skill and Adventure On 2 Kinds of Oboe
description: Nora Post's oboe recital Monday night at Town Hall was by no means an ordinary event. First of all, there was Miss Post's adventuresome program, which called upon her to perform a Baroque group in the first half on a reconstruction of an, early 18thcentury German twokeyed oboe, and then to return in the second half for a contemporary group with a modern oboe.

title: Miss Evert Wins Easily in Dallas
description: DALLAS, March 5 (AP) Chris Evert and Laurie Fleming, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., products who trained and roomed together on the pro tennis circuit, displayed similar form in coasting through firstround matches at the Maureen Connolly Brinker tournament today.

title: Fruit, Vezetables and KnowHow
description: Joseph Doria picks up an apple, evaluates the intensity of its color, studies its contours, contemplates its stem, rubs its skinand issues an instant verdict on its flavor, texture and perishability.

title: Sol Hurok, the Impresario, Dies at 85
description: Sol Hurok, one of the world's foremost impresarios, died yesterday afternoon of a massive heart attack at the age of 85.

title: ExCoach Is Indicted On 52 Sex Charges
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 5 The 28yearold former coach of a Mamaroneck football team in the Pop Warner League has beeen indicted on 52 counts of sexual abuse and sodomy, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari announced today.

title: Sale by U.S. Financial Of Mosser Is Approved
description: SAN DIEGO, March 5 (AP)A bankruptcy judge has approved a request by U.S. Financial, Inc., to sell Mosser Construction, Inc., of Ohio to four Mosser employes.

title: Peronism: Violence the Theme
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 5During the final days of his 18year exile, Juan Domingo Pern's trump card was his ability to convince most Argentines that only his movement had the strength and substance to end the violent political divisions among them and give their potentially rich country a fresh start, Now, five months after he assumed the presidency, he has presided over a growing upsurge of political violence, most of which is exploding in his own heterogeneous movement.

title: Two Captured Hijackers Pose Big Problem to the Netherlands
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 5 (Reuters)The Netherlands, already subject to an Arab oil embargo, would rather extradite two captured Arab hijackers to Britain than try them here and run the risk of raising new Arab antagonism, informed sources said here today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Wilson Assails RailCutback Plan

title: Finding Golden Threads Among the Silver
description: I am over 60 and most distressed, not only by failing vision, missing teeth, barnacles on the spine, aching joints, gray hair and wrinkles, but because every effort is being made to separate and isolate me from a portion of my life and the rest of the living.

description: AT ATLANTA

title: Knicks Beat Sonics, 111106, On 3922 Edge in Foul Shots
description: The Seattle Supersonics were not super from the foul line in the final six minutes of their game against the Knicks last night at Madison Square Garden. In fact, they were foul. With a chance to beat the Knicks for the first time in 11 meetings, they missed nine of 15 free throws after tying the game, 9090, with 6 minutes 45 seconds to play.

title: Israeli P.O.W.'s in Syria Are Reported to Be Well
description: TEL AVIV, March 5 (UPI)  The International Red Cross said today that 65 Israeli prisoners held by Syria were in good condition.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The to 20, with points figured on a 10987654321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace votes In parentheses) and wonlost records through games of last Saturday with total points.

title: Carnegie Hall Is Swept by an Emotional Torrent
description: For hours before Maria Callas's electrifying return to the concert stage here last night, telephones at Carnegie Hall had been ringing without letup.

title: Lou Piniella: Yankees' Last Angry Man Puts Reins on His Tempestuous Nature
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5Lou Piniella was the first kid on his block to have a water cooler from baseball park. I figured I might as well take, it home, the new Yankee said today. I paid for it. In fact, I paid for a couple of them.

title: Cahill Analyzes Failures as Governor
description: PRINCETON, March 5Former Gov. William T. Cahill, reflecting on his four years in office, portrayed himself this evening as a political leader who had failed to galvanize public support for many of his programs and had become a victim of the legislative opponents who fought them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 6, 1974

title: IranianIraqi Shelling Goes On; 2Day Toll Is Put at 4 Killed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 5 Iranian and Iraqi border forces exchanged artillery fire today for the second day, and Iraq said three of her men were killed and 12 wounded.

title: Kelly Now WHN Manager
description: Jack Kelly has been appointed vice president and general manager of radio station WHN by its parent corporation, Storer Broadcasting. He was previously vice president and executive officer of Storer Television Sales, station representatives. Mr. Kelly succeeds Charles Renwick, who was appointed administrative assistant to Jay Watson, ?? president of the Storer rad. division.

title: Patients Flee Hospital Fire
description: Thirtyseven patients and more than 50 outpatients of Harlem Hospital Center were evacuated about noon yesterday from a building on 136th Street between Lenox and Fifth Avenues that houses the hospital's outpatient clinic and psychiatric department when a rubbish fire broke out in the basement, the hospital reported. No one was injured.

title: Democrat Wins in Ohio; 3d House Loss for G.O.P.
description: CINCINNATI, March 5 Thomas A. Luken, a 48yearold Democrat, eked out a narrow victory tonight in a special election in Ohio's First Congressional Districtan election in which Watergate played role.

title: GOING OUT
description: IN THE BRONX The Bronx County Historical Society 8818900) by no means limits itself to the city's only mainland borough. Tonight at 8, for instance, it's going to give all its attention to its sister across the East River, Queens, by saluting two of the main events in that borough's history, the World's Fairs of 1939 and 1964.

title: Freedoms Sign Stolle
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP)  The Philadelphia Freedoms signed Fred Stolle, their secondround draft choice, today for the World Team Tennis franchise.

title: Olivares Floored in 10th, But Retains Ring Crown
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 5 (AP)  Ruben Olivares of Mexico survived a 10thround knockdown and went on to win a split decision from Irish Art Hafey in 12 rounds to retain his North American featherweight boxing title last night.

title: About New York When Nixon Was Out, Agnew In
description: There has been a great shakeup among some of the Nixon old guard, The Times said on page one, and it told of the old guard's fall from grace and power. This was a story from The Times Jan. 10, 1906, and while news stories then were sometimes short on details, such as first names, it at least was clear that a politician named Nixon had just been replaced by a politician named Wadsworth as Speaker of the New York State Assembly. The first thing Wadsworth did, the story said, was to appoint a new chairman of the Gas, Electricity and Water Supply Committee. His name was Agnew.

title: 7 Inmates Reported Dead In Mexican Prison Incidents
description: HERMOSILLO, Mexico, March 5 (AP)Six prisoners died during a jail riot in Hermosillo prison yesterday, while at another Sonora state prison, in Nogales, one prisoner was killed during a mass escape.

title: Papal Primacy
description: In an age when nationalistic antagonisms are fierce over much of the globe and racial hostilities show few signs of diminishing, human society has ground for hope in the patient, steady effort of contemporary Christians to resolve ancient controversies and achieve reconciliation.

title: POWER RATES STIR A 2AGENCY CLASH
description: ALBANY, March 5  The chairman of the Public Service Commission warned today of a possible doubling of electric utility rates in New York State in the next decade, based on environmental considerations alone.

title: St. John's Beats St. Francis, 8266
description: Mel Utley and Ed Searcy each scored 25 points as St. John's defeated St. Francis last night, 8266, in the 61st game of a basketball rivalry that started in 1907. The game was played at Alumni Hall in Jamaica.

title: 3 More Charges Dropped Against Dale Anderson
description: BALTIMORE, March 5 (AP) Lawyers for Dale N. Anderson began their defense of the Baltimore County Executive today after gaining dismissal of three more charges. The charges ere dropped after the prosecution concluded its case.

title: REGIME CLAIMING GUATEMALAN VOTE
description: GUATEMALA, March 5Amid charges by the main opposition party of fraud, Guatemala's army  backed Government announced tonight the victory of its candidate in the Presidential election Sunday.

title: New Offerings of Corporate Bonds Sell Briskly
description: Corporate bond prices showed selective, modest improvement yesterday. Government issues remained mixed, A busy taxexempt market showed good firstday response to a heavy calendar. In the corporate market two new offerings, one by a financial institution and the other by a utility, were well received. Prices in the secondary market appeared to slow their recent downturn somewhat.

title: NearEast Origin
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 5The soft sounds of what is now believed to be the oldest song in the world were played here today at the University of California.

title: Striking Miners Win Easing Of West Virginia fuel Plan
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 5 (AP)Coal miners striking in protest against a state fuelallocation program forced officials today to modify it, but there was no indication that the change would bring an end to a weeklong walkout by about 20,000 miners.

title: HOUSE MANEUVER ON TRANSIT BILL PERILS 35C FARE
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said today that he was flatly opposed to HouseSenate conference bill on urban mass transit and had urged President Nixon to veto the legislation, which appeared all but doomed today in parliamentary quagmire in the House.

description: TRENTON, March 5  New Jersey officials asked today that, the Federal Communications Commission find a way to assure better television service for the state, even if it meant moving one or two New York stations to New Jersey.

title: Red Smith
description: Ed Garvey, the lawyer who runs the Professional Football Players' Union, was quoted the other evening by one of those people who make a living by reading the scores of games on television. The item was something do with gains the players hope to make in collective bargaining with the owners. The character on the air jeered. He said the players already received pension and insurance benefits in addition to their wages, and he pointed out wittily that there was no law requiring any man to play football. In other words, love it or leave it. If Bob Kuechenberg isn't satisfied opening holes for Larry Csonka, let a him get a job opening oysters and see how he likes that.

title: G.I. Dies in Air Accident
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, March 5 (UPI)One person was killed today when a window blew out of an American military plane carrying servicemen from Alaska to Texas. The victim's name was being withheld pending notification of next of kin.

title: Where to Take the Children? Try Table Tennis
description: Any number of parents, including the single variety who see their children only on weekends, are finding the iverside Table Tennis parlor run by Marty Reisman good or an hour's entertainmentmore if the children get iterated in the sport.

title: Landing Strip Is a Road
description: SUMMIT BRIDGE, Del., March 5Robert A. Keller of Farmingdale, L. I., his fuel almost gone, landed his singleengine plane on a twolane highway in northern Delaware last night and hitchhiked to the nearest airfield where he purchased fuel, returned to his plane and took off.

title: Sketches of Principal Figures in the Wilson Cabinet
description: Foreign Secretary, 61... Only one of four ministers not to have gone to Oxford but has been visiting fellow there... Father a chief petty officer in Royal Navy...Left school at 17 and began work as incometax inspector... Served disastrous threeyear tenure as Chancellor of Exchequer, 196467...Left after pound was devalued to become Home Secretary... Fared better at sensitive post, notably with conciliatory policies in Northern Ireland...Genial and popular, nicknamed Honest Jim... Considered a moderate, uncommonly in tune with public sentiment...Cuts reassuring figure, one of party's most astute television performers...sent to Parliament by Welsh districts since 1945.

title: COURT SEEKS AID IN SCHOOL DISPUTE
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein announced yesterday that he would appoint a master to help formulate plans among government agencies to increase racial Integration at Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island.

title: TV: Casals Master Class Returning
description: In an effort to supplement a skimpy Public Broadcasting Service programing schedule, Channel 13 has returned to the past and found that it works. Beginning tonight, the station will rerun the 25part series called Pablo Casals Master Class. Tonight's hourlong installment begins at 7. The rest, each running a half hour, will be shown on Wednesdays at 7:30 P.M.

title: Music: St. John Passion
description: Thomas Dunn, who used to give New Yorkers some provocative programs with his Festival Orchestra before moving to Boston seven years ago to direct the Handel and Hayden Society there, returned to a local concert stage for the first time to lead a performance of Bach's Passion According to St. John in Alice Tully. Hall on Monday night. Since age and anniversaries do not matter in the case of a masterpiece, it may be irrelevent to point out that the work had its first permance 250 years ago.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Army Corps of Engineers has awarded a $109.7million contract to the Arundel Corporation and two other companies for the construction of the new Melones Dam on the Stanislaus River, east of San Francisco, Arundel announced yesterday. The contract was bid jointly by Arundel and the Guy F. Atkinson Construction Company and Gordon H. Ball, Inc. Atkinson will act as sponsor for the venture in which Arundel has a 17.5 per cent interest.

title: Former Goldstein Head Sentenced in Mail Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES, March (Reuters)  Harold Goldstein, former chairman of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., bankrupt commodity option company was sentenced today to 18 months in jail on three counts of mail fraud by the United States District Court here.

title: Prospects for Early End of Embargo by Arabs Spurs Rise
description: The stock market came alive yesterday, registering its biggest advance in two months in heavy trading as prices were spurred by prospects of an early end of the Arab oil embargo.

title: When History Comes Home to Roost
description: SYRACUSENo one seems to know whether the oil crisis is real or contrived. But one thing is clear: Americans are paying more and more money for less and less gas, acquired under increasingly difficult, distasteful, and even dangerous circumstances.

title: Nastase Advances In Virginia Tennis
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 5 (AP)Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania whipped Kim Warwick of Australia, 61, 62, in the opening round of the $35,000 Coliseum Mall tennis tournment tonight.

title: Call of the Yukon Now Is SelfGovernment
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory Seventyfive years after, the rush to find gold along the Klondike River called this vast, wild land to the world's attention it is restless againthis time with a yearning for selfgovernment.

title: British Pound and Stocks Up
description: LONDON, March 5  The formation of a Labor Government with Harold Wilson as Prime Minister sent the pound and stock prices sharply higher today in Britisn markets.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he would support City Council legislation to repeal one set of rent increases in the city's rentcontrolled apartments. At the same time, he also urged the Council to approve a second set of increases.

Brinegar said today that he was flatly opposed to a HouseSenate conference bill on urban mass transit and had urged President Nixon to veto the legislation, which appeared all but doomed today in a parliamentary quagmire in the House.

title: DAYAN WILL JOIN CABINET IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, March 5Premier Golda Meir announced today that she would complete the formation of a new coalition tomorrow and that it would include Moshe Dayan as Defense Minister.

description: CINCINNATI, March 5Thomas A. Luken, a 48yearold Democrat, eked out a narrow victory tonight in a special election in Ohio's First Congressional Districtan election in which Watergate played a role.

title: CANADIAN CANDY RECALLED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration recalled from United States markets today all chocoate products made by a Canadian concern because of suspected salmonella bacteria contamination.

title: Burch, Under Senate Pressure, To Step Up F.C.C. Departure
description: Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who was to have left on March 15 to become counselor to President Nixon, yesterday moved up the timetable and instead will take his new post, which has Cabinet rank, in the next day or two.

title: A.E.C. IS PLANNING NEW SHALE BLASTS
description: DENVER  Just as critics of nuclear tests thought they were winning, the Atomic Energy Commission has revitalized plans to expand research and testing of underground nuclear stimuation blasts to extract natural as and shale oil in the Rocky Mountains.

title: New Jersey Sports A Tennis Mother
description: WAYNE, March 5Mention tennis mother and the picture usually portrayed is that of a fussy, overprotective woman determined to let nothing stand in the way of her youngster's success. Some tennis mothers can be helpfulto a point. Others are known to leave psychological scars on their offspring, or to work on them so much that they become burntout cases on the court after a few years.

description: WATERSHIP DOWN. By Richard Adams. 429 pages. Illustrated with maps. Macmillan. $6.95.

title: Soviet and West Germany Agree To Seek Out Joint Investments
description: MOSCOW, March 5  West Germany and the Soviet Union agreed today to seek opportunities to set up joint companies for operating in third countries with mixed SovietGerman capital, management and production.

title: Banker and Broom Foil a $340 Sweep By Two at Branch
description: A bank manager wielding a broomstick foiled a holdup yesterday at the Chemical Bank branch at 201 Park Avenue South, at 17th Street, and held two robbers at bay until the police arrived.

title: Selassie Pledges to Seek Democratic Government
Callas Returns to Fans' Adulation
description: There once was a great soprano who, in the last days of her career was singing at the Vienna Opera, and not singing very well any more. A visitor, attending one of her performances and watching the audience go wild, asked an opera buff how come? There was a beatific smile. What a singer she used to be, he said.

title: Islanders Bow, 21, to Penguins
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 5 It was an absolutely frustrating way to lose a game but the New York Islanders managed it bowing to the Pittsburgh Penguins, 21, in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: MRS. DELMER F. HUBBELLI
description: Mrs. Harriet Weed Hubbell, author of books for children and the widow of Delmer F. Hubbell, an investment counselor who wrote for newspapers on economics and politics, died of cancer Monday in Santa Fe, N. M., where she had been living. She was 64 years old and a former resident of New York and of Chatham, Mass.

title: Senate Rejects, 6628, Bid To End WagePrice Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The Senate rejected today an attempt to repeal wage and price controls.

title: Senate Unit Adopts Bill for Integrated Market System
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved today a bill that calls for common tape and quotation system and an integration of all securities markets into centralized system.

title: U.S. GIVES SILVERCUP A REPRIEVE ON TAXES
description: The Internal Revenue Service said last night it would give the Silvercup bread company in Long Island City, Queens, more time to settle its $1.5million backtax bill.

title: Gold Bugs: Varied, Anxious and Feisty
description: Gold bugsmembers of that widely scattered group that John Maynard Keynes more decorously referred to as the champions of goldgathered from all over the world this past weekend at Arden House in Harriman, N. Y., the baronial estate of E. H. Harriman, the 19thcentury financier and railroad tycoon. The gold bugs came in response to the call of the Committee for Monetary Research and Education, a group of scholars and businessmen who believe the gold standard must be restored if the world is to be rescued from monetary corruption. The committee contends that debasement of the currency has in the past paved the way for civil disorder, political impotence, and sometimes precipitated world war.

title: Bridge:
description: Responding to doubles of one notrump opening bids is a murky area in which there are two schools of thought. The majority nearly always bids. The minority, but a minority that includes nearly all the topranked players, nearly always passes.

title: NIXON SEES A VETO ON EDUCATION BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)President Nixon said today he would be forced to veto a pending education bill because certain provisions on grants funding would create a bureaucratic nightmare.

title: Pension Security
description: The House of Representatives has now joined the Senate in recognizing the need for Federal standards govern the private pension plans that cover thirty million workers, and to prevent expected benefits from proving illusory to workers on retirement.

title: To Peter Link, Composing for Theater Is School
description: The gospel according to Paul Hindemith has always been so and every music student who has taken Theory I knows it: Thou Shalt Not Write Parallel Fifths, Thou Shalt Avoid Leading Any Two Voices in Parallel Octaves and If Thou Wisheth to Get an A, T'would Be Advisable Not to Double the Third of a Dominant Chord. Hindemith's venerable treatise on Traditional Harmonystill standard in many schools and music departmentscontains an interminable list of other Thou Shalt Nots, all of them clearly set down.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Senator Anthony Imperiale, Independent Essex County, officially entered the race for Mayor Newark yesterday by filing petitions bearing more than 10,000 signatures with the City Clerk. So far only he and the incumbent, Kenneth A. Gibson, have filed petitions. The filing deadline for the May 14 election is March 28.

title: Gromyko Returns to Syria After 5Day Visit to Cairo
description: CAIRO, March 5The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromylco, flew to Damascus today after a fiveday visit to Egypt that was apparently designed to show Moscow's determination to reassert its influence in the area.

title: Harvard Fees Rise by $325
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5 (AP)Harvard College has raised its fees by $325 to $5,350 a year effective with the next azademic year. Tuition will go up $200 to $3,400 and room and board fees will rise to a total of $1,950, the college announced yesterday.

title: Oscar Wilensky, 69, Dies; Jersey Legislator in 30's
description: CLIFTON, N. J. March 5 Oscar R. Wilensky, a Republican State Senator from 1939 to 1942 and former majority leader of the Assembly, died today in Passaic General Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: Uruguay Shuts a Magazine Over Story Regime Opposed
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 5 (Reuters)  The Government of President Juan Marta Bordaberry today shut the leftwing weekly magazine Marcha for 10 editions for publishing a short story frowned on by the apthorities.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There must be some women around who can put on a size 8 or 10 or 12 dress, or a size 16 for that matter, and walk out looking as though the design had been custommade for them. There must be but, unfortunately, these women are rarely thee and me. They are also, one might be happy to know, not Jacqueline Onassis, Gloria Vanderbilt Cooper, Barbra Streisand or Sybil Burton Christopher.

title: SUN OR RAISES FUELOIL PRICES
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had raised its prices for residual fuel oil by $1.55 a barrel, effective immediately. The oil is used primarily by industry. The increases, applicable to fuel refined at the company's plant at Marcus Hook, Pa., bring the price of No. 4 residual fuel oil to $14.42 a barrel, of No. regular to $11.17 a barrel, and of No. 6 low sulphur to $13.36 a barrel.

title: U.S. Envoy Meets With Soviet Chief In Warm Welcome
description: MOSCOW, March 5The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, today received a personal letter from President Nixon and spent an hour and 45 minutes discussing international issues and SovietAmerican relations with Ambassador Walter J. Stoessel Jr.

title: French Bank Opens Here
description: Credit Industriel et Commercial of France opened yesterday a fullservice branch at 280 Park Avenue in Manhattan. The bank said it hoped to provide a new channel to accelerate the flow of trade and investments between the United States and France.

title: Colleges Urged to Curb Tenure To Avoid Inflexibility in Staffs
description: Faculty tenure, the system that protects the jobs of professors, came under intense scrutiny at an allday meeting here yesterday devoted to examining the role of college and university trustees in setting academic policy.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: AMEX STOCKS RISE IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: In the most active trading in almost two months, prices the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Vermont Town Favors Impeachment of Nixon
description: THETFORD, Vt., March 5  The first week in March is Town Meeting time in much of New England. In the little towns on the farmlands and coastlines of Maine and Massachusetts, and along the rivers and mountain valleys of New Hampshire and Vermont, the citizens  as they have done since Colonial timescome together to vote on their taxes, town regulations and other issues of mutual concern.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
description: FOREIGN SECURITIES

title: New Yonkers Manager Invites Press to Meetings of His Staff
description: YONKERS, March 5  The new City Manager of Yonkers, Clifford W. O'Key, today announcedmuch to the surprise of the Mayor, who hired him that his staff meetings would be open to the press.

title: Arab Editor Missing From Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, March 5  At 12:30 A.M. on Feb. 6, the 35yearold radical editor of a muckraking Arabic weekly was dropped off by friends outside his East Jerusalem apartment.

title: Shortages of Textile Fibers Cause Problems for Industry
description: Shortages of textile fibers have created problems for the textile industry, James D. Finley, chairman of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., said at the company's annual meeting here yesterday. He said the concern had taken steps to stretch out the use of synthetic fibers by greater use of cotton and wool wherever possible.

title: C.A.B. HEAD BACKS AIRLINEFUEL AID
description: Robert D. Timm, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, conditionally endorsed yesterday the concept of providing Federal subsidies to United States international airlines because of high jetfuel costs.

title: FUTURES PRICES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: The bears continued to dominate the commodity futures markets yesterday as once again almost every basic raw material was bid down in price.

title: 12 More Key Indictments Are Foreseen by Jaworski
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, expects at least a dozen more major indictments, according to a letter sent to Chief Judge John J. Sirica two months ago.

title: Convictions in Fur Union Payoff Case Called Big Gain in Racketeering Drive
description: Criminaljustice officials yesterday hailed the convictions last week of four fur union offidais for having accepted payoffs. They called it a big gain in the long and mostly futile effort to crack labor racketeering in the garment industry.

title: AMERICAN DEATHS OH JET PUT AT 22
description: PARIS, March 5At least 22 Americans are believed to have been among the 346 persons who died Sunday in the Turkish jetliner crash near Paris, the United States Embassy said today.

title: AIRTICKET THEFTS ARE CHARGED TO 19
description: Nineteen persons were charged in indictments unsealed yesterday in the Federal District Court in Brooklyn with the theft of more than 7,000 blank airline tickets  thefts that wer said to have resulted in a loss to carriers of more than $2million.

title: RODINO PANEL BIDS LAWYERS OBTAIN GRAND JURY DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The House Judiciary Committee directed its lawyers today to obtain a sealed grand jury report on President Nixon's possible role in the Watergate coverup and to determine by Thursday if the White House would supply evidence for use in an impeachment inquiry.

title: Report by AntiDefamation League Sees Examples bf New Kind of AntiSemitism
description: The AntiDefamation League, of B'nai B'rith asserted yesterday that American Jews were, becoming increasingly concerned over a new kind of antiSemitism expressed by individuals and institutions.

title: BOSTON PLAZA PLAN IS BACKED BY STATE
