description: BOSTON, March 5The controversial $266million Park Plaza redevelopment plan for the section of downtown Boston known as Park Square received conditional approval today from Lewis S.W. Crampton, the Massachusetts Community Affairs Commissioner.

title: 11 Federal Narcotics Agents Face Trial in Illinois Today on Charges Stemming From Mistaken Drug Raids
description: ALTON, Ill., March 5The Federal Government will take 11 of its own narcotics agents to trial here tomorrow, charging them with violating the constitutional rights of innocent persons.

title: INVESTIGATED AIDE QUITS POST ON L.I.
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 5 Steven R. Saunders, deputy supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay, who has been subpoenaed to appear before a Nassau County grand jury, investigating allegations of wrongdoing in the town, submitted his resignation today.

title: MORE MONEY ASKED FOR CENTRAL PARK
description: More money to rehabilitate Central Park was demanded yesterday by Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President, and a delegation of City Council members from Manhattan at a news conference on the front steps of City Hall.

title: Law Barring Private Lewdness Indirectly Challenged by Court
description: TRENTON, March 5A state law outlawing private lewdness was indirectly challenged today by the State Supreme Court.

title: People in Sports
description: Otto Graham, onetime ace quarterback with the Cleveland Browns and athletic director at the United States Coast Guard Academy since 1970, was named yesterday as the New London, Conn., institution's head football coach, succeeding Tad Schroeder. Graham also will continue as athletic director.

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: The stock market climbed 19.24 points yesterday, registering its biggest advance in two months in heavy trading spurred by hopes of an early end to the Arab oil embargo. Page 47.

title: Man With Shotgun Hijacks Truck in Hearst Food Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 (UPI)A man carrying a shotgun hijacked a truck loaded with meat and poultry today as it as being taken to a food distribution center in the program to secure the release of Patricia Hearst.

title: Ferryboat Bidder Defaults
description: The city yesterday rejected the high bid on the cannibalized old ferryboat Gold Star Mother. Purchase Commissioner Robert I. Cohen said that EastWest Merchants and Traders, of 10 East 40th Street, the high bidder on the 37yearold craft, which once ran between Manhattan and Staten Island had defaulted on its $77,500 offer. The craft will be auctione off at an nudetermined date, he said.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Louis F. Powell Sr. Father Of Supreme Court Justice
description: RICHMOND, March 5 (AP) Louis Franklin Power Sr., father of Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court, died yesterday at his home. He was 94 years old.

title: Hockey Scoring
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 6, 1974

title: WITNESS RELATES PLOT BY BRASCO
description: A financial agent named as a coconspirator in the corruption conspiracy Indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco testified in Federal Court yesterday that the Brooklyn Congressman had discussed with him the possibility of obtaining a loan for a sham trucking company that was to be run secretly by a reputed Mafia captain.

title: The Way She Tells the Story, It's a ManHater's Dream
description: SAN FRANCISCOLouise Thoresen has a new life now. She's a changed woman, she says. She's unmarried, unattached and lives quietly with her 11yearold son in a small white house five blocks from the Greek Revival mansion she used to share with her husband.

title: Blame Urges the Repeal Of LaborCost Rent Rises
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would support City Council legislation to repeal one Set of rent increases scheduled in many of the one million rentcontrolled apartments here, At the same time, he urged the Council to approve a second set of increases.

title: ROGER FLOOD DIES; HOUSING AIDE, 70
description: Roger W. Flood, who retired in 1970 as a member of the New York City Housing Authority, died Sunday at Sydenham Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 21 Stuyvesant Oval.

title: Lonetree Scores Upset On Hialeah's First Day
description: MIAMI, March 5Hialeah Park, hoping for the best and fearing the worst, took a dose of the worst today as it opened a 49day meeting with a crowd of only 12,359 and, a mutuel handle of $1,440,579. It was a tough day for both the track management and the chalk players as Tartan Stable's Lonetree scored an upset in the $25,000added Royal Poinciana. The 4yearson of Restless Wind outran Mr. Prospector, ostensibly the fastest horse in Florida and the oddson favorite, to win by 2 lengths. He set a track record in the process, running seven furlongs in 1:21 and lowering the mark by twofifths of a second. Ridden by Bobby Woodhouse, Lonetree paid $7.20 for a $2 win ticket.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 8 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 239 compared to 231 from the week ended Feb. 19, 1974.

title: Moynihan Is Attacked in Indian Press
description: NEW DELHI, March 5The United States Ambassador, Daniel P. Moynihan, was sharply attacked today by an Indian newspaper closely linked to the ruling Congress party and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Egyptian Cooks Say No To Monkey a la Zaire
description: CAIRO, March 5 (Agence FrancePresse)  Players of the Zaire national football team were asked to dine in their hotel rooms after a little gastronomic upset, the Middle East News Agency reported here.

title: Advertising: Playboy Sales Lag
description: The average issue of Playboy during the second half of last year had about 500,000 less circulation than the average issue in the second half of 1972. It was the first such loss in Playboy's fabulous 20 years.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Lefkowitz Backs Wide Reforms In Election Law but Adds Caveat
description: ALBANY, March 5Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that reform proposals for a statewide election commission and partial public financing of campaigns might require timeconsuming constitutional amendments.

title: DAM WILL JOIN CABINET IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, March 5Premier Golda Meir announced today that she would complete the formation of a new coalition tomorrow and that it would include Moshe Dayan as Defense Minister.

title: Out of Prehistory
description: The startling discovery of the Hurrian cuneiform tablet containing a cult love song pushes back the frontier of notated music well over a thousand years.

title: Beame Bids Radio and TV Promote City
description: Mayor Beame played pitchman yesterday in a hard sell to the radio and television industry, asking it to devote large segments of air time to promote the positive side of the city.

title: Man Charged in Embezzling
description: CHICAGO, March 5 (UPI)A man who worked as a mail room clerk at the National Boulevard Bank of Chicago was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday and charged with embezzling $185,000 In United States Treasury bills. An F.B.I. spokesman said Reynold A. Mohammed worked in the bank's mail room for, about six months when he allegedly stole the bills about Feb. 14.

title: Bridge:
description: Responding to doubles of one notrump opening bids is a murky area in which there are two schools of thought. The majority nearly always bids. The minority, but a minority that includes nearly all the topranked players, nearly always passes.

title: Auto Group Finds 20% of Gas Stations Lacking Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Twenty per cent of service stations have been found, in a national random survey, to be without gasoline, the American Automobile Association said today.

title: New Orders at Factories Rose Sharply in January
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Manufacturers' new orders took a huge jump of $4.12billion in January to a record after a decline in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: The stock market climbed 19.24 points yesterday, registering its biggest advance in two months in heavy trading spurred by hopes of an early end to the Arab oil embargo. Page 47.

title: Take a Cab
description: City officials understandably stressed the importance of Federal funds to help save the 35cent transit fare when testifying before a Senate transportation subcommittee hearing here the other day. But the experience of the subcommittee's chairman, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, points up that cost isn't the only consideration affecting ridership on the city's subway system.

title: Bangor Punta Head Says It Can Weather Storm
description: David Wallace, chairman of the Bangor Punta Corporation, told the annual meeting in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday that the conglomerate is experiencing a very severe cash flow, but he added the company can weather the storm if Management is free to make the right decisions.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top 20, with points figured an a 10987654321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records through games of last Saturday with total points.

title: 40 Hours in Great Swamp: Ordeal of a Boy and a Dog
description: CHATHAM TOWNSHIP, March 5Kurt Wagner took Brans, his 160pound great Dane, for a walk last Saturday night. Planning to be gone for only half an hour or so, the 13yearold boy wore only a denim jacket, jeans and a Tshirt.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Moldavian Farms Go Conglomerate
description: SOROKI, U.S.S.R.,In tidy rows of barrackslike buildings outside this northern Moldavian town, 54,000 pigs a year go from birth to the slaughterhouseevidence of a transformation that could change the face of Soviet agricuture. Until the modern complex went into operation last year, hog production in the Soroki region had been scattered among 15 collective farms.

title: FREEDOM GRANTED TO PAROLE VIOLATOR
description: A 31yearold man who violated his parole by coming to live in New York from Alabama two years ago was set free yesterday in Criminal Court in Queens after being arrested on an extradition warrant two weeks ago.

title: 70Member Citizens' Panel Scores State Parole System
description: The state parole system, in troduced in 1876 as a means of softening the harshness of prison, was attacked yesterday by a citizens' group as oppressive and arbitrary, a tragic failure and beyond reform.

title: DuPont Glore Sets Closings
description: DuPont Glore Forgan confirmed yesterday that it had closed five of its brokerage offices in Europe. The firm said offices in Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Lausanne, London and Paris were closed as of March 1. The brokerage house associated with duPont Walston has been negotiating for the sale Or lease of some of its foreign branches since duPont Walston announced in January it was getting out of the brokerage business.

title: Farr, Lions' Back, Traded to Oilers
description: DETROIT, March 5 (UPI)Mel Farr, a sevenyear running back with the Detroit Lions, was traded today to the Houston Oilers for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: CANADA PUSHING DEAL WITH CUBA
description: OTTAWA, March 5Resentment of a United States law that is blocking an $18million sale of Canadian locomotives to Cuba has stirred the Parliament here, with opposition members demanding that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government take steps to assure that the pending deal goes through in spite of opposition by Washington.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Sale of Tams Reported Near

title: Legal Question Over Jury Report Baffling
description: WASHINGTON, March 5By 10 A.M. tomorrow, Judge John J. Sirica's courtroom will be filled with lawyers eager to speak definitively about what the judge should do with the secret report that the Watergate grand jury gave him last week for forwarding to the House impeachment inquiry.

title: Ives and Schubert MiniFestivals Set
description: The New York Philharmonic and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will join forces for the first time to present two weeklong MiniFestivals during the 19741975 season.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: South America and West Indies etc. ATLANTIC MERCHANT (Atlantic), St. Maarten March 17, Antigua 18, Barbados 19, Trinidad 22, Georgetown 24 and Paramaribo 26; sails from 39th St., Brooklyn. MICHELANGELO (Italian), nineday West Indies Cruise; sails 4 P.M. from W. 46th St.

title: KERRM'GEE LOSES ANTITRUST DECISION
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 5 (AP)  The KerrMcGee Chemical Corporation monopolized trade in ammonium perchlorate, a key ingredient in solid rocket propellent, and illegally priced the chemical in violation of antitrust laws from 1966 to 1970, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: MRS. HENRY HERSHBERG
description: Mrs. Rebecca Grun Hershberg, a retired teacher at the Traphagen School of Design, and the wife of Henry Hershberg, a retired school principal, died yesterday in the Riverdale Nursing Home. She was 70 years old and lived at 3280 Rochambeau Avenue in the Bronx.

title: FRAUD CASE FILED ON SEABOARD CORP.
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in Federal court today that investors were defrauded of $9million through muttialfund manipulations and disajpropriation of funds by offices of the Seaboard Corporation of Los Angeles, a mutual fund management concern, and yarious brokerage firms.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, March 5, 1974 (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: 21 Going on Trial Oct. 1 In Equity Funding Case
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5 (UPI)  Former executives and employes of the Equity Funding Corporation will go on trial here Oct. 1. The Government charges that the concern created thousands of fictitious insurance polides that were sold at a profit to other companies.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
Wilson's Second Chance
description: We've got a job to do, said Harold Wilson as he stood once again on the threshold of 10 Downing Street as Britain's Prime Minister. We can only do that job as one people. If Mr. Wilson gears his actions to his own maxim his minority Labor Government may not merely survive for a considerable period but may serve a hardpressed country well in one of its worst economic crises since World War II.

title: DonatedArt Auction to Finance Renovation of Carnegie Mansion
description: Nearly 200 objects of fine and decorative arts and pieces of jewelryall donatedwill be auctioned or sold through sealed bids on March 19 to help finance renovations of the Interior of the Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue, now the CooperHewitt Museum of Decorative Arts and Design.

title: Brezhnev Cites Big Loss In Soviet Grain Storage
description: MOSCOW, March 5Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, has disclosed that Soviet agriculture suffered large losses of grain during last year's record harvest because of inadequate storage and transport facilities.

title: ROTHKO OIL PRICES STIR ARGUMENTS
description: Prices paid for paintings by Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist, during his lifetime by Mary Lasker, Edward Albee and Dr. Franz Meyer were cited yesterday in Surrogate's Court by lawyers defending a contract made by the executors selling or consigning all of his paintings to Marlborough Gallery le after his death by suicide Feb. 25, 1970.

title: U.S. SAYS ALLIES FAIL TO CONSULT
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 The State Department complained today that the ninenation European Economic Community had failed to consult the United States in advance of its offer of loniterm economic and technical cooperation to the Arab countries yesterday.

title: Prosecutor, Facing Tax Fraud Charges, Is Apparent Suicide
description: GREENSBURG, Pa., March 5 (AP)Robert W. Duggan, district attorney of Allegheny County, was found shot to death in a field at his home early today, hours before a Federal grand jury in nearby Pittsburgh indicted him for income tax fraud.

title: NASA REORGANIZING FOR '70'S AND '80'S
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today a reorganization in which Dr. Rocco Petrone, former director of the Apollo program, will be responsible for all of the space agency's research and development programs.

title: Marketplace:
description: Americans have always had a love affair with sugar. despite the admonitions of family dentists. Lately, the sweet tooth has paid off for owners of sugar stocks.

title: Democratic Leaders Will Try to Select Balanced Ticket for the State Primary
description: Top Democratic leaders have agreed to try to put together a Democratic state ticket representing various ethnic and rellgous groups before the Democratic State Committee's endorsement meeting in midJune, in an effort to reduce the number of candidates in the Democratic primary.

title: Rhodes of Ohio Testifies
description: CLEVELAND, March 5 (UPI) Ohio's former Governor, James A. Rhodes, testified today before the Federal grand jury investigating the May 4, 1970, killing of four Kent State University students by National Guard troops. The former Governor, who called out the Guard at the time, testified for 90 minutes, but could not comment on what questions he was asked or what he had told the jury.

title: Bobby Allison's Pit Crew Has Its Moment of Glory
description: Perhaps the first reference to, pit crews is found in the Bible: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein (Proverbs, 26:27). But whereas the author probably witnessed a sloppy job of refueling at a chariot race, by the time Alexander Pope came around, the men in the pits were already proficient.

title: Mitchell Is Linked To Vesco by Sears
description: The Government started yesterday to get to the core of its case against John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, with the first testimony linking former Attorney General Mitchell to Robert L. Vesco, the financier who is now a fugitive.

title: People and Business
description: The Exxon Corporation yesterday announced the nomination of Martha Peterson, president of Barnard College, to its board of directors.

title: DEFENSE OBJECTIONS LOST IN BROWN TRIAL
description: Despite defense objections, a former assistant district attorney and a detective both testified yesterday in the case of Henry S. Brown, on trial in the murder of Police Officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie.

title: Hope Is Seen for Easing Of Oil Curb at Arab Talks
description: KUWAIT, March 5The meeting of Arab oil ministers to be held in Libya Sunday holds out strong prospects for a relaxation of Arab oil restrictions, including the embargo against the United States, according to Arab diplomatic sources.

title: U.S SAYS ALLIES FAIL TO CONSULT
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 The State Department complained today that the ninenation European Economic Community had failed to consult the United States in advance of its offer of longterm economic and technical cooperation to the Arab countries yesterday.

title: Out of Prehistory
description: The startling discovery of the Hurrian cuneiform tablet containing a cult love song pushes back the frontier of notated music well over a thousand years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: SPANS IS LINKED TO CASH DEMAND
description: A Government witness testified yesterday that he had been told that Maurice H. Stans had asked Robert L. Vesco, a financier undergoing a Federal investigation, to make his $200,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign in cash.

title: SEARCH FOR BALLOON IN ATLANTIC HALTED
description: WASHINGTON, March (Reuters)The Defense Department is officially giving up its plane search in the South Atlantic for a missing American balloonist, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Established Parties In Denmark Lose Votes to Tax Foes
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 6 (UPI)  Denmark's political establishment lost ground today in nationwide municipal elections to new parties advocating tax cuts.

title: SHIP LAUNCHINGS SET WORLD RECORD AGAIN
description: LONDON, March 2 (AP)Ships launched throughout the world in 1973 reached record figures for the eighth straight year, Lloyds Register of Shipping reports.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mario M. Cuomo withheld for political reasons two dramatic facts from his 1972 compromise report on the Forest Hills housing project: that a number of blacks were opposed to it and that the controversy touched off a serious increase in the vacancy rate in Forest Hills apartments. Mr. Cuomo reveals and explains these points in his coming book on the 163 days in which he investigated, wrote and fought for the compromise proposal that scaled the controversial project in half. The book is called Crisis of Low Income Housing:. Forest Hills Diary. Mr. Cuomo says that it was a mistake to have chosen the Forest Hills site, but that by time he came into it, it would have been an even bigger mistake to have dropped the project.

title: New Testimony
description: President Nixon has wisely pulled away from a constitutional confrontation with the Congressional impeachment investigators at this time, though the full extent of his readiness to cooperate is yet to be tested.

title: Embargo by Bauxite Producers Unlikely
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 6The seven nations that produce about 63 per cent of the world's bauxite will probably not attempt actions similar to the Arab oil embargo during their meeting now going on in Conakry, Guinea, informed sources predicted here.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Miami Beach  James Scott, 176 pounds, Newark, knocked out Baby Boy Rolle, 180, the Bahamas, 8 rounds.

title: Gasoline Prices Raised 3 Cents by Sun Oil Co.
description: Citing higher costs of raw materials, the Sun Oil Company raised yesterday its gasoline prices by 3 cents a gallon, effective immediately.

title: Mayors Plan Road Show On Energy Crisis Problems
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) The United States Conference of Mayors plans a road show to make cities realize they are taking the brunt of joblessness caused by the energy crisis.

title: St. Clair Says President Will Submit to Questions
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Nixon has agreed to turn over to the House committee considering impeachment all the documents and tape recordings that the White House has sent to the special prosecutor, Leon. Jaworski, the President's lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today.

title: FEDERAL PAY RISE BARRED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Senate today sidestepped a politically sensitive issue in an election year by killing all proposed salary increases for Congress, the Federal judiciary and toplevel Federal officials.

title: Saw Mill's A Different Dog Show
description: Saw Mill River stands alone.

title: 52Week Bills Rose At the Treasary Sale
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The yield on United States Treasury 52week bills rose in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: JAPAN IS WARNED BY OIL COMPANIE
description: TOKYO, March 6The pres. ident of the Japanese subsidiary of the Mobil Oil Corporatior asserted today that several oil companies here were in serious danger of going bankrupt because they were caught between the vastly increased prices of crude oil and a Japanese Government price freeze on petroleum products.

title: A.B.C. Official Assails Ratings of Children's Shows
description: James E. Duffy, president of the American Broadcasting Company's television network, has identified national audience ratings for children's programs on Saturday mornings as one of the deterrents to the improvement of children's fare.

title: CLINTON T. LOVATT
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., March 6Clinton T. Lovatt, president) since the midnineteenforties of the Rockland Real Estate Company, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Music: Trio From Japan
description: When an ensemble such as the Japan Trio comes together to devote itself to a significant segment of the chambermusic repertory, the instinctive response of the serious musiclover is positive. Since fortunes are not made in this field, love of the art must be the motivating factor. Thus, the Japan Trio's performances of piano trios by Schubert, Ravel and Ives at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night were to be admired for the dedication and musical sensibilities they revealed.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Yacovelli Refuses to Testify Before a Jury in Brooklyn
description: Joseph Yacovelli, the reputed acting boss of the organizedcrime family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., appeared briefly before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday and was excused after he exercised his constitutional right and refused to testify.

title: Wilson Reception by Labor Proves Shock to Samuels
description: Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic gubernatorial contender, declared yesterday that the friendly reception given Governor Wilson by the state A.F.L.C.I.O. leaders Monday was a shock to me and added that he could not believe that labor would support the Governor in the November election.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Maroh 6Growth of consumer instaljment credit rebounded. in January from the twoyear low established in December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Poll Finds Films Regaining Popularity
description: Nearly half of all persons interviewed in the latest survey 46 per centsaid that watching television was their favorite way of spending an evening. However, the popularity of television has not increased since a 1966 survey when the same proportion named it as their favorite pastime.

title: TERENZIO REFUSES CITY HOSPITAL JOB
description: The leading candidate for the presidency of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, Joseph V. Terenzio, has formally withdrawn his name from the list of contenders, causing search committee to begin again its sevenmonthold effort to find a man for the job.

title: Nets Defeat Q's, 12397; Regain Lead
ADVANCE NARROW FOR RETAIL SALES
description: Bigstore retailing in New York and the metropolitan area, affected by the gasoline shortage and erratic consumer buying of durables, started its new fiscal year last month on a slow, disappointing note.

title: Albany Minority Caucus Assails Legislators' Districting Tactics
description: ALBANY, March 6The I. Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus charged today that politicians had been using divisive ethnic tactics in al attempt to discourage them from suppprting a Federal in quiry into the racial equity New York City's legislative districts.

title: METROPOLITAN LIFE SHOWS SALES UP 13%
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company registered a 13.4 per cent rise in sales to $18.1billion last year, Richard R. Shinn president and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

title: New Traffic Curbs Golnto Effect Today On Hudson Parkway
description: There is a new slowdown order for motorists on the city's most ramshackled route  the Henry Hudson Parkway and West Side Highway.

title: Miss Wade Victor In Dallas, 75, 61
description: DALLAS, March 6 (AP)Virginia Wade of Britain moved into the second round of the Maureen Connolly Brinker women's tennis tournament today with a 75, 61 victory over Kristy Pigeon of Danville, Calif. Miss Pigeon made five doublefaults in the first set.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, March 8

title: ExSchool Chief in Philadelphia To Head Connecticut Education
description: HARTFORD, March 6Dr. Mark Shedd, a controversial, reformminded former Superin tendent of Schools in PhiladelI 1phia, was named Connecticut's Commissioner of Education today.

title: I.C.C. Tells Smokers to Sit In Back of Interstate Buses
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Smokers are to be banished to the back of the bus on longdistance trips as a result of an order issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Ohio's Election: A Clue to November Races
description: CINCINNATI, March 6The Republicans and Democrats split two special elections yesterday., and today, to no one's surprise, the politicians were full of phrases like Mexican standoff and inconclusive outcome. But the situation is not that simple, for several reasons. In truth, it was a better day for the Democrats than the Watergatebattered Republicans, if less than the Republican disaster it might have been.

title: Yevtushenko Is Publicly Criticized by the Soviet Writers' Union
description: MOSCOW, March 6The Soviet Writers' Union establishment today publicly criticized the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko for his statement on Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn and warned him to stay out of ideological controversies.

title: The Opera
description: The Mannes College Opera Workshop unveiled the two winners of its 1973 opera competition on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y.M. & Y.W.H.A.: To Let the Captive Go by Frank Graham Stewart and The System by Jan Bach. Both works are in one act and there any resemblance between them ceases.

title: Chess Mobility of Opposite Bishops Is a Horse of Another Color
description: The drawing tendencies of bishops of opposite color have traditionally been overrated. One of the main reasons for this has been the evaluation of them in terms of material, without sufficient regard for positional factors.

title: Bill on Mailing Lists Offered
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, introduced a bill today to prohibit placing a person's name on a mailing list without the individual's consent. Violators would be subject to a year's imprisonment or $1,000 fine; telephone directories, government lists and similar directories would be exempt from the provisions.

title: With Right Equipment, the Kitchen Isn't an Obstacle Course
description: Niccolo Paganini (17821840) was a legendary showoff. During the course of a concert he would, in the middle of a concerto, sonata or whatever, snip one of the strings of his violin and continue unabated on three strings.

title: Stage: The Andrews Sisters Return
description: The Andrews Sisters are as American as apple pie, apple blossom and apple tree. Patty, Maxine and LaVerne, and their closeharmony vocalizing became embedded in the mythology of World War II, along with Glenn Miller's trombone, Benny Goodman's clarinet, Harry James's trumpet, Betty Grable's legs, Sonja Henie's skates, Esther Williams's swimsuits; F.D.R.'s cigarette holder, war bonds, stagedoor canteens, Spam and other signs of the times.

title: General Motors Will Increase Output of Transit Buses by 40%
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its output of transit buses by 40 per cent beginning next week. Production of buses will be expanded from 35 units to 50 units a week in addition to the construction of 10 intercity models:

title: People and Business
description: William C. Freund, vice President and chief economist, of the. New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that there was hope for an easing of the currently high rate of inflation by the end of the year.

title: FASHION TALK Summer Comfort
description: Everybody knows that clothes are getting looser and Ilia Wacs, in his summer collection on Seventh Avenue, makes it easy to make the adjustment from the familiar bodyclinging looks.

title: Paris Rejects Criticism
description: PARIS, March 6The French reacted sharply today to new American criticism of their policies and those of their partners in the European Common Market.

title: City Told Not to Put More Relief Clients Near Twain School
description: Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein yesterday directed city agencies to refrain from, moving welfare families into a deteriorating twoblock area of Coney Island near Mark Twain Junior High School so that the area could be added to the urbanrenewal district there.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was

title: MOBIL WILL IMPORT SUBSTANTIAL FUEL
description: The Mobil Oll Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to import substantial additional supplies of gasoline and crude oil in the coming weeks.

title: Professional Gamblers Copy Churches' Las Vegas Nites
description: For several years synagogues and churches in Brooklyn and Queens have been running Las Vegas Nites  weekend evenings of blackjack, craps, poker and wheel games  to raise money.

title: 6 in Masks Set Blaze At Madrid University
description: MADRID, March 6 (AP)Six masked youths armed with heavy chains set fire to the dean's office early today at the Madrid University School of Political Science.

title: HUROK SERVICE SET FOR CARNEGIE HALL
description: A funeral service for Sol Hurok, who died of a heart attack Tuesday afternoon at the age of 85, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in Carnegie Hall.

title: Consumer Notes: Egg Substitute Is Rated on Nutrition
description: You can, these days, eat a standard American breakfast that looks or tastes like orange juice, bacon, eggs and the cream in the coffee without coming within miles of the real thing or, in some cases, of any food at all.

title: U.S. AIDE IN INDIA CRITICIZED AGAIN
description: NEW DELHI, March 6Pri. vate comments by Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan about United States plans to establish a naval and air base in the Indin Ocean erupted today into controversy that annoyed and embarrassed the American Embassy here.

title: On Welfare Reform
description: WASHINGTONIn his 1974 State of the Union Message, President Nixon made a welcome commitment to submit a new welfare reform plan to the Congress. Unfortunately, the 93d Congress with less than a year, and Watergate, ahead of it cannot reasonably be expected to enact fundamental welfare reform legislation this year.

title: Ohio's Storm Warning
description: The result of the special election in Ohio's First Congressional District may not be quite so ominous for the Republican party as last month's Democratic triumph Michigan, but it doesn't miss by much. A district that has gone Republican all but three times in this century and those in years of nationwide Democratic landslideshad to be moved strongly to elect Democrat Thomas A. Luken over his Republican rival.

title: An AllStar Tale of Two Cities for Seniors Only
description: New York City and Philadelphia colleges have agreed to be opponents for a day in the form of two allstar basketball games at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, on April 6, a Saturday. There will be a college division game and a universitydivision game involving selected senior players. This is the first such venture in postseason pickup games matching teams from two of the nation's oldest basketball cities.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Jacksonville University yesterday became the 12th basketball team for the 16team field in the 37th annual National Invitation Tournament, scheduled for Madison, Square Garden March 16 to 24.

title: Drivers Granted Hearing
description: A probable drivers' walk+out at Yonkers Raceway was averted a few hours before post time yesterday when the chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board agreed to discuss horsemen's complaints over stricter regulations.

title: Velasquez Rides Five Winners
Bahamas to Try American
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, March 6 (AP)Michaia Shobek, a 19yearold from Wisconsin, has been ordered to stand trial in the slayings of three American tourists here. Mr. Shobek, who has refused to speak with Magistrate Wilton Hercules, maintained silence when his prelimnary hearing ended today.

title: STANS IS LINKED TO CASH DEMAND
description: A Government witness testified yesterday that he had been told that Maurice H. Stans had asked Robert L. Vesco, a finander undergoing a Federal investigation, to make his $200,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign in cash.

title: SmallCollege Ratings COACH'S POLL
description: (Final ratings of too 15 teams with number of firstplace votes in parentheses.)

title: PROF. EDWIN C. ROSWENC
description: AMHERST, Mass., March 6Dr. Edwin C. Roswenc, Dwight Morrow Professor of History at Amherst College, died yesterday at his home. He was 59 years old.

title: People in Sports
description: Richard (Digger) Phelps, who lifted Notre Dame basketball from mediocrity to high national ranking, was named coach of the year yesterday by United Press International.

title: Met Finds Vase Purchase Legal
description: Douglas Dillon, president the Metropolitan Museum of Art's board of trustees, and Thomas P. F. Roving, director of the museum, said yesterday that it was their considered judgment, after a long inquiry, that the Euphronios vase the museum acquired in 1972 and lawfully purchased and was not smuggled out of Italy.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Measles Spreading in Jersey

title: Stamos, Rothko Executor, Tells Of Friend's Artistic Progress
description: Theodoros Stamos, an abstract expressionist whose paintings hang in a good many museums, obligingly analyzed and described the work of his friend the late Mark Rothko yesterday in Surrogate's Court in reply to questions from Surrogate Millard L. Midonick and a lawyer.

title: Notes on People
description: The SecretaryGeneral of the Action Committee on AmericanArab Relations, Dr. M. T. Mehdl, was fined $250 in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday, on charges stemming from a City Hall demonstration during the Yom Kippur War between the Arab nations and Israel.

title: Advertising: W Shows a Profit
description: W, the bigger, more beautiful bid less businesslike sister newspaper of Women's Wear Daily, will begin its third year in April the way a nice girl should  making money.

title: HANOI HANDS OVER 12 AMERICAN DEAD
description: U. TAPHAO AIR BASE, Thailand, March 6 (UPI) United States military officials today brought back from North Vietnam the bodies of 12 Americans who died in captivity there and expressed the hope that this would lead to an accounting of all Americans still missing in action.

title: L. RICHARD BAMBERGER
description: L. Richard Bamberger, a member of Fahnestock & Co., stockbrokers of 110 Wall Street, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 35 East 85th Street.

title: Mrs. Meir Forms Cabinet; Syrian FlareUp Doubted
description: JERUSALEM, March 6Premier Golda Meir announced the formation of a new coalition Cabinet tonight, ending nine weeks of domestic political stalemate in Israel.

title: Dual Approach to Problem Of Discarded Cans Urged
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 6John L. Loeb Jr., chairman of the New York State Council of Environmental Advisers, recommended today both a legislative and voluntary solution to the litter problem created by discarded bottles and cans.

title: Rita Hunter Gets Ready for Met Role She Hopes She Doesn't Have to Sing
description: Rita Hunter rushed about getting costumes pinned, fitted and sewn at the last minute yesterday for a performance she hoped she would never have to sing.

title: Reynolds Begins Tests of Laterite to Obtain Alumina
description: BAUXITE, Ark., March 6 The Reynolds Metals Company began test production here today of alumina, the raw material for aluminum, from Oregon and Washington laterite ores.

title: Mikhail Tikhonravov, 73, Dies; Pioneer in Rocketry and Space
description: MOSCOW, March 6  Prof. Mikhail K. Tikhonravov, one of the Soviet Union's rocketry ploneers, died Monday at the age of 73, it was reported today in the Soviet press.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: MRS. LOUIS I. SNYDER
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., March Mrs. Agnes Tilton Snyder, pianist and composer, died Monday at her home here. She was in her nineties and was the widow of Louis L Snyder.

title: FEDERAL PAY RISE BARRED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Senate today sidestepped a politically sensitive issue in an election year by killing all proposed salary increases for Congress, the Federal judiciary and toplevel Federal officials.

title: L.I. Boy, 8, Kidnapped in Car On His Way Home From School
description: An 8yearold boy walking home from elementary school with a companion in Dix Hills, L. I., was enticed into a car and kidnapped yesterday afternoon by three persons, the police reported.

title: U.S. Promises to Support Thai Effort for Democracy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Mara 6 (Reuters)Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth Ruth today pledged United States support for Thailand's efforts to bulk a constitutional democracy, which he described as one of the most promising develop. ments in Asian political affairs.

title: PENTAGON'S STAN ON ELLIERG TOLD
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Nixon authorized prosecution of Daniel Ellsbe after publication of the Pent gon papers in June, 1971, eve though the Defense Departmet objected to the court case national security grounds, wellplaced sources said today.

title: What Mr. Heath Lacked
description: During the recent British election campaign, Roy Jenkins of the Labor party was moved to compliment Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath for stubbornness or determination. But Mr. Jenkins added: The tragedy is that Mr. Heath does not accompany these qualities with judgment, persuasiveness or imagination to see across the chasm of disagreement into the minds of others who disagree with him.

title: LeI. MAN IS GUILTY IN $256,000 FRAUD
description: MINEOLA, L. L, March 6Nathan Lemler was found guilty today of 20 of 21 counts of grand larceny for having (bilked 19 families out of $256,000 by making false promises to place their children in medical or dental schools.

title: St. Clair Says President Will Submit to Questions
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Nixon has agreed turn over to the House committee considering impeachment all the documents and tape recordings that the White House has sent to the special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, the President's lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today.

title: Architect Named Director Of City Planning Board
description: Charles M. Smith Jr., a 42yearold architect and planner, was appointed executive director of the City Planning Commission yesterday. He is director of the Queens office of the Department of City Planning.

title: Child Dies in Brooklyn Fire
description: Fire swept through a secondfloor apartment at 40 Wyckoff Street in South Brooklyn yesterday, and an 18monthold girl found in the apartment was pronounced dead later at Kings County Hospital. The child was identified as Marisol Corteguera.

title: RILAND JURY IS TOLD OF INCOMEDATA GAP
description: An Internal Revenue Service auditor told a Federal jury here yesterday that a doctor who treated President Nixon and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller could not explain the source of $19,000 that was not reported on his incometax returns.

title: Goldman Sworn in as Culture Chief
description: It was matinee day yesterday, but the Broadway show bus was leaving from Shubert Alley. The destination was City Hall, where Irving Goldman, head of the Shubert Theater empire, was to be installed by Mayor Beame as his Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

title: Mrs. O'Leary's Cow
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Like Mrs. O'Leary's cow, which supposedly kicked over a lantern and started the great Chicago fire, I might have been personally responsible for the whole Watergate conflagration.

title: ABORTION DEBATED BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON. March 6Advocates and opponents abortion clashed today at hearing on constirtutional amendments that would over turn last year's Supreme Court decision legalizing such opera. tons.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Jacksonville University yesterday became the 12th basketball team for the 16team field in the 37th annual National Invitation Tournament, scheduled for Madison Square Garden March 16 to 24.

title: Fire Hazards to Be Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)  The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that it would conduct public hearings to consider possible fire hazards arising from aluminum wiring in two million homes.

title: Law Firms Shifting From Wall St.
description: Ten years ago, the partners thought it absolutely necessary for us to have a Wall Street address, recalls Louis Auchincloss, the lawyerauthor. None of them feels that way now.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Affairs
description: Following is a transcript of President, Nixon's news conference in the Eait Room of the White House last night as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Kissinger Reviewing Policy
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Top Administration officials said today that the Government had begun reexamining its policy toward France in view of what it regards as the French policy of trying to separate the European Common Market from the United States.

title: MINERS IN BRITAIN END THEIR STRIKE; GET RAISE OF 35%
description: LONDON, March 6Britain's striking coal miners and her new Government reached agreement tonight on a pay increase that met the union's demands virtually in full.

title: Agency Tells Chrysler to Recall 825,000 '73 Models to Cut Smog
description: DETROIT, March 6The Environmental Protection Agency ordered the Chrysler Corporation today to recall 825,000 of its 1973 model automobiles and 1,000 of the 1974 model trucks because of a defect in the pollution control system.

title: I.R.S. Revokes 1969 I.T.T. Tax Ruling That Eased Hartford Fire Co. Merger
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Internal Revenue Service revoked today a 1969 tax ruling that enabled the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to acquire the Hartford Fire Insurance Company for $1.5billion.

title: Contract Awards
description: Canadian Kellogg Company, Ltd., a unit of Pullman, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received a contract for about $45million to design and build a large ammonia plant near Brooks, Alberta. The award was received from PanCanadian Petroleum, Ltd.

title: Amex Prices Rise as the Volume Slows
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose to their highest level in more than three months yesterday although volume dipped slightly. Advances also were scored in the overthecorter market as volume fell somewhat.

title: Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook

title: KHRUSHCHEV TAPE IS REVEALED HERE
description: Time Inc. disclosed yesterday that it had 180 hours of taperecorded memoirs dictated by Nildta S. Khrushchev, the former Soviet leader, in its possession and was presenting them to the Oral History Collection of Columbia University.

title: NIXON INSISTS HE DIDN'T AUTHORIZE HUSH MONEY IN WATERGATE CASES; OFFERS TESTIMONY TO RODINO UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Nixon denied tonight that he had ever approved paying hush money or granting executive clemency to Watergate defendants.

title: TRANSIT BILL DEAD, SPONSOR ASSERTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 The House Rules Committee in effect killed the HouseSenate conference bill on urban mass transit today, an action that, the bill's sponsors said, virtually doomed New York City's 35cent fare.

title: NEW ROLE IS SEEN FOR WIFE OF MAO
description: HONG KONG, March 6Mao Tsetung's wife, Chiang Ching, appears to be reemerging as a major political force in Peking, resuming an active role as spearhead of a radical faction there.

title: A Metric Measurement Bill Voted by House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (Reuters)The House Rules Committee approved today a bill establishing a national board to convert the United States to the metric measurement system over a 10year period.

title: Mix, Carter Help 76ers Win, 11299
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 6 (UPI)Steve Mix and Fred Carter combined for 53 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 11299 victory over the Capital Bullets in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Panel Says an Informed Public Would Demand Prison Reform
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) A congressional subcommittee that has been studying the nation's prison system says the American people would insist on improving it if they knew more about it.

title: VORSTER CONFERS WITH TOP BLACKS
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 6Prime Minister John Vorster had discussions today with the black leaders of South Africa's eight tribal homelandsthe first time that such an official meeting had taken place between blacks and whites in this country.

title: Injury Risk Stressed in HotDogging
description: Skiers not wishing to expose their spinal cords to unnecessary risk of injury would be wise to avoid hotdogging, the daredevil aspect of the sport that involves doing acrobatics and stunts on skis.

title: Nixon Hopeful, but Avoids Predicting Oil Ban's End
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Nixon said tonight that he thought the American efforts to spur a Middle East settlement would Inevitably lead to a lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States. But he declined to predict flatly that this would happen because indicating what they will do might lead them to do otherwise.

title: NIXON INSISTS HE DIDN'T AUTHORIZE HUSH MONEY IN WATERGATE CASES; OFFERS TESTIMONY TO RODINO UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 President Nixon denied tonight that he had ever approved paying hush money or granting executive clemency to Watergate defendants.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IRON MAN The Friends of Cast Iron Architecture are the particular watchdogs of our old ironfront buildings still prevalent in lower Manhattan. The organization sponsors walking tours, in season, and in general campaigns for the preservation of cast iron. Once a year, it offers a scholarly lecture by someone who is deep into cast iron and the third annual one of these takes place at 7:30 o'clock tonight in the auditorium of the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street (7906447).

title: Legislators Urged to Outlaw Sex Bias' in Insurance
description: ALBANY, March 6  Elinor Guggenheimer, the city's new Consumer Affairs Commissioner, and at least a dozen other witnesses urged an Assembly committee today to eliminate all actuarial and cost considerations from insurance in the interest of removing sex discrimination from the insurance industry.

title: Thruway Authority Lifts Ban On Sale of Gasoline on Sunday
description: The New York State Thruway Authority said yesterday that it was ending its ban on Sunday sales of gasoline because the ban was causing too much hardship and inconvenience to travelers.

title: European Football
description: BY Reuters

title: Slippery Path in Britain
description: LONDON, MARCH 6After all the angry arguments of the past weeks, an unaccustomed peacefulness has descended on the British political scene. Even newspapers that most strongly urged the defeat of Harold Wilson are wishing him luck. He will need it. Quite apart from the country's economic difficulties, he faces the most complicated and slippery political situation that a British Prime Minister has encountered in this century.

title: Hiroko Yajima Puts Energy and Power Into Violin Recital
description: Some of the best chambermusic groups in town include Hiroko Yajima in their concerts, where her playing has matched that of her distinguished colleagues. On Tuesday night the violinist had a chance la her first solo recital here since she made her debut three years ago in the Young Concert Artists Series. This time she was appearing at the Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with Walter Ponce again her skillful and sensitive pianist.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: NARCOTICS AGENTS LOSE TRIAL APPEAL
description: ALTON, Ill., March 6Federal Judge Omer Poos denied today a series of defense motions seeking to dismiss charges against 11 Federal narcotics agents accused of violating the constitutional rights of several southern Illinois families.

title: Sudden Spanish Crackdown Shakes Thin Hopes for Some Liberalization
description: MADRID, March 6If the political mood in Madrid has turned sour after a brief period of hope, it has in some ways followed the lead of this capital's main rival, Barcelona, where skepticism about promised political change has been rife and hope at best cautious.

title: Spectators at the Trial Seek a FrontRow Seat for History
description: The time: 9 A.M. The place: the hallway outside Federal District Judge Leo P. Gagliardi's courtroom. The goal: to get beyond the wooden doors to watch the trial of John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, and Maurice H. Stans, the former Commerce Secretary.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HAVEN LINES TO GET 100 CARS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Connecticut Department of Transportation announced plans yesterday to purchase 100 more airconditioned Cosmopolitan cars for the Penn Central's New Haven commuter line.

title: CHARLES SNIPPER
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6Charles Snipper, who retired in 1964 after 24 years as controller of Ohrbach's, Inc., department stores, died today at St. Mary's Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Flailing the Cities.
description: The Nixon Administration has delivered a blow to New York and the nation's other major cities by manipulating a subservient House Rules Committee to sidetrack a bill that would have provided immediate operating aid to hardpressed transit systems throughout the country.

title: Personal Finance
description: Prices slashed to the bone. . . . We will not be undersold. . . . Plain pipe rack prices. . . . Buy now and save!

title: Met Finds Vase Purchase Legal
description: Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's board of trustees, and Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the museum, said yesterday that it was their considered judgment, after a long inquiry, that the Euphronios vase the museum acquired in 1972 was lawfully purchased and was not smuggled out of Italy.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, MARCH 7, 1974
description: Britain's new Labor Government and leaders of the striking coal miners agreed on a wage settlement that gives the strikers virtually everything they had demanded. The workers are expected to return to their jobs early next week and Prime Minister Wilson will move to end the threeday work week that has crippled most of British industry for more than two months. [1:4.]

title: Bridge: Doctor Docter, Whose Play Was Local, and Notable Too
description: Players of great ability may fail to win public acclaim for a variety of reasons. From choice or necessity they may compete at the club and local level rather than travel to major tournaments. They may fail to find regular partners and team mates of their own caliber. Or they lack the physical stamina for the long haul.

title: Brooklyn BMT Train Derails
description: A BMT train derailed at the Pacific Street station in Brooklyn at 5:45 P.M. yesterday, throwing local southbound train service between Pacific Street and 36th Street out of service during the night. One person on the RR train was injured, but he refused treatment, the Transit Authority said.

title: Soviet Pair Wins Skating Title
description: MUNICH, West Germany, March 6 (UPI)Irina Rodnina and Aleksandr Zaitzev won their second successive title tonight in the pairs event of the world figureskating championships, despite a rare mistake by the 24yearold queen of skating.

title: French Banks Hit by Labor Disputes
description: PARIS, March 6Labor unrest among France's bank workers has disrupted normal banking services and has cut off the supply of new banknotes.

title: Major Health Groups Propose A National Blood Donor System
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Major national health groups proposed today creation of an American blood commission to establish an efficient, allvolunteer national blood donor system by the end of next year.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LAST BUTTERFLY. By Michael Jacot. 221 pages. BobbaMerriil. $6.95.It's a powerful and startling idea: A halfJewish comedian is sent to amuse Jewish children on their way to the gas chambers of Auschwitz. They are stopping off in Czechoslovakia at Terezin, a concentration camp disguised as a new Jewish State. Rumors of gas ovens have leaked out, and the Nazis are afraid that this will turn world opinion more strongly against them, will inspire the Allies to fight even harder. The Jewish State is counterpropaganda especially prepared for the coming visit of International Red Cross officials.

title: Gun Curb Hearings Planned
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)  Representative John Conyers Jr. Democrat of Michigan said today that his subcommittee on crime would attempt to winnow more than 90 gun control hills into one measure and then hold hearings on it next year.

title: A Soviet Career Woman in a Man's World
description: MURMANSK, Soviet Union  Maria Fyodorovna Maksheyeva has a wide and ready smile, a flair for singing sad romances about her youth, and a selfconfident, gregarious manner that can be comradely or commanding toward men as well as women.

title: Arab Hijackers Say Arms Awaited Them On British Airliner
description: AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, March 6 (Reuters) The two young Arabs who hijacked a British airliner to Amsterdam and set it on fire say that the arms and explosives for the operation were hidden in the plane by accomplices before they boarded, police officials here said today.

title: Phnom Penh Force Falls To Open Route 4 to West
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 6, (UPI)  More than 1,000 Government troops, backed by 40 armored personnel carriers, tried tuisuccessfully today to break a Communist blockade of strategic Route 4 only 15 miles west of Phnom Penh.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday ruled that an incurably insane man accused of a violent crime should have the opportunity to avoid lifetime commitment to a state mental hospital. In a 5to0 decision, the court held that the mental patient should be given a chance for freedom despite possible risk to the general public.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, March 6, 1974

title: 12 Questioned for Bell Jury
description: The first 12 prospective jurors from a panel of 80 veniremen were questioned in State Supreme Court yesterday to determine whether they will hear testimony in the murder trial of Herman Bell and four other alleged members of the reputed Black Liberation Army. They are being tried in the ambush shooting of two police officers at a Harlem housing project in May, 1971.

title: Film Rights on Watergate Book Sold
description: A movie company owned by Robert Redford, the actor, has agreed to pay $450,000 for the film rights to a book about the Watergate scandals written by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, two investigative reporters for The Washington Post, the book's publisher, said yesterday.

title: Republican Governors Looking to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts, a Republican; said today that the country would be better off if President Nixon turned his office over to Vice President Ford. Other Republican executives here for the National Governors Conference were clearly tempted to agree.

title: ECONOMIC OUTLOOK HELD POOR IN STATE
description: TRENTON, March 6 (AP)The State Department of Labor and Industry issued a gloomy report today on New Jersey's economy and predicted further slowdowns.

title: Soviet Gain Seen in Peaceful ABlast
description: American scientists monitoring the Soviet Union's atomic energy program believe that the Russians have perfected the use of nuclear explosions for engineering purposes to the point of routine industrial technology in some applications.

title: Columbia Campus Gets Its First Gawk At Streaking Fad
description: Streakers zipped across the Columbia campus early yesterday morning in a display of raw power and unfettered spirits.

title: Assembly Votes to Outlaw Job Queries on Arrests
description: ALBANY, March 6  A bill that would prohibit government agenoies and departments from asking a job applicant whether he had ever been arrested passed the Assembly and was sent to the Senate today.

title: JAMES M'CONNELL, EXU.S. AIDE, DIES
description: HORSEHEADS, N.Y., Mud 6James A. McConnell, Assts tant Secretary of Agriculture during the Eisenhower Admin istration under Secretary Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson died on Sunday in a nursini home here. He was 82 year old.

title: Walking the West Side Highway
description: These days I'm walking the West Side Highway. I'm actually jaunting down the patch of the perpetual tidal wave. Thirty years I've known that road and it's rushed uptown and downtown forever, no less inevitable than high tide and low ebb. Last month it stopped. From my window I saw an emptiness so miraculous had to test it with my shoes.

title: 6 Judges Disqualify Selves From Kerner Case Review
description: CHICAGO, March 6 (UPI)All six judges on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit disqualified themselves today from reviewing a decision that upheld conviction for racetrack stock bribery of former Gov. Otto Kerner, who is also a member of the appeals court. Mr. Kerner has been on leave of absence since his indictment Dec. 19, 1971.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 7, 1974

title: New Bell Cable Can Relay 108,000 Calls at Once
description: An 823mile stretch of what the Bell System describes as the highestcapacity underground telephone cable in the world began carrying calls between the Pittsburgh and St. Louis metropolitan areas yesterday.

title: Princess to See Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 6 (AP)  Officials at Churchill Downs said today that Princess Margaret of England and her husband, Lord Snowden, would attend the 100th running of the Kentucky Derby on May 4.

title: RAMAPO STUDENTS WIN CONCESSIONS
description: MAHWAH, March 6Minor ity students signed an agreement with the administration of Ramapo College here today that was believed to answer the students' demands for greater campus participation.

title: Nixon Vetoes Energy Bill and Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 President Nixon vetoed the emergency energy bill today, and the Senate sustained the rejection in a vote taken within hours of his action.

title: Billy DeWolfe, Comedian, Dies; In Call Me Madam, Other Films
description: LOS ANGELES, March (AP)Billy De Wolfe, the comedianactor, died yesterday after having undergone treatment for lung cancer. His age was 67.

title: Nixon Vetoes Energy Bill and Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 President Nixon vetoed the emergency energy bill today, and the Senate sustained the rejection in a vote taken within hours of his action.

title: FOOD PRICES DROP 2D WEEK IN ROW
description: For the second week in a row, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City declined last week to 1.3 per cent less than the previous week's, it was reported yesterday by Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Kissinger Reviewing Policy
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Top Administration officials said today that the Government had begun reexamining its policy toward. France in view of what it regards as the French policy of trying to separate the European Common Market from the United States.

title: Senators Back Ads On TV Urging $1 In Tax for Elections
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate urged the television networks and local stations today to broadcast on prime time a public service, commercial encouraging each taxpayer to earmark $1 of his tax payment to finance the next Presidential campaign.

title: Shellfish Area Is Opened
description: TRENTON, March 6 (UPI) An eightmile stretch of Little Egg Harbor and Manahawkin Bay has been opened to the taking of shellfish by the state's Environmental Protection Department. The department also announced yesterday that it had closed an area between Brigantine and the Steel Pier in Atlantic City because a high concentration of harmful bacteria from sewage had been found in the surf.

title: WILLIAM ERB, 70, OF PRENTICEHALL
description: PATTERSON, N.Y., March 6 William E. Erb, author and former senior copywriter with PrenticeHall, Inc., died Saturday at the Putnam Community Hospital in Carmel after a stroke. He was 70 years old and lived here.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, March 6In his three years as swimming coach at Princeton, Bill Farley has developed a men's team that he believes is in a class with Michigan and Ohio State, traditional Midwestern powers, and a women's team that has become a national power with a composite record of 24 victories against two losses.

title: Seminary Enrollment Lags
description: ST. LOUIS, March 6 (UPI)Only 78 students began the spring quarter at Concordia Seminary yesterday, while more than 400 former Concordia students were in classes at the seminary in exile. The coexistence of the two seminaries is the result of a deep doctrinal dispute within the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod.

title: G.O.P. CAUTIONED ON COAST VICTORY
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 6Robert J. Lagomarsino, the only Republican winnet in four recent special Congressional elections across the nation, cautioned the national party leadership today against interpreting his victory as a vote of confidence in President Nixon.

title: Palestinians Said to Await U.S. Signal Before Deciding on Mideast Peace Role
description: CAIRO, March 6Informel sources said today that Yasir Arafat and other moderate Palestinian leaders were waiting for a signal of encouragement from Washington before deciding on their attitude towerd the peace effort underway in the Middle East.

title: Market Place: Analysts Meet On McDonald's
description: The management of the McDonald's Corporation greeted securities analysts yesterday at Fraunces Tavern, the same place where General Washington bade farewell to his officers.

title: TaxExempt Issues Lead CreditMarket Advance
description: Bond market prices showed Ii provernent yesterday. The taxexempt sector was the most active and, for the second consecutive day, gave good firstday response to a fairly heavy flow, of new offerings.

title: AID FOR MISS HEARST HINTED BY PRISONERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March (UPI)Two suspected members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army said tonight that they had suggestions that could lead to the release of Patricia Hearst, who was kidnapped Feb. 4.

title: Moscow Refuses to Admit New Newsweek Reporter
description: MOSCOW, March 6The Soviet authorities disclosed today that they were rejecting the application of Newsweek to send a new correspondent here.

title: LEGISLATIVE UNIT CALLED WASTEFUL
description: ALBANY, March 6  The New York Public Interest Research Group, a citizens watch+dog committee, charged today that 20 of the 25 staff members of the Select Committee on Consumer Protection were no+work, noshow employes and that $30,000 of the committee's $85,000 appropriation had been wasted on nonperformers.

title: TRANSIT BILL DEAD, SPONSOR ASSERTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 The House Rules Committee in effect killed the HouseSenate conference bill on urban mass transit today, an action that, the bill's sponsors said, virtually doomed New York City's 35cent fare.

title: Dodge Colt Prices Raised by Chrysler Second Time in '74
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the manufacturers retail price for 1974 Dodge Colt passenger cars by an average of $128, or 4.5 per cent. Chrysler said that accessory prices were being increased on a selective basis. The Colt, a subcompact, is imported by Dodge from Japan. Because it is made abroad, its price is not subject, to Government regulation.

title: Sounding Loud And Clear
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The ceremonial courtroom of the United States Courthouse rang with phrases about the historic character of the case.

title: Cuomo Withheld Key Facts in Report on Forest Hills
description: Mario M. Cuomo withheld, for political reasons, two dramatic facts from his 1972 compromise report that scaled down the controversial Forest Hills scattersite housing project from three 24story buildings to three 12story structures.

title: VENEZUELA REJECTS OIL PRICE CUTBACK
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 6 (UPI)The Venezuelan Mines Minister, Hugo Perez La Salvia, flatly rejected today any possibility of a rollback in Venezuelan oil export prices.

title: Knicks Thwart Hawks' Rally to Win, 9694
description: ATLANTA, March 6  The Atlanta Hawks, on the brink Of playoff elimination for the first time since 1962 when they played in St. Louis, had enough spunk and energy to throw a kingsized scare into the New York Knicks tonight before losing a 9694 decision before a crowd of 5,819 at the Omni.

title: ALBERT ADAMS
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 6Albert Adams, senior partner in the law firm of Ferris, Adams & Creidy at 475 Fifth Avenue, New York, died today of a heart ailment at New Rochelle Hospital. His age; was 71 and he lived here. Mr. Adams was a graduate of the New York University Law School. Surviving are his widow, the former Jeanne Orenstein; a daughter, Mrs. Iris Libresco; a brother, William; a sister, Mrs. Ruth Freedman, and three grandchildren.

title: FIRM STAND TAKEN ON BID BY BEKER
description: The Commercial Solvents Corporation, continuing its firm stand against a stock tender offer made recently by Beker Industries, filed yesterday in the United States District Court here seeking an injunction to halt solicitation of its shares by Beker. Late last week Beker offered to buy as much as 26 per cent of Commercial Solvents' stock for $26.50 a share.

title: Suarez Is Swinging for Players' Rights
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 6Unless they become comedians, like Joe Garagiola, or managers, like Ralph Houk, reserve catchers generally are remembered after their retirement only in baseball trivia contests. Ken Suarez could be different.

title: Oilers Beat Aeros
description: HOUSTON, March 6 (AP)  Edmonton's Ron Climie scored a tiebreaking goal in the third period tonight shortly after Houston's Frank Hughes had missed an opennet goal to lead the Oilers to a 42 Wonld Hockey Association victory over the Aeros.

title: Princeton Streak Cites Candor And Runs for Student President
description: PRINCETON, March 6A Princeton University sophomore is runningbareskinnedfor the student government presidency; but it does not look as if he will run away with the election.

title: 3 National Records Set In High School Track
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 6 Tim Walker, a Rhode Island schoolboy who competed in the United States+Soviet Union track meet last weekend, set a national interscholastic record for the high jump tonight at 6 feet 11 inches.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Celerino Sanchez finally arrived in Fort Lauderdale from Mexico, but still hasn't agreed to terms for 1974. The difference of opinion stems from the little playing time the third baseman had last season. His argument is that it wasn't his fault that he didn't play more; the club contends he doesn't deserve a raise because he didn't do anything to merit one.... Gabe Paul, Yankee president, had a lengthy telephone conversation with Harold Meizler, Sparky Lyle's Boston lawyer, but they didn't get anywhere on contract terms.

title: L.I.U. Five Sets Back Iona, 8473
description: Long Island University posted an 8473 basketball victory over Iona College last night at the winner's court in Brooklyn in the season finale for both teams.

title: 292,400 Report Jobs Lost Because of Fuel Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)The number of Americans seeking or receiving unemployment benefits for jobs they said were lost because of the energy shortage rose to 292,400 last wek, the Labor Department said today.

title: Wounded Knee Judge Says F.B.I. Is Deteriorated Badly
description: ST. PAUL, March 6 (UPI)A Federal judge angrily criticized the Federal Bureau of Investigatoin today, saying it had deteriorated badly, and ordered it to open all its files on the occupation of Wounded Knee in 1973.

title: Article 1  No Title
Oil Watchers Focus on Shah of Iran
description: You can spread the bad news and add that it comes from someone who knows what he is talking about. I know everything there is to know about oil, everything. I'm a real specialist and it's as a specialist that 1 can tell you the price of oil must rise.

title: Kuwait to Invest Riches in Arab Channels
description: KUWAIT, March 6Kuwait intends to deploy her oil riches primarily through channels under Arab control and will not contribute to special funds proposed by the Shah of Iran and the International Monetary Fund to meet the world's oil payments crisis.

title: Jersey Central Conductor Wins $1Million Lottery
description: LODI, March 6 (UPI)A railroad freight conductor won $1million today in the state lottery and called his good fortune the Lord's will.

title: EXECUTOR EXPLAINS SALE OF ROTHKO ART
description: Theodore Stamos, an abstractexpressionist painter, was questioned yesterday about the sale of works by his friend the late Mark Rothko in Surrogate's Court, where Mr. Rothko's daughter, Kate, seeks dismissal of Mr. Stamos and two other executors named by her father.

title: Turco, in Tears, Resigns, Saying He Failed Public
description: NEWARK, March 6  City Councilman Louis M. Turco, the controversial political leader of the city's East Ward, resigned today, tearfully declaring that he had failed as a public official and that he had let down the thousands of people who had supported him.

title: Rangers Rout Canadiens, Tie for 2d
description: Step No. 1 of the Rangers' twostep program toward capturing second place from Montreal went off perfectly last night. With adrenalin flowing in their veins the New Yorkers walloped the Canadiens 92, before a rapturous sellout crowd at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Beame Announces Accord To Keep Rheingold in City
description: Mayor Beame said last night that craftunion problems at the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn had been resolved and that he was optimistic that Rheingold was going to stay in business here under the management of Chock Full O'Nuts.

title: Saints' Walton Scores
description: ST. PAUL, March 6 (AP)Mike Walton scored four goals and led the Minnesota Fighting Saints to an 86 World Hockey Association victory over the New England Whalers tonight.

title: Dave Anderson
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 6His assistant coaches were leaving for lunch.

title: Gross Trial Testimony Is Rebutted by Sherwin
description: COLLINGSWOOD, March 6 (AP)Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State, denied today that he knew of a $44,000 tax fraud scheme allegedly started by two of former Gov. William T. Cahill's other top strategists.

title: Illinois Justice Scored
description: CHICAGO, March 6 (UPI)The American Bar Associations says that, after a study of a year and a half, it has found that the Illinois system of criminal justice fails to meet most minimum standards of quality established by the A.B.A., The Chicago Sun+Times said today.

title: Durham, N.H., Rejects Onassis Refinery Plan
description: DURHAM, N. H., March 6Aristotle Onassis' plans for a giant oil refinery in this university town were given an overwhelming no by voters tonight1,254 to 144.

title: Hiroko Yajima Puts Energy and Power Into Violin Recital
description: Some of the best chamber+music groups in town include Hiroko Yajima in their concerts, where her playing has matched that of her distinguished colleagues. On Tuesday night the violinist had a chance fat her first solo recital here since she made her debut three years ago in the Young Concert Artists Series. This time she was appearing at the Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with Walter Ponce again her skillful and sensitive pianist.

title: Bergen, Essex and Passaic Are Hard Hit As Measles Epidemic Spreads in State
description: HACKENSACK, March 6 The measles epidemic in New Jersey, already described as the worst in more than a decade, appears to be spreading. Counties reporting the most serious spread of the disease are Bergen, Essex and Passaic.

title: Dow Index Up 7.43 As Oil Hopes Grow
description: The stock market posted a modest pin yesterday in active trading amid growing optimism that the Arab oil embargo would end soon.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified pages distributed in metropolitan New York and adiacent territory.

title: 5 TRAPPED IN CARS IN A PARK FLOOD
description: The sudden flooding of a portion of Central Park shortly after 11 o'clock last night trapped at least five persons in their automobiles on the park's 96th Street transverse. They were rescued by two policemen and an auxiliary police sergeant.

title: Dance
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet opened its fourweek season at the City Center last night with more than a couple of oldies that, significantly, are also among the company's recent productions.

title: PRICE TREND OFF IN COMMODITIES
description: The general trend of commodity prices continued to decline yesterday, but the uniform movement of the last week was broken by some scare buying and bargain hunting.

title: The Rev. Jesse Jackson Marks Depar Lure From Yale as a Chubb Fellow With Game of Stickball
description: NEW HAVEN, March 6The Rev. Jesse L, Jackson grasped a bat and glared at the pitcher.

title: . . . Wrecking the Rails
description: The same insensitivity to energy and environmental urgencies that marks the Administration's approach to urban mass transit characterizes its proposals for wholesale abandonment of rail trackage in the Northeast and Midwest.

title: Police Deliver a Baby In Bronx Station House
description: A baby boy was born in the muster room of the Alexander Avenue station house in the Bronx. yesterday morning. Three policemen who assisted in the delivery said mother and son were in good condition.

title: FARMERS' TAX DATA NOT SOUGHT BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) The Agriculture Department's yearold plan to use farmers' income tax returns as a source of mailing lists for statistical surveys is currently inoperative, a top department official said today.

title: U.& MAY STOP AID TO 40,000 INSTATE
description: The state has been notified that 40,000 disabled poor people will be dropped from Federal Supplemental Security Income rolls here on March 31 unless the present law is changed, the Social Security Administration said here yesterday.

title: Iran Puts Iraqi Dead at Over 50 in 3 Days of Fighting
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 6 (UPI)  Iranian and Iraqi forces battled with tanks, mortars and artillery today in what the Iranian Government press agency Pars described as heavy fighting. It was the third consecutive day of combat in a longstanding border dispute.
