title: Mrs. Klein Calls State Approach On Mental Health Inadequate
description: NEWARK, March 6  The Commissioner of State Institutions and Agencies today called New Jersey's approach to mental health care totally inadequate and said that a substantial revamping of it would be one of her top priorities.

title: Paris Crash Spurs F.A.A. To Issue Safety Decree
description: The Federal authorities, alarmed because a DC10 that crashed near Paris Sunday in history's worst air disaster had lost a cargo door in flight, issued an urgent order yesterday to protect other DC10's against this possible cause of the crash.

title: Manila Sets Death Penalty For Rebel Chief and 2 Aides
description: MANILA, March 6 (Reuters)  A Filipino rebel leader and two of his aides, found guilty by a military court of kidnapping and murder, have been sentenced to death by firing squad, the police said today.

title: Justice Charles J. Gaughan Of State Supreme Court
description: BUFFALO, March 6State Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Gaughan, chief administrative judge for the Eighth District, died today in Buffalo General Hospital of cardiac arrest. His age was 52. He lived in suburban Hamburg, of which he was a former Town Court judge and Supervisor.

title: Clarification Made On Hayden, Stone
description: A Washington dispatch reported erroneously yesterday in the first edition of The New York Times that the Securities and Exchange Commission had charged in Los Angeles that investors had been defrauded of $9million through mutualfund manipulations and misappropriation of funds by officers of the Seaboard Corporation of Los Angeles, a mutual fund management concern, and various brokerage firms, including Hayden, Stone, Inc:, of New York.

title: Paris Rejects Criticism
description: PARIS, March 6The French reacted sharply today to new American criticism of their policies and those of their partners in the European Common Market.

title: Ceremonies to Mark Purim's Start Tonight
description: Purim, the colorful Jewish festival that symbolizes religious freedom for all people, will be marked with ceremonies in synagogues and homes beginning at sundown tonight. The festival, which ends at sundown tomorrow, has its roots in the Biblical story of Queen Esther, who saved the Jews from Haman, the Persian tyrant.

title: Aid for Joint Float Is Pledged by Five In Common Market
description: THE HAGUE, March 7The five European Economic Community countries left in the joint European float after France cut the franc loose to float alone will give each other virtually unlimited support if a new monetary crisis arose, the Dutch Finance Minister said today.

title: PAIR IN KIDNAPPING OF EDITOR INDICTED
description: ATLANTA, March 7 (AP)William A. H. Williams and his wife, Betty Puth, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges related to the abduction of J. Reginald Murphy, editor of the editorial page of The Atlanta Constitution.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $799million up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $761million. Total retail store sales were about $9.325billion, up one per cent from last year's $9.251 billion.

description: BASKETBALL

title: FOUR IRAQIS KILLED IN NEW IRAN FIGHTING
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 7 (Reuters)  Iraq said today that four of her soldiers had been killed and dozens wounded in new infantry, artillery ands tank clashes with Iranian forces.

title: Laver Beats Smith in World Cup
description: HARTFORD, March 7 After playing now I've got youno you don't with Stan Smith for a while, Rod Laver, the tenacious Australian, grabbed hold of the lanky American and didnt let go until he had swept past Smith in straight sets tonight to take the first match of the World Cup tennis tournament.

title: A Plea for Fairness to Mr. Nixon
description: WASHINGTONLet's assume that President Nixon, horrified at first learning of the Watergate fiasco, yielded to the very human instinct to try to brush it off, hoping it would all blow over. Let's assume also that in so doing he went along too long with high advisers grown arrogant and corruptible through excessive power.

title: State May Increase, Not Slash, Its Aid For Schooling of Handicapped Children
description: ALBANY, March 7  State aid for the education of handicapped childrenwhich many parents feared was in jeopardy after a ruling by the State Education Commissioner last f allwill not be cut and may, in fact, be increased sharply in the next fiscal year, legislative officials said today.

title: SALES BY CHAINS UP FOR FEBRUARY
description: The shortage of gasoline has only had a slight effect on chainstore sales, a survey of leading companies in the field showed yesterday. February volume was ahead of the level of sales in February, 1973, but the gains were not as large as those registered in January.

title: Market Place: Why Analysts Rejected Plan
description: A proposal to make securities analysis a legally recognized professionconferring status similar to that of a doctor, lawyer, or certified public accountant  apparently will not be introduced before the New York State Legislature this session.

title: PUBLIC ISSUES UNIT APPEALS FOR FUNDS
description: PRINCETON, March 7 (AP)The Center for Analysis of Public Issues, an independent public interest research organization, today announced that it was seeking public contributions to keep operating.

title: Bonn Sees Itself in Middle, Forced to Choose Between Paris and Washington
description: BONN, March 7West German officials and diplomats are saying that they feel the American criticism of the European Common Market's offer of cooperation to the. Arab world has put them in the position of having to choose between France and the United States.

title: Notes on People
description: A former French foreign minister, Maurice Schumann, was elected to the French Academy yesterday, succeeding the late Ambassador Wladimir Dormesson. Mr. Schumann gained national fame during World War II, as spokesman for the Free French on radio programs beamed nightly from London to France. He is a former journalist and the author of political essays and two novels. Also brought Into the Academy, was Robert Aron, a historian best known for two exhaustive studies of France under Occupation and at the time of its liberation. He succeeds the late Georges Izard, a lawyer.

title: Lewis W. Douglas Is Dead; Envoy to Britain 194750
description: Lewis W. Douglas. Ambassador to the Court of St. James's in the late nineteenforties and deputy chief of the War Shipping Administration in World War II, died yesterday morning at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 79 years old and had been in failing health for several years.

title: Amex and Counter Stocks Are Lower
description: Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in lighter trading.

title: Big Drop in Carbon. Monoxide Attributed to Lack of Gasoline
description: A substantial reduction in the level of carbon monoxide pollution in Manhattan has been one of the positive aspects of the gasoline shortage, the city's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday.

title: Finn Takes Skiing Race In Norway
description: OSLO, March 7, (UPI)Juha Mieto of Finland became the second ski runner to successfully defend his crown in the 15kilometer event today in the annual Holmenkollen Nordic ski games.

title: Notes on People Schumann's Accolade
description: A former French foreign minister, Maurice Schumann, was elected to the French Academy yesterday, succeeding the late Ambassador Wladimir Dormesson. Mr. Schumann gained national fame during World War II, as spokesman for the Free French on radio programs beamed nightly from London to France. He is a former journalist and the author of political essays and two novels. Also brought Into the Academy was Robert Mon, a historian best known for two exhaustive studies of France under Nazi occupation and at its liberation. He succeeds the late Georges Izard, a lawyer.

title: Witness Testifies Mitchell Got Fast Action for Vesco
description: John N. Mitchell picked up the phone and made a call that led the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission to meet with a lawyer for Robert L. Vesco within hours after Mr. Vesco contributed $200,000 in cash to President Nixon's reelection campaign, a Government witness testified yesterday.

title: Amex and Counter Stocks Are Lower
description: Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in lighter trading.

title: Nixon Seeks to Limit House To Inquiry on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Nixon, in an apparent attempt to limit the scope of the impeachment inquiry, has refused to give the House Judiciary Committee tape recordings or documents that do not bear directly on the Watergate coverup, the committee disclosed today.

title: National Space Club Issues 1974 Awards
description: Representative Olin E. Teague, chairman of the House Science and Astronautics Committee, has been awarded the Goddard Memorial Trophy by the National Space Club for his contributions to the United States space effort.

title: Mame Puts On New but Familiar Face--Lucille Ball
description: Some great characters of literature will not be still. They keep coming back. Dracula is one. Auntie Mame is another.This determinedly eccentric Beekman Place hostess, who was first introduced to us by Patrick Dennis in his 1955 novel, appeared next as a 1956 Broadway comedy, "Auntie Mame," which was adopted into a 1958 film and then as a 1966 Broadway musical called "Mame," which has now reappeared as a 1974 movie musical.It opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, a little tired though certainly not out of breath. The newest "Mame," with Lucille Ball in the title role wearing a different colored wig for every Administration from Hoover's through Truman's is as determined to please in its way as Mame is in hers.The opening credits, which look like a Cubist collage in motion, are so good they could be a separate subject. The songs by Jerry Herman, when he isn't writing material ("Open a New Window") more fit for a lesser Walt Disney effort, are full of zest and sometimes wit. From time to time the dances by Onna White are allowed to take over the screen, a rare occurrence in most movie musicals these days.It's all relentlessly good-natured but unless you've been packed in storage some where it's so familiar that it puts a tremendous burden on its star. Miss Ball is a great comedienne who has spent the last 20 years creating an in-home image as a lucky nut whose worst-laid plans al-always turn out successfully.When the character of Lucy, an inspired slapstick performer, coincides with that of Auntie Mame, the that of Auntie Mame, the Big-Town sophisticate, "Mame" is marvelous. I think of Lucy's turning a Georgia fox hunt into a gigantic shambles, or of her bringing the curtain down on a New Haven first-night when, as a budding actress, she falls off a huge cardboard moon. I even treasure her prying loose the fingers of a sloshed Beatrice Arthur who won't give up her martini glass.Miss Ball has some great moments but she is not even a nonsinger who fakes singing very well, and as for the dances, well, she just more or less follows what the chorus people do with her, or she stands aside and sort of conducts them. What is worse is that she has been photographed in such soft focus that her face alternately looks beatificall a religious glowor like something sculptured from melting vanilla ice cream.Gene Saks, the director, has so protected Miss Ball's appearance that when the comparatively rugged Robert Preston, who plays Mame's Georgia millionaire, comes into the same frame, he too, becomes suddenly fuzzy of contour, as if he'd walked into a Nylon tent.Neither is the camera (or maybe its the customer) terribly kind to Beatrice Arthur, another fine comediienne who plays Mame's bitchy actress-friend. Miss Arthur ("Maude") has been dressed up to look like a football player in drag, which may be more in keeping with the kind of comedy "Mame" is than I remember from earlier incarnations.So much of it is insult or put-down comedy that when Mame undertakes to save her nephew Patrick (Bruce Davison) from the clutches of bigoted suburban bores, the effect is less funny than smugly rude.The movie does have two first-rate production numbers, one, early on, featuring Miss Ball and her 9-year-old nephew (KirbyFurlong), which becomes a salute to the nineteen-twenties. The other is the title song performed by the star and a chorus of what looks to be about 1,000 redcoated black-toppered fox hunters. Both numbers have a kind of plush, old-fashioned extravagance about them that takes us back not to the periods depicted in the film but to the innocent fifties when movie musicals hadn't yet thought of themselves as significant.I have great reservations about "Mame." but I suspect a lot of people couldn't care less. All things being equal. Mame's next metamorphosis could be as a television series, by which time most of us may be too old to remember that her story wasn't handed down to us on tablets.

title: A Nixon Disclosure Raises New Queries
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Nixon's statemen last night that he learned last March 21 that hush money had been paid to the Watergat?? burglars raised new questions today about his actions after learning of the coverup.

title: Monitor's Fight With Merrimack Began Age of Iron Ships
description: All through the morning of March 9, 1862, the two ugly, metalclad warships  one from the North and one from the South and both unlike any ever to do battle before  hammered at each other in Hampton Roads.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion tonmiles, 1.8 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Carloadings in the same period totaled 526,637 cars, 0.6 per cent below last year.

title: Saxbe Discloses 4Year Effort By F.B.I. to Harass Key Blacks,
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation campaigned for nearly four years to harass and disrupt black militant organizations and their leaders, according to secret agency files disclosed today.

title: U.S. Businessmen Chided On Criticism of Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 7The American business community has been accused of narrow selfinterest following the publication of a survey by the American Chamber of Commerce in Australia. The report concluded that the climate for investment had deteriorated and said the Government was out of tune with the problems and needs of business.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
CommodityBuying Burst Ends WeekLong Declines
description: The weeklong decline in commodity prices ended yesterday in a burst of buying that sent most bids to limit or nearlimit highs.

title: Waldheim Says Worst of African Drought Is Not Over
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7Secretary General Waldheim, back from an inspection of droughtstricken areas of West Africa, said today that thousands weere dying and the worst is definitely not over.

title: Bridge:
description: The world team championship to be played in Venice in May is likely to be a contest on three levels. At the top level, and likely to fight for the world title in the final playoff, will be Italy and North America.

title: Verona Policeman Slain With Own Gun in Game
description: CALDWELL, March 7  A 27yearold Verona policeman was shot to death early today with his own revolver here in what the Eisex County Prosecutor's office described as some sort of Russian roulette game.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball SCORING LEADERS
Germanys Finally Agree on Diplomatic Missions
description: BONN, March 7More than a year after agreeing to establish relations, East and West Germany finally came to an accord today on establishing permanent diplomatic missions in each ether's capitals.

title: Warriors' Final Shot Tops Bucks
description: MIWAUKEE, March 7 (AP) Rick Barry poured in 31 points, the last 2 on a 20foot jump shot at the buzzer, lifting the Golden State Warriors to a 97.95 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: Seton Hall Makes It to N.I.T.
description: Manhattan College, with its bid to the National Invitation Tournament already secured, scored an 8176 victory over Fordham before 12,739 fans in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS STAGE A RETREAT
description: After three days in which the stock market posted sizable gains, issues on the New York Stock Exchange staged a wide retreat yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: Rock Island Asks $100Million Loan

title: S.E.C. Files a Suit Against Avis, Inc., On Profits Source
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against Avis, Inc., the car rental concern, charging it misrepresented the source of its profits in the first quarter of last year.

title: Red Smith
description: Henry Aaron is an honest man and a splendid hitter who has played professional baseball for 22 seasons and given full value to customers in the Northern League, the South Atlantic League and the National League. Now, confused by loyalty to Bill Bartholomay, his present employer, he is saying foolish things.

title: People and Business
description: The president of the Ford Motor Company called yesterday for the abolition of all price controls on and allocations of petroleum products and for the burning of those standby rationing coupons.

title: JEROME V. KEATING, A TIMES COPY EDITOR
description: Jerome V. Keating, who retired as a national news copy editor for The New York Times in 1962, died yesterday in Queens General Hospital, after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 8810 178th Street, Jamaica.

title: Nets Defeat Rockets and Retain Lead
description: DENVER, March 7Mission accomplished, by means of a 114100 victory over the Denver Rockets tonight, the New York Mets prepared to spend tomorrow morning flying to ew York and tomorrow evening battling Kentucky for first place in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Mitchell Book Reportedly Brings Offers of $250,000
description: Book publishers have made offers of up to $250,000 for the memoirs of Mrs. John N. Mitchell, her New York literary attorney reported yesterday, but she is holding out for more.

title: Beame Names McDonnell To City Bargaining Board
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, was named yesterday by Mayor Beame as a member of the city's Board of Collective Bargaining. He will still retain his chairmanship on the state board.

title: Paddle Tennis Gets Its Day on Court
description: NEW CANAAN, March 7 A man driving on Route 123 the other day slowerd as he passed the New Canaan Field Club and then asked his companion: What were those women doing in that cage?

title: Tracks Are Betting on Fiddles, Guitars
description: Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga race tracks will open their doors for the first time to a wide variety of entertainment events after each of their racing meetings ends.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Surgery in MistakenIdentity Case

title: The Lessons of Parole
description: The idea of parole is that if an offender's degree of rehabilitation can be judged and found sufficient, he or she can safely be released from prison; and with that promising start, a program of close supervision can help the offender find a useful place in society. Most of the time, unfortunately, this idea proves to be an illusionprimarily because nobody knows how to bring about rehabilitation or whether it has occurred.

title: North Carolina, Maryland Reach A.C.C. Semifinals
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 7 (UPI)  Fourth ranked North Carolina defeated Wake Forest, 7662, and fifthranked Maryland, whipped Duke, 8566, today in the quarterfinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

title: Three Designs Chosen For Bicentenial Coins
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)A colonial drummer boy, Independence Hall and a Liberty BellMoon combination were announced today as choices for designs for the nation's 1976 bicentennial coins.

title: Spain Is Said to Threaten End of Pact With Vatican
description: MADRID, March 7  The Spanish Government reportedly has threatened to break the accord that has governed Spain's traditionally close relations with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Miles to Head Bridgeport U.
description: ALFRED, N. Y., March 7 (AP)  Dr. Leland Miles announced his resignation today as president of Alfred University to become head of the University of Bridgeport on Aug. 15. Dr. Miles said his decision to resign stemmed from compelling personal reasons. Dr. Miles, who was Alfred's president for eight years, will succeed Dr. Thurston E. Manning, who announced his resignation at Bridgeport Dec. 15.

title: FRENCH BANK STRIKE DELAYS STATE LOAN
description: PARIS, March 7 (Reuters)The Bank of France called in police today to deal with more than 1,000 strikers here as another strike at the big Crdit Lyonnais Bank delayed a major loan to the Government.

title: Theater: The Young Vic
description: The Young Vic, which last night made its press debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has developed over the years as Britain's people's theater. Originally an offshoot of the National Theater in Londonits permanent home is just along the street from the National Theater's Old Vic, hence the titleit is soon to become, under its founder Frank Dunlop, totally autonomous.

title: Federal MassTransit Aid: The Hope That Fizzled
description: WASHINGTON, March 7From the, beginning, the urban masstransit bill was a long shot. The White House, oriented toward conservative middle America, and the ruralsuburban  dominated Congress have provided operating subsidies to farmers, oil men (through tax relief), railroads, airlines and the maritime industry, to name a few. But mass transit, vital to the economy of most larger cities, has been regarded as a sinkhole.

title: TV: Battle Behind News
description: Tonight the Columbia Broadcasting System has two special hours on tap: Really, Raquel, an identity trip with Raquel Welch, at 9 o'clock; and Shanghai, a C.B.S.Reports portrait of that city, at 10 o'clock. Before touching on either, however, I direct your attention to a segment on this Sunday's edition of 60 Minutes that is considerably more special.

title: ThirdMarket Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (Reuters)Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, today introduced a bill that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to prohibit securities listed on national exchanges from being traded overthecounter in the third market.

title: Back to the Gas Lines?
description: President Nixon has said that the back of the energy crisis is broken but the March allocations released to the nation's governors yesterday make it appear that many Americans, including New Yorkers, will be flocking again to the gas lines this month.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE IN FEBRUARY, BUT PACE SLOWED
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The rapid rise in wholesale prices slackened in February, with an increase only about onethird as much as In January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Stitch, Chatter and Toil Go Into Blair House Project
description: Most women who take needlepoint seriously have long since filled their own places with pillows, chair seats, footstools, telephone book covers, rugs, benches, straps for luggage racks and bell pulls  even when there aren't any bells.

title: Flyers Seal Playoff Spot On 61 Rout
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 7 (UPI)  Simon Nolet scored three goals tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 61, and clinched a spot in the Stanley Cup playoffs of the National Hockey League.

title: CutRate Senators
description: The Senate's veto of the pay increase President Nixon had recommended for Congressmen is an act of political cowardice more than of selfabnegation. The cost living has soared by nearly a third since the lawmakers got their last salary boost in 1969, plainly entitling them to more money now. But Watergateborn fear of voter resentment obviously convinced many Senators that struggling along on their present pay of $42,500 a year was more prudent than risking involuntary retirement by taking the proffered raise.

title: 3DAY WORK WEEK ENDING IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, March 7  The threeday work week imposed on most of British industry because of the nationwide coalmine strike will end at midnight tomorrow under a Government directive issued today.

title: Nixon Seeks to Limit House To Inquiry on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 President Nixon, in an apparent attempt to limit the scope of the impeachment inquiry, has refused to give the House Judiciary Committee tape recordings or documents that do not bear directly on the Watergate (coverup, the committee disclosed today.

title: Wreck of the Monitor Is Reported Found
description: DURHAM, N. C., March 7 The longsought wreck of the U.S.S. Monitor, the Union vessel in history's first duel between ironclads, during the Civil War, has been found on the bottom of the Atlantic off Cape Hatteras, N. C., an oceanographic researcher at Duke University reported today.

title: 4 CARDINALS URGE U.S. ABORTION BAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Four Roman Catholic cardinals testified before a Senate subcommittee today that the Constitution should be amended to prohibit abortion.

title: Advertising: Motels, Gasoline
description: The gasoline shortage, even if it weren't real, could well take the mo (for motor and money) out of the motel business.

title: Utica's Mayor Bars Aides From Talking To 2 Papers' Staffs
description: Mayor Edward Hanna of Utica said yesterday that he was directing all city department heads not to talk to reporters of the city's two newspapers because of what he termed their inaccurate, irresponsible and lopsided reporting out of City Hall.

title: Big Insurgent Unit In Cambodia Shifts To the Government
description: KAMBOL, Cambodia, March 7 (AP)A group of 742 former insurgents swore loyalty to President Lon Nol's Government today in the largest defection of antiGovernment forces since the Cambodian war began In April, 1970.

title: Mt. Vernon Takes Basketball Crown
description: WHITE PLAINS, March Poughkeepsie High and Mount Vernon High won championships today at the New York State Section L basketball tournament at the Westchester County Center.

title: U.N. GENERAL HAILS PULLBACK AT SUEZ
description: UNITED NATIONS BUFFER ZONE, Sinai, March 7  The commander of the United Nations force in the Middle East today celebrated the successful Egyptian and Israeli troop pullback along the Suez Canal front by praising both sides for their unfailing understanding and cooperation.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, MARCH 8, 1974
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Books of The Times
description: TIMES TO REMEMBER. By Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy. 536 pages. Illustrated. Double. day. $12.50.

title: Yanks Told to Sound Off Loudly on Popups
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7When Bill Virdon arrived in the Yankees' spring training camp, he brought with him a number of drills the players weren't accustomed to under their previous leader, Ralph Houk. Virdon sent his team through one of those drills today, a drill that could be called game of bazooka baseball.

title: Paddle Tennis Gets Its Day on Court
description: NEW CANAAN, March A man driving on Route 123 the other day slowed as he passed the New Canaan Field Club and then asked his companion: What were those women doing in that cage?

title: Utica's Mayor Bars Aides From Talking To 2 Papers' Staffs
description: Mayor Edward Hanna of Utica said yesterday that he was directing all city department heads not to talk to reporters of the city's two newspapers because of what he, termed their inaccurate, irresponsible and lopsided reporting out of City Hall.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: DR. ERNEST BECKER
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 7Dr. Ernest Becker, professor of anthropology at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, British Columbia, died yesterday in Vancouver. He was 49 years old and formerly had lived here.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion tonmiles, 1.8 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Carloadings in the same period totaled 526,637 cars, 0.6 per cent below last year.

title: Soviet Aim in Mideast
description: MOSCOW, March 7Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's diplomatic shuttle race with Secretary of State Kissinger is being widely read here as evidence of Moscow's concern over how to maintain a strong Middie East position as the Arabs and Israelis turn from hostility to negotiation.

title: Opera: Donizetti's Choice
description: Donizetti's Parisina d'este falls a little beyond the halfway mark in the list of 73 operas that he wrote. First produced in 1833, it had a career like most of the composer's works, making its way quickly throughout Europe and into various Western Hemisphere centers, including New York in 1850. Then neglect, until it was brought to light in Siena, Italy, in 1964.

title: The Politics Of Fantasy
description: PARIS, March 7There has always been an air of fantasy about Paris, but somehow the unreality seems more real now than ever and is affecting everything from prices to politics.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 8, 1974

title: Jottings From Texas
description: DALLASThese are some random observations after a trip to west Texas (part of it icebound) and which may or may not be instructive about our times.

title: The Pop Life
description: Aretha Franklin, who opens a week's run tonight at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, has been called the queen of soul, but she sensibly resists such categorizations.

title: Wood, Field & Stream The Cold Man and the Sea
description: PUNTA GORDA, Fla. Palm fronds streamed and ruffled in a vigorous north wind and the temperature was in the high 30's when we converged at the Punta Gorda Isles Marina shortly after dawn to decide whether to go fishing.

title: DELIVERERS AT NEWS WALK OFF THE JOB
description: Newspaper deliverymen at The Daily News walked off their jobs last night in protest against workschedule changes for 11 truck drivers. Most deliveries of today's editions of The News were halted.

title: Miss Miness Wed To Martin Farber
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., March 7Miss Susan Beth Miness and Martin Stuart Farber, students at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, were married here today at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving J. Miness. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein of Roslyn Heights and Rabbi Andrew J. Robbins of New Hyde Park performed the ceremony.

title: Diamond Match Concern Fined For Illegal Campaign Donations
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The Diamond International Corporation and one of its vice presidents, Ray Dubrowin, pleaded guilty today to charges by the Watergate special prosecutor that the corporation had made $6,000 in illegal campaign contributions to Republicans and Democrats.

title: New John L. In Feature At Garden
description: John L. Sullivan of Olympia, Wash., has a famous name and like the Boston Strong Boy of yesteryear, the present John L. has the credentials to back it up22 fights, 22 victories.

title: About the DoralEastern ...
description: Steve Caulkins started with an eagle and a birdie and made the turn in 32, but he shot 38 on the back nine... Orville Moody attributed his 67, his second sub70 round this season, to recovery of his putting touch. He putts crosshanded.... Sam Snead, whose straw hat is a trademark, said golfers would profit by wearing hats because they shade the eyes and make them last a bit longer. Ed Furgol, United States Open champion in 1954, shot an 8 on the par4 third hole.

title: High School Sports
description: After the first ClintonTaft basketball game this season, it was apparent that, with a little luck in the draw, the two teams could play for the Public Schools Athletic League title. Tomorrow at noon at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens the Bronx schools play for that crown.

title: L.I. Boy Released Safely After Abductors Are Paid
description: John Calzadilla, an 8yearold boy who was kidnapped on Wednesday a block from his Suffolk County home, was recovered safely early this morning at a New Jersey motel after his father paid a ransom of an undisclosed amount.

title: Airlines Weigh New Rise In TransAtlantic Fares
description: International airlineswhich have raised fares between the United States and Europe by more than 16 per cent within the last year, and have approved an increase of 7 per cent morestarting next month are considering still another rise because of higher fuel costs.

title: General Strike in Ethiopia; Drive for Change Growing
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 7Ethiopian workers began a general strike today, increasing pressure on Emperor Haile Selassie and the new Cabinet of Premier Endalkachew Makonnen to give or at least promise economic and social changes in the shortest possible time.

title: Concern Is Indicted In Tank Blast on S.I.
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation was charged with 40 counts of criminally negligent homicide yesterday as a result of the explosion at its Bloomfield, S.I., liquidnaturalgas tank last winter that killed 40 workmen.

title: SHIFT OF OIL TALKS CALLED CAIRO'S IDEA,
description: CAIRO, March 7The shift of a conference of Arab oil ministers to Cairo from Tripoli, Libya, was made at Egyptian request, informed sources said today.

title: NAY WORK WEEK ENDING IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, March 7  The threeday work week imposed on most of British industry becaue of the nationwide coalmine strike will end at Midnight tomorrow under a Government directive issued today.

title: Market Averages
description: Thursday, March 7, 1974

title: Three Designs Chosen For Bicentennial Coins
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)A colonial drummer boy, Independence Hall and a Liberty BellMoon combination were announced today as choices for designs for the nation's 1976 bicentennial coins.

title: TIMES WARNS I.T.U. ON INTERFERENCE
description: An official of The New York Times warned Typographical Union No. 6 yesterday that if there was any interruption or interference with normal employment or production operations of the newspaper, The Times intended to take the matter to court.

title: Exchange of Letters on Evidence for House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Following are an exchange of letters between Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, and President Nixon, and the reply of James D. St. Clair, White House lawyer, to a committee request for evidence. The committee request, from John M. Doar, special counsel on impeachment, was not made public because it contained specific references to items of evidence.

title: Newark Set to Abandon Stella Wright to Tenants
description: NEWARK, March 7  Toby Henry leader of the rent strike at the Stella Wright housing project that lasted four years, said today that the tenants' decision to resume rent payments was in anticipation of the Newark Housing Authority's plan to end operation of the project next month.

title: Upstate ExMental Patient Kills Himself in a Church
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., March 7Wielding a shotgun and a pistol, a former mental patient with a criminal record marched an employe of a gun store through the center of town this afternoon and then, inside a church and surrounded by policemen, shot himself to death in the head, the police said.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: JETS BARS POST FOR BUCKLEY MAN
description: Senator Jacob E. Javits has blocked the reappointment of Kieran O'Doherty, vice chairman of the Conservative party, to a $36,000 patronage post as a member of the United States Foreign Claims Settlement Commission.

title: Rises in AllElectric Bills Protested
description: ELMSFORD, N. Y., March 7About 400 angry residents of allelectric homes and apartments in Westchester County voted tonight to refuse to pay their bills as a protest against soaring utility costs. The voice vote seemed to be unanimous.

title: JOHN SIBLEY DIES; REPORTER WAS 45
description: John Sibley, a reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., of complications of diabetes. He was 45 years old and lived at 907 Stuart Avenue.

title: Bomb Threat Against Press
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)An anonymous telephone caller threatened today to blow up the White House press center. Three Executive Protection Service policemen searched the area, on two sublevels of the White House, but found nothing. It was a typical crank call, one official said, adding that two or three such calls are received every week.

title: Thomas Danby Dies at 80; Circulation Director at Post
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., March 7Thomas W. Danby, circulation director of The New York Post from 1956 to 1958 and later for several years executive director of the New York Metropolitan Newspapers Association, died yesterday at his home, 66 Orleans Road. His age was 80.

title: Trainers to Hear Kerlan
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7 (UPI)  A student trainers' emergency sports medicine seminar will be held tomorrow and Saturday at the International Hotel. Dr. Robert Kerlan, medical director of the National Athletic Health Institute, is scheduled to open the session. More than 300 high school student trainers, coaches and athletic directors will participate.

title: Hoffmann Wins World Skate Title
description: MUNICH, West Germany March 7 (UPI)Jan Hoffmann of East Germany crowned 12 years of dedication tonight with a nearperfect performance to win the men's title at the 1974 world figure skating championships.

title: GUATEMALAN LEFT THREATENS STRIKE
description: GUATEMALA, March 7 Guatemala's leftleaning opposition has vowed to paralyze the country by strikes of nonviolent resistance if the apparent victory of its candidate in the Presidential election of last Sunday is not upheld.

title: Streaking: A Mad Dash To Where?
description: Is it an art form? Is it an uncontrollable urge? Is it political? Perhaps perverse? Healthy? Naughty?

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Statement to Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Kissinger's opening statement today to the Senate Finance Committee:

title: Film: Mekas's Very Personal Journey to Lithuania
description: Reminiscences of a Journey to Lithuania was shown at the 10th New York Film Festival. The following excerpt is from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared Oct. 5, 1972, in The New York Times. The film opened Sunday and will be shown again today and tomorrow at noon and midnight at the First Avenue Screening Room, at 61st Street.

title: House, in Reversal, Kills Oil Price Rollback Item
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The House of Representatives passed today a bill giving legislative authority for the operation of the Federal Energy fice after reversing an oilpricerollback provision that had raised the threat of a Presiderstial veto.

title: 3 Die in Alabama Crash
description: AVON, Ala., March 7 (AP)A headon collision last night took the lives of three persons. Those killed in the twocar accident were Identified as James D. Crittenden, 19 years old, of Little Rock, Ark.; Jayne A. Stoia, 18, of Tulsa, Okla., and Thomas W. Quigley Jr., 20, of Syracuse, N. Y.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SNAPPERS Photography is probably the most prolific art in the land, and if you don't believe it, saunter into the Kodak Photo Gallery, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street (2626170). It will take some time to go through this glowing profusion of 720 finalist photos in the 1973 Kodak International Newspaper Snapshot Awards, the lite of more than 250,000 entries by amateur lensmen and women in contests run by 95 newspapers last summer.

title: EARLY NIXON VISIT STILL A SOVIET AM
description: MOSCOW, March 7The So viet leadership has conveyed to the United States that despite the latest legal developments this Watergate affair the Kremis still counting on a visit from President Nixon this summer, a United States Embassy solace said today.

title: Du Pont of Canada Expands
description: Du Pont of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday that it would begin construction during the spring of a nylon staple fiber plant at CoteauduLac, Quebec.

title: WILSON DISPUTES GAS ALLOCATION
description: Reaction ranging from dismay to pleasure marked the responses yesterday of Governors and energy officials in the tristate region to the announcement of March gasoline allocations by the Federal Energy Office in Washington.

title: BANK TAKEOVER BID IN TEXAS IS CLEARED
description: The Fort Worth National Corporation, Texas' sixth largest bank holding company with $1.25billion in assets, has received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to acquire the Southern National Bank of Houston. The merger agreement provides for an exchange of 650,000 shares of Fort Worth National stock, worth about $25 each at current prices, for a total of about $16,250,000.

title: Commercial Solvents Gains a Second Suitor
description: A bid by Beker Industries to acquire a substantial interest in the Commercial Solvents Corporation spurred another suitor as the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation yesterday made a counterbidpossibly for all Commercial Solvents shares.

title: KISSINGER FIGHTS TRADE BILL CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Secretary of State Kissinger told a Senate committee today that he would recommend a veto of the Nixon Administration's own trade bill if Congress refused to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union because of its restrictions on the free emigration of Jews and others.

title: VEGAS NITE INQUIRY ON MOB ROLE BEGUN
description: The Police Department's Organized Crime Control Bureau has begun an investigation into the role of professional gamblers and, possibly, organized crime in the running of Las Vegas Nites in Brooklyn, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: RENOBoone Kirkman, Renton, Wash., knocked out Larry Renaud, Tampa, Fla., 3 rounds, heavyweights.

title: NEWS INDEX
Pentagon Bars Jailed Deserter From House Testimony on Amnesty
description: An imprisoned Army deserter who had been a leader of young American exiles in Sweden has been prevented by the Defense Department from testifying at Congressional hearings on amnesty beginning this morning in Washington.

title: Lewis Douglas Dies
description: Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James's and Budget Director and deputy chief of the War Shipping Administration under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., at the age of 79. Page 36.

title: Streaking: A Mad Dash To Where?
description: Is it an art form? Is it an uncontrollable urge? Is it political? Perhaps perverse? Healthy? Naughty?

title: Nowadays the Boys Aren't the Only Ones Taking a Night Out
description: For many moons now, this country has had an institution loosely called the night out with the boys, but, of course, no boys are involved. It is that night of the week when a group of husbands get together to bowl, drink beer, play cards, shoot the breeze or whatever, while their wives stay home with the kids.

title: Building of 2 Plantsis Delayed by G. M.
description: DETROIT, March 7The General Motors Corporation announced today that construction of two new auto assembly plants in Oklahoma City and Memphis would be delayed because of the slump in newcar sales.

title: Fit for a Dog
description: A high school girl was attacked and bitten by a pack of stray dogs in Flatbush the other day, victim of growing menace in many parts of a city that now has an estimated 150,000 dogs running wild.

title: Ayala to Start in Left for Mets Tomorrow
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7  Manager Yogi Berra of the National League champion Mets announced today his lineup for the opening spring exhibition game against the St. Louis Cardinals Saturday. He added: I hope it will be the lineup I can use in Philadelphia on opening day.

title: Bold Paris Airport to Be Europe's Biggest
description: PARIS, March 7  The Charles de Gaulle Airport, which will be the biggest in Europe and one of the biggest in, the world, went on public view today. Its initial incoming flight, from New York, is scheduled to touch down Wednesday.

title: East Orange Apartments Are Offered to Tenants
description: EAST ORANGE, March 7 Federal officials and private realestate developers today announced plans to convert a 12story apartment building into New Jersey's first federally subsidized condominium.

title: Lewis Douglas Dies
description: Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James's and Budget Director and deputy chief of the War Shipping Administration under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., at the age of 79. Page 36.

title: People in Sports
description: The man who emerged briefly last week from Wilt Chamberlain's towering shadow decided yesterday to have the limelight all to himself.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Miss Hunt Gains In Dallas Tennis
description: DALLAS, March 7 (AP)Leslie Hunt of Australia defeated Wendy Overton of New York, 46, 75, 75, in secondround play of the Maureen Connally Brinker women's tennis tournament today.

title: BUZHARDT TELLS VIEW ON ELLSBERG
description: WASHINGTON, March 7A White House aide, J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., acknowledged today that the Defense Department had objected to the Nixon Administration's decision to indict and try Dr. Daniel Ellsberg following publication of the Pentagon papers in June, 1971.

title: Crangle Suggests a Woman Javits Foe
description: The Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, is encouraging party leaders to consider a woman to run against Senator Jacob K. Javits this year, but he is meeting strong resistance from feminist leaders, who want a woman nominated for Lieutenant Governor rather than for the difficult Senate race.

title: Heard, Aaron Lead in Golf
description: MIAMI, March 7I did me some real path today, I'm playing awful solid, said Jerry Heard after taking only 25 putts.

title: EHRLICHMAN, COLSON, LIDDY AND 3 OTHERS ARE INDICTED IN THE ELLSBERG BREAKIN
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Six persons, including John D. Ehrlichman and Charles W. Col. son, who were once among President Nixon's most trusted aides, were indicted today for the 1971 breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: WOMENS BASKETBALL
TAXFREE BONDS SHOW STEADY TONE
description: A busy week, especially in the taxexempt sector, moved toward what appeared to be steady closing yesterday in the bond markets, The taxexempt market itself took something of a breather yesterday as participants continued to work off remaining unsold portions of the large number of new offerings on Tuesday's and Wednesday's calendar.

title: Yanks Told to Sound Off Loudly on Popups
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7When Bill Virdon arrived, in the Yankees' spring training camp, he brought with him a number of drills the players weren't accustomed to under their previous leader, Ralph Houk. Virdon sent his team through one of those drills today, a drill that could be called a game of bazooka baseball.

title: Issue Tops Active List
description: Nervous stockholders, reacting to an unfavorable tax ruling against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, pushed down the price of the giant conglomerate's stock yesterday by more than $3 a share.

title: TestScore Release In Jersey Is Upheld
description: TRENTON, March 7Justice William J. Brennan of the United States Supreme Court has upheld the New Jersey Department of Education in its protracted battle with the New Jersey Education Association by refusing to stop the department from releasing statewide testing scores of publicschool students.

title: STATE MAY CANCEL A LANDUSE STUDY
description: TRENTON, March 7A high official of the State Department of Transportation said today it may be prudent to cancel $20,000 grant for a study by the University of Pennsylvania of land use.

title: ORAL BOOK ORDER IS QUERIED BY CITY
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday approved payment of $52,300 for 523 sets of a reference work that had been ordered orally by a Brooklyn College department head for distribution to disadvantaged students.

title: Occidental Offering Set
description: Plans for public offerings of equity securities by both Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Hooker Chemical Corporation, to be registered under the Securities Act of 1933, were announced yesterday.

title: Vietcong Accused of Terrorism, including Killing of 11 in Pagoda
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 (UPI)The South Vietnamese Government accused the Vietcong today of terrorist acts; including the tossing of two hand grenades into a pagoda filled with refugees from the war. The Saigon command said 11 persons had been killed and 30 wounded in the pagoda.

title: Nassau Prosecutor Forms Rape Squad Headed by Woman
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 7The formation of a rape squad headed by a woman within the Nassau County District Attorney's office was announced today by the prosecutor William Cahn.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, March 7All Bill Boylan could hope for this college basketball season was to finish with a winning record. No one could blame him for his modest goal because Boylan's team, Monmouth College, wasn't performing like a basketball unit.

title: ' Montreal Main,' the Offbeat Life of 13-Year-Old Boy
description: "Montreal Main," the Canadian-made feature that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is obviously the dedicated effort of a production crew and a cooperative cast who conceived and performed it all with a will. But despite a cinma vrit-like approach, their delineations of the relationships between a young, bearded artist-photographer and a 13-year-old boy, the boy's parents who are disturbed by this strange friendship, and a covey of homosexuals and others, makes for dolefully sincere but vague and unconvincing drama.Frank Vitale, who wrote the original story, directed and stars as the artist, has focused his color cameras on the sleazy, Bohemian areas of a Montreal far removed from a tourist's itinerary. And his disquieting, if not moving, slice of offbeat life is in keeping with its squalid, if authentic, surroundings.The cast, reportedly non-professionals using their real names and improvising much of the dialogue, does not act so much as react to situations that often call for fuller explanations. There seems to be a good deal of confusion in Frank's sexual leanings. He is in conflict both with girls and his apparently bisexual friend, Allan, who resents the attention he pays to John, the boy.This odd couple eventually is forced apart by the youngster's parents, but the problems of the principals, the boy's family and the unloved and grimly gay types remain largely unresolved, even if they seem all too real.The driven denizens of "Montreal Main" speak their minds, often in four-letter language, in a technically polished production that unfortunately doesn't generate much compassion for them.

title: 2 BROTHERS KILLED IN A BROOKLYN FIRE
description: Two young brothers died yesterday afternoon in a fire in their fourth floor apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn while their mother was out shopping.

title: Harassed, Democratic Governors Say
description: WASHINGTON, March 7A group of Democratic Governors contended today that they and their close associates were being systematically harassed by Federal police agencies and the Republican party.

title: Parents Await Call As Hunt Is Pressed In L.I. Kidnapping
description: DIX HILLS, LI., March 7The parents of John Calzadilla waited for word today from the kidnappers of their 8yearold, son, as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and 60 Suffolk County policemen pressed their search without any apparent hard leads.

title: Oil Crisis Raises Cost of Everything in Japanese City
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan  The oil crisis that started in the Middle East has caused a department store in Shizuoka, Japan, to stop putting a traditional red paper decoration on its gift packages.

title: Squire's Defense Rests After a Single Witness
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 7The defense in the murder trial of Clark Squire rested its case today after presenting only one witness.

title: PRICES INCREASED BY ARMCO STEEL
description: More steel producers raised their prices on several product categories yesterday in accordance with new Cost of Living Council regulations.

title: KISSINGER FIGHTS TRADE BILL CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Secretary of State Kissinger told a Senate committee today that he would recommend veto of the Nixon Administration's own trade bill if Congress refused to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union because of its restrictions on the free emigration of Jews and others.

title: LAXFREE BONDS SHOW STEADY TONE
description: A busy week, especially in the taxexempt sector, moved toward what appeared to be steady closing yesterday in the bond markets. The taxexempt market itself took something of a breather yesterday as participants continued to work off remaining unsold portions of the large number of new offerings on Tuesday's and Wednesday's calendar.

title: 2 Reasons Denied
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that the Internal Revenue Service, which yesterday revoked a 1969 tax ruling facilitating the takeover of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company in 1970, had asserted that there were flaws in the proceedings leading to the merger.

title: CREW DICE TO FIND BROKEN PARK MAIN
description: Repairmen dug deep yesterday to find the ancient water main that erupted Wednesday night in Central Park and caused extensive damage to some parts of the park, flooded a large area of the nearby East Side and trapped five cars on the 96th Street transverse under as much as nine feet of water.

title: Princeton Ahead in East Swim
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March Curtis Hayden, a Princeton junior, and Hess Yntema, a Harvard sophomore, set meet records tonight as Princeton took a 31point lead after the first day of the Eastern swimming championships.

title: Business Spending Plans Revised Upward in Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 7United States industry has raised slightly its planned investment in plant and equipment this year, compared with projections of three months' ago, despite energy and other problems, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Rating Gameand an 11Table, **** Example
description: I'd like to get a few things straight about the stars by which restaurants are classified here as good, very good, excellent and, if you'll check today's change in the accompanying information, extraordinary instead o the former superb.

title: New Hampshire Rejects Plan for Refinery
description: CONCORD, N. FL, March 7The state House of Representatives turned down tonight Aristotle Onassis' bid to build a $600million oil refinery in the face of overwhelming local opposition.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: S.E.C. Approves Hardship Rule

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: North Vietnam Partly Identifies The 12 U.S. Bodies It Returned
description: TOKYO, March 7 (AP)North Vietnam today gave partial identifications of 12 dead American prisoners whose bodies were flown to Thailand yesterday.

title: Defense Disputes Accuser of Gross; Paints Himas Manipulator, Not Dupe
description: NEWARK, March 7 (AP)A key prosecution witness in the contributiontax fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross was pictured by the defense attorney today as a corporate wheelerdealer who used Mr. Gross rather than being victimized by him.

title: Leadership Restored
description: Papering over their differences of personalities and policies, Israel's leaders have finally coalesced into new government that should stand as a relatively stable interlocutor in the tense diplomatic weeks ahead. The move came in the nick of time.

title: City Opera Gives Cherubini Medea
description: Luigi Cherubini was a very proper composer who wrote very proper music, and that is one of the reasons why it has not lived. The New York City Opera last night staged what probably is the first fullscale performance in New York, certainly the first by a major company. But not even the exertions of that fine singing actress, Maralin Niska, in the title role, save it from being something of noble bore.

title: New York, Jersey Will Get Less Gas Per Day in March
description: WASHINGTON, March 7New York State and New Jersey have been allocated less gasoline for each day of March than they received in February, even though the nation's inventories of gasoline have risen to the highest level in almost two years.

title: The Composer Lived by the Book
description: Luigi Cherubini (17601842) was one of the most famous composers of his day and was held In the highest esteem by none less than Beethoven. But little of Cherubini's voluminous output is played any more. Posterity has decreed that his music, elegant though it might be, lacks personality. There are many musicians, however, who insist that a fresh look at Cherubini's music is overdue, and last night's revival of Medea by the City Opera may help the composer's cause.

title: Horsemen Are Giving More Credit To Jockeys for Achieving Victories
description: The streaking (noncollegiate) achievements of Jorge Velasquez and Angel Cordero have been recent highlights of thoroughbred racing. With Velasquez coming through with five victories the in six attempts Agueon the Aqueduct program on Wednesday, and Cordero registering three triumphs at Hialeah on the same day, the question of the importance of a rider was a topic of conversation and conjecture yesterday among the cognoscenti at Aqueduct.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS March 7, 1974
description: Tickets matching only the last number become eligible for the millionaire semifinal drawing to be held later.

title: New Orleans Will Join N.B.A. Next Season for $6.15Million
description: The National Basketball Association expanded into an 18team league yesterday for the 197475 season by establishing a franchise in New Orleans.

title: 4 TRUMPETS FLAVOR THE MUSIC OF CHASE
description: For more than three years, Bill Chase, a trumpeter in the Maynard Ferguson powerhouse, highnote tradition who has sparked both the Stan Kenton and Woody Herman trumpet sections, has been trying to mold an eightpiece jazzrock group, split between four trumpets and a rhythm section. In its early stages, his group, which is called Chase, seemed to be essentially a miniature Blood, Sweat and Tears. But the latest version, which is at the Half Note this week, has a definite identity of its own, focused on the brassy brilliance of the trumpet quartet.

title: Former I.O.S. Fund Figure Given Bait by Luxembourg
description: LUXEMBOURG, March 7 (AP) Milton F. Meissner, 60, former president of five major Investors Overseas Services mutual funds, has been released from custody in Luxembourg on $50,000 bail, his lawyer's office reported today.

title: Market Awaiting New British Policy
description: BRUSSELS, March 7Diplomats here look upon the change in government in Britain this week as raising the prospect of further stagnation for the already troubled European Common Market.

title: About New York
description: It was warm, it was sunny, it was a good day for a demonstration. There were perhaps 35 people, who would do nothing more than walk in a circle and every so often chant, but they were neighborhood people, and the demonstration had to do with their neighborhood.

title: 6 IN BYRNE CABINET REPORT NET WORTH
description: TRENTON, March 7 (AP)Six more members of Governor Byrne's cabinet disclosed their financial status in statements released today by the Governot's office.

title: CONCERN INDICTED IN S.I. TANK BLAST
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation was charged with 40 counts of criminally negligent homicide yesterday as a result of the explosion at its Bloomfield, S.I., liquidnaturalgas tank last winter that killed 40 workmen.

title: GROWTH SLOIAIED IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: The nation's money supply  the total volume of balances in checking accounts plus currency in the hands of the public  declined sharply in the week ended Wednesday, ending three weeks of explosive growth.

title: Witness Testifies Mitchell Got Fast Action for Vesco
description: John N. Mitchell picked up the phone and made a call that led the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission to meet with a lawyer for Robert L. Vesco within hours after Mr. Vesco contributed $200,000 in cash to President Nixon's reelection campaign, a Government witness testified yesterday.

title: Jurors Dine Well and They May Attend the Theater, but There Are Drawbacks
description: The 18 sequestered jurors serving in the John N. MitchellMaurice H. Stans trial eat dinner at wellknown restaurants. Each has a room of his own at a good midtown hotel. And this weekend or next they may go out on the town, to see a movie or a play.

title: The State Plans to Spend $670Million on Highways
description: The State Transportation Depertinent plans a $670million capital program for highways for the year beginning April 1, including $223million for interstate highway projects.

title: W. R. Grace Sales and Net at Record
description: W. R. Grace & Co. ended last year with exceptionally fourth quarter sates and earnings lifting the annual net income by 29 per cent. In reporting the record results yesterday, J. Peter Grace, chairman, attributed the increase largely to the company's chemicallybased products and services.

title: A Rothko Executor Explains Difficulty In Pricing Works
description: Theodoros Stamos, an artist named by the late abstract expressionist Mark Rothko as one of the executors of his will, defended himself vigorously yesterday in Surrogate's Court against charges that he had not fulfilled the obligation properly.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: SCORING LEADERS

title: Newark to Abandon A Housing Project To Striking Tenants
description: NEWARK, March 7  Toby Henry, leader of the rent strike at the Stella Wright housing project that lasted four years, said today that the tenants' decision to resume rent payments was in anticipation of the Newark Housing Authority's plan to end operation of the project next month.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE IN FEBRUARY, BUT PACE SLOWED
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The rapid rise in wholesale prices slackened in February, with an increase only about onethird as much as In January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Wreck of the Monitor Is Reported Found
description: DURHAM, N. C., March 7 The longsought wreck of the U.S.S. Monitor, the Union vessel in history's first duel between ironclads, during the Civil War, has been found on the bottom of the Atlantic off Cape Hatteras, N. C., an oceanographic researcher at Duke University reported today.

title: New York and Jersey Get Less Gas Daily in March
description: WASHINGTON, March 7New York State and New Jersey have been allocated less gasoline for each day of March than they received in February, even though the nation's inventories of gasoline have risen to the highest level in almost two years.

title: A Nixon Disclosure Raises New Queries
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Nixon's statement last night that he learned last March 21 that hush money had been paid to the. Watergate burglars raised new questions today (about his actions after learning of the coverup.

title: BroadwayHale Bids for 20% of House of Fraser
description: BroadwayHale Stores, Inc., the West Coast retail chain that owns Bergdorf Goodman and NeimanMarcus, announced an agreement here yesterday to purchase 24 million shares, or 20 per cent, of the common stock of the House of Fraser, Ltd., Glasgow, for $78million in cash, The offer is contingent, however, on the rescinding of a tender offer for Fraser shares by a British company.

title: T. T. Krishnamachari, 74, Dead; Was Finance Minister of India
description: NEW DELHI, March 7Tiruvallur Thattai Krishnamachari, former finance minister of India and a close associate of the late Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, died today of kidney failure. He was 74 years old.

title: Legislator Says State Program Of MentalPatient Release Fails
description: ALBANY, March 7 Assemblyman Robert C. Wertz of:Commack, L. I., asserted today that the administration of the state's program of discharging mental patients had broken down.

title: After the Energy Veto
description: The Senate's failure to override President Nixon's veto of the emergency energy act makes new legislation essential. Even if the Arab oil producers lift their embargo, the energy problem is not going to disappear. The United States will have to alter its basic pattern energy consumption for many years to comepresent overdependence on petroleum gradually giving way to coal, shale, nuclear power and other energy sources.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dr. Matthew Wins Stay of Sentence

title: DR. WILSON POWELL, BERKELEY PHYSICIST
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 8 Dr. Wilson Marcy Powell, professor emeritus of physics at the University of California here, died last Saturday at the age of 70.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: After failing to reach agreement on a contract, Gabe Paul sent a letter to Sparky Lyle, notifying him that he had invoked the renewal option clause. It means that if Lyle reports to the Yankees, he would play for a salary designated by the club until he signs a 1974 contract. It can be anything from 80 per cent of last year's salary on up. There was no word on whether Lyle would report. He has said he wouldn't unless he received a raise.... Lee MacPhail former Yankee general manager and new American League president, threw out the first ball before the opening exhibition game.... Pat Dobson, Scott McGregor and Tom Buskey will pitch Saturday's game against Baltimore in Fort Lauderdale. Steve Kline will test his sore arm for the first time against Baltimore in Miami Sunday.

title: Music: Young Conductor
description: The New York Philharmonic is running a kind of youth festival in its subscription concerts this weekend, and the results, as sampled at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, are engaging.

title: INSURER IS CITED IN FRAUD CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Charges of fraud and other violations of Federal securities laws were brought today against the Republic Life Insurance Company of Dallas; the Fealty Equities Corporation of New York; two accounting firms and 11 individuals.
