description: LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) Separate studies by a grout at Boston University Medical Center and a team from Britain's Medical Research Council have strengthened speculaton that aspirin may play a role in preventing heart attacks.

title: Colonels Top Nets, 111100, To Move Into First Place
ELON G. BORTON, 85, LED AD FEDERATION
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 8  Elon G. Borton, former president and general manager of the Advertising Federation of America, died here Tuesday at a nursing home. He was 85 years old.

title: Witness Says Gross Advised Him to Lie to U.S. Jury
description: NEWARK, March 8The former president of the Triple Blue Stamp Company testified today that Nelson G. Gross advised him to disguise a $5,000 contribution to former Gov. W Liam T. Cahill's 1969 campaign and later to lie about it to a Federal grand jury.

title: U.S. Envoy in Saigon Charges Times Article Was Inaccurate
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Graham A. Martin, the United States Ambassador in South Vietnam, has complained to the State Department that an article in New York Times on continued American involvement in Vietnam contains numerous inaccuracies and halftruths.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary prices for the week ended Feb. 26.

title: Michelin Adds a 17th To Its List of the Best
description: PARIS, March 8Picasso would have been delighted.

title: HOROK RITES PILL CARNEGIE HALL
description: More than 2,600 mourners filled Carnegie Hall yesterday to attend the brief, simple funeral of Sol Hurok, the 85yearold impresario who died of a heart attack Tuesday.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Daily News Resumes Publishing as Strike Ends
description: Publication and delivery of The Daily News resumed late last night after the newspaper and its deliverers union resolved a work dispute that had touched off a walkout that blocked distribution of 2.2 million copies of yesterday's editions and 215,000 copies of this morning's paper.

title: Big Rise in Pork Output By Israelis Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI)  The United States Embassy in Tel Aviv has notified Washington that pork has risen to a rather astonishing 30 per cent of Israeli meat production.

title: Ziegler Says Nixon Questioners Dwelt Too Much on Watergate
description: MIAMI, March 8President Nixon's press secretary accused newsmen today of too much dwelling on Watergate during a White House news conference Wednesday night, and said he hoped for more balance in the questioning as the President met the press more often in the months ahead.

title: Miss Creed Leads Golf By Stroke
description: HOUSTON, March 8 (AP) Clifford Ann Creed, who hasn't won a tournament since 1967, battled high winds and rain for a oneunderpar 72 today and took the firstround lead in a $100,000 women's professional golf event.

title: Planners Believe Harlem Is on the Verge of a Major Revitalization
description: For the last several weeks, John Edwards, a 35yearold planner, has been supervising tilt construction of his new offices5,000 square feet of space at 150 West 127th Street in Harlem. That job, he says, is fun.

title: Amex and Counter Stocks Bound Back
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter, market bounded back yesterday after having fallen on Thursday.

title: Scientists Envision Tapping Power of the Black Holes
description: What probably qualifies as the most farout proposal yet advanced to meet the world's future energy needs  harnessing hypothetical, black holes within the solar system  was presented here Thursday to an international audience of physicists.

title: BERNARD RUIN 59, OF RHEINGOLD DIES
description: Bernard Relin, a publicrelations executive who became chairman and president of the Rheingold Corporation and a director and executive of several other major corporations, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 720 Park Avenue.

title: Park Transverse Reopened
description: The 96th Street transverse in Central Park was reopened to traffic at 7 o'clock last night, the police reported. It had been closed since Wednesday night after a watermain break.

title: Britain's Museum Charges May Be Lifted in April
description: LONDON, March 8Admission charges at Britain's public museums and galleries are expected to be abolished next month. The new Labor party Government's Minister for the Arts, Hugh Jenkins, said today that abolition was his first priority in his new post.

title: 12 in Police Narcotic Unit Charged With Corruption
description: Twelve present and former members of the Police Department, including two lieutenants, were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of stealing cash from narcotics dealers, reselling heroin they had seized in an arrest and offering bribes to fellow officers to hinder prosecution of drug traffickers.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CLIFTONMarch 8All I want is a full shot, the chance to prove that I can or can't play big league football.

title: FIRST WOMAN PICKED FOR SUPERIOR COURT
description: TRENTON, March 8Judge Sonia Morgan of the Essex County Court was nominated today by Governor Byrne to become the first woman in New Jersey to serve as a Superior Court judge.

title: Giant Draft Pick Wins 440 Title
description: DETROIT, March 8The New York Giants, who are searching for speed and winning material, may have uncovered a champion in Larance Jones, their 15thround draft choice, who won the National Collegiate indoor 440yard dash title tonight.

title: Life Poor, but Cambodian Refugees Are Glad to Be Free of Rebels
Judge Orders Quick Trial For Brooklyn Jail Inmates
description: A Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered that defendants in the Brooklyn House of Detention be brought to trial within seven and a half months after their. arrest.

title: Unemployed Rate at 5.2%, Halting 3Month Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.2 per cent of the labor force in February after three months of increases, the Labor Department reported today.

title: High School Notes Black Students Plan A Weekend Retreat
description: Pamoja, a caucus of black students at Friends Seminary High School in Manhattan, is planning to hold a weekend consciousnessraising retreat at Powell House, a Quaker retreat in Old Chatham, New York.

title: Workers in Hawaii Stage Sugar Strike In Dispute Over Pay
description: HONOLULU, March 9 The sugar workers of Hawaii went out on strike at 6 A.M. today, halting production in the state's third biggest industry.

title: U.S. LAG ON ENVOY PUZZLES SWEDEN
description: STOCKHOLM, March 6The Swedish Government is puzzle and concerned over President Nixon's delay in restoring SwedishAmerican relations normal by sending an ambassa dor here.

title: Milestones
description: ACROSS

title: Sunday Obsenier By Russell Baker
description: In this fantasy I am standing before Judge Sirica for sentencing, wearing my white collar and little. American flag pin in the lapel of my earnest, offtherack gray suit. My face is a marvel of insincere contrition. Recently I have let the press know that I have been attending church vespers. Oh, I have been cunning. I have been the very model of a modern felon penitent.

title: 3 Charged by F.B.I. With Plot to Kidnap A Foreign Diplomat
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP)A young woman and two jailed men were charged today with plotting to kidnap a foreign consul general to bargain for therelease of the two men, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Mrs. Joan Rosenthal Wit Is Rewed
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N. Y., March 9Mrs. Joan Rosenthal Wit, a sculptor, was married here at noon today to Dean Michael I. Sovern, of the Columbia University School of Law.

title: Public Warned On Job Offers
description: NEWARKThe Better Business Bureau of Greater Newark has warned the public to beware of workathome schemes, which ere being spawned by today's economic uncertainties.

title: Horticultural Therapy
description: WASHINGTON CAREER horticulturists know that their profession can help the handicapped. The dawning is not new, but the need for more information and coordination of efforts has spawned the formation of a National Council for Therapy and Rehabilitation Through Horticulture.

title: CROP FERTILIZERS HELD ADEQUATE
description: CHICAGO, March 9Middle Western grain farmers may not get all the chemical fertilizers they would like this spring, but there is already enough on hand or in the pipeline to keep their yields high next fall.

title: An Orthodox Day of Prayer Is Observed by Jewish Students
description: LONG BEACH, L.I.The whole world is talking about love and peace, sing Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, if only they would observe one Shabbos they would find them.

title: Elizabeth Keating to Be Bride Of F. C. Schroeder 3d, Banker
description: WAYZATA, Minn., March 9 Stephen F. Keating, president and chief executive officer of Honeywell Inc., and Mrs. Keating have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Keating, to Frank Canfield Schroeder 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schroeder Jr. of Sewickley, Pa.

title: 7 NATIONS ADOPT BAUXITE ACCORD
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 9Seven bauxiteproducing countries ended a nineday meeting in Conakry, Guinea, yesterday with generally moderate agreements that included setting up a permanent organization.

title: Nastase Irks Pilic, Gains Net Final
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 9 (AP)Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania and secondranked Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., advanced today to the $10,000 final of an international tennis tournament.

title: WideOpen Race Is Seen for Frelinghuysen's Seat
description: TRENTON  Republicans leaders believe that, despite any repercussions from the Watergate scandal, the energy crisis and an inflationary economy, the state's Fifth Congressional District will remain as the party's safest constituency in the November elections for the House of Representatives.

title: Opera: Closing the Ring
description: About a half dozen years after it started, the Metropolitan Opera has finally brought its new Ring cycle to, a close. Friday Gtterdmmerung was staged, and it followed, more or less, the lines of the previous three operas of the Wagner cycle. It was based on Herbert von Karajan's version, with sets and projections by Gilnther SchneiderSiemssen, staged by Wolfgang Weber, and with costumes by George Wakhevitch.

title: A School Election Is Assessed
description: ENGLISHTOWN  Three weeks after the school balloting in this area, the victors and the vanquished alike looked back with mixed emotions on a vote that rejected a $6.5million budget and elected five members, including two incumbents, to the ManalapanEnglishtown Regional Board of Education.

title: 5 TeenAgers Held in L.I. Kidnapping
description: Five New Jersey teenalters, including a 17yearold girl, were charged yesterday with kidnapping 8yearold John Calzadilla, as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pressed their search for two more suspects.

title: DECENTRALIZING SCHOOLS DECRIED
description: The city's fouryearold school decentralization plan was described here yesterday as disruptive at the spring educational conference at the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Ohio Voter Poll Hints G.O.P. Has Lost Independents
description: WASHINGTON, March 9A poll taken immediately after the voting last Tuesday in the special Congressional election in Ohio strongly suggests that Watergate has cost the Republicans the support of the bulk of independent voters.

title: Tania LawsonJohnston Fiancee of John Tassie
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 9The engagement of Miss Tania LawsonJohnston to Mark Tassie has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Peter O. LawsonJohnston, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of John M. Tassie of New York and Mrs. Brogan Tassie, also of Princeton.

title: Weiskopf, Devlin in Golf Lead
description: MIAMI, March 9  Tom Weiskopf, who has been fishing the last few days with Jerry Heard, teamed up today with Bruce Devlin to catch a prize fish  Heard himself.

title: Epilogue
description: A Return of Property

title: Paperbacks Best Sellers
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: Twins Give $88,000 Pact To Oliva
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 9 (AP)Tony Oliva agreed to terms with Calvin Griffith, the Minnesota Twins president, today and will receive $88,000 for the 1974 baseball season, compared with $91,000 a year ago.

title: A. BRUCE BIELASKI JR.
description: SMITHTOWN, LI., March 9 A. Bruce Bielaski Jr., a partner in the law firm of Klein & Bielaski, of which Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein was formerly a member, died here today. He was 63 years old and lived in St. James.

title: College of Nursing Plans New Course
description: NEWARKA new undergraduate course will be offered next fall by the Rutgers University College of Nursing.

title: Banker Is Fiance Of Mary McCann
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 9Miss Mary Anne McCann, a designer bf women's dresses for Oxford industries in New York, plans, to be married April 20 at the College of New Rochelle to George Hamilton Boyd 3d, an assistant investment officer for the Bank of New York.

title: Serious Infection From Drinking Water Afflicts Visitors to Soviet
description: Hundreds of Americans and Scandinavians who drank tap water while visiting the Soviet Union have come home with an intestinal parasitic infection that can last months unless it is treated with a drug specifically effective against the ailment, Federal physicians reported yesterday.

title: 7 NATIONS ADOPT BAUXITE ACCORD
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 9Seven bauxiteproducing countries ended a nineday meeting in Conakry, Guinea, yesterday with generally moderate agreements that included setting up a permanent organization.

title: I Think Tank Shift Is Dividing Princeton
description: PRINCETON  Robert Hosford and Richard Leibler used to have a casual, neighborly relationship. But a dispute over the future of the large woodlands bordering both of their backyards not only has severed their personal communication, but also has raised political and environmental questions that are reverberating throughout the community.

title: Dr. Clark Says City School Board Officials Further Segregation
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and educator, charged yesterday that the insensitivity of city education authorities had fostered the maintenance of racially segregated schools here.

title: MILLIONS UNUSED IN COLLEGE GRANTS
description: The Federal Government is apparently finding it difficult to et rid of millions of dollars that it wants to distribute to needy college and university students through its Basic Educational Opportunity Grants program.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Six persons were injured in a fourcar collision yesterday evening on the lower level of the George Washington Bridge headed for Manhattan. The police said the collision, in which two cars burst into flames, came minutes after the outbreak of a minor fire in an abandoned tunnel on the New York side of the lower level.

title: Colwell, 24, Takes First In Bowling
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (UPI)  Paul Colwell of Tucson, Ariz., missed three easy spares today but managed to win all four final matches and the $6,000 top prize in the Lions Club open bowling tournament.

title: The Urbane Strategist
description: WASHINGTONWhen James Draper St. Clair took over President Nixon's legal defense a little more than two months ago, there was considerable wonder as to why such a highly regarded and successful lawyer from the antiNixon center of Boston should step into such treacherous waters.

title: Kuchar Takes Golf Lead
description: IPOH, Malaysia, March 9 (AP)Wally Kuchar of Edgewater, Fla., carded a sixunderpar 66, including an eagle on the par 4 seventh hole, to take a threestroke lead after today's third round of the Malaysian open golf championship. Kuchar's total for three rounds over the Perak Turf Club course was 205.

title: MILLION UNUSED IN COLLEGE GRANTS
description: The Federal Government is apparently finding it difficult to get rid of millions of dollars that it wants to distribute to needy college and university students through its Basic Educational Opportunity Grants program.

title: Hamilton Club: A Toast to Past
description: PATERSONIf a man's dub is no longer his home away from home, it can still claim his affection at lunchtime. In Paterson, things are so different.

title: Unafraid, a New Music School Opens
description: AT a time when music conservatories are financially afflicted by inflation and declining contributions, a new one is going to open its doors. This is the Shepherd School of Music, which will be a part of Rice University in Houston. It has, in fact existed in name since 1950, but only now are the wishes of the donor, Sallie Shepherd Perkins, being fully implemented.

title: St. Albans Hospital Entering New Phase
description: After more than a year of phasing out, St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens will be officially transferred to the jurisdiction of the Veterans Administration next week.

title: WOMAN IN MOSCOW SETS HERSELF AFIRE
description: MOSCOW, March 9 (AP)A woman attempted suicide by setting herself afire in Red Square, witnesses reported today.

title: News of the Stage
description: Joel W. Schenker, whose Broadway credits include The Royal Hunt of the Sun, A Far Country, A Case of Libel, The Homecoming and Indians, has engaged Leonard Spigelgass to dramatize Lucy Freeman's book The Dream.

title: Hearsts Get Message
description: A taped messagethe first in 16 daysfrom the reputed kidnappers of Patricia Hearst was received yesterday by a San Francisco radio station. A voice said to be Miss Hearst's was heard. Details on Page 28.

title: Judge Named to L.I. Court
description: ALBANY, March 9 (UPI) Governor Wilson today announced the appointment of District Court Judge Patricia D. Collins of Freeport, L.I., as a judge of the Family Court. Miss Collins, 53 years old, will serve for a term ending nest Dec, 31. She succeeds Raymond Harrington, who has been appointed as a Nassau County judge.

title: Hearsts Get Message
description: A taped messagethe first In 16 daysfrom the reputed kidnappers of Patricia Hearst was received yesterday by a San Francisco radio station. A voice said to be Miss Hearst's was heard. Details on Page 28.

title: Some Answers to Common Problems
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, the entire Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these letters pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not be published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page.

title: Saints Win, 95; Walton: 4 Goals
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., March 9 (UPI)Mike Walton, on the wildest scoring streak in pro hockey, scored four goals and added two assists today to move past the 100point mark and lead the Minnesota Fighting Saints past the Quebec Nordiques, 95, in the World Hockey Association.

title: Flower Shows Are Open
description: TULIPS, daffodils, hyacinths and rhododendrons are in full bloom at the National Guard Armory, Morristown, N.J., where the New Jersey flower show is flowering. The nineday show will be open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and next Sunday; daily, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Admission is $2.50.

title: Hip, Silly and Pop
description: Children do not have to watch the Electric Company on television to benefit from the six 39cent The Electric Company Easy Reader Golden Books that are going on sale this month in variety stores, dime stores, supermarkets and wherever else Western Publishing Company normally places its Little Golden Books and Shape Books. Of course, the TV show's entertaining lessons will reinforce the book's entertaining lessons, and viceversa.

title: Londoners Take Pleasure Saving the Midnight Oil
description: LONDON, March 9 For London nightlife, two months of the threeday week wasn't the worst of all problems. While television was fading oat at 10:30, people were getting into the movie habit again, lining up in Leicester Square.

title: Five Dishwasher Models Called Potentially Perilous
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)Consumers Union has urged the Government to ban the sale of five models of electric dishwashers. It said the five can continue operating when their doors are open, possibly spraying out scalding water and soap.

title: 203, 211, 926 of us
description: It has no doubt escaped your attention that the city of Ann Arbor, Mich., leads all American communities in the per capita frequency of both dentists and robberies. What is one to make of such an unexpected disclosure, culled from E. J. Kahn's relentless study of the 1970 United States Census? Several interpretations of the Ann Arbor finding suggest themselves at once:

title: Educators Prepare for First Major Study of Sports in 45 Years
description: A few clays before the Carnegie Report came out in 1929, New York University's football coach told his troops:

title: A Judge's Son Dies. In FourStory Leap In Apparent Suicide
description: The 19yearold son of a Civil Court judge killed himself yesterday afternoon, according to the police, who said the youth bolted from a couch where two friends had been trying to console him and dived through a closed fourthfloor window of an East Side apartment.

title: Ethiopian Students in Moscow Protest Selassie's Rule
description: MOSCOW, March 9About 80 Ethiopian students occupied the Ethiopian Embassy for three hours today and demanded the abdication of Emperor Haile Selassie and the trial of both the Emperor and other high officials of his newly appointed government.

title: Dave Anderson
description: His image is one of glowering concentration. He leads the National Basketball Association in stares. But in the photo, Kareem AbdulJabbar was doing something he is rarely seen doing. He was smiling. He was sitting on the Milwaukee Bucks' bench and actually smiling. When he was shown the photo, he smiled again.

title: Hero or Grinder or Sub, Sports Food Is Big Time
description: If you want a milk shake at Suffolk Downs in Boston, you'd better ask for a frappe. And they won't know what a meatball hero is when the New Orleans Superdome opens (ask for a po boy).

title: Growing Jewish Journal Mixes Controversy With Humor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. The liveliest new religion journal to appear in this country in recent years has no office, no fulltime staff and lots of typographical errors.

title: U.S. LAG ON ENVOI PUZZLES SWEDEN
description: STOCKHOLM, March 6The Swedish Government is puzzled and concerned over President Nixon's delay in restoring SwedishAmerican relations to normal by sending an ambassador here.

title: F.A.O. Sees Third World Menaced by Fertilizer Cut
description: Rome, March 9A shortage, of fertilizers, aggravated by the energy crisis, is seriously threatening food production in thirdworld countries, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported this week.

title: $4.60 Torsion Wins 4Horse Roseben
description: Torsion of the Buckland Farm was the winner of the $54,100 Roseben Handicap, which had its 31st running yesterday at Aqueduct. Despite gray skies and the fact that the Roseben was listed to be contested by a sparse field, a crowd of 32,049 attended the races, which were held on a sloppy track.

title: Patricia Sobers Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Sobers of Springfield Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Rhonda Sobers, to Dr. John Pope Mitchell, who is completing an internship at Harlem Hospital Center here. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Margery Atherley Mitchell of Brooklyn. Miss Sobers, who graduated from Mount Holyoke College, is studying clinical psychology at Columbia University. Her fianc is an alumnus of Cornell University and the Cornell Medical College.

title: UPPER VOLTA COUP TYPICAL IN AFRICA
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta,Since the ouster of king Farouk of Egypt in 1952, there have been 30 military coups on the African continent, the latest of them last month in this landlocked country of subsistence farmbers and desert herdsmen.

title: ISRAEL OPPOSITION ADAMANT ON LAND
description: TEL AVIV, March 9  Five Israeli political groups are united in an Opposition bloc through their dedication to the idea that Jews have a historic right to all the land between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean.

title: Londoners Take Pleasure Saving the Midnight Oil
description: LONDON, March 9  For London nightlife, two months of the threeday week wasn't the worst of all problems. While television was fading oat at 10:30, people were getting into the movie habit again, lining up in Leicester Square.

title: Abigail Stewart Engaged To Dr. David G. Winter
description: The couple will be married in June.

title: News of the Screen
description: Frank Perry, the director, needs no one like Joel Grey, the clairvoyant in his current mystery, Man on a Swing, to divine his future. It's fairly well set with no fewer than three features he hopes to make this year. The first, Rancho DeLuxe, is slated to be filmed, starting April 29, with Elliott Kastner producing for United Artists release.

title: APPLICATIONS UP 2D YEAR AT N.Y.U.
description: Freshman applications, the closely watched barometers of a college's reputation and financial health, have risen for the second year in a row at New York University, according to preliminary comparisons with last years' figures.

title: 23 South Vietnamese Children Killed as Shell Hits Schoolyard
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 (AP)A mortar shell landed in a primary school playground in the Mekong Delta today, killing 23 children and wounding 32, the Saigon military command reported.

title: U.S. Pay Adviser Renamed
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 9 (AP)President Nixon has reappointed Frederick R. Livingston, a New York lawyer, to a sixyear term on the Advisory Committee on Federal Pay, the Florida White House announced today.

title: Cardinals Lose, 41
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9  The New York Mets opened their exhibition season today with a 41 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals before a full house of 5,780 customers and two young men who contributed a victory streak across the outfield in the ninth inning.

title: Democrats Face Hartford Showdown
description: HARTFORD, March 9The contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor in Connecticut may be resolved this week in the shifting balance of power among Democrats in city politics here.

title: Tax Cuts For Elderly Owners of Homes Rise
description: It took about an hour last week for Mrs. Leonora Kiesling to get the property tax on her twofamily home ity the Woodside section of Queens cut in half.

title: Slumlord Flight Laid to Economy
description: PISCATAWAY  Slumlords, those absentee urban landlords who are accused of drawing excessive profits from helpless tenants in inadequate buildings, have largely left the city of Newark for economic reasons, according to a Rutgers University study.

title: U.N. RIGHTS GROUP IS UNDER ATTACK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 8 The Human Rights Commission is being attacked by outside critics as well as by some of its own members because of its meager accomplishments during a fiveweek session that ended today.

title: MRS. JOHN H. MORTIMER
description: Mrs. Harriet Watson Mortimer, wife of John H. Mortimer, a senior vice president of The New York Times, died yesterday at the Miami Heart Institute after a short illness. Herd age was 49, and she lived at 25 West Way, Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Special Lane for Trucks In Cities Is Under Study
description: SYRACUSE, March 9 (AP)A pilot project in Elmira for the State Transportation Department may lead to construction of an exclusive lane for trucks and buses in cities, a department spokesman said.

title: Teddy WilsonImpeccable
description: TEDDY WILSON'S name would have to be included in any list of important and influential jazz pianists. Onethird of the classic Benny Goodman Trio, onequarter of the Goodman Quartet, Wilson's delicate, incisive touch and melodically graceful style first came into prominence during the thirties through the enormous popularity of the Goodman band. Echoes of Wilson's piano can be heard in the work of such fine craftsmen as Jess Stacy, Billy Kyle, Hank Jones, Ellis Larkins, Mel Powell, and the late Nat King Coleeven in the polite sound of that much maligned breed, the cocktail pianists.

title: The von Richthofen Sisters
description: Almost exactly midway in this book's journey, D. H. Lawrence and Max Weber glare intensely from facing yellow glossy pages into a world which is, perhaps, too small for them. With dark eyes, black and pointed beards running into full moustaches over thin and serious lips, ears just a little too prominent, hair slightly forward over the brows (though more so with Lawrence than Weber), they look astonishingly alike. Even the noses, seen from threequarter view, push out at the same angle. The juxtaposition of the two portraits implies a relationship, and the connection is that Lawrence loved and married Frieda von Richthofen, Weber loved (but did not marry) her elder sister, Else.

title: A Championship Season That Got Away
description: Charles Dickens had the French Revolution in mind when he wrote: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, but that description is particularly appropriate to the bittersweet season just concluded by the University of New Hampshire hockey team. The Wildcats started quickly with six straight Division I victories and grabbed first place right away. After that sixth game, a 54 overtime victory at Boston College, tragedy struck. Driving home for Christmas vacation after that game, three players were involved in an automobile accident on the snowy Massachusetts Turnpike. Warren Brown was killed and Jim Harvie and Dave Bertollo were severely burned attempting to save Brown from the flaming automobile.

title: SPANISH CHURCH DEFENDS BISHOP
description: MADRID, March 9The Roman Catholic Bishop of Bilbao, the Moat Rev. Antonio Afioveros Atan, received the full backing of the hierarchy of the Spanish church tonight in his dispute with the Madrid Government over his call for more Basque freedoms.

title: Strike Forces The News To Drop a Sunday Section
description: The Daily News, which resumed publication and delivery late Friday night after the newspaper and its deliverers union resolved a work dispute that had touched off a walkout, announced in the first edition of its Sunday paper yesterday that it had had to drop one of its sections.

title: Martha A. Fain Plans June Bridal
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9  Mr. and Mrs. Norman Myron Fain have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Ann Fain, to Maurice Arthur Roberts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts of Fairlee, Vt.

title: Democrat Runs for House
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., March 9 (AP)Norman E. D'Amours, a Manchester Democrat, says he will run for the U.S. House of Representatives. The incumbent, Louis C. Wyman, a Republican, seeks a Senate seat.

title: Miss Musket Triumphs, Shoemaker's 4th of Day
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March (AP) Bill Shoemaker, riding his fourth winner in his fourth race today, guided favored Miss Musket to a 4length romp in the $55,300 Santa Susana Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: More's the Pity Coward's Gone
description: CONSIDERING that one expects a Noel Coward play to live, lust, and otherwise make its way through the starry night on language alone, it is astonishing how many of the very best effects in Nol Coward in Two Keys are slyly, even surreptitiously, visual. Of course Coward always did leave spaces for the actors to fill, with fairly strong hints as to how they might most happily be inhabited, but one tends to forget that until, at the Ethel Barrymore, Hume Cronyn's face suddenly dissolves into a grin that shouldn't be there or until Anne Baxter lifts her arms in what seems surrender to a firing squad though she is really only making it possible for a napkin to be placed on her lap. (I am leaving Jessica Tandy until later, because the evening does; and because she's quite another matter altogether.)

title: College Is Offering One Course at a Time
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Although she is a fulltime student at Colorado College, Margy Felcher is taking exactly one course these daysand finding it pretty demanding. But like most of her fellow students, she thinks the arrangement is just fine because it permits depth of learning and freedom for intellectual involvement.

title: CLEANUP IS TOPIC IN DIRTY BELGRADE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 9  Despite Government optimism expressed at an environmental conference here this week, there seems little hope of early relief for the lungs of Belgrade residents, who In a day breathe air rated as equivalent to smoking 20 cigarettes.

title: A Postage Stamp Raises West German Tempers
description: BONN, March 8Rosa Luxemburg, the Red Rosa who was executed in Berlin 55 years ago for her revolutionary activities, is raising political tempers in Germany again through that most conservative of institutions, the Post Office.

title: Dropping of Campground Fees Brings Protests to U. S. Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, March 9It may be hard to believe, but some people want to pay for something that the Government has been providing for free.

title: Where have all the heroes gone?
description: At Yankee Stadium we'd crowd down to the front of the grandstand as the game worked to close, hunching so the people sitting there wouldn't complain to an usher. The ushers' job was to keep the field clear until the final out, but as the ball was caught, their resistance turned to remonstrance, as if to say you oughtn't. We scrambled across the barriers, hundreds of us, to intercept the players running for the dugout, running to the brink of it ourselves, seeing the graceful stoop by which they got past the low roof and to the locker room. Joe DiMaggio and Snuffy Stirnweiss, Charley Keller, Phil Rizzuto, in their white uniforms, all looked marvelously tall and seemed to personify the very prime of life and what could embody in effectiveness. They ran in loping stridesnot ragged bursts, like usand though we ran right next to them, most of us didn't try to touch them, hardly dared call their names. Johnny Mize switched over from the National League to play first base in the twilight of his career, and there were visitors like Hank Greenberg in the traveling team's gray uniform to admire occasionally, along with New York's own roster of pitchers, each one taking his turn, but the buildup of years of radiolistening was what mattered in our worship of these more familiar figures. We saw them only three or four times in a season, when we spent the money for a ticket, but the radio (for our fathers, maybe the sports page) served up clarified profile of an athlete we could look up to. No bleary succession of games televised daily, no muzzy appearance on LaughIn to confuse us, no chuckling debut on The Merv Griffin Show to blur the tall image. Instead, simply Joltin Joe, or Scooter, or Old Reliable.

Everything looks calm and permanent except its master.

title: Tucker Takes a Sentimental Journey

Tucker was unable to convince Rudolf Bing to stage the work, and by Bing's own admission no impresario has ever had more reason to be grateful to a leading tenor after over two decades of unfailingly dependable service.

title: Paperbacks Of the Month
description: The latest (and for American readers probably the most accessible) novel by Russia's foremost living writer and exile. Presumably August 1914 is only the first part of an enormous literaryhistorical fresco; it concentrates on the first weeks of World War I. The central and longest sections are fictionalized military history, setting forth in excruciating detail several days of, the disastrous Russian offensive against the Germans. Framing them are scenes of civilian life, with semifictionalized portraits of Solzhenitsyn's own pirents. Interspersed are Dos Passoslike camera's eye newsreel interludes. In the course of it all, Solzhenitsyn reveals his religious concerns, muted in his other work.

title: To quit after 140,000 puffs a year is like giving up eating
description: Several months ago my husband had a heart attack and we both stopped smoking. We had tried often before, made fine high ceremonies of sharing the last cigarette, incinerating the packs, and wound up always with the same stylish finale, rummaging for butts in the cool of dawn. But a heart attack is persuasive. We stopped.

title: Will Duke Wayne Survive McQ?
description: 'THERE'S nothing wrong with a gun in the hands of the right person, says the Tennessee sheriff in Walking Tall. The San Francisco cop in Magnum Force puts it another way: There's nothing wrong with shooting as long as the right people get shot. In McQ, John Wayne plays a Seattle' detective who looks as if he should be celebrating his diamond jubilee on the force. When the police captain scolds Wayne tor playing fast and loose with the civil rights of a hood, specifically for throwing the hood off the roof of a building, Wayne draws himself up as tall as what seems to be his corset will allow, saying: Well, it him off the streets, didn't it?

title: Criminals At Large
description: Whoever R.B. Dominic is, he knows his Washington. He has written several previous novels about Congressman Ben Safford (D., Ohio), and each has been distinguished by a thorough knowledge of what goes on in Capitol Hill and how a busy Congressman gets through the day. Up to now, Dominic's books have not been especially rooted in current events, but in his new EPITAPH FOR A LOBBYIST (Doubleday, $4.95), he touches on something that will inevitably bring to mind Dita Beard and the ITT case. For here a woman lobbyist has written an indiscreet memo that involves the bribery of a Congressman, and it is leaked to the press. All hell breaks loose, and Safford is appointed head of an investigating committee.

title: BRITISH ELECTION HURTS POLLSTERS
description: LONDON, March 9Britain's politakers have emerged from the confusion of the recent election somewhat damaged in public esteem but generally insisting that they did rather well. Of seven polling organizations whose reports were carried in the London newspapers, six predicted correctly that the Conservatives would receive a higher percentage of the vote than the Labor party. But they went on to conclude  or allowed the newspapers that used them to conclude  that this would give the Conservatives a majority in the hew Parliament. Neither party received a majority in Parliament, and the Labor party won more seats than the Conservatives.

title: Art
description: AMONG the myriad statements that modern artists have made about their work, one of the Most often quoted and probably least understood is the passage from Henri Matisse's Notes of a Painter (1908) in which he wrote as follows: What I dream of is an art of balance, of purity and serenity, devoid of troubling or depressing subject matter, an art which could be for every mental worker, for the businessman as well as the man of letters, for example, a soothing, calming influence on the mind, something like a good armchair which provides relaxation from physical fatigue.

title: Sol HurokA OneMan Show and the Dowser of Impresarios
description: IN AN age of cartel, combine, consolidation and computers, Sol Hurok, who died last Tuesday, was an anachronism: a oneman show who Was referred to as The Last of the Impresarios, the Barnum of the Arts and The Mahatma of Music. Mediumsized, plump, bald, owllike, with a silverheaded cane and black slouch hat, Hurok always swore that his only mission in life was to bring music to the masses. That he did, at no little profit to himself in the process. He was so successful because he had an infallible instinct for smelling talent. One press agent used to say that Hurok could divine a master performer much the same way a dowser can find underground water.

title: 2 Rosenberg Sons Try to Vindicate Executed Parents
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 9For 20 years they have lived in quiet obscurity: going to college, venturing into radical politics and student protests, then marrying and rearing children. But for Michael and Robert Meeropol, growing up in America was not quite the same as for most young people, for they carried a searing childhood memory that would not go away.

title: Taking Jazz Personally
description: JAZZ record producers have traditionally functioned as middlemen, balancing their artists' desires against their employers' demand for salable product, attempting to create studio conditions conducive both to music making and to optimal sound reproduction. In ?? and soul music, the artist is often simply the producer's voice. In jazz, few producers have been able to establish personal styles without compromising the individuality of their artists in the process.

description: PARIS, March 9  Thirty years later Frenchmen are beginning to examine with open eyes how they really behaved under occupation during World War II.

title: 5TH AVE. REPORT STIRS A DISPUTE
description: Though sources in the city's Transportation Administration have said it has begun preliminary studies of a plan to widen upper Fifth Avenue by cutting 10 feet into the treearcaded Central Park side, a spokesman for the agency said this week that it has no proposal presently before it to widen Fifth Avenue.

title: Power City Track Champion
description: It took a week, but Power Memorial got its revenge yesterday.

title: Red Smith
description: John L. Sullivan is a gallant lefthander who looks like a young Whitey Ford bent on mischief, but the resemblance ceased when the bell opened his fistfight with Vito Antuofermo Friday night. Mr. Ford is a man of peace, yet if he had been in the Madison Square Garden ring he would have pitched more effectively, thrown more ??kes and scored better as Sullivan did in the first professional match he ever lost. It was the toughest evening for man of his name, thoughtful witness observed, since Sept. 7, 1902, in the Olympic Club in New Orleans.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Before adjourning for a month to digest Governor Byrne's probudget $2.8billion statebudget, the overwhelming Democratic majority In the Assembly adopted a series of rules that promise to revitalize segments of its legislative process.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The United States Public Health Service estimates that prolonged exposure to toxic chemicals, dusts, noise, heat, cold, radiation and other industrial conditions each year results in the deaths of 100,000 workers and disabling diseases in 390,000 more. Thousands of others are believed to be affected by insidious diseases not yet discovered by science.

title: N.F.L. Stages Football Olympics Today in Miami
description: MIAMI, March 9 (UPI)Professional football, refusing to take a betweenseasons rest, will stage the first AllPro Football Olympics in the Orange Bowl tomorrow.

title: Panel Looks Ahead To Ecology of 2020
description: MORRISTOWNAn energetic organization based in this Morris County community is asking  and acting upon  vital questions about New Jersey's future.

title: WOMAN IN MOSCOW SETS HERSELF AFIRE
description: MOSCOW, March 9 (AP)A woman attempted suicide by setting herself afire in Red Square, witnesses reported today.

title: Balms Attract Bees, Repel Pests
description: BEE BALM and Lemon balm are two distinct herbs, alike in many ways. Both belong to Labiatae, the mint family. Both herbs are hardy perennials, easy to grow, attract bees, yet repel pests. Both make excellent tea or tisanes.

title: Paul Rigney Fiance of Barbara Epstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan B. Epstein of New York and Tarrytown, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Lee Epstein, to Paul M. Rigney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond I. Rigney of Winchester, Mass.

title: When the message was the message in the American theater
description: Jay Williams, now known as a novelist, was an actor and stage manager in the radical theater of the 1930's. Five years ago, in London, he saw a series of performances by (very differently) radical groups and talked to many of the actors. These conversations afflicted him with dj vu: Thirtyfive years before, but in another country . . I had been a member of a group something like these, and we had used much the same language in describing what we were doing.

title: Memorial for Agatha Young
description: A memorial service for Agatha Young, the author, who died Feb. 6, will be held tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. at the Overseas Press Club's quarters in the Biltmore Hotel. Miss Young, a novelist and writer on medical subjects, was a member of the press organization.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The following is an excerpt from a letter containing a detailed list of proposed rail improvements for the state.

title: Alabama Is Criticized on Mental Care
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 9A Federal court order that set forth stringent standards nearly two years ago for protecting the rights of the mentally ill remains almost entirely unimplemented, a court  appointed official who monitors Alabama's leading mental institution has charged.

title: Week's Open Hearings Of Council Committees
description: The following open hearings of City Council committees will be held this week:

title: Miss Kathy Goldstein Is Engaged to Marry
description: WESTBURY, LI., March 9  Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Goldstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathy Susan Goldstein, to Randy Scott Maultasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Maultasch. Both families reside here.

title: Design By Norma Skurka
description: Teddy bears, boots, games, collections. There.is just no end to childrents paraphernalia. Where does one put them allespecially in a city apartmentand still have a room for a child to play, a place for homework and space for a bed? One solution is the bed with roomy storage drawers underneath. Another is the loft bed that frees the floor for daytime activities. Two architectfathers designed rooms for their children that attacked the problem in different ways. One parent who wanted to make a highceilinged room seem cozier, used a tubular shelving system (the same kind he uses in designing product displays for department stores) to build twin towers and ceiling canopy. The other father built a plywood loft that holds twin beds for his two children. While that solution has its disadvantages (fumbling down the ladder in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom), it does make room for two big storage bins and two desks underneath.

title: Future Social Events
description: An Igloo in the Negev?

title: Kiekhaefer Is Weighing Next Step on Two New Products
description: MIAMICarl Kiekhaefer, the outstanding marine mechanical engineer of his time, has two new products he thinks will make major contributions to recreational boating. The first is an outdrive unit (propeller and steering in one package on the transom) that is likely to make all others obsolete. The second is a small marine engine (40 horsepower but only 65 pounds) that Kiekhaefer claims has achieved new standards in performance, quiet, smoothness, small size and simplicity surpassing the rotary engine and outmoding all previous concepts of engine design.

title: Nassau To Raise Recreation Prices
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.A general increase in fees will take effect April 1 at many county  operated recreational facilities, according to an announcement last week by Richard A. Fitch, Nassau County's Recreation and Parks Commissioner.

title: The Resurrection Of Private Slovik
description: ON Jan. 31, 1945, at 10:05 A.M., in the walled garden of a house in St. Marie aux Mines, France, Private Eddie D. Slovik became the only American soldier executed for the crime of desertion in this century, the first such execution since the Civil War.. After his body was anointed with oil by the attending Catholic chaplain, it was placed inside a mattress cover, bound for an unmarked grave. And a shroud of secrecy was drawn around the event.

title: Army Asks Federal Judge To Revoke Calley's Bail
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., March 9 (UPI)  Charging that First Lieut. William Calley Jr. had been freed improperly, the Army has asked the Federal judge who set bail for him to reverse his decision.

title: SPANISH CHURCH DEFENDS BISHOP
description: MADRID, March 9The Roman Catholic Bishop of Bilbao, the Moat Rev. Antonio Afioveros Ata0n, received the full backing of the hierarchy of the Spanish church tonight in his dispute with the Madrid Government over his call for more Basque freedoms.

title: Food
description: It started out as something to do on a boring afternoon and escalated into a home industry, a parttime one to be sure, but enough to keep Peter Moore, 15, as busy as he wants to be. The business? Baking bread. Good solid loaves of whole wheat flour and blackstrap molasses. Peter has figured out that the ingredients cost 55 cents at his neighborhood health store in Manhattan for a loaf that he sells to the same store for 90 cents. He is unconcerned with such trivia as the right temperature for raising dough. His does quite nicely, he reports, in the living room, whatever temperature that is. His parents are quite keen on his product, but Peter says, I eat plain old white bread myself.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The nation's apparel industry has a profit formula but lately it hasn't been working the way it used to.

title: Movies
description: ONCE upon a time, the dream of every Hollywood, producer was to open his movie at Radio City Music Hall. If he couldn't crash the Hall, he'd try to console himself with the Boxy or the Capitol or one of the other movie palaces along Broadway. But the premiere had to be in New York. Success in New York quickly spread the word around the country, made everybody all over the U.S.A. want to see the producer's latest epic. Then, after a solid run in New York, the film began its travels around the country, virtually assured of good business.

title: Islanders Lose, 31, To Wings
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 9  We couldn't buy a goal. That was the way Al Arbour, coach of the New York Islanders, summed up tonight's 31 loss to the Detroit Red Wings.

title: DeBusschere Is Star
L.I. Youth Killed in Collision
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., March 9 (UPI)A Long Island teenager was killed shortly after midnight in a twocar crash here, The Suffolk County Police said the driver of the other car had been arrested for driving while intoxicated. The victim was John Nuss, 19 years old, of 18 Woodland Drive, Old Bethpage. Arrested on a charge of driving while intoxicated in the collision at the intersection of Old County and Manetto Hill Roads was David Ashe, 35, of 29 Ferney Street, Hicksville.

title: Scholar Gets F.B.I. File on Ezra Pound
description: A young literature scholar here is finding that using F.B.I. files instead of graduate students as research assistants can prove a sometimes frustrating, sometimes rewarding technique.

title: Workers in Hawaii Stage Sugar Strike In Dispute Over Pay
description: HONOLULU, March 9 The sugar workers of Hawaii went out on strike at 6 A.M. today, halting production in the state's third biggest industry.

title: Nassau Legislators Act for Consumers
description: MINEOLA  Nassau County's influential 13man Republican state legislative delegation has introduced a series of bills aimed at helping the consumer during the present energy crisis.

title: The Picture Is, Alas, Clear, But Not Good
description: Two years ago, cable television was a new and growing industry that seemed to promise to deliver the communications of the future by 1974. Through television by wire, so the cable dream went, agencies of city governments would be interconnected, hospitals would be linked with outlying health care centers, neighborhoods would have their own local stations, minorities would have a television forum. Social scientists and educators planned the impact of the medium on the culture of the country, and venture capital was readily available from the financial community.

title: Chapot Wins Two Titles at Horse Show
description: READINGTON, N.J., March 9Frank Chapot, captain of the United States Equestrian Team, rode two champions, but he was defeated in two divisions today at the Four Seasons horse show.

title: Death of a Black in a White Bar: 2 Versions
description: Fifteen minutes after 20yearold James Hills entered Mickey's Shanty bar at 2604 118th Street in Astoria, Queens, he was shot dead by one bullet fired pointblank into his chest by John Neville, an offduty police officer who, in 19 years on the force, had never before fired his gun.

title: 7 EXNIXON AIDES PLEAD NOT GUILTY TO COVERUP PLOT
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 Seven of President Nixon's former associates, charged with covering up the Watergate burglary, pleaded not guilty today before Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court here.

title: Letter to a robber
description: Listen, I hope you won't think I'm not grateful for the way you handled it. I mean not killing us or... anything. How often does a New York holdup man burst into a brownstone on a quiet Satur day night, tie up a whole family, stuff all their cash and valuables into a couple of jumbo shopping bags, and then quietly sashay out into the rain, breaking stride only to select a nice umbrella from the hall rack? As the police put it, 10 minutes after you left, Count your blessings, folks. We have, we have. So, many thanks from all of usme and Bob and the kids. We'll never forget you.

title: 6 CHINESE YOUTHS SEIZED WITH ARMS
description: Six members of a Chinatown youth gang known as the Flying Dragons were arrested last night after they reportedly used a chimney atop the Alfred E. Smith housing project as a target for a .30caliber machine gun.

title: In City or Suburb, Officialdom Comes Fragmented
description: For Charles Dickens, the Whole Science of Government was embodied in the slogan: How Not To Do It. Every politician who deplored that it hadn't been done, and who pledged to the voters that it would be done, devised, on entering office, how it was not to be done. Whatever was required to be done, Dickens wrote in Little Dorrit, the Circumlocution Office was beforehand with all the public departments in the art of perceivingHOW NOT TO DO IT.

title: TEAHOUSE IN PARK DESTROYED IN FIRE
description: A picturesque Oriental teahouse that was a fashionable gathering place at the turn of the century in Prospect Park in Brooklyn was destroyed early yesterday in a fire set by vandals, the police reported.

title: Not DDT Again
description: DDT, that proved despoiler of wildlife and the ecosystem which the Environmental Protection Agency banned over a year ago, Is being slyly built up for a return engagement. Bowing to chemical manufacturers, the timber lobby and the United States Forest Service, the E.P.A. has caved in, lifting the ban in order to protect Douglas firs of the Northwest from an admittedly harmful species of moth.

title: Hiatus in Bonn
description: Less than sixteen months after its impressive election victory, Chancellor Brandt's coalition Government West Germany is mired in disunity and immobility. Here is the only Government in the West in strategic position to provide badly needed initiatives for both the European Community and the Atlantic Alliance; yet seems strangely uncertain and ineffective.

title: From the Sports Editor's Mailbox: Bettors Do Better at a Race Track
description: To the Editor.Since the advent of OTB, the New York track have claimed that bettors at the track have an edge over their off track counterparts (e.g., ontrack bettors can watch the horses and odds board). Moreover, a recent Police Department study indicates that on bettors appear to be largely unsophisticated gamblers, such as housewives and students, who lose more frequently than racegoers.

title: Too Much Credit, Built Up Too Fast
description: In the United States, an excessive rate of credit formation has been expanding monetary purchasing power faster than real output practically all of the time for nearly 30 years. It is thus no wonder that inflation is beginning to get out of hand. Conventional economic theory deals satisfactorily with the impact of the rate of credit formation on the level of real output and on the price level.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Airships may be quietly gliding back into our lives.

title: JoAnn Tomaiuolo Plans Nuptials
description: EASTON, Conn., March 9  Mrs. Frank P, Tomaiuolo has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss JoAnn M. Tomaiuolo, to C. Edward Scebold of New York, national executive secretary for the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A major Arab split seems to have develeped over Egypt's insistence that the American effort to bring about military disengagement with Israel would be matched by relaxation of Arab oil restrictions, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, has announced that she will be represented at the meting of Arab producers in Cairo today and has made an official statement supporting an end of the embargo against the United States. Egyptian officials said categorically that the oil ministers' conference would be held in Cairo today. In Algiers, the Energy Minister said that the oil producers had been officially asked to meet in Libya on Wednesday. [1:23.]

title: Hunters and hunted: all caught up by forces beyond their control
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif. You could hear them cracking through the dry red shank and manzanilla brush, then the echo of their footsteps as they ran through a concrete drainage tunnel under Interstate Route 5, just half a mile from Tijuana, then their heavy breathing; it was like stalking big game, rather than men who only wanted bread. The wetbacks were all around us. They had been patient, these wetbacks. Mexico had taught them how to be patient. They had waited on the Tijuana side until they had met the right coyote, which what they have traditionally called one who specializes in smuggling hungry people to the Promised Land. In Tijuana they had also spoken of a pollero, a more recent, less fearsome name for a coyote. In Spanish, a pollero is one who tends to his chickens, his patios, and the wetbacks had joked that they wanted to be pollos for a reliable pollero; they would pay $250 or even $300 to a good pollero who would hide them in a truck or under a truck or even next to the engine of a truck and take them to Los that could vanish Into the city. Even before Tijuana they had waited. They had waited in the dust outside little huts of adobe, huts filled with hungry children and holloweyed old men and old women, humorless and taciturn, still waiting for the promises of a revolution to come true; wretched little places in Guanajuato, San Luis Potosi, Durango, Jalisco, Chihuahua and Sonora, places with lovely names where God seemed forever bringing drought or flash floods or more children; always children. But they had waited and perhaps they had sold a good cow, a few pigs and they had saved pesos and centavos until now, finally, their time had come. With all of their belongings in a cardboard box or a shopping bag or a battered piece of luggage they had gone to the bus station and purchased a ticket which enabled them to ride north on the Autobus of the Three Stars of Gold and soon they could see the rutted, dreary streets of Tijuana.

title: Numismatics
description: AS part of its 64th anniversary celebrations, the Boy Scouts of America recently presented President Nixon with a set of gold medals depicting the Scout oath, law and slogan. While the medals gave the ceremony a strong numismatic flavor, and pictures of the presentation appeared in the daily press from coast to coast, it is not likely to bring many recruits into the growing army of young numismatists. The B.S.A. has done something else, however, that will almost certainly, help to instill in large numbers of boys a lasting rather than a temporary interest in the coin hobby. It has revisedbroadening but also easingthe requirements for the coin collecting merit badge.

title: Ethiopian Students in Moscow Protest Selassie's Rule
description: MOSCOW, March 9About 80 Ethiopian students occupied the Ethiopian Embassy for three hours today and demanded the abdication of Emperor Haile Selassie and the trial of both the Emperor and other high officials of his newly appointed government.

title: Taft Beats Clinton, 5554, for City Basketball Title
description: Taft outscored Clinton yesterday in the fourth quarter of their Public Schools Athletic League basketball final, 1514, and that one point was the difference as Taft won, 5554, for its first city title. After 23 games and three quarters of another, and in the fourth meeting of the season between the two schools, Taft proved one point better than the Governors.

title: Ten Annuals For Great Performance
description: THE almost unlimited varieties of annuals available today can satisfy anyone's individual preference whether it be for color or longevity of bloom. Having grown all of the common and most of the unfamiliar annuals for many years, I set a criteria of dependability and selected ten favorities. They are easy to grow, withstand the vagaries of weather add have a long blooming period until frost. They are versatile in color, height and suitable for cutting beds or borders.

title: CORKY HALE CHANGES FROM HARP TO PIANO
description: Corky Hale, a small, sparkling woman who has for years been a legendary figure in the music business as a harpist in studio recording, sessions and as an accompanist for Barbra Streisand end Tony Bennett, made a couple of brief appearances in public during the last two years at Soerabaja and at Michael's Pub. She apparently enjoyed, it so much that she has opened a place of her own where she can perform six nights a week.

title: INVESTING
description: The energy crisis has laid its cold hand on the stock market since last October, shaking big companies and small.

title: A Way to Reclaim Oil Sought
description: BAYONNE  The Federal Government has invested almost $700,000 in a company here in an attempt to solve a persistent environmental problem and conserve dwindling petroleum supplies during the energy crisis.

title: Hughes Bus Reprimand of Lawyer for Newspaper Interview
description: TRENTON  To what extent should a lawyer, whose professional conduct is regulated by a formal and sharply defined code of ethics barring selfadvertising, be restrained from granting interviews or permitting photographs that might otherwise be considered simple exercises of the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech?

title: UPPER VOLTA COUP TYPICAL IN AFRICA
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta,Since the ouster of king Farouk of Egypt in 1952, there have been 30 military coups on the African continent, the latest of them last month in this landlocked country of subsist. ence farmbers and desert herdsmen.

title: Paula Kalayski Fiancee of Skater
description: BEL AIR, Md., March 9Miss Paula Jean Kalayski plans to be married to John Misha Petkevich, 1971 United States men's figureskating champion and a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University. The wedding is planned for June in Cambridge, Mass., when the bridetobe graduates from Radcliffe College.

title: Diagramless, 18 by 18
description: 1 Kind of lands

title: Question Of Hospital Costs Stirs Wide Debate
description: TRENTONAre New Jersey residents paying excessively high Blue Cross rates because of unnecessarily high hospital costs?

title: Whitworth Leads Golf On 72145
description: HOUSTON, March 9 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth shot birdies on two of the final six holes today to overcome an earlier bogey, scored a oneunderpar 72 and took a onestroke lead with a 145 total in the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association; S&H Green Stamp Classic.

title: U.N. RIGHTS GROUPIS UNDER ATTACK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 8The Human Rights Commission is being attacked by outside critics as well as by some of its own members because of its meager accomplishments during a fiveweek session that ended today.

title: SQUIRE JURY RETIRES WITHOUT A VERDICT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 9  The jury trying Mark E. Squire, areputed Black Liberation Army figure charged with murdering a New Jersey state trooper on the New Jersey Turnpike in a shootout last May 2 while in the company of another black man and a black woman, was ordered at 9:45 tonight to return to its nearby motel.

title: Athletic Recruiting: A Campus Crisis
description: This is the first in a series of articles on the big business of college sports recruiting, and the financial and ethical crisis this slave market in athletes has produced.

title: $14 Winner In Garden State Race
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., March 9 (AP)Corporate Headache scored a 2length victory over Wing South in the $26,250 Benjamin Franklin Handicap at Garden State Park today.

title: 2 Junior Colleges Fall Victim To Rising Costs, Lagging Rolls
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS More than 250 students out on a limb, and 50 colleges aiming to get them.

title: Elizabeth Greene to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Greene of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Greene, to James P. McShane, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. McShane of Paramus, N. J. Both the future bride and her fianc are with the United States Customs Service. Miss Greene is a secretary in the New York office, and Mr. McShane is a special agent with the Newark office.

title: BIGTIME GAMING ANGERS ITALIAN
description: ROME, March 9The allege bigtime gambling of a wealth Roman contractor is being dis cussed in the city and nations Parliament at a time when th nation is being told to obsery rigorous austerity.

title: President and Presidency
description: In his latest news conference, President Nixon said: ... I will do nothing to weaken the office of the Presidency.... But the real question is: has Mr. Nixon so acted that he has in fact greatly weakened the office of the Presidency?

title: Lisa Todman Wed To William Plough
description: Miss Lisa Susan Todman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Seidman Todman of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married here last evening to William Benjamin Plough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice David Plough of Memphis. The ceremony was performed at the Pierre by Rabbi Maurice Davis.

title: SAIGON DISPLAYING DIPLOMATIC VIGOR
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9South Vietnam has begun to inject a bit of vigor into its conduct of foreign relations, for years an area of neglect overshadowed by war and Washington.

title: Last Year's Boycott Had No Lasting Effect
description: CHICAGOLast year a very unusual thing happened in this country: there was a spontaneous nationwide boycott of meat because of prices that had gone out of sight. It worked briefly. Prices fell for a time.

title: R. S. Bambino Engaged To Barbara L. Tunick
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 9Miss Barbara Lynne Tunick and Richard Stephen Bambino will be married this month in Paris.

title: Tar Heels Vote on N.I.T.
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 9 (AP)  Dean Smith, the North Carolina basketball coach, said today his sixthranked Tar Heels have voted to accept a bid to the National Invitational Tournament if one was received.

title: KLANSMAN FOUND GUILTY OF KILLING
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 9A frail, bespectacled, 22yearold man who says he is a member of the Ku Klux Klan has been convicted of killing last Nov. 26 a black Gadsden minister he did not know.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE PARTNERS, by Louis Auchincloss. (Houghton Mifflin, $6.95.) The gentle moralist of the Wall Street lawfirm jungle in another of his knowledgeable novels pitting what people want against deeper forces.

title: Labor Zionist Chief Backs Jackson Plan For Curb on Soviet
description: The president of the Labor Zionist Alliance urged yesterday the passage of the Jackson amendment that would bar credits and favored treatment to countries that restrict emigration and rejected Secretary, of State Kissinger's opposition to the amendment.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mickey Mantle is impressed in the Yankees' training camp with the hitting and attitude of Terry Whitfield: I haven't seen a kid like him around here in a long time. He has the real good bat and he's so eager to learn that he'll come back and ask questions after he tries what you've told him.

title: G.O.P. Begins to Rally Around Ford; Growing Crowds Hail New Boldness
description: WASHINGTON, March 9As Vice President Ford's jetliner slipped through the darkened skies just after midnight earlier this week, one passenger glanced at the gathering of Cabinet members and Senators aboard and jokingly observed, Maybe this is the making of a cabal.

title: The queen lost her heart, he lost his head
description: The Elizabethan world was a wild world in which the courtiers and the aristocrats moved about like demigods, ruled by the goddess herselfDiana, Cynthia, Gloriana, Pandora, the Lady of the Sea, or, more mundanely, Elizabeth I. And as if to set themselves apart from common humanity, they dressed evermore elaborately. Never in English history have clothes for males been so outrageous or so expensive. Sir Edmund Bacon wore 138 gold, buttons on a suit that he discarded after wearing once. And women did not lag behind. The Viscount Montague cheerfully spent 1,500 on two dresses for his daughters to make a good show at Court. The goddess herself was incredibly bedecked. Emblazoned like an icon; dress, petticoats, stomachers and wig ablaze with jewels; her face set in a frame of elaborate starched lace.

title: KLANSMAN FOUND GUILTY OF KILLING
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 9A frail, bespectacled, 22yearold man who says he is a member of the Ku Klux Klan has been convicted of killing last Nov. 26 a black Gadsden minister he did not know.

title: QUESTIONS
description: The questions appearing in this column are asked and answered by readers in exchange of gardening knowledge. If you have a question or answer, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be published. Please include stamped return envelope.

title: The Nation
description: Throughout the Arab oil embargo, there has been doubt about how effective it really was, either by design or disunity. Now the embargo seems to be approaching an end, and there is doubt about when, and even where, a resumption of shipments will be announced.

title: Penn State Takes Title Gymnastics
description: ITHACA, N. Y., March 9Penn State won its fourth straight Eastern intercollegiate gymnastics championship last night at Cornell's Barton Hall by narrowly defeating Southern Connecticut, 161.55 to 160.15.

title: Brewers Leave Their Mark on Bushwick
description: The el over Brooklyn's Broadway storms with steady thunder and darkness. The KK and QJ trains pound above the florid flatiron of the Bush wick RKO, scene of a million movie matinees and now of live musical extravaganzas direct from San Juan.

title: OPINION: NoCut Contracts Cheat the Fan
description: An American Basketball Association player on an opposing team recently told members of the San Antonio Spurs that he was not going to take a shot in the game against them that night. He kept his word, too.

title: Hilda B. Smith Is Bride on L.I.
description: WADING RIVER, L. I., March 9Miss Hilda Burgess Smith, daughter of Dr. Harold H. Smith, senior geneticist at the Brookhaven National, Laboratory, and of Mrs. Smith of Shoreham, was married here this morning to Dr. Don Delaruse Hodges, a resident physician for chest diseases at the University of Michigan Medical Center.

title: Heavy Mayonnaise Wins
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (AP)Heavy Mayonnaise edged Don't Be Late Jim by a nose to win the $25,000 Louisiana Derby Trial Handicap at the Fair Grounds race track today. The winner ran the mile and 40 yards in 1:39 45 and returned $4.20.

title: Friday's Fights
description: New York (At Madison Square Garden)  Vito Antuofermo, 158 pounds, New York, outpointed John L. Sullivan, 156, Olympia, Wash., 10 rounds.

title: Television
description: THERE will be no escaping Marlo Thomas and her friends. If, for your sins, a prior appointment with a gas pump or Leon Jaworski prevents you froth seeing Miss Thomas's special tomorrow night at 8 on ABC, Free To Be . . You and Me is also available in book form  with sheet music, in both hardcover and paperback editions from McGrawHill. And an LP record consisting of much of the same material has been around long enough for every bar to be burned into the brain of my daughter, who sings Mommies Are People even as she dissects her pet gerbil.

title: Mrs. Hugh L. Carey Dies; Representative's Wife, 49
description: Mrs. Helen Owen Carey, the wife of Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, died of cancer Friday night at Lenox Hill Hopsital. She was 49 years old.

title: Pele Will Attend World Cup Matches but He Will Talk, Not Play
description: Brazil will open the World Cup on June 13 in Frankfurt, West Germany, against Yugoslavia, and it is now definite that Pel, Tostao and Gerson, the men who helped Brazil win its third World Cup four years ago, will be thereas radio commentators.

title: Lucky seven
description: It was in 1933 that an official of Standard Oil of California named Lloyd Hamilton outwitted British bidders and bought from King Ibn Saud, the mighty ruler of Arabia, the right to search for oil over a concession surrounding the Al Hasa oasis, on the east coast of Saudi Arabia.

title: RICHARDSON SEES WATERGATE BENEFIT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9 (AP)Former United States Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said today there is much that is positive and encouraging in the recent months of the Watergate investig??tion.

title: Is a Failure
description: Vacancy decontrol has permitted sharp increases in rents in the city. And yet, it has failed to achieve its Wowed purposes. For these reasons the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy appointed by former Governor Rockefeller to study the effects of vacancy decontrol is urging its repeal.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: House Plant Feeding
description: WITH the added light from lengthening days, winterlagging house plants begin their spring awakening. Feeding becomes a regular task.

title: Chile Taking Cuban Defector
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9 (Reuters)Chile will give political asylum to a Cuban woman tennis player, Aleida Spex, who sought refuge in the Chilean Embassy in the Dominican Republic, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Windmill Home in Queens
description: Richard Ostergren's home is not nearly so spacious or luxurious as those of his neighbors in Douglaston, Queens, but it is different. After all, not everyone goes home at night to a 255yearold pink windmill.

title: New U.S. Ski Coach Planning to Rebuild With Youth
description: Stowe, Vt.Hank Tauber, the recently appointed director of the United States Alpine ski squad, is concentrating on youth. He attributes part of his move in that direction to the large numbers of promising youngsters he's seen in the East in the last two weeks.

title: BurglarProofing of Homes
description: PLANDOME MANOR, L.I. The Neighborhood Security Unit of the Nassau County Police Department has been called in to keep a rash of burglaries from spreading in one of the richest communities in Nassau County.

title: Hearst Abductors Score Food Plan in a New Tape
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 9The Symbionese Liberation Army broke its long silence tonight with a message to Randolph A. Hearst accusing him of being deceitful and dis??est in negotiations for the ease of his 20yearold kid??ped daughter.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: SAIGON DISPLAYING DIPLOMATIC VIGOR
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9South Vietnam has begun to inject a bit of vigor into its conduct of foreign relations, for years an area of neglect overshadowed by war and Washington.

title: TechnicalLandmark Quest
description: LLOYDS NECK, L.I.John Gable seems to do things a little bit backwardhe hunts for windmills in the city and factories in the country and he has already found samples of both.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Organic Food Myth Dispelled
description: SAN FRANCISCO Basically, whether you have a garden 5 feet long and 2 feet wide in Westchester or 10,000 acres in California's Central Valley, there are still only two ways to grow tomatoes.

title: Manes Testing Political Waters For Possible Gubernatorial Sail
description: Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes, who has been taking political soundings on his chances of winning the Democratic nomination for Governor, declared last week that the reaction had been excellent so far.

title: Son to Mrs. Yates
description: A son was born here on March 2 to Mr. and Mrs. Timothy T. Yates of Islip, L.I. at Lenox Hill Hospital, The child, the couple's second son, has been named Christopher LeMaire.

title: A Store Just for Handmade Crafts
description: It is called CraftHog, bu?? one should not expect to buy bacon, ham, or sausage there

title: Waldrop's 3:59.5 Mile Extends Streak
description: DETROIT, March 9Tony Waldrop capped the most remarkable string of mile races in indoor track history today with his seventh consecutive subfourminute performance in winning the event at the National Collegiate championships.

title: Gail Fordyce Married
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 9  Miss Gail Ann Fordyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gailon Corwin Fordyce of Smoke Rise, N. J., was married here this afternoon to Dr. William Houston Sailing Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sailing of Wilmington. The Rev. H. Langill Watson performed the ceremony in the Grumman Chapel of the University Methodist Church. Dr. Sailing, a dentist in Durham, was previously married and divorced.

title: BUCKLEY ASSAILS STUDENT CARTOON
description: Senator James L. Buckley has called on the directors of the civilrights divisions of both the Justice Department and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to investigate whether Federal discrimination statutes had been violated in the publication of a cartoon in a City College student newspaper.

title: NIXON HELD AWARE OF QUERY ON FUND
