description: MIAMI, March 9A spokesman for President Nixon said today that the White House was aware of contradictory statements by the President about his knowledge that funds had been given to the original Watergate defendants in return for their silence about the role of higherups in the Watergate case.

title: David Reiss to Wed Marianne C. Shallow
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., March 9Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Shallow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marianne Carol Shallow, to David Lawrence Reiss son of Mrs. William Reiss of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Mr. Reiss.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Bard at Hofstra: Multimedia Event
description: For some students, it is winning a varsity letter. For others, it is being elected to student government. But at Hofstra University, there is a group of undergraduates who would be loathe to graduate without participating in the school's annual Shakespeare Festival.

title: Justice Official Opposes Newsmen's Total Immunity
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 9 (DPI) Assistant Attorney General Robert G. Dixon Jr. said today that giving news reporters absolute immunity from having to disclose their confidential sources would provide the press with unrestrained freedom to destroy public careers.

title: The Shrinking Slush Piles
description: The biggest slush pile in publishing just dried up. Doubleday made no public announcement. Manuscripts from unknowns are being returned unopened.

title: Dance
description: IN foundation, organization and impetus, moderndance companies are clearly different from classic ballet troupes. A company such as the Paris Opra Ballet, centuries old, will go through good times and bad times. It will have its creative moments and its barren intervals, but it will continue to survive, because it is a machine for dancing.

title: True Knight Triumphs in Bowie Race
description: BOWIE, Md., March 9A skillful ride today by Angel Cordero, who picked his way through heavy traffic, provided favored True Knight with a comefrombehind victory in the 21st running of the $118,000 John B. Campbell Handicap at Bowie Race Course.

title: Carol Seabrook, Lawyer, to Be Wed
description: Miss Carol Ormsby Seabrook, a lawyer with Wender, Murase & White in New York plans to be married in June to Jacques Pierre Rodolphe Boulanger, an investment banker with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York.

title: N.C. State Wins Title In Overtime
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 9 (AP)Tom Burleson scored 38 points and Monte Towe delivered two clutch free throws with six seconds left in overtime, giving topranked North Carolina State a 103100 victory over, Maryland for the championship of the Atlantic Coast Conference tonight.

title: Militant Mood Reported in Shanghai
description: HONG KONG, March 3 Travelers from China say that Shanghai has a markedly more political and militant atmosphere than other Chinese cities.

title: Miss Foscato Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Raymond Foseato of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss DeLourde Foscato, to Peter Brian Owen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Seaman Owen of Garden City, L. I. An August wedding is planned.

title: 2 Towns Adopt AssetDisclosure Laws
description: EAST BRUNSWICKNew Jersey officials are viewing, as a sign of the times and the beginning of a trend, two newly adopted conflictofinterest ordinances that require local officials to disclose their assets.

title: FELIX SCRAG, 82, SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: OWOSSO, Mich., March 9 (AP)Felix Schlag, who won $1,000 in 1938 for his design of the Jefferson nickel, died today at Owosso Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: A Sad Double Standard
description: Two items from The New York Times:

title: Architecture
description: IN New York, Grace Church seems to be going ahead with its plan to demolish its two 19thcentury Gothic Revival houses for a new school and community activities building, wringing its hands all the way to the bulldozer.

title: 23 South Vietnamese Children Killed as Shell Hits Schoolyard
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 (AP)A mortar shell landed in a primary school playground in the Mekong Delta today, killing 23 children and wounding 32, the Saigon military command reported.

title: The School Aid Bills
description: Within the last two weeks, President Nixon has issued two separate warnings that he would veto the pending school and legislation if Congress were to approve the bill that is now under consideration in the Senate. At the same time, unofficial word from the White House indicates that the President would sign the bill coming out of the House Education and Labor Committee.

title: Reid Gubernatorial Drive Steps Off Early With a Walking Tour
description: The calendar may say March, but Representative Ogden R. Reid is already campaigning as if it were October.

title: Rebel Turned Classicist
description: ISTILL look back with awe and pleasure on the spectacle of Paul Taylor playing Paul Taylor in a ballet by George Balanchine. Actually, Episodes, when it was given its premiere in 1959, was an unlikely twopart collaboration between Balanchine and Martha Graham. And in the middle of Balanchine's half of the ballet, PAU Taylor, then a member of the Graham company, walked onto the stage dwarfing the exiting ballet dancers  and began, with great composure and the winsome deadpan he often affects, to bend his body into some astonishing knots.

title: Green Wins Dash In School Track
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 9Neil Green of Millbrook won the. 60yard dash in 6.2 seconds and Ken Murphy of North Salem was a double winner last night in the Section One scholastic indoor track championships at the West Point fieldhouse.

title: An Approach to Dtnte, Trade and Human Rights
description: The United States is approaching a choice in the next few weeks about whether economic relations with Soviet Union should be developed or discouraged. The forthcoming Senate debate on the Trade Reform Act, with its proposed amendment to prohibit credits and normal tariff status to the Soviet Union unless that country permits free emigration, will have an importent effect on the future course SovietAmerican relations.

title: Sweet Morsels From Raisin
description: RAISIN IN THE SUN became, as Raisin, a much better musical than one might have expected. For this we can thank a score by Judd Woldin and Robert Brittan that underlines the flavor of the play and a cast that, in Donald McKayle's dynamic staging, has both the musical and dramatic projection to make the most of that score. The transferral of Raisin from theater to disk (Columbia KS 32754), however, points up the interdependence of elements that makes Raisin an effective theater work. Without the visual impact created by McKayle's staging and by the physical presence of such actorsingers as Virginia Capers and Ernestine Jackson, the relatively routine nature of many of the songs becomes more evident.

title: Mrs. Hill Wed To Tom Wicker At Home Here
description: The marriage of Mrs. Pamela Hill, a producer of documentary programs for the American Broadcasting Company, to Tom Wicker, an asociate editor and a columnist for The New York Times, took place here yesterday afternoon.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  When a German or British or French or American motorist pays 20 or 30 cents more a gallon for gasoline than he did a year ago, obviously he has less money to spend on other things. His real total consumption must go down by some amount from what it would have been.

title: Wheels Are Turning With 665 Applicants
description: DETROIT, March 9 (UPI)More than 600 aspiring players crammed into the offices of the Detroit Wheels of the New World Football League today for a mass interview.

title: Dogs Join Dignitaries of World In Gaining Philatelic Posterity
description: The international appeal of the dog is manifested in recent issues of stamps from the sunny Mediterranean, to Central Europe, the Balkans and the Persian Gulf.

title: Hasty Flyer, at $20.40, Posts Upset at Hialeah
R. J. Schneider to Wed Miss Cunningham
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 9  Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Cunningham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Cunningham, to Robert J. Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schneider of New York, where Mr. Schneider practices law. Mr. Cunningham is vice president of international operations in the Latin American division of the Continental Can Corporation.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: March 15  Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey night gimmick rally; start at Bowlero, junction of Routes 3 and 46, Clifton, N.J. Novices welcome. Registration: 7 P.M., first car off 8. Information: Barbara Rosalsky, phone (201)3349711.

title: Irene Halsman to Be Wed on March 31
description: Mr, and Mrs. Philippe Halsman of New York have announced that their daughter, Miss Irene Aline Halsman, will be married on March 31 to David Lorin Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rosenberg of Montclair, N.J.

title: Aid Is Sought for Nontenured Teachers
description: TRENTONThe Assembly's Education Committee will hold a public hearing here tomorrow on two bills that would make it procedurally more difficult for Boards of Education to dismiss certain nontenured employes.

title: Laura Butler Engaged
description: WOODBURY, L. I., March 9Mr. and Mrs. Robert Butler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Lee Butler, to Ivory Kenneth Mauldin Jr., son of Mr. Mauldin and Mrs. Hilda Marie Cotton, both of Detroit. The wedding is planned for Aug. 31.

title: F.A.O. Sees Third World Menaced by Fertilizer Cut
description: Rome, March 9A shortage, of fertilizers, aggravated by the energy crisis, is seriously; threatening food production in thirdworld countries, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported this week.

title: James D. St. Clair and His Troubled Client Are Speaking of Cooperation and Acting Combatively
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon has promised fight like hell against impeachment, and lest anyone doubt his resolve, he need only watch James Draper St. Clair, counsel for the defense in the developing case against Richard Nixon. Mr. St. Clair, ever so elegantly, is making good on the President's promise.

title: Immaculata Five Wins
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 9 (AP)Topseeded Immaculata College of Pennsylvania defeated East Stroudsburg, Pa., 6051, to win the MidAtlantic Regional women's basketball championship today. Federal City of Washington defeated West Chester (Pa.) State 5856, in the consolation game.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: The Big Scramble for Scarce Benzene
description: Some call benzene a superstar of the petrochemical industry. Others call it a pain in the neck. Still others, particularly purchasing agents, wish they had never heard of it.

title: BUCKLEY ASSAILS STUDENT CARTOON
description: Senator James L. Buckley has called on the directors of the civilrights divisions of both the Justice Department and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to investigate whether Federal dis crimination statutes had been violated in the publication of a cartoon in a City College student newspaper.

title: Energy Gap Makes It Harder to Sell a House
description: Stephen Harrold of Long Valley, N.J., is a religious man, so he finds that it helps to take his biggest problem to church with him each Sunday.

title: Bill Would Establish Unit On Problems of the Aging
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)Legislation proposed by Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, would set up a National Institute of Aging for research in geriatric medicine and problems of the aging.

title: New Judicial Sensitivity
description: A child was dragged from her bicycle on a Baltimore street and murdered. A suspect was arrested, a radio station broadcast that he had a long criminal record, that he had confessed, that he had reenacted the murder for the police and led them to the buried weapon. Local feeling was so aroused by the broadcast that the suspect's lawyer, fearing he could never get an impartial jury, agreed to have the case tried by judges.

title: Fort Greene Park To Get Lost Eagles
description: Four bronze eagles which were part of the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument in For?? Greene Park have been found after a diligent and often frustrating search for almost eight years by Roy Vanasco, Republican leader of the 57th Assembly District.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE revoked its favorable 1969 tax ruling that paved the way for International Telephone and Telegraph to acquire the Hartford Fire Insurance Company. I.T.T. said the I.R.S. action is wrong. ... The wholesale price index in February rose 1.2 per cent, compared with a leap of 3.1 per cent in January. The February level was 152.7 per cent of the 1967 base.

title: Social Animals Do Not Always Compete
description: When Charles Darwin sought to explain his observations of biological phenomena by a theory of natural selection, he did not himself use the term the survival of the fittest. It was Herbert Spencer, the 19thcentury philosopher, who coined the phrase, when he applied the Darwinian principle of biological evolution to all aspects of thought and life, including human social organization.

title: Joan Banks Affianced
description: ALPINE, N. J., March 9The engagement of Miss Joan Marie Banks to Daniel Joseph Mulcahy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Peter Banks, parents of the future bride. Her fianc, a lawyer with the New York firm of Breed Abbott & Morgan, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Mulcahy of Silver Spring, Md. Miss Banks is an alumna of Marymount College of Virginia and Marymount Manhattan College. Mr. Mulcahy is a graduate of Syracuse University and the University of Virginia Law School.

title: Opryland Is a Dream to Believe In
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. IT'S a recent Saturday night in Nashville, and I wait with the crowds to get into the Grand Ole Opry. I wait with the other believers and dreamers to push past the ugly face of the Opryhouse and reach the sweet inside. As usual, most of the crowd has come great distances to get into this show. The parking lot is a testament to the faith: dusty pickup trucks, chartered buses and silver campers.

title: Spain, as Ever, Contradictory
description: In a Europe where the news is phrased in repetitive abstractionsdevaluations, cabinet crises, elections with inscrutable results, conferences in Brusselsevents in Spain preserve a most original concreteness.

title: Number of Farms In State Dips 2%
description: TRENTONThe number of farms in operation in the state in 1973 dropped 2 per cent from the year before, according to the New Jersey Crop Reporting Service. The 1973 farm total was estimated at 8,100, as compared with 8,300 in 1972.

title: Athletic Recruiting: A Campus Crisis
description: America's college campuses, rocked by unrest in the nineteensixties, are being shaken again by a new crisis: a frenzied slave market in recruiting and paying athletes.

title: The Region/ Continued
description: Gerte Tuckler is 70 years old. She has been partially disabled since the age of 5 when her spine was damaged during an operation meant to cure the effects of polio. As a result, she is only four feet six inches tall. Age has made her deaf.

title: Syrian Guns Fire Across Truce Line in Golan Area
description: BANIYAS, Occupied Syria, March 9 (AP)Syrian artillery fired briefly across the IsraeliSyrian ceasefire line today as Israeli troops and tanks reinforced the front against any Syrian offensive.

title: Music in Review
description: The Carnegie Hall Corporation has a series called Concert Artists of Puerto Rico, which It cosponsors with the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs. On Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall the performer in it was Evangeline Collin, a soprano with a doctor of music degree from the Florida State University in Tallahassee who now teaches at the University of Puerto Rico.

title: ALUMINUM PENNY MAY BE IN OFFING
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz called upon Congress this week to grant his department authority to produce aluminum pennies because the price of copper is approaching the point where the metal content of a penny will be worth more than one cent.

title: Social Announcements
description: Engagements

title: The Region
description: There is speculation that highly publicized crimes sometimes generate similar crimes. Kidnapping, a fairly infrequent crime in the United states since the Lindbergh case in 1932, has recent. ly received national attention because of the California kidnapping of Patricia Hearst. Yet another abduction, this time with a happy ending, occurred on Long Island. John Calzadilla, the 8yearold son of a tire company sales representative, was kidnapped and later released after the boy's father paid $50,000 ransom.

title: Public in Poll Sets $152 as Needed Pay For Family of Four
description: The American public estimates that an average minimum of $152 e week is needed by a nonfarm family of four to to meet basic necessities, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: At Last, the Truth About Cows
description: The author, former director of the Folger Shakespeare Library and now historical consultant to the National Geographic Society, describes life as a smalltown boy in Barefoot in Arcadia, a book of recollections to be published in September. Following an excerpt.

title: FEDERALISM KEY TO BELGIAN VOTE
description: BRUSSELS, March 9Federalism is a word with the same political impact in Belgium that impeachment has in the United States.

title: Robert Vogel Fiance Of Michele Roberts
description: WESTBURY, L.I., March 9 Mr. and Mrs. Albert Roberts have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michele Janet Roberts, to Robert J. Vogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. Martin Vogel of New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: CITY CENTER SITE MAYBE CLEARED
description: The City Center of Music and Drama is negotiating to sell its lease to a builder who is planning a major residential and commercial development covering most of the block between 55th and 56th Streets from the Avenue of the Americas to Seventh Avenue.

title: ISRAEL OPPOSITION ADAMANT ON LAND
When Is an Auction Not an Auction? (You Might Be the Last to Know)
description: THE art auction business has been getting bigger and bigger and yet bigger over the last decade, as everybody knows from newspaper reports of one multi  million dollar recordbreaker after another. Not everybody, however, is favored to receive installments of the curiouser and curiouser corpus of documents released through mailing lists, in which the major auction houses summarize their salesroom victories in terms of public service. Their major interest, it seems, is not in making money for themselves, but in seeing that you and I get a fair shake as buyer or seller with the auctioneer as benevolent middleman.

title: A RealLife Drama at P.A.F.
description: HUNTINGTON STATION Ten years ago Clint Marantz, then a teacher in the English Department of Huntington High School, took a leave of absence to found a professional theater that would use the performing arts as a teaching tool.

title: Ford to Aid 2 in House
description: WASHINGTON, March 9, (AP)Vice President Ford will attend fundraising affairs for two Kansas Republican Representatives April 13, their offices said Tuesday. They are Larry Winn Jr., who is seeking a fifth term in the House, and Keith G. Sebelius, who is running for a fourth term.

title: Byrne Monitors State Contracts
description: TRENTONThe Byrne administration has begun to formulate a new policy of awarding state contracts. The object, according to Richard C. Leone, the State Treasurer, is to eliminate a traditional system in New Jersey politics under which heavy contributors to political parties or election campaigns often end up with lucrative state contracts.

title: 2 Titles For Baruch Track Star
description: Tyrone Cunningham, who entered Baruch College last September as a 24yearold freshman, made his debut in the 21st annual Collegiate Track Conference championships yesterday, scored 20 points and set a meet record at Queens College, Flushing.

title: DR. FRANCIS UTLEY, EDUCATOR, 66, DIES
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 9  Dr. Francis L. Utley, author and professor of English and folklore at Ohio State University, died yesterday in Riverside Methodist Hospital. He age was 66.

title: Labor Zionist Chief Backs Jackson Plan For Curb on Soviet
description: The president of the Labor Zionist Alliance urged yesterday the passage of the Jackson amendment that would bar credits and favored treatment to countries that restrict emigration and rejected Secretary, of State Kissinger's opposition to the amendment.

title: Student Weds Miss Ambrose
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 9  Miss Kathleen Anne Ambrose and Thomas Hugh Ley, seniors at the University of Maryland, were married here this afternoon in the university's Memorial Chapel. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. James F. Meade of Deer Park, L.I., a member of the order of the White Fathers of Africa.

title: 5 TeenAgers Held in L.I. Kidnapping
description: Five New Jersey teenagers, including a 17yearold girl, were charged yesterday with kidnapping 8yearold John Calzadilla, as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pressed their search for two more suspects.

title: Militant Mood Reported in Shanghai
description: By FOX BUITERFIELD special to The New York TimesHONG KONG, March 3Travelers from China say that Shanghai has a markedly more political and militant atmosphere than other Chinese cities.

title: A Decade of Tomorrow's Golden Oldies  Today
description: TEN years isn't old, as record companies goColumbia will be 87 this year, for instance but it's a good start. First thing you know, Nonesucn Records, which was born in 1964, will be sitting there in a rocking chair on the front porch along with the other oldtimers in the business, talking about the good old days when music came to you out of loudspeakers. And, no doubt, reissuing golden oldies from its vaults.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: These stories are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: MRS. MITCHELL SAYS CALL WAS THWARTED
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell complained yesterday that when she had tried to return repeated phone calls from the Senate Watergate committee's chief counsel, Samuel Dash, she was shunted to the special Watergate prosecutor's office by a committee staff member.

title: Promises
description: The signs are subtle, but down at the root of things the processes that will add up to spring are busily at work. The leaf and the flower so compactly waiting in the buds on lilac bush and maple tree will not burst into being overnight. They had their beginning last summer, and in some mysterious way they are almost ready now for April. Most of the flowering bulbs needed the winter rest to rouse their summer vitality, and many of the wildflower seeds would not sprout without having felt winter's icy bite.

title: News of the Camera World
description: THE Film Forum, 256 West 88th Street, is a small experimental theater which screens independently made 16mm films, and tonight they are showing a retrospective of New York documentaries by Rudy Burckhardt, starting at 8 P.M. The films, which have been showing each evening since Thursday of last week, will again be screened this week, Thursday through Sunday, (March 710), at 8 P.M. To include six short films that span a 30year period, the complete program takes 85 minutes. The phone number is (212) 3620503.

title: Little Notice Is Taken Of Stalin Aniversary
description: MOSCOW, March 9 (UPI) Two small bouquets lay on the ground in front of the 8foothigh granite bust, but otherwise nobody seemed to pay much attention to the tomb of Stalin.

title: Craig Lubin to Marry Susan Ablon
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, March 9Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Ablon of Shaker Heights and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ablon, to Craig Howard Lubin, son or Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lubin of Tulsa, Okla. The wedding is planned for June 2 at the Oakwood Country Club in Cleveland Heights.

title: FEDERALISM KEY TO BELGIAN VOTE
description: BRUSSELS, March 9Fee eralism is a word with th same political impact in Be Slam that impeachment ha in the United States.

title: Nancy Amy Bride of Howard Pywell 3d
description: WATCHUNG, N. J., March 9Miss Nancy Pauline Arny and Howard Ross Pywell 3d, doctoral candidates in the School of Forestry at the University of Masachusetts, were married here this noon.

title: Grace Lawson, Robert A, Cohn To Be Married
description: POTOMAC, Md., March 9 Mr. and Mrs. Joel Smith Lawson Jr. of Potomac and Honolulu have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Colgate Lawson, to Robert Ashley Cohn, son of Robert Cohn of Potomac and Mrs. Margaret Elizabeth Collier Cohn. The wedding is planned for June 15.

title: They Sell All Kinds of Drugs On Television
description: TELEVISION has a knack for demanding not just the suspension but the obliteration of disbelief. Basic training for the viewer begins in the commercials, stuffed with adultlike children, childlike young adults and constipated or arthritic elders ("If the doctor said so, Madge, it must be good"). After that, it's easy.

title: L.l. Youth Killed in Collision
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., March 9 (UPI)A Long Island teenager was killed shortly after midnight in a twocar crash here. The Suffolk County Police said the driver of the other car had been arrested for driving while intoxicated. The victim was John Nuss, 19years old, of 18 Woodland Drive, Old Bethpage. Arrested on a charge of driving while intoxicated in the collision at the intersection of Old County and Manetto Hill Roads was David Ashe, 35, of 29 Ferney Street, Hicksville.

title: Wendy L. Wile Plans Nuptials
description: WESTON, Mass., March 9 Miss Wendy Lyn Wile and Brantz Mayer Bryan Jr. of Falmouth and Montclair, N. J., son of Mrs. Bryan of Montclair and East Chop, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and the late Mr. Bryan, will be married this spring.

title: Is It Far Out Or Old Hat?
description: I understand that there is considerable controversy going on just now over the propriety of nominating performers for Academy Awards whose work has actually been a composite: substituted voices, substituted bodies, and so on. That's one thing about the theater: no faking. When, in the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's production of Charles Ludlum's Hot Ice, a policeman rises from his card game to urinate, he urinates: unzips, delivers, rezips all by himself. He may not persuade us that his need was quite as urgent as he'd announced it wasperhaps he was overrehearsed  but if, come spring, there's an award in this category, it's his and his alone.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN the last few years, it has become fashionable question the concept of economic growth. Attention has turned toward measuring the quality rather than just the quantity of national wellbeing, and the issue is often encapsulated in a question: growth for what?

title: BALTIMORE TRIAL IN FINAL PHASES
description: BALTIMORE, March 9 The extortion trial of the chief official of Baltimore County has entered its final phases in Federal District Court here, but apparently it will be several days before the case goes to the jury.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, seeking a National Basketball Association playoff berth for the 14th straight season and a sixth consecutive Pacific Division title, will meet the New York Knicks in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night at 7:30. Thursday the Knicks start a fourgame road trip against the Golden State Warriors in Oakland.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Hammocks Are for Wildlife
description: PUNTA GORDA, Fla.Armadillos scuttled across the shademottled floor of Counterfeit Hammock, and the glossy, green leaves of wild grapefruit, orange and calamondin trees beckoned.

title: Where It's Shady
description: THOSE whose gardens are shaded by trees or buildings should consider themselves lucky for they can grow many different plants that those with sunny gardens cannot. Many plants require shade to grow properly while others will endure shade. It is just a matter of selecting plants carefully and knowing their requirements.

title: Carol Bancker Is the Fiancee Of A. W. Vietor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I, March 9Mrs. William D. Bancker 4th has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Lynn Snicker. to Alexander Wellman Vietor. He is the ton of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander O. Vietor of New Haven and Old Lyme, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass.

title: GULAG DELAYED BY TRANSLATION
description: The United States publication date of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956 has been postponed for about four weeks because of differences of opinion between translators as well as other factors, according to publishing executives.

title: World News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, March (UPI)  A man and woman killed a rightwing Peronist last night and a bomb damaged the offices of a leftwing daily this morning. Bombs also exploded in front of two United States branch banks here.

title: Competition Tough in Basketball Tourney on Wheels
description: The main point Fred Francis wants to convey about this weekend's Eastern regional wheelchair basketball tournament is that it's for real.

title: Scalawags, Readjusters, Populists and others
description: Southern Dissenters in the Nineteenth Century. By Carl N. Degler. 392 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.

title: Arabs Appear to Be Split Over Easing Oil Embargo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 9 A major Arab split seems to have developed over Egypt's insistence that the American effort to bring about military disengagement with Israel should be matched by a relaxation of Arab oil testrictions.

title: Rabbit Boss
description: Imagine that we are making up a parable about the Winning of the West. Imagine two characters. One is an Indian, the native host. He might be like Don Juan, the Yaqui mystic of Carlos Castenada's books: a man who doesn't abstract himself from nature, a nondisturber, nonachiever who talks to birds and is counseled by winds. The other, the white newcomer, is his polar opposite, an adventurer and outlaw. Imagine these two meeting.

title: Mangan Duo Upset In Platform Tennis
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 9John Mangan and Bob Kingsbury, the defending champions, were eliminated today in the quarter finals of the national platform tennis doubles championship, 63, 68, 63, 64, by Bradley Drowne and Hank Irvine.

title: A Shortcut to Vegetables
description: BOOKS on gardening stress the importance of spading or otherwise loosening the soil to a depth of several inches before planting vegetables. This notion the aging, infirm or lazy gardener can forget, at least for sweet corn, squash, and tomatoes.

title: Jury in the Tramunti Case Recesses Its Deliberation
description: A jury deliberated for several hours yesterday without reaching a verdict in the narcotics trial of Carmine Tramunti, a reputed Mafia chief, prosecution as the chairman of the board  the financier of a massive heroin operation.

title: The Boxwoods
description: EVERY one who travels South comes back thrilled by the boxwoods they have seen in Mt. Vernon, Colonial Williamsburg or in the many southern gardens. Some bring back plants they have purchased.

title: Israel: The Strongest of the Weak Survives the Infighting
CITY CENTER SITE MAY BE CLEARED
description: The City Center of Music and Drama is negotiating to sell its lease to a builder who is planning a major residential and commercial development covering most of the block between 55th and 56th Streets from the Avenue of the Americas to Seventh Avenue.

title: Lion Back Arrested
description: KINGSVILLE, Tex., March 9 (AP)Levi Johnson, a defensive back with the Detroit Lions, was arrested yesterday along with three Texas A. and I. University athletes for investigation of rifiarijuana possession, the police reported. They were taken into county court, where bond was set at $500 each. Johnson was a rookie standout for the Lions last season. He was dismissed from the A. and I. football team his senior year for disciplinary reasons.

title: Youths Tell How to Save River
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I.Acknowledging that they are never too high, mighty or old to learn from youth, a group of civic and political leaders sat meekly in a high school cafeteria and allowed a group of high school students to lecture them on how best to preserve the Nissequogue River.

title: Foyt Is Too Revved Up to Quit Auto Racing
description: In a car whose engine was built by A. J. Foyt and whose chassis was designed by A. J. Foyt, the man most experts say is the greatest American driver in history will start from the pole position today in the $300,000 California 500. The man's name is. A. J. Foyt and he has won over the hallowed bricks of Indianapolis and through the famed turns of Le Mans. He's lion even on the dirt in Nebraska and no driver hats won as many United States Auto Club Championship Trail events or national titles.

title: 2 Rosenberg Sons Try to Vindicate Executed Parents
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 9For 20 years they have lived in quiet obscurity: going to college, venturing into radical politics and student protests, then marrying and rearing children. But for Michael and Robert Meeropol, growing up in America was not quite the same as for most young people, for they carried a searing childhood memory that would not go away.

title: Dobson Stops Orioles
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 9  Even though they're paying him a hefty premium, Pat Dobson believes he's worth more to the Yankees than serving as a mere insurance policy. And if not to the Yankees, then someone else.

title: GULAG DELAYED BY TRANSLATION
description: The United States publication date of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956 has been postponed for about four weeks because of differences of opinion between translators as well as other factors, according to publishing executives.

title: He Won't Kick His Bad Habits
description: TERRENCE McNALLY plops his Bloody Mary down on the coffee table of his snug West Village apartment and takes a long, immensely satisfying drag on his cigarette. His blond hair is closecropped his eyes babyblue, and as he sinks onto the sofa, sipping and smoking and shushing Charley; his peppery puffball of a dog, he looks like a slightly fallen, 34yearold cherub.

title: Stress Prosperity In 1974 Campaigns, Ford Advises G.O.P.
description: Led by Vice President Ford, Republican leaders urged party members yesterday to take the offensive in the battles for Congressional seats this year by stressing the Nixon policy of peace and prosperity and the failings of the Democraticled Congress.

title: Business Lobbyists Converge On Albany
description: ALBANYMembers of the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry descended on Albany last week for a twoday lobbying session with the legislators who represent them.

title: MRS. ARTHUR G. WARD
description: MELVILLE, LI., March 9Mrs. Rita Close Ward, secretarytreasurer of Gamut International, Ltd., an advertising agency, which she founded with her husband, Arthur G. Ward, died yesterday at her home, 9 Vista Lane, after a long illness. Her age was 48.

title: BONN AIDE FAILS ON SOVIET MISSION
description: MOSCOW, March 9The West German Minister for Special Affairs, Egon Bahr, eded 10day visit here today without brealchig the deadlock over a complex issue that has become a touchstone in SovietWest German relations as well as Chancellor Willy Brandt's Eastern policy.

title: First Big Challenge For Toll Roads
description: In rising through the rough and tumble of New Jersey politics to become head of the Garden State Parkway, John P. Gallagher earned a reputation as a man who was not easily discouraged.

title: Margaret Schenkel Garden City Bride
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 9In the Garden City Community Church this afternoon, Miss Margaret Johnston Schenkel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Schenkel, was married to Frank Alfred Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Watson of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg performed the ceremony.

title: SOCCER SPURRING CATALONIA PRIDE
description: BARCELONA, SpainIn this capital of what was once autonomous Catalonia, a 26yearold Dutchman with one of the fastest pairs of legs in European soccer is doing more for local, pride and regionalist sentiment than any political leader could hope to achieve.

title: Diagramless, 16 by 21
description: ACROSS

title: Miss Errath Wins World Skate Title
description: MUNICH, West Germany, March 9 (AP)  Christine Errath, a petite 17yearold from East Berlin, won the women's figure skating title at the 1974 World championships tonight, completing the first East European sweep of the four world titles.

title: BALTIMORE TRIAL IN FINAL PHASES
description: BALTIMORE, March 9 The extortion trial of the chief official of Baltimore County has entered its final phases in Federal District Court here, but apparently it will be several days before the case goes to the jury.

title: British Concerns Urged To Raise Africans' Pay
description: LONDON, March 9 (Reuters) A British Parliamentary committee has urged concerns thate operate in South Africa to narrow the gap in average wages paid to black and white, workers.

title: Anticrime Unit In Detroit Broken Up by the Mayor
description: DETROIT, March 9 (UPI)One of the most controversial police units in the United States, the anticrime STRESS squad, was disbanded last night.

title: Mark Barth to Marry Jannette Morgan Berg
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., March 9  Miss Jannette Morgan Berg, who expects to be graduated this spring from Johns Hopkins University, and Mark Harold Barth, a 1973 graduate of that university, plan to be married this summer.

title: Gretchen Johnsen Colorado Bride
description: VAIL, Colo., March 9Miss Gretchen Anita Johnsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Niels Winchester Johnsen of New York, Rumson, N. J., and Vail, was married here this noon to David Grant Bryant, son of Mrs. Ruth G. Bryant of Washington and Thomas V. Bryant Jr. of Bend, Ore.

title: Russians at Exhibit Get The Facts of U.S. Life
description: KISHINEV, U.S.S.R.Can black people in America own cars? A Soviet visitor asked this question at an American outdoor exhibition on display here.

title: BONN AIDE FAILS ON SOVIET MISSION
description: MOSCOW, March 9The West German Minister for Special Affairs, Egon Bahr, eded a 10day visit here today without brealchig the deadlock over a complex issue that has become a touchstone in SovietWest German relations as well as Chancellor Willy Brandt's Eastern policy.

title: The New Third Force on the British Scene
description: LONDONWhen the new House of Commons came together, somewhere in that crowd on the floor were people named Dafydd Wigley, Hamish Watt, James Molyneaux and Michael Winstanley. They are not among the great and familiar names in British politics. But when they sit down to play parliamentary games this ydar, nobody is going laugh.

title: Headliners
description: Openness in Yonkers

title: Modern ArtA Series of OneNight Stands?
description: THERE is something irrepressibly oddball about the current exhibition, People and Places, now on view at the Downtown Branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 55 Water Street, through April 4. It looks as if the uptown museum had done a bit of housecleaning, rummaging through the attic to come up with a few treasures and a number of old souvenirs.

title: Oil Price Rollbacks, End of Tax Breaks Asked in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Three SenateHouse subcommittees recomended today that the Federal Government roll back oil prices and get into the petroleum business as a means of alleviating the energy shortage.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Europaische Treuhand Akitienegsellschaft & Co., KG, has acquired the property at 315 East 48th Street, where it plans to build a 30story, 180unit apartment building.

title: ALUMINUM PENNY MAY BE IN OFFING
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz called upon Congress this week to grant his department authority to produce aluminum pennies because the price of copper is approaching the point where the metal content of a penny will be worth more than one cent.

title: Nuptials May 11 Set By Mrs. Rinehimer
description: TUNKHANNOCK, Pa., March 9Dr. and Mrs. John S. Rinehimer Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Patricia Courtenay Rinehimer, to John Loring Swasey Jr., son of Mrs. Philip Potter of Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Swasey of New York and Tuxedo Park, N.Y., who was vice chairman of Mitchell Hutchins & Co., Inc.

title: Ashe Scores First Victory Over Layer; Aussies Lead in World Cup Tennis, 32
description: HARTFORD, March 9 When Arthur Ashe was a teenager playing at Forest Hills he was first beaten by Rod Laver. In the next 15 years he was beaten by the Australian every time they met but Ashe persevered and after 15 defeat he finally threw a punch of his own. He beat Laver today, 63, 6.3, in the Aetna World Cup tennis tournament.

title: State Drafts Rules to Bar Bias in Volunteer Fire Companies
description: TRENTON In 1989, state civil rights officials accused volunteer fire companies of discriminating against blacks.

title: Princeton: A Puzzling Art Exhibit
description: PRINCETON  Even the most intrepid student of contemporary art occasionally wanders into an exhibition that makes him feel as if he might be in the wrong place. He has been told to expect art, but, as he looks about him, he wanders whether his informants were merely pretending to see something that really was not there.

title: Chess Mednis Now in Hot Pursuit Of International Master Title
description: SICILIAN DEFENSE

title: Gallagher's Wife Will Run
description: BAYONNE, N. J., March 9 (UPI)Claire Gallagher, the wife of former United States Representative Cornelius Gallagher, today announced her candidacy in the May election for Mayor of Bayonne. She will oppose Mayor Francis G. Fitzpatrick, who is also the Hudson County Democratic chairman. Mr. Gallagher, a Bayonne Democrat, was convicted last year on incometax evasion charges and is serving a twoyear prison term at the Federal Penitentiary in Allenwood, Pa.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: $1Million Given to M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. March 9 (AP)A couple from Dallas has given the Massachusetts Institute of Technology $1million to be used for graduate student fellowships primarily awarded to women just beginning studies at M.I.T., the school announced. Cecil H. and Ida M. Green emphasized the needs of female students but did not restrict the fellowships to women in offering the gift, officials said. Each Ida M. Green Fellowship will provide $3,350 tuition for the 1974.75 academic year plus, a ninemonth stipend of $2,700.

title: Trial Set for Copter Pilot
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 9 (UPI)An April 17 trial has been scheduled for Pfc. Robert Preston, 20 years old, a Fort Meade mechanic who allegedly stole a helicopter from the military post and landed it on the White House lawn.

title: 3 Charged by F.B.I. With Plot to Kidnap A Foreign Diplomat
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP)A young woman and two jailed men were charged today with plotting to kidnap a foreign consul general to bargain for therelease of the two men, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Largest Radio Scope Planned by U.S.
description: SOCORRO, N. M., March 10A $76million Federal project to construct the world's largest and most sophisticated radio astronomy telescope to probe new distances into space has been begun on an isolated, arid ranch area near the eastern slopes of the Continental Divide.

title: Ethiopian General Strike Ended; Workers Due Back at Jobs Today
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 10 (Reuters)Ethiopia's general strike was called off tonight and labor unions announced that the approximately 100,000 workers would be back tomorrow.

title: Fund Crisis Closing Circle in Square
description: Faced with a financial crisis, Circle in the Square, one of New York's most eminent institutional, theaters, plans to close March 24, ending 23 years of continuous operation. The Circle needs $191,110 to meet this season's operating budget of $1,560,000.

title: Election Held in EI Salvador Is the First Since '72 Coup
description: SAN SALVADOR, March 10 (Reuters)  El Salvador held congressional and municipal elections todaythe first since charges of fraud in the presidential elections in 1972 triggered a bloody but unsuccessful coup.

title: Village Parents Seek to Avert Closing of St. Joseph's Academy
description: Parents and teachers are attempting to dissuade the Sisters of Charity from closing their 120yearold elementary school in Greenwich Village.

title: SENATOR SEES RACE BY WALLACE IN 1976
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will be a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976, his foremost ally in Congress, Senator James B. Allen said today.

title: U.S INCREASING AID TO INDOCHINA
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The costs of military and economic aid programs in Southeast Asia, which dropped sharply with the withdrawal of American forces from South Vietnam, is beginning to rise again. The increase is attributed by Administration officials to inflation and the continued fighting in South Vietnam.

title: Costly Business of Sports Recruiting Escalates Toward a Public Scandal
description: If you want a winning team, a visiting rival tells the hockey coach at a college in the Midwest, you'd better build some dorms and fill em up with booze and broadslike we did.

title: William Matthew Byrne Sr., West Coast Federal Judge
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10 (UPI)William Matthew Byrne Sr., a senior Federal Court judge here and former chief judge, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Jersey Jets Gain Wheelchair Crown
description: Joe Reilly's 3point play with 16 seconds left gave the Jersey Jets a 4847 victory over the Boston Mustangs in the Eastern Regional invitation wheelchair basketball tournament final yesterday at Queens College.

title: CITY UNIT PRAISED FOR PRODUCTIVITY
description: The city's Sanitation Department deserves high marks, for improvements in productivitygetting more for its moneythe Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday.

title: Molloy Wins, 6750, Power Five Upset
description: Molloy, the defender, and St. Francis Prep advanced to the semifinals of the Catholic High School Athletic Association basketball playoffs yesterday at St. John's University in Queens.

title: New Books
description: Bud: The Brand I Knew by Carle Fiore (Delacorte Press, $7.95). A personal biography of the actor.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Mrs. Meir Premier Again After Winning Vote, 6246
description: JERUSALEM, March 10 Premier Golda Meir and her new Cabinet took the oath of office in Parliament tonight after having received a vote of confidence.

title: SOVIET PRETENSES SATIRIZER BY POET
description: MOSCOW, March 10In a new cycle of poems, Andrei Voznesensky parodies the intellectual lethargy of Soviet cultural life today, mocks the bourgeois pretensions of an uncultured rising middle class and pokes fun at the technological revolution.

title: HELGE FIVE
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., March 10 Helge Five, a senior engineer on the Long Island Park Commission who worked on the design of buildings at Jones Beach, died here Friday at his home. He was 72 years old.

title: The Closing Circle
description: BOSTON, March 10Imagine that we had as President a person of ordinary sensitivity to right and wrong. One day he is told by his Special Counsel some news of which he has had no inkling before: His own aides have for months been covering up a crime and paying hush money to the convicted criminals.

title: MRS. MAGDA SHELDON
description: AMAGANSETT, L.I., March 10Mrs. Magda Merck Sheldon, a daughter of George W. Merck, founder of Merck & Co., the pharmaceutical manufacturers, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home here. She was 69 years old.

title: 55M.P.H.Winds Buffet the City
description: Some branches, signs, windows, awnings and many hats fell victim yesterday to leonine winds, which at times gusted to 55 miles an hour.

title: The Theater: Ulysses in Nighttown
description: The first thing to be said about Ulysses in Nighttown is that it is more Zero Mostel than James Joyce, and for Broadway audiences that is doubtless no great disadvantage. The play, which opened at the Winter Garden Theater last night, has been dramatized from aspects of James Joyce's novel Ulysses.

title: Attempt to Influence Juror
description: ALBANY, Minn., March 10 (AP)A 40yearold man was arrested today for allegedly attempting to influence a juror in the Wounded Knee trial of Dennis Banks and Russell Means, (the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported. The F.B.I. would not comment on whether the material that Richard C. Carlson mailed was damaging to the defense.

title: Seaman Presumed Drowned
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 10 (UPI)A seaman from Philadelphia apparently fell overboard from the tanker Gulf Prince last night and was believed drowned, the authorities said today. The identity of the seaman was being withheld pending notification of his family.

title: Music: Ashkenazy Keyboard Triumph
description: There are a blessed few musicians in their middle 30's whose continued growth and stillunexhausted artistic resources make their performances not to be missed. Vladimir Ashkenazy, the Sovietborn pianist who now lives in Iceland, is oneof that interesting few. Mr. Ashkenazy's recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon fulfilled all reasonable expectations, while leaving the listener with the tantalizing impression of a major musician who is headed for even more major things.

title: Toll in Vietnam Blast Is 32
description: CAI LAY, South Vietnam, March 10 (AP)The death toll from the explosion of a Vietcong mortar shell in a schoolyard here rose to 32 today, South Vietnamese officials said. Twentythree children were killed in the blast yesterday, and nine more died later in a hospital.

title: Gasoline in Brooklyn Selling at 89.2c Legally
description: A Brooklyn service station that was fined recently for selling gasoline for almost a dollar a gallon on Christmas Day is now charging dime a gallon lessand it is all perfectly legal.

title: TWO MORE SOUGHT IN L. I. KIDNAPPING
description: Boarders at a rooming house in Union City, N.J., where John Calzadilla was allegedly held for more than 25 hours last week by his abductors, recalled yesterday that they had seen the 8yearold boy during his captivity and that he was laughing and happy at times.

title: MRS. SAMUEL WILLIAMS
description: Mrs. Helen Morrison Williams principal of Public School 309 in Brooklyn, died of complications following surgery Tuesday in Interboro Hospital. She was 41 years old and lived at 778 Hendricks Street, Brooklyn.

title: British Miners Back on Job After Ratifying Settlement
description: LONDON, March 10 (AP)Britain's 280,000 coal miners returned to work tonight, ending a fourweek strike that resulted in the election defeat of the Conservative Government and seriously disrupted the national economy.

title: 76ers Surprise Knicks Third Time, 109108
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 10  Even Coach Gene Shue of the Philadelphia 76ers was shaking his head in disbelief today after his spunky squad had the audacity to upend the New York Knicks, 109108, at the Spectrum.

title: 2 SLAYINGS SPAWN TOMS RIVER FEAR
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., March 10 The sadistic murders of two teenaged girls have filled this quiet, shore community with the kind of fear that many residents used to think existed only in the big cities.

title: Candidates Get Plea
description: BOSTON, March 10 (AP) MassAction, a citizen lobby, today called on gubernatorial candidates to speak out on such issues as waste and unethical conduct in state government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S INCREASING AID TO INDOCHINA
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The costs of military and economic aid programs in Southeast Asia, which dropped sharply with the withdrawal of American forces from South Vietnam, is beginning to rise again. The increase is attributed by Administration officials to inflation and the continued fighting in South Vietnam.

title: Hefner Sees Bright Future for Playboy Empire Despite Critics
description: CHICAGOThe 45 or so guests, maybe a third of whom he actually knew, finished their buffet dinners as the syrupy mood music ceased and joined their host, Hugh Marston Hefner, the doyen of American hedonism, in his living room for a Sunday night movie.

title: Red Smith
description: Baseball players, baseball writers and baseball fans are so preoccupied with money at this time of year, so concerned with contract negotiations, with arbitration and with holdouts, that a dip into history might help us all recapture a sense of proportion. For instance, does it clear the air somewhat to be advised that when Christy Mathewson, the Tom Seaver of his day, broke into organized ball with Taunton, Mass., his contract called for $80 a month to be paid in $10 installments, and he didn't get them all? Or that ly Cobb drew $110 a month in his first season with Augusta, Ga., and $1,500 for his first full season in Detroit? Or that when Eddie Plank was a rookie winning 17 games for the Philadelphia Athletics, Connie Mack paid him $1,000? To be sure, Eddie made an independent income between seasons as a guide on the Gettysburg battlefield.

title: Major Bills In Congress
description: March 11, 1974

title: Shiping/Mails
description: AlHours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: SUNDAY MOTORING PICKS UP IN REGION
description: Sunday driving may yet bloom again with the return of spring, it seemed possible yesterday. Along with the sunshine, there were indications that more motorists were venturing forth with fewer fears about finding the gasoline to take them home again.

title: BELGIANS ELECT NEW PARLIAMENT
description: BRUSSELS, March 10More than 6 million Belgians today elected a new Parliament, the tenth since World War II.

title: Dr. Thomas Cahalan Dies; Taught English at Fordham
description: JEFFERSON VALLEY, N.Y., March 10Dr. Thomas L. Cahalan, a professor of English at Fordham University, died yesterday at his home here. He was 64 years old.

title: CONSUMERS IN U.S FACE COMPETITION FOR NATION'S FOOD
description: When Americans push shopping carts through their supermarkets, not many of them are aware that they are now competing for much of the food they buy with people in Japan, Western Europe, the Soviet Union, China and most of the rest of the world. But they are.

title: African Singer, Too, Got A Start in Church Choir
description: Another black singer has come into prominence from a start in her church's choir. The singer, Abeti FinaMasikini, however, did not begin in a Baptist gospel group, as have so many black American singers.

title: Hustling Odd Jobs Keeps A Super Ahead of Inflation
description: Willie Hall is one of those Countless New Yorkers who must cope with the rising cost of living on a limited income. And because he hustles, he does it better than most.

title: MISS CHUNG GIVES RECITAL ON VIOLIN
description: KyungWha Chung gave an impressive, highly serious violin recital Saturday night at the Hunter College Assembly Hall. Among other things, it contradicted one of the standard clichs these days about Oriental violinists.

title: Maryland Turns Down Spot in N.I.T.; U.C.L.A. Romps for N.C.A.A. Berth
description: The Maryland basketball team was not in a consolation mood yesterday.

title: GOING OUT
description: AFRICAN ART The huge stretch of black Africa just below the Sahara consists of more than a halfdozen countries sorely afflicted by drought. The art of the area has its own striking characteristics, which vary from region to region.

title: ARABS POSTPONE EMBARGO TALKS; NOT ALL SHOW UP
description: CAIRO, March 10A meeting of Arab oil ministers called by, Egypt to consider lifting the oil embargo against the United, States floundered here today and was postponed until Wednesday, in Tripoli, Libya.

title: British Soccer Results
description: SCOTTISH F.A. CUP

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, MARCH 11, 1974
description: A meeting of Arab oil ministers scheduled in Cairo yesterday to discuss the removal of the Arab oil embargo against the United States was postponed and is now expected to take place Wednesday in Tripoli. Representatives of only six of the nine Arab countries that imposed the embargo arrived in Cairo for the meeting. They decided that nothing could be done without the other threeAlgeria, Libya and Syria. These countries apparently oppose the removal of the embargo without more evidence of progress on Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights. [1:8.]

title: Coalition of Bronx Leaders Drafts JobCreation Program to Revivify Borough
description: In a dramatic turnaround of mood and expectations, Bronx businessmen who only few months ago had been despairing over their own and their borough's prospects, now are hopeful that the social and economic decay that has made much of the Bronx a wasteland can be halted and reversed.

title: 131 Shot Captures Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 10 Sigmund Sommer's Prince Dantan, a 131 outsider, ridden by Ron Turcotte, upset a stellar field to win the $170,000 Santa Anita Handicap today.

title: About New York West 85th Street Revisited
description: Old Charlie was gone, and so were the big automobiles driven by the pimps. Johnny Armen had changed his name back to John Medici, which was what it had been in the first place, and 15 or 20 people were now walking their dogs together in Central Park every night. A new pervert was on the loose; Mrs, Amelia Stark was feeling bad; Ellen Zimmerman had a job, and Jeffrey Mayer, grown older, was at I.S. 44. Things had changed on West 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, but things do not change all that quickly in the city, and the block was still the same.

title: Nets' Regulars Take a Seat and Watch As Substitutes Trounce Squires, 11476
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 10  We haven't had a game like this in a loong time, said Brian Taylor after the New York Nets had trounced the Virginia Squires, 11476, before a crowd of 10,237 in the Nassau Coliseum today.

title: British Duo Stalks Jack the Ripper
description: Who was Jack the Ripper? A sixpart British Broadcasting Corporation television series with this title probably comes as close to the truth as any other belated assimilation of fact and theory since the London murders in 1888.

title: CREDIT ANALYSTS DIVIDED ON RATES
description: Credit market analysts, endeavoring to assess the current scene, have been obliged to reach for the shelf that contains such useful entries as stabilizing, sorting out, correction and the like. In the period since Feb. 26, when the Federal Reserve's chairman, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, addressed himself to the continuing question of inflation, in testimony before the SenateHouse Joint Economic Committee, the Government, taxexempt and corporate bond markets have been busily adjusting, as some specialists put it.

title: TV: Specials on Truman and John Derzver on A.B.C.
description: Tonight's specials on the American Broadcasting Company network are The John Denver Show at 9 o'clock and PortraitThe Man From Independence at 10, The first is pleasant, even charming if you happen to be a Denver fan, The second is, well, fascinating, no matter what you thought about Harry S. Truman.

title: Heavy Fighting Reported In Mekong Delta by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 11 (UPI)Heavy fighting broke out in the Mekong Delta 60 miles west of Saigon yesterday and South Vietnamese Government warplanes raided Communist forces, Government military officers here said today.

title: Convicted Irish Sisters Ask Return of Vermeer Painting
description: LONDON, March 10 (UPI)The father of two Irish sisters serving life sentences after their conviction in bombings said today that his daughters had appealed for the return of a stolen Vermeer painting.

title: PIUS XII WAR ROLE IS PRAISED BY POPE
description: ROME, March 10Pope Paul VI made his first public appearance after suffering from influenza for a week as he appeared briefly in a window of the Vatican's Apostolic Palace to give his customary Sunday benediction.

title: Screen: Czech 'Valerie'
description: The exquisite color of "Valerie and Her Week of Wonders" sustains this admirably conceived Czechoslovak film, directed and co-written by Jaromil Jires, now showing at the Elgin Theater, 171 Eighth Avenue.As Mr. Jires depicts the tender, sensual and bizarre daydreaming of a 13-year-old girl, with the accompaniment of lyrical music and a flow of simple and surreal imagery, the picture evokes a pictorial music of its own. So do the expressions of the young heroine, Jaroslava Schallerova, looking like a beautiful young Rita Tushingham.In content, the film is a weird exercise, striking out boldly in the paths of Bergman, Fellini and Buuel with characters in something of a clutter who shift into evil incarnate or plain tooth-chomping vampires. One creepy sequence in a coffin-crammed lair is right out of "Dracula."Mr. Jires finally brings his story back to reality in simple, neat fashion, but only after his Grand Guignol transformations have redundantly cluttered the action and landscape, like a milling horror-show road company. "What ails you, child?" the daydreaming girl is gently asked by her grandma, a part-time vampire.The movie remains far more impressive when it blends the heroine's virginal wonderment with the sights and sounds of nature, minus the macabre symbolism tapped from other sources. A born director like Mr. Jires can be forgiven a lopsided beauty that still commands full attention.

description: NEWARK, March 10 (AP)New Jerseyans are wasting no time in filing for tax refunds this year.

title: Nixon Court Gives a Conservative Ruling on the Laws of Fashion and Decorum
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Supreme Court that President Nixon has retailored along more conservative lines is asserting a cautious traditionalism on sartorial as well as legal issues.

title: Japanese Officer Found in Philippines After 29 Years
description: MANILA, March 10 (AP)  A Japanese lieutenant emerged from the Philippine jungles today 29 years after the end of World War II. He told Japanese newsmen he had not come out before because I had not received the order.

title: Ships Sight Debris in Ocean; Could Be Balloon Gondola
description: LONDON, March 10 (AP)two ships have reported sight ing large drifting objects in the Atlantic Ocean off the Liberian coast that could be the gondola of the missing American balloonist, Thomas Gatch Jr., Lloyds of London reported today.

title: Bridge: Kaplan Team Reaches Final After 15Hour Battle Here
description: The topseeded team headed by Edgar Kaplan of New York reached the final of the Grand National team championship at the New York Hilton Hotel here yesterday, but only after a 15hour semifinal battle that was prolonged by a legal brouhaha.

title: Sales Off for G.O.P. Dinner That. Costs $1,000 a Plate
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)Ticket sales for a $1,000aplate Republican fundraising dinner March 27 are trailing last year's pace when the party failed for the first time in recent years to top the $1million mark, sources said today.

title: NIXON NAMES HEAD OF AGENCY FOR '76
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 10President Nixon named today Secretary of the Navy John W. Warner to head the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration, a new Federal agency that will coordinate the nation's celebration of its 200th birthday.

title: White House Challenged By Environmental Chief
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The White House and the Environmental Protection Agency have collided over Administration proposals for a drastic revision of the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: Home Rule Tradition Triumphed as New Hampshire Citizens Defeated Refinery Project
description: BOSTON, March 10Aristotle Onassis' milliondollar effort to put an oil refinery in Durham, N.H., was defeated around kitchen tables.

title: Prime Time, Public Time
description: Every time the Federal Communications Commission raises an eyebrow or the Supreme Court blinks, eventually the body of programing is shaken slightly on the TV receiving end in 66 million living rooms. The two latest rulings offer no reason for great optimism that the standard fare of Los Angeles cops and courtrooms and Doctor Feelgoods treating All in the Family will be interrupted by anything but the next commercial.

title: PROF. JAMES BREWER
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 10 (AP)James H. Brewer, professor of history at the Univeryesterday, apparently of a heart yesterday apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Durham. He was 64 years old.

title: 55M.P.H. Winds Buffet the City
description: Some branches, signs, windows, awnings and many hats fell victim yesterday to leonine winds, which at times gusted to 55 miles an hour.

title: I.B.M. Starts Bus Shuttle for Westchester Plants
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 11  The fuel shortage has prompted the I.B.M. Corporation, Westchester County's largest employer, to develop a bus system to link 12 of its sites in the county.

title: 25 on Boards of Oil Companies Scrutinized in Antitrust Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 Federal officials and members of Congress have for the last three months been quietly investigating possible antitrust violations by business executives who simultaneously sit on the boards of directors of several oil companies.

description: About 80 union leaders and 25 eity officials attended labor reception at Gracie Mansion last night as guests of Mayor Beame.

title: MRS. EDWARD W. LEE
description: PORT WASHINGTON, LI., March 11Mrs, Eleanor Millar Lee, who retired 15 years ago as head of the girls health education department at Andrew Jackson High School, Cambria Heights, Queens, and earlier taught at Jamaica and Textile High Schools, died today in the Sands Point Nursing Home. She was 78 years old and lived here.

title: MRS. KING PLANS CONFERENCE HERE
description: Declaring that people are now more open to nonviolence than at any time since her husband's death six years ago, Mrs. Coretta Scott King yesterday announced a twoday conference to try to utilize the civil rights coalitions of the nineteensixties in working on problems of the seventies.

title: MRS. MORRIS MEISTER
description: Mrs. Florence Glickstein Meister, retired teacher of music in the city schools and wife of Dr. Morris Meister, retired principal of the Bronx High School of Science and former president of the Bronx Community College, died Sunday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. Her age was 73 and she lived at 315 Riverside Drive.

title: URIS WILL SELL HOTEL INTERESTS

title: DR. OLIVE HAZLETT
description: PETERBORO, N. H., March 11 Dr. Olive C. Hazlett, a retired associate professor of mathematics at the University of Illinois, died Friday in a Keene nursing home. She was 83 years old and had lived here for many years.

title: Blast Kills 10 in Mexico
description: MUN ITARLY, Mexico, March 11 (UPI)  At least 10 persons were killed today and an unknown number injured when an explosion ripped through steelstructure workshop here. As night fell reserve workers were still searching in wreckage for survivors.

title: SAIGON BUILDS UP ISLAND SUPPLIES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 (AP)South Vietnamese forces have started the second phase of an operation to consolidate sovereignty over the disputed Spratly archipelago in the South ChinaSea, military sources said here today.phase of the operation was completed last month when South Vietnamese troops landed on the islands after the South Vietnamese had been defeated by China in a twoday war over the Paracels, another chain of coral reefs to the north.

title: Dissident Soviet Writer Tells of Threat

title: Wood, Field &Stream
description: Returning to my desk after a trip to Georgia and Florida where I slayed a wild hog, a dozen quail, two largemouth bass, five mangrove snappers, one jack crevalle, four dozen oysters, three azaleas and two yellow jasmines, found a packet of letters awaiting me, most of which deplored the act of hunting as manifested in a recent Wood, Field and Stream column on pursuing snowshoe rabbits in the Adirondacks.

title: Oil Group Plans Termination
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, March 11  The Americanowned West Indies Oil Company, one of four foreign corn= panies distributing gasoline and other petroleum products here, will terminate its operations at the end of this month, an official source disclosed this today and said the company with a refinery in the Caribbean Island of Antigua distributed about 100,000 barrels annually.

title: About the Knicks
description: Willis Reed has decided to postpone his return to the team until next week in phoenix at the last stop of fourgame road trip. Reed will work out with the club on Tuesday, March 19, and hopes to play the following night against the Suns. I've decided I can make more progress working here by myself than by traveling with the team, he said yesterday after practice at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks play in Oakland on Thursday, Portland on Friday and Los Angeles on Sunday before meeting Reed in Phoenix. New York needs only two victories clinch second place in the Atlantic Division, To gain the homecourt advantage against Capital in the playoffs, the Knicks require a combination of six New York victories or Bullet defeats. When Reed is reactivated, one player will have to be trimmed from the roster. The most likely candidate is Tom Riker, the secondyear forward from South Carolina who has scored 38 points in 17

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOOK AND LAFF The brandnew Nicholls Gallery, on the fifth floor of 1014 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street (4720211), has an exhibition that's laughable. Small wonder, the art consists of the original drawings by the people who do covers and cartoons for the New Yorker magazine. This standup comedy show has pictures and captions by Charles Addams, Whitney Darrow Jr., Arthur Getz,  Charles E. Martin, Warren Miller, Frank Modell, George Price, Charles Saxon, lames Stevenson, Barney Tobey. You may have seen many of these 58 cartoons and covers in print, but they lose nothing on reruns in the original. And they're for sale, the cover originals from $325 to $850, the drawings from $175 to $600. Virtually all of the artists in this gallery have a New Yorker association. This particular exhibition remains through March 31; then the emphasis will shift to oneand twoman shows. Open free, Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5.

title: Metric System Bill Stalled

description: The jury In the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans heard a letter read yesterday that depicted Robert L. Donald Nixon, that if the inquiry were not stopped there would be international and national repercussions.

title: Limited Local Autonomy Granted to Kurds in Iraq
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 11 The Government of Iraq, acting just before the expiration of a deadline set four years ago, proclaimed local selfrule today for the restive Kurdish minority in the mountainous northern region of the country, but on terms far short of the Kurds demands.

title: SAMUEL SEGAL DIES; CRIMINAL LAWYER, 77
description: Samuel Segal, a wellknown criminal lawyer who also tried maritime negligence cases, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South. His office was at 11 Broadway.

Train, administrator of the National Environmental Protection Agency, views the amendments that the President's Office of Management and Budget is reported to be preparing as not only unnecessary but capable of doing substantial harm.

title: Music: Group of Firsts
description: The New England Contemporary Ensemble lived up to the contemporary in its name with its program Monday night at Town Hall. Of the four pieces on the bill, two were first performances and two were first New York performances. Three of them were composed in 1974 and the fourth, from 1966, sounded quite new enough.

title: Lyle Reaffirms Position as Yank Holdout
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12When Sam McDowell pitched the first three innings of the Yankees 9.0 victory over Kansas City today, it left only two Yankee pitchers who haven't worked this spring, One of them, Fritz Peterson, was only 48 hours away from his first appearance; the other, Sparky Lyle, was 1,700 miles and an unpredictable number of days sway from his.

title: $2.1Million Saved By City After Notes Receive Top Rating
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldir said that the city would say( $2.1,million in interest pay menfs on the sale yesterday $362million in shortterm notes, mostly because of the recent upgrading of the city's credit rating.

title: United Air Lines Narrowed February Loss to $13Million as Traffic Grew.
description: UAL, Inc., reported yesterday that its subsidiary, United Air Lines, had a $1.3million loss in February. In the yearearlier month the airline, biggest in the industry, had a loss of $6.6million.

title: CURB ON LENDING TO SOVIET SCORED
description: United States corporations that are heavily engaged in EastWest trade were reported yesterday to be putting pressure on the White House to resolve promptly the current impasse over ExportImport Bank loans to the Soviet Union and three East European countries.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
