description: College, School Results

title: Citizens Inquiry Ends With Hopes of a Possible Break in 7Month Coal Miners Strike at Harlan, Ky
description: HARLAN, Ky., March 12A citizens inquiry by a panel of urban liberals and academicians Into a bitterly deadlocked coal mine strike here in the remote Appalachian Mountains ended today with an unexpected, if tentative, break in a sometimes violent sevenmonth bargaining impasse.

title: Alexander Chisholm, 74, Dead; Aided Leontyne Price's Career
description: Alexander Field Chisholm, banker and oil executive who played a major role in the development of Leontyne Price as a soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday of a stroke at Spohn Hospital, Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 74 years old, and made his home in Laurel, Miss., where Miss Price had spent her early days.

title: Sidonie Gruenberg Dies at 91; Leading Authority on Children
description: WriterEditor Headed Child Study Group 27 Years Compiled Encyclopedia

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Assembly Panel Approves A 10Page Obscenity Bill
description: ALBANY, March 12  The Assembly Codes Committee voted today to release for floor debate a comprehensive obscen1ty bill that contains a long, detailed list of specific sexual acts whose depiction would be prohibited.

title: PANEL VOTES CUTS IN OIL TAX BENEFIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to do something about reducing the depletion allowance that producers of oil and natural gas use to reduce their income taxes. But the committee appeared to be far away from being able to decide exactly how or how much to reduce the allowance.

title: Golden Gate Bridge Is No. 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)The Golden Gate Bridge has been declared the top manmade tourist attraction in the United States by the Commerce Department, which had conducted a; poll of the travel industry. The bridge was followed by Mt. Rpshmore, the Houston Astrodome, the Statue of Liberty, Hoover Dam in Arizona, Walt Disney World in Florida and Itiel Gateway Arch in St. Louis.

title: GOLD AND POLICE ACCUSED OF LYING
description: The Police Department an the office of Brooklyn Distric Attorney Eugene Gold were ac cused by the New York Civi Liberties Union yesterday o covering up the truth abou the shooting in December, 1972 of a man by two police of ficers.

title: Westphal Leaves Bench, Helps Celtics Win,11093
description: PROVIDENCE, R. March 12 (UPI)A reserve guard, Paul Westphal, left the bench in the second period and scored 21 points as the Boston Celtics beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 11093, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Leader of the Opposition
description: PARISThe only sure thing about France's next presidential election is that the principal opposition candidate will be Francois Mitterrand, head of the Socialist party and leader of its leftwing alliance with the Communists. The date is expected to be 1976 and one presumes the favored contender will ultimately be selected as his personal choice by Georges Pompidou, present incumbent and inheritor of Gaullism's political apparatus.

title: About the Mets
description: For the Red Sox, the main chase this year involven the Baltimore Orioles, who led them by eight games list season before Darrell Johnson replaced Eddie Kasko manager Dr. James Parkes, the Mets new team doctor, watched from the box seats with Jerry Koosman after busy first day on the job. His patients: Cleon JoneS (strained rib cage) improved enough to play center field, which he did; Greg Harts (struck by ball), is all right, and pinch hit; Rusty Staub (pulled leg muscle) better, but sitting it out George Theodore, who dislocated his right hip last July, ran out a triple Monday. and reported: did O.K. but couldn't cut the bases properly. The doctor says we'll know if it's all right in five years. Mets and Red Sox played before 2,799 and were outdrawn in nearby auditorium by Lawrence Welk and his band Against the Montreal Expos at Daytona Beach today in Mets first trip: Jon Matlack, Koosman and Tug McGraw, who worked the last Saturday.

title: Nationwide Alarm Issued In Police Slaying in Queens
description: The police issued a nationwide alarm yesterday for a 22yearold paroled convict who is wanted for questioning in thel murder Saturday of a policeman during the holdup of a bar in Queens.

title: Walton Gains Awatd
description: DETROIT, March 12 (UPI) Bill Walton of the University of California, Los Angeles, was honored today by Basketball Weekly as the college player of the year for the third consecutive year.

title: Dome Stock Split Proposed
description: Directors of Dome Mines, Ltd., yesterday proposed a threeforone stock split subject to shareholders approval. Directors also declared a 5cent extra dividend on the outstanding shares, as well as the regular 25cent quarterly dividend. Both dividends, payable in Canadian funds, will be distributed May 31 to holders of record March 29.

title: Mrs. Johnson Tours Harkness Theater To Applause of Workers Completing It
description: Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson yesterday toured the Harkness Theater, which will open next month as the city's first theater specifically designed for dance, with Mrs. Rebekah Harkness, the arts patron who is rebuilding it.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Two Plays Postponed
description: An American Millionaire, the Murray Schisgal comedy now in previews at the Circle brthe Square/Joseph E. Levine Theater on Broadway, has postponed its press opening schedAiled for Monday. Thieves, the Herb Gardner play, has postponed its March 21 opening at the Broadhurst Theater. The play is now being shown in Boston.

title: Spencer Church Closes Doors; Role in Brooklyn Heights Faded
description: The Spencer Memorial Church in Brooklyn Heights, known for its innovative and often controversial services under its pastor, the Rev. William Glenesk, has closed.

description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES AT LAKELAND, FLA.

title: Lazaro Pena, ExSecretary Of Workers Unit in Cuba
description: MIAMI, March 12 (UPI)  Lazaro Pefia, former secretary general of the National Confederation of Cuban Workers, died last night at the age of 73, Radio Havana reported today.

title: NIXON COMMITTEE CLOSES ITS BOOKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)The Finance Committee to Reelect the President, the money manager for the richest political campaign in United States history, has closed its books and transferred $3.57million to a trust account with a Washington bank.

description: Black youngsters are deluded and seduced by athletic fleshpeddlers. Dr. Roscoe C. Brown Jr.

title: STAMOS DEFENDS SHIFT TO GALLERY
description: Theodoros Stamos, the abstract expressionist painter named as one of three executors by the late Mark Rothko, testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court that he had left his former agent to become a client of Marlborough Gallery because he was impressed with the way the gallery had handled Mr. Rothko's paintings following his death.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Mayor's Car in Mishap But No One Is Injured
description: A cab clipped Mayor Beane's official automobile last night, according to the police, but no one was injured in the minor mishap, which occurred at the intersection of West 54th Street and Madison Avenue shortly before 10 P.M.

title: LEWIS SINGS AENEAS IN MET'S TROYENS
description: Berlioz's Les Troyens, which had its premiere performance at the Metropolitan Opera this season, returned Monday night after several months in mothballs. For this ninth performance, William Lewis stepped into the role of Aeneas (Jon Vickers reportedly had a cold).

title: Legal Expenses for Park Aides Scored
description: JERSEY CITY, March 10 A decision by the Hudson County Park Commission to pay $39,100 in legal fees for two commissioners has left some citizens groups here concerned about setting a precedent.

title: Grand Jury Believed Firm On Date for Hush Money
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Watergate grand jury concluded that a disputed hush money payment to the attorney for E. Howard Hunt Jr. was made on the evening of March 21, less than 12 hours after White House meeting involving 1President Nixon, sources close Ito the investigation said today.

title: 2 Quakes in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12 (AP) Two mild earthquakes rumbled through downtown Lost Angeles early today, apparently, causing no damange and attracting little attention from a Bleeping city.

title: American Express To Take Over Avis
description: The American Express Company, Inc., Avis, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reached an agreement in principle last night for the proposed merger of Avis into a subsidiary of American Express. The transaction would involve $150million in cash.

title: ROBERT J. LEVY DIES; WALL ST. BROKER, 71
description: Robert J. Levy, a senior vice president of A. G. Becker & Co., a brokerage firm at 55 Water Street,. died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue.

title: HOUSE AND NIXON SEEM NEAR CLASH ON WITHHELD DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 A major confrontation between Congress and the White House appeared today to be developing over information the White House is withholding from the House Judiciary Committee.

title: STAMOS DEFENDS SHIFT TO GALLERY
description: Theodoros Stamos, the ab stract expressionist painter named as one of three executors by the late Mark Rothko, testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court that he had left his former agent to become client of Marlborough Gallery because he was impressed with the way the gallery, had handled Mr. Rothko's paintings following his death.

title: Women Pros Differ Over Team Tennis
description: Kris Kemmer signed her contract and sent it to Denver; Virginia Wade told Miami thanks, but no.

title: Union and Alioto Defy Antistrike Order by Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12  A union spokesman defied today a judge's order that striking municipal workers return to their jobs and Mayor Joseph L. Alioto said he would not direct the police to enforce the judge's order.

title: N. Carolina Seeded No.1 In N.I.T.
description: North Carolina's basketball team is under the onus of being seeded No. 1 in the National Invitation Tournament, which begins Saturday in Madison Square Garden. But the Tar Heels have none of the benefits of playing a weak team first.

title: IBrasco, on Stand, Denies a Conspiracy For Postal Contract
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco took the stand at his trial yesterday to deny that in return for payoffs he had conspired to help an underworld figure obtain Post Office contracts and an $85,000 loan for trucks to carry out the contracts.

description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: HOSPITAL BOUGHT BY GROUP HEALTH
description: Group Health, Inc., a nonprofit medical insurer, announced yesterday that it had acquired Hillcrest Hospital in Flushing, Queens, as part of a move toward lowering the cost of health care by as much as 20 per cent.

title: CronynsPlay'Keys'asEverinTune
description: Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy have been acting, together and apart, for more than 40 years. They are the longest running team on Broadwaycurrently costarring with Anne Baxter in Noll Coward in Two Keys.

title: F.B.I. TO SURRENDER DATA ON PANTHERS
description: CHICAGO, March 12 (UPI) The Justice Department agreed yesterday to surrender a truckload of documents pertaining to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's role in gathering intelligence on the Black Panther party before a 1969 raid that left two Panther leaders dead.

title: Islanders Beaten, 21, By Flyers
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 12When the New York Islanders can stand off the Philadelphia Flyers for 20 minutes, it has to be a moral victory.

title: Slaying Suspect`Hypnotized Trail Told
description: NEWARK, March 12An attempt to hypnotize Robert Petrarca last June while he was only a suspect and before he was indicted in the May 14 murder of two Upper Montclair women was disclosed today in questioning by the prosecution of one.of its chief witnesses.

title: CONGRESS GETS PLEA TO END GAS LIMITS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)Spokesmen for motorists and service station operators urged today that drivers be permitted to fill their gasoline tanks to discourage long waiting lines at service stations.

description: For high tide et Asbury Park and Belmar deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook

title: ORNIANDY LEADS DARKHUED MUSIC
description: It was a darkhued, tenslonful program that Eugene Ormandy chose for the Philadelphia Orchestra's visit to Avery Fisher Hall Monday night, from the avowed irrationality of Witold Lutoslawski's Livre pour Orchestre, through the seductive intensity of La Mer, on to the sublime melancholy of Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony.

title: Business Briefs
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, March 12 (AP)The Governmentcontrolled oil concern, Veba, A. G., announced today that, it would stop its Soviet oil purchases at the end of the month. The West German company said the Russians were making excessive price demands and slowing down deliveries.

title: Conteh Halts Dane To Retain Title
description: LONDON, March 12 (AP) John Conteh of Britain recovered from a firstround knockdown and retained his European lightheavyweight title tonight when Tom Bogs of Denmark was unable to answer the bell for the seventh round because of a cut.

title: Preventing Kidnapping
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Future kidnappings cannot be prevented by physical security measures like those established at airports to reduce the risk of hijacking. There are far too many potential victims to think of solving the problem by bodyguards. Yet unless some measures are taken in advance, the crime is likely to be contagious because of the huge ransoms being paid and the widespread publicity that the mass media so freely provide to people who often desire publicity more than ransom.

title: Soviet Radio Beamed to Arabs Backs Those Favoring Oil Ban
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Administration officials said today that Soviet broadcasts to the Middle East were taking the side of the radical Arab nations opposed to lifting the oil embargo against the United States.

title: Mills Says Congressional Report on Nixon's Taxes Will Outrage Americans
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Representative Wilbur D. Mills says he believes that the American people will be outraged when they see a forthcoming Congressional report on President Nixon's taxes because there will be so many different items on which the legality, or at least the morality, of Mr. Nixon's claims will be questioned.

title: Advertising: Creating for Banks
description: Way back in 1967 when Scali, McCabe, Sloves was launching itself with the Volvo account, Sam Scali, resident art directing genius, was proving that he not only had an eye for graphics but also a head for business and a heart for money. His liVer wasn't so bad either.

title: Monday's Fights
description: NEW YORK (at Felt Forum)Domenico Monaco, 131 pounds, Italy, outpointed Pedro Guzman, 129, Puerto Rico, 10 rounds.

title: PHILLIPS AND SUN SEEK SHALE LAND
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 12 (AP)  An apparent high hid of $75.6million was offered today for a tract of oilshale land that contains an estimated 244 million barrels of recoverable crude oil.

description: BUENOS AIRES, March 12President Juan Domingo Per6n appointed one of his conservative followers today to replace the deposed leftwing Peronist Governor in the strifetorn industrial city of C6rdoba.

title: Sears Denies Bid to Fix Vesco Case With Mitchell
description: A Government witness testified yesterday under cross, examination that never at any time did he ask John N. Mitchell to fix a case for Robert L. Vesco, the financier, who is now a fugitive.

description: At a time when schoolboy athletes are being heavily recruited and virtually assured of a diploma, only 62 per cent of the nation's basketball professionals have their college degrees.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame proposed legislation that would extend for five years the city's rentstabilization program, which limits rent increases when leases are renewed in 300,000 city apartments. Without such legislation, the program enacted for five years in 1969would expire at the end of this month and all the apartments covered by it would be subject to unrestricted rent rises.

title: Plastics Workers Screened for I11 Effects of Vinyl Chloride
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  For the last three and a half days, the Union Hall along Chemical Row here resembled the field hospital in M'A'S'''H as 401 workers from the Goodyear polyvinyl chloride plant lined up for the most intensive mass medical examination in the history of occupational health.

title: TROOPS CONFINED 3 DAYS BY LISBON
description: LISBON, March 12A semJay, alert confined Portuguese armed forces to their barracks Jean Saturday to today, accord. ing to an official Government spokesman. The alert was lifted today.

title: Premiere of Motet By. Pkskotv Given By Aeolian Group
description: The Aeolian Chamber Players can seldom play together as a complete ensemble since literature for flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano can hardly be said to exist at all. At Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night, the five young musicians, joined forces only once during the concert, to give the pre, miere of Raoul Pleskow's Motet and Madrigal.

title: New Security System Installed at Zoos
description: Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. announced an immediate new security program for the city's zoos yesterday following what he called the senseless and brutal beatings last week of five Fallow deer at the Central Park Zoo and the tlieft of two parrots and 30 fancy pigeons from Prospect Parks's Zoo.

title: Chicago Board Options Exchange
description: Tuesday, March 12, 1974

title: WAR CASUALTY LIST PRINTED IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, March 12 (UPI)  Israel distributed yesterday a memorial booklet listing 2,522 soldiers, sailors and airmen killed or missing in action from the beginning of the October war up to Feb. 12. Nearly one fourth of the casualties were officers.

title: Soldier's Return From 30 Years In Jungle Stirs Japanese Deeply
description: TOKYO, March 12Second Lieut. Hiroo Onoda of the Imperial Japanese Army, who came down from a mountain hideout in a Philippine jungle on Saturday, returned to his native land today to an outpouring of patriotic emotion.

title: MobileHome Shipments Fall
description: Shipments of mobile homes in January totaled 28,850 units, down 29 per cent from 40,700 units in January, 1973, the Mobile Home Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

title: ARABS TALK TODAY ON OIL STRATEGY
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 12Arab oil ministers began arriving here today for a crucial review of Arab oil strategy tomorrow, including a decision on continuation of the embargo on oil shipments to the United States.

title: ETHIOPIAN MUTINY SAID TO CONTINUE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 12 (AP)The military mutiny that began two weeks ago is continuing in the Ethioplan Air Force, informed sources reported today. The airmen are said to be demanding the ouster. of 21 officers. The sources said enlisted men at the air force bases in Asmara and Debra Zeit, near Addis Ababa, were being insubordinate, threatening their officers and refusing to come to work.

title: Lockheed's Tristar Is Displayed in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, March 12The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has brought its Tristar airbus to the Soviet Union to show to top Soviet aircraft and airline officials in a bid for a major order, a Lockheed spokesman disclosed today.

title: STATE FACES LOSS IN EDUCATION AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 12

title: AFRICAN INFLUENCE MARKS DAVIS DANCE
description: Chuck Davis is currently devoting all his dance and choreographic energies to presenting folk dances derived from African forms, and doing it very well. The Watcher (Religion X 5), his latest dance in this style, was given at Clark Center Monday evening.

title: Cambodia Reopens Road to a Key Town From Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 12 (AP)  Government forces cleared a fivemile strip of Route 4 from here to the coast today, opening it to the important provincial town of Kompong Speu, the Cambodian cofnmand reported.

title: Kodes, Taylor, Cox Toppled in Brazil
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 12 (UPI)  Three upsets marked the second round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: ALEX BENSON DIES; N. B, C, NEWS AIDE
description: Alex Benson, an editor and producer of specials for the National Broadcasting Company's radio network news, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of complications from meningitis. He was 46 years old and lived at 711 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Blaze Leaves 49 Homeless
description: A threealarm fire in Brooklyn's Park Slope section yesterday afternoon destroyed one fourstory apartment building and heavily dainaged a second, leaving 49 persons homeless. There were no injuries, the police said. The blaie started at 441 13th Street near Eighth Avenue and spread to an adjoining apartment house at 439 13th Street before being brought under control at 2:15 P.M.

title: Man Found Dead on Roof
description: The nude body of 38yearold David Cramer was found on the roof of the Centre Hotel at 249 West 80th Street, where he resided, the police said yesterday. The police said there were no visible signs of violence, and an autopsy was ordered.

title: Lord Acton's Famous Remark
description: Power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely.

title: CITY COUNCIL BACKS CURB ON POLICE USE
description: The City Council passed a homerule message yesterday supporting two bills introduced in the Legislature that would bar the use of city policemen as guards at foreign government delegation buildings.

title: Paper Industry Is Urged to Try to Preserve Resources
description: The top official of a major paper company said here yesterday that future demand for paper and related products could he met if industry and the Government coordinated their efforts to preserve natural resources.

title: South's Signing Day A Football Jamboree
description: Of all the big college football days in the Deep South, and there are many, few are bigger or more highly dramatized than the second Saturday in December. It is Signing Day, a day like no other.

title: Parking Anachronism
description: The Mayor's capital budget, which goes before the City Council and Board of Estimate for final action tomorrow, contains at least $18 million in funds earmarked for new parking facilities. This at a time when the gasoline shortage has reduced auto use, when a national energy crisis that is likely to endure for years dictates a longterm switch to more efficient modes of transportation, when private city garages are operating at far below capacity, and when the city is under Federal mandate to reduce incity parking spaces among other necessary steps to achieve air quality standards.

title: Yale, Cornell Gain In National Polo

title: Hussein Assured on U.S. Peace Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, March 12President Nixon assured King Hussein of Jordan today that the United States would continue to use its influence to bring about agreements between Israel and her Arab neighborsincluding Jordaneven if the oil embargo is not lifted tomorrow at a meeting of oilproducing nations.

title: School Board Yields on Ethnic Data
description: The local board of Community School District 28 in Queens voted 5 to 4 early yesterday to comply with a Federal demand that it submit data on the ethnic composition of its teaching staffdata that the board has resisted giving.

title: Market Place: Ammonia Lure In Tender Bids
description: Rival tender offers for the Commercial Solvents Corporation have sent the stock of this industrial chemical producer moving ahead briskly and, in the process, provided another fastunfolding drama on Wall Street.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOLS CHIDED INALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 12  Bills that would penalize medical schools in the state that did not admit New Yorkers on preferential basis were introduced today by a bipartisan coalition of 52 Senators and Assemblymen.

title: Bruins Top Sabres, 40, With Surge
description: BOSTON, March 12 (UPI) Wayne Cashman broke a scoreless tie late in the second period tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 4.0, in a National Hockey League game.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12  The game of baseball may or may not be coming apart at the seams as some critics have charged, but a 160pound shortstop actually tore the cover off the ball today while the Boston Red Sox were defeating the New York Mets, 31.

title: Uruguay, in Decline, Awaits Full Military TakeOver
description: MONTEVIDEO, UruguayA year has passed since the Uruguayan armed forces Issued wideranging program of national reconstruction. Eight months have gone by since the military found that this declaration was not enough and decided to institute a joint dictatorship with President Juan Maria Bordaberry, a conservative elected in 1971.

title: U.S. Banking Expansion Worries West Germans
description: PARIS, March 12American banks are moving exuberantly into lucrative consumer finance operations in West Germany and the West German central bank Is worried that this may circumvent its policies of credit restraint.

title: Bridge: 3 Players Commit Errors In a Game During Tourney
description: Deals on which all three active players have made errors in the play are seldom worth reporting. But if the errors are sophisticated ones, they may repay analysis. The diagramed deal from the Grand Nationals during the weekend is of this type, and the players can remain shrouded in anonymity.

title: Notes on People
description: Claude and Paloma RuizPicasso, offspring of the late Pablo Picasso and Frangoise Gilot, his longtime mistress, were officially recognized yesterday as legal heirs of the great artist. Each is thus entitled to oneeighth of Picasso's large estate. The decision was handed down by a court in Grasse, off the Riviera, after it had given lawyers for Picasso's widow, Jacqueline RoquePicasso, and those for Claude and Paloma, a month to reach an outofcourt settlement, The settlement apparently failed to materialize.

title: LEWIS SINGS AENEAS IN MET'S TROYENS

title: CORRECTIONS
description: There were errors in a chart and article dealing with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in The New York Times Monday, A corrective article appears on Page 55.

title: People and Business
description: Alger B. Chapman Jr., president of Shearson, Hammill & Co., has been named to the additional positions of chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee. In those posts, he succeeds Robert C. Van Tuyl, who continues as chairman.

title: More Security for KMart
description: TROY, Mich., March 12 (AP)  The S.S. Kresge Company, which owns and operates KMart stores, said today that tighter security measures were being implemented in an effort to discourage kidnapping of the company's executives. Since Christmas, four KMart store managers have been kidnapped.

title: 3MONTH PROFIT UP A BIT AT MAY
description: Continued disappointing results at the New York division of R. FL Macy & Co. limited earnings to a gain of 2.3 per cent in the Christmas buying period of its second fiscal quarter, ended Feb. 2.

title: The Number of Family Doctors in State Is Rising
description: CHERRY HILL, March 12 The family doctor appears to be thriving in New Jersey. This happy subtheme was repeated again and again today at the 22d annual convention of the New Jersey Academy of Family Physicians, meeting in the Cherry Hill Inn here since Cunday.

title: KISSINGERSOFTENS WORDS ON EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON. March 12  Secretary of State Kissinger sought today to soften the impact of his harsh remarks yesterday about America's European allies.

title: Guild Members Authorize Strike Against Wire Service
description: Employes of United Press International, represented by the Wire Service Guild have voted 9 to 1 to authorize a strike if necessary to achieve a new contract.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 13, 1974

title: People in Sports
description: It probably will come to a screeching halt soon, said Mary Bacon yesterday about the six triumphs and three secondplace finishes in 24 months at Aqueduct, which have helped her supplant Robyn Smith as the country's top woman jockey. It's just that I'm riding better stock now.

title: Four Leading Cambodians Go Over to Sihanouk's Side
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia. March 12 (UPI)Four leading Cambodians have left the coontry to join Prince Norodom Sihanouk's government in exile, political sources said today.

title: BEHAVIOR PROJECT IN PRISON STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)  Federal prisoners who were compelled to participate in a behavior modification program were routinely kept in solitary confinement for almost three weeks, a Congressional committee has reported.

title: The St. Clair Doctrine
description: James D. St. Clair has created an astonishing legal theory that would make the Chief Executive at once superior to, and immune from, any of the laws that govern the rest of the nation's citizens and institutions.

title: LILCO Fuel Costs Raise Bills By 19% to Average of $24.27
description: MINEOLA, L I., March 12 The Long Island Lighting Company today announced that its 836,000 customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens would be charged an additional 19 per cent for increased fuel costs this month. This brings the average residential customer's bill to $15.28, plus $7.40 for fuel adjustment, and a 7 per cent tax, for a total of $24.27.

title: Role of Indian Ocean Base Is Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Defense officials, facing questioning about the Diego Garcia navalibase in the Indian Ocean, left it unclear today whether the United States wished to use the facility for B52 strategic bombers or could do so.

title: D.C. Elections Unit Cancels Nonvoting Delegate Primary
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)The District of Columbia elections board yesterday canceled the May 7 primary for the city's nonvoting delegate to Congress.

title: Westphal Leaves Bench, Helps Celtics Win, 11093
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 12 (UPI)A reserve guard, Paul Westphal, left the bench in the second period and scored 21 points as the Boston Celtics beat the Portland Trail Blagers, 1,1093, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.Twice the Celtics led by as many as 18 points, but Portland cut the lead to 9 with 3 minutes to play. However, a basket by John Havlicek and a 3point play by Westphal increased the Celtics lead to 14 points with 1:28 to play.Havlicek finished with 27 points and Don Chaney 23. John Johnson had 32 for Portland to lead all scorers.

description: There were errors in a chart and article dealing with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in The New York Times Monday. A corrective article appears on Page 55.

title: Japanese Prices Up by 37%
description: TOKYO, March 12 (AP) Japan's wholesale prices hi February were 37 per cent higher than a year earlier; the Bank of Japan reported toddy. The bank said the wholesale price index in February stood at 147,4 against the 1970 base of 100, up 3.9 per cent from January. Overseas factors ltccounted for 54 per cent of the rise.

title: WILSON RETREATS ON NORTH SEA OIL
description: LONDON, March 12Prime Minister Wilson retreated today from his campaign pledge to nationalize North Sea oil, the natural resource that is regarded as Britain's greatest potential asset in foreign trade.

title: Witness Says Gross Solicited a Donation T oinsureTisibility
description: NEWARK, March 12 (AP)The key prosecution witness in the trial of Nelson C. Gross testified during crossexaminal tion today that the former Republican state chairman had asked him for a $25,000 cash, donation to former Gov, William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: Jumbo Jet's Hijacker Seized on Okinawa
description: TOKYO, March 12The hijacking of a Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 ended after seven hours tonight when policemen disguised as airport maintenance men arrested an 18yearold Japanese who said he wanted to 'research the earth.

title: Red Sox Rip Cowhide, Top Mets Islanders
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12  The game of baseball may or may not be coming apart at the seams as some critics have charged, but a 160pound shortstop actually tore the cover off the ball today while the Boston Red Sox were defeating the New York Mets, 31.

title: BENJAMIN FENSTER
description: Benjamin Fenster, a writer on the staff of The Jewish Daily Forward since 1957, died Monday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 30 East Ninth Street.

title: Premiere of Motet By Pleskow Given By Aeolian Group
description: The Aeolian Chamber Players can seldom play together as a complete ensemble since literature for flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano can hardly be said to exist at all. At Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night, the five young musicians joined forces only once during their concert, to give the premiere of Raoul Pleskow's Motet and Madrigal.

title: Ford Feels Nixon Should Have Acted In CoverUp Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Vice President Ford said today that had he been in Mr. Nixon's place last March 21 when the Iformer White House counsel, John W. Dean 3d, detailed the involvement of top Presidential aides in a Watergate coverup, I think I would have taken the information directly, to the Attorney General.

title: A Critic Charges That Cosmetics Industry Is 50 Years Behind the Times
description: Dr. Bedford Shelmire Jr., 8 mildmannered Texas dermatologist, wrote a popular book on skin care last year, but it didn't say it all.

title: HARTFORD IS SEEN ON A NEW COURSE
description: HARTFORD, March 12  In the political uncertainty left in Connecticut by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's decision not to seek reelection, the General Assembly appeared today headed on a more independent course. There are now expectations of increased school aid, higher welfare payments, higher government salaries and other marginally increased spending the Governor wanted not to have.

title: Music: Group of Firsts
description: The New England Contemporary Ensemble lived up to the contemporary in its name with its program Monday night at Town Hall. Of the four pieces on the bill, two were first performances and two were first New York performances. Three of them were composed in 1974 and the fourth, from 1966, sounded quite new enough.

title: State. Lottery Account Is Won by Wells, Rich
description: Although its name wasn't picked out of a drum, Wells, Rich, Greene has won the New York State Lottery account, which has been at Fuller & Smith & Ross since the lottery started in 1967. The billings are $2million.

title: Blue Pool
description: The agreement to merge Blue Cross and Blue Shield in the metropolitan area is unquestionably a desperation move born of the financial and administrative woes that have engulfed Blue Shield in recent months. Even without these exigencies, the projected consolidation would have represented a worthwhile step toward simplifying the maze of financial interlocks that push countless New York patients to the brink of relapse in trying collect reimbursement for hospital and medical bills.

title: 2 SENATORS CLASH ON DEATH PENALTY
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  A proposal to legalize capital punishment and make it mandatory for a series of Federal crimes touched off an emotional debate in the Senate today.

title: Jersey Orchestra Members Ask Appointment of Fiscal Agent
description: Musicians of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra have charged the management of the orchestra with neglect and mismanagement, and asked that a fiscal agent be appointed to direct the financial affairs of. the organization.

title: Kuh Forbids Aides on His Staff To Deal in Sentence. Bargaining
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan directed his 200 assistants yesterday to refrain both from recommending sentences to judges and from bargaining with judges over sentences. Until now, he saia, assistant prosecutors have not uncommonly urged judges to impose particular sentences and also have extracted pledges from judges on what sentence a defendant would receive before he would be permitted to plead guilty.

title: JEROME J. BERG1DA, OTOLARYNGOLOGIST
description: Dr Jerome Jacob Bergida, an otolaryngologist, died Monday in Loyola Hospital, Brookfield, while visiting in that state. He was 67 years old and lived and practiced at 1615 Dorchester Road in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn since World War II.

title: Music: Bruckner Week
description: In one of those coincidences that strike the concert field now and then, Bruckner's rarely performed String Quintet turned up three nights in a row at Alice Tully Hall this week, The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center performed it on Sunday and last night, and it was played in the Music From Marlboro program on Monday night.

description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 12 (UPI)  The Turkish Government has sent official word to the United States that Turkey will resume the cultivation of the opium poppy, official sources said here today.

title: Chile to Reimburse Cerro For Copper Mine Seizure
description: The Cerro Corporation said yesterday it had signed compensation agreements in Santiago for $41.8million in cash and notes with the Government of Chile for Chile's 1971 expropriation of the business of Compailia Minera Andina, S.A., then owner of the Rio Blanco copper mine, which went into production in mid1971.

title: MORTGAGE BROKER ADMITS A PAYOFF
description: A New Jersey mortgage broker, pleading guilty to conspiracy, admitted yesterday that he paid the Sewer Commissioner a fee for depositing $1million in bond money of the Bergen County Sewer Authority in a New York bank.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WORDAGE One of the most verbose places in town today has to be Lehman College in the Bronx at Bedford Park Boulevard West and Jerome Avenue. At 1 P.M., Allen Ginsberg shows up in the West Lounge of. Student Hall to read his poetry and to discuss it.

title: 2 BODIES ARE FOUND IN THE EAST VILLAGE
description: Two bodies were discovered in the East Village yesterday, touching off investigations by the police and the Medical Examiner's office.

title: 2 Safe on Mt. Washington
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. H., March 12 (AP)Two brothers were rescued and reported in excellent condition today after spending three days in subzer6 temperatures and hurricaneforce winds near the summit of Mount Washington. A state conservation officer found John Kelley, 26 years old, of Marblehead, Mass., and Joseph Kelley, 41, of New York, in a leanto shelter about one  half mile from the summit of the 6,288foothigh mountain.

title: LAUGERUD IS RULED GUATEMALA WINNER
description: GUATEMALA, March 12 (Reuters)  Guatemala's Congress today proclaimed the former Defense Minister, Gen. Kjell Laugerud Garcia the winner of last week's presidential election.

description: BRUSSELS, March 12European Common Market officials in Brussels, seeking indications of the policy the new British Cabinet of Prime Minister Wilson will take toward the trade bloc, were disappointed by the terse program announced. by Queen Elizabeth II.

description: LONDON, March 12  An anonymous letter threatening that a painting worth about $5million would be burned next weekend was received by The Times of London here today.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 12 (Reuters)  South Vietnamese military negotiators boycotted a scheduled meeting with the Vietcong today to protest the shelling of a Government school in the Mekong Delta Saturday.

description: TEL AVIV, Macrh 12 (Reuters)  An Israeli Army spokesman announced tonight that after two days of quiet on the Syrian border, Syrian forces directed artillery fire against Israeli positions in the northern sector. Israeli units returned the fire, the spokesman said.

description: NYACK, N. Y.Inside the 45,000square  foot factory, Haitian women and men sit side by side in a ratio of roughly 4 to 1.

description: Despite a rising annual deficit and the recurring necessity of dipping into endowment funds, The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is considering a bold 20year master plan that would feature a new building devoted to the scientific display of plants in simulated subtropical rain forests, in savannas, in desert and tundra areas and in subfreezing Arctic and Antarctic regions.

title: TV: Deserter's Ill Fate
description: In 1953, William Bradford Huie began writing a book about an American soldier executed in 1945 for desertion, the first such case of military execution since the Civil War. The book, published in 1954; was called The Execution of Private Slovik. Although there is nothing controversial about the book itself, various planned film treatments have been balked over the years. Tonight at 8:30 o'clock, a twoandahalf hour drama tization of The Execution of Private Slovik will he presented on the Nationat Broadcasting Company, network. Richard S. Dubelman, who acquired the rights to the book from Frank Sinatra in is the producer.

title: Transatlantic Slanging
description: It is difficult to understand why President Nixon and his Secretary of State are allowing the differences between the United States and its European Common Market allies to be exacerbated into a. verbal brawl. The latest salvos can only make it harder for Washington to get wholehearted European Community backingleaving aside the hopeless case of Francefor a collective approach to the oil producers or even for Middle East peace efforts.

title: Sears Denies Bid to Fix VescoCase With Mitchell
description: A Government witness testified yesterday under crossexamination that never at any time did he ask John N. Mitchell to fix a case for Robert L. Vesco, the financier, who is now a fugitive.

title: Newspaper Case Is Moved
description: John J. Sheehan, lawyer for Typographical Union No. 6, said that, a proceeding involving a request by The Daily News for a permanent injunction enjoining the union from interfering with the newspaper's operations had been moved from the State Supreme Court to Federal Court in the Southern District. No date has been set for a hearing, he said.

title: $2.1Million Saved By City After Bonds Receive Top Rating
AMEX PRICES UP; OTC IS MIXED
description: Prices rose for the third] straight session yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but were mixed in the overthecounter market in moderate trading.

title: Theater: Dead Legends at St. Clements
description: The Theater at St. Clements is becomingor now, I suppose, has becomeone of our most interesting institutional theaters in town. It is willing to try anything in its protean space in St. Clements Church on 46th Street between Ninth and 10th. Currently it is alving a new play, Alive and Well in Argentina by Barry Pritchard.

title: FUTURES ADVANCE ON MIDEAST NEWS
description: Reports of renewed military action between Israel and Syria yesterday added to the rising costs of most basic commodities. The notable exceptions were cotton, livestock products and lumber.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Hypnotism Alleged in Murder Trial

title: EXTENSION ASKED IN RENT STABILITY
description: Mayor Beame proposed legislation yesterday that would extend for five years the city's rent  stabilization program, which limits rent increases in 300,000 apartments here when leases are renewed.

title: DR. RADOVAN PAVELIC
description: Dr. Radovan A. Pavelic, an ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Columbus Hospital, where he was an attending physician. Dr. Pavelic, who was 62 years old and lived at 225 East 63d Street, conducted a private practice at 105 East 63d Street.

title: VESCO OFFER TIED TO MOVE BY STANS
description: Within minutes after Robert L. Vesco promised to contribute $500,000 to President Nixon's reelection campaign, Maurice H. Stans tried to get him an appointment for that same day with John N. Mitchell, a Government witness testifed yesterday.

title: Gasoline Lines Deplored
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 13 (UPI)California highway patrolmen wasted 5,000 hours waiting in gasoline lines during February, and this cost the taxpayers $50,000 for the idle time, the assistant highway patrol commissioner, E. D. Herringer, said today.

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
description: Pesas In 32d of a mint, composite bill yields In basis points.)

title: Democrats in Assembly Defeat Measure to Save School Fuel
description: ALBANY, March 13  In a rare show of strength, the Democratic minority in the Assembly today defeated a Republicansponsored bill that would have allowed local districts to close schools for up to 10 days to save fuel without losing their state aid.

title: We Can Forgive
description: Ever since president Nixon said categorically more than a year ago that we cannot provide forgiveness for draft resisters and selfexiled opPtments of the war in Vietnam, it has been evident that any hope of amnesty rests with Congress. Legislation to create an amnesty board to rule on individual cases is now under consideration in the House.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WILLCOX A; GIBBS makes cloth inspection machines (INGAMEX)  Advt.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob Gibson has the miseries. The 38yearold pitcher is aching all over and complaining, and that augurs well for the St. Louis Cardinal's 1974 campaign.

title: Governor Backs Rail Bond Issue For Upstate to Offset Aid to City
description: ALBANY, March 13Governor Wilson will recommend that a state bond issue of $250million be put to the voters this fall to raise capital for commuter and upstate railroad improvements, reliable sources said today.

title: SHOT WOUNDS FOUND ON 2 BODIES ON ROOF
description: The badly decomposed bodies of a couple who were found on the roof of a Lower East Side building Tuesday night had bullet wounds in their heads, the police reported yesterday.

title: MANUFACTURERS SEE SALES SLIDE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)The nation's manufacturers expect a 3.1 per cent decline in sales in the first quarter of this year, followed by a rise of 2 per cent in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Dallas Symphony Suspends; $800,000 in Red for Season
description: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra has suspended operations for an indefinite period due to a financial crisis. Kenneth Meine, general manager of the Texas orchestra, said yesterday that the organization was $800000 in debt and that it would need $1million to finish the season in the black.

title: Tisch Shows Growing Interest in CNA
description: Laurance A. Tisch, board chairman of the Loews Corporation, has begun to show increasing interest in the CNA Financial Corporation, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: I.T.T.'s 4thQuarter Net Down 6.6%
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, one of the world's largest and most controversial conglomerates, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1973 declined 6.6 per cent to $117.2million from yearearlier levels.

title: Local Congressmen Take Opium Protest to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)Two New York area Congressmen flew to Turkey today to protest the decision to resume the cultivation of the opium poppy, which is used to produce heroin.

title: For a National Economic Planning Board
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Maybe we need an economic planning agency. Coming from Herbert Stein, this statement might reflect momentary frustration with the inability of the invisible hand of the automatic market mechanism to arrest galloping inflation, rising unemployment and mounting shortages of prime necessities.

title: Books of The Times
description: VIET JOURNAL. By James Jones. 257 pages. Delacorte. $7.95.

title: fatally Bludgeoned Woman found in Bronx Apartment
description: An 84yearold Bronx woman who lived alone was found bludgeoned to death yesterday in her secondfloor apartment at 2166 Bronx Park East, near Boston Road.

title: 16 Resume N.C.A.A. Action Tonight
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., March 13  No one booed, yelled Roll Tide or otherwise expressed their feelings when the Notre Dame basketball team arrived today at the home of the University of Alabama for the second stage in the 36th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: Funeral of Slain Officer Attended by 4,000 Police
description: more than 4,U00 police officers, including many from 26 police departments in New Jersey and Connecticut, filled the Church of the Incarnation in Queens Village and lined the sidewalks for two blocks in all directions at the funeral yesterday of Police Officer Timothy Hurley Jr.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Bond prices were characterized as flat to mixed yesterday in continued quiet trading.

title: Chess: The Short Unhappy Life Of an Opening Innovation
description: Original ideas or known ideas revitalized in the openings usually score only brief success. As soon as their potency is acknowledged, no one willing to play into the positions where they operate can be found.

title: EVERETT H. LANE
description: BOSTON, March 13Everett H. Lane, chairman of the Boston Mutual Life Insurance Compcany, died yesterday in Massahusetts General Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Dover.

title: 68 Campaign Charge Upheld
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 13 (UPI)A motion by attorneys for Dwayne 0. Andreas, a financier, to dismiss charges of illegal campaign contributions against him was denied today by Federal District Judge Earl R. Larson. Mr. Andreas is charged on fonur counts of illegally contributing $100,000 through a corporation under his control to the 1968 presidential campaign of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota.

title: The Sc Cup of Coffee
description: WASHINGTONIn The American Condition, published today, Richard N. Goodwin, the former speechwriter for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, provocatively explores the baneful effects of bureaucracy on individual freedom.

title: 70 Die in Java Bus Accident
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 13 (UPI)A bus plunged down a river bank about 100 miles east of Jakarta Monday, bursttag into flames and killing at least 70 persons, newspaper reports said today.

title: Kuh Edict Banning Sentence Bargaining Draws Critical Response From Judges
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh's directive that his assistants refrain from recommending sentences to judges drew a generally unfavorably response yesterday from other New York City prosecutors, sitting judges and lawyers.

title: WMCA Seeking to Reverse F.C.C. Ruling on Bob Grant
description: Radio station WMCA has asked the Federal Communications Commission to reverse decision of the F.C.C. Broadcast Bureau that the station violated the commission's personal attack rules when Bob Grant, one of its interviewers, called Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Queens Democrat, a coward on the air.

description: Choosing the right moment to play game in a minor suit is an area that many players find difficult. Obviously the partnership needs the values for game but not slam. But it must also be clear that a ninecard fit or better is available, that there is weakness prohibiting three notrump, and that there is no majorsuit fit.

title: Sports Recruiting: Odds Against N. C.A. A. Policing Unit
description: Sports recruiting has forced the National Collegiate Athletic Association into the predicament of a man fighting a forest fire with a garden hose: 664 members and only four investigators.

title: PALMER IS AWARDED $3.8MILLION IN SUIT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (AP)A Federal court jury has awarded $3.8million in antitrust damages against Burroughs Corporation of Detroit to a man whose computer data processing center went bankrupt in 1971.

title: Opera
description: Ruth Welting is about as cute a Zerbinetta as you could wish to find In Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos, Making her first appearance in the role with the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night, she was delightfully nonchalant and impish and contrasted splendidly with the stately ladies of the solemn roles in the opera.

title: UMass Dribbling Here en Masse
description: AMHERST, Mass., March 13 (AP)Twelve University of Massachusetts students are dribbling a basketball to New York City to demonstrate support for the Massachusetts basketball team. The university will compete in the National Invitational Tournament at Madison Square Garden and faces its first test Saturday evening against Jacksonville University. The students left the campus in 14degree weather this morning and planned to dribble in shifts one mile apiece.

description: PITTSBURGH, March 13The Richard King Mellon Foundation has made a $10million grant to Carnegie Institute. The grant is the largest in the foundation's history. The institute is conducting a 10year, $32.9million development program to upgrade exhibition halls and displays, expand the endowtpent for professional staff and curators, and renovate Me institute building in the Oakland section of Pittsburgh.

title: Death Penalty Restoration Is Voted by Senate, 5433
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Senate approved tonight legislation designed to meet the Supreme Court's objections to the death penalty and to reinstate it as punishment for( a group of serious Federal crimes. The vote was 54 to 33.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 13In August, 1970, Howard R. Hughes was informed by one of his executives that his Nevada gambling operations lost $12,723,016 in less than four years, according to an exhibit entered into evidence in a Federal trial here today.

description: LOS ANGELESSince he wound up as a bloody mummy at the end of Public Enemy (1931), tapdanced on a bar with Ruby Keeler as Shanghai Lil in Footlight Parade (1933), went to the chair in Angels With Dirty Faces (1938), ganned down Bogart in The Roaring Twenties (1939), became a patriotic masterspy in 13 Rue Madeleine (1946), lost his mind in White Heat (1949), raised the rhubarb in Mister Roberts (1955) and portrayed a maniac international Coke executiveSchlepping that syrup over the Andes in One, Two, Three (1961), James Cagney retired enthusiastically after 62 movies to focus on farming in Dutchess County, New York, where he has some 200 head of beef cattle, breeds Morgan horses and raises hay and oats and

title: NIXON GIFTS ASKED OF Silk CONCERNS

title: Egypt to Raise Output
description: CAIRO, March 13 (AP)Egypt plans to increase her industrial production 10 per cent to $4.6billion this year with the help of foreign investments. The production increases include cotton, textiles, sugar, cement, edible oil, soap, refrigerators, heaters, washing machines, cigarettes and television sets, according to a report.

title: American Officer Is Said to Advise Cambodian Troops
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)An American mill. tary adviser is working in the field with Cambodian combat troops, according to a dispatch from Cambodia printed in The Washington Post today.

title: Britain Had $3.3Billion Deficit In Last Year's Trade, a Record
description: LONDON, March 13 (Reuters)Britain had a deficit of $3.3billion last year in her commercial transactions with the rest of the world, in contrast to a 1972 surplus of $158million, the Treasury announced today.

title: ARAB DECISION TO END EMBARGO ON OIL SALES TO U.S. IS REPORTED; LEVEL OF OUTPUT UNDER STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, March 13William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, said today that despite the reported Arab plan to lift the oil embargo, the United States would continue to experience spot shortages of gasoline. But officials said they would be much less acute than in recent months.

title: Major Utilities Seeking Electric Rises
description: Every major electiic cornpany in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut is asking or about to ask for an electric rate increase except for two in New Jersey. One of the exceptions is that state's biggest utility, which got its latest rise last January.

title: SAXBE SAYS LAW APPLIES TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, March. 13 Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that the President was no different than any other citizen when it came to the duty to report immediately any information he received about the commission of crimes.

title: C.A.B. Judge Backs Airline On Low TransAtlantic Fare
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 Reuters)A British airline won preliminary approval today for its plans to introduce cutrate scheduled flights between New York and London.

title: U.S. Gives Saigon Air Force New F5E FighterBombers
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 13 (UPI)The United States today turned over to South Vietnam four new F5E fighterbombers, South Vietnamese Air Force sources said. The planes are the first of 150 the United States is expected to provide:

title: Butz Seeking Rail Cars to Carry Fertilizer to Farms
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Secretary of Agriculture Earl. L. Butz called today for emergency shifting of rail cars to transportation of fertilizer to assure vitally needed food production.

title: Giants Coaches Hit the Clipboards Hard
description: John Hicks will be tried at right offensive guard, Jack Gregory will line up at right defensive end, and Brad Van Pelt will get another shot at linebacker for the New York Giants next season.

title: About the Yankees
description: Pat Dobson posted his second consecutive scoreless threeinning effort against the Orioles. His former teammates have managed only four hits off the righthander. Juan Bernhardt, a 20yearold third baseman, got his first chance to play second base in Bill Virdon's latest experiment, and looked impressive. Jerry Kenney, trying regain a spot on the roster after a year's absence, had two more hits, giving him seven for 15. Ken Wright strained a tendon in his right knee when he fell covering first Tuesday and was limping. The relief pitcher said the knee was still sore, but the doctor didn't think it was serious. Fritz Peterson makes his spring debut today against Atlanta. With Sparky Lyle still absent, Virdon said he would take longer looks at a pair of young lefthanders for possible relief use, Scott McGregor and Tippy Martinez.

description: ROME, March 13 (Reuters)

title: LEON SVIRSKY DEAD; MAGAZINE EDITOR, 69

title: Personal Finance: Taxes And Insurance on Flying
description: Joseph E. Berman, a Mississippi food broker and attorney, died a few years ago in a plane crash while en route to a convention.

title: Rockets Down Bullets

title: About the Mets
description: Minor injuries, continued to dog the Mets, even the troops left behind for a workout at HugginsStengel Field in St. Petersburg. Jerry Grote, the No. 1 catcher, who was struck on the elbow two weeks ago by a ball hurled from a pitching machine, fouled a ball off his left foot in batting practice. Ice was applied, and he continued the workout. Not even the battingpractice pitcher was immune. Bob Garbatini, who was invited to camp solely to supply an extra arm, took a line drive on the hand from the bat of Don Hahn. Coach Willie Mays left for New York, where he will be inducted into the Black Hall of Fame. He was expected back this weekend, while the Nets are in West Palm Beach. The Mets will get their first look at Ralph Houk in his Detroit Tigers uniform today, when they play. the Tigers in St. Petersburg. To make the occasion complete, Houk and the Tigers will get their first look of the at Tom Seaver. #

description: There is a marvelous new play in town that I heartily commend to you. It is called Short Eyes, and it opened last night at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater complex in the Anspacher Theater.

title: No Armies March in Modern Balkan Feud but the Polemics Fly
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 13An old Balkan quarrel of the kind once capable of starting major European wars has been striking vestigial sparks during the last week, causing muted grumbling between the neighboring Communist governments of Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.

title: About the Yankees
description: Pat Dobson posted his second consecutive scoreless threeinning effort against the Orioles. His former teammates have managed only four hits off the righthander Juan Bernhardt, a 20yearold third baseman, got his first chance to play second base in Bill Virdon's latest experiment, and looked impressive. Jerry Kenney, trying regain a spot on the roster after a year's absence, had two more hits, giving him seven for 15. Ken Wright strained a tendon in his right knee when he fell covering first Tuesday and was limping. The relief pitcher said the knee was still sore, but the doctor didn't think it was serious. Fritz Peterson makes his spring debut today against Atlanta. With Sparky Lyle still absent, Virdon Said he would take longer looks at a pair of young lefthanders for possible relief use, Scott McGregor and Tippy Martinez.

title: Yanks Big Dread Machine Rolls Over Orioles, 183
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13In his typically quiet way, undetected by even the closest and most knowledgeable observers, Bill Virdon has been building lethal weapon in Florida this spring.

title: Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 59yearold woman died of burns in a fire of unknown origin in an East Side apartment last night. She was identified as Marie Fallet of 401 East 50th Street near First Avenue. According to the police, fireman found her body on the floor of the thirdfloor apartment when they responded at 11:53 P.M. The fire was confined to the apartment.

title: Little Early Improvement Seen in Local Fuel Supply
description: Officials in the metropolitan area, which has always been heavily dependent on imported oil, cautioned last night that the end to the Arab embargo would probably not ease fuel shortages here for another couple of months and might never return prices in the region to their previous low levels.

title: Scanning of Stars Fails to Detect Sign Of Life Near Earth
description: SAN FRANCISCOA systematic search of the 500 nearest stars that seem the likeliest centers of planetary systems line that of the sun has failed in a preliminary analysis to reveal any radio emissions suggestive of other technological civilizations.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that the General Atomic Company had signed two letters of intent, each for more than $50million, with the Chicago Bridge & Iron Company and the PittsburghDes Moines Steel Corporation for the construction of eight carbon steel liners for nuclear power plant reactor vessels. General Atomic is joint venture of Gulf and the Royal Dutch Shell Group.

title: HIGHER COSTS NOTED IN NIXON HEALTH BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)The Nixon Administration acknowledged today that under its national health insurance plan the elderly would have to pay more than they do now for shortterm hospitalizations and doctors services.

title: RED WING, 90, STAR IN 1913 SQUAW MAN
description: Lillian Red Wing St. Cyr, an American Indian who played the leading role in The Squaw Man, said to be the first featurelength film to be made in Hollywood, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 90 years old.

title: Jeweler Shoots Holdup Man
description: JERSEY CITY, March 13(UPI)A wouldbe bandit was shot by a jewelrystore owner today when he tried to flee with a tray of 43 diamond rings brought out of a safe for his inspection. The police said the victim, Robert Brown, 20 years old, of Jersey City, had been shot once in the left side by Larry Schonborn, 49, owner of the Dansinger Jewelry Store.

title: Stars Rout Flames

title: People and Business
description: John C. Bogle, who was forced out of his 6100,000ayear job as president and chief executive officer of the Wellington Management Company in late January, is expected by his associates to try to fight his way back at the next board meeting, scheduled to be held within a week.

title: Campbell Red Lake Split
description: Campbell Red take Mines authorized yesterday a twoforone split of the corporation's shares through a special resolution redividing the authorized capital into 8 million shares with a par value of 50 cents each. Shareholders will meet April 29, 1974, to approve the split. Directors declared an interim extra dividend of 7 cents a share on present stock in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 12 cents. A 15centashare extra dividend was paid in February.

title: PompidouBrezhnev Meeting Ends With Some Disagreement
description: MOSCOW, March 13President Pompidou of France ended two days of talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev today by supporting the Soviet leader's call for a more rapid conclusion of the European security conference now under way in Geneva.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 13The reaction in Northern Ireland to Prime Minister Cosgrave's declaration was mixed, with those who support NorthSouth conciliation welcoming it and Protestant opponents dismissing it as worthless.

title: $645,500 Player
description: LONDON, March 13 (AP)Peter Osgood, one of Europe's top soccer players, was sold by Chelsea to Southampton today for a reported record cash deal of $645,500. Although deals involving players and cash have exceeded that for Osgood, the biggest previous single straight money transfer was the $575,000 paid by Derby to Leicester for David Nish in 1972.

title: Hanoi Gives U.S. the Remains of Last 11 P.O.W.'s

title: Siberian Gas
description: The Administration's dubious proposal to channel billions of American investment dollars into developing the Soviet Union's Siberian natural gas fields has run into a welltimed legal barrier. On political and strategic grounds, beyond the technical point of law involved, the Congress would do well to grasp this unexpected opportunity to subject the Siberian venture to harder scrutiny.

title: Defense of Privacy
description: A system that fails to respect its citizens right privacy, fails to respect the citizens themselves. title: Cultivated Grass Roots

It seems that, behind the scenes, President Nixon had changed his mind and privately endorsed the wholly meaningless alternate bill proposed by Republican Representative Steiger of Arizona.

title: The Screen: 'Christo's Valley Curtain' Is a Real Tall Story
description: "Christo's Valley Curtain," directed by Albert and David Maysles and Ellen Giffard, is a 28-minute report on the hanging of a curtain in August, 1972. It was no ordinary curtain. It was made of nine tons of orange nylon polymide fabric, was a quarter of a mile long, was suspended from four steel cables as much as 365 feet above the floor of Rifle Gap, Colo., and cost $700,000. It lasted for less than 24 hours before it was torn to ribbons by the wind, but that didn't matter.Christo, the Bulgarian-born New York artist who conceived the project, was not interested in hiding a garbage dump or a pot-bellied mountain. He's a compulsive "packager," and when he came to hang the valley curtain he'd already had experience as the man who wrapped one mile of Australian coastline and Chicago's Museum of Contemporary Art. Separately, of course."Christo's Valley Curtain" was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room Sunday and will be repeated there today and tomorrow at noon and midnight. Technically, I suppose, you could say it supports the Screening Room's feature, "Confessor," an amateurish mishmash of poetic film making that you might want to break your neck to avoid.If, at 73 minutes, "Confessor" is 72 minutes too long, "Christo's Valley Curtain" is not long enough. It makes no lugubrious attempt to explain Christo's art ("revelation through concealment," according to David Bourdin), which can be shown more easily than it can be explained.Christo himself, a wiry, intense man wearing jeans and white hard-hat, talks about his esthetics as involving the entire process of packaging, or in this case, of curtain hanging. That is, the business of negotiating with engineers, architects, politicians and construction workers. It's like being a kid all over again, though here the play looks a bit dangerous.The surprise of the film is the enthusiasm with which this project was greeted by the residents of the town of Rifle (pop. 2,150) and by the construction workers who risked limbs and lives on the stunt. Says one hard-hat: "It's not the erection of it [that's important], it's the thought."The film is marvelous reportage of the sort the Maysles brothers do best, but it brought out every philistine feeling I've ever had. Seven hundred thousand dollars? Even though Christo raised the money from the sale of his own drawings and models, that seems the sort of staggering indulgence that once sent the mobs ransacking Versailles.This much about "Confessor": It's a series of disconnected images, some surreal (a football player runs through a museum. Superman lies dead on a New York street) and all banal, describing urban alienation. It is less expensive to observe life in any midtown cafeteria on a weekday afternoon.

description: Robert M. Morgenthau, who as a United States Attorney prosecuted such political figures as Carmine G. De Sapio and James L. Marcus, said yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for District Attorney in Manhattan.

title: Liberals Will Join Tories on Wage Issue
description: LONDON, March 14  The Liberal party announced today that it would join forces with the Conservatives on a key is sue in the first parliamentary test of the new minority Cabinet of Prime Minister Wilson.

title: Coritract Awards
description: The Ralph M. Parsons Company announced yesterday that it had been selected to design, engineer and construct the petroleumprocessing facilities for the Aaska North Slope project of the Atantic Richfied Company. The constructed value of the facilities will be in excess of $400million.

title: The Pop Life
description: Maggie Bell, who appears as the opening act for Foghat and Frampton's Camel at the Academy of Music for two shows tomorrow night, must be tired of being compared to the late Janis Joplin, but the comparison remains an inevitable one. Miss Bell used to be the lead singer for a Scottish band called Stone the Crows, and she toured this country with the group before it broke up. Although since then she has been twice voted best British woman singer by. British fans, she has delayed her first solo tour until she had recorded a solo album that pleased her.

title: Israelis, Heavily Shelled, Tighten Watch on Syrians
description: MAZRAT BEIT JINN, IsraeliOccupied Syria, March 14 Syrian artillery shells struck in and all around this deserted village for about an hour this morning. The harassing fire drove Israeli troops into their bunkers and caused no casualties.

title: Tuweep, Ariz.: A Solitary Man Against the Wilderness
description: TUWEEP, Ariz.Everyone in Tuweep owns an airplane. Everyone in Tuweep gets his water from the rain. Everyone in Tuweep is 62 years old. Everyone in Tuweep is John H. Riffey.

title: Caracas Poor Look to New President
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 14In the ranchos, or slum dwellings, that blight the green hills of Caracas, people talk hopefully of Venezuela's new President and his promises.

title: Janie Barnett Is Bride Of Martin J. Levine
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., March I4Miss Janie Sue Barnett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Barnett, was married this evening to Marvin Joseph Levine, son of Mrs. Leo Levine of Rockville Centre and the late Mr. Levine.

title: Connecticut Indians Act To Reclaim Reservation
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., March 14The Cheyenne, the Sioux, the Apache and other Western Indian tribes have lost hundreds of thousands of acres of their land in the last 100 years. The 100member Golden Hill tribe of suburban Fairfield County has lost only 1934 acres, but they want it back anyway.

title: New Chief of Hospitals John Lawrence Sullivan Holloman Jr.
description: His name is John Lawrence Sullivan Holloman Jr., but everyone calls him Mike. The nickname came from college friend who decided more than 30 years ago that

title: Michigan Ousts Irish in 7768 Upset; U.C.L.A. Triumphs in Triple Overtime
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 14 (AP)Bill Walton's 5 points in the third overtime period kept alive the hopes of U.C.L.A. for an eighth straight National Collegiate basketball championship tonight as the Bruins beat a stubborn Dayton team, 111.100, in the opening game of the Western Regional tournament.

title: Black Hall of Fame Inducts 3 Whites
description: Three black women and three white men were among more than two dozen persons inducted into the Black Hall of Fame at the organization's first dinner at the Americana Hotel last night attended by about 1,000. The women were Althea Gibson, tennis champion; Wilma Rudolph, Olympic gold medal winner, and Alice Coachman, the first black woman winner of an Olympic gold medal.

title: 2 FROM U.S. APPEAL TO TURKEY ON OPIUM
description: ANKARA. Turkey, March 14 (UPI)ATwo New York Congressnien arrived today to ask the Turkish Government to reconsider its decision to allow, cultivation of the opium poppy once again.

title: MORRIS BIENENFELD
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 14

title: Lindsay Mentioned For Hunter Faculty
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay is expected to be recommended for appointment as a Distinguished Professor at Hunter College, it was learned yesterday.

title: Grand Jury Inquiry Reported to Involve Jersey City Police
description: The chief of police in Jersey City and several other senior officers are being investigated by a New Jersey grand jury looking into collusion between the police and organized crime in a series of hijackings five years ago, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

description: LANDOVER, Md., March 15 (AP)Ilie Nastase, the No. 1 player in the $50,000 tennis classic, advanced to the tournament semifinals today along with Tom Okker, Cliff Drysdale and Tom Gorman.

description: NATIONAL INVITATIONAL

title: FIRE IN L.I. HOSPITAL
description: FREEPORT, L. I., March 15 A disgrunted former employe allegedly set a fire in the basement of Doctors Hospital tonight, forcing administrators to transfer or discharge 70 of the 176 patients, the police said.

description: This Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area

title: HOTEL URGED ANEW FOR TRADE CENTER
description: The plan for a big hotel as part of the World Trade Center las been revived, and the Port kuthority of New York and Jew Jersey, is undertaking negotiations to have it built pith private financing.

title: E. A. HODGE, OFFICIAL OF HARCOURT BRACE
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 15  Edward A Hodge, a vice president and a director of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., the publishers, died Wednesday evening of a heart ailment in Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. He was 63 years old and lived here until recently.
