description: ACROSS

title: U.S. AIRLIFTS HELP TO CAMBODIA POR1
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 15 (AP)  A United States C130 transport parachuted ammunition to beleaguered Government troops in the seaport of Kampot while the troops opened a counteroffensive against insurgent positions, military sources said today.

title: STEEP OIL PRICES SEEN FOR PRESENT
description: VIENNA, March 15As the world's major oilproducing countries prepared to meet here tomorrow and set new prices, strong indications emerged today that the present high rates for crude oil would be maintained for at least three months more.

title: Birth of Son to U.S. Prosecutor Brings a Recess in Gross Trial
description: NEWARK, March 15  The birth of a son to the wife of Jonathan L. Goldstein, the Acting United States Attorney, caused an unexpected recess today in the campaignfraud trial of Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman.

title: CORRECTION
description: The New York Times reported incorrectly yesterday that Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader, had been called before grand jury five years ago in an investigation of Carmine G. De Sapio, the former Manhattan Democratic chairman. Actually, Mr. Rossetti appeared as a defense witness at the conspiracy trial of Mr. De Sapio.

title: Transportation Package
description: Governor Wilson's threepart transportation package shrewdly combines promised assistance for hardpressed mass transit in New York and other cities with two railroad aid proposals designed to garner rural support.

title: Chinese Art to Coto Canada
description: TORONTO, March 15 (Canadian Press)An exhibition of more than 600 Chinese archaeological treasures insured for $50million will open, at the Royal Ontario Museum here in August under an agreement between Canada and China announced today. The exhibition, now in Vienna, would remain in Toronto until Nov. 16.

title: Fertilizer Freight Assigned
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters)The Interstate Commerce Commission has begun assigning freight cars to move fertilizers, a spokesman said today. Acting on the request of Agriculture Secretary Earl Butz for additional cars to meet farmers immediate needs, the I.C.C. said it would place some of its staff in the field to assure prompt turnaround of cars so that the fertilizer could be moved as quickly as possible.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Holloman to Sever Outside Ties

title: Percy Rejects Nixon Case For Withholding Documents
description: CINCINNATI, March 15 (UPI) Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, said today that President Nixon's refusal to give up documents sought by Watergate investigators on the ground of protecting the rights of future Presidents was not valid.

title: Trial of Roncallo Delayed by Judge In Reluctane Move
description: A Government request for an adjournment of the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo, Republican of the Third Congressional District, and two other defendants, was granted reluctantly yesterday by Edward R. Neaher, a Federal judge in Brooklyn.

title: Stalking the Elusive Campus
description: BOULDER, Colo., March 15Every year about this time the University of Colorado invites six or eight dozen guests, ranging from statesmen through pedagogues, artists, bureaucrats, activists in the cause of social uplift, parsons, publishers, philosophers and even occasionally felons and journalists to come sit on the side of the Rocky Mountains and spend week talking to students.

title: The Aged and Disabled Protest New U.S. Program at Pace Rally
description: More than 2,000 disabled and elderly people held a rally yesterday in the auditorium at Pace College here to demand emergency funds because, they contended, a new Federal assistance program is not working.

title: Screen: Three Tough Guys' Proves Soft Stuff
description: "Three Tough Guys" is about a Roman Catholic priest (Lino Ventura) and a cashiered Chicago cop (Isaac Hayes) who joined forces to solve a bank robbery and murder involving an ambitious hood (Fred Williamson).The exteriors were shot on location in Chicago and the interiors in Rome in what sometimes seem to be hand-me-down Fellini sets. The results are made even more disorienting by the post-synchronized English dialogue. Everyone sounds as if??? he were talking through an exhaust pipe.The movie, which opened yesterday at the DeMille, is international junk of no interest, by far the worst film yet produced by Dino De Laurentiis since he left Rome to make movies in this country.

title: 8,500 Gallons Missing In Coast Gasjacking
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 15, (Reuters)  The police reported today what they said was the city's first gasjacking.

title: ROCKEFELLER FEES TO DR. RILAND CITED
description: The Rockefeller family's chief accountant testified yesterday that former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller paid Dr. W. Kenneth Riland a retainer of $1,000 month, plus extra for extra services.

title: State's OilInquiry Jury Starts Taking Evidence
description: A special grand jury looking into possible violations of the state's antitrust laws by oil companies began hearing evidence here yesterday.

title: British Golfers Lead
description: KOBE, Japan, March 15 (AP)British golfers, led by Tony Jacklin, took a 131 lead against an eightman Japanese team on the first day of the first threeday BritainJapan golf tournament today.

title: People in Sports
description: Walt Tkaczuk of the Rangers suffered a fracture of the jaw Thursday night against the Chicago Black Hawks and will be out of action for an indefinite period. The 190pound center, who had collected 17 goals and 39 assists in 65 National Hockey League games this season, will undergo an examination tomorrow to determine the exact extent of the injury and to learn if his jaw will require wiring.

title: Big U.S. Refinery Projects Have Been Put Off; Libya Opens Up Oil Tracts to Foreign Concerns
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 15Libya is opening up large blocs for exploration by foreign oil companies while nationalizing the concession holdings a major American oil companies that refuse to do business on Libya's terms.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MORRISTOWN, March 15 There were two 197374 basketball seasons for Morristown High School.

title: Nixon Reception Mixed Applause and Protests
description: CHICAGO, March 15Inside the cavernous grand ballroom of the Conrad Hilton Hotel it was warm and dry, and President Nixon's huge luncheon audience of Chicago business and professional persons was friendly and polite.

title: Kidnap Insurance to Be Sold To DetroitArea Residents
description: DETROIT, March 15 (UPI)Detroitarea residents will soon be able to take out kidnap and ransom insurance at a cost of from $300 to $400 a year providing a liability of $500,000.

title: About the Mets
description: Rusty Staub, who has been to bat only five times in the Mets first seven games, suffered another injury in batting practice. The 29yearold outfielder strained the hamstring muscle in his right leg last Monday but was included in the lineup yesterday against the Boston Red Soxwhen he strained his right shoulder while checking a swing at bat. The injury, the Mets doctor said, is not related to the shoulder dislocation that crippled him during the playoffs last October. Jim Russo, superspy for the Baltimore Orioles, is tracking the Red Sox this week. told Darrell Johnson, he said, that he's got the team we'll worry about the most. Straight from Luis Aparicio Venezuela on the heavyweight championship fight in his country March 26 between George Foreman and Ken Norton: Norton's the guy. Bob Veale, at 38, trying to prolong his pitching career with Boston. But I have a choice, the lefthander reported. If I don't make the team, I'll be a pitcher and coach with their farm club

title: Vietcong and Saigon Blame Each Other for Killing of 32
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Government and the Vietcong bitterly denounced each other today over a mortar shell that killed 32 children and wounded 56 children and adults at a primary school in the Mekong Delta last week.

title: Berlioz Conducted With Fine Balance By Andrew Davis
description: The big workand it is very big work,in Andrew Davis's concert with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night was Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique. The 29yearold British conductor, whose slight figure makes him look 10 years younger on the podium, conducted it in a way that reaffirmed the talent he showed in his debut with the orchestra the previous week.

title: Brezhnev Unveils a Vast Effort to Farm Steppes of Northern Russia
description: MOSCOW, March 15Leonid I. Brezhnev today announced vast agricultural development project for the northern regions, costing $44billion in the next FiveYear Plan, on the model of Nikita S. Khrushchev's famous and controversial virgin lands program.

title: Market Place: Treasury Bills Now Yield 8%
description: People who are leery of Investing in the stock or bond markets at present but who want to maximize the yield on their money might well consider Treasury bills.

title: A Writers Colony Thrives in Diverse Ozarks Town
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., March 15The place would be named the Blue Ribbon.or the Ritz or maybe the Elite in some other Southern towns. Here it is, simply Roger's Pool Hall.

title: COURT CURBS U.S. ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 15A Federal judge ordered the Government today to stop paying for the sterilization of children and mentally incompetent persons and to redraft its regulations for all such operations on welfare patients.

title: Pastore Criticizes Nixon Proposals For Vote Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Senator John O. Pastore, DeMocrat of Rhode Island, said today that the most serious defect in President Nixon's campaign reform Proposals was his opposition to public financing.

title: Knights Beat Saints
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., March 15 (AP)The Jersek Knights erupted for three goals in 80 seconds early. in the second period, two of them by Wayne Rivers, and went on to hand the Minnesota Fighting Saints a 53 World Hockey Association setback tonight.

description: BASEBALL

title: Six Women Are Named For Communication Prizes
description: New YOLK women In Communications yesterday named the six recipients of its annual Matrix Awards for exceptional achievement in the communications industry.

title: South Korea Rounds Up 47 On Charges of Espionage
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 15The South Korean Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it had rounded up 47 South Koreans allegedly involved in an espionage ring in the service of North Korea.

title: Jazz: The BraffBarnes Quartet Style
description: After an unusually notable debut last June at the Newport Jazz Festival here, the Ruby BraffGeorge Barnes Quartet now has its first engagement in a New York nightclub. The group, which is sharing the bill at the Rainbow Grill with the singer Damita Jo until the end of March, is reemphasizing the qualities it revealed at the festival; a distinctive ensemble sound based on Mr. Braff's trumpet and Mr. Barnes's electric guitar, a light but crisply propulsive rhythmic foundation produced by two guitars and string bass but without drums (and, consequently, occasionally reminiscent of the Quintet of the Hot Club of France), and the two leaders individualistic solo styles.

title: Ricker, Treharne Win Yacht Races
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 15 (Reuters)Bill Ficker, an America's Cup champion, and Hugh Treharne, the sole Australian entrant, scored double victories yesterday on the opening day of the threeday Congressional Cup yacht racing series, which was plagued by fog.

title: JOSEPH E. UNSWORTH
description: Joseph Edward Unsworth, who retired four years ago as chief of transportationservice contracts in the State Department's Bureau of Cultural and Educational Affairs, died Thursday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 65 years old and lived in College Park, Md.

title: CABBYSEIZED HERE IN SLAYINGS AT BAR
description: A 29yearold driver of a gypsy cab was charged yesterday with slaying two persons and wounding two others during a $200 robbery last Monday in a Queens bar and grill.

title: Big U.S. Refinery Projects Have Been Put Off; Libya Opens Up Oil Tracts to Foreign Concerns
description: A number of major oil re finery construction project have been quietly dropped deferred since the Arab oil em bargo began in October, an both the Federal Energy Offici and a Senate committee are in vestigating to see if the delay will further aggravate the na tion's energy problems.

title: A Noted Soviet Sculptor Asserts Officials Curb Work and Travel
description: MOSCOW, March 15More than a decacte ago, Ernst Nelzvestny, an internationally known modernist sculptor, caused a sensation by standing toetotoe with Nikita S. Khrushchev and arguing the merits of abstract art with the leader, who had called it filth.

description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 15 (UPI)Advocates of teaching the theories of divine creation in California schols have suffered another setback.

title: Sentence Bargaining
description: In separating the prosecutorial function from the judicial obligation to impose sentencing, District Attorney Kuh of New York County has taken a purist and sound position that deserves a chance in practice.

title: MRS. ISIDORE SCHWARTZ
description: SYRACUSE, March 15Mrs. Pauline Eisenstein Schwartz, a psychologist with the Bureau of Child Guidance in New York from 1945 to 1965, died yesterday on a visit here. She was 81 years old and lived at 8 Highland Court, Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Priests as Human Beings
description: THESE PRIESTS STAY. By Paul Wilkes, 250 pages. Simon & Schukter. $6.95.

title: Why Do Americans Push to Get Ahead?
description: MIACA, N. Y.  The American Revolution Bicentennial seems to be spawning a good many gimmicks and commercial products, but also some symposia with serious historical substance. At a recent brainstorming session whose purpose was to reassess American values and culture in hi storical perspective, a difficult cluestea arose: Why do Americans have such a strong impulse to get ahead? The reasons seem to be elusive, yet worthy of pursuit.

title: Energy Shortages Have Minimal Effect on Most Amish in Ohio
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Ohio Dan Byler paused in running his file over the teeth of the manual circular saw that he uses to cut up fat hickory logs into firewood and pondered the energy problem.

title: Green's 137 Sets Pace By Stroke
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 15 (AP)  Hubert Green made birdies on four Of the first five holes he played today, carded a fiveunderpar 67 and took the secondround lead by one stroke in the $150,000 Gregor Jacksonville golf tournarant.

title: Art: The Modern's Picasso Collage
description: To its already immense collection of the works of Pablo Picasso, the Museum of Modern Art has now added an item that, although small in size (19 by 16 inches), looms large in the artist's works of the nineteenthirties and in the history of the surrealist movement with which he was temporarily allied. This is the collage, composed of a pencil drawing, paper doilies, tin foil. corrugated cardboard and a twig tacked on wood, that Picasso created in 1933 as the design for the cover of the first issue of the surrealists lavish art journal called Minotaure.

title: A New Bonanza for South Africa: Soaring Gold. Prices
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 15 (AP)The soaring freemarket price of gold promises a bonanza for South Africa, which produces most of the world's supply.

title: Wire Designed to Save Energy Is Invented
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 A professor of physics has invented a superconducting wire that is expected to save energy in motors, generators, magnets and other devices

title: Baby Dies in Stuck Stroller
description: ENID, Okla., March 15 (AP) baby boy died in his home as his mother slept when his stroller became trapped on the grating of a floor furnace, the police reported. Jason R. Damron, 3monthold son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Damron, was found dead yesterday afternoon.

title: General Geisel Is Sworn In as President of Brazil As Hopes Rise for Some Political Liberalization
description: BRASILIA, March 15Gen. Ernesto Geisel was ceremoniously sworn in as Brazil's new President today amid cautious hopes for some liberalization after a decade of authoritarian military rule.

title: Squire Sentenced to, Life For Killing State Trooper
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. March 15  Clark E. Squire, a 36yearold black militant and admitted member of the Black Liberation Army, was sentenced to life in prison here today by a Middlesex County Court Judge for having murdered a New Jersey state policeman in a turnpike shootout last May 2.

title: Henri Pequet Dead at 86; Air. Poneer Flew First Mail
description: VICHY, France, March 15 (UPI)The aviation pioneer Henri Pequet, who became the first flying postman when he carried mail by plane in 1911, has died at his home here, friends said today. He was 86 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish economist, has been named to receive the first Frank E. Seidman Distinguished Award in Political Economy. He is salpeduled to receive the $10000 award at a banquet given by Memphis State University on May 20.

title: In French Town, Demons Linger
description: LOUDUN, France  They burned Urbain Grandier at the stake for witchcraft three centuries ago, but the people of Loudun think and speak of him to this day.

title: 14 JEWISH WOMEN DEAD1N SYRIA CAVE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 15 The bodies of four Jewish women have been found in a cave in Syria near a mountain trail leading to Lebanon, According to Syria's Minister of the Interior, the women had been killed by four smugglers, two of them memliers of Syria's small Jewish community.

title: BRASCO JURY WEIGHS CASE FOR 4 HOURS
description: The jury in the corruptioncbnspiracy trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco deliberated for three hours and 50 minutes yesterday before being excused by Federal District Judge Inzer B. Wyatt until 10 A.M. Monday.

title: Jacobsen Denies Committing Perjury in Watergate Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Jake Jacobsen, a former aide to President Johnson, pleaded not guilty today to perjury charges arising from his statements to a Watergate grandjury about milk producers political funds.

title: Hearing on L.I. Electricity Rise Transferred as Anger Mounts
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 15 Nearly 600 residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties confronted an official of the Public Service Commission at a hearing here today and angrily told him that they would not tolerate a proposed 18 per cent increase in their electricity bills.

title: Dr. Patrick Kilburn Dead; Wrote on Lexicography
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 15Dr. Patrick E. Kilburn, chairman of the English department of Union College, who wrote and spoke widely on lexicography, died here today of a heart attack. His age was 51.

title: Dean Witter
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., the wholly owned investment banking subsidiary of the. Dean Witter Organization, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $1.2million for the second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, down from $1.4million a year ago. Net income per share was 30 cents, compared with 36 cents.

title: Oklahoma State Takes Mat Lead
description: Oklahoma Iowa, Manch 15 (AP) Oklahoma State crept into a narrow lead tonight in the 44th National Collegiate wrestling championships but was closely pursued by crosssate rival Oklahoma.

title: AMERICAN CAN SETS PAPERBOARD RISE
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday that it had raised prices for paperboard and certain plastic film packaging products.

title: Works of Arp and Noguchi Well Paired
description: In terms of style and esthetic temperament, two artists could hardly make a more complementary pairing than in the exhibition of sculptures, drawings and collages by the late Jean Arp and Isamu Noguchi now on view at Cordier & Ekstrom Inc., 980 Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The show is an unadulterated pleasurethe adjective used advisedly, since the work of both artists tends toward a purity of form that is often breathtaking.

title: Moonshine Whisky Drops
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 15 (UPI)  West Virginia's moonshine whisky production is declining because of inflation and changing attitudes among bootleggers descendants, a Federal revenue agent says on a licensed beverage report released today.

title: CIBA Scientists Complain as Strike Goes On
description: SUMMIT, March 14As the strike here against the CIBApeigy Corporation by Local 9, International Chemical Workers Union, enters its eighth week, scientific workers at the pharmaceutical plant are complaining that they are being forced to perform janitorial and animalmaintenance duties.

title: CORRECTION
description: The New York Times reported incorrectly yeSterday that Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader, had been called before a grand jury five years ago in an investigation of Carmine G. De Sapio, the former Manhattan Democratic chairman. Actually, Mr. Rossetti appeared as a defense witness at the conspiracy trial of Mr. De Sapio.

title: Missing Element
description: There is a curious mix of esthetic values at the corner of 79th Street and Park Avenue now that a Henry Moore sculpture has been installed, with conspicuous fanfare, in front of a big, new apartment house. It could be called throwing good art after a bad building, since the event forces on the spectator a comparison of the art of sculpture and the art of architecture. There are a few notably handsome and wellhandled examples of apartmenthouse design currently visible in New York, but the trend, particularly in the highrent category, continues to be to offer corn for class.

title: Paper Blocked in Inquiry
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (UPI) Judge Paul Ribner of Common Pleas Court has temporarily blocked The Philadelphia Inquirer from publishing the identities of some 400 city policemen charged with corruption. Judge Ribner yesterday refused the newspaper's request for access to the policen'ten's last names but left undecided the issue of whether payroll records that would identify the policemen are public information and open for inspection.

title: Notes on People
description: The American Broadcasting Company has canceled the guest appearance of Mrs. Richard M. Nixon on tomorrow's Issues and Answers television interview, because of a dispute with the White House over ground rules for her appearance. The White House had originally agreed to a format for the program that included a few minutes of film from Mrs. Nixon's LatinAmerican trip, followed by questions from a panel of newsmen.

title: Five Men Carrying M16 Rifles Take $15,000 in Ambush
description: Five holdup men, at least two of them armed with M16 automatic rifles, ambushed a team of armed guards in an alleyway behind a Brooklyn hospital yesterday and escaped with $15,000 that was being delivered to cash employes pay, checks.

title: Copper Rise in Canada
description: TORONTO, March 15 (Canadian Press)The. Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company, Ltd., announced an immediate increase today in the price of copper sold in Canada, to 77.5 cents a pound from 74 cents. The move follows similar increases announced by International Nickel of Canada, Ltd., and the Noranda Sales Corporation.

description: NARRATIVE CINEMA  FART ONE: CHARLIE BENSON'S RETURN TO THE SEA by Victor Nunez, 42 minutes; PASSING QUIETLY THROUGH by Denitla McCarthy, 28 minutes; HOT DOGS FOR GAUGUIN by Martin Brest, 22 minutes, At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: U.S. QUESTIONNAIRE WILL BE ALTERED
description: A Federal civil rights official said yesterday that the Government would make changes in its proposed pupil data questionnaire, intended to be given next month to 100,000 elementary school pupils here, to meet the legitimate concerns of the New York City Board of Education.

title: 2 Old Syrian Rooms to Go on Display
description: The interiors of two 18thcentury Syrian houses will go on exhibition here late this year, more than 40 years after they were brought to this country only to be rejected by prospective buyers and left to gather dust in warehouses.

title: Blazers Defeat Knicks
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 15 Not even a 15point lead late in the second quarter was enough to prevent the New York Knicks from suffering their annual Portland prattfall tonight as they lost to the Trail Blazers, 107105, before a crowd of 10,160.

Held in Attack on Bishop
description: HOUSTON, March 15 (UPI) Roger Glen Lewis, 24 years old, was charged yesterday with beating and robbing the Most Rev. John L. Morkovsky, 63yearold Roman Catholic Bishop of the GalvestonHouston Dia: cese. Two men forced their way into Bishop Morkovsky's home last Friday night, pistolwhipped him and took his wallet and car keys. The Bishop's left eye had to be removed because of the beating.

title: Aerialist in Good Condition
description: MIAMI, March 15 (UPI)A circus aerialist,. Jacqueline Serbini, was reported in good condition today after falling 30 feet to a concrete floor last night when the rigging on her highwire act collapsed at the end of her performance. An audience of 7,000 at the Mahi Shrine Circus saw the 28yearold performer fall in a tangle of rigging at the Flagler Kennel Club.

title: M'INTOSH TO APPEAL A. RULING ON A,&P.
description: The McIntosh Foundation, which owns about 5 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, said yesterday it would appeal a ruling by a State Supreme Court judge denying it the right to inspect the records of the supermarket chain for the last 11 years.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority announced yesterday that it had awarded a $184.4million contract to the Brown Boveri Corporation of North Brunswick, N. J., for four steam turbogenerators of about 1.23 million kilowatt capacity each. The generating equipment is for use in a new fourunit nuclear power installation that is being planned for commercial operation in 1980.82 to help meet projected demand of the T.V.A. area at that time. Contracts for the reactors and fuel for the installation, were awarded in late 1972 to the General Electric Company. The turbogenerators will be manufactured in Switzerland, home of Brown Boveri, and at Richmond, Va. T.V.A.

title: U.S. Family Planning Aid Lost by Pioneer Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  The Government said today that it would not give any more money to the Louisiana Family Health Foundation, a private family planning program that has been accused of multimillion  dollar irregularities.

title: Purge of Moderate Military Officers Is Reported in Portugal
description: LISBON, March 15  The split within the Portuguese armed forces over the war in Africa appeared to deepen today with reliable reports of a purge of officers who favored an early peace through politi, cal accommodation with Afri. can guerrillas.

title: 2 BRITONS APPEAL YUGOSLAV SPY TERM

description: LAKEWOOD, March 15  Superintendent of Schools WilLiam D. Mackolin pledged yesterday to continue his efforts to desegregate the three elementary schools here despite the local school board's rejection of the largescale busing plan he supported.

title: 35 HOTEL TENANTS REFUSE TO VACATE
description: About 35 tenants of the Knickerbocker Hotel, which the city has ordered vacated as unfit for human habitation, stayed in or near their rooms yesterday for fear that the police stationed in the lobby would not permit them to return if they went out even for food.

title: About the Yankees
description: Terry Whitfield, the young outfielder who has a slim chance of making the Yankees this spring, socked a threerun homer in the eighth inning that was the difference in yesterday's game. Rich Bladt also homered. Steve Kline, coming back from elbow trouble, pitched the first three innings and allowed only one hit. Every ball the Rangers hit against him was on the ground. Jim Ray Hart had to leave the game in the first inning after fouling a ball off his left leg below the knee. He suffered a bruise and also twisted his knee while falling to the ground. He'll probably miss a day or two. Ron Blomberg has four hits in 11 times at bat against lefthanded pitchers this spring. He added a single off Dave Moharter yesterday. Fred Stanley has been hampered in his efforts to win a job by a pulled leg muscle. Ken Wright, the reliever obtained from Kansas City, isn't doing well at losing weight. He weighed in yesterday at 235, only 8 pounds less than when he reported three weeks ago. Virdon has said he'd like Wright to weigh around 220 the of

title: Dow to Seek House Seat
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., March (UPI)John G. Dow, a former Representative who had announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, said today that he had changed his mind and would seek the 26th District seat, The seat is held by Representative Benjamin Gilman, a Republican who defeated Mr. Dow in 1972.

title: McCall Will Not Run
description: SALEM, Ore., March 15 (UPI) Gov. Tom McCall, Republican of Oregon has decided against seeking the United States Senate seat of Robert W. Packwood, also a Republican, because he says, Oregon is where my family and I want to be. In announcing his decision yesterday, Governor McCall said By turning my back on, politics I can wind up my second term most productiyely and face my neighbors through the years ahead with an untroubled conscience.

title: FASHION TALK

It was Mr. Pearson's first fashion show.

title: Squire Sentenced to Life For Killing State Troopet
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. March 15  Clark E. Squire, a 36yearold black militant and admitted member of the Black Liberation Army, was sentenced to life in prison here today by a Middlesex County Court Judge for having murdered a New Jersey state policeman in a turnpike shootout last May 2.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The Agriculture Department announced today a transfer of 158,540 tons he 1974 United States sugar quota to 19 other foreign countries because some production areas could not provide their full share. Officials said the redistribution was the result of deficits in Puerto Rico, 55,000 tons; the Texas sugar cane area, 40,000, and Venezuela, 63,540 tons.

title: It's Not the Way to Police Lawyers
description: Last September, the Judicial Conference of the United States, headed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and composed of the chief Federal judges of the country, offered anew plan for ferreting out misconduct by lawyers throughout the country. The Conference proposed that Congress enact a law that would permit a Federal judge to call in the F.B.I. to investigate lawyers who have been accused of unethical conduct or other conduct unbecoming a member of the bar. The judges defended the proposal as a means of standardizing disciplinary procedures in all Federal courts since it would supply needed manpower to aid state bar grievance committees who normally lack adequate funding or personnelto make proper inquiry. The plan was introduced into Congress

title: United States and France: I
description: PARISThe petulance now featuring United States relationships with France is ridiculous and unnecessary. From certain remarks attributed to Henry Kissinger one must conclude he should never be indiscreet in private, which he now inferentially acknowledges. It is one thing to use the calculated public leak for policy purposes but it is quite another to blow off steam and have it surface in a cloud of embarrassment.

description: The Senate vote of 54 to 33 to restore the death penalty for a number of vaguely defined Federal crimes allows a dismal glimpse into the savage irrationality beneath the veneer of civilized society. description: The First National City Bank, a bank that has been trying to demonstrate that the rates charges on corporate loans are largely the result of market forces out of its control, raised its prime, of base rate, yesterday back to 8 per cent from 8 per cent; a level put into effect two weeks ago.

title: Louisiana Bishop Gets Drunken Driving Fine
description: BATON ROUGE, March 15 (UPI)A state court has ordered the Roman Catholic Bishop of Baton Rouge to pay a $150 fine or spend 30'days in jail for driving while intoxicated.

title: His First Fight Is Fatal
description: ROME, March 15 (UPI)Fabrizio Avincola, 20 years old, died in a hospital yesterday of head injuries he suffered in his first amateur boxing bout. Doctors said Avincola had been in a coma since he was knocked down and hit his head on the ring floor during a fight Tuesday.

title: Italy's Star, Miss Proell Win Slaloms
description: ASPEN, Colo, March 15 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni, the threetime World Cup titleholder from Italy, rebounded from yesterday's disappointing disqualification to win the slalom today in the Nations World Series of skiing.

title: Bridge: Starts at a New Site Today New York SwissTeam Play
description: New York tournament players are sure to make more mistakes than usual today. A substantial number of them planning to play in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss teams event are likely to show up at the New York Hilton Hotel, the headquarters of every major tournament here for the last decade. However, those who go to the Hilton will be disappointed because play will start at 1:30 P.M. at the Biltmore Hotel, a move that seems to foreshadow the gradual abandonment of the Hilton as a tournament site.

title: A Writers Colony Thrives in Diverse Ozarks Town
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., March 15The, place would be named the Blue Ribbon or the Ritz or maybe the Elite in some other Southern towns. Here it is simply Roger's Pool Hall.

title: Agriculture Department Sees Ample Food Supply
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 Top economists at the Department of Agriculture said today that their projections of this year's yields from major crops showed that the nation would have ample food supplies, and they derided fears of scarcity resulting from fuel and fertilizer shortages and heavy grain exports.

title: Manhattan Five Tests Md.Shore Today in the N.I.T.
description: Mysterious Maryland Eastern Shore will be the curiosity factor during eight hours of college basketball today as the National Invitation Tournament gets under way at Madison Square Garden. There will be afternoon and evening doubleheaders.

title: GOING OUT Guide

But today and tomorrow you can take a look around for only $1 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. On Monday, the mansion will be open from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M.

title: COURT CURBS U.S. ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 15A Federal judge ordered the Government today to stop paying for the sterilization of children and mentally incompetent persons and to redraft its regulations for all such operations on welfare patients.

title: COL. ROBERT S. BEARD
description: Col. Robert S. Beard, Army Corps of Engineers, retired, who taught spatial geometry at Yeshiva University in New York, died Wednesday in Arcata, Calif. He was 91 years old and lived in Trinidad, Calif.

title: Realty Management Concern Failing; Use of Coops Funds Is Investigated
description: A realestate company that managed more than 70 apartment buildings, including 15 cooperatives built under city and state middleincome housing programs, has collapsed financially, its lawyer said yesterday. City and state agencies are investigating whether money belonging to the coops under their supervision is missing.

title: Nickel Project Set in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY, March 15The International Nickel Company is at last going ahead with the development of extensive nickel deposits in eastern Guatemala after more than a decade of financial and political difficulties that have sharply reduced the size, and probable profitability for the company, of the project.

title: Labor Techniques Settle Wide Range of Disputes
description: For almost two years, the new Seward Park housing project on New York's Lower East Side stayed empty while Spanishspeaking and Jewish groups argued about how tenants should be chosen. The argument had gone to court. Last October, George Nicolou, a mediator from the

title: Percy Sees Need to Restore Credibility to the Presidency
description: CHICAGO, March 16 (Reuters)Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, a possible Republican Presidential contender in 1976, said here today that President Nixon was beloved by many Americans, but the question was now to restore credibility to the Presidency.

title: Television This Week
description: Today 11:00 AM. (2) CAMERA THREE. Nightwalk. The second of a twopart series on the Open Theater's last play before the group disbanded.

title: SAHARAN SPRING: A TIME TO SUFFER
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 16 The loss of two young chil dren and 45 head of cattle to the sixyear drought in the southern Sahara was recently described by a Fulani herdsman with a single word: Soudure.

title: Esposito Scores Twice As Bruins Rout Leafs, 52
description: TORONTO, March 16 (UPI)  Phil Esposito scored his 62d and 63d goals of the season and Ken Hodge broke seven  game goal scoring drought today by picking up his 44th and 45th tallies to lead the Boston Bruins to a 52 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: A Mechanized. Port Thrives in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH  The operation goes off as easily as dunking a doughnut in your morning coffee.

title: March Doth Make Liars
description: Shakespeare never used it in his plays, but he must have several times been tempted to say, at least as an aside, March doth make liars of us all. For March in London was as perfidious as it was in Stratford. And Stratford March is not too different from March in Manhattan, or in Queens or Bergen County or in nearby areas of Connecticut. March means maybe, but don't bet on it.

title: Carol Oughton Is Married to Frank J. Biondi Jr.
description: DWIGHT, III., March 16Miss Carol Oughton of New York, director of research in the documentary division of the American Broadcasting Company, and Frank J. Biondi Jr., a New York financial consultant, were married here this afternoon in the Pioneer Gothic Church by the Rev. James Steele of St. Thomas. Episcopal Church in Morris.

title: Minnesota Wins Title In Hockey
description: BOSTON, March 16Tonight was the night when the American hockey player finally arrived. In a stunning upset, the Minnesota Gophers defeated the nation's No. 1 team, Michigan Tech, 4.2, and became the first totally Americanborn squad to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association crown since Boston College won in 1949. Every Gopher skater who played is a Minnesota native, and the title was Minnesota's first in its 50 years of intercollegiate hockey.

title: Things Are Looking Up for Bobby Unser
description: Four months ago, Bobby Unser broke his left foot, mashed his right hand and cracked several ribs in a crash at FasTrack International, Phoenix. He still feels

The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Kilmarth is an associate editor of Glamour magazine. Her husband, who is production manager of Wolfsehmidt Vodka, Is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mangan of Hicksville, L. t

title: Pamela A. Paul Fiancee of Officer
description: The engagement of Miss Pamela Ann Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Paul of Sao Paulo, Brazil, formerly of Birmingham, Mich., to SecoId Lieut. James Wilson McKee, 3d, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., formerly of no Paulo, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: IKON IN MARCH FOR ST. PATRICK
description: More than a hundred thou sand strong, the Irish and their friends marched up Fifth Ave. nue in the rain yesterday, pas, some of the landmarks of their own local history and bearing banners that told of their pep pie's troubled present.

title: By the Grace of the President, Mr. Fitzsimmons Keeps His Post, Mr. Hoffa Notwithstanding
description: WASHINGTONThe political base upon which President Nixon built his landslide reelection victory in 1972 is melting away like a sand castle before an incoming tide. But one block of that base, at least, has remained almost touchingly steadfast to the Presidentthe International Brotherhood Teamsters, the nation's biggest trade union, and its President, Frank E. Fitzsimmons.

title: SOCIALIST VIEWS ON ARABS SHIFTING
description: CAIRO, March 12Western European Socialist parties, which have traditionally been among Israel's stanchest supporters, are taking an increasingly active interest in the Arab world.

title: May Bridal Set By Miss Bush, Philip Nadeau
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 16  Mr. and Mrs. Prescott Sheldon Bush Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Kelsey Bush, to Philip Gerald Nadeau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Nadeau of St. Paul's River, Quebec.

title: Golf Post to Mangum
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16(UPI)Clyde C. Mangum Jr. has been named to the new, post of, tournament coordinator for the Tournament Players Division of the Professional Golfers Association, the P.G.A. announced today.

title: Concert: Musica Sacra
description: Given the splendid setting of the Metropolitan Museum's Medieval Sculpture Court and the excellence of the performers Richard Westenburg had brought together for a Musica Sacra concert of Bach cantatas on Thursday night, there was good reason to expect that the event would be one of special luster.

title: Women, From Eve To This Evening
description: AT the nation's centennial celebration in Philadelphia in 1876, feminists were denied permission to read the Women's Declaration of Rights and Articles of Impeachment in Independence Hall. Tonight at 8, CBS will partially redress that grievance by launching The American Parade, its epic (threeyear, 13part, primetime) celebration of the nation's bicentennial, with We the Women.

title: Republicans: Some Not Waiting for The Deluge
description: Eight months before election day, the political casualties from Watergate, inflation and energy are already strewn about the tristate landscape in what may become the biggest electoral unheaval since Barry Goldwater was overwhelmed 10 years ago and carried many Republicans down with him.

title: Steam Rallies Mark the British as the World's Greatest Gadgeteers
description: THE throng of about 50,000 people suddenly comes alive on the rolling English hillside. Mothers grab their kids out of the way and spectators shove each other back against the beer tents and candyapple stands as the magnificent steaming monsters begin to move. Slowly, inexorably, like Singleminded steel and brass dinosaurs, the ponderous traction engines move out, one after another, to parade around a vast circle, huffing and hissing, whistles tooting, flywheels spinning and sparkling. They're all thereawesome steamrollers, smoking road locomotives, stalwart ploughing engines and tractors, and the lovingly decorated, holidaymaking showman's engines.

title: City Opera Substitutes Traviata f0 r Medea ta a
description: The New York City Opera substituted a performance of Verdi's La Traviata for Cherubini's Medea yesterday afternoon. It was the first time in the company's 30year history that a lastminute switch had been made, according to Julius Rudel, its director.

title: Japan Raises Domestic Prices Of Oil Products by About 62%
description: TOKYO, March 16 (Reuters)  The Japanese Government today authorized steep increases in the domestic prices of oil products to help prevent a decline in crude oil supplies.

title: $50Million Sought ToUpgradeL.I.R.R.
description: ALBANY  A special $50million bond issue to improve the Long Island Railroad's service to Suffolk County and to protect the resort industry of the Hamptons from the ravages of the energy crisis has been quietly proposed here and is gradually drawing some major support.

title: Nixon's Criticism of Allies Stirs Bitterness in Europe
description: LONDON, March 16  President Nixon's criticism of Amer. ca's allies stirred bewilderment and bitterness in European capitals today, with the sharpest reaction coming in France.

title: Concrete Canoes to Gompete

title: The Man Is Not The Office
description: In his stubborn determination to hang on to his office, Richard Nixon keeps trying to blur the distinction between it and himself. Like the unlamented Committee for the Reelection of the President, he would have us believe that he is not so much mortal man as a function; and that the Presidency is not so much a political office as a sort of natural force flowing at a constant rate through American history.

title: Hanoi Leader to Visit Cuba
description: MIAMI, Fla., March 16 (AP) Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam will visit Cuba at the end of this month at the invitation of Premier Fidel Castro, the Havana radio said today.

title: 20% of Queens Drugstores Said to Skirt Price Law

He had been there for 29 years and rebuilt the place, taking on children usually considered incurable, like the mute autistic ones, increasing the number of inmates from 30 to 50odd, and adding adolescents and young people in their twenties. The school has achieved a salvage rate  returned to full participation in lifeof better than 85 per cent, and done so, incidentally, on a budget quite comparable to those of more orthodox

description: WANTAGH, L. I., March 16  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Ashley of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Lea Ashley, to Stephen P. Bradley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Bradley of New York. Miss Ashley graduated from the Fashion institute of Technology in New York. Her fiance, an alumnus of Fordham University, attends the University of Bologna Medical School in Italy.

You have to be able to take the disappointments, the grief, the moaning. It's like teaching school. You have to know what player needs a pat on the head and which one should get a good kick in the pants.

title: Recordings
description: THERE are very few operas that present the bass with a real star, turn, Boito's Mefistofele fs definitely one of them, and when Norman Treigle performed the title role in the City Opera's 1969 production, he seized the opportunity with the kind of unrelenting energy, concentration and flamboyance that can leave an audience tired but happy. His performance did have its hokey side perhaps, but for all the vaudeville flavor this Mephisto was always a vivid and at times disgustingly dehumanized force of evil.

title: Son to the Rosenblatts

title: The Nation
description: The widespread corruption discovered in the police forces of New York, Chicago and some smaller cities in recent years has reached an ironic high point in Philadelphia. There, the administration of Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, who captured City Hall in 1971 by exploiting his reputation as the toughest cop in America, finds itself accused of tolerating police corruption as serious as anything that has come to light elsewhere.

title: OPINION: A College Coach Tells Why
description: College football Is a great game and I'm very happy to be A part of it. The recruiting excesses and abuses discussed on these pages the last week disturb me, as they do all people committed to sound intercollegiate athletics. But rather than elaborating on what has been written, I believe we can perform a more useful service if we first explore the recruiting syndrome from a coach's viewpointto try to give you a better insight into why we have the abuses and excesses and then suggest remedies to the disease.

title: Ficker Gains Edge In Sailing on Coast

title: In Paris, Everything Starts at a Cafe Table
description: PARISYou are sitting, let's say, at a small, round, bare table more than casually etched by the traces of a thousand beer glasses, and when the waiter comes you announce that you would like, please, a demiblonde (demiblonde being a term you acquired on your first day in Paris), and idly you wonder how much, this time, the short light beer will cost. The price is posted somewhere, of course, as required by law, but the list evades your eye. It really doesn't matter, does it? Two francs or 3this is not, after all, a world that pares down the profits to the irreducible minimum. Anyhow, Maybe it's only a coffee you want on this morning of shimmering sun (or pearly cloud), a small blackin fact, jet blackcaf express. The coffee could be priced at 1 franc 30 centimes (about 25 cents) as it is on the sidewalk at Ma Bourgogne in the stately Place des Vosges, where once it was fashionable for gentlemen to duel, or 2 francs, the price at the ParisMadeleine on Rue Royale, a neighborhood close to the sources of feminine fashion, or 3 francs, as at Boulevard Saintgermain's Cafe de Fiore, patronized by strikingly beautiful young Frenchmen whose dainty collation is paid for by handsome French

title: The New Plan to Share Power Failed to Include the I.R.A.
description: LONDONIrish unity, to the outsider the most satisfying solution for Ireland's distresses, recedes faster and faster into the mists of the future. Liam Cosgrave, Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, now has solemnly acknowledged in the Dublin Dail that the factual position of Northern Ireland within the United Kingdom cannot be changed except by decision of a majority of the people of Northern Ireland.

title: Trying to Be Mostel, Trying to Be Joyce
description: ZERO MOSTEL does a curious bit of business with his hands in Ulysses in Nighttown that I think may mean something. As Joyce's Leopold Bloom he is already deep into Nighttown itself, spinning dizzily between the child he was and the man he wants not to be, haunted by the necessity of whores and hunted down by the demonic powers that make him everybody and nobody, taking his revenge for the death of his only son and the cavalier infidelities of his wife by giving birth in fantasy to eight yellowandwhite boy children that areat the Winter Gardenno more than paper dolls.

title: Newspaper Group to Move

title: Stuefer Is Winner In Giant Slalom
description: LES MENUIRES, France March 16 (UPI)  Harald Stuefer of Austria won today's giant slalom of the $30,000 Grand Prix des Menuires ski competition for professional ski racers, part of the World Grand Prix. Two other Austrians, Eddy Reich and Hugo Nindl, were second and third, with Ken Corrock, a Sun Valley, Idaho pro fourth. Stuefer won $4000 while Reich got $2,500 and Nindl, $1,500. Nindl's victory raised his leading season total to $33,900.

title: Impeachment Politics
description: Although impeachment is a grave question that ought to be considered in a judicial spirit, President Nixon seems to be pinning his hopes not on the law or the facts but on propaganda and political manipulation. This is not a strategy based on inherent strength. On the contrary, it suggests that the President's position is weak and increasingly desperate and that the nation is in for a rough, stormy passage in the weeks ahead.

title: Difficult Questions, Easy Answers

The prose of speculative old men seems, to be much alike in tone, no matter what decade it is written inYeats's On the Boiler and Graves's recent essays: the sentences short and choppy, yet seemingly chosen out of thousands of short sentences that went floating by in the mind, the mood without selfpity, the language without longing for rhetoric and peacock tails. title: If I Had the Wings of a ClingCling Back to Jamaica I'd Fly

No shirt, no undershirt, just a naked white body protruding from overalls and ending in a mustachioed head. I rise in my seat and notice an odd. assortment of people in casually bohemian attire milling about in the aisle now that the Fasten Seat Belts sign is off. I turn inquiringly to my seatmate, who is rather conventionally dressed but evidently loves modern sculpture since he is wearing a piece of it around his neck as a pendant.

title: Renting a Villa in Foreign PartsFrom Home

A spokesman for one of the oldest, At Home Abroad, 136 East 57th Street, New York 10022 (tel: 2124219165), said that generally it costs a lot less for a family or group of friends to rent a villa or an apartment than to stay in a hotel.

title: Solos a Bore to ExBrubeck Drummer

title: How lawyers are proving that mental inmates have a right to treatment
description: For most of history, it has been the fate of those whom we now call the mentally ill and the mentally retarded to bestowed away somewhere, in accord with the adage, out of mind, out of sight. Private hospitals and schools, with comfortable accommodations and attentive treatment, are available to those whose families can afford very large fees. But today, as ever, the less affluent must make do with publicly financed institutions whose main function is to keep their inmatesupwards of half a million peoplefrom getting in the way of society that has pretty much given up on them.

title: When Linus Pauling stops sneezing, it is not like when you and I stop sneezing
description: Ah, those were the days, those were the days when we doctors knew all about vitamins, and the people who stuffed themselves with B and were cranks and food faddists, not Nobel Prize winners! Those were the days, the lovely days, when we could sit round the doctors dining room and tell about examining some nutty woman who was taking 800 units of vitamin E daily, and not have to worry that some colleague across the table would reply that he took 1,600 units and had never felt better. Best of all, in those prePauling days, when some steelyeyed patient fixed us across the consultingroom table and asked if we believed in supplemental vitamins, we could look sympatheticscientific and reel off a bit of vitamin tape from our minds, something to the effect that it wasn't really necessary to supplement a normal diet (And I'm sure you eat a normal diet ), but that if the patient felt better taking vitamins, them.

Certainly, in my own experience, I have never heard so many silly, illinformed comments passed about any other public sculpture in New York.

title: What's Doing in DUBLIN
description: SPECIAL EVENTSAnyone who is ready to leave immediately might just make the tail end of St. Patrick's Day in Ireland. The St. Patrick's Day parade in Dublin is a piddling affair compared with the hooley that goes on in New York and other American cities. Still it's a great day to be in the pubs drowning the shamrock in Guinness and whisky. One of the subjects drinking Irishmen talk about is horses and this year the famous Dublin Horse Show will run from Aug. 6 to 11. The best day for a visit is Friday, Aug. 9, when the international jumping competition takes place, with horses and riders from at least half a dozen nations participating. The wellbred horses bring out the wellbred people and the social highjinks last all week. For prices and ticket information, write to the Irish Tourist Board, 590 Fifth Avenue, New York 10036, or phone

title: Commanders Are Reluctant to Examine Their Crooked Blue Lines
description: In 1961, a burglary ring was discovered in the Denver Police Department. In 1963, city officials and police were indicted in Newport, Ky. In 1966, survey by the President's Crime Commission found that 27 per cent of a sampling of policemen in Boston, Chicago and Washington, D. C., were observed in misconduct situations or admitted to observers they engaged in misconduct. In 1970, testimony in a Federal trial showed policemen in Seattle were receiving at least $144,000 a year from one vice ring. In 1972, the Knapp Commission concluded that corruption was indulged in to some degree by sizable majority of New York police officers. Within the last year, 60 policemen have been indicted in Chicago, 10 members of the 70man police force in Newburgh, N. Y., have been dismissed and charges of widespread corruption have been raised in Indianapolis. And now Philadelphia.

title: Chess:; CHaipsasbtlyanlecaIsLsitvile Still the (aWltheyll)
description: Jose Raul Capablanca (18881942) and his successor as world champion, Alexander Alekhine (1892.1946), stood poles apart in style. A typical Alekhine game evolved into a threeringcircus in which so much happened so quickly the opponent did not know what to expect next. On the other hand, an opponent of Capablanca was all too often deluded into thinking that nothing was going on until resignation became imminent. Alekhine's conjuring of complications reached its ascendancy after World War II, but the Capablanca style was never outmoded  it needed only a Bobby Fischer to revive it. Fischer demonstrated the superiority of bishop over nigh knight with pawns on both sides of the board in winning the fourth game of his match with Mark Tananov in Vancouver ni 1971. In the Orense International Tournament, the American grandmaster Arthur Bisguier also took up the cudgel for Capablanca, pulling off a clean victory against Guillermo Estevez of Cuba that was made possible by the superiority of a bishop in free play over one blocked by its own pawns. What Estevez needed was a sharp freeing maneuver in the opening such as 6 PKR3; 7. BR4, PKN4; 8 BN3, NK5. Instead, his 6 00 led him into a variation of the Queen's Gambit in which his king bishop was misplaced at QN5. With 11 NK5, Bisguier was already threatening 12 NxN followed by the breakup of the kingside with 13 BxN, thus forcing the retreat of the black king bishop. Since Bisguier threatened to set up a classical attacking position with 13 QB3 and 14 PKN4, Estevez had little choice but to exchange minor pieces with 12 NK5.

title: The inimitable shad
description: Today, there is, for better or worse, almost no food on earth that isn't available out of season. One rare and notable exception is fresh shad, shown above, as much a sign of spring as the first jonquil or the robin on the lawn. On America's Bait Coast the first shad comes from southern waters. The fish then makes its way into all the river systems up the coast, including the bright blue Delaware, the Hudson, and the Connecticut Rivers. An elegant way to celebrate the first shad of the season is to prepare it in the, traditional French manner called Doria, which is served with cucumber ovals.

title: Gardens
description: THE DiaLrLY has long been laminar to pr deners In two showy, carefree species Hemerocallis (lava the lemon lily and the tawnyorangeflowered H,. fulva which has osamen from gardens to grow in abundance along numerous country roads. I grow both of these attractive  though spreading:7 perennials of the lily family. The lemon lily is easily controlled at the garden's edge, and the fragrance of its light yellow flowers is welcome in late May. The more aggressive Japanese species is spreading nicely along our lane where it eliminates many undesirable weeds.

title: pear Diary: A Day6yDay Log of Life in a Caribbean Villa
description: Since the winter weather in Kingston,. N.Y., where we live, ranges from miserable to unbearable, I shopped around for an alternate plan. The firit thing did was consult a travel agent, but she net my request for a villa with gales of Daughter. All the places she was familiar with had long since been rented, she said, some as much as a year in advance. Next I learned that not only chuld villas be rented on the spot in the Caribbean through realestate agencies on the various islands but also that there were agencies right in New York that had vacation homes available for rental throughout the world (see box at end of story).

title: Jones and the generals
description: James Jones and this reviewer were fellow privates in the 27th Infantry Regiment at Schofield Barracks, Territory of Hawaii, back before World War II, and since then the reviewer has followed the Jones career with a kind of spiritually proprietary interest. This being the case, it pains me to report that this book is a disappointment. Much of it seems to have been written hastily, and without passionate conviction, pro or con, about Vietnam. As Jones, himself, says: I was cynical about both sides. So I went ahead with my life, and my work, trying to steer between the fanatics.

title: Epilogue
description: note to the Dubcek story that ended with the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia. In a letter reportedly written to the widow of Josef Smrkovsky, a close associate of Mr. Dubcek's during the invasion, Mr. Dubcek said that he and his wife are dishonored and undefended. The letter continued: And it is this, I think, which is the most tragic aspect of all these events. Even my wife has been expelled from the party. Mr. Dubcek told Mrs. Smrkovsky that she could expect the same difficulties that he himself encountered after his mother died 18 months ago. The party repudiated my mother even after her death, Mr. Dubcek wrote. The only official to attend her cremation at the Bratislava cemetery was said to have been the cemetery night watchman. Mr. Dubcek added, When I wanted to inter the urn with her ashes in my native village of Uhrovec, I was asked to do this secretly and without a public gathering. Mr. Dubcek now lives in obscurity as a minor official in the Alexander Dubcek himself has provided a human foot

title: Don't Call Carla's Jazz jazz
description: IN THE midst of the freeblowing, often cacophonic turbulence produced by the jazz avantgarde during the nineteensixties, one consistent oasis for straight ears was the work of Carla Bley (rhymes with hay), young pianist and composer whose melodic and harmonic ideas managed to be a valid part of the musical milieu in which she was working and, at the same time, refreshingly clear and accessible to traditionally oriented listenem. Along with Ornette Coleman, she was the most widely accepted composer to emerge from the jazz avantgarde in those years (and the first woman in all of jazz whose reputation has been made primarily as a composer).

title: The. Best Living English Novelist
description: When Jean Rhys published her first book, a collection of short stories called The Left Bank, in 1927, it came with an enthusiastic preface by Ford Madox Ford. He was presumably rather less enthusiastic about her first novel, Quartet, which appeared the next year. It is the story of a young woman, left penniless when her husband is sent to prison, who drifts into an affair with an older man, egged on by his crushingly understanding and emancipated wife. Writing of The Left Bank, Ford had praised his protegees passion for stating the case of the underdog. It turned out that the underdog heroine had an uncanny eye for the hypocrisies and secret brutality of those on top and an equal gift for expressing, without dramatics, the pain and confusion of her own condition. Ford himself was the model for the novel's unspeak

title: Tennis Camp: Learning to Face Opponents With a Steely Glint
description: YOU are going to a what? a friend asked incredulously. A tennis camp, I repeated, somewhat surprised. If the skepticism had been expressed by nontennisplaying acquaintances, I might have expected that reaction. Coming from a partner who shares my infatuation with the game, I was dumfounded by it. To me, going to a tennis camp seemed entirely logical. After several years of play my forehand was only passable, my backhand erratic, my serve a threat to no one and my volley the result of just plain luck. I was tired of being a baselihe player and ready to charge the net. A,week at tennis ciinp, with four hours daily instruction for five and onehalf days, seemed the obvious answer.'`

title: Summering on Long Island and Going Easy on the Gas
description: OW that the crocuses are popping up and the breezes off the sea are gentler, the annual migration to the beaches of Long Islehd is about ready to get underway. I,o,e;those with families, it isn't an easy earl to make, and this year, aside from thee usual concerns of everescalating rentals and the pressure of crowds, there is the matter of transportation at a time of fuel shortage. For that reason, I'd like to encourage you to cast aside Harnptons chic this year and consider renting on the Great South Bay of Long Island, in one of the villagee that has access to a stretch of the 32 miles of gotleous beach across the bay on Fire Wand. Here, from Bay Shore in the west (ibtint 45 miles from New York City) to Center Moriches in the east, are a score of oncefashionable watering places that are now yearround communities. The ferries across the bay put these villages within easy reach of the beeihes of the Fire Island National Seashote. Often the inhabitantrof the South Shore want to go on their vacations anermay rent their homes for a fraction of.the cost involved in setting up residence in the more rarefied resorts. Indeed, for two summers in a row my husband and I and our two young children, have found a certain cachet in redikOvering western Suffolk County as

title: The Inflation Infection
description: TURIN, Italy  Every European commentator seems to agree that the recent British crisis is part.of a much wider decline of the West. Too many democratic countries are simultaneously a prey to political instability: Britain and Italy, the United States and Belgium, France. and Israel:, The Symptoms of the disease are, the same. everywhere. But all hese nations, and others that show a healthier political setup, share a serious socialandeconomic illness, runaway inflation, and seem to be equally unable to stop it.

I vowed to be trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean and reverent. I, as a Scout, would have integrity.

title: Atlantic Asperity
description: President Nixon's outburst in Chicago against the European allies makes it clear that serious difficulties have again overtaken Secretary of State Kissinger's yearlong flickering effort to reinvigorate the Atlantic Alliance and establish a special relationship with the ninenation Common Market. The vehemence with which Mr. Nixon wielded his bludgeon was apparently designed to pave the way for yesterday's disclosure that he has decided cancel his projected April visit to those allies in Europe.

title: To Dance Again
description: Valery Panov is a Russian Jew and one of the world's great ballet dancers. The Soviet Government has granted him permission to emigrate to Israel but, paradoxically, threatens him with unspecified administrative measures because he refuses to leave without his nonJewish wife, Galena, who is also a dancer. During the long period which the Panovs have struggled with the obdurate Soviet bureaucracy, they have been forbidden to dance in public and been deprived even of proper space practice, a deprivation that is a living death for dancers.

title: Dangerous Arrogance

Young people were drifting about on Saturday, and tourists from the suburbs were, too. SoHo is a good place to begin a walk in New York.

It will bel interesting to hear her, and soon, in a setting in which she is the headliner and has time to work up her crowd for her show. Even at the late show on Saturday, however, with a crowd of Academy denizens who had clearly come to boogie, Miss Bell made her mark.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Once again, Chatham Borough's basketball team frustrated many of its opponents this seasonnot only by winning most of its games, but also by the method used to win. That tactic has been a key ingredient in the school's 60 victories in the last three seasons.

title: Less Is Better
description: The Arab oil producers seem finally to have made official. Their lifting of the fivemonth embargo against the United States removes the proximate cause of the winter's dramatic fuel shortages. But the frailty of the reopened supply lines is underlined by the Arabs declared intention to review this decision next June, on the basis of whether United States policy in the Middle East still warrants their favor.

title: Coed Slain in Huntsville
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., March 18 (UPI)  A man attacked and beat two University of Alabama coeds for no apparent reason here during the weekend. One of them died, and the other, a young symphony violinist, was in critical condition today at a hospital. The police said that Bobbie Ostrander, 19 years old, of Lohman, Mo:, and Jacqueline Zettle, 19, of Florence, the girl killed, had each been beaten on the head with an iron bar but neither had been raped. The fled.

title: Lions of Liberty
description: When the House of Representatives considers a possible impeachment, it acts as a grand jury for the whole nation. In that awesome capacity, the authority of the House is supreme. When busy as it usually with the passage of legislation, its work can be vetoed by the President or reviewed and overturned by the courts. But sitting as the body considering an impeachment, the House is accountable to none but the people at the next election. The Executive and the judiciary have no responsibility save to assist the House as best they can. The Constitution has designated the members of the House for the uniquely serious duty of serving as the lions of liberty. They are to guard against treason, bribery and other high crimes and misdemeanors on the part of those officials who may be subverting the free government they were sworn to uphold.

title: Morse Seeks Senate Seat

The 74yearold Mr. Morse said he had decided to run after the many urgings of the past 60 days from both Democrats and Republicans. He is seeking the seat he lost to Senator Bob Packwood, Republican, who filed earlier as a candidate for reelection.

title: About the Knicks
description: John Gianelli posted a career high of 25 points in the 126114 game the Knicks lost at Los Angeles Sunday, but that didn't cancel out the uncharacteristically weak defense the whole Knick team displayed. Leading the league in defense with a 97.8pointspergame average, the Knicks yielded their highest total of the season to a Laker team that looked depressed and tired for most of the first three quarters. When the Leiters found, at that stage, that they still had a chance after all (trailing 8681), they caught fire, rekindled their playoff aspirations and outplayed the Knicks thoroughly over the last 15 minutes. . The Knicks have looked this way before at comparable stages of a season, and have always prided themselves the ability to turn it on again when the games become important. But one of these days, the careless habits from the nothing game may not be so easy to shed. Earl Monroe is nursing a painful arch and sat out part The Laker game when he couldn't run well. Bill Bradley got a painful belt on the nose early in the Laker game, go along with longerlasting pains in his shoulder and hip, Dave DeBuSschere seems fully recovered from his recent knee problem. The Knicks have four games left, all against losing clubs (Phoenix, Cleveland, Philadelphia and Kansas CityOmaha) and must win two clinch the odd home game for the playoff series with the Bulletsunless, of course, the Bullets lose a couple of their

title: Dance: Alba Articulation
description: When Maria Alba first stepped onto the Kaufmann Concert Hall stage on Saturday night, she received a showstopping ovation, and enthusiasni both off and on the stage persisted throughout the program of Spanish dance. Her, find company danced with a delicacy and attention to detail that made the softest articulation of heel work as clear as the most regally curved back. The singer Simon Serrano and the guitaristcomposer Guillermo Rios provided music with a skillfully restrained passion that made it much more than accompaniIn the evening's new work, Curro Saraya's Yerma, Miss Alba was joined by the American Ballet Theater's William Carter; who was most adept in the barefoot flamenco and gave a performance of great conviction. Miss Alba, however, is too earthmotherly to be totally believable as the barren wife, and the music and choreography, lacking in dynamic change, never really moved beyond the passion of the form to the anguish of Yerma.

title: Portugal Lifts Curbs on Her Soldiers
description: LISBON, March 18  Alert measures confining all military personnel to barracks were lifted today but the crisis persisted within Portugal's armed forces over the long war in Africa.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 18 (UPI)Cambodian rebels today captured Phsar Oudong, a former royal capital 24 miles northwest of Phnom Penh, the military command said. It was the first major town to fall to the Communists in more than three years.

title: Sirica's Finale as Chief On a Day to Remember
description: WASHINGTON, March 184t was another of those remarkable days in the Watergate affair and once again, Judge John J. Sirica was in the middle of it all: He ruled today that he would turn over secret Watergate grand jury report bearing on President Nixon's possible role in the affair to the House Judiciary Committee, which is studying impeachment.

title: U.S. Aide Reports Decrease of 1011% In Heart Disease

title: Wood, Field
description: Countrymen are wont to pity the city dweller whom they regard as trapped in a dismal world of noise and smog, and it is therefore rather ironic that the fierce peregrine falcon, a symbol of freedom incarnate, may make its Eastern comeback in the metropolitan areas.

title: BROWN TRIAL HEARS DEFENSE SUMMATION
description: The defense lawyer, summing up in the murder trial of Henry S. Brown, said yesterday that the police left that someone had to pay for the killing two years ago in the East Village of Police Officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie. And the lawyer, Gerald Lefcourt, added: Why not Henry Brown?

title: About the Yankees
description: The Yankees reportedly are working on at least two separate trades, one of the minor variety, one possibly major. The latter could involve the Minnesota I'wins and another club. Jerry Moses didn't make the trip to St. Petersburg, for which he had been scheduled, and there was speculation he was involved in a deal. But. the catcher said he was ill and rejoined the club in Lakeland. Celerino Sanchez also stayed behind nursing a leg ailment. Bobby Murcer was the only nonpitching regular who remained home. He'll spend his workout time primarily taking batting practice, although his record of six hits in 14 exhibition times at hat indicates he has his timing.

description: Joseph Monty, former chief investigator for the Queens District Attorney, was sentenced] yesterday to an indeterminate term not to exceed four years for having received free use of Avis cars as bribes.

description: A coed was raped in a dormitory at the Bronx campus of Fordham University Sunday night, within yards of the resident adviser's room. Her assailants, one of them armed with a shotgun, apparently entered and left within 80 yards of a manned security post, but they escaped detection.

The sponsor of the bill, Representative Paul A. Schneiders, Democrat of Canton, called it a back door way to force communities to assess property at 100 per cent of value.

title: Trial on the Discharge of Ore Wastes Into Lake Superior Is Nearing Completion

title: Call of Conscience
description: In calling on President Nixon to resign as an extraordinary act of statesmanship and courage, Senator James L. Buckley has aligned himself with a broad spectrum of opinion that places the nation's interest above partisan loyalties. The crux of the Senator's message is that only by stepping down now can Mr. Nixon serve the interests of the Presidency. This appeal diametrically opposed to the view propounded by Mr. Nixon that he must cling to his office in order to save the Presidencya view he reiterated last night in rejecting the Buckley plea.

title: Bingham Urges Controls
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)  Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, called on Congress today to extend wage and price control legislation beyond the April 30 cutoff date. Mr. Bingham,decrying reports that a lapse of the present controls after April 30 is a foregone conclusion, said inflation is raging in the United States and controls are the best way to handle it.

title: Capistrano Hails Swallows
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19 (UPI)Mission bells pealed, a crowd of 10,000 cheered and 150 swallows flew back to Capistrano on schedule today. For more than 175 years the migratory swallows have returned to the old, mission, built in 1776, to reclaitt their nests on St. Joseph's Day.

title: MAX KASE IS DEAD; SPORTS EDITOR, 75; Broke Basketball Fix Story for JournalAmerican
description: Max Kase, sports editor of The New York JournalAmerican for 28 years who broke the story of the basketball fix scandals in the nineteenfifties, died yesterday at the age of 75. He suffered a heart attack at his Yonkers home and was pronounced dead at Yonkers General Hospital.

It takes the form of public acknowledgment by Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave of Dublin's recognition that Northern Ireland is within the United Kingdom and that the status of the province cannot be changed except by a decision of a majority of the people Northern Ireland.

Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, in their brief presidential campaigns. (In the last two cases, the money returned to Gulf.)

Some fans, as usual, took the change calmly; others did not.

description: Louis I. Kahn, whose strong forms of brick and concrete influenced a generation of architects and made him, in the opinion of most architectural scholars, America's foremost living architect, died Sunday evening, apparently of a heart attack, in Pennsylvania Station. He was 73 years old.

title: Shippers Ask Court to Bar I.C.C. Truck Fuel Charge

title: Mets Rout Reds In Quiet Rematch
description: St, PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19Far from Shea Stadium and the riotous playoff of six months ago, the New York Mets defeated the Cincinnati Reds on a sunny little field in Florida today with no pennant at stake and no grandstand mob on the rampage.

title: Suffolk G.O.P. Chief Being Investigated By U.S. on a Pressurefortoan Charge; By MARY BREASTED
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is investigating the Suffolk County Republican leader, Edwin M. Schwenk, for possible violations of Federal extortion and interstate commerce statutes, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Help! Wanted: Hero or Heroine
description: CLOSTER, N. J.Two traumatic events are booked for spring. One, we may have to face up to an impeachable President, and, two, we will probably witness the destruction of Babe Ruth's homerun record. If we expect to get out of the season comfortably, we had better find someone to show us the way.

title: CAMBODIAN FORCE REPORTED RINGED; 1,200Man Unit Said to Be Bombarded by Insurgents
description: PHNM PENH, Cambodia, March 19 (UPI)A 1,200man Government force trying to retreat from a captured provincial capital northwest of Phnom Penh has been surrounded by insurgent troops and subjected to heavy mortar fire, reports from the field said today.

title: Attempt to Portray Cali Deaths As Possible Suicides Is Rebutted
description: NEWARK, March 19 (AP)A prosecution witness in the doublemurder trial of Robert D. Petrarca refused today to go along with defense attempts to portray the deaths as possible suicides.
