title: GOVERNOR OFFERS BANKING MEASURE; Bill Would Allow Offices of OutofState Units Here on Reciprocal Basis; FOREIGN FREEDOM CITED; Propoal Seeks to End Rule That Places U.S. Banks at Competitive Disadvantage
description: ALBANY, March 19Governor Wilson and the State Banking Department introduced legislation today that would allow outofstate banks to do business in New York and New York State banks to operate in other states.

title: T.W.U. Starts to Present Its Case for Pay Raises
description: The Transport Workers Jnion began presenting its case yesterday for wage increases of at least 21.4 per cent over two years for the city's 37,000 bus and subway workers, whose contract txpires at midnight, March 31. This percentage increase is required to compensate for the erosion of wages by inflation Ind to provide real increases of 2,5 per cent each year of a twoyear agreement, according to John F. O'Donnell, lawyer for the union.

title: Hanagata Stops Billiones
description: TOKYO, March 19 (UPI) Susumu Hanagata, the Japanese flyweight champion, knocked out Rudy Billiones of the Philippines in the third round of a scheduled 10round bout today. The 27yearold Hanagata, the World Boxing Association's No 7 ranked flyweight, stopped Billiones, 31, with a left to the body at 1 minute 23 seconds of the round. Hanagata weighed 116 pounds, Billiones 114%.

title: JAVITS OPPOSES BUCKLEY'S STAND
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Senator James L. Buckley's proposal that President Nixon resign gained no visible converts today among Republican conservatives, brought the Neiv Yorker a stack of angry telegrams and evoked glee in some Democratic quarters.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 20 Arthur Ashe and New Zealand's Brian Fairlie shook off long plane journeys to win firstround matches in the $150,000 American Airlines tennis tournament at the Tucson Racquet Club today. Rod Laver also triumphed.

Greenberg, costumes by Liz Covey, Production stage manager, Gig Cascio. Presented by the American Place Theater, Wynn Handman, director. At 111 West 46th Street.

title: Cost Council Frees Machinery Makers From All Controls
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The Cost of Living Council lifted wage and price controls today from more than 36,000 companies in 20 machinery manufacturing industries with annual sales of $43. billion.

description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)A Superior Court judge ruled yesterday that the police here were discriminating against women in their enforcement of the prostitution statute.

title: Fan Sues Aeros, Howe Over Fight
description: CLEVELAND, March 20 (AP)A Cleveland man is seeking $23,000 damages in a suit filed against William, Dineen, Gordie Howe, the Houston Aeros of the World Hockey Association and the Cleveland Arena. The action filed in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court by William Petroff stems from an altercation during a game at the arena Jan. 30 between the Aeros and the Cleveland Crusaders. Petroff alleged that Dineen, coach of the Aeros, entered the seating area, engaged in a fight with a specta71 for behind Petroff and placed Petroff and his wife in fear and apprehension of their safety. The suit also alleges that Howe, the Aeros star right wing, left the ice, entered, the spectators area in full hockey gear and struck Petroff from behind deliberately, maliciously and with great force and violence. The Cleveland Holding Corporation was, named in the suit because of what Petroff called inadequate precautions to protect spectators from attack and abuse from hockey players and personnel. Howe said after the altercation that Petroff started shoving me, so I took him.

title: TV: Cavett's Show WithRadicals and a Rebuttal
description: Tonight at 11:30, the American Broadcasting Company will finally unveil the postponed Dick Cavett Show, featuring four celebrities left over from radical protest movements of the nineteensixties. The original show is intact. But for balance, evidently sought by the A.B.C. legal department, an extra halfhour, without commercials, has been tacked on to afford rebuttal time to spokesmen for the political right. The result brilliantly proves the old showbiz maxim that two bads don't make a good.

title: Films: Thieving Midgets:The Cast
description: If you're old enough to recall some of the off-color versions of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, then "Little Cigars," the mildly comic film adventures of a conniving well-stacked blonde who leads a carnival troupe of small-time, thieving midgets into big-time crime, might be your after-dinner pleasure. But like its likable midgets, the comedy-melodrama that opened at local theaters yesterday, unfortunately, rarely measures up to its king-sized intentions.Angel Tompkins, as the double-dealing damsel on the lam from a mobster she has bilked, is, of course, not averse to latching onto Billy Curtis and the other midget "Little Cigars" in his troupe in order to avoid her pursuers. Thereafter, naturally, it's one caper after another, until the big one and the ultimate double-cross.It's not really a double-cross because, it turns out, Miss Tompkins loves Mr. Curtis as much as moneyto the accompaniment throughout these hectic holdups of a series of one-liners in four-letter dialogue that are not terribly funny. As Mr. Curtis sardonically observes, "You get mixed up with midgets, there's no way you're gonna do anything big."

title: Ethiopia's Throne AllPowerful No Longer

A few hundred yards away, on the grounds of the Grand Palace, peasants in homespun white cotton wait to present petitions and express loyalty to Our LordEmperor Haile Selassie I.

title: Screen: 'The Super Cops' Arrives:Film Depicts Real-Life Batrman' and 'Robin' The Cast Drug Pushers Chased by Determined Duo
description: "The Super Cops," this week's only new cop film, is based on the story of David Greenberg and Robert Hantz, the two New York City policemen who became known, not always fondly, as Batman and Robin because of their pow-bam-smash adventures fighting drug pushers in the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant. It opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters.The nicknames define the comic-book style of the film, which was written by Lorenzo Semple Jr., and directed by Gordon Parks, and is played, mostly super cute, by Ron Leibman (Greenberg) and David Selby (Hantz).The movie is escapist sociology: rather silly but not boring. Its pace is set by the big beat of Jerry Fielding's soundtrack music, which scores the flights, pursuits and last-minute escapes, including one in which the two intrepid cops are rescued by a wrecking ball that is demolishing the building they're standing on.As in "Serpico," the villains of the film are not really the hoods and drug pushers but the other cops, who are either corrupt or lazy.In "The Super Cops" this corruption is hardly more than a plot device, something to impede what otherwise would be the immediate rise to success of the two ambitious policemen. The movie, however, is fuzzy on details and so inconsistent that, at the end, when Greenberg and Hantz are being promoted, I couldn't help wondering how they made it in the face of all the departmental opposition.At one point in the film, the real Detectives Greenberg and Hantz show up playing crooked cops. Which makes me wonder even more. If one is a cop who isn't on the take, one can always sell his story to the movies. It has become one of the residuals of honesty.

From such prices, understandably, the less fortunate have turned aside.The Harvard Club is burning artificial logs made of wax and compressed sawdust.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: TRENTON, March 20 (AP)A Federal Court judge here has refused to issue an injunction ordering seven major oil companies to increase gasoline supplies in Ocean County, which embraces the Jersey shore communities. But the judge also refused to dismiss the case. Judge Clarkson Fisher ruled yesterday that the emergency that existed when the suit was filed by the Ocean County Board of Freeholders on Feb. 1 had passed, but he denied a request from Exxon that the complaint be dismissed and set hearing for June 3, noting that he would advance the date if another crisis arose in the meantime. The county contends it needs more and the oil companies are shortchanging local dealers by not meeting Federal allocation requirements. The oil companies deny the allegation. Ten companies were originally named in the complaint, but Sun Oil, American Oil and Citgo have yielded to the county's demands. Besides Exxon, the other companies are Mobil, Texaco, British Petroleum, Shell, Gulf and

description: DETROIT, March 20  The General Motors Corporation, citing an improvement in car sales, announced today that it was canceling scheduled layoffs that involved 27,000 workers at seven plants over the next two weeks, and ending plans to shut down those plants temporarily.

title: U.S. SAYS SCHOOLS MISUSED MILLIONS
description: An audit by the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare has accused the New York City school systern of improper use of $28million in Federal funds from 1965 to 1972 and has asked that the money be returned or made up.

title: Pro Standings Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: City Opera: 11 Barbiere
description: II Barbiere di Siviglia, given its remarkable score and perfect libretto, ought to be just about foolproof. But both the foolish productions of Rossini's masterpiece currently available to New Yorkers in their leading opera houses demonstrate otherwise. The season's first performance of The Barber at the City Opera on Tuesday night was a special type of misfortune because it put on stage an excellent cast of singers and then trapped them there like flies in an old candy box.

title: A Strong Pitch for Obedience Training
description: By WALTER R. FLETCHER

title: Cosmos No. 636
description: MOSCOW, March 20 (AP)The Soviet Union today launched Cosmos 636, an unmanned earth satellite, the official news agency Tass reported. Cosmos has been used as a name for a wide range of Soviet space missions, from collection of weather data to tests of multiple.target missiles.

title: GULF TRIMS PRICE FOR HEATING ES
description: The Gulf Oil Company yesterday announced reductions in the prices of heating and residual fuel oils, kerosene and jet fuel. Gasoline prices were unchanged.

title: Notes on People
description: The black comedian Godfrey Cambridge used to get mileage out of a routine in which he offered a rentawhite service to blacks having difficulty making white cab drivers stop to pick them up. But, on Dec. 5, 1969, Mr. Cambridge charged, he had the unfunny experience of being dragged more than a dozen blocks by a taxi after the driver had refused to take him as a passenger.

title: Ranks With Political Ties Get Large Share of State Deposits
description: TRENTON, March 20One of William E. Marfuggi's last official acts as Treasurer in the Cahill administration was to certify a report listing the commercial banks and savings institutions in which the state was carrying $232.8million in tax receipts and other revenues.

title: MAN GUNS SEEN VOIRICAL ROLE
description: TEL AVIV, March 20The epwup in Syrian artillery atcks on the territory captured the Israelis during the Ocber war is viewed here as a political use of military power. In the opinion of qualified nirces, who declined to be eptified because no official ssessment of the reasons for le increase in Syrian shelling ver the last two weeks is big made public, the Syrian uns are firing more for intrnal political reasons and international diplomatic effect than to attain a military objective. The shelling is not regarded as a prelude to a resumption bf fighting on the Golan Heights front. However, officials have not ruled out the risk that the stepup of the barxages, if accomloanied by Isneli casualties, could bring an

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES; (In U.S. Dollars) Price In dollars are valid only for stocks eccompanlod by Validation Certificate.
description: AUTHORITY BONDS*

title: NIXON IS REBUFFED ON SCHOOL AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today, by a vote of 170, a $22.5billion bill to extend for four years, major Federal aid programs for elementary and secondary education.

title: FRAUD PROSECUTION OF TWO IS DROPPED
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (AP)  The fraud prosecution of two former Penn Central executives accused of diverting more than $100million from America's biggest railroad is being dropped by District Attorney F. Emmett Fitzpatrick.

title: Afets Win as Tams 3Point Shot Fails
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 20  In 10 previous games, the New York Nets had taken the measure of the Memphis Tams nine Times. Tonight in the Nassau Coliseum the Nets posted victory No. 10, but only by one shot, 103101.

title: BONN BIDS EUROPE GIVE U.S ACCESS TO POLICYMAKING
description: BONN, March 20West Germany is discussing with its eight Common Market partners a proposal to answer American complaints that Europe does not consult Washington adequately before making important decisions.

title: PUPIL SHIFT BARRED IN NORTH BRUNSWICK
description: TRENTON, March 20  The state Department of Education here has barred the North Brunswick School Board from unilaterally withdrawing 10th, kith and 12th grade students from the. New Brunswick High School next September.

title: Islanders Tie Penguins On Goal by Stewart, 14
description: PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP)Ralph Stewart scored his 20th goal of the season with 7 minutes left in the last period as the New York Islanders salvaged a 11 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Sudanese Reported Set to Try Terrorists in Death of Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)  After more than one year of legal maneuvering, the eight Black September terrorists who killed three diplomats last March will be tried in the Sudan, American officials reported today.

title: Your Evil Embargo; Our Purity of Purpose
description: LatinAmerican countries regard as proof of our economic imperialism.

title: Consumer Notes
description: First you could buy appliances in department stores, then discount stores, then catalogue stores and now you do not need any stores at all, Telephone discount buying of large appliances and TV sets has suddenly become popular.

title: DR. LULA WOODS GARST
description: Dr. Lula Woods Garst, a retired physician who was on the staff of the Catawba (Va.) Sanatorium for Tuberculosis for more than 40 years, died Tuesday in Lewis Gale Hospital, Roanoke, Va. She was 77 years old. Dr. Garst, a graduate of Westhampton College of the University of Richmond and of the Medical College of Virginia, also of Richmond, served her internship at Bellevue Hospital here. She was one of the first woman physicians in Virginia. A brother, Robert E. Garst of New York, a former assistant managing editor of The New York Times, survives.

title: BONN BIDS EUROPE GIVE U.S. ACCESS TO POLICYMAKING
description: BONN, March 20West Germany is discussing with its eight Common Market partners a proposal to answer American complaints that Europe does not consult Washington adequately before making important decisions.

title: Nassau Hospital Head Bowing Out Under Fire but Undaunted
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., March 17He watched it grow, the tallest building in Nassau and Suffolk, with its gleaming new operating rooms and sparkling patient quarters, stretching 19 stories above the plains of Long Island.

title: MOSBACHER OUT AS RACING CHIEF
description: ALBANY, March 20Governor Wilson today announced the resignation of Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the $75,000ayear chairman of the state's new gambling superagency. Mr. Mosbacher's appointment has been the subject of politicians envy since it was made by former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller six months ago.

title: ED PLATT CHIEF IN GET SMART, 58
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 20 (AP)Ed Platt, who played the Chief on the Get Smart television series with I bon Adams, was found dead in his apartment yesterday. His lage was 58. The police said he had apparently died of natural causes.

title: Islanders Tie Penguins On Goal by Stewart, 11
description: PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP)Ralph Stewart scored his 20th goal of the season with 7 minutes left in the last period as the New York Islanders salvaged a 11 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: POPE SEES FATHERS OF ISRAELI P.O.W.'S
description: ROME, March 20Pope Paul VI, in a formal address to the fathers of two Israeli soldiers held by Syria, called today for a speedy exchange of prisoners of war and for reconciliation in the Middle East.

title: FAKE PREDICTOR ESTED BY SOVIET
description: Using a portable generator diet can allegedly drive a currant of many millions of kiloNyatts through the earth, Soviet scientists hope to identify in advance the time, place and magnitude of impending earthquakes.

title: U.S. Industries Net Off 47.9% in Quarter
A RENTRISE PLAN
description: The City Council, heeding Mayor Beame's suggestion voted unanimously yesterday to extend for five years the rent stabilization program, which limits rent increases on lease renewals in about 275,000 apartments here.

title: INSURER SPEEDING MEDICAL RECORDS
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in a major innovative step, disclosed here yesterday that trained company clerks would soon be taking basic medical data from new insurance prospects with the aid of a tabletop device developed for the insurer by the General Electric Company.

title: Most Futures Prices Off in Slow Day
Kennedy Accepts InvitatiorI To Visit the Soviet Union
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy has acepted an invitation to visit the Soviet Union next month, his office said today.

title: A Gunman in Stockholm Holds Out in an Embassy
description: STOCKHOLM, March 21 (AP) A Frenchspeaking gunman invaded the Belgian Embassy today, took a secretary hostage and handcuffed her to a sofa on the third floor. Then he demanded that his child be returned to him from Belgium and that he be allowed to explain everything on television.

title: Kenneth Chorley, ExPresident Of Colonial Williamsburg, Dies
description: Kenneth Chorley, who associated with the late D. Rockefeller Jr. in the restoration of Williamsburg, the 18thcentury capital of the Virginia Colony, and became president of Colonial Williamsburg, died yesterday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Skillman, N.J.

title: Music: Ozawa Firebird
description: Any good conductor knows what a major orchestra can do and how to get it to perform up to the top level of its ability. A few superior conductors are somehow able to seduce an orchestra into playing better than it knows it can, and knows what to do when such transcendental accidents take place. Seiji Ozawa, the Boston Symphony Orchestra's music director, had his musicians operating beyond even their own lofty levels at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night, to the benefit of Mozart's Piano Concerto in A (K. 488) and Stravinsky's Firebird.

title: Democrats Scored By Common Cause On Election Reform
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)Common Cause, a citizens group advocating public financing of elections, accused the Democrats today of stalling electoral reform.

title: Abba Eban's Mother Dies
description: LONDON, March 21, (Reuters) The mother of Abba Eban, Israel's Foreign Minister, died here today after a long illness. She was in her 80's. Mr. Eban flew here from Washington yesterday.

title: Britain to Turn Her Lights Up on Sunday
description: LONDON, March 21  The lights in Piccadilly Circus, extinguished five months ago with the onset of the national energy crisis, will be turned on again Sunday; with the rest of the lights in Britain, under a Government directive issued today.

title: Report Charges Conniving For Lottery Bonus Prizes
description: TRENTON, March 21Three state lottery ticket agents who knew the winning numbers before their unsold tickets had to be returned won four station wagons  each filled with $500 in groceriesDduring a special bonus program last summer, a state report charged today.

title: Pope Sees a Modern Parallel Between Mary and Feminists
description: Pope Paul VI has called for increased devotion by Roman Catholics to the Virgin Mary, declaring that such action is fully in keeping with the modern women's rights movement and the search for Christian unity.

title: KAROL BACILEK,CZECH LAID PURGETO STALIN
description: VIENNA, March 21 (AP)Karol Bacilek, a former Czechoslovak police chief who made sensational disclosures that Premier Josef Stalin of the Soviet Union masterminded the trials of Prague leaders in, the nineteenfifties, died Tuesday at the age of 77, the Czechoslovak News Agency, C.T.K., said today.

title: An Oasis of Green In Need of Rescue
description: Much of the grass is worn away. The ground is packed hard as concrete. The trees are dying and the duck pond is a bed of mud and crumbling rock. It is overused, trampled upon, neglected, disrespected and abused. Like aging courtesan, once blooming and the pride of fine company, it has grown worn and withered and past its time.

title: Conferees Agree on Federal Pay Base Of $2 an Hour May 1 and $2.30 by 76
description: WASHINGTON, March 21A HouseSenate conference committee agreed today to increase the Federal minimum wage for most workers in manufacturing and retail jobs from $1.60 an hour to $2 as of May 1. The minimum would rise again to $2.10 on Jan, 1 and $2.30 a year later.

title: Garment Union Locals Told To Reopen Contract Talks
description: The president of the Inter, national Ladies Garment Workers Union, Louis Stulberg, directed all affiliates of the 428,000member organization yesterday to reopen their current contracts and seek wage adjustments to compensate for the sharp costofliving rises in the last year.

title: COURT HEARS PLEA ON MIRANDA RULING
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The Supreme Court has been told that any relaxation of its 1966 Miranda ruling would seriously threaten a criminal suspect's right against selfincrimination.

title: Percy Has Raised $135,000 To Explore Presidential Bid
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, has raised $135,000 to finance his exploration of prospects for Presidential bid in 1976.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Severe reservations about the effectiveness of the sixyearold Ghetto Medicine program were voiced by top city officials yesterday as the Board of Estimate reluctantly approved contracts covering $6.8million in services provided to the poor by 30 voluntary hospitals. Council President Paul O'Dwyer and Controller. Harrison J. Goldin voted in favor of the contracts but made clear their feeling that the program had departed from its intended purpose financing new or expanded health services to residents disadvantaged neighborhoods. Instead, they contenaed, the money is being used merely to help erase the hospitals general deficits.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were estimated at $906million, up 7 per cent from last year's $845million. Total retail store sales were about $9.6 billion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $9.2billion.

title: Shaper of Ideas
description: Ideas change society; architecture changes the visible, functioning environment. Occasionally, one man's creativity spans both; and the way men build to express their emotional and physical needs is never quite the same again. Louis Kahn was such a man.

title: Notes on People
description: Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger announced yesterday that President Nixon had taken the rare action of moving to give a general's star posthumously to an Air Force officer who was said by the North Vietnamese to have died while a prisoner of war. The officer was Col. Edward B. Burdett, who was shot down in 1967, The ,Pentagon said that remains purported to be those of Colonel Burdett were handed over to United States officials in Hanoi on March 6. This is the first case in the war in Vietnam of promotion to general after death, although there have been many instances of posthumous promotion to other ranks

title: KerrMcGee to Expand
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 21 (AP)The KerrMcGee Corporation plans 50 per cent expansions of its Wynnewood, Okla., refinery, and Trona, Calif., chemical plant.

title: 2 Lawyers Charged In an Effort to Bribe Judge With $25,000
description: Two Brooklyn lawyers were arrested yestettlay and charged with attempting to pay $25,000 bribe to a State Supreme Court justice to get him to fix the case of a man indicted for attempted murder.

title: The Times Appoints Wark An Assistant News Editor
description: The appointment of Thomas E. Wark as an assistant news editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by. Seymour Topping, assistant managing editor. Mr. Wark, who is 39 years old, has been an assistant national editor.

title: T.W.A. IS RECALLING LAIDOFF WORKERS
description: KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP)  Trans World Airline said today that it was recalling furloughed flight attendants and mechanics, adding that planned layoffs of pilots had been reduced.

title: Ethiopian Premier Selects 30 to Confer On Charter Reform
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 21 (Agence FrancePresse)Premier Endalkachew Makonnen of Ethiopia announced today that 30 experts would take part in a conference to revise the 1955 Constitution as a result of a recent decision by Emperor Haile Selassie.

title: Dr. Gerald Sinnott, Headed Jersey City Medical Center
description: CUTCHOGUE, L.I, March 21 ,Dr. Gerald W. Sinnott, who retired 10 years ago as administrator of the Jersey City Medical Center, died Saturday in Eastern Long Island Hospital, Greenport. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 21Ken Rosewall, the 39yearold Australian, provided the chief interest today in a $150,000 tennis tournament here before he.was upset by Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 6.4, 6.4, in the third round tonight. Rosewall, competing in his first international tournament in four months, rallied to eliminate Ross Case, his 22year old countryman, 4.6, 76, 6.2, with a string of 15 straight points during the day.

title: People and Business
description: Howard W. Blauvelt has been named president of the Continental Oil Company. The position has been vacant since 1972, when John G. McLean, 56 years old, was elected chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Woman Slain on Far Rockaway Street
description: A 21yearold woman, on her way home after working late, was shot and killed Wednesday evening by an unknown assailant along a quiet residential street in far Rockaway, Qinens.

title: DC10 Study Ordered
description: Federal officials ordered yesterday an analysis of whether major design changes are needed on DC10 jumbo jetliners. Page 77.

title: Amex Stock Index Declines 0.22 as Trading Drops
India Restricts Students in Effort to End Violence
description: PATNA, India, March 21Two thousand students have been confined by the police to dormitories on the university campus here as part of an effort to end the violent demonstrations that have erupted in Patna and other cities of Bihar state in the last few days.

title: Man, Bride Found Dead; MurderSuicide Is Seen
description: NEW CASTLE, N.Y., March 21Richard A. Neiss, a Yonkers businessman, and his young bride were found dead last night in their $150,000 Chappaqua home an apparent murder and suicide, according to police and medical officials.

title: Wilson Plan Weighed
description: Governor Wilson's proposed reciprocal banking bill is receiving a cool response from officials in three of the four states affected by the measure.

title: S.E.C. SETS HEARING FOR CASE ON ZERKIN
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today public hearing of staff charges of violations of Federal securities laws against Max Zerkin and Associates, Inc., a registered brokerdealer in a nearby Maryland suburb, and its president, Max Zerkin. No date was set.

title: 2 DIE IN OUTBREAK OF LASSA FEVER
description: A renewed outbreak of Lassa fever has occurred in Nigeria, claiming two lives and generating intensive efforts to cope with the deadly and baffling viral infection.

title: end of Oil Embargo Arrives Too Late To Save the Winter Season in Florida
description: MIAMIAlthough the termination of the Arab oil embargo brightens the outlook for tourism in the United States for the rest of the year, the full flow of gas will not resume in time to salvage Florida's important winter season, which traditionally ends on Easter Sunday: At a time when no vacancy signs are usually lighted around the clock and the queue at the snake farm turnstile normally stretches half a block, business has been off about 25 per cent.

title: Ailing Pompidou Absent
description: PARIS, March 22 (AP)President Pompidou skipped a dinner for members of the diplomatic corps tonight because of what official medical sources described as a case of hemorrhoids.

title: Impeachment Politics May Cost Nitze Pentagon Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Six weeks ago it appeared but certain that Paul H. Nitzi a former Deputy Secretary Defense, would be appointee to a high Pentagon post. No it appears that Mr. Nitze ha become a casualty of impeach ment politics.

title: Dr. Joseph Bram, Taught Sociology at Hofstra, 69
description: BALDWIN, L.I., March 21 Dr. Joseph Bram, professor emeritus of sociology at Hofstra. University, died yesterday in Brunswick General Hospital, Amityville. He was 69 years old and lived at Prospect Street.

title: Record Farm Pay May Lift Food Costs
description: TRENTON, March 21East Coast farmers have agreed to the largest pay increases in 25 years for their Puerto Rican contract laborers in justcompleted wage negotiations.

title: Monaghan, ExPolice Commissioner, Is Cited for Perjury in LoanSharking
description: Former Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan was described in an indictment here yesterday as an active participant in a loansharking scheme in which one victim was threatened with being thrown from the 18th floor of the Commodore Hotel.

title: Cost of Living Council Lifts Price Controls on Metals
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The Cost of Living Council today removed price controls from manufacturers of ferroalloy metals. It maintained wage controls in the industry, however.

title: BRITON IS CHARGED IN ROYAL AMBUSH
description: LONDON, March 21A 26yearold Londoner was charged and held without bail today in the attempted kidnapping of Princess Anne and her husband, Capt. Mark Phillips.

title: Montana Acts to Guard Its Water Supply
description: HELENA, Mont., March 15The Montana state government has fired the first shot in what is expected gradually to become a major battle beween energy producers and food producers over the West's most vital natural resourcewater.

title: A Presidential Primer on How to Use the TV Medium
description: Prsident Nixon's present campaign to win public support through television, as exemplified by his two most recent news conferences only five days apart, is being regarded by many in the communications field as primer on the effective use of the medium by one with almost unlimited access to it: They pointed out that both appearances were before gronps whose sympathies for the President were assured in advancethe Executives Club in Chicago last Friday and the National Association of Broadcaateis in Houston on Tuesday and, their appreciation of the PreSident, indicated by their exuberant applause for his Most emphatic statements, may well have impressed television viewers that Mr. Nixon was scoring telling points on every issue.

title: U. S. Aid to Nixon Estates Put at $17Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Government spending on President Nixon's private estates in California and Florida is now put at $17million, with $7million representing personnel costs, according to a confidential report approved today by the House Government Operations Subcommittee.

title: PROF. JOSEPH TYNAN OF CITY COLLEGE, 91
description: Joseph L. Tynan, emeritus professor of English literature at City College, died Wednesday at the Woodland Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. His age was 91.

title: Sarafan Appointed Racing Board Head
description: ALBANY, March 21 Governor Wilson moved quickly today to still the controversy over the State Racing and Wagering Board by appointing Bertram D. Sarafan, a veteran government official, as the new chairman and by cutting the job's salary by almost 30 per cent, to $55,000 a year.

title: What Does It All Mean?
description: WASHINGTONTo a society that takes pride in political candor and directness, the current ConfuciusBeethovenLin lab fury in China is hilarious.

title: BURGER IS SILENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has maintained a judicious silence in the face of press commentary on the Supreme Court and its leadership, but elements of the American Bar Association have taken up the cudgels for him.

title: COURT OF APPEALS SAYS JURY REPORT CAN GO TO HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 21. The United States Court of Appeals here refused today to prevent a secret grand jury report on President Nixon from going to a House impeachment inquiry.

title: Tams Lose
CANDY DARLING DIES; WARHOL SUPERSTAR
description: Candy Darling, the transvestite performer who appeared in films and on the stage, died yesterday of cancer and pneumonia at the Columbus Hospital Division of the Cabrini Health Care Center. Candy Darling was 26 years old and lived at 79 First Avenue in Massapequa Park, L. I.

title: Reed Is Given a Passing Grade
Increase of 1.5% Here Is One of Highest in the Last 25 Years
description: Consumer prices in the New York area, rose 1.5 per cent in February, one of the highest monthly increases in 25 years, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Red Smith Hang a Towel Around Their Necks
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 21The Fifth Street Gym is one narrow flight up from the dazzling sunshine of South Beach, the subtropical slum at the lower tip of this sand bar. Close your eyes as you enter, and you can imagine yourself back in Stillman's when that sylvan retreat still ornamented New York's Eighth Avenue. The sights and sounds an smells at the top of the stairs are no different from those of the Passayunk Gym in Philadelphia, the Clark Street Gym in Chicago or the Main Street Gym in Los Angeles, but the Fifth Street Gym is Sports busier than most. That is because Miami of Beach is home base for Chris Dundee, whose weekly shows keep boxing healthier here The Times than anywhere else this side of Los Angeles. Lou Gross was watching with little interest while a man with a tufted chin sparred with a kid in a yellow Tshirt with 133d Battalion across the chest. That's Mat King, Lou said, the black guy. A 10round fighter. The kid's an amateur.

title: A CUT IS ORDERED IN SCHOOL STAFFS
description: Irving Anker, Chancellor of the city school system, has ordered District 26 in Queens to eliminate 38 teaching positions and seven supervisors in an effort to reduce a $700,000 deficit in the district's budget.

title: Thurmond to Run in 78
description: GREENWOOD, S. C. March 21 (AP)Senator J. Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, announced today that he planned to seek reelection in 1978. I think what counts is how a man feels, his mental and physical, said the 71year old Senator. He was in Greenwood following the birth yesterday of his third child. He was elected to his first term in the Senate in 1954.

title: Screening City Judges
description: Until the State Legislature sets up an appointive method that mandates use of a screening commission, mayors and other elected officials are free to decide for themselves how much they will or will not rely on bar associations and on impartial panels of their own before naming or renaming judges. In New York City the Mayor has the authority to appoint Criminal Court, Family Court and Civil Court judgesa procedure that once was based primarily on the advice and consent clubhouse leaders.

title: The Skies Didn't Fall in L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21Senator Alan Cranston is running for reelection this year, and although no serious opposition is in sight he and his men are taking no chances. They recently commissioned a statewide poll and, just as expected, it showed that Cranston was highly favored by his fellow Californians.

title: New Yank Pitcher Traded to Phillies
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies acquired a righthanded pitcher, Ed Farmer, from the New York Yankees today fora cash settlement or a player to be named by April 6.

title: Iowa Couple Fight to Regain Children Taken Summarily in 1969
description: DES MOINES, On June 20, 1969, after a 20minute visit by a county probation officer to the modest home here of Charles and Darlene Alsager, the couple's six children were rounded up in the back yard without prior notice, taken without a court order and placed in the Polk County Juvenile Home.

title: Dance: Joffrey Ballet's N.Y.Export Is a Smash
Bodies of Six P.O.W.'s Arrive on the West Coast
description: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 21 (AP)The bodies of six servicemen who died in captivity in North Vietnam arrived here today, military officials said..

title: N. J. Police Cashed Trot Bets
description: A decorated police lieutenant and an acting detective, both on the Hoboken, N. J., force, admitted yesterday they had cashed superfecta tickets for a former convict who is a coconspirator in the Government's harness racefixing trial.

title: Money
Rise of 10% in a Year Is Worst Since Korea New Orders Climb
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Consumer price inflation worsened again in February, bul there was further evidence that the slowdown in production and employment may be mild, Government reports disclosed today.

title: Europe's New Initiatives
description: New initiatives from Britain and West Germany this week provide hope of combating the trend toward disintegration within West Europe's Common Market and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND SETS TAKEOVEROFBRINCO
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, March 21 (Canadian Press)The Newfoundland Government will take over Brinco, Ltd., and proceed with development of the hydroelectric power potential of the lower Churchill River in Labrador, Premier Frank Moores said today.

title: GLADYS ROSS CHAUVIN
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., March 21  Mrs. Gladys Ross Chauvin, former executive secretary of the Alice Chapin Adoption Service, now the SpenceChapin Adoption Service, and director of special services of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, died in a nursing home yesterday. She was 81 years old.

title: Millers Hold Top Golf Spots
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: MARCH 22, 1974

title: Index Here Increases 1.5% for Month
description: Consumer prices in the New York area, rose 1.5 per cent in February, one of the highest monthly increases in 25 years, United States Bureau of Lebor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: STARS RECEIVES DEANNIXON TAPE; Judge Ordered U.S. Move Illness Adjourns Trial
Music: Bachauer Power
Learning First
description: During the activist nineteensixties the universities were under pressure to come to the rescue of the nation's strifetorn and decaying urban centers. Many higher education spokesmen, in fear of militant attacks, agreed too readily to action programs which, though temporarily popular, held out little hope for practical success. Sociology departments, transformed into social policy task forces, could not make up in enthusiasm for their lack of practical knowledge and experience.

title: STARS RECEIVES DEANNIXON TAPE
description: The judge in the MitchellStans trial has ordered the Government to turn over to the defendants portions of a transcript of a tape of John W. Dean 3d talking to President Nixon.

title: DC10 Study Ordered
description: Federal officials ordered yesterday an analysis of whether major design changes are needed on DC10 jumbo jetliners. Page 77.

title: Inaction on Inflation
description: For American consumers, it is slaughter at the checkout counters and the gasoline pumps. Food and fuel prices soared again in February, giving another big thrust to skyrocketing consumer prices. With last month's increase of 1.3 per cent, the cost of living has climbed 10 per cent in the past twelve monthsthe first doubledigit rate of inflation in consumer prices since the Korean War. As a result, the real spendable incomes of workers have dropped 4.5 per cent below a year ago.

title: VISIT TO MOSCOW BY ASSAD IS SEEN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 21 President Hafez alAssad of Syria is reported planning to go to Moscow Sunday for talks with Soviet leaders before Secretary of State Kissinger arrives there later in the week.

title: Cambodia Sends More Troops As Key Drive Remains Stalled
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia March 21 (UPI)  The Govern ment sent more soldiers north westward today to join troop trying to retake the fallen provincial capital of Phsar Oudong but military sources reporter that all efforts were stalled by heavy insurgent resistance.

title: DR. HELEN PAULSON
description: Dr. Helen Paulson, a child psychologist at the City and Country School, died yesterday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 52 years old and lived at 180 East End Avenue.

title: Law on Rent Stabilization Is Extended for 5 Years
description: The City Council,. heeding Mayor Beame's suggestion, voted unanimously yesterday to extend for five years the rent stabilization program, which limits rent increases on lease renewals in about 275,000 apartments here.

title: New Books GENERAL
description: A Concise History of the Spanish Civil War, by Gabriel Jackson (John Day, $8.95).

title: Dent Opposes Cutting Off Credits to Eastern Bloc
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 21The current threat to cut off ExportImport Bank credits to the Soviet Union, Poland, Rumania and Yugoslavia will serve only to eliminate and prevent expansion of jobs in the United States, Frederick Dent, Secretary of Commerce, said here today.

title: Mady Werner Bride in West
description: DENVER, March 21Miss Mady Jo Werner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney C. Werner of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married here today to Fred W. Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis W. Roberts of Rock Springs, and Cokeville, Wyo. Civil Judge Edward J. Byrne performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The sofa is shabby, the carpet looks worn, the bathroom needs papering, the walls should be painted and the, closets could use a few shelves. Call a paperhanger, a painter, a carpenter and an upholsterer? Of course, if you wish, but life needn't be so complicated.

title: Brown Is Acquitted
description: Henry S. Brown, the reputed Black Liberation Army member, was acquitted last night in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of the murder of two New York City patrolmen in the East Village in 1972. Details, Page 13.

title: 32 INJURED IN FIRE IN OFFICE BUILDING
description: Twelve civilians and 20 fire. men were treated for smoke inhalation last night, and 60 immigration deportees were evacuated, as a threealarm fire swept through two floors of a 15story office building in lower Manhattan, the Fire Department reported.

title: Agency Invites Comments on New Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Federal Power Commission gave a new signal today that it is pressing toward a decision that would mean higher natural gas prices throughout the nation.

title: Advertising: Using Black Media
description: Citing lack of data as an excuse for staying out of black media is an advertiser cop out, a leading black marketing executive said yesterday.

title: Hurok Group Elicits Hope and Concern
description: Sol Hurok's death last month left a gap in America's cultural life wide enough for one of his ballet troupes to dance through lineabreast. The magnitude of the loss was dramatized yesterday.by the decision of the conglomerate that owns Hurok Concerts not to name a presiden,t of the concertmanagement organization to replace the impresario.

title: Maize, Citing Need for a Letter By Auditors, Bars Helme Deal
description: The hoard of the American MaizeProducts Company yesterday decided its plan to acquire Helme Products, Inc. cannot be carried out. The board, which met yesterday to reconsider the acquisition Merger of Helme, said it News could not waive the provision of the acquisition agreement requiring the furnishing of a comfort letter by Helme's auditors. A comfort letter indicates that financial reports will be factual but unaudited and not certified.Earlier this week, Helme announced that indicated profits for Jan. 1 to Feb. 24, 1974 showed earnings of about $17,000, or I cent a share, on sales $14.84milion, against profits of $279,000, or 16 cents a share, on sales of $16.62million for the yearbefore period.

title: The Pop Life
description: Stevie Wonder, who will appear Monday at Madison Square Garden for his first American concert performance since his nearfatal automobile accident last August, has clearly reached a turning point in his young career.

title: American Hoechst Plans Plant in Texas
description: The American Hoechst Corporation, a subsidiary of West Germany's giant Farbwerke Hoechst, A.G., announced here yesterday that it would build a large petrochemical plant in Port Arthur, Tex., at an initial cost of $100million.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The finals of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association basketball tournament begin tonight with 14 teams competing for seven championshipsfour public and three parochial.

title: CommunicationsBase Pact Signed by Australia and U.S.
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 21 (UPI)The United States and Australia formally signed a new agreement today giving Australia more control over operation of the North West Cape communications base in Western Australia.

title: The Waves and the. Tides
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Something's going on here besides the Impeachment proCess. The peach blossoms are out on Florencio Olguin's tree in our kitchen garden. George Shultz is leaving the Treasury, but the tulip trees outside his executive palace are opening up from purple to pink. Even at the.White House, which is the central battleground of our politics, the grass is now emerald green, the boxwood is billowing with buds under the white columns, and the star magnolias are flowering on the first day of spring.

title: Scandinavia Tightens Hold on Welfare Costs
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 8  Sweden, Denmark and Norway have resisted any retreat from the welfare state despite serious election setbacks last year for their Socialist parties. But government and opposition parties are subjecting the welfare state's institutions and practices to closer critical scrutiny than ever.

title: G.O.P. TACTICIANS LOOK AT GABRIELLI
description: ALBANY, Mar. 21Republican sources said today that speculation over the possibility that Associate Justice Domenick L. Gabrielli of the Court of Appeals might run as the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor had reached the point where he could have it, if he's willing to leave the bench.

title: RICHARD OKAMOTO
description: Richard Okamoto, a freelance writer and editor who had served in World War II with the Office of War Information and, later, in Army Intelligence in Austria, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 150 West 82d Street. He was 53 years old.

title: W. L. Boyle Jr. Weds Mrs. Ahrendt
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 21Mrs. Sarah Roberts Ahrendt, widow of Douglas E. Ahrendt, was married here this afternoon to William L. Boyle Jr. of New York, a vice president of the Council for Financial Aid to Education. The ceremony in the Methodist Church was performed by the Rev. Paul L. Sartorio.

title: Contract Awards
description: Compagnie Generale d'Electricite announced in Paris yesterday that it had received a $44million contract from the public utility district Of Chelan County, Wash., for the supply of eight generators of 54 megawatts each for its Rock Island, Columbia River, hydroelectric power plant.

title: MOBIL ASSAILS A.B.C. FOR SHOW ON OIL
description: The vice chairman of Mobil Oil assailed the American Broadcasting Company yesterday for what he called vicious, inaccurate, irresponsible, biased and shoddily researched reporting on a recent A.B.C. News CloseUp that focused on the oil shortage.

title: Mirthful Theater Pierces South Vietnam's Gloom
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March. 21One of the few sources of laughter in this capital, fatigued by war and disenchanted with the peace that is on paper but not yet at hand, is the audacious concatenation of eternal themes, classical Chinese crooning, modern rock rhythms, old China scenery, JerryLewismugging, double takes, screeches, pratfalls and offstage explosions that make up the South Vietnamese popular theater.

title: Business Briefs
description: Alcan Aluminium, Ltd.. indicated yesterday that an early decision would be made authorizing the construction of new aluminum smelter facilities in the SaguenayLac Saint Jean region of Quebec.

title: LIBYAN SAYS U.S. MADE OIL THREAT
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 21 (Reuters)The Libyan Minister of Petroleum, Izzidin alMabruk, said here today that other Arab oilproducing nations had been prepared to maintain their embargo against the United States but had decided to lift it only after threat from Washington.

title: BEAN APPROVES MENTAL CENTER
description: A $14million mentalhealth center to serve the impoverished South Bronx, a project that was quietly abandoned during the last year of the Lindsay administration, after the foundation was laid, will be built as a result of a decision by Mayor Beame to reverse his predecessor.

title: Gross Denies Knowledge Of Any Illicit Fund Raising
description: NEWARK, March 21 (AP) Nelson G. Gross, the former Republican state chairman, emphatically denied at his conspiracytax fraud trial today that he knew of an illegal fundraising scheme during Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: About New York Orchids to Alston Harris
description: Alston Harris got a medal from City College yesterday. Mr. Harris works in the boiler room of City College, but he got the medal for looking after things on Convent Avenue. He plants shrubs there, tells people to curb their dogs, and sometimes hangs signs saying things like, Say good morning to your neighbor.

title: Orr Scores 3 Goals as Bruins Win
A Plant to Convert Garbage Into Fuel Planned for Harbor
description: A resource recovery center that would buy garbage from the city and convert it to fuel for sale is being proposed by a private company that wants to build the center on a 225acre island of garbage in New York's lower harbor.

title: A SUBPOENA SEEKS MORE NIXON FILES
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, disclosed today that he had subpoenaed additionaltiouments from the White House files.

title: Trager, Professor at Brooklyn Law, Is Reported Choice for U.S. Attorney
description: David G. Trager, a professor at Brooklyn Law School, is expected to be nominated as the new United States Attorney for the Eastern District, reliable sources said yesterday.,

title: 6. ALLEGED PIMPS CITED IN TAX CASES
description: Federal tax indictments were announced yesterday against six alleged procurers who were charged with failure to pay income taxes on the proceeds of prostitution.

title: Discharged Korean Veteran Wrongly Held as Deserter
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., March 21 (AP)Michael A. Kinney, who returned home this week after 18 months in the Army in Korea, ended up in jail mistakenly charged with desertion.

title: Recycling Incentive Is Urged
description: TRENTON, March 21 (AP)A state environmental council proposed today that the state sales tax be removed from certain unspecified recycled goods as an incentive to recycling. The New Jersey Solid Waste Advisory Council made the proposal as a means of coping with the problem of refuse disposal. The council is an advisory body to the Departments of Environmental Protection.

title: KISSINGER NOTES DIFFICULT PERIOD IN U.S.SOVIET TIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Secretary of State Kissinger said today that relations between the Soviet Union and the United States had entered a more difficult period but that on his forthcoming visit to Moscow he would try to keep alive the policy of relaxing tensions.

title: Leone Says Rate of Return on Deposits Will Be Main Guide in Choosing Banks
description: TRENTON, March 21 Richard C. Leone, the State Treasurer, said today that New Jersey intended to make the rate o return the prime/ criterion for allocating deposits of tax money and other revenues to banks.

title: F.A.A. Orders Wide Study Of DC.10 Jetliner's Design
description: The recent Paris crash that killed 346 persons has prompted Federal authorities to order an urgent Government analysis of whether major design changes are needed on DC10 jumbo jet airliners.

title: Agriculture Agency Barred From Farmer Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)President Nixon today revoked permission for the Agriculture Department to inspect income tax returns of farmers as part of its statisticsgathering operations.

title: LUFKIN GIVES UP CONNECTICUT RACE
description: HARTFORD, March 21Dan W. Lufkin of Newtown, an early favorite to win the Republican nomination for Governor of Connectcut, bowed out of the running today, citing personal considerations.

title: Job Interviews Held Behind Bars
description: TRENTON, March 21 They sat together uneasily today in a welllighted classroom at the Trenton State Prison, a handful of businessmen and five inmates soon to be released.

title: Consumer Prices Rose 1.3% Last Month in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Consumer price inflation worsened again in February, but there was further evidence that the slowdown in production and employment may be mild, Government reports disclosed today.

title: THOMAS P. O'HARA POLITICAL WRITER
description: Thomas Patrick O'Hara, will for many years had been one this city's leading political re porters, died last night of can cer at his home, 144 Guyon Avenue, Oakwood, S. I. He was 60 years old.

title: 3 Inmates Seize Federal Prison Guards
description: Three armed inmates at Federal Detention Headquarters in lower Manhattan were holding two prison guards and the guards chief supervisor hostage early today after a commotionfilled revolt that drew dozens of Federal agents and police officers with shotguns and bulletproof vests to the area.

title: Rodino Scores Plea For a St. Clair Role In Inquiry by House
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that the White House bid for an adversary role in the impeachment inquiry could turn the House proceeding into a fullscale trial and thus usurp the Senate's constitutional role as the sole judge of President Nixon's conduct in office.

title: Brown Is Acquitted
description: Henry S. Brown, the reputed Black Liberation Army member, was acquitted last night in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of the murder of two New York City patrolmen in the East Village in 1972. Details, Page 13.

title: STEEL CAPACITY RISE PLANNED BY LUDLUM
description: PITTSBURGH, March 21Richard P. Simmons, the president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, said today the company planned a major expansion of its steelmaking capacity to meet growing demands in the next 10 years.

title: MoneySaving Suggestions Pay Off
description: Samuel K. Michael spends most workdays at a grinding machine in the Middletown, Conn., plant of the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Aircraft Corporation. Yesterday, however, he was in New York to receive a certificate from the National Association of Suggestion Systems as his company's suggester of the year, along with a dozen winners from other companies.

title: Arctic Proposal
description: OTTAWA, March 21A group of American and Canadian corporations formally applied today in Ottawa and Washington for permission to build a 2,625mile pipeline that would tap the naturalgas reserves of the Arctic. Their action raised the curtain on what is expected to be a prolonged controversy.

title: Upper Ski Resort Areas Get a Big Bonus  Snow
description: Another heavy snowstorm the second of the weekyesterday provided upper New York and New England resorts with their best skiing conditions in two seasons. As much as one foot of snow dropped on many of the areas.

title: Pope Sees a Modern Parallel Between Mary and Feminists,
description: Pope Paul VI has called for increased devotion by Roman Catholics to the Virgin Mary, declaring that such action is fully in keeping with the modern women's rights movement and the search for Christian unity.

title: Mrs. King Gains With Miss Casals
City Morgue Aides Barred From Work For Funeral Homes
description: In a decision apparently designed to prevent socalled body snatching by funeral homes, the Board of Ethics rules yesterday that employes of the Medical Examiner's office could not work also for funeral directors.

title: Key Crime Witness And His Wife Killed By Nevada Gunman
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 21 (UPI)A shotgun blast in dark hallway yesterday killed a gambling figure, John Dubcek, who was expected to testify against a Mafia chieftain and others, His wife was also killed.

title: CHARLES W. CARVIN
description: HILLSBORO BEACH, Fla., March 21  Charles W. Carvin, who retired in 1968 as head of the New York fabricdistributing company of his name, died Tuesday in Boca Raton. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: Going Out Guide
description: IDS AND KIDS The lecture at 8:30 tonight at the New York Academy of Sciences, 2 East 63d Street (8380230), may not tell you how it all ends, but it will fill a piece of the hole in the longrunning, perhaps eternal generationgap business. Dr. Leo Spiegel, president of the New York Psychoanalytic Association, will deliver a paper, Youth Culture and Psychoanalysis, one that he had previously given for the trade at a professional meeting. Dr. Spiegel is an author who has written about late adolescence and even a book of psychoanalytic poetry.

title: ORDERS UP AGAIN IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods rose in February for the second consecutive month after the larg automobilerelated decline in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Miss Sills Electrifies Crowd
description: Champagne glass in hand, Beverly Sills was beaming as she spun gracefully through the crowd on stage in the first act of La Traviata. She was doing what theater people call bits of businessflirting here, laughing there, sharing a toast with someone on the side.

title: The New York Times Sunday, December 2, 1973 Mother's Day Will Be a Little Late This Year
description: JEAN EUSTACHE'S The Mother and the Whore may well be the most important film of 1973, yet it still does not have an American distributor, despite the fact it won the Special Grand Jury Prize at Cannes last spring. And it is very likely that American audiences won't have a chance to judge the film for themselves until late next year, if at all.

title: SPORTS COMPLEX SET FOR MIDTOWN
description: A major new sports complex that will include 11 indoor ten; nis courts, three iceskating rinks, four squash courts, a health club and related facilities Is scheduled for midtown Manhattan.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Second Man In Minnesota Kidnapping
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 21 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a second man here today in connection with the kidnapping of Eunice Helen Kronholm, the agency said.

title: Rodino Scores Plea For a St. Clair. Role In Inquiry by House
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that the White House bid for an adversary role in the impeachment inquiry could turn the House proceeding into a fullscale trial and thus usurp the Senate's constitutional role as the sole judge of President Nixon's conduct in office.

title: 31 Arrested in Drug Raids Over Falsified Prescriptions
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP)The arrest of 31 persons broke up a citybased drug ring that took in $800,000 through illegal narcotics sales and falsified prescriptions over the last nine months, the police reported,

title: Record Farm Pay In East Is Expected To Lift Food Costs
description: TRENTON, March 21East Coast farmers have agreed to the largest pay increases in 25 years for their Puerto Rican contract laborers in justcompleted wage negotiations.

title: Two Oil Experts Say Major LongTerm Energy Problems Remain
description: Two of the world's leading oil experts indicated yesterday that euphoria over the end of the Arab embargo was unwarranted and that major longterm energy problems still faced the United States and other countries  problems that threatened international economic and political stability.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KosherChinese a Feat and a Treat
Curbs on Press Shield British Suspect
description: LONDON, March 21If someone had tried to kidnap Julie Nixon Eisenhower on Park Avenue, and had been arrested after shooting her chauffeur, two policemen and a reporter, it is safe to say that within a day or two a lavish portrait of that someonecomplete with childhood reminiscences, opinions, proclivities, food habits and pronouncements by publicityminded psychiatristswould have been splashed through the press.

title: Nixon Makes Fund Request
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)President Nixon asked Congress today for a supplemental appropriation of $85million for the Labor Department and $6.4million for the Civil Aeronautics Board for the fiscal 1974s and 1975.

title: Boston College, Utah Advance in N. I.T.
Rise Is $535Million
Slippage Continues in Prices of Bonds
U.S. Swedish Rift Ends As Envoys Are Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 21President Nixon named Robert StrauszHupe today to be the new United States Ambassador to Sweden, ending a 15month diplomatic freeze lyetween Stockholm and Washington.

title: Fashion's Family Gathers to Mourn and Honor Anne Klein
description: In a great outpouring of affection and respect, store presidents, seamstresses, models and designers packed the Frank E. Campbell funeral home yesterday to pay final respects to Anne Klein, who died Tuesday at the age of 51.

title: INSTITUTIONS WIDEN STAKE ON BIG BOARD
description: The percentage of shares. listed on the New York Stock Exchange that are owned by institutions rose slightly in 1973, to an estimated 31.4 per cent from 30.8 per cent the year before, the exchange announced yesterday.

title: BRIBERY OF JUDGE LAID TO 2 LAWYERS
description: Two Brooklyn lawyers were arrested yesterday and charged with attempting to pay $25,000 bribe to a State Supreme Court justice to get him to fix the case ,of a man indicted for attempted murder.

title: Carey Sees No Chance of Early Abortion Change
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., March 21  Representative Hugh L. Carey, a Democratic gubernatorial contender and a prominent Catholic layman, predicted today that a proposed Federal constitutional amendment banning almost all abortions would not be approved by Congress in the near future.

title: Nadjari Asserts Proposed Budget Cut Of $650,000 Will Hurt Inquiries Badly
description: ALBANY, March 21  Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, said today that budget cuts of $650,000 recommended by the legislative fiscal committees would hamstring his investigations.

title: $650 Reward Offered For Park Zoo Vandals
description: The Society for Animal Rights yesterday offered a $650 reward for information leading to the arrest of those who attacked five fallow deer in the Central Park Zoo two weeks ago. One of the deer died later.

title: COURT OF APPEALS SAYS JURY REPORT CAN GO TO HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The United States Court of Appeals here refused today to prevent a secret grand jury report on President Nixon from going to a House impeachment inquiry.

title: Schools Closed by Flu
description: SHELBURNE, Vt., March 21 (AP)  School officials have closed four of the six schools in the Chittenden South School District for the remainder of the week because of an outbreak of influenza.

title: KISSINGER NOTES DIFFICULT PERIOD IN U.S.SOVIET TIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Secretary of State Kissinger said today that relations between the Soviet ,Union and the United States had entered a more difficult period but that on his forthcoming visit to Moscow he would try to keep alive the policy of relaxing tensions.

title: Long Road to Trotters Paying Off for Spencer
description: YONKERS, March 21It was way back in the days of the Mineola Fair that Fred Spencer first had his chance to drive harness horses. The program used to feature what was called the matinee club and Spencer fulfilled a boyhood urge by competing in the nonbetting and unrecorded events.

title: BRITON IS CHARGED
description: LONDON, March 21A 26yearold Londoner was charged and held without bail today in the attempted kidnapping of Princess Anne and her husband, Capt. Mark Phillips.

title: Anker Links Fund Audit To Move to Cut U.S. Aid
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that a Federal audit accusing the city system of misusing $28million in Federal aid coincides with and appears calculated to reinforce an effort now under way in Congress to reduce Federal aid to disadvantaged pupils living in urban areas.

title: Gasoline Exemptions For Handicapped Due
description: ALBANY, March 21The state's Emergency Fuel Office announced today that procedures had been set up for the physically handicapped to apply for exclusion from the oddeven regulations on gasoline sales.

title: Yugoslavia Accuses Italy Of Violating Trieste Accord
description: BELGRADE, March 21 (Reuters)  The Belgrade Government has accused Italy of attacking Yugoslav sovereignty and territorial integrity in part of Trieste.

title: Move to Cut State Arts Budget To $19Million Brings Protests
description: State arts leaders vigorously protested yesterday a proposal by the fiscal cornmittee of the Legislature that would cut Governor Wilson's recommended budget of $30.5million for the Council on the Arts by more than onethird.

title: A SUBPOENA SEEKS MORE NIXON FILES
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, disclosed today that he had subpoenaed additional documents from the White House files.

title: IRISH BILL ERASES BAN ON BIRTH CURB
description: DUBLIN, March 21  A bill to permit the sale of contracep tives, but only to married couples, was introduced in the Irish Parliament today. Under the bill only pharmacies could

title: Bridge: Spring Nationals Opening In Vancouver First Time
Litvinov, in Rome With Family, Indicates He Will Go to the U. S.
description: ROME, March 21Pavel M. Litvinov, a grandson of one of Stalin's Foreign Ministers and a dissident who was allowed to leave the Soviet Union early this week, arrived here today and said he needed some time to think.

title: LowKey Black Meeting
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  The second national political meeting of black Americans, held here last weekend, was considered a success by many participants, not so much for what took place as for what did not. The meeting was almost entirely without the flair and fire of the first meeting two years ago in Gary, Ind. Missing was the soulstirring rhetoric that proved to have so little substance. Missing were the controversial issues that left deep divisions after the Gary meeting.

title: Mishaps on Penn Central Rise
description: The Penn Central Railroad had 1,179 derailments last month because of the seriously deteriorated condition of its roadway and equipment.

title: BROWN ACQUITTED IN POLICE SLAYINGS
description: A State Supreme Court jury. found Henry S. Brown not guilty last night of charges that he murdered Police Officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie on Manhattan's Lower East Side two years ago.

title: Soviet War Hero Renounces Citizenship
description: MOSCOW, March 21 (Reuters)A former Soviet Army colonel with several wartime decorations formally renounced his citizenship today and handed back his medals, expressing his protest at official refusals to allow him to emigrate to Israel.

title: Howard Leland Smith, 80, Dies; Skyscraper, Bridge Architect
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Howard Leland Smith, an architect who supervised the design of early Manhattan skyscrapers and bridges, died Tuesday of pneumonia in Canandaigua, N. Y. He was 80 years old.

title: SHORT INTEREST ROSE FOR MONTH
Flames,
Books of The Times
description: In yesterday's column, I raised some questions about the nature of the evidence Studs Terkel gathered by tape recording 130 people talking about their jobs. Were they telling the truth? Did they know the whole truth about themselves? Is Working an accurate picture or one more instance of the intellectual's tendency to translate the ordinary American into tragic figure trapped by fate?

title: MINNESOTA ACTS TO CUT ABORTION
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 21Despite medical opposition and questions about its legality, Gov. Wendell R. Anderson signed today a bill that prohibits most abortions in Min neiota during the second half of pregnancy.

title: SITE OF REFINERY IS AGAIN STUDIED
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., March 21  Renewed interest in a Gulf Coast site for a $600million refinery planned by a company owned by Aristotle Onassis has been reported following the rejection of the refinery by a small New Hampshire town.

title: Market Place: Polaroid Falls On Wall St.
description: Wall street coma use few more speed readers. Al least, that is one implication of the sharp price plunge yesterday in Polaroid's stock.

title: SPORTS COMPLEX
description: A major new sports complex that will include 11 indoor tennis courts, three iceskating rinks, four squash courts, a health club and related facilities is scheduled for midtown Manhattan.

title: Texaco Trims Wholesale Fuel Price
description: Texaco, Inc., the nation's thirdlargest oil company and the largest seller of gasoline in the United States, announced yesterday a wholesale price reduction of 1 cent a gallon on all its grades of gasoline and residual fuel oil.

title: Schoolboys In Spotlight At Hofstra
description: One team traveled eight hours on a bus from Buffalo, Another was Just down the road in Rockville Centre, Those two and six ether high school basketball teams were going to the Top Eight Classic at Hofstra University this weekend, the closest thing to a New York State tournament.

title: Sports Today
G.M. to Lay Off 300 At New Jersey Plant
description: LINDEN, N. J., March 21 (AP)A General Motors spokesman said today another 300 workers would be laid off at the company's assembly plant here, reducing the work force to 1,900, compared to the approximate 5,000 employed before the gasoline shortage.

title: Renewal Clause Is New Target
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. March 21  While professional football players are preparing picket signs calling for Freedom Howl, their baseball counterparts seem to be moving closer and closer to a historic confrontation that could bring them their freedom sooner than they ever could have hoped for:

title: 2,500 Ducks Found Dead
description: SAN JACINTO, Calif., March 21(AP) Nearly 2,500 ducks have died of a mysterious malady, their bodies found strewn around a dry lake near this Southern California desert community.

title: Patterson Is Appointed United Fund Chairman
description: The appointment of Ellmore C. Patterson as the 1974 general chairman of the United Fund of Greater New York, was announced yesterday by R. Manning Brown Jr., the present chairman.

title: Mayor of Paterson Testifies in Inquiry On Corruption in Highway Construction
description: TRENTON, March 21Lawrence F. Kramer, the former state commissioner of Community Affairs, and Mayor of Paterson, and Betty Kordja, the chairman of the Passaic County Democratic organization, testified here today before a state grand jury investigating alleged corruption involving highway construction in New Jersey.

title: Chinese Revive the U. S. Tiger
description: HONG KONG, March 21In the course of an ideological campaign in China, an ingeniobs piece or polemics is.repeated so often that it seems to acquire the force of inexorable logic. Thus Confucius and the fallen Communist leader Lin Piao have been so firmly linked together as jackals, from the same lair that it causes no surprise when anti4in rallies are staged in front of Confucian temples.

title: Extension on Air Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was giving three large coalfired power plants 16 more months in which to cut air pollution. The extensions were granted to the Arizona Public Service Company's Four Corners plant in New Mexico; the San Juan plant of Public Service Company, of New Mexico; and the Navajo plant of the Salt River Project Agriculture Improvement and Power District, in Arizona.

title: Greensboro: Scalpers Semifinal
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 21The price of college basketball has gone way upto about $150 a ticket for the semifinals of the 36th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: News Summary and Index
Saraf an Appointed Racing Board Head
description: ALBANY, March 21 Governor Wilson moved quickly today to still the controversy over the State Racing and Wagering Board by appointing Bertram D. Sarafan, a veteran government official, as the new chairman and by cutting the job's salary by almost 30 per cent, to $55,000 a year.

title: AUTO OUTPUT DOWN BY 29.8% IN A WEEK
description: DETROIT, March 21American auto plants are scheduled to build 149,722 cars this week, off 29.8 per cent from the yearearlier period but up 24.7 per cent from last week's production.

title: People in Sports Cavaliers Find Winning Can Be a Way of Losing
description: Perhaps despondent over five straight victories that eliminated his Cleveland Cavaliers from a shot at the coin flip for the draft rights to Bill Walton, Coach Bill Fitch was absent without explanation as his squad lost a 10191 decision to the Capital Bullets on Wednesday night at Landover, Md. Jimmy Rodgers, his assistant, did the coaching in Fitch's place.

title: Upper Ski Resort Areas Get a Big BonusSnow
description: Another heavy snowstorm the second of the weekyesterday provided upper New York and New England resorts with their best skiing conditions in two seasons. As much as one foot of snow dropped on many of the areas.

title: Schoolboys In Spotlight At Hofstra
description: One team traveled eighl hours on a bus from Buffalo. Another was just down the road in Rockville Centre, L. I. Those two and six other high school basketball teams were going to the Top Eight Classic at Hofstra University this weekend, the closest thing to a New York State tournament.

title: Wood, Field &
description: If wooden birds could fly, those carved by Gilbert Maggioni and Grainger McKoy would be among the first to take wing.

title: Moderate on Languagei Issue Seeks to Form Belgian Cabinet
description: BRUSSELS, March 21King Baudouin today asked a moderate on the issue of autonomy for Belgium's two language regions to form a new national Cabinet.

title: Witness Gives Petrarca Partial Alibi in Slayings
description: NEWARK, March 21 (AP)A childhood friend of Robert D. Petrarca testified today that he was with her about the time he is accused of murdering a Montclair woman and her daughter.

title: In Defense of St. Clair's Role as Counsel
description: WASHINGTONAs a lawyer, I have been at once saddened and dismayed to read and hear the criticisms that are being heaped upon James D. St. Clair for his defense of President Nixon. It is especially disturbing when these assaults on the constitutionally guaranteed right to counsel come from members of the liberal community.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, Democrat of Gloucester, has. asked Governor Byrne to require newspapers with offices in the State House to pay rent and phone bills. Mr. Gewertz said he would consider filing a suit or introducing a bill in the Legislature if the administration turned him down. He estimated that the free office space and phone service was costing the state $130,000 a year.

title: Nixon to Talk at Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)President Nixon will address next week's Republican SenateHouse fundraising dinner in Washington, the dinner committee disclosed today. The disclosure came when a press notice about next Wednesday's $1,000aplate dinner said reporters would be admitted at the time of the President's speech. There has been no White House announcement that Mr. Nixon would attend the dinner.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Reject Efforts To Ease LowSulphur Fuel Rules
description: Cleanair advocates declared yesterday that the Federal Energy Office had a legal obligation to divert lowsulphur fuels from other regions to the city, and they urged state and city agencies to dismiss bids for the easing of sulphur restrictions.

title: Beame Appoints Dr. Eagle To Health Research Panel
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. J. Frederick Eagle as scientific director of the New York City Health Research Council, which evaluates proposed health research projects.

title: People in Sports
description: Perhaps despondent over five straight victories that eliminated his Cleveland Civaliers from a shot at the coin flip for the draft rights to Bill Walton, Coach Bill Fitch was absent without explanation as his squad lost a 101.91 decision to the Capital Bullets on Wednesday night at Landover, Md. Jimmy Rodgers, his assistant, did the coaching in Fitch's place.

title: Estate Outlay Expected to Top 17Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 The tally of Government spending associated with President Nixon's private estates in California and Florida is likely to be even higher than the $17million reported yesterday by the House Government Activities Subcommittee, officials on Capitol Hill said today.

title: Of Crime and Punishment: A Bronx School Version
Nixon at Camp David; Radio Talk Set Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)President Nixon flew to his Camp David mountaintop retreat in Camp David, Md., today, and the White House announced that he will make a live radio broadcast to the nation tomorrow on education legislation.

title: MILTON GOLDBERG, RETAILER, 64, DIES
description: Milton H. Goldberg, a merchandising consultant and former senior vice president of Bloomingdale's department store, died yesterday, after suffering a heart attack at his home, 203 West Shore Road, Great Neck, L. I. He was 64 years old.

title: FRENCH QUESTION ARABS OIL POLICY
