description: PARIS, March 22  Foreign Minister Michel Jobert, has warned the Arab oil countries that they must treat all European consumers equally if they want special links with Europe.

title: Bonn Pact Makes U.S. Hopeful NATO Will Share Troop Costs
description: WASHINGTON, March 22For the first time in many months the Nixon Administration has gained confidence that it can obtain adequate support from its European allies to share the costs of maintaining 315,000 American troops in Western Europe, officials said today.

title: Charles Gulbrandsen, 83, Muralist and Scenic Artist
description: Charles Gulbrandsen, muralist and scenic artist who retired in 1969 from the Columbia Broadcasting System, died yesterday. He was 83 years old and lived at 3316 86th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: ' CasualRelations' and 'Princeton' on Bill
description: Impatience dwells a long way from outrage, and boredom never was a substitute for shock. Mark Rappaport's "Casual Relations," whose two-day run ends today at the First Avenue Screening Room, is supposed to be outrageous, but it's no more stimulating than one prolonged shot of a pitcher and a basin.The movie yields a vague patchwork of preoccupations: a young woman dreams at monsters and wakes exhausted, a man suffers through a bad trip, another woman watches television all day long, a couple lunches one year after their separation, there's a very dull murder in a swamp, a chap who likes newsreels of catastrophes gets his knee fondled in a movie theater, a typist in an office recalls a threatening dream, and an amateur photographer admires one photograph in a gallery.A woman who does nude modeling also performs in stag films and a vampire picture. Both are filmed with such enthusiasm that you suspect that these were the movies that the director really wanted to make. But his vampireswho move as slowly and stiffly as limbs in plaster castsseem like forlorn traitors to their class.A puff for Princeton on the same bill has been mysteriously nominated for an Oscar. But it seems more like a fund-raising kit than a documentary. "Princeton: A Search for Answers," by Julian Krainin and DeWitt Sage Jr., mocks the seriousness of teaching and learning when we're given only little scraps of lectures, ranging from "Man is an animal" equipped with "a mind which has a passionate lust to know" to "Nobody really knows what a galaxy is like." Scholars are poorly served when their work is presented as a slick collage.Outside of one fine reading of "Measure for Measure" and a chorus rehearsal for Bach's B minor Mass, the professors and students appear desperately conscious of the camera. There's some further gargle about "the place of man"ah, man"in the scheme of things," plus praise for "the diversity of opinion" cherished at Princeton. Evocations of the arts and shots of Frisbees and a number of young blond persons fail to characterize the institution in any way that might distinguish it from any other leafy university.

title: 4% Air Fare Rise Allowed As C.A.B. Cites Fuel Cost
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, blaming a precipitous rise in the price of jet fuel, authorized the nation's domestic airlines yesterday to raise fares 4 per cent on April 16.

title: MEETING PLANNED ON GRACE CHURCH
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission said yesterday that it planned to set up a meeting between preservationists and officials of Grace Church in an attempt to resolve the controversy concerning the church's plans to demolish a row of houses on Fourth Avenue that constitute part of its gothicrevival grouping.

title: Brownstein Named as the Judge In Lawyers Alleged Bribe Plan
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irwin R. Brownstein was identified by authoritative law enforcement sources yesterday as the judge to whom two lawyers allegedly tried to pay a $25,000 bribe to fix an attemptedmurder case.

title: Wiretap Data on Muskie's Plans Reported Sent to White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 22At least one of 17 wiretaps authorized by President Nixon for national security reasons provided the White House with political intelligence about the Democratic Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, according to sources who have seen written summaries of the overheard conversations.

title: Dissident Lutheran Seminarians Are Approved as Parish Interns
description: Sr. LOUIS, March 22The Council of Presidents of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod has decided to allow dissident students from Concordia Seminary to serve as parish interns but has refused to recognize their seminary in exile.

title: 4 HOSTAGES FREED AT U.S JAIL HERE
FRENCH QUESTION ARABS OIL POLICY
description: PARIS, March 22  Foreign Minister Michel Jobert has warned the Arab oil countries that they must treat all European consumers equally if they want special links with Europe.

title: Threat to Historic Structures Adds to Dispute on Tocks Dam
description: MILLBROOK,.N. J., March 22  The presence of many old and possibly historic buildings scattered across the area to be flooded by the proposed Tacks Island dam on the Delaware River has added to the controversy over the project.

title: Notes on People
description: There has to come a time when one clearly has to give it up and hand it on to someone else, said Sir Alec DouglasHome, British Prime Minister in a Conservative government in 196364, in announcing he would quit politics soon. Sir Alec, a Scottish nobleman who gave up the 14th earldom of Home to sit in the House of Commons and become Prime Minister, is 70 years old. He said yesterday he would not run for the Commons again if another Tory candidate could be found for his Scottish seat before the next election. In view of the uncertainty of the duration of the minority Labor Government, the betting is that there will be another election within 12 months. Sir Alec, first elected to the Commons in 1931 (his father was the 13th Earl and still alive then), was Foreign Secretary in the last

title: Fiscal Trustees Assigned To Queens School District
description: Irving Anker, the city's School Chancellor, appointed two trustees yesterday to supercede the authority of a community school board in Queens on financial matters.

title: Appeals Court Sends Evidence on Nixon Back to Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Watergate grand jury's secret report on President Nixon, locked in its briefcase, was carried back today from the Court of Appeals to Federal District Judge John J. Sirica's chambers to be ready Monday for delivery to the House of Representatives.

title: Douglas Aircraft Holders Of Bonds Win Data Suit
description: A United Slates District Court judge ruled here yesterday, in a closely watched classaction lawsuit, that prospectus issued by the Douglas Aircraft Company in 1966 offering $75million in debentures contained misrepresentations and omissions of facts.

title: Yanks Shifting Blomberg; Gibson Shelled by Mets
Front Page 2  No Title
WINE TALK
description: Rodney D. Strong is probably the only winemaker in the business who got his early training under George Balanchine.

title: Background of Suspect Is Emerging in Britain
description: LONDON, March 22A fuzzy portrait of Ian Ball, the man charged in the kidnapping attempt on Princess Anne, began to emerge today with the discovery of a house he apparently rented early this month.

title: GOVERNOR SPEAKS TO 2,000 TEACHERS
description: MONTREAL, March 22 Governor Wilson of New York told 2,000 enthusiastic New York State teachers meeting here today that he favored reducing the probationary period before teachers become eligible for tenure from flve years to three.

title: ECONOMIST SEES AN END TO SLIDE
description: WASHINGTON, March 22A top Treasury economist spelled out today the statistical and other evidence supporting the Administration's growing confidence that the slide in the economy would hit bottom this month or next.

title: JAMES C. HIGGINS, 53 INSURANCE OFFICIAL
description: James C. Higgins, executive vice president and a director of Marsh & McLennan, Inc., insurance brokerage concern, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday. He was 53, years old and lived at 114 Slope Drive, Short Hills, N.J.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BERN, Switzerland, March 22 (AP)The United States rink from Superior, Wis., skipped by Bud Somerville, recorded its sixth triumph today in the world curling championships and reached the semifinal round. The Americans defeated Scotland, 82, and will meet unbeaten Switzerland next.

title: The Good Life Passes at 28
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The meaning of 70cent gasoline, $250 electricity bills and 10 per cent mortgages is that the good life is over, kaput, dead. Its obituary follows:

title: Europe's Defenseless Immigrant Workers
description: LONDONFrance now has 3.4 million immigrant workersover 15 per cent of her labor force. They come from Algeria, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Morocco, Tunisia, South Korea, Yugoslavia and black Africa. Most live in slums and a significant number still live in bidonvilles, hastily thrown together, dwellings made of bits of cardboard, corrugated iron, old car doors and wood.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 22Behind him, the tops of the greenish brown mountains disappeared in the clouds. Below, sunlight sparkled on the windows of modern office buildings and autos zoomed along the freeways. In a blue denim jacket as is his manner, Ken Norton was sitting on a terrace today at the Tamanaca Hotel, where he has been staying in his role as the aspirante, the challenger for George Foreman's world heavyweight title. a few hours he would depart to a hideaway in the hills to await Tuesday night's title bout at the Poliedro, a new 13,500seat arena. With its global aluminum roof, it resembles a high spacecraft that landed next to the Rin conada race track where Canonero II once ran. Norton finished his sparring there yesterday but with the fight still several days away, it was a time for words instead of action.

title: Oil Price Rise PosingVast Problems in japan
description: TOKYO, March 22The 62 per cent increase in the price of petroleum products here this week seems certain to add to Japan's already roaring inflation, subtract from her export, competitive power, and multiply the governing party's political difficulties.

title: DRIVE IS STARTED
description: A campaign to raise $40,000 to enable the Metropolitan Opera to continue its free performances in city parks this summer was begun yesterday by City Council President Paul O'Dwyer.

title: Device Lets Disabled Run Machinery
Wiretap Data on Muskie's Plans Reported Sent to White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 22At least one of 17 wiretaps authorized by President Nixon for national security reasons provided the White House with political intelligence about the Democratic Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, according to sources who have seen written summaries of the overheard conversations.

title: Atherton Picked by Nixon For State Department Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)The White House announced today that President Nixon had selected a veteran State Department official, Alfred L. Atherton Jr., to be Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.

title: Volkswagen Issues Warning on Defective Seat Belts
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)  The National Highway Safety Administration said yesterday lap and shoulder belts on some 1968through1972 Volkswagens may be ineffective in a crash because of exposure to battery acid.

title: Soviet Expels Dissident Backer From Moscow to His Kiev Home
description: MOSCOW, March 22 (Reuters)Viktor Nekrasov, the prizewinning Soviet writer who recently declared support for Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the banished author, and Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, was expelled today by the police from. Moscow to his home city of Kiev.

title: 4 HOSTAGES FREED AT ES, JAIL HERE
description: Three convicted bank robbers who attempted to escape from Federal Detention Headquarters in lower Manhattan surrendered shortly before 9 A.M. yesterday and released four hostages unharmed after they had been promised they would not be prosecuted for the escape attempt.

title: Uncle Sam's Army Is Policing Up Its Faults
description: A suggestion was made in the press recently that if the Soviet Union had challenged the American military machine during the recent Middle East crisis, in anything short of nuclear exchange, the American forces would have been severely, if not fatally, mauled.

title: Bonn Denies the Mark Will Be Revalued
description: BONN, March 22The West German Government has no plans to revalue the mark formally. spokesmen said today but Government sources said they felt that the advance of the mark on European money markets this week, caused part ly by rumors of a revaluation, was fully justified.

title: U.S. Designates 2 Areas. For New Sludge Dumping
description: The Federal Government has designated two large areas in the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island and New Jersey within which it will locate one or two sites for the dumping of sewage sludge to replace the present dumping area, which is 12 miles east of New Jersey and 10 miles south of Long Island.

title: Westfield Woman to Head State D.A.R.
description: Mrs. Robert M. Sutton, a 48yearold housewife who does not think of herself as a liberated woman, was elected head of the New Jersey Daughters of the American Revolution in a hotly contested election here today.

title: Brazil's New Chance
description: While emphasizing priority for maintaining the country's spectacular economic development, Brazil's new president, General Ernesto Geisel, has pledged sincere efforts for gradual but sure progress toward democracy. His two immediate.predecessors, also generals, made comparable promises only to retreat under pressure into more repressive measures than ever.

title: Soviet Expels Dissident Backer From Moscow to His Kiev Home
description: MOSCOW, March 22 (Reuters)Viktor Nekrasov, the prizewinning Soviet writer who recently declared support for Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the banished author, and Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, was expelled today by the police from. Moscow to his home city of Kiev.

title: SENATE APPROVES TIGHTER CONTROL OVER THE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Senate unanimously approved today legislation that would revolutionize Congressional procedures for consider ing the Federal budget and setting national spending priorities.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Transport of New Jersey has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to allow a 5 cent increase in interstate bus fares, effective April 14. A Transport of New Jersey spokesman said the fare rise would affect about 50,000 New Yorkbound commuters and about 5,000 Philadelphiabound New Jersey commuters. Interstate fares will remain at 40 cents a ride, the spokesman said.

title: Environmental Approach InEnergyBuilding Urged
description: Russell W. Paterson, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality proposed yesterday an energy program that he said would attain selfsufficiency for the nation and provide for continued economic growth while protecting the environment,

title: People and Business  Lawyer Named Helme President
description: G. Jackson Ratcliffe Jr. was named yesterday as president and chief operating officer of Helme Products, Inc. He succeeds William W. Knauer, who was appointed to the new post of vice chairman. Arthur T. McGonigle continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the candy, snacks and tobaccoproducts maker.

title: Peru Flash Gets Chance In Widener
description: MIAMI, March 22The sign on the gate outside the clubhouse said, Hialeah Wildlife Sanctuary, but Agosto Maggiolo went in anyway, because he doesn't understand English and it looked like a race track to him.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
STIMULATING MUSIC BY GIL EVANS'S BAND
description: Gil Evans's conceit at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening for the New York Jazz Repertory Company series wasviewed simply as a concertone of his better performances of his music. With a much larger band than he usually has 22 musicians including four bassistsMr. Evans's rich layers of sound and his exotic colors were carried on rhythmic foundations that were, even for him, remarkably varied and stimulating.

title: Killing and Mistreating of NationalPark Bears
description: ALBANY, Calif.The rangers are going to kill another bear tonight, a friend told me in a Yosemite restaurant. I didn't believe him. He said that a bear that had caused property damage but no injuries was about to be shot with an overdose of tranquilizer. I thought that rangers would merely move the bear to a wild area.

title: A Mixed Bag of Short Narrative Films
description: Narrative Cinema, Part Two, the program of short, story films that opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art Thursdaythe first series ended a week's stand there Wednesdayagain illustrates the uneven, if sometimes commendable efforts of its varied but decidedly committed filmmakers.

title: 3 Victors Enough for Barrera, But Cordero Finds 4Too Few.
description: Laz Barrera was satisfied with three winners at Aqueduct yesterday, and Ahgel Cordero was disappointed with four. The former, one of the steadiest trainers on the major racing scene, was so confident before the program started that he ventured to say, I ought to win all my races today. All his races meant three, the first, the fourth and the eighth.

title: Pennsy Corrects Figures
description: The Penn Central Railroad incorrectly reported to The New York Times for a news article published in these columns yesterday that it had 1,179 derailments on its trains during February. This was the number of accidents it suffered in January and February. There were 530 derailments in February and 649 in January.

title: People in Sports
description: At last, Marvin Miller and Bowie Kuhn agree on something. Each thinks Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, can direct Henry Aaron to play in the Atlanta Braves opening series with Cincinnati.

title: Sandman's Son Seized On a Marijuana Charge
description: EGG HARBOR, March 22 (AP) (AP)Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s son, Robert, and another youth were free on bond today after having been charged with possession of marijuana.

title: MONROE J. WINSTON
description: Monroe J. Winsten, lawyer here for more than 40 years, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 67 years old and lived at 89 Maple Avenue, Tuckahoe, N. Y.

title: Of Crime and Punishment: A Bronx School Version
description: Police Officer James Sullivan burst into a classroom at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx and rushed over to Bruny Moravcik's seat.

title: High School Notes 200 Weigh Mock Impeachment
description: About 200 students from throughout the East are meeting at Lawrence High School in Cedarhurst, L. I., this weekend for the school's annual GovernmentinAction Conference.

title: capt.Edward H. Molyneux, 79; Dominated Fashions for Years
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 22 (Reuters)Capt. Edward H. Moiyneux, the British fashion designer, died at his home in Monte Carlo today at the age of 79.

title: Music: Busy Leinsdorf
Shapp Vetoes Bill On Death Penalty; challenge Likely
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 22 (AP)A bill to restore capital punishment in Pennsylvania was vetoed tonight by Gov. Milton Shapp.

title: Radio
TV Review
description: A pair of 30minute television documentaries examining unfamiliar aspects of life on two islands, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and remote Bali, make rewarding weekend viewing. Tonight at 7, station WABC will show Don PedroDiary of a People, with the second part continuing next Saturday. Tomorrow afternoon at 1,the parent network, the American Broadcasting Company, will show Bali: Religion in Paradise, the fourth study of Far Eastern religions in the Directions series.

title: Radio
Upstate Town Luring Sunday Trade With a Free Bus
description: COLD SPRING, N. Y.,A group of merchants, proprietors and managers of historic sites in this Hudson highlands area, all heavily dependent on weekend motorists for their trade, have organized a free culture loop bus tour to help overcome the effects of the energy crisis on Sunday driving.

title: Basque Rail Explosion
description: ST JEAN DE LUZ, France, March 22 (Reuters)  A militant group blew up part of the rail line near this Basque townl early today, halting all trains between France and Spain. The police said the Autonomy In tervention Group placed an explosive charge on the track and scattered leaflets. claiming responsibility for the blast.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Sorecho Nalo, described by authorities as the leader of the gang that took $4million in jewelry and cash in robbery at the Pierre Hotel bn Jan. 2, 1972, was arrested and accused of another crimeinvading a Queens home last January and stealing $7,000 after holding two persons at gunpoint. The Queens robbery allegedly occurred while Mr. Nalo was free on $50,000 bail, pending appeals in the Pierre robbery.

title: Art: Looking Back at the W.P A. Days
description: American art in the nineteen+thirties was, like so many other areas of American. life in that decade of ecdriptpic depression and politicaLcrisis, a battleground of conflicting ideologies. Exponents of European modernism vied for attention with painters of the American scene. An art turned inward, concentrating on the most subjective materials, coexisted:with styles aligned with public iSsues and explicit social functions. Id that turbulent and fecund period, American art seemed to expand and contract in almost equal, measure, and we are still I long way from sorting out its really definitive achievements.

title: U.S. Designates 2 Areas For New Sludge Dumping
description: The Federal Government has designated two large areas in the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island and New Jersey within which it will locate one or two sites for the dumping of sewage sludge to replace the present dumping area, which is 12 miles east of New Jersey and 10 miles south of Long Island.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO END ENERGY LAG
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 22William E. Simon, the administrator of the Federal Energy Office, called today or Congres to lift its legislative embargo on the Administration's energy proposals.

title: 7 Nations on Baltic Sign Pact Designed To Cut Its Pollution
description: HELSINKI, March 22The seven countries bordering the Sallie Sea signed a convention today aimed at reducing its alarming pollution.

title: Bonn Plan for Allies to Consult Stirs Little Enthusiasm
description: BONN, March 22The West German compromise proposal on consultations between the Common Market and the United States has reportedly been greeted skeptically by the French, who think it goes too far, and with some reserve by the British, who wonder if it goes far enough.

title: A Lunch and Memories For Doolittle in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, March 22  On Dec. 7, 1941, Lieut. Heijiro Abe and Lieut. Kiyokuma Okajima led their respective bomber and fighter squadrons through the gray dawn to attack the American naval base at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii.

title: Coast Guard Graduates Only AllWoman Class
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., March 22 (UPI)The United States Coast Guard graduated its. firstand lastcompany of women recruits today at its training center here.

title: I Just Got Angry, The Princess Says About the Ordeal
description: GREAT SOMERFORD, England, March 23 (UPI)Princess Anne said today that her encounter Friday with a man seeking to kidnap her happened so quickly that. she did not have time to be frightened, so I just got angry with the attacker, she said.

title: $2.45MILLION ASKED IN SUIT ON COAST
description: San DIEG0, mdrch, 22 (AP) A lawsuit seeks $2.45million from Robert Walter, for mer chairman of the financially troubled United States Financial Corporation and 11 other persons over a 1973 promissory note.

title: Milwaukee Papers Up to 150
description: MILWAUKEE, March 22 (AP) The single copy price or in Milwaukee Journal and Milwaukee Sentinel will increase from 12 cents to 15 cents, effective Monday, Newspapers, Inc., the publishing company; announced today.

title: GROSS ACCUSES 113, IF HARRYING FIRM
description: NEWARK, March 22Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, angrily charged the United States torney's office today with at ing to devastate his law practice by calling his firm's clients all over the state.

title: GROSS ACCUSES U.S. OF HARRYING FIRM
description: NEWARK, March 22Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, angrily charged the United States Attorney's office today with trying to devastate his law practice by calling his firm's clients all over the state.

title: Eximbank Resumes Lending to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The ExportImport Bank announced today that it would resume lending to the Soviet Union and three other countries of Eastern Europe.

title: Fading Prospects Of the NATO Alliance
description: PARISThe North Atlantic Alliance marks its 25th anniversary this spring In a far gloomier atmosphere than had been anticipated. Whatever efforts that were still in the air to produce a gala vanished amid the exchanges of verbal brickbats between the United States and France, which is still loyal to the treaty although quit the NATO military organization More than seven years ago. Now President Nixon, who was supposed to come to Europe as a kind of master of ceremonies, may well cancel his trip.

title: VIETCONG OFFER A DETAILED PLAN FOR VOTE IN SOUTH
description: The Vietcong proposed today sixpoint plan that included detailed provisions for a new ceasefire and the holding of general elections in South Vietnam.

title: INCREASED SUPPLIES OF COTTON EXPECTED
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 22William E. Reid, president of the National Cotton Council, told textile manufactirers today that their supply of cotton would be greater this year than at any time since 1965.

title: Pattern of Deception
description: In his televised remarks from Houston last Tuesday, President Nixon sought again to convince the nation that he was being fully cooperative in supplying information to Leon Jaworski, his special prosecutor in the endless chain of Watergate scandals.

title: Nets Subdue Q's, Take 1Game Lead
COST UNIT BACKS A.M.C.: PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (Reuters)The Cost of Living Council said today it had permitted the American Motors Corporation to raise its base vehicle prices by an average of $50 above the levels to which American Motors agreed last December.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Undefeated St. Anthony's of Jersey City, needing a victory to achieve the best record in New Jersey high school basketball this season, will be in the spotlight tomorrow in the parochial finals of the state tournament. The Friars, who have won 29 games will also bolster a claim to be the top ranking team in the state.

title: Nixon Men Compromise on Amending Clean Air Act
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today a package of proposed amendments to the Clean Air Act of 1970 that would extend several deadlines for abatement of pollutants and in other ways weaken the act under the mounting pressures of energy demands.

title: Screen: othello  Loseth
Market Place : Analysts Rate  Auto Concerns
description: First quarter earnings are likely to be little short of disastrous, David Healy, vice president and director of re search at Drexel Burnham & Co., stated in an analysis of General Motors Corporation common stock last week. Many leading auto analysts agree that not only G.M. but also the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation will report steep declines in their net income for the first three months of 1974.

title: Antiques: Free Appraisal
description: How much is it worth? will probably be the question most often posed first, and What is it? the second, during Sotheby Parke Bernet's appraising bee that opens Wednesday for a fourday run at the galleries, 980 Madison Avenue (at 76th Street).

title: Amex Retreats as Counter Stocks Rise
Fatal Irresponsibility
description: United States safety experts are convinced that the recent crash near Paris of a Turkish Airlines DC10 with 346 deaths, the worst disaster in the history of civil aviation  was caused by the sueking out of an inadequately secured rear cargo door. If that proves the official finding, this tragedy could and should have been prevented for there had been ample warning of the danger.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
St. Anthony's, Molloy Advance
description: Molloy, the New York Catholic high schools champion, and St. Anthony's of Smithtown, the Long Island Catholic champion, advanced to the semifinals of the Top Eight basketball tournament Iast night at Hofstra University.

title: Hertta Elina Kuusinen Is Dead; Finnish Communist Leader, 70
description: Hertta Elina Kuusinen, a Finnish Communist leader who was one of her country's most popular politicians, died Tuesday while on a visit to Moscow. She was 70 years old.

title: Price Changes
description: United Parcel Service, raising its rates for the first time in three years, said yesterday that effective March 30 the charge for each package would be increased 3 cents, and in addition rates per pound would be increased a half cent to 1 1/2 cents.

title: Hale Named Coach At Oral Roberts
description: TULSA, Okla., March 22 (AP)Jerry Hale, coach at College of Southern Idaho for five years, was named had basketball coach at Oral Roberts University today.

title: Russell R. Anspach Weds Ellan A. Metz
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 22Miss Ellen Ashton Metz was married here this afternoon to Russell Roy Anspach, a principal in the New York marketing communications and design firm of Anspach Grossman Portugal. Justice of the Peace Sheldon Coletan performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Gerquest, friends of the couple.

title: Good Bet
description: Governor Wilson appears to have picked a winner his selection of State Liquor Authority Chairman Bertram D. Sarafan to succeed Emil (Bus) Mosbacher as head the State Racing and. Wagering Board.

title: Nixon Aide Charges Media Distortion
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)A White House official said today that The Washington Post, Time magazine, New York Times book and the television networks had committed specific acts of the type President Nixon has called distorted coverage.

title: DOW EDGES AHEAD AS VOLUME DROPS
U.C.L.A. vs. N.C. State: Final Within a Semifinal at Greensboro
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 22Not since 1965, when the University of California, Los Angeles, won the second of its nine National Cgllegiate Athletic Association basketball championships, has anyone seriously doubted the Bruins ability to take the title once they reached the semifinal round of an N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Phillip Morris Accord Set on Soviet T'obacco
description: MOSCOW, March 22 (AP) Phillip Morris, Inc., and the Soviet Government signed an agreement today to cooperate in the production of tobacco products, the Soviet news agency Tass reported.

title: Nixon's Brother Retiring Early; Marriott Austerity Drive Cited
description: WASHINGTON, March 22F. Donald Nixon, a brother of President Nixon, will retire next month as an executive of the Marriott Corporation, a company spokesman announced today. Mr. Nixon has been employed as the organization's vice president for community and industry relations since 1970, when he was hired by J. Willard Marriott. Mr. Marriott, the company's chief executive, has been a close friend and political supporter of Mr. Nixon.

title: TEST HELD VALID FOR NEW BABIES
description: For more than 20 years, the Apgar score has been used to measure the health of babies in the moments after birth. The score, a rating based on five body functions, is used throughout the world to determine whether a baby needs help to sustain life.

title: GUNMAN GIVES UP IN EMBASSY SIEGE
description: An armed Frenchman surrendered early today after holding the Belgian Ambassador's secretary hostage for 14 hours in the embassy here. He said he wanted his 9yearold son returned to him from Belgium, where the boy is in the custody of his mother and stepfather.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACKS PLAN SUIT TO GET F.B.I. FILES
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, president of Operation PUSH (People ,..United to, Saye Humanity), said yesterday that he was calling on other black leaders to join him in a class action suit to subpoena Federal Bureau of Investigation files relating to an F.B.I. counterintelligence program directed at black organizations.

title: CON ED RESUMES BURNING OF COAL
Germans Join in $ 1Billion Pact To Equip a Soviet Steel Plant
description: BONN, March 22A West German steel consortium has concluded a $1billion agreement with the Soviet Union for an iron and steel plant. The agreement is the largest EastWest industrial project since World War II, Economics Minister Hans Friderichs said.

title: Secretary to Hugh Hefner Seized on Cocaine Charge
description: CHICAGO, March 22 (UPI) Federal agents entered the mansion of Hugh Hefner, publisher of Playboy magazine. and arrested his social secretary yesterday on a charge, of conspiracy to distrfibute cocaine.

title: Two Masterpieces Dominate aConcert By Concord Group
description: The Composers Theater at the Washington Square Church is presenting its May Festival this spring, and the series is subtitled 10 Concerts of Contemporary Music. Assuming that one takes the subtitle seriously, the Concord Staring Quartet was a bit unfair in the programing for its part of the series Thursday night, since its concert began with Ives's String Quartet No.2 (1907.1913) and ended with Berg's Lyric Suite (1926).

title: Peru Flash Gets Chance In Widener
description: MIAMI, March 22The sign on the gate outside the clubhouse said, Hialeah Wildlife Sanctuary, but Agosto Maggiolo went in anyway, because he doesn't understand English and it looked like a racetrack to him.

title: For Kissinger, Momentum Is the Key to Success
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Diplomatic momentum produces success, success feeds success and leads to strengthening one's position at home: This is how officials describe Henry A. Kissinger's strate gy as Secretary of State. This revolvleg performance of momentumsuccesspersonal power, the officials say, explains why Mr. Kissinger held his news conference yesterday and why he is to journey this weekend to Bonn, Moscow and London, and then fly off to the Middle East in April.

title: VIETCONG OFFER A DETAILED PLAN FOR VOTE IN SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 The Vietcong proposed today sixpoint plan that included detailed provisions for a new ceasefire and the holding of general elections in South Vietnam.

title: TEACHERS BEGIN DRIVE ON COMER
description: Dr. Helen Wise, the president of the National Education Association, announced yesterday the beginning of a campaign by teachers to elect a Congress that cares about the education of our children.

title: EXXON Is CHARGED BY MAINE IN SUIT
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 22 Jon A Lund, Attorney General of Maine, has filed a civil suit accusing the Exxon Corporation of having miSled dealers land.the public about its supply levels.

title: ISRAEL SAYS EGYPT MOVES ARTILLERY UP
description: TEL AVIV, March 22 (Reuters)Israel has complained to the United Nations Emergency Force that Egypt has moved up new artillery on the eastern bank of the Suez Canal, an Israeli military spokesman said here today.

title: Assembly Committee Propoises To Expand Aid for Arts Upstate
description: ALBANY, March 22Legislature fiscal experts announced today a plan for state aid to the arts designed to guarantee percapita aid to rural upstate communities that have felt neglected by the State Council on the Arts during the years of Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Builder of DC10 Rejects Blame In Crash in France Fatal to 346
description: The builder of the DC10 airliner involved in history's worst air crash said yesterday that preliminary evidence indicated the plane's rear cargo door did not have all changes approved after the nearcrash of another DC10 in June, 1972.

title: ETHIOPIAN FAMINE IS STILL SPREADING Many More Deaths Feared Government Relief Plans Are Called Inadequate
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March.19The Ethiopian fain; ine, which killed tens of thousands of people last year, is continuing to spread relentlessty to new areas in the southern and eastern areas of the country.

title: 3 Victors Enough for Barrera, But Cordero Finds 4Too Few
JACK FUERST
description: Jack Fuerst, proprietor of the Newton Pharmacy, 675 Madison Avenue, for the last 40 years, died Thursday at Leonx Hill Hospital. His age was 75, and he lived at 44 East 80th Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, preseason, at Pompano Beach, Fla. (RadioWMCA, 1:30 P.M.)

title: Bridge:Distance Is No Enchantment For Stars Missing Title Play
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 22  Many familiar experts were missing, when the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals began here today. Distance has discouraged many of the New York stars, many of whom, will take, the shorter road to the Southeastern, Regionals in Miami Beath next week.

title: EXPERTS GLOOMY ON SAVING PENNSY
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad filed five affida vits yesterday with judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia to support their position that the 20,000mile system could not be reorganized on a moneymaking basis within a reasonable time under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Kissinger Asked to Get Pledge On Exit for 1,600 Soviet Jews
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Two major American Jewish organizations have asked Secretary of State Kissinger to give Soviet officials a new list of about 1,600 Soviet Jews who have reportedly been repeatedly.turned down in efforts to emigrate to Israel.

title: The Post Raising Its Price To 20c, Starting Monday
description: The New York Post, which publishes six afternoons a week, announced yesterday that the newsstand price of its daily and weekend editions would be increased from 15 to 20 cents, starting Monday.

title: Report on Atlantic Drilling Would Put It 30 Miles Out
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Council on Environmental Quality, in a step that brings closer the start of offshore oil drilling in the Atlantic, implied today that while such drilling was environmentally acceptable, it should not be done within 30 to 50 miles of New Jersey, Long Island or Cape Cod.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) The World Bank announced today that it had arranged to borrow $200million from Iran.

title: Ashe Beats Laver To Gain Semifinal
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 22Arthur Ashe, who had lost fifteen straight matches to Rod Laver since 1959, scored his second victory in two weeks over the former grandslam winner today and reached the semifinals in a $150,000 tennis tourney. He will meet the firstseeded player, John Newcombe.

title: 50 Who Served During Vietnam War Pass PracticalNurse Course
description: About 50 men and women, all of whom were in service during the Vietnam war, graduated yesterday from a special practicalnursing course instituted by the Board of Education.

title: Revsort Killed in Crash in South Africa

description: Ellen Beatrice Crowe, a retired actress and former speech and drama faculty member of the University of New Mexico and Centenary College in Haekettstown, N. J., died Wednesday in Bellevue Hospital.

description: A modest twoline advertisement on the front page of The New York Times on Thursday has caused a stir in Millburn, N.J., an affluent Essex County suburb.

title: Mayor Tells News Executives City Faces Insuperable Deficit
description: Mayor Beame detailed for news executives yesterday a looming budget deficit that he said you need a magician to solve.

title: Cambodian Government Forces Report a Riverfront Beachhead
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 22 (AP)  Government soldiers trying to recapture the fallen provincial capital of Phsar Oudong have reportedly succeeded in establishing a riverfront beachhead a few miles away.

title: JACKSON, MISS., TOLD TO PROMOTE BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)The Justice Department obtained a consent degree today requiring the city of Jackson, Miss., to hire and promote more blacks and women in virtually all municipal jobs and pay $200,000 to victims of alleged discriminatory practices.

title: One Family's Plan for Eating on $34 a Week (Beef Included)
In French Coal Town, Mine Jobs Are Rarer and Outlook Is Bleak
description: LALLAING, France  Like the horn of a prehistoric beast, the towering hoist of the Bonnet mine has dominated one corner of this bleak town in northern France and swalThe Talk lowed its men for at least half a Lelleing of century. Bonnel is closing on April 1, and the other mines around Lallaing with such names as Barrois, Gavant, Escarpelle and Dejardin  are due to shut before the decade is out under a longrange program of the nationalized coal

title: 2 Top U.S. Banks Join In Lifting of Prime Rate
description: The Bank of America, the largest commercial bank in the United States, and the First National City Bank, the second biggest, both joined a growing number of other banks yesterday in announcing increases in the prime lending rate from 83/4 to 9 per cent.

title: U. S. Ban of 22 Million Chickens Sought Over Pesticide Residue
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Twentytwo million chickens contaminated with a recognized cancercausing pesticide will be plaCed on the market unless the Environmental Protection Agency liars the sale within the next fee days, government and environmental sources indicated tonight.

title: Kissinger Will Take Children to Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 Secretary of State Kissinger, whose global hops have left him little time to spend with his two children, will take them along when he sets out on his trip to Moscow tomorrow night, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: PETRARCA ACCOUNT IS READ AT HIS TRIAL
description: NEWARK, March 22 (AP)  In a statement read to the jury in Robert D. Petrarca's murder trial today, the suspect's version of where he was the day two Montclair women were strangled was in conflict with the version given by two defense witnesses.

title: A Kurdish Guerrilla Force in Northern Iraq Is Reportedly Put on Defensive Alert
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 21 A Kurdish guerrilla force that controls the mountains of northern Iraq has reportedly been put on a defensive alert throughout the area and ordered not to start hostilities with Iraqi troops. Its leader is said to believe, however, that war is 80 per cent certain over the Kurds demands for autonomy.

title: BP Oil Shifts Credit Cards
description: CLEVELAND, March 22 (AP) The BP Oil Corporation is eliminating its own credit cards in favor of nationally distributed Master Charge credit cards, a spokesman for the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday. BP Oil is Sohio's East Coast subsidiary.

title: MobileFood Van Business Is Thriving on Long Island
description: BABYLON, L. I.At A.M. sharp, seven days a week, Vincent J. Alu drives into the Long Island Rail Road station here, parks his van, steps out, goes around to the rear and, with a few adjustments of levers and bolts, converts his vehicle into a snack shop. By 5 P.M., Mr. Alu has served more than 1,000 comtnuters and has earned at least $150.Some of the more than 1,000 mobile food venders on Long Island earn more than $500 a week in the $7millionayear business. Above, van near Sunrise Highway, Bay Shore. for her kosher hot dogs and homemade coffee. She earns $600 a week.

title: Recycling Prisoners
description: The state's prisonreform efforts still seem largely confined to the semantics of giving to penal institutions the new label of correctional facilities. Since wishing alone can't convert a jail into a place of rehabilitation, there was a flicker of hope in the proposal by Chancellor Ernest L. Boyer of the State University to create a college for prisoners. The plan, regrettably, has proved too sensible and too humane for the Legislature, which is trying to kill it by eliminating a projected $500,000 appropriation from Governor Wilson's budget.

title: Noel Follows the Fencing Tradition, Wins Foil Title
Loeb Rhoades Unit Seeks Securities Role in Japan
description: TOKYO, March 22 (AP)The Loeb Rhoades Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of Loeb, Rhoades & Co., is expected to be granted a license soon by Japan's Finance Ministry to engage in the securities business in Japan, a ministry official, said today.

title: Teacher Strike Enters 3d Week in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22  Public education for 76,000 students here, already in deep trouble because of a widerange of problems, is entering its third week of a teachers' strike.

title: Fiscal Trustees Assigned To Queens School District
description: Irving Anker, the city's School Chancellor, appointed two trustees yesterday to supercede the authority of a community school board in Queens on financial matters.

title: INQUIRY ON POLICE ASKED IN CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN, March 22 (UPI) Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti requested a grandjury investigation today into charges of brutality against blacks by white policemen.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Soybean futures prices on the] Chicago Board of Trade showed a sharp decline yesterday. The active May delivery opened at $6.441/2, 4 cents above the preceding day's close, moved as high as $6.471/2 and then closed around $6.35, down more than 5 cents on the day.

title: 4% Air Fare Rise Allowed As C.A.B. Cites Fuel Cost
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, blaming a precipitous rise in the price of jet fuel, authorized the nation's domestic airlines yesterday to raise fares 4 per cent on April 16.

title: Pentagon Abolishes Code on Discharges Of Military Misfits
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)  Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger abolished a numerical code today that permitted employers to identify military misfits, alcoholics and drug abusers even though they received honorable discharges from the service.

title: DualPurpose Funds MARCH 15, 1974
Thursday's Fights
description: Los Angeles:Alberto Davila, 114 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Mario Rogelio, 114, Mexico, 7 rounds; Frankie Duarte, 119, Los Angeles, knocked out Frankie Granados, 117, Mexico, 5.

title: After 7 Months, Police Learn of $80,000 Theft
description: More than seven months after the event, a retired merchant told the police yesterday that $80,000 in cash that he stored in shoe boxes had been taken from his apartment.

title: Arlan's in Chapter X Step
description: Arians Department stores was authorized yesterday by the United States District Court here to reorganize under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, with Irving Bernstein appointed as trustee.

title: 8 Tires on Plane Blow Out
description: BOSTON, March 22 (AP) Eight tires on a National Airlines DC8 jetliner carrying 100 passengers and a crew of seven blew out upon land at Logan International Airport yesterday. The passengers and crew were unhurt.

title: Pope Paul Described as Author of Key Passage in Document on Mary
description: ROME, March 22Pope Paul VI wrote the key passage on the way women live today in a long document on the devotion to Mary that the Vatican issued this week, members of his entourage say.

title: ExArgentine Labor Chief Killed on the Way to Doctor
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 22 (UPI) gunmen assassinated a retired rightwing union leader, once one of the most powerful men in President Juan Domingo Pdron's laborbased movement, as he attempted to visit his physician, police (sources said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: First quarter earnings are likely to be little short of disastrous, David Healy, vice president and director of research at Drexel Burnham & Co., stated in an analysis of General Motors Corporation common stock last week. Many leading auto analysts agree that not only G.M. but also the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation will report steep declines in their net income for the first three months of 1974.

title: News Summary and Index
European Favored in Fencing Here: It's Tradition
GOING OUT Guide
description: SIGHT AND SOUND John Cage, the composer, holds the stage tonight at 8:30 at the Hunter College Playhouse on 68th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues (5355350). He's going to be doing, fulllength, a new work called Empty Words and, in the Cage tradition, it promises to be like something you never heard before. It is composed, he says, or someone says, of nonsyntactical mixed phrases, words, syllables and letters obtained by subjecting The Journal of Henry David Thoreau to a series of I Ching chance operations and so on. It will be done against a backdrop of slides of abstract line drawings by Thoreau, with the Cage audio and the Thoreau art determined by chance, or whatever. It's all a benefit for the Center of New Music, a group dedicated to disseminating information and other work in behalf of contemporary music.

title: Discovery of Rare Cancer Spurs Concern About Environment
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 22The recent discovery of a rare liver cancer among workers exposed to vinyl chloride has enhanced the concern of some scientists about the myriad substances in the gen. eral environment that are known or suspected of causing cancer.

title: A New Haggadah Will Be Used By Reform Jews on Passover
description: For the first time in a halfcentury, Reform Jews will be using a new Haggadah when they observe Passover at sundown April 6.

title: I.M.C. Ends Plan to Buy Commercial Solvents
description: The international Minerals and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the termination of its offer to purchase the outstanding common shares of Commercial Solvents Corporation.

title: 4 Survivors Play Today In N.I.T.
3 PERSON SHOT IN OR BY SCHOOLS
description: A youth was accidentally shot and wounded in an Upper West Side junior high school yesterday and two other youths were wounded in separate shootings near Queens schools.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Britain Orders Cuts in Profit Margins
description: LONDON, March 22In an effort to curb inflation, the Government ordered today major retail food companies to reduce their gross profit margins by 10 per cent and at the same time reported that retail prices rose 1.7 per cent between midJanuary and midFebruary.

title: Celtics Top Trail Blazers, 126118;Cowens Returns
Ton of Marijuana Seized
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 22Police officers and Federal narcotics agents seized one ton of marijuana today that they said was on its way to New York City. The raid at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Tony Villarreal netted what. authorities called the largest such haul of marijuana in San Antonio's history. The police said the marijuana would wholesale for $450,000.

title: Dividend Rise Is Voted
description: Directors of Texas. Intsruments, Inc., raised the quarterly dividend yesterday from 17 cents to 25 cents, payable April 29 to shareholders of record April 8. Last September the board increased the quarterly dividend from 14 cents a share, which was the rate followItig a twoforone stock split distributed in May, 1973

title: U.S. Mission Chief, Two Months Away, Returns to Peking
description: PEKING, March 22 (Reuters) David K. E. Bruce, head of the United States mission in Peking, returned here today after an, eightweek absence that had raised doubts over the health of WashingtonPeking relations.

title: TV Review
description: A pair of 30minute television documentaries examining unfamiliar aspects of life on two islands, the Commonwealth pf Puerto Rico and remote Bali, make rewarding weekend viewing. Tonight at 7, station WABC will show Don PedroDiary of a People, with the second part continuing next Saturday. Tomorrow afternoon at 1, the parent network, the American Broadcasting Company, will show Bali: Religion in Paradise, the fourth study of Far ,Eastern religions in the Directions series.

title: Nonaligned Nations Ask World Change In Economic System
description: Political leaders representing some two billion people in the poorer countries of the world sent out an urgent appeal today for a total overhaul of the international economic system.

title: TAIWAN PROPOSES SAUDI PROJECTS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 22 Taiwan has proposed a series of investment projects to Saudi Arabia in hopes of getting a larger and more secure supply of oil.

title: SENATE APPROVES TIGHTER CONTROL OVER THE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 The Senate unanimously approved today legislation that would revolutionize Congressional procedures for considering the Federal budget and setting national spending priorities.

title: Treatment for Bone Cancer Is Hailed
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla March 23Children with bone cancer are being treated effectively with very large, doses of a highly toxic anticancer drug followed by another chemical that rescues normal noncancerous cells from the drug's damaging effects, a seminar here was told today.

title: Trial Set in Abduction
description: ATLANTA, March. 23 (AP)The couple charged, in the abduction February of Reginald Murphy, an Atlanta Constitution editor, are tentatively scheduled to go on trial April 22, assistant United States Attorney. William. P. Gaffney said yesterday. William A. H. Williams, 33 years old, is being held on $150,000 bond. He is charged with extortion and six related counts.. His Wife, Betty Ruth,. 26, is free oh $20,000 bond. She is charged with concealing a crime and aiding and abetting extortion.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
Klepto 1 Length Victor In Correction at Aqueduct
description: An impressive stretch drive by Klepto enabled that filly to carry Dr. Leon Hekimian's ?? to victory in the $55,600 Correction Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: HONG KONG ADOPTS A LANGUAGE LAIN
description: HONG KONG, March 23 (Reuters)  A new language law in this British colony makes Chinese an official language along with English for the first time, but officials will have difficulties in dealing with all the dialects spoken here.

title: Food: Choice and (relatively) cheap; The versatile chicken
Letters To the Editor
description: In the issue of Jan. 13 Steven Marcus reviewed a new book by Stanley Milgram, Obedience to Authority, which describes experiments performed by. Mr. Milgram in which unknowing subjects were told that they were taking part in learning experiments. The latter experiments entailed delivering seemingly painful electric shocks in response to their subjects failure to learn. The point of Mr. Milgram's experiments was to determine how far ordinary people might go in inflicting pain when sanctioned by scientific authority. Mr. Marcus found. Mr. Milgram's experiments and book objectionable. On Feb. 24 the Book Review published a defense of the experiments in letter from Roger Brown, a defense of the review by Saul Rosenzweig, and a reply from Mr. Marcus.. Although the Book Review prefers to conclude such controversies in one exchange the following letter seemed of exceptional interest:

title: New Shakeout in Real Estate Syndicates
description: With 12 Kidder, Peabody partners investing in the same deal, I asked myself, How could it go wrong? Well, it went wrong. It sure went wrong.

title: JOBERT CONFERS WITH BOUMEDIENE
description: ALGIERS, March 23  Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France ended a twoday visit to Algeria today in a twohour discussion with President Houari Boumediene, who had just returned from a 24hour visit to Tunis.

title: L.I. Studio Provides a Vivid Portrait Of Artist as Scottish Deerhound Owner
Swiss Trying to Keep Ancient Tongue
description: CHUR, Switzerland, March 23 (Reuters)Tucked away in mountain valleys near the Italian bor,der, Switzerland's 50,000, Romanshspeaking people are struggling to preserve their ancient culture against encroachment by the major languages.

title: AUTO SALES HERE REPORTED ON RISE
description: With dtente at the fuel pump, the sales of large and smaller cars have picked up at some city dealerships and salesmen are guardedly predicting that the worst is now over. While a spokesman for the Peter Zage and Co., Ltd., the RollsRoyce dealer at Second Avenue and 57th Street, reported sales unchanged, a spokesman for Potamkin Cadillac, at 1113 York Avenue near 60th Street, said that sales this month has been better than ever after a period a few weeks ago that really had us worried.

description: UPTON  Sprawled across the pine barrens of Central Suffolk, Brookhaven National Laboratory reflects in microcosm the uneasy relationship of science and government.

description: It has been more than eight years since Ralph Nader first charged that unsafe cars, not unsafe drivers, were largely responsible for death and injury on the highways. And for more than seven years, there has been a Federal law requiring safety standards for all cars built in the United States.

title: Boyle, ExPresident of Miners, Stands Trial Tomorrow in Yablonski Murder
description: MEDIA, Pa., March 23Nearly four years after he is alleged to have ordered the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his opponent In a bitter union election, W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, goes on trial for murder here on Monday.

title: Swimming Still Rated Top Participant Sport; Camping on Increase

description: Is it racist to ask young schoolchildren questions such as, Do you think black students in this school cause more trouble than other kinds of students?

title: Calling Dr. John
description: ROCK today displays nearly as many facets as the Hope diamond. Among its faces are the esoterla of a Yes, the high energy of a Foghat and the humor of a Martin Mull. Then there's the sensuous brand of rock as performed by Dr. John (real name Mac Rebennack), a leading exponent of the New Orleans sound, and Ann Peebles, just emerging nationally as a vital force on the Memphis front. Although rock by nature of its rhythmic appeal to the body as well as to the spirit, this music by both Dr. John and Miss Peebles also caresses the senses like a steamy, hot, perfumed bath.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tenants pay taxes as part of their rent, which can amount to as much as 40 per cent of their rent. It is only equitable that those senior citizens who happen to live in apartments should receive the same benefits as those who are homeowners. Both are faced with the same skyrocketing costs, and both should have the same relief.

title: School Helping Problem Students
description: STONY BROOK  Eight first graders with serious social and academic problems are being given a second chance at a school sponsored by the Psychology Department at the State University Center here.

title: Steps to war
description: Four years ago the British Government documents concerning the events of 1939 were taken off the secret list and made available to scholars. It is a common phrase of politicians that history will judge"; Sidney Aster has now judged, or at least made it possible for his readers to do so. 1939: The Making of the Second World War is a very detailed and authoritative study, a daytoday account of motives and memoranda based on evidence about as complete as there is ever likely to be. It will provide no lessons to contemporary leadersthe interest of the events it deals with lies not in general principles but in particularitiesnor lead to any revolutionary revisions by scholars. However, it does illuminate many previously obscure events, and it makes a fascinating story. And it may be read as a sort of guide to hownot

title: Rumania Advances In World Hockey
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, March 23 (AP)Rumania routed Austria, 101, today in the world hockey championship tournament.

title: Royalty Get Tight Guard In Britain
description: LONDON, March 23 (AP)A large security guard described by one.policeman as a ring of steel was thrown around Britain's royal family today.

title: Assembly Bill Seeks Greater Scrutiny of Judiciary
description: TRENTON  The State Legislature has been confronted again with a proposal that calls for greater scrutiny of the judiciary.

description: Maury P. Medwick, president of the Adhesive Products Corporation in the Bronx, is a frustrated man. He has been forced to cut production of certain items in half because the chemicals he needs to manufacture adhesives are in short supply.

title: Expo 74 Gradually Replacing Spokane's Skid Row

description: District Attorney Richard H. Kali of Manhattan said yesterday that his office next summer would be able to hire only about half of the 40 law school graduates who had been promsea jobs as assistant district attorneys.by his predecessor.

title: Fighting Impeachment
description: In his effort to escape possible impeachment President Nixon is trying to overpower the House Judiciary Committee, setting limits to the evidence it can obtain, prescribing its operating procedure and defining the scope of its inquiry. The Judiciary Committee, while dealing fairly with Mr. Nixon and carefully observing its own rules, has an obligation to the entire House and to the nation to retain control of its own proceedings and not be outmaneuvered in a cynical public relations game.

title: U.S. Expert Is in Cairo To Plan CanalClearing
description: CAIRO, March 23 (Reuters) The American admiral who commanded the mineclearance operation in Haiphong harbor last year today set about a similar task in the Suez Canal.

title: Keeping the Heat Inside
description: American homeowners, caught up in the energy crisis, may well feel helplesshow can anyone stem the rising tide of fuel costs? But many have found a way to alleviate the situation, and the result is a boom in the fiberglass industry.

title: Last Keeper of Lighthouse
description: Frank Schubert and Ms wife, Marie, have been watching the moods of the sea from the Nortons Point Lighthouse in Sea Gate for 14 years. Today, he is the last civilian lighthouse keeper working for the Coast Guard, and he has the feeling that it will not be long before the lighthouse becomes automated,

title: August Bridal Set By Susan Hastings
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., March 23  Mr. and Mrs. William H. Hastings have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Hastings, to John B. Glendon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Glendon of Scarsdale and Fishers Island, N. Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Upzoning in East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTONActing to preserve the rural character of our town, East Hampton upzoned 5,529 acresmore than 40 per cent of its undeveloped landfrom oneto twoacre minimum lots.

title: Photography
description: THE title of Michael Mar tone's first book, Dark Light, contains multiple meanings. Polarity, for one; opposition and tension. Chiaroscuro also, Pictorial representation in terms of light and shade, the basis of the photographer's craft. And a specific mood or quality of light  brooding, ominous  is suggested as well.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are Tilted four stars to none, based on 'the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: The Liner France Reported SCuttling FreeWine Policy
description: The France, a symbol of opulence, is running into heavy weather financially and reports from Paris indicate there may be short rations for all hands.

title: U.S. NOW HOPEFUL ON EUROPEAN PACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Although the fundamental dispute between the United States and the Common Market has yet to be.resolved, the latest exchanges across the Atlantic appear to have cleared the way for an understanding, in the view of Washington officials.

title: INSPECTORS SCORE A HEAD START UNIT

Is the resignation of any President, not yet accused formally of serious wrongdoing, compatible with orderly constitutional processes?

title: Four novels
description: The very, first page of this topical potpourri is, I'm afraid, the tipoff: it's the day of Kennedy's inauguration, and in Senator Hugh Pierce's office, drinking French champagne and talking about Lyndon, cluster Hubert Humphrey, Stu Symington, Scoop Jackson, John Sherman Cooper and Clark Clifford. Where does one go from there? Easy answerto Nixon's first inaugural on the final page. And in between? Name it and it's yours: the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, Valenti, McGovern, Bob Dylan, the East Lansing S.D.S. THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Ants in a pyramid... ruminations on regicide... omens of a civilization coming unhinged
description: WASHINGTON. I came to Washington in the high afternoon of the imperial American Presidency, although we did not recognize it as such at the time. Eisenhower, two years into his peaceful occupation of the White House, was a gentle Caesar, more a homespun Marcus Aurelius than great Julius, certainly no Caligula, but the imperial machinery was already in place awaiting the dynamic imperator es, Kennedy and Johnson, and after them the Whittier brooder doomed to inherit the whirlwind.

title: Howard U. Is Still Home For Two Former Stars
Watergate Ensnares the Press, Too
description: WASHINGTONFrom the beginning of the Watergate scandal the news media have played a part in the unfolding story that goes beyond its usual investigative and reporting roles. Sometimes wittingly, sometimes not, the press has become an arena for the struggle now taking place between the :branches of government. Lawyers representing those caught in the scandal seek out the press and television to poslure their clients, and targets of investigations test strategies or signal antagonists through news reports. With the exception, at least until now, of the House Judiciary. Committee's impeachment inquiry, hardly an interest involved has hot included tactics as part of its strategy.

Peepers
description: The common name is spring peeper. Sometimes it is called tree frog. Scientifically it is known as a hyla, and the one best known in our area is Hyla crucifer, the hyla with a cross on its back. The cross is a lighter marking on the hyla's skin. It is a small cross because the hyla, or peeper, is no bigger than a man's thumbnail.. But when.the peepers begin to call you would think they were big as bullfrogs, at least.

It essential that we convict as felons those who commit crimes with pistols and revolvers for which they have license, he told members of the Greater New York Rifle and iPstol Clubs Federation at their annual convention at Irving Plaza. The federation represents 300 clubs with 5,000 members in the metropolitan area.

title: Assembly Votes Measure to Curb SchoolBus Strikes

title: The End of The American Future
description: Once upon a time, says Peter Schrag, America was a land of promise and hope, and all its people were filled with a sense of possibility and optimism. But now it's all vanished, we're told, and in a book that reads like a longwinded lament over paradise lost, the author sketches the features of what he takes to be the very twilight of the country's existence  its anomie and alienation, its declining expectations, its loss of mobility and, finally, the collapse of the grand postwar consensus that produced all the social reforms of the recent past.

If the eagle had been present at the second concert Friday night, he might well have been puzzled by the final work, Edward Burlingame Hill's Sextet (Op, 39) for winds and piano.

title: Dave Anderson

Each gladiator will receive $5million, double what Ali and Joe Frazier each collected for their 1971 extravaganza. The site will be a 120,000seat soccer stadium in Kinshaha, Zaire, once known as Leopoldville, the Belgian Congo. The date will be sometime in September, unless Ken Norton disrupts the master plan by dethroning Foreman here Tuesday night. The catalyst is Don King, a 42yearold black vicepresident of Video Techniques, Inc., the closedcircuit television firm that is handling the ForemanNorton bout, In a business dominated by black boxers, a black promoter finally has emerged with influence and

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Since Martha Lear declares that even her husband's heart attack can't make her stop smoking, I am hardly surprised that nowhere in her article (All the warnings, gone up in smoke, March 10) does she acknowledge the newlyproven health hazard nonsmokers (who are, after all, merely the majority of Americans) must endure when they are cooped up in close areas with smokers.

title: A PSYCHOLOGIST WINS JOB RULING
Nixon and a Right of Reply
description: In his campaign reform message two weeks ago, President Nixon suggested new laws to counter libelous criticism political candidates. At present, he said, good and decent people  may be put off politics by fear of slanderous attacks on them or their families. In the deluge of Watergate and impeachment, the proposal did not get much attention. But it has now begun to stir controversy, especially among the media who are evidently its chief targets.

title: Lagging Minimum
description: The official disclosure last week that higher living costs have cut a dime out of the consumer's dollar in the last twelve months alone makes it elementary justice that SenateHouse conferees have reached swift agreement on a higher Federal minimum wage.

title: She Finds French Trot Establishment Impregnable
description: BOISSY SAINT LEGER, France Though the men in her family have soared to great heights in politics and planes, Rosamonde Pinchot can't get off the ground in her struggle with the French trotting powers.

title: Music; What on Earth Is an Urtext'?
description: NOT long ago I wrote, in this column, an article about the Henle urtext edition of the Liszt B minor Sonata. Shortly after that, a lady wrote. She said that she had looked up urtext in the dictionary and couldn't find it. What was an urtext"? The article also prompted a letter from Willard A. Palmer of Houston. Palmer runs a workshop for pianists and teachers, and also brings out carefully edited editions of masterworks for the piano. He raised some questions about the urtext problem that are well worth going into.

title: Wyandanch Seeks Aid To End School Debt
description: ALBANYThe Wyandanch School District, with nearly $700,000 in debts, has asked the State Legislature to allow It to issue longterm bonds to cover the debts it has accumulated.

title: Waterfront Plan Approved by City

title: Palisades Power Squadron Fights Sex Discrimination Decision
description: Since its Inception In 1914, the United States Power Squadrons (USPS) has been an allmale organization. It has also been a private club although it offers free boating classes to the public. These two points are at the heart of a controversy that began last December when the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety's Civil Rights Division looked into a complaint by Marilyn C. Hinden, a woman who was denied membership in the Palisades Power Squadron of New Jersey. She charged sex discrimination.

title: In the shadow of Stalin
description: Jozsef Lengyel, a Hungarian writer now in his deep seventies, began his career as an avantgarde poet, become a Communist and, after the collapse of the Hungarian Revolution of 1919, fled to Moscow as an exile. Like millions of others, he was swept up by the Soviet purges and in 1937 began an 18year stay in Siberia. He made his way back to his homeland in 1955 and since then has been writing fiction about the ordeal of Communists who discover that their belief has been falseor has been falsified by those who speak in its

title: Reich Is Winner In Lange Slalom
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 23 (AP)Ed Reich raced down an icy sunlit course to victory in the Lange Cup giant slalom today, the first winnnig run of his professional career.

title: ACTION IS URGED ON ELECTION LAWS
description: The advisory committee to a. state select committee on campaign law reform in its final report yesterday urged tough new election laws that would include creation of in independent commission with wide powers and would limit campaign spending and contributions.

title: India Seeks To Change Her Beggar Image
description: NEW DELHI"We're a society of survival and we've lost the capacity to identify, to tackle the problems, says the former government official. We can't change without paying the price, without breaking up the caste system and this hierarchal system of government. Yet who's willing to pay this price?

title: Caryn Coogan Engaged To George Whitney 3d
description: Gordon Gordon Coogan of New York and Mrs. Malcolm D. MacDougall of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caryn Gordon Coogan, to George Whitney 3d. He is the son of Mrs. Whitney Jr. of Beverly Farms, Mass., and the late Mr. Whitney, a grandson of the late George Whitney, who headed J. P. Morgan & Co., and a greatgrandson of the late Robert Bacon, Ambassador to France and Secretary of State under President Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Recordings
description: IF SUCH a place as Hollywood circa 1938 still existed, The Erich Wolfgang Korngold Story would go before the cameras instantly. What a plot, What a cast. Consider a few of the highlights.

title: An Army Without A General
description: BEVERLY HILLS The left wing of the Democratic party, powerful in 1968 and triumphant in 1972, is without a recognized leader today. The wealthy, liberal contributors of Beverly Hills, for instance, men like Max Palevsky, Miles Rubin and Stanley Sheinbaum, seem not quite sure which way to turn.

title: Rain Gives Staub, Jones Extra Day to Heal Injuries

Moscow Criticizes U.S. Oil Companies
description: MOSCOW, March 23The Soviet press today accused American oil Companies of committing financial sabotage by selling oil in Western Europe below the current market price.

title: The gallant adventurers
description: Part of a later generation, I must work to grasp a sense of the charisma that Anne Morrow Lindbergh and her husband Charles radiated in that past. To their honor, they refused to massage their wild celebrity. The diary mentions neither press agents nor business. managers The pictures of. the Lindberghs are appealing: a handsome, brave, ardent, selfsufficient couple, free spirits too devoted to each other to be lonely. Yet if the diary, prose and photographs, shows how attractive the Lindberghs were, it fails to tell why they provoked such frantic awe.

title: A New Phase of Hemispheric Cooperation
description: Two new LatinAmerica presidents were inaugurated this month, Carlos Andres Perez in Venezuela and Gen. Ernesto Geisel in Brazil. These changes, coming so soon after the meeting of foreign ministers in Mexico City in midFebruary, which Secretary of State Kissinger said heralded a new relationship among the nations of the region, have focused attention on Latin America and have occasioned suggestions that a new phase of Western Hemispheric cooperation is beginning.

title: Katherine Hawkins, Physician, Engaged
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 23Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Hawkins have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Katherine Ann Hawkins, to Dr. Paul Chrzanowski, son of Mrs. Jane Cullen and Dr. Gerard Chrzanowski, both of New York. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Passion Plays Are Offered
description: UNION CITY  The curtain rose yesterday on the new season of the longestrunning play in New Jersey theatrical history. The production, now in its 60th consecutive season, is Veronica Wipes the Face of Jesus, the passion play presented by the Holy Family Church of Union City.

title: COURT IS WATCHED FOR MERGER SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Has the Supreme Court developed a working majority that is sympathetic to permitting some big business mergers and resistant to the efforts of the Department of Justice to blook such activity?

title: Finishing School
description: The most exclusive finishing school in New York is located not on the fashionable Upper East Side, but rather down on King Street in Lower Greenwich Village, an unprepossessing,. primarily residential block: wedged in among the truckclogged highways leading to the Holland Tunnel. Its neighbors range from moderately expensive apartment buildings to tenements, and the school itself, a grimy brick and stone pile marked with an American flag and an inconspicuous sign identifying the establishment as The Livingston Junior and Senior High School,, blends in well on the block. Behind its orange doors is a fourstory cluster of classrooms designed in 1875, and not Mitch changed since, where some 120 rigidly selected young New York ladies studyornot, as they choose, since the institution is operated along progressive, opencorridor principlesEnglish and basic mathematics, of course, as well as music, song writing, beauty culture, urban affairs, elementary merchandising applicable to intelligent shopping, and a smattering of, business practices.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 23 (AP)  Malcolm Alexander's face glows and his hands gesture emphatically as he describes what happened when he took a bronze statue of the late Roberto Clemente to Pittsburgh for inspection.

The medal is considered the university's highest honor and has been gwen to American Catholics since 1883.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 23Witnesses will testify that Hubert H. Humphrey received an attache case with $50,000 from Howard R. Hughes, the jury in a defamation trial was told here this week.

Otherwise things have not changed much, for Wright just happens to be a lawyerdetective. That is, he is a lawyer who has to solve a case on his own before justice is done.
