description: PETERSBURG, Va., March 23 (UPI)For modest Moses Malone, being recruited by 200 colleges is a little hard to believe, but not for anyone who has seen him play basketball.

title: Molloy Captures Prep Relay Title
description: Pat Conroy, the allcity indoor twomile champion, set a meet record yesterday and led Archbishop Molloy to the Division A team title in the Fordham Prep scholastic relay carnival at the Mount St. Michael track in the Bronx.

title: Everybody who's nobody and the nobody who's everybody
description: One of the most poignant and powerful of American dreams is the dream signified by the expression Popular Front. These words are ordinarily held to denote a political and cultural policy adopted by international Communism from 1934 to 1946: a policy of deemphasizing struggles for revolution, and striving instead to unite liberal and democratic forces within each country in the face of the dangers of Fascism. At the end of World War II, in accord with shifting needs and interests, Communist policies were abruptly and drastically changed. But, in America at least, the Popular Front policy had liberated immense imaginative energies that no party directive could kill. It had articulated a vision of a genuinely democratic communityperhaps the first such vision in American history.

title: Baraka's Power Is Said to Wane
description: NEWARKAs a new round of city elections draws near, Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist whose organizational skills helped Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to win almost four years ago, finds himself. shunted off, to the sidelines by his uncompromising ideology and a series of political reversals.

title: SCHOOLAID PLAN GAINING SUPPORT

description: Don Price, 25 years a reporter and editor on the staff of The Daily News, died yesterday at his home, 128 Webster Avenue, Manhasset, L. I. He was 52 years old.

description: MONTREAL, March 23As 1,836 New York state teachers gathered here this week, the mood at the top was exuberant. In the 18 months since the United Teachers of New York merged with the New York State Teachers Association to form the New York State United Teachers, membership has grown by 30,000 to 207,000 membersabout 93 per cent of all eligible teachers in the state.

title: An enormous infusion of Federal funds into culture

description: A pair of anniversaries are coining up in a few weeksthe birthdays of the Nassau Coliseum and Madison Square Garden. Almost 100 years ago, P. T. Barnum put up his grand Hippodrome, which became Madison Square Garden I. And two years ago, major league arena came to Nassau County when the Coliseum officially opened.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market ended a dull week in dull fashion, with the DowJones industrial average rising 2.66 points Friday to 878.13 on a turnover of 11.93 million shares. The Dow's net change for the whole week was a minus 9.70.

title: Fight on Blue Laws Continuing on L.I.
description: MINEOLA  A clothing retailer who has received 35 summonses in the last two years and has been arrested three times for violation of the state's controversial blue laws vowed last week to remain opan on Sundays as a matter of principle.

SAMUEL SELIGSOHN
description: Samuel Seligsohn, a trial lawyer here for more than 50 years, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 145 East 15th Street.

title: Five Sect Leaders in Chile Sent to Desert Prison Carnp
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 23 As part of its crackdown on hippies, spiritualists and social nonconformists, the military junta of Chile announced yesterday that it had sent five leaders of the Silo religious movement to one of its main political prison camps.

title: 1975 Cars to Offer No Major Changes in Economy or Technology
description: DETROIT, March 23When customers walk into automobile dealer showrooms next fall to look over the 1975 models, they will find few surprises even though the industry has been undergoing al radical transformation because of the energy crisis.

title: Some Basic Facts For Iris Growers
description: THE modern iris is so superior to those which grew in grandmother's gardens, the obsolete varieties should be tossed upon the compost heap. The newer kinds are in an almost infinite variety of colors, form, height and size and they are reasonable to buy.

description: The Magen David Adorn, Israel's emergency medical service, has applied for membership in the League of Red Cross Societies, renewing a request that was first rejected in 1949.

It has music by Stephen Schwartz, who provided the songs for Pippin, and a book by Bob Randall, author of 6 Rms Riv vu.

title: Letters to a highschool buddy
description: How can you explain hurnor? People try. They talk about the psychology of laughter and basic joke variations on classic themes. I don't know what they are talking about. All I know is, what is funny to you may not be funny to me.

title: MRS. GOLDA R. MORROW
description: Mrs. Golda Rosenberg Morrow, executive secretary to Samuel Bronfman, founder and former president of Distillers Corporation Seagram's, Ltd., from 1933 until his death in 1971, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 45 East 66th Street.

title: The Region In Summary
description: Consistently in the history of opiate addiction, the attempted cures have turned into still other problems, In the 19th century, for instance, opium and morphine addicts were treated with new drugscocaine and heroin; the patients became cocaine and heroine addicts.

title: PLANT &
description: THE homeowner who faces gardening for the first time can have shrubs that are easy to grow and readily avail able from most of the larger nurseries. They require no special care or soil, and have no particular disease or insect pests.

description: MOST OF THE ARAB oilproducing countries announced the end of their oil embargo against the United States. They also said prices would be frozen until June

title: Design: For the carriage trade By Norma Skurka
description: This carriage house, built in the early nineteenhundreds is all that remains of a huge estate, complete with mansion and all the appropriate outbuildings. The present owners, a young business executive and his wife, were attracted by the charm and roominess of the 100by40foot building, although the interior truly reflected the function of the structureto house cars, not people. It was unfinished and in need of everything. The challenge posed to architect Myron Goldfinger was to take this raw space and turn it into a contemporary, lightfilled home without destroying the charm. He turned the center section into an open twolevel living area. The loft was transformed into a master bedroom with its own luxurious bathroom and dressing room. The remodeling was not cheap. It came to around $85,000 but, as the architect points out, a new house with the same 7,000 square feet of space would cost a quarter of a million to build from scratch today.

title: G.M. May Raise Car Price Despite Pledge to Hold Line
description: DETROIT, March 23 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation indicated today that it might follow the lead of its competitors and raise prices of its 1974 model automobiles for the third time despite a pledge to hold the line until September.

title: CONSUMER AGENCY TO SHIFT EMPHASIS
Sports Editor's Mailbox: On College Recruiting, Amateurism and Moral Decay
description: On March 10, The New York Times started a sixpart series on sports recruiting by colleges. It told how leading highschool athletes received many offers from colleges of fulltuition payments, room and board, books and incidental money and sometimes illegal offers beyond that. One story in the series, on March 12, told about Sandy Climan, an allAmerica mathematics student from the Bronx, who is attending Harvard only because his father was able to borrow money to pay for tuition and other costs.

title: Tara's Hill Victor In Horse Jumping
Anchorman
description: In American broadcasting a special niche is regerved for television's anchormenthe familiar and trusted journalists who deliver a summary of the world's day crisply and objectively. Because tens of millions of viewers see the network news programs nightly, every story and every raised eyebrow is watched carefully by public and Government.

title: The Liner France Reported Scuttling FreeWine Policy

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his March 10 column James Reston presented a sympathetic view of French Foreign Minister Michel Jobert, essentially by allowing him to air his grievances against Dr. Kissinger's rough tongue, I wish Mr. Jobert had restrained his emotion and presented Mr. Reston with his very good case on French petroleum policy.

description: Because he turned a hob by into a career, Hans Joachin Holzner will be in the Soviet Union next winter fOr the Moscow horse auction.

description: How highly are Indiana's chances rated as the Hoosiers go for their seventh straight National Col legiate swimming title starting Thursday? I honestly believe that the United States Olympic team would have trouble beating Indiana, says Minnesota's coach, Bob Mowerson.

description: EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I.The chief of the Nassau County Police Department's Marine Bureau expects the coming boating season to be one of the busiest in the department's history.

title: Baker Gets Homesick Away From Track
Sunday Observer
description: The world is as follows: Upon removing his shoes at bedtime, P. B. Sykes observes that the feet inside his socks are not his feet, but quite obviously someone else's feet. His wife, noting an unusual expression on his face, inquires if something is wrong. No, says Sykes, quickly dousing the light.

title: News of the Camera World
description: Workshops for beginners and advanced students will be held on Wednesday evenings and Saturday afternoons by David Ehrenpreis, 24 East 21st Street, with the beginner's workshop devoted to camera and darkroom techniques. The advanced course will cover studio work and experimental techniques and will help students set up their own portfolios. Each class will be limited to four students, and the cost will be $58 for four sessions or $108 for eight sessions. For more information call (212) 6481365 and OR 42679.

title: Ideas &

description: WASHINGTONHenry Kissinger is off to Moscow again seeking to restore the lustre to SovietAmerican detente with a new set of flexible working principles" he hopes will lead to a new agreement on strategic nuclear arms.

title: East Orange Wins Third Title in Row

description: GLEN COVE Fifty four families of mixed racial and economic backgrounds have been living harmoniously for nearly a year in a multifamily project built by the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and there are more than 200 families on the waiting list.

description: WASHINGTONThe American people crave openness in government. The relationship between government inforthation policies and democracy is close and direct. The rights to vote and run for office mean little without the rights to know the activities of the incumbent Government and make or hear informed criticism of public officials and policies.

Singlehandedly, he had kept a ragtag band of athletes in neverending search of that most elusive of grailesan American League pennant.

title: Four Major Libraries Combine Research Operations

The Californian who won the first three events of the 1974 tour, has just returned to competition after a three week rest. During that span he did not touch a club.

title: Report on Spending For Nixon's Homes Disputed by G.S.A.
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI)The head of the General Services Administration maintained today that Congressional Subcommittee report that $17million had been spent at President Nixon's estates in California and Florida was deliberately manufactured distortion of the truth.

title: Red Smith
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 23The Minnesota Twins, formerly the old Washington Senators, came down here the other day for an exhibition game with the Texas Rangers, who used to be the new Washington Senators. With the Twins was Bob Darwin, who used to be a pitcher of no great distinction and now is the top powerhitter on club that includes Harmon Killebrew, Tony Oliva and Rod Carew, threetime batting champion of the American League. At the age of 31, Darwin is still learning to play in the outfield. After eight years as a pitcher, all in the minor leagues except for seven innings, he got a sore arm and set out to earn a living with his bat. He was chatting about it with a visitor when the Rangers second baseman, Dave Nelson, stopped by and greeted him.

title: A Return to Rivalry
description: MOSCOW, March 23A renewed sense of rivalry and frustration with the United States now colors the Soviet policy of detente, so warmly proclaimed, when President Nixon visited Moscow 22 months ago.

title: Committees With Clout
description: General Motors runs by Alfred Sloan's prescription of decentralization with coordinated control, otherwise known as rule by committee. Perhaps the most important, certainly from a long range point of view, is the bonus and salary committee, which will meet this fall, just off the rosewood paneled board room in New York, to pick the new chairman and the new president.

title: Lab Renovating Navy Barracks
description: MONTAUK  In an effort to keep pace with its growing research programs, the New York Ocean Science Laboratory is renovating a World War II Navy barracks to form. 18 efficiency apartments as housing for graduate and visiting scientists conducting research here.

title: The great negative explorer The Life Of Captain James Cook
description: Deep in the Antarctic on Jan. 30, 1774, as the field ice closed in and We could not proceed one inch farther south, Captain Cook described himself as a man whose ambition leads me not only farther than any other man has been before me, but as far as I think it possible for man to go. At the same time, he was not sorry at meeting with this interruption, as it in some measure relieved us from the dangers and hardships, inseparable with the navigation of the southern polar regions. This episode dramatized both Cook's range and his prudence. His life was a climax of seafaring exploration when hopes were high, vistas were misty, the planet still full of undiscovered islands and even a few un

title: Moon Still Is A Generally Silent Witness
description: Hundreds of geologists spent four days at the Fifth Annual Conference on Lunar Science in Houston last week, picking over the results of their investigations into the meaning the moon rocks.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Weather for Striped Bass
The Boys From Chicagah
description: Studs Terkel has a new book out called Working (see Page 1), and Nelson Algren recently had one out called The Last Carousel (Book Review, Nov. 11), and they were sitting in the back room of Riccardo's one Friday evening matching cognac against martinis. This was a while back, and they were putting on a hick from the First. City, or maybe only testing the throwaway lines, but there they were, still showing a lot of stuff in their early sixties, two boys from Chicagah who are literary fixtures here as monumental as Mayor Daley and the Water Tower.

title: 2 Die in HeadOn Crash
description: NEW CITY, N. Y. March 23 Two persons died at Nyack Hospital early_ today as a result of a headon collision last night on the causeway across Lake DeForest, two miles east of here. The victims were Mrs. Anna Pechefsky, 65 years old, of Congers, a passenger in one car, and James Conklin, 19, of Valley Cottage, a passenger in the other car. Both drivers were in Nyack Hospital with minor injuries.

title: The Nation

Appearing at broadcasters convention in Houston, the President said that because the Arab oil embargo had been lifted, there would be no gasoline rationing and the existing ban on Sunday gasoline sales would be removed.

title: The perils of human behavior
description: Esther Vilar's thesis in The Manipulated Man is simple: women are subhuman creatures, incapable of intelligence, integrity or feeling, who, make of men their willing slaves. Love is synonymous with power, liberation with subtler forms of exploitation, childbearing with putting a man into harness. Men work, according to Vilar, while women consume. Men think; women languish. Men have a conscience. Women have none. Men are capable of devotion, women only of narcissism. Men, though intelligent and visionary, are fools. Women, though moronic, are strategically brilliant. There is scarcely a single female activity which does not exist as an example of sloth, stupidity, venality or

title: Miss Susan Lowry to Be Bride Of William M. Bristol on June 8
description: ESSEX, Conn., March 23Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Lowry of Essex and Point O'Woods, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Lowry, to Brian Tilton Bristol. He is the son of Mr, and Mrs. William M. Bristol 3d of Upper Makefield Township, Pa., and Point O'Woods.

title: Notes: Travel to U.S. Is Up
description: AST year, after five years of growing balance of payments deficits in regard to tourism, the U.S. finally reversed the trend. The reversal was dramatic enough to be termed startling by C. Langhorne Washburn, Assistant secretary of Commerce.

title: Levinand Variations It's a Grand Old Name
description: It is not a Specter which is haunting Europe, let alone America. It is a Levin,

title: Aaron Evokes Adulation From Mates For What He Does So Effortlessly
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 23.  Hank Aaron evokes a wide range of reactions from people with whom he comes in contact and those who see him only from a distance. It's those closest to him, though, his teammates, who appreciate him the About most. Ron SwoBaseball boda hasn't been with the soonto be career home run king for even one whole spring training, but even a few weeks have enabled the former Met and Yankee to understand what Aaron's all about.

title: Ocean and Sound Are Dirtier Still
description: The New York City Commissioner of Water Resources ducks the polluted spray aboard the Staten Island ferry, The regional administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency won't eat uncooked local shellfish. And a bistate study has just declared that much of Long Island Sound is badly polluted and getting worse.

title: Newcombe Beats Smith; Ashe Victor Over Okker
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 23 John Newcombe defeated Stan Smith in a tense match, 75, 67, 76, and reached the final of the $150,000 American Airlines tennis tournament at the Tucson Racquet Club.

title: U.S. DUMPING PM STIRRING PROTESTS
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.  The Army Corps of Engineers expects to issue a permit soon for a controversial dredging operation here that environmentalists and fishermen say will dump 2.80 million cubic yards of dangerously polluted river mud into Long Island Sound.

title: Wallace Seeks 3d Term And Warns Top Parties
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 23 (AP)  Hinting at another Presidential race, George C. Wallace has begun his quest for a third term as Governor of Alabama,

title: Women on/in movies
Barbara Shore Sets May 12 Bridal
description: HADDONFIELD, N. J., March 23Miss Barbara Ann Shore, an assistant attorney general in the litigation department of the New York State Department of Law in New York, and Arnold E. Resnicoff, a former Navy lieutenant studying for the rabbinate at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, plan to be married here May 12.

title: The rabbits'
description: The impulse to make animals represent or incarnate human significances is of long standing in literature, going back at least as far as Aesop. For whatever reason (Victorian repression leading to the use of surrogate spokesmen in fur or feathers? Racial guilt over bearbaiting and foxhunting?) English literature has for scene time been especially lavish in the granting to animals of human properties: speech, humor, moral values, histories. One distinction of this kind of writing is that while it is mostly directed toward children, adults have enjoyed the best of it as much as children and sometimes more: Edward Lear and Lewis Carroll, surely, but also Kipling, A. A. Milne, Kenneth Grahame, even Beatrix potter.

title: Omelettes Drawings and History
description: THE exhibition of 80 French drawings now at the Metropolitan Museum is a connoisseur's history of art in Paris in the 49th century, with an 18thcentury prologue (Jacques Louis David) and a 20thcentury epilogue (early cubism and fauvism). It is comparable to a political historian's tour de force by which a turbulent century might be summarized in a series of brief informal comments made by presidents, generals, revolutionists, statesmen and other historymakers, taking for granted the reader's knowledge of the wars, treaties, and political struggles that inspired them. For that is what a drawing is  a pithy comment, a spontaneous response, a first thought, sometimes an  epigram, in contrast with the fully deliberated, carefully phrased and balanced statement the artist makes in painting or sculpture.

title: CANADIANS ARGUE OVER OIL PROFIT
description: OTTAWA, March 21Working against an April 1 deadline, Canada's oilproducing provinces and the federal Government are trying to negotiate their way out of a legal dispute that involves the confederation that holds this country together.

title: Activists in Suburbs Under Fire as Landlords
Kissinger Departs
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Secretary of State Kissinger, left for Moscow tonight concerned about signs of a chill in SovietAmerican relations but hopeful of progress toward anotheraccord on strategic arms and of bigpower cooperation in Middle East diplomacy.

title: For Charter Study Units; Awareness Is One Goal
description: HACKENSACK  The charterstudy commissions that nine counties elected last November to review their freeholder systems of government have run up against a common problem: How to get the public to understand what they are doing.

title: CYRIL QUINN DIES; INVESTMENT HEAD
description: Cyril J. C. Quinn, senior partner of J. & W. Seligman & Co., investment brokers, and a former vice chairman of the TriContinental Corporation, died here yesterday in his sleep. He was 81 years old and lived at 755 Park Avenue.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Face the Nation: The guest is Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, Channel 4, 11:30 A.M.

title: APPEAL PLANNED ON ANKER RULING
description: A Queens community school board whose spending authority was suspended on Friday sale yesterday that it would go to court in an effort to force the central Board of Education to increase its budget. The local board said that if it was unsuccessful it might have to recommend the closing of two schools net term.

title: Deirdre Duffy Engaged
description: Miss Deirdre Jane Duffy, an assistant buyer in the Importique Shop of Lord & Taylor in New York, plans to be married in September to Richard Edward Meyer, who is with Henski & Son, contractors, in Roslyn, L. I. The bridetobe is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Duffy of Manhasset, L. I. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. William Meyer of Roslyn and the late Mr. Meyer.

title: A family of executioners
description: As an exSan Quentin guard, exDeath Row gunman, traitorous son (now resident in France) of a long line of Godfearing, law'n'orderminded, procapitalpunishment prison bulls, it was with great interest and some apprehension that recently picked up Barbara Levy's Legacy of Death, the strange, gruesome, fascinating story of the Sanson Family, who served as executioners of France for seven generations.

title: Life with a wealthy, sadistic, murderous lunatic
description: Louise Thoresen writes about 10 years of courtship, marriage, childrearing and deterioration with a wealthy, sadistic, murderous lunatic. William Thoresen was never really the misunderstood kid he played so often; after age 13 everybody in his life seemed to know he was as mean as this memoir, devoid of any redeeming social or psychological insights. Largely selfjustifying, pseudoremorseful, his widow (and executioner) remains just as insensifive to who he and she were together and what was going on between them from day to day as she must have been during all their years together. Despite everything rotten he'd been responsible for in my life, she writes here, I loved him deeply.

title: Herb Washington Pursuing Degrees In His Education as A's BaseRunner
description: MESA, Ariz., March 23 The second semester of Herb Washington's crash course in running from base to base begins today with the arrival of a special professor, Maurice Morning Wills, dean emeritus of the Advanced Institute for Basepath Mechanics.

title: $16,000 Found in Room Of Dead Brooklyn Loner
description: A total of $16,000 in cash was found Friday in the $65 amonth furnished basement flat of Arthur Trimboli, 62yearold loner who had lived at 2162 East 29th Street in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn for the last six years.

title: Schnauzer Is Best at Bronx Show
Bisexual LifeStyle Appears to Be Spreading and Not Necessarily Among Swingers
description: A small but apparently growing number Americans are practicing bisexuality an ageold but still largely mysterious life style that is just beginning to come under the scrutiny of scientific study.

title: J. RAE CONWAY
description: J. Rae Conway, an insurance broker here for nearly half a century, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn. lie was 81 years old and lived at 7100 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn.

title: SEX WEEK IS QUIET ATU. OF ALABAMA
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., March 23The University of Alabama, probably best known as the place Where Gov. George C. Wallace stood defiantly in the schoolhouse door to block the admission of two black students in 1963, seems an unlikely setting for the showing of obscene movies and a lecture by a star in a pornographic movie.

title: BALL CRITICIZES NIXON ON EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS, March 23 (UPI)  former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball says that Secretay of State Kissinger is tired and shows it, that President Nixon is using Europe to distract attention from Watergate, and that neither really wants a united Europe.

title: Stamps
description: THE United States, to mark the 25th anniversary of the North Palm Treaty Organization, the alliance in which America made historic and unprecedented commitments to Western Europe, is issuing a commemorative aerogramme for the quarter century of security in the Atlantic community that NATO helped engender.

title: Alfred D. McKelvy Jr. To Wed Miss Johnson
description: SADDLE RIVER, N, J., March 23Mr. and Mrs. Murdoch Linton Johnson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Leigh Johnson, to Alfred Douglas McKelvy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKelvy of Atherton, Calif.

title: 8 Killed in FireBombing At Bar in Allentown, Pa.
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 23 Eight persons were killed and a dozen more were injured this afternoon when gasoline can was ignited and tossed into a crowded bar, fire officials said.

title: Kerr on Seapino
description: THE Young Vic, last of the British companies to invade Brooklyn this season, will be at the Academy of Music for just one more week, which means that you have just one more week to save yourself an enormous amount of time and energy. If, for instance, you wanted to catch a performer named Jim Dale in London, you'd have a breathless time doing it: in London, when Mr. Dale isn't on television he's in musical comedy, and when he isn't in musical comedy he's at the Old Vic, and when the Old Vic gets too Old he slips clown the street a bit to help out its offspring, The Young Vic. Helping out, I should say, consists in taking over entirely; those who benefit from his ministrations as often as not wind up flat on their backs  a perfectly good place to be, it turns out. One whale comic sequence in Scapino finds at least three performers prostrate, waiting for Mr. Dale

title: Seaman Is Saved by Divers
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23 (UPI)Divers rescued a man trapped in an air pocket in his ship's hull for four hours, but two others aboard the vessel were still missing tonight. The 1,000ton freighter Straitsman capsized and sank in Melbourne's Yarra River.

title: Forego Wins Widener At Hialeah
Pop
description: EARLIER the first night I saw Cleo Laine I'd done time at the City Opera. The production at the State Theater had been unrelenting in everything except logic; the singing was a depressing catalogue of desperate devices.

title: Numismatics
description: THE centennial of this nation in 1876 was celebrated by the government and the citizenry with a.good deal more gusto than seems likely to attend the bicentennial in 1976. One of the stars of that first celebration was a memorable exposition held in Philadelphia, and one of the things that made that exposition so memorabl was the great abundance and variety of souvenirs available to the public.

title: I Am Prince Kima, and I Desire to Tell You About My Country

description: Under the pressure of soaring electric utility rates, builderS in the metropolitan area have been forced to rethink their plans for heating the homes now on their drawing boards.

title: Big Decisions
description: The Constitution does not so much define impeachment as declare its existence, its availability. The few words said about it give impeachment its legal characteristics and what is unsaid permits the play of political forces. Last week, the events in the first Presidential impeachment procedure in century had purely legal aspects, purely political ones and combinations of the twocombinations most scholars regard as in the true nature of the process.

title: Gayelord Hauser: On the Move at 80
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CalifThe tall couple walked past the jewelry section in I. Magnin's Wilshire Boulevard store recently on their way to the elevator.

title: Columbia Oarsmen Take Cup
SovietIndonesia Trade Pact
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 (Reuter)  Indonesia and the Soviet Union signed a new trade agreement today. The accord was signed by Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia and a Soviet Deputy Trade Minister, Ivan T. Grishin. The last such trade agreement expired in December, 1965.

title: News of the Screen
description: Carroll O'Connor, who plays that archbigot, Archie Bunker, in television's All in the Family, will also he playing the streets of New York next month. He will start facing cameras here in a starring role in a movie tentatively titled Law and Order. It will, he says, be his first movie since 1970, when he made Kelly's Heroes.

title: Kenon's Shooting Helps Keep Nets a Game in Front

description: GRACEHAM, Md,, March 23 (AP)Fewer blackbirds returned to the Graceham pines today to brave a second night of noisy human assault designed to evict them from the village.

title: Lawyers Have Become the Dominant Figures in Mitchell Trial
description: Inside the courtroom where John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, is facing charges that could send him to prison, his chief attorney, Peter Fleming Jr sits facing the jury, his eyes rarely losing contact with the men and women who will decide his client's fate.

title: Anguish of Dealers
description: The last three years were fat for General Motors 13,000 franchised dealers but that doesn't alleviate the pain of the past few lean months when sales have fallen 35.7 per cent.

title: Fulbright's Hardest Challenge
Prince Clyde, on and off the court
description: This could be the first coffeetable book about a Jock. Not just any jock, of course, but the Prince of Madison Square Garden, Walt (Clyde) Frazier, one of the few top athletes whose life style is perhaps even more extraordinary than his statistics. And that's what makes this glossy, widerthanusual sports book with its spectacular color photographs different from most: The statistics and basketball fundamentals play second fiddle to the Frazier life style.

title: Overseas, Big but Not Gargantuan
description: G.M. casts a large shadow on the international scene, though not large enough to satisfy its management or some of its critics. Last year, overseas sales amounted to a record $5.8billion, or 16 per cent of revenues. Net income from abroad was or 9 per cent of total earnings. Manufacturing and assembly plants dot 31 countries from Argentina to Zaire, employing 193,000 persons of whom only 360 are American citizens. In this coma try, 590,000 men and women worked for G.M. last year.

title: Artist Keeps Old New York Harbor Alive
description: At times intense, disdainful, sometimes sentimental but always honest, John A. Noble sat in his barge studio next to the graveyard of ships remembering when New York was a waterfront community.

title: Mrs. Price Has Son
description: COBLESKILL, H. Y., March 23A son was born March 6 to Mr. and Mrs. John McFerren Price at Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown. Mrs. Price, the former Miss Martha Jane MacDonald of Monroe, is an assistant professor of nursery education at the State University College here, where her husband is an associate professor of physical education. The.child has been named John MacDonald.

title: Astray Wins Coast Race, Pays $13.60
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 23 (AP)  Astray rallied in the stretch and then stood off a challenge from the 1973 winner, Big Spruce, to win the $112,000 San Luis Rey Stakes today at Santa Anita.

title: The President Is Trying to Hold Anyone On His Right
description: WASHINGTON  Over the past few weeks, President Nixon and his assistants have been pursuing a broad and expanding policy of appealing to the conservative constituency that makes up the mainstay of his vastly diminished support, a minority that might well prevent an impeachment conviction. Not only is the President actively campaigning with speeches and gestures designed to appease the right; there are indications that the White House is using its influence on Congress and on the bureaucracy to the same end. In the process, national policies and legislation are being altered.

title: Balance Sheet Shows Economic Progress and Moslem Unrest
description: HONG KONGDespite the fact that it has been under martial law for the past 18 months, the Philippines recently celebrated a new national holiday called Constitution Day. Waxing philosophic on the occasion, President Ferdinand E. Marcos said he was worried about a dangerous tendency towards exalting one man and focusing all power and authority towards that one man.

title: Creative Video for Artists
description: CAPE MAYSouth Jersey. artists are recording their work on videotape for distribution and broadcast by cabletelevision systems.

title: BAR GROUP ADOPTS OPENDOOR POLICY
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is taking steps to liberalize its membership requirements following renewed criticism of the organization as a Brahmindominated, Wall Streetoriented group with little knowledge about lawyers and judges in the outer boroughs.

title: Joan Slavin's Nuptials
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., March 23Miss Joan Margaret Slavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Slavin of Osterville, Mass., and John Winslow Rice were married here this afternoon in St. Johnes Episcopal Church by the Rev. W. Charles Hodgins, assisted by the Rev. Bruce L. Benshoff. The bridegroom, a teacher at the Berwick (Me.) Academy, is a son of Mrs. Stiles M. DeCker of Kittery Point, Me., and John H. Rice of Portsmouth.

title: Portuguese Maintain Traditions in Mineola

Antonio Da Silva, Roy Diego, Manny Nabica, and clustered friends scanned the scene while close by, longlocked young women, flanked protectively by their parents, waited to be asked to dance.

title: Bridge
description: A bad rule for the game of life, but a good rule for the game of bridge, is Never do today what you can put off until tomorrow. Postponing the play of a key suit is often the best policy for the declarer. Procrastination will often improve his chances, because he will have more information about the lie of the opposing cards when the time finally comes for action.

title: Calm Labor Front
description: When the energy crisis burst over Detroit last year, an unwritten understanding was quickly reached by General Motors and the United Auto Workers that G.M.'s energyinduced vulnerability would not be used as an advantage in local bargaining by either the company or the union.

title: Daughter to the Shutzers
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. William A. Shutzer on March 3 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Shutzer is the former Miss Fay Lampert of Topsfield, Mass. The child has been named Katherine Lauren. Mr. Shutzer is with the industrial department of Lehman Brothers, Inc.

title: DISSIDENT'S MOTHER IN PLEA TO PODGORNY
description: MOSCOW, March 23 (AP)The mother of the dissident writer Vladimir Bukovsky wrote to. President Nikolai V. Podgorny today, saying that she would take her son's place if a human sacrifice is necessary.

title: Poland, Here Comes The Bronx
description: The Bronx Community and College Symphony Orchestra is complaining that no one takes it seriously except for the Poles. This is not strictly true, since in the same breath it boasts that its concerts in a 1,000seat auditorium at the college are played to full houses. What all this means Is that while it is not getting sufficient recognition from neighboring boroughs and counties it has received an invitation from the Polish government to playa threeweek tour in Poland next August.

title: Plant NowUnder a Tent
description: THE vegetable seed packet directions carry explicit instructions: sow after all danger of frost is past. The neighbors warn of lurking danger: You don't dare plant until after May 15... remember a few years back when we had freezing temperatures right before Memorial Day?

Klein, WNYL Radio; Simon, New Yori., Stasio, Cue) and 3 mixed reviews (Watts, Post; Sanders, WABCTV; Clurman, Nation).

description: Beginning next fall, students who take the Scholastic Aptitude Test for college entrance will be given a new halfhour examination of competence in ;standard written English.

description: Portugal's brief Crisis of the Generals appears to be over, the generals dismissed and their followers unable to carry on. But the effects of the miniature revolution will be to lessen even further the Portuguese Army's diminishing will to fight the African wars the generals said are unwinnable.

description: William Black has not made a habit of doing things the, easy, conventional way. And friends of the philanthropist, who founded the Chuck Full O'Nuts restaurant chain, have come to expect the unexpected from him.

description: Miss ,Susan Jane. Rosenfield and Benjamin ,Ton Winter will be married this June in Montreal.

title: Smoking in Markets Banned
description: NEWTON, Mass., March 24 (AP)  Starting Tuesday, its will be illegal to smoke cigarettes, pipes or cigars in supermarkets and grocery stores in this Boston suburb. The ban contained in an ordinance that provides a maximum penalty of a $50 fine.

title: Bonnie M. Sherman Bride of Engineer
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 24Miss Bonnie May Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Sherman of Flushing, Queens, was married here this afternoon to William Bradford Twaddell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Q. Twaddell of Sacramento, Calif. Rabbi Sidney Sterling performed the ceremony at the Westbury Manor.

title: Purdue Five Triumphs
description: Purdue University won its first major postseason basketball competition yesterday with an 87.81 victory over Utah in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. Page 43.

title: Transit Union Votes Strike If Contract Is Not Settled
description: Four thousand shouting and stamping members of the Transport Workers Union voted yesterday to strike the city's subways and buses if they did not have a new contract by Sunday at midnight, when the present agreement expires.

title: People's Park: A Parable of the Nation
description: Behind the desk is a window that overlooks People's Park. People's Park in Berkeley has become worldfamous; it is for many both a political and religious symbol, a place where blood was shed and life lost in the cause of radical ecology and the struggle against the American political and economic Establishment.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 24Like bishops on the road to Rome, football coaches from every state in the country and Canada are converging here today for the beginning the 27th annual National Football Clinic, which bills itself as the nation's most outstanding football school. More than 4,200 coaches, most of them from high schools, will stream down the Boardwalk into Convention Hall, a procession of plastic rain jackets, blue blazers, and threebutton sweaters that advertise schools and towns across the countryNorth Schuylkill, Amityville, Speedway, Berryville, West Mifflin, Alepora, Camp Hill.

title: Fonda, Set to Open in Darrow, Is Still Excited by the Theater
description: When Henry Fonda had his first real part in a play, in 1925 in an Omaha community theater production of Merton of the Movies, he felt the excitement of being on stage. It was, he later remembered, like being 10 years old and playing cops and robbers.

description: Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union 6, told his members yesterday that an agreement had been reached with their international officers that would permit them to strike one, two or all three of New York City's daily newspapers if they could not arrive at a new contract settlement with the papers.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)  President and Mrs. Nixon returned to the White House by helicopter this evening after spending the weekend at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md.

description: RCA Records has named Thomas Z. Shepard as vice president for Red Seal artists and repertory and has appointed his predecessor, R. Peter Munves, as director of marketI. for Red Seal and special projects. Mr. Shepard, who assumes his new job April 1, has been director of Masterworks and original cast albums for Columbia Records. Mr. Munves, who joined RCA in 1970 as director of classical music, also came from Columbia Records.

description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y.Donna Blum does not believe in the Second Coming, as Seventhday Adventists do, but she is a convert to their way of cooking.

description: Jimmy Winkfield, a turnofthecentury black jockey who won the Kentucky Derby twice consecutively and then embarked on a picaresque riding career in Russia and Europe, died Saturday in the Paris suburb of MaisonsLaffitte. He was 91 years old.

description: Puerto Ricans, like other groups here, have suffered an identity crisis.

description: James R. Dumpson, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday that his aim in reorganizing the agency was to make the providing of such services as homemaking, day care and other help  rather than the simple distribution of welfare checks  the core of the operation.

title: Immaculata Women Win
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., March 24 (AP)Tina Krah and Theresa Shank scored 18 points each and Immaculata College of Pennsylvania defended its championship in women's collegiate basketball last night, defeating Mississippi College, 6853.

title: Niederhoffer Team Wins Squash Title
URBAN CENTER HERE CRITICIZED IN AUDIT
description: ALBANY, March 24A state audit of the Brooklyn Urban Center, which was designed to train disadvantaged youths for jobs and further education, disclosed today that more than 40 per cent of those enrolled in the program were more than 30 years old and that the effectiveness of the programs had not been evaluated.

title: Sine Nomine Employs Biblical T ext Well
description: Harry Salzman, conductor of the Sine Nomine Singers, is ever full of ideas for unusual programs,. and for the concert he and his group gave Saturday Night at Tully Hall, he turned for the text to the Bible and The Song of Songs. The music ranged from anonymous motets of the 13th century to Henry Brant's new Solomon's Garden, which was given its premiere, but all of the words of all of the works were from The Song of Songs.

title: CONSUMER GLOOM DEEPENS FURTHER
description: The consumer's confidence in the economy continued to decline in January and February, according to a study of 10,000 households by the Conference Board, an independent business research group.

title: Mary Van Vlaanderen Is Married
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 Miss Mary Van Vlaanderen, daughter of Mrs. William A. Kirmse of New York and Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and Cornelius H. Van Vlaanderen of Palm Beach, Fla., was married here yesterday evening to Jake Edward Kreider, son of Mrs. Joseph W. Gingras of Hollywood.

title: Helen Reddy Helps Y.W.C.A. in Newark Celebrate Women
description: NEWARK, March 24Helen Reddy, the singer whose popu lar hit I Am Woman has become a sort of feminist anthem, brought her show here last, night to help the Y.W.C.A. of Central New Jersey Celebrate Women!

title: Maffei Paces Italian Fencing Triumph
Monmouth Arts Festival Draws 500 Performer
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, March 24The campus of Monmouth College became a showcase for Monmouth County arts groups of all kinds this weekend.

title: Glenn Tetley Appointed Stuttgart Ballet Director
description: Glenn Tetley, the American choreographer working in Europe in recent years, has been appointed artistic director of the Stuttgart Ballet. He succeeds John Cranko, the South Africanborn choreographer who died last June.

title: The Mousetrap Moves After Ran of 22 Years
description: LONDON, March 24 (UPI)  The Mousetrap, the world's longestrunning play, moved to another house tonight after 8,860 performances at the Ambassador Theater.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Archdiocese of New York opened its annual appeal in 408 parishes for Catholie Charities and Education Services yesterday with a pontifical mass of concelebration at St. Patrick's Cathedral celebrated by Cardinal Cooke. The parish phase of the appeal has a goal of $3million.

title: State Is Pressed Anew To Improve Mental Care
description: The cost of mentalhealth care  which frequently is prolonged  is a source of continuing concern to those who are forced to use New Jersey's inadequate, obsolete facilities.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AFRICA Talk about parks in Africa, and you in think of a place occupied by Ernest Hemingway, white hunters and angry elephants. But there are cities in Africa, and the cities have parks, tooplaces where the city folk go to take a breather from urban turmoil. These parks, in cities of Niger, Upper Volta and the Ivory Coast, are the topic at 7:30 tonight for the Friends of Central Central Park and the Friends of Prospect Park, at Pace University auditorium, Spruce Street and Park Row, east of City Hall.

title: College Costs Will Rise by 9.4% in Fall
An Israeli War Hero In Demand as Critic
description: TEL AVIV, March 21For the Israelis, Motti Ashkenazi, a 33yearold infantry captain who looks owlishly through thick hornrimmed glasses, is an authentic hero of the October war. He commanded the only position on the BarLev Line at the Suez Canal that resisted the Egyptian onslaught and, although surrounded, was not overrun.

title: Reds Rally to Win, 10.8
4Hitter Stops White Sox
Yarborough Wins Atlanta 500 Race; Pearson Is Second
SuperPresidency
description: In his latest efforts to uphold the doctrine of executive privilege, President, Nixon is warning that excessive intrusion by Congress or other investigators upon the confidentiality of the Oval Office would leave future Presidents surrounded by a staff of yesmen and eunuchs. At the heart of an extensive report to the Senate Watergate committee by a panel of experts on government the charge that precisely such a condition did exist the Nixon White Housenot because of any lack of confidentiality but rather because of a dismaying misinterpretation of the Presidency.

title: MASON BRITTON, 91, M'GRAWHILL AIDE
description: Mason Britton, who retired as vice chairman of the board of the McGrawHill Publishing Company in 1941 and had been publisher of the American Machinist, a technical publication, died Tuesday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 91 years old and also lived in West Southport, Me.

title: Sealing History Behind Walls and Iron Bars
description: FROGMORE, N.C.For reasons that seem perfectly wellintentioned, Tennessee has announced it wishes to move James Earl Ray from its state penitentiary at Nashville into a Federal prison.

title: BADILLO, BEAME CLASH OVER JOBS
description: In a break with Mayor Beame, Representative Herman Badillo said yesterday that he would not head a cabinetlevel committee on ethnic tensions until the Mayor appointed more Puerto Ricans to high positions in city government.

title: Red Smith
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Maroh 24 The Avila Hotel perches on a mountain high over this capital city which, someone has said, looks like a Los Angeles built by Mexican architect. There in a handsome, breezy lounge, Dick Sadler stood explaining the sweet science of boxing to an international audience. I don't give a damn if they put three women in there, he was saying. I don't give a damn if they put three mules in. I don't give a damn if the guy counts onze, douze or what language. I'm talking about the best interests of fair play, justice and compassion for all concerned. I'm talking about procedure. Now for the benefit of those who don't know what procedure is, there was these 13 colonies got together and says we write down here this constitution and all of the 13 colonies can submit laws from their own constitutions and the Supreme Court renders the decision as long as the local laws don't conflict with the national laws or that state and that's the whole jujitsu.

title: Personal Finance: Evidence for Tax Deductions
description: Judge William M. Taylor Jr., in Dallas, in a broad decision on entertainment deductions, has ruled that businessman is entitled to take tax deductions for business entertainment even when his records of that entertainment do not always show a business connection.

title: HOUSING ACTIVITY OFF 40% IN CITY
description: The pace of housing construction, which had zoomed in 1971 and 1972 in response to a variety of governmental and private actions, plummeted last year by 40 per cent in New York City and by 29 per cent in the state as a whole, state housing officials reported yesterday.

title: 5 Die in Island House Fire
description: LITTLE DEER ISLE, Me., March 24 (AP)Adefective oilfired stove was the apparent cause of a house fire on this Penobscot Bay island that took the lives of a fisherman, his wife and three children, officials said. The victims were identified as Herbert Grindle Jr., 29 years old, his wife Linda, 19, and their children, Herbert 3d, 4, Tracy Lynn, 5, and Tracy Lynn Eaton, 1.

title: Pincay Wins 5
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 24 AP)Laffit Pincay returned from a fiveday suspension to ride five winners, including Tallahto in the featured $66,000 Santa Barbara Handicap, at Santa Anita today.

title: Films: Honesty in Sillitoe's Ragman's Daughter
New Jersey Briefs
description: Three masked gunmen held five persons captive in South Orange, N. J., home Saturday night while they ransacked the house and made off with two fur coats, jewelry, $1,200 in cash and an automobile.

title: Slogans in China Cite Attacks on the New Cultural Revolution
description: HONG KONG, March 24 Slogans in praise of revolutionary violence and revolutionary rebellion were sounded in China last week, along with attacks on reactionaries at home and abroad who were said to be striving to attack, slander and sabotage the movement to revive the values of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Dean Expected to Provide Telling Testimony Today
description: John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel, is expected to give key testimony today in the Federal court conspiracy trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, according to United Press International.

title: The Screen: Badlands Is Ferociously American
Dayan's Visit to U.S. Reportedly Periled
description: TEL AVIV, March 24An Israeli source said today that Defense Minister Moshe Dayan might cancel his visit to Washington for indirect disengagement talks with Syria this week unless the Egyptians removed what the Israelis say are illicit artillery pieces in the Sinai.

title: Senate Sources Say Rebozo Testimony Was Unclear on Some Details About $100,000 From Hughes
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Charles G. Rebozo was unable to recall with certainty for the Senate Watergate committee last week several details of his receipt of a $100,000 cash payment he received from the Howard Hughes organization nearly four years ago, according to sources close to the panel's investigation.

title: Exceptional Bill
description: The Assembly acted to remove a serious source pollution from the state's waters the other day when voted to forbid the discharge of oil or gasoline from outboard motorboats. But for reasons never adequately explainedand certainly impossible to justifythe bill's sponsors excluded from the ban the waters of Long Island, including the Sound, where motorboat owners concentrate in largest numbers.

title: Landmark Nuclear Pact Up for Review
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Some 25 nations will gather in Geneva next month to begin an international review of the treaty to limit the spread of nuclear weapons to additional nations.

title: $375,000 BOND 15 SET IN BAR FIREBOMBING
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 24 (UPI)Ernest J. Burton Jr. was held today under $375,000 bond on 32 charges, including murder, attempted murder and arson, in the deaths of eight persons in a fire in a neighborhood bar from which he had been ejected.

title: Beame and Wilson Vow Support Of Soviet Jews at a Rally Here
description: A pledge of solidarity with Soviet Jews was given by New York's Jewish community yesterday at ceremonies led by Governor Wilson and Mayor Beame.

description: Four thousand shouting and stamping members of the Transport Workers Union voted yesterday to strike the city's subways and buses if they did not have a new contract by Sunday at midnight, when the present agreement expires.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 25, 1974

title: Arab Foreign Ministers Meeting In Tunis on Wide Agenda Today
description: TUNIS, March 24 (UPI)Arab League foreign ministers will meet here tomorrow to discuss prospects for IsraeliSyrian talks on troop disengagement on the Golan Heights and preparations for a new Arab summit meeting.

title: Amin Survives Uganda Army Clash
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 24 Units of the Uganda Army clashed for several hours last night, but the fighting ended this morning and Gen. Idi Amin, the controversial President of the East African nation, was still in power.

title: About New York
description: Eric Lander, who may be the smartest kid in town, was talking about Arthur, his brother. Arthur does most of the cooking, and he gets very creative, Eric was saying. Last night, mother and I were sitting here with a chicken cutlet, and we decided to wait to see what Arthur would do with it. Well, he made a chicken cutlet omelet, with herbs and spices. He's an amazing kid, really.

title: Kissinger and the Question of Policy Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The day after he was named Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger pledged that I will conduct the foreign policy of the United States regardless of religious and national heritage.

title: MAN, 52, IS SLAIN ON THE WEST SIDE
description: A 52yearold man, Pack Teng Lem, was robbed and stabbed fatally Saturday night on the northeast corner of 70th Street and Broadway.

title: Jay Sanford, Writers'Agent At International Famous, 65
description: Jay Sanford, a literary and motion picture agent with International Famous Agency, Inc., died Friday of a heart attack here. He was 65 years old and lived at 2 Washington Square, Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Report Says Mills Got Election Funds From Dairy Coop
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills's brief Demcratic Presidential campaign got early financial support in corporate contributions from the nation's largest dairy cooperative, according to a report on the dairy group's political dealings.

description: This weekend the Joffrey Ballet passed the threequarter mark in its month's spring season at the City Center 55th Street Theater. It has been beset by sickness and injuries, resulting in ballets being canceled and casts being changed. However, the morale of the company is such that it seems to be managing to keep its head above water and its feet above ground.

The determination shown by Nicole and numerous other girls has traumatized Little League baseball in New Jersey and threatens to revolutionize it across the nation.

title: Books of The Times
description: Mental hospitals in America are depressing because of what they are, and dreams of what mental hospitals in America could be are depressing because they simply aren't. So Bruno Bettelheim would appear to have written in A Home for the Heart a book that is twice depressingfor it is both a scathing indictment of psychiatric institutions in this country, and a master plan for a seemingly utopian alternative. It scores the typical American hospital for being everything its inmates don't need to regain their sanity an alien, antiseptic environment whose implicit message is that they are irredeemable outcasts from humanity. And it insists that such institutions be replaced by just the oppositeintimate surroundings that tell the patient he is just like you or me, only more so. More precisely, what Dr. Bettelheim insists on is the model of the Orthogenic School of the University of Chicago a hospital that specializes in the treatment of autistic and severely schizophrenic children, which Dr. Bettelheim directed from 1944 until his retirement last year at the age of 70, and about which he has already written three books, Love Is Not Enough, Truants From Life and The Empty Fortress. In these books he dealt with the therapeutic techniques he applied at the Orthogenic School, and with case histories that illustrated them. Now, in A Home for the Heart, he explains the grand design of the school and details why its theory of total milieu therapy might apply to the treatment of mental patients everywhere.

title: Bruins Win, Clinch Title in N.H.L. East

As he arrived, dock workers began a work stoppage over a minor dispute and closed the port for 24 hours.

Rule, president of the American Broadcasting Company, that freedom of information is indivisible.
