title: Hays Draft of Campaign Financing Is Said to Weaken 1971 Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Representative Wayne L. Hays has privately circulated a, draft of his proposed campaign financing legislation that would seriously weaken the reporting and enforcement provisions of the 1971 Federal election campaign act, Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: EXPERT OPPOSES NEW NERVE GASES
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 A British expert on chemical warfare contends that the disadvantages of a new family of nerve gases that the United States Army wants to produce far outweigh any potential advantages.

title: G.O.P Endorsement for Levitt Rejected
description: Some Republicans, including Governor Wilson, are talking about a Republican endorsement this year for Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, but some Democratic leaders, including the Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, are making it plain they will not welcome such an endorsement.

title: Sabres LoseGilbert Gets 2
OLDEST MOON ROCK HAS BEEN FOUND
description: HOUSTON, March 24 (AP)Discovery of the oldest moon rock and the youngest meteorite known to have hit the earth have been reported by lunar scientists who examined samples collected by the Apollo astronauts.

title: Newfoundland, Butt of Canadian Jokes, Has Lots of Aid and the Last Laugh
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland Twentyfive years after formally becoming part of Canada, this bleak, rocky island remains in many ways a land apart, as independent in outlook as the crusty fishermen who work its rugged coast.

title: Keeping the Children Safe: Signs of Hope, Voices of Concern
description: If you look back at the safety hazards faced by generations of children, it might seem that there was a kind of pseudoDarwinism at work: the survival of the luckiest.

title: R. E. M'GEE, DIES; HEADED TENNECO
description: Reginald E. McGee, president since 1972 and chief executive officer since 1974 of Tenneco Inc., a leading diversified company, died Saturday evening apparently of a heart attack, at the Columbia Lakes Conference Center near West Columbia, Tex. A resident of Houston, where the company has its headquarters, he was 57 years old and had been presiding at a meeting of the conference board at the center.

title: Civil Rights of Mental Patients Are Debated by Medical and Legal Professions
description: Psychiatrists and civil liberties groups are engaged in a bitter struggle in this city and state to decide which group will win the dominant role in determining when and if mental patients are released from public and private hospitals.

title: BAKER BIDS NIXON GIVE HOUSE PANEL RELEVANT TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The ranking Republican on the Senate Watergate committee, Senator. Howard H. Baker Jr., of Tennessee, urged President Nixon today to turn all relevant tapes and documents over to the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Youths in Queens Warned by Judge On Making Threats
description: Three teenaged youths were released with a judge's warning yesterday after being charged with menacing the manager of he JackintheBox Restaurant in St. Albans, Queens, the scene of a wild furnituresmashing and windowbreaking ramage by 200 gang members last month.

title: Democrats on Economic Panel Recommend $10Billion Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Democratic majority of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee urged today a $10billion tax reduction, benefiting mainly lowand moderateincome taxpayers, to expand consumer demand and insure against recession this year.

title: Amin Survives Uganda Army Clash
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 24 Units of the Uganda Army clashed for several hours last night, but the fighting ended this morning and Gen. Idi Amin, the controversial President of the East African nation, was still in power.

title: Dr. R. V. Clayman Weds Miss Heineman
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24Miss Carol Heineman, who is working for a Ph. D. degree in microbiology at the University of Minnesota, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Ralph V. Clayman, a surgical interne at University Hospital in Minneapolis. Rabbi Edgar J. Magnin performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Bel Air.

title: East Title Tennis Set
description: The annual Eastern men's indoor tennis championship will open Friday, April 12, at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx. Applications, which close Sunday, are being accepted at the center, 162d Street and Jerome Avenue

title: BRAZILIAN PRESS FACES NEW CURBS
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 24Despite assurances from Brazil's new Government that censorship would be eased, official censors last week issued a, ban on press mention of devils, angels and streaking.

title: Girls a Hit in Debut on Diamond
description: Nicole Hottendorf, her brown; hit two home runs past a wall pony tail dancing behind her, of boys Saturday afternoon asi practice for the Little League baeball season opened in Tenally. Later she caught a fly and showed she could pitch better than many of the boys.

title: 3,000 Delegates at Chicago Meeting Organize a National Coalition of Labor Union Women
description: CHICAGO, March 24More than 3,000 women members of 58 labor unions voted into existence this weekend a national organization to be called the Coalition of Labor Union Women.

title: STUDENTS IN INDIA CONTINUE PROTEST
description: PATNA, India, March 24The students of the troubled Indian state of Bihar have pledged to continue their struggle, until the state government is toppled and the legislature is dissolved to provide for new elections.

title: 4Hitter Stops White Sox
TOOL SHIPMENTS UP IN FEBRUARY
description: Both shipments and orders of machine toolsan important indication of industrial expansion plansgrew during February, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: Cambodian Monks Appeal to Rebels To Spare Old City
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 24 (AP)Thousands of saffronrobed Buddhist monks gathered in a stadium here today to protest the destruotion of historical and religious landmarks in fighting in the old royal capital of Phsar Oudong, 20 miles northwest of Phnom Penh. Demonstrators carried many banners declaring: We Want Peace.

title: Blues Trounced By Flyers, 41
GEORGE W. PHILLIPS
description: George W. Phillips, a retired lawyer and partner in the former firm of Cutting, Phillips & Hall, died Saturday at his home, 1150 Park Avenue. He was 91 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
White's Status as Yankee Is Out of Focus
OilExport Price Raised 30c a Barrel by Canada
description: The Canadian National Energy Board announced yesterday that it had increased the export price for Canadian oil for April by 30 cents a barrel.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Stock Market Indecisive; BigBlock Trading Slows
Victory Over Drugs
description: With each new claim of cure or assertion about success rates in rehabilitating narcotics addicts, the often acerbic debate over how to treat addiction has quickened. Yet it has always reverted to standoff between advocates of group psychotherapy, or drugfree treattreatment, and proponents of chemotherapy, or treatment with such drugs as methadone, a synthetic narcotic.

title: Trainer. Races at Big A Where Real Money Is
description: Ramon Coto has an extensive background in racing, having been the security head at Oriental Park and at the dog Mick in preCastro Havana. A strategic move to Puerto Rico was in order a decade and a half ago, and since then Coto has had further experience in the thoroughbred activity, as a turf editor, purchasing agent,. trainer and owner.

title: Bridge: California Team Sets Pace In Spring Nationals Final
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 25  A team dominated by players from the East Coast of the United States and a Californian quartet battled for the national men's team championship in the final of the, American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here tonight, with most of their rivals far behind.

title: Big Board Now Listing All Treasury Securities
description: Seven Treasury bonds and 30 Treasury notes have been approved for listing on the New York Stock Exchange and will be eligible for trading effective today, the exchange said yesterday.

title: ESTHER M. DAVIS
description: Esther Michelson Davis, sculptor and painter, died Sunday at her home, 10 Park Avenue. She was 80 years old, and the widow of Harold M. Davis, who headed a printing and publishing company.

title: Business Briefs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday asked the tenth United States Circuit Court Appeals to reverse an antitrust judgment brought against it in favor of the Telex Corporation.

title: A Missing Element
description: SAN FRANCISCOPolitics in California is almost always an interesting and important business, as befits the most populous state in the Union. California is on the western edge of things and has two of the nation's most fascinating cities, as well as reputation for being first to exemplify what will later become national trends. But this election year, something seems to be missing.

title: Victory Over Drugs
description: With each new claim of cure or assertion about success rates in rehabilitating narcotics addicts, the often acerbic debate over how to treat addiction has quickened. Yet it has always reverted to standoff between advocates of group psychotherapy, or drug free treattreatment, and proponents of chemotherapy, or treatment with such drugs as methadone, a synthetic narcotic.

title: Senate Votes for a Study Of Court Ruling on Taxes
description: TRENTON, March 25 (AP)The state Senate voted today to establish two committees to study the impact of a State Supreme Court ruling requiring an overhaul in the financing of public education.

title: Metropolitan
description: More than 4,715 disabled poor in New York State are being removed from Federal Supplemental Security Income rolls as of next Sunday on the ground they do not meet stricter Federal definitions, though they had qualified under last year's state standard. They now will have to try to gqt back on welfare. The Social Security Administration said those affected included 4,160 mothers who had been on the city's welfare family rolls but had been reclassified last Jan. to get transferred to the Federal program with higher grants.

title: Public Employe Leaders Ask U. S. Law Granting Right to Bargain Collectively
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The leaders of three public employe organizations urged today the enactment of a Federal law guaranteeing the right of all Government workers to bargain collectively.

title: May 1 Will Be Loyalty Day
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)President Nixon signed proclamations today designating May 1 as Loyalty Day and the two weeks beginning May 19 and 26 as World Trade Weeks.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 10 (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWNBC, 7:30 P.M.) HARNESS RACING Yonkers Raceway, Central and Yonkers Avenues, 8 P.M. Freehold (N. J.) Raceway, 1:30 P.M.

title: Foreman At 224 For Bout
10 Food Places Fail A 2d Sanitary Test By City Department
4 COUNTS DROPPED FOR 2 IN DRUG RAIDS
description: ALTON, III., March 25 (AP) A Federal judge acquitted two of 10 narcotics agents today on four counts of civil rights violations in drug raids Last year However, the pair still face two conspiracy charges.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 25 (AP)Workmen erected 165 yards of triplecatch fencing today at the spot where Peter Revson, the American racing driver, died in a highspeed crash Friday at Kyalami Circuit. Workmen started on the job Sunday, said Francis Tucker, chairman of the South African Motor Racing Club. We didn't even have time for a quote, but at a time like this the expense is not important.

title: Impeachment Debate Argued and Scuttled in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 25A bitter debate about whether to allow a debate on the impeachment of President Nixon gripped the Senate this afternoon but ended as it beganwith the impeachment petition referred to the Committee on Finance, almost certainly forever.

title: Boyle Murder Trial Delayed at Start
description: MEDIA, Pa., March 25 The murder trial of W. A. Boyle opened here today after hours of unexplained conferences among lawyers in the judge's chambers,

title: U.S. Replies to Networks On Antitrust Suit Motive
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to dismiss arguments by the major television networks that antitrust suits had been filed against them for political motives.

title: SOVIET WON'T LET 12 AMERICANS GO
description: MOSCOW, March 25  In the late nineteenforties, when Walter J. Stoessel Jr. was a young consular officer here, he interceded on behalf of a Brooklynborn woman in Lithuania who was trying to go home.Mr. Stoessel returned to Moscow last month as the new American Ambassador. He found that the Amen, Eleanor Iechepene, was still waiting for an exit visa after 30 years.

title: Window Washer Convicted Of Dual Murder in Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 25  Robert D. Petrarca, a 26yearold window washer, was found guilty today of firstdegree murder in the death of an Upper Montclair matron and her married daughter last May 14.

title: Five in Family Die in Fire
description: FLINT, Mich., March 25 (AP) A mother and her four children died last night in a fire in their home in Davison Township, 20 miles east of here. The State Police identified the victims as Linda Tyler, 26 years old, Rhonda, 9; Lora, 7; Larry, 6, and Tammy, 3.

title: TwoThirds Found to Gain In Adult Education Program
description: WASHINGTON, March (AP)Twothirds of the students in adult educaticin programs gained proficiency in reading to the first nationwide study of a program that has cost $320million over seven years.

title: Assembly Votes for a Public Advocate
description: TRENTON, March 25  A new branch of state government that promises to be highly controversial by requiring the state to advocate the public interest in a wide range of areas was unanimously approved this afternoon by the New Jersey Assembly.

title: Jersey's Dumping Ban Is Ruled Invalid
description: TRENTON, March 25  A state environmental law prohibiting the dumping of outofstate garbage in New Jersey was declared unconstitutional by the State Superior Court today on the ground that the ban constituted an unlawful', interference with interstate commerce.

title: Church Unit Helps Manhattan Tenants Press Complaints
description: The report noted that at 25 Cummings Street the bathtub and kitchen floor had been repaired and at 574 West 176th Street the ceiling to the bathroom had been newly plastered.

title: Police Charge Two Aides With Selling of Marijuana
description: Two civilian employes in the Communications Bureau at Police Headquarters were arrested yesterday on a charge of having sold marijuana to undercover policemen in the building at 1 Police Plaza.

title: Julien Hyer, Lawyer, Dies; ExLions International Head
description: FORT WORTH, March 25 (UPI)  Julien C. flyer, lawyer and a former president of Lions International, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.

title: LOUISE TAYLOR
description: Louise Taylor, a soprano who sang on the opera and concert stage for more than 50 years and had been a member of the Chicago Opera Company and the Cosmopolitan Opera Company of New York, died Sundayat the Sanger Nursing Home, 500 West 57th Street. Her age was 89.

title: 2 Rob Queens Dental Lab Of Gold and Silver Powder
description: Two armed robbers stole $50,000 to $100,000 worth of gold and silver from a dental laboratory in Queens yesterday afternoon, the police reported. Detectives said the holdup had occurred at Coramco, Inc., 3116 Hunters Point Avenue,Long Island City.

title: Judge Chides Little League Lawyer as Out of Tune on Girls
description: NEWARK, March 25  A lawyer defending Little League baseball as a masculine preserve was told by a judge in Superior Court here today that he was philosophically out of time with the whole idea of Isexdiscrimination statutes.

title: World Theater Festival Planned for Bicentennial
description: A U.S. Bicentennial World Theater Festival, which in 1976 would bring to America 42 of the world's leading institutional and commercial theater compavies, was announced yesterday by Alexander H. Cohen, the Broadway producer who is executive producer of the festival, The World Theater Festival will be the theater's major contribution to the Bicentennial, Mr. Cohen said.

title: FransCanada Pipeline Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)In a letter to Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton, released today 22 Senators have urged the Nixon Administration to approve a transCanada natural gas pipeline that would benefit the Middle West. The Senators expressed opposition to an alternate proposal that would pipe the gas across Alaska,

title: Wilkens to Skip Finale
description: CLEVELAND, March 25 (UPI)The Cleveland Cavaliers captain, Lenny Wilkens, will sit out tomorrow night's season finale against the Bulls in Chicago because he pulled a hamstring muscle in last night's victory over the New York Knicks.

title: DR. RAYMOND W. SMITH
description: Dr. Raymond Worden Smith, an obstetrician for more than 25 years, died Sunday of a heart attack at the Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I., where he, was a staff member. His age was 70, and he lived in Hempstead, L.I.

title: JUDGE RESTRAINS PRINTERS AT NEWS
description: Federal Judge Murray I. Gurfein signed an order yesterday continuing until next Monday a temporary restraining order enjoining New York Typographical Union No. 6 from holding union meetings or taking other action that would interfere with operations at The Daily News. But the judge reserved decision on the request of The News for a preliminary injunction.

title: PLAN IS OFFERED FOR EQUITY LIFE
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25A plan to safeguard policyholders of the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America was unveiled here today for court approval.

title: AUSTRALIA IN PLEA TO U.S, AND SOVIET
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 25 Australia has called on the United States and the Soviet Union to exercise mutual restrata' in the Indian Ocean.

title: 16 INDICTED HERE PAYOFF RACKET IN MEAT INDUSTRY
description: Three officials of the meatcutters union and 13 executives of metropolitan area supermarket chains were charged yesterday with incometax evasion and other Federal crimes following an investigation into a widespread system of payoffs and kickbacks in the meat industry here.

title: McGuire Coach of Year
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 25 (AP)Al McGuire, whose Marquette team played North Carolina State for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball title tonight, was selected yesterday as the university division coachoftheyear by the National Association of Basketball Coaches.

title: Treasury Bills Rose At the Weekly Sale
BOND PRICES OFF IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Prices of corporate and taxexempt bonds were lower yesterday but the Government market turned mixed.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 26, 1974 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M.

title: Saudi Oil Output Up By Million Barrels
description: Saudi Arabia, the largest Arab oil producer and the world's biggest petroleum exporter, has increased her production by 1 million barrels a day to approximately the preOctober embargo level of 8.3 million barrels a day.

title: Unit of Indiana Standard Seeks F.P.C. Rate Approval
description: The Amoco Production Company, a subsidiary of Standard Oil of Indiana, said yesterday it had asked the Federal Power Commission for a rate increase on natural gas produced at two Kansas fields in order to finance further gas exploration and development.

title: Two Killed in Dune Buggy
description: AMARILLO, Tex., March 25 (UPI)Darwin Bagley, 36 years old, bought a dune buggy and asked Judy Burley, 23, to take a ride with him. An hour later they were dead. The dune buggy flipped over in an Amarillo vacant lot, crushing both of them, the police said yesterday.

title: Advertising: Mailgram Markets
description: This week in New York Western Union has begun a multimedia advertising effort that has proven successful for it in six test markets.

title: New Dance Fund Seeks Business Support
description: A national fundraising organization has been formed to seek support from business exclusively for the dance field.

title: BID TO U.S, MADE BY NORTH KOREA
description: HONG KONG, March 25 (Reuters)  North Korea announced today that it had proposed talks with the United States on peace accord to, replace the Korean armistice agreement signed in 1953. It said the proposal was made in a letter addressed to the United States Congress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: People in Sports
description: The great World Series catch is only a memory as far as the Atlanta Braves are concerned and yesterday they released Ron Swoboda unconditionally.

title: Top Republican on House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Jesse Edward Hutchinson is a millionaire who wears white socks, even with his conservative blue business suits. Despite his wealth, despite his access to the glamour, sophistication and power of Wash ington, the Michigan Representative holds on to his simple ways, the ways of the small town residents and farmers of the rolling hills on the southern border of Michigan the wealthy strawberry, apple and grape growers, the dairymen, the Christian Reformed Church members, the conservatives, John Birchers and others who elected him to Congress.

title: Even Pauses For a Female Streaker
description: It wasn't Dashing Dan; it was a young woman who brciught streaking to the Long Island Rail Road yesterday morning.

title: Fragile Tie
description: There was always more opportunism than trust in the alliance that Representative Herman Badillo formed with Mayor Beame shortly before the municipal election last November. On that basis, it is hardly a surprise find Mr. Badillo denouncing the Mayor and refusing go ahead with his preelection commitment to chair committee to ease New York City's racial and ethnic tensions.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Indochina War Appears Only Subway Stops Away
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 21  In Saigon and Phnom Penh the rumble of artillery at night is a reminder that people are probably being killed not far away. The magic words become outgoing and incoming. Outgoing is intended to kill Communists or those who support them. Incoming is to kill you, if you have no luck. In Saigon, there is no in coming. In Phnom Penh there is incoming and outgoing.

title: Study at American U. Disputes President on Distorted Newscasts
description: Three teams of graduate students in broadcast journalism at the American University in Washington have found a charge by President Nixon that television network news was outrageous, vicious, distorted to be generally without substantiation. The students findings were based on a study of the twoweek period before the President's attack was made last Oct. 26. Three teams of graduate stu

title: Cigarette Smoking Up As Tobacco Use Falls
description: WASHINGTON, March 25, (Reuters)  The world is smoking more but is using less leaf tobacco, the Agriculture Department's Foreign Agricultural Service reported today.

title: FOUR SEASONS ROLE SENDS GRAY TO JAIL
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 25 (AP)Thomas J. Gray, cofounder of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, surrendered at the United States Medical Center in Springfield, Mo., today to begin a oneyear term for mail fraud.

title: Dave Anderson
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 25Before all the commotion began over the nationality of tomorrow night's referee, George Foreman put the ,situation in perspective. I got my referee with me, the clampion said, clenching his fists and holding them aloft. I don't need a referee. God gave me my referee 25 years ago.

title: Straphangers Cliffhang
description: A dreary ritualism prevails in the biennial negotiations for new wage agreements covering New York City's mass transit lifeline: On the Sunday before the old con tracts expire thousands of subway and bus workers gather in Manhattan Center to vote almost unanimous authorization for a strike, after which New Yorkers hold their breath until the Mayor's factfinders come up with eleventhhour recommendations that settle everything.

title: KISSINGER BEGINS TALKS IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, March 25Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger began their series of discussions today with eight hours of talks in the Kremlin devoted mostly to Europe and the prospects for new SovietAmerican agreement on limiting strategic weapons.

title: Jackson, Miss., Agrees To Hire More Blacks
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 25 (UPI)The city of Jackson agreed today to hire more blacks for its police and fire departments. A consent decree was signed ending two Federal suits,

title: British Leyland Discloses A Heavy 6Month Deficit
description: LONDON, March 25 (UPI)The world energy crisis and the threeday work week gave Britain's biggest auto concern, the British Leyland Motor Corporation, a heavy loss for the first half of its fiscal year ending in March, Lord Stokes, chairman, told the annual meeting in London today.

title: BELGIUM TO OFFER OIL COMPROMISE
description: BRUSSELS, March 25As Belgium began to feel severe gasoline and heatingoil shortages Premier Edmond Leburton amloufounced the working out of a compromise formula today in efforts to break a threemonth deadlock over retail oil price increases.

title: END OF MAGAZINE ON ARCHITECTURE
description: Architectural Forum will cease publication with its March issue, Billboard Publications, Inc., announced yester day.

title: Bonn's Eastern Troubles
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt's chief Cabinetlevel negotiator with the East, Egon Bahr, recently described West Germany's contacts with Communist East Germany in these terms: For decades we had no relations. Now we have bad relations. That's a kind of progress, too!

title: Car Makers Find Hope in Sales Trend
description: DETROIT, March 25After months of gloom auto executives and some dealers are looking over the sales charts of the last few weeks and beginning to see small signs of encouragement.

title: N.B.A. To Vote on Bid By San Diego Tomorrow
description: National Basketball Association club owners will meet in Los Angeles tomorrow to vote on the possibility of adding San Diego as a 19th team for next season. A couple of weeks ago New Orleans was accepted as an 18th team.

title: NonMessage on Schools
description: Without offering a single new idea, President Nixon managed in his radio broadcast on education to run the gamut from mischievous rhetoric on busing to misleading explanations of aid for college students.

title: PLAN FOR U.S. ROAD ON HUDSON PUSHED
description: Despite protests from community planners, key state and city official's appeared ready yesterday to press for Federal designation of the entire Hudson. shore corridor from the Battery to the George Washington Bridge as an interstate expressway route.

title: Guilty in Dual Murder
description: After less than three hours of deliberation, a jury in New Jersey convicted a 26yearold window washer, Robert D. Petrarca, of the murder last May of Mrs. Renee Cali of Upper Montclair and her daughter, Mrs. Leslie Grant. Details on Page 45.

title: LowFat, LowCholesterol Diet Called Possible Bar to Some Forms of Cancer
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. March 25The lowfat, lowcholesterol diet that is widely recommended as a preventive measure against heart disease may also protect against cancer of the colon and rectum, the nation's second largest source of cancer deaths, a leader in preventive medicine suggested here today.

title: People and Business
description: The Regional Railroad Act, under which the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads will be restructured, is the closest thing to nationalization of anything ever proposed in the railroad industry, according to W. Thomas, Rice, president of Seaboard Coast Line Industries.

title: Library of Congress (320 Miles of Shelves) Has an Opening and a Problem
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 it is not exactly your neighborhood library.

title: Notes on People
description: Galina Panov, the nonJewish wife of Valery Panov, the former star of the Leningrad Kirov ballet, says that her mother is mentally ill and is preventing her immigration to Israel because she hates Panov as a Jew.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AFRICAN SUN (Farrell), Dar.esSalaam April 13 and Mombasa 28; sails from Joralemon St., Brooklyn.

title: Maryland Ranked First in Lacrosse
At Graveyard Rallies, China Resurrects Crimes of Imperialist'
description: HONG KONG, March 25 Rallies have been held at graveyards in China as part of what appears to be an organized effort to remind the Chinese people of atrocities committed by foreigners when weak and pliable governments opened the country to them.

title: Guilty in Dual Murder
description: After less than three hours of deliberation, a jury in New Jersey convicted a 26yearold window washer, Robert D. Petrarca, of the murder last May of Mrs. Renee Cali of Upper Montclair and her daughter, Mrs. Leslie Grant. Details on Page 45.

title: Reduced Birth Rate Cuts Enrollments In Lower Grades
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Enrollment in the nation's elementary schools has dropped 2.4 per cent in the current school year, the Census Bureau said today. It was the third straight year of decline because of the nation's lower birth rate.

title: People in Sports
description: The great World Series catch is only a memory as far as the Atlanta Braves are concerned and yesterday they released Ron Swoboda unconditionally.

title: DeBusschere: Thanks for the Memories
Philippine Moslem Rebels Prepare for a Long War
description: JOLO, the PhilippinesPeople are slowly returning to this island town of ruins to try to begin their lives again. But nothing is settled.

title: The Presidential Connection
description: In the summer of 1923, President Warren G. Harding turned to his Secretary of Commerce, Herbert Hoover, and asked to speak to him in private. When they were alone, the President said to the future President, If you knew of a great scandal in our Administration, would you for the good of the country and the party expose publicly or would you bury it?

title: Reds Nolan to Test Shoulder in Minors
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 25 (UPI)The Cincinnati Reds announced that Gary Nolan, pitcher, would be optioned to Indianapolis of the American Association when the farm club breaks camp in midApril.

title: GIRL, 5, DIES IN FIRE; PARENTS ARE SAVED
description: A 5yearold girl died yesterday and her mother was critically injured in a fire in their home at 70.21 Ingram Street in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Irish Find Arms on Ship But They're Their Own
description: DUBLIN, March 26 (AP)Irish troops searching a freighter for smuggled weapons found 134 crates containing small arms and ammunition today, but discovered they had been ordered by their own Government.

title: Thousands Get Top Quality Food in Response to Hearst Kidnapping Demands
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 25  The free food program that Randolph A. Hearst hopes will lead to the release of his kidnapped daughter was resumed here today with the promised distribution of top quality groceries.

title: Court Voids Law Barring Contemptuous Use of Flag
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Supreme Court, on a vote of 6 to 3, struck down as unconstitutionally vague today a Massachusetts law that made it, a crime to treat the United States flag contemptuously.

title: I.R.S. Official Who Praised Nixons Promoted to Head Philadelphia Office
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Internal Revenue official who praised President Nixon for the careful preparation of his 1970 and 1971 tax returns and who accepted them, without change, after a very brief audit has been promoted to head the agency's Philadelphia regional office.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Umberto's Clam House, the Little Italy restaurant Mulberry and Hester Streets where Joseph Gallo was fatally shot in 1972, won the approval of the state Appellate Division for a wine license yesterday. The State Liquor Authority had denied the license, contending that Robert Ianniello, president of the restaurant's corporate owner, Osbro Restaurant, Inc., was fronting for others and thus was not the sole party in interest. However, the Appellate justices wrote that they had found insufficient factual support for the authority's stance.

title: M'CORD'S APPEAL BRINGS REBUTTAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)James W. McCord Jr. might have stopped the Watergate coverup at his conspiracyburglary trial in January, 1973, but deliberately chose not to, the special Watergate prosecutor said today.

title: SAMUELS RELEASES NAMES OF BACKERS
description: Five months before the deadline for filing such information with the New York Secretary of State, Howard J. Samuels released the names yesterday of 951 persons who have contributed and lent a total of $360,000 to his campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Asphalt Trust Suit Will Be Reviewed By Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Federal antitrust law applies to a dispute involving California producers of asphalt and asphaltic concrete.

title: Syria and Israel Continue Shelling Duel for 14th Day
description: TEL AVIV, March 25 (Reuters)Syrian and Israeli forces shelled each other today for the 14th day on the Golan Heights front.

title: ZIEGLER PRESSES PANEL FOR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The White House escalated its criticism of the House Judiciary Committee today, suggesting that its staff should perhaps work late into the evening to complete quickly a preliminary assessment of the impeachment evidence against President Nixon.

title: 400 Protest Proposal for Cuts at Schools in Queens
description: Four hundred mothers, chanting and carrying picket signs, marched in the 20degree cold, in front of Public School 179 in Fresh Meadows, Queens, for more than an hour yesterday morning. They were protesting the Board of Education's proposal to eliminate 38 teacher and seven supervisory jobs in District 26 to ease its $700,000 deficit.

title: ADMIRAL BEHRENS, RADIOLOGY EXPERT
description: Rear Adm. Charles F. BehTens, retired, former commander of the Naval Medical Research Institute at Bethesda Md., and an authority on radiology and atomic medicine, died Thursday at his home in Fair Haven, Md. He was 78 years old.

title: Work of Easter Seals
description: For, the thousands of handicapped people in New York State, help is as close as the, nearest telephone, thanks to Easter Seals. When a disabled youngster or adult needs information about available services, when the public requests educational material concernIng crippling, the Easter Seal Society's Information and re ferral service is always there to lend a hand. Help Easter Seals continue to provide this essential service. Send your contribution to the society at 185 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Coach Has Finest Hour In Victory
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 25 (AP)A relieved, almost solemn Coach Notm Sloan paid tribute to a beautiful bunch of guys after his North Carolina State basketball team had beaten Marquette, 76.64, tonight for the National Collegiate championship.

title: NIXON AIDE DISPUTED ON TRANSIT ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The White House prediction of speedy enactment of masstransit legislation was disputed today by Senator Lloyd Bentsen. Democrat of Texas and chairman of the transportation subcommittee of the Public Works Committee.

title: Merits of Bet Patterns Argued
description: A defense lawyer trying to make a point at the sportsbribery trial of 13 harness drivers proposed a hypothetical race yesterday involving a couple of fictitious long shots named Plug and Fire Horse.

title: Allied Stores Net Up 2.2% in Quarte
Cairo Under Soviet Attack For Drift From Socialism
Carbon Monoxide Found to Aggravate Pains From Hardening of Leg Arteries
description: Three California scientists, have documented apparently for the first time how atmospheric pollution and cigarette smoking can aggravate the se vere pains that result from hardening of the leg arteries.

title: ZIEGLER PRESSES PANEL FOR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The White House escalated its criticism of the House Judiciary Committee today, suggesting that its staff should perhaps work late into the evening to complete quickly a preliminary assessment of the impeachment evidence against President Nixon.

title: Selassie Orders inquiry On Government Corruption
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Emperor Haile Selassie ordered an inquiry today into the activities of former Goverment ministers and members of the present Goverment led by Premier Endalkachew Makonnen, to uncover possible abuse of office.

title: Canadian Pipeline Sought
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  Twentytwo Senators have urged Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton to reaffirm his support for construction of a pipeline across Canada to deliver natural gas from Alaska. The request was made after another proposal last week called for liquefying the gas and shipping it via tanker to the United States West Coast. The Canadian line would run through the MacKenzie Valley.

title: Boy Dies After Saving Baby
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 25 (AP)Timothy Blessing, 10 years old, carried his 6monthold brother, Sean, to safety from a fire in their holm, then dashed back inside the house yesterday, fire officials said. He died of suffocation in the smokefilled residence. A Fire Department spokesman said: It was cold. All we can figure is he ran back inside to put some clothes on.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS REPORTS A DEFICIT
description: Smithfield Foods, Inc., incurred a consolidated loss of $4million in the fourth quarter last year and $3.5million loss for all of last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

title: A. Raymond Katz, 78, Muralist And ReligiousArt Painter, Dies
description: A. Raymond Katz, muralist and painter of religious art, died Sunday at Miami Beach. His age was 78, and he lived at 260 Riverside Drive and in Poughquag, N. Y.

title: WOMEN'S JOB CENTER ORDERED SHUT BY U.S.
description: JERSEY CITY, March 25The Labor Department has ordered the Women's Job Corps Center here, long the subject of political controversy, to shut down as of April 17. The Center was opened in 1967.

title: Trade Panel Urges New Rules to Help Payments Balance
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A group of United States trade experts, nearly all former high Government officials, proposed today a new set of international rules governing when nations can impose acrosstheboard import restrictions to help their balance of payments.

title: Slaying of Antiques Dealer Shakes Up Neighbors in a Changing East 81st St.
description: Residents and businessmen on East 81st Street were shocked and fearful yesterday following the murder of an antiques dealer in his shop there last week.

title: KISSINGER BEGINS TALKS IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, March 25Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger began their series of discussions today with eight hours of talks in the Kremlin devoted mostly to Europe and the prospects for new SovietAmerican agreement on limiting strategic weapons.

title: Outlook for Chocolate Bars: Sweet on Weight but Bitter on Price
description: The standard 15cent chocolate bar is about to fall victim to the record prices of cocoa on world markets. According to cocoa dealers here, the new retail price will be 20 or 25 cents.

title: U. S. SAYS GROSS MISUSED HIS JOB
description: NEWARK, March 25  Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was accused today by the Federal Government of having used his political power to enrich his law practice.

title: Dollar Set Back on European Markets
description: LONDON, March 25 (Reuters)The dollar suffered further severe exchange losses in Europe today at one stage ranging to 500 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, or more against the mark and other major currencies.

title: St. Petersburg Council Votes to Cut Back Population
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25  St. Petersburg City Council took action last week that could establish the city's population of 235,000 as of July, 1973, as a ceiling and require about 25,000 persons who have moved here since then to pack up and move within six months after the ordinance takes effect.

title: END OF MAGAZINE ON ARCHITECTURE
description: Architectural Forum will cease publication with its March issue, Billboard Publications, Inc., announced yesterday.

title: Democrats Rebut G. O.P. on End Of State's DayCare Aid to City
description: ALBANY, March 25  The Democrats fiscal experts took issue with the Republican majority in the Legislature today over whether special daycare assistance to New York City should be discontinued.

title: Stiffer U.S. Rtlies Cut Aid To 4,715 Disabled in State
description: More than 4,715 disabled poor in the state  about 90 per cent of them in the city  are being removed from Federal Supplemental Security Income rolls next Sunday because they do not meet stricter Federal definitions, though they had qualified under last year's state rules.

title: Brooklyn CourtJob Political Payoffs Reportedly Being Studied by Nadjari
description: The special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, is investigating the purchase of jobs in the Brooklyn courts through payoffs to political leaders in the borough, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: PITONS EXPECT TAX RISE FOR RICH
description: LONDON, March 25A shopping spree for alcoholic beverages, furs, jewelry and other luxury goods materialized across Britain today on the eye of the new Cabinet's first budget as people of wealth high incomes tried to hedge against expected tax increase.

title: DEAN SAYS STAR, MITCHELL SOUGHT VESCO CASE DELAY
description: John W. Dean 3d, smiling and confident, testified yesterday that two former Cabinet officers, John N. Mitchell and Maurice H, Stans, had made determined and continued efforts to keep Robert L. Vesco's financial scandal secret at least until after Election Day in 1972.

title: SAMOA GOVERNOR CHIDED BY COURT
description: The Governor of American Samoa, John M. Haydon, was cleared yesterday of six counts of violating the Hatch Act, but the administrative law judge criticized him for an unwarranted intrusion into the electoral process.

title: Bill Provides Funeral Fare To Dead Veterans Families,
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (Reuters)The House of Representativespassed and sent to the White House today a bill allowing the Government to pay transportation expenses for families going to the funerals of Vietnam prisoners of war. The Senate passed the bill last Friday.

title: Arab League Told Jordan and Tunisia Will Renew Links
description: TUNIS, March 25 (Reuters)The council of the 20nation Arab League tonight opened a fourday meeting here at which it will review the Middle East situation and its relations with Europe and the third world.

title: Governor Wilson Said to Be Drafting His Own CampaignPracticeReform Proposals
description: ALBANY, March 25  Governor Wilson may forgo his policy of waiting for the Legislature and introduce his own campaignIracticereform proposals this week, reliable sources disclosed today.

title: Chess: The Middle Game Can Be A Fighthig Time in Life, Too
New Jersey Sports
description: LINCROFT, N. J., March 25Jay Jones, after a remarkable performance, was on the verge of tears in the Hillside High locker room after his team lost to Pleasant, ville, 60.55, in the Group 2 public school final of the state basketball tournament Saturday at Brookdale Community College.

title: KOPPERS EXPECTS DOUBLING OF NET
description: The Koppers Company, Inc., expects firstquarter earnings will at least double the 64 cents a share earned in the period last year, Fletcher L. Byrom, chairman, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh.

title: Trenton Prison Superintendent Is Shifted to Administrative Job
description: The superintendent of the troubled Trenton State Prison was removed yesterday and reassigned to an administrative post.

title: Jersey's Dumping Ban Is Ruled Invalid
description: TRENTON, March 25  A state environmental law prohibiting the dumping of outofstate garbage in New Jersey was declared unconstitutional by the State Superior Court today on the ground that the ban constituted an unlawful interference with interstate commerce.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Pollock Named to P.U.C.

title: Munich: American Dada and Shakers
description: MUNICH  In rapid succession Munich has offered two important exhibitions centered on American developments of European stimuli. Dada in New York, in the Lenbach House, focuses on Duchamp, Picabia and Man Ray. It surprised some onlookers, who were unaware that there had been an American dada even before the official creation of dadaism in Zurich in 1916. However, in Munich one could not help being aware of the difference between an explosion with political overtones, such as European dadaism, and an American revolution inside culture, establishing a tradition that remains evident today in concept art. The fact that a rich catalogue seemed to offer more than the exhibition itself with the exception of some early Picabia worksconfirmed the feeling of an event inside culture.

title: N.C. State Wins Title
description: North Carolina State defeated Marquette last night, 7664, in Greensboro, N.C., for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball title. The University of California, Los Angeles, winner of the title the last seven years, beat Kansas, 7861, in the consolation for third place. Details on Page 49.

title: STATE AIDES SEEKING ANTITRUST DAMAGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The National Association of Attorrieys General urged Congress today, to give states the right id sue to recover damages to its citizens from violations of antitrust laws.

title: Competitors Fight G.M.'s Plan in Spain
description: MADRIDA solid front of opposition among automobile manufacturers operating in Spain has been erected against the entry of the biggest manufacturer of all, the General Motors Corporation.

title: Mets Staff Routed,140, By Tigers
New Head of Ethics Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada, has been elected chairman of the bipartisan Senate Ethics Committee.

title: British Wilkinson Sword Seeks Shares of Scripto
description: A Britishowned company, Wilkinson Sword, Inc., has offered to purchase 2.9 million shares of Scripto, Inc., common stock directly from the cornpany at a price of $2.70 a share. H. W. SaMs, Scripto president, said the sale would provide about $8million.in capital for the company and would give Wilkinson about 51 per cent of the 5,844,245 shares that.would be outstanding following a proposed increase in shares.

title: DANIEL HICKS DIES; CITY HEALTH AIDE
description: Daniel B. Hicks, special assistant to the vice president for ambulatory care and community health for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, died Sunday at the age of 31. His body was found in an automobile on the Henry Hudson Parkway near Mosholu Avenue in the Bronx. The Medical Examiner listed the milk of death as carbon monoxide poisoning. Mr. Hicks lived at 3900 Arlington Avenue in the Bronx.

title: RadialTire Sales Rise
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 25Sales of radial tires have risen 6 per cent since the advent of the gasoline shortage, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today. Due to lower rolling resistance, radialply tires can help provide about 10 per (lent more gasoline milage, Robert Finlay, manager of automotive tire sales, said.

title: Watergate a Presence at the Mitchell Trial
description: Watergate was not mentioned, but its silent presence permeated Room 110 yesterday at the United States Courthouse here.

title: Knights Out of Playoff
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., March 25 (AP)Jersey's chances for a playoff spot ended tonight, when the Edmondton Oilers scored a 41 World Hockey Assocation victory over the Knights. With four more games, the lastplace Knights have no mathematical chance of reaching the fourth and final playoff spot in the W.H.A. East.

title: Frost's Aide, Publishing Picture Book, Fondly Recalls His Atrocious Spelling
description: For the quarter of a century immediately preceding his death in 1963, Robert Frost was aided and abetted by his secretarymanagerfriend, Kathleen Morrison, who corrected his spelling (which was atrocious), mended his ego (always faltering), bolstered him against his chronic feelings of insecurity (he needed to be reminded of his excellence) and watched him emerge as one of America's greatest poets.

title: Liquor and Cigarette Smuggling By Officers Charged in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam March 25 (AP)The South etnamese Government says it has broken a smuggling ring that used sampans, a navy boat and army convoys to bring French liquor and American cigarettes to Saigon.

title: DEAN SAYS SIAM, MITCHELL SOUGHT VESCO CASE DELAY
description: John W. Dean 3d, smiling and confident, testified yesterday that two former Cabinet officers, John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, had made determined and continued efforts to keep Robert L. Vesco's financial scandal secret at least until after Election Day in 1972.Mr. Dean, former counsel to President Nixon and a star witness at the Senate Watergate yhearings, had been billed as the Government's star witness in this case, and as far as the prosecution was concerned, he lived up to that billing.He testified that Mr. Mitchell had spoken to him about the Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of Mr. Vesco at least 19 times, and said the former Attorney General had asked him to see if some subpoenas in that case could be delayed until after Election Day.Stans Interest CitedHe testified that Mr. Stans, the former Secretary of Commerce, who was then leading the Nixon election fund campaign, had told him that he was concerned about the circumstances of Mr. Vesco's $200,000 cash contribution to the Nixon drive.

title: Woodcock for Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The United Auto Workers president, Leonard Woodcock, urged Congress today to proceed with the impeachment of President Nixon. Until now he favored Mr. Nixon's resignaition, but said he had decided this would leave the myth of martyred President.

title: AMEX PRICES FE IN SLOW TRADING
Trainer Races at Big A Where Real Money Is
description: Ramon Coto has an extensive background in racing, having been the security head at Oriental Park and at the dog track in preCastro Havana. A strategic move to Puerto Rico, was in order a. decade and a half ago, and since then Coto has bad further experience in the thoroughbred activity, as a turf editor, purchasing agent, trainer and owner.

title: The Wonderful BlinkingBox Solution
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Question What is the Presidency?

title: TV: Programs on Cancer, V itamin E and Childbirth
description: Among the reviews that got away in the last week or so was a respectable batch involving programs linked to the medical profession.

title: N.C. State Wins Title
description: North Carolina State defeated Marquette last night, 7664, in Greensboro, N.C., for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball title. The University of California, Los Angeles, winner of the title the last seven years, beat Kansas, 78.61, in the consolation for third place. Details on Page 49.

title: IllEquipped Bandit Bagged in Bank Here
description: Give me a bag full of motley, a man told a teller around 11 A.M. yesterday in the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company branch at 969 Eighth Avenue at 59th Street. The man did not have his own bag.

title: MEXICO OFFERS CARS FOR ST. LOUIS TRAINS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 25 (UPI)By SuMmer, passenger trains may run between St. Louis and Mexico City, eliminating the need to change trains at the Mexican border.

title: News Summary and Index
Guitar Flair
description: Michael Newman, a 16yearold classic guitarist of extraordinary talent, gave his New York debut recital on Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall and immediately established himself as an artist to be reckoned with. Although an amateurish platform manner and a few rough edges, musically, marred his strenuous and serious program, he displayed a formidable technique throughout and a direct approach to music that left no doubt as to his basic gift.

title: SUIT BEING SETTLED BY FILTER DYNAMICS
description: Filter Dynamics International said yesterday it had reached an a settlement with shareholder in a lawsuit challenging the purchase by some company directors of shares of Rayco International.

title: DC10 Jet Builder Concedes a Defect
New Fence at Revson's Crash Site
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 25 (AP)Workmen erected 165 yards of triplecatch fencing today at the spot where Peter Revson, the American racing driver, died in a highspeed crash Friday at Kyalami Circuit. Workmen started on the job Sunday, said Francis Tucker, chairman of the South African Motor Racing Club. We didn't even have time for a quote, but at a time like this the expense is not important.

title: Maine Legislature Rejects Bill to Control Woodlands
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 25The Maine House rejected today a bill that would have returned to full public control about 400,000 woodland acres in northern Maine.

title: NIXON 1968 AUDIT DENIED BY ZIEGLER
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, denied today a published report that President Nixon's tax return for 1968 was being examined by Internal Revenue agents.

title: Olive Higgins Prouty Dies; Was Author of Stella Dallas
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., March 25 (AP)Olive Higgins Prouty, author of Stella Dallas, died at her home here last night. She was 92 years old.

title: CILBERT C. HALSTED
description: Gilbert C. Halsted, chairman of the board of the E. S. Halsted Company of Jersey City, textile bag manufacturers, died yesterday at the Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I.

title: Mottram, 18, Tops Smith by 62, 64
description: ATLANTA, March 15 (AP) Buster Mottram, an 18yearold Briton, toppled Stan Smith, America's No.. 1 player, 62, 64, at the start of a $50,000 World Champion,ship Tennis circuit, tournament today. Smith won the event last year.

title: Books of The Times
description: GOOD MORNING, MIDNIGHT. By Jean Rhys. 190 pages. Vintage Books, Paperbound. $1.65.

title: CITY COUNCIL CHIDED ON SPEED OF REFORM
description: The Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization, charged yesterdaythat the City Council still has a long way to go toward proving itself an effective legislature despite steps recently taken for greater accountability to the public.

title: DC10 Jet Builder Concedes a Defect
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 25  The builder of the DC10 jumbo jet involved in history's worst air crash said today that the plane had left the factory apparently lacking a critical cargodoor design change even though company records show the change had been made.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  The assistant administrator of the Federal Energy Office said today that farmers would get an additional 220 million gallons gasoline this year to plant an additional 10 million acres in grain and other crops in an effort 'to curb inflationary trends. The official, Duke R. Ligon, told a Senate agriculture subcommittee studying farm fuel problems that while agriculture already was entitled under the rules of the energy office to 100 per cent of current fuel needs, the end of the Arab oil embargo would help farmers by easing potential fuel dislocations and assuring adequate supplies for food processors and haulers. a prepared statement, Mr. Ligon also told the senators his agency was particularly concerned with the problem of getting gasoline for migrant farm workers. He said the office was considering setting up telephone hot line systems to tell migrant workers where they could get gasoline.

title: Gruenberg Memorial Set
description: A memorial meeting for Mrs. Sidonie M. Gruenberg, an authority on children who died March 11, will be held next Tuesday, at 3 P.M. at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: CORRUPTION REPORT ON POLICE REBUTTED
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP)Charges by the Pennsylvania Crime Commission of widespread corruption in the Philadelphia police department are unsubstantiated, the city Police Commissioner, Joseph O'Neill, said today.

title: Massachusetts Governor Vetoes Death Penalty Bill
description: BOSTON, March 25 (AP)A bill restoring the death penalty in Massachusetts was vetoed today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: World Theater Festival Planned for Bicentennial
description: A U.S. Bicentennial World Theater Festival, which in 1976 would bring to America 42 of the world's leading institutional and commercial theater companies, was announced yesterday by Alexander H. Cohen, the Broadway producer who is executive producer of the festival.

title: German Researcher in Behavior Suggests That Violence Is Culturally Based
description: A leading German researcher into human and animal behavior, proposed yesterday that violence and war were not primarily the result of inborn instinct but rather of culturally based factors.

title: MORE TEACHERS IN COAST STRIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 The school board kept school open today despite strikes by both major teachers organizations, but only 23 per cent of the students attended classes.

title: InvestorDefense Group On I.O.S. Assets Is Formed
description: GENEVA, March 25 (AP) A group to defend the interests of investors in the defunct Investors Overseas Service has been created at United Nations headquarters in New York, it was announced here.

title: LEGAL FEE $600,000 ON SPORTS COMPLEX
description: TRENTON, March 25 (AP)The law firm that has handled the legal defense of the proposed Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex has billed the state for $600,000 in fees, officials disclosed today.

title: 5 KILLED AS WAVES RAGE OVER HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, March 25Waves pounding Hawaiian shores claimed five lives and caused extensive damage over the weekend. The 35foot waves churned up by a storm far to the north were the highest seen here since 1969.

title: PO FOR U.S. ROAD ON HUDSON PUSHED
description: Despite protests from community planners, key state and city officials appeared ready yesterday to press for Federal designation of the entire Hudson shore corridor from the Battery to the George Washington Bridge as an interstate expressway route.

title: Farmers to Destroy Tainted Chickens Bred in Mississippi
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  Government officials and Mississippi poultrymen agreed today that millions of chickens contaminated by a cancercausing agent in a crop pesticide should be killed and buried as soon as possible.

title: Banks and Argentina Discuss TakeOver
description: Two New York City banks are negotiating with the Government of Argentina for return to Argentine control of banks in that country in which the New York banks hold an interest.

title: Canada in Trade Deficit
description: OTTAWA, March 25 (Reuters)Canada's seasonally adjusted trade balance showed deficit of $47million for February, a sharp turnaround from the $219million surplus in Jan. uary, Statistics Canada reported today. The trade balance with the United States deteriorated to a deficit of $37million in February from a January surplus of $54million.

title: Steel Production Rose 1.3% in Week To 2,875,000 Tons
Chang Chien Dies in Peking; Vice Premier's Widow, 52
description: TOKYO, March 25 (AP)Chang Chien, widow of the Vice Premier of China, Chen Yi, died of lung cancer in Peking on Wednesday, the official Hsinhua news agency reported. She was 52 years old.

title: Watergate Jury's Report Goes to House Unit Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A Watergate grand jury's secret report dealing with President Nixon, along with supporting evidence, will be sent to impeachment investigators at the House of Representatives tomorrow.

title: Judge Chides Little League Lawyer as Out of Tune on Girls

description: WASHINGTON, March 25 It is not exactly your neighborhood library.

description: Some of the best work of many of the nation's professional and amateur waterfowl decoy carvers will be entered in the United States National Decoy Show on Long Island this weekend.

title: Cambodian Toll Reported High In Battle With Rebels for Town
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 25 (UPI) Military sources said today that Government soldiers suffered heavy casualties as they continued their attempt to retake the town of Phsar Oudong northwest of here.

title: News Summary and Index
FAMILIES EXODUS SEER ON WEST SIDE
description: A new statistical study pictures the middle West Side as an area with an older, more Welltodo and bettereducated population than Manhattan as a whole, but notes that families are moving out of the neighborhood at a rate four times faster than single individuals.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: POETRY Sterling Brown is now 72 years old, a poet and teacher who performed outstandingly in fostering a knowledge of black literature in the years when little attention was paid to this in the general world. Mr. Brown essembled much of he store of writing in prose and verse in the library at Howard University, where he, like his father, served as professor. He also wrote Southern Road" (1932) The Negro in American Fiction (1937) and Negro Poetry and Drama (1937). He knew and reflected the speech, the peotry, the music of black people.

title: Justice John J. Dillon, 73, Dead; On the State Bench Since 1961
description: Justice John J. Dillon of the State Supreme Court died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 54 Ralph Avenue, White Plains.

title: Stan Smith Is Toppled By Mottram
Transit Authority Rebuts Unions On Demands for a 21.4% Raise
description: The Transit Authority yesterday completed presenting its economic arguments against wage and fringebenefit demands of its unions, which have threatened to strike the subways and buses next Mon day morning if they do not have a new contract by then.

title: Watergate Jury's Report Goes to House Unit Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A Watergate grand jury's secret report dealing with President Nixon, along with supporting evidence, will be sent to impeachment investigators at the House of Representatives tomorrow.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday receipt of a $173million order from Japan Air Lines for one 747 jumbo jet freighter and five 747 passenger aircraft. They are to be delivered from next December through April 1975.

title: GUESTS RECEIVED BY CHIANG KAISHEK
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 25 (UPI)President Chiang Kaishek received foreign guests for the first time in nearly 20 months today as he and his we gave a farewell dinner for the American Ambassador, news reports said.

title: Norway Won't Back Soviet Summit Call
description: MOSCOW, March 25The Soviet Union has failed to persuade Norway to back the Soviet call to have the current talks on European security and cooperation end early this year on the summit level.

title: Six Turkish Farms In Anatolia Region Sow Opium Poppies
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 25 (Reuters)Opium poppy cultivation has been resumed after a twoyear break on six state farms in southwest Turkey, agriculture officials said today.

title: Window Washer Convicted In Dual Montclair Killings
description: NEWARK, March 25  Robert D. Petrarca, a 26yearold window washer, was found guilty today of firstdegree murder in the death of an Upper Montclair matron and her married daughter last May 14.

title: The Screen
Prisoner on Rikers Island Hangs Himself in Cell
description: A 32yearold inmate at Rikers Island was found hanged by a bedsheet in his cell late last night. Authorities called the death a suicide.

title: Nunzio Waved for Quiet and Talked of Profits
description: STAMFORD, Conn.I sat in Bevivino's Tavern on Liberty Street one night recently and listened idly to the ebb and flow of conversation, waiting eagerly for the inevitable gem that would emerge from the frothy talk. It was here one night that I heard Pete Zaccardo, a garbagetruck driver, say that a candidate for the local school board was xenophobic.

title: M. Herschel Parsons Dies; Turner Construction Aide
description: M. Herschel Parsons, who retired in 1962 as vice president of the Turner Construction Company, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 495 Dean Drive, Mattituck, L. I. He was 68 years old.

title: ADMISSION IS CITED AT MURDER TRIAL
description: Avon White, a reputed member of the Black Liberation Army, testified yesterday that Robert Hayes had told of shooting a transit patrolman in the Bronx last June to avoid getting busted.

description: A History of the African Peopte, by Robert W. July (Scribners, $15). Revised and expanded edition of a 1970 work.

title: Cubs to Open Season With 5 New Regulars
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 26Since the Chicago Cubs are one of the two oldest major league baseball teams in the known cosmos (the Cincinnati Reds are the other), it is of more than routine significance to note that they are entering a new era.

title: Condon, Physicist, Dies
description: Dr. Edward U. Condon, the physicist who had a major role in World War II _atomic bomb and radar programs, died yesterday. Page 46.

title: EARNINGS UP 25%, CITICORP REPORTS
description: The two biggest banking concerns in New York held their annual shareholder meetings here yesterday. The First National City Corporation, whose stockholders approved a change in its name to Citicorp, reported a 25 per cent increase in firstquarter earnings.

title: Rumania Gets a New Premier As Maurer, Ill, Resigns at 71
description: VIENNA, March 26 (Reuters) Ion Gheorghe Maurer retired today as Premier of Rumania and was replaced by Manea Manescu, a Deputy Premier, the official Rumanian news agency, Agerpres, reported.

title: A Whisper From Joe Louis Inspires Foreman
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26 (AP)A whisper from Joe Louis inspired George Foreman to his savage, fiveminute knockout victory over Ken Norton tonight at El Poliedro.

title: AMEX PRICES FAIL FOR 8TH SESSION Volume Shows a Slight Gain OTC Issues Decline
Will Rogers Opens May 6
description: Will Rogers U.S.A., the oneman show starring James Whitmore, makes its Broadway debut on May 6 at the Helen Hayes Theater for a fiveweek run. The prgoram was adapted and directed by Paul Shyre from the writings and sayings of the American humorist. George Spota is the producer.

title: From Prison,Nowhere Being Nobody, A Young Playwright Emerges to Fame
description: The morning after Miguel Pinero's first play Short Eyes, opened to rave views at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, the playwright, instead of basking in his new fame, checked in, with his probation officer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The energy shortage is a world crisis which will not disappear with the renewed flow of Arab fuel, even if at prices Americans can afford. Necessary changes in our lifesupport systems will not happen easily as vested interests have much to lose by changes in the status quo.

title: Man Slain as 2 Ransack His East Village Apartment
description: A 50yearold East Village man was stabbed to death and his nephew was injured last night in a robbery in which woman was used as a decoy.

title: Championship to Close
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Jason Miller's That Chamnionship Season, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the Antoinette Perry and the New York Critics awards for the best play of the 197273 season, will end its Broadway run at the Booth ;Theater on April 21. It wil have given a total of 844 per, formances.

title: Advertising: New Yorker Meets
description: There were about 55 people in the secondfloor room. All were dignified. More of them oldish than youngish. More of them men than women. The east and west walls were papered with a muted Chinese print and adorned with giltframed mirrors. The south wall was an olive green with two Oriental art works. Rich creamyellow drapes all but covered the windows on the north.

title: TV Fuzzy But Blows Are Clear
description: Boxing fans at the RKO Coliseum in upper Manhattan booed George Foreman at first. Then they cheered the heavyweight champion for his devastating knockout of Ken Norton in the second round in Caracas, Venezuela, last night.

title: INMATES DEPLORE TRENTON SHAKEUP
description: Inmate leaders and senior guard officers at the State Prison in Trenton expressed their regret yesterday at the abrupt transfer of Superintendent Albert D. Gray Jr. to another post.

title: Hearst Food Distribution Plan Has Been Completed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (AP)A $2million food distribution program designed to gain the release of Patricia Hearst ran out of money today, and its organizers said they had met the demands of her kidnappers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Supreme Court justice in Queens dismissed the case against two, corporations and two of their officers charged with criminally negligent homicide following the collapse last August of a cofferdam in which two workmen drowned. Justice Louis Wallach threw out the indictment against the contracting concern of Spearin, Prestin and Burrows and its senior vice president, George Reider, and Ebasco Services Corporation, and one of its, officials, J. Ormand Booth. Justice Wallach ruled that the indictment was not sufficiently precise, but he did find that a corporation could be indicted for homicide. The two workmen died at the Consolidated Edison plant on the East River in Astoria, Queens, when a wall of the dam collapsed.

title: Ehrlichman Trial Scheduled To Begin April 15 on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 (UPI)The trial of John D. Ehrlichman, former White House adviser on domestic affairs, on perjury charges is scheduled to begin April 15. That would make Mr. Ehrlichman the first former high White House official to face a jury for the Ellsberg burglary.

title: U.S. ALTERS STAND ON EUROPE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Nixon Administration has notified Western European countries that it is no longer interested in obtaining any redefinition in writing of their relationships with the United States. It suggested instead that they propose a system of consultations.subject of protracted wrangling between Washington and Western Europe, the Administration had asked the Europeans come up with proposals for consultations needed between the Common Market and United States.

title: Dollar Gains in Europe As Gold Prices Decline
description: BRUSSELS, March 26 (UPI) The United States dollar gained in most European money markets today and the price of gold slipped back.

title: NEWARK SUPPORTS AIRPORT CABBIES
description: NEWARK March 26 The city administration today expressed total support for demand by Newark taxi drivers that they be allowed to have full access to terminals at Newark International Airport.

title: Moscow Is Said to Push For CanalClearing Role
description: CAIRO, March 26The Soviet Navy is reported pressing to join American and British naval teams in the largescale operations needed to clear the Suez Canal of mines and other explosives and military obstructions left behind by years of war.

title: Britain Raises Taxes in Bid To Combat Economic Ills
description: LONDON, March 26A broad range of taxincreases, subs stantial food subsidies and other fiscal measures were announced by Britain's new Cabinet today in a dramatic effort to resolve the country's economic difficulties and bolster international confidence in her.

title: TV: Feasting With Panthers, a Play About Wilde
description: At 8:30 this evening, the Public Broadcasting Service Is presenting Feasting With Panthers, a play about Oscar Wilde, and the production is by far the best thing to happen to the WNET series called Theater in America.

title: Turnpike Planning June 1 Crackdown On Noise Pollution
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 26 (UPI)  The New Jersey Turnpike adopted the nation's first toll road noise pollution regulation today in an effort to reduce the din from faulty exhaust systems and tires.

title: Pakistan, Under Bhutto, Is Entering a New Stage
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 25The Prime Minister of Pakistan and the 70 million people he leads so exuberantly and so emphatically are entering a new and eventually decisive stage in their connected destinies. They have seen the future and now they will see whether it works.

title: Israelis and Syrians Report Deaths in Golan Shelling
description: TEL AVIV, March 26 (Reuters)  A Druse villager was reported killed today by Syrian artillery fire during the 15th successive day of shelling on the Golan Heights front.

title: Foreman Keeps Title
description: George Foreman retained the world heavyweight boxing title last night by knocking out Ken Norton in the second round of a scheduled 15round bout in Caracas, Venezuela, Page 49.

title: TESTIMONY BEGINS IN POLICE SLAYING
description: Five men on trial in the murder of Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini were depicted in opening statements yesterday on one hand as executioners and on the other as five men dedicated to social change in this countryrevolutionary change.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Ethiopian Forces Threaten Action Against Government
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 26 (AP)Army and police forces in northern Ethiopia reportedly threatened action today against what they described as the Government's slowness in meeting demands for social and political reforms and trial of corrupt. officials.

title: British Champion Wins in 4th Round
description: LONDON, March 26 (UPI) The British welterweight champion, John Stracey, stopped Jack Tillman of Mobile, Ala., at 58 seconds of the fourth round tonight to move closer to a world title fight with Jose Napoles.

title: U.S. ALTERS STAND ON EUROPE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Nixon Administration has notified Western European countries that it is no longer interested in obtaining any re1 definition in writing of their relationships with the United States. It suggested instead that they propose a system of consultations.

title: Impeachment and Law
description: An important national debate is now focused on the constitutional phrase high crimes and misdemeanors, the standard for impeachment.

title: Mets Shut Out 2d Day in Row
Carrnines's The Future Looks at 2048
description: Al Carmines's new musical, The Future (at Judson Memorial Church through April 15), is one of his more contemplative works, although in some respects it is not contemplative enough.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: MARCH 27, 1974

title: 3 Bomb Explosions Rock An Army Base in England
description: LONDON, March 26 (AP)Terrorist bombs rocked the headquarters of an army bombdisposal regiment in northern England today.

title: Steel NoStrike Agreement Is Upheld by Federal Judge
description: PITTSBURGH, March 26A Federal District judge upheld today the legality of an experimental negotiating agreement between the United Steelworkers of America and the steel industry to avert a nationwide strike.

title: Segretti, in U.S. Prison 4 Months, Is Released
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Donald H. Segretti, the 32yearold California lawyer who pleaded guilty to committing dirty tricks against Democrats in 1972 primary election campaigns, has been released from prison, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Snow. Shuts Virginia Schools
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 26 (AP)  Schools were closed in the Hampton Roads area today after a storm covered Virginia's southeastern tip. with 7.4 inches of snow yesterday. The police attributed two deaths, to the storm. Alvin McCray, the driver of a truck that crashed through the railing on the Hampton Roads BridgeTunnel after Colliding with a car during the storm, was.believed to have drowned. The body of a passenger.in the truck,t Melvin A. Powell, 22 years old, of Chesapeake, was recovered.

title: Anderson to Stay in Office
description: TOWSON, Md., March 26 (AP) The Baltimore County executive, Dale Anderson, said again today that he would not resign despite his conviction last week on 32 counts of extortion, conspiracy and tax evasion. At his first news conference since last Nov. 20, Mr. Anderson reiterated that he was not guilty and said that until due process is achieved, I intend to stay in office until the end of my term.

title: French to Import Chessie Mine's Coal
description: RICHMOND, March 26France's largest steel company has completed arrangements to import one million tons of coal a year for the next 35 years from a new deep coal mine to be developed over the next three years at Beckley, W. Va., on properties owned by the Chessie System, Inc., the big holding company that owns the Chesapeake and OhioBaltimore and Ohio Railroads.

title: House Panel Votes Duty Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)A bill changing the dutyfree personal imports system by fixing a onecarton limit on cigarettes and a uniform onequart limit on liquor was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee. There would be no charge in the dutyfree ceiling of $100. Currently, there is no limit on the number of cigarettes that can be brought in under this ceiling.

title: Britain Raises T axes in Bid To Combat Economic Ills
description: LONDON, March 26A broad range of tax increases, sub. stantial food subsidies and other fiscal measures were announced by Britain's new Cabinet today in a dramatic effort to resolve the country's economic difficulties and bolster international confidence in her.

title: Shea Urged by Mayor To Get N.F.L.Team Here
description: William A. Shea, who gave his name to Shea Stadium, was appointed special sports adviser to the Mayor yesterday and told to try to find a football team to play in Yankee Stadium.

title: J. C. Penney Dividend Up
description: The directors of J.C. Penney Company, Inc., yesterday raised the company's quarterlydividend to 29 cents a share from 28 cents, payable on May 1 to shareholders of record on April 10.

title: Brazil Announces Rise In Price for Oil Products
description: BRASILIA, March 26 (AP)A 34 per cent increase in the price of petroleum and its byproducts; effective April 1, was announced today by the Brazilian Petroleum Council.
