title: Slim Reed in Vietnam
description: Anything that can breathe even the prospect of life into the moribund political provisions of the 1973 Vietnam accords merits exploration. For that reason alone, the sixpoint plan proposed last week by the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Governmentdespite its manifestly selfserving characterdeserves better than a kneejerk reaction of scorn from Saigon's President Thieu

title: Foreman Keeps Title
description: George Foreman retained the world heavyweight boxing title last night by stopping Ken Norton in the second round of a scheduled 15round bout in Caracas, Venezuela. Page 49.

title: Most of $9Billion Budget Voted by Legislature as G.O.P. Blocks Democratic Amendments
description: ALBANY, March 26  After more than seven hours of often acrimonious debate, the Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature pushed through the bulk of Governor Wilson's $9.3billion budget for the new fiscal year which begins Monday.

title: Detectives Recover Art After Posing as Buyers
description: Detectives posing as prospective buyers yesterday recovered about $250,000 worth of art objects, including a centuriesold Russian madonna and child painted on wood that was stolen last month from the apartment of a Greenwich VIIlage physician.

title: General Tire Earnings Fell 13.5% in Fiscal Quarter
Wives Warned on Prostate Cancer
description: Wives of men with cancer of the prostate should have checkups every four months because they may be at greater risk of developing malignancies than wives of men without prostatic cancer, according to results of a ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center study reported in Houston yesterday.

title: Wonder: Symbol at Center of Black Music
description: Stevie Wonder's concert Monday evening at Madison Square Garden built to quite wonderful climaxor two climaxes, more accurately. But apart from its specifically musical aspects, this was an occasion that reached beyond the moment to assume a symbolic function.

title: Rockets Illuminate Sky
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., March 26 (AP)  Two atmosphere measuring rockets launched by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration lit up the sky off the New England coast Monday night as their empty casings fell to the Atlantic Ocean. An official at the NASA launching station here said that they had received telephoned reports of the lighting all along the coast.

title: HOUSE PANEL GETS JURY'S NIXON DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Attorneys for the House Judiciary Committee received today a briefcase of evidence relating to President Nixon's role in the Watergate scandal.

title: KREISKY NOTES DROP IN EMIGRATING JEWS
description: VIENNA, Austria, March 26 (AP)  Austria's Chancellor, Bruno Kreisky, said at a news conference today that fewer Jews were emigrating at present from the Soviet Union to Israel through Austria.

title: British M.P. Reports Soviet Seduction Plot
description: LONDON, March 26 (Reuters)A British Member of Parliament has told the Foreign Office that a Russian woman attempted to seduce him in Moscow in January. He believes it may have been part of a blackmail plot.

title: BRAIN STIMULATED BY A PACEMAKER
description: A mental pacemaker has been developed that can be implanted under the scalp to stimulate certain parts of the brain on radio command.

title: High School Glued Up
description: >WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26 (AP)More than 1,900 Forest Hill High School students got an extra day of spring vacation after someone filled the school's locks with epoxy glue. Classes were canceled yesterday while maintenance men tried to find way to open the school's doors and gates.

title: Japanese Head Venture For Saudi Steel Mill
description: TOKYO, March 26 (AP)Japan's two major steel makers have agreed in a joint venture with United States, Dutch and Saudi Arabian companies to establish a large steel mill in Saudi Arabia, a Japanese company spokesman said today.

title: U.S. to Aid Cattlemen With Beef Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, March 26. (AP)  The Federal Government plans to aid the cattle industry by buying $45million worth of beef, Senators from farm states were told at a White House meeting today.

title: Charles H. Green, Counsel To Hat and Cap Unions
description: Charles H. Green, counsel to the millinery workers health and retirement funds and also to the Cap Makers Union, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 382 Central Park West.

title: Girl Scouts Here Begin Project for Bicentennial
description: As a prelude to the city's bicentennial celebration, Mayor Beame yesterday inaugurated twoyear project for the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York called, Take Stock in New York.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL ON CANCER STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Senate passed today by a vote of 89 to 0 a bill to extend for three years the nation's research against cancer at a cost of more than $2.7billion.

title: Blackton Fifth Avenue Files Petition in Chapter XI Step
description: A petition for rearrangement of its business under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was filed yesterday in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York by Blackton Fifth Avenue, Ltd., operators of retail women's specialty with headquarters at 15 West 37th Street.

title: Bill Would End a Fuel Duty
description: WASHINGTON March 26 (AP) A bill to allow permanent taxfree imports of methanol for use as a fuel was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee. The legislation, would end the duty of 7.6 cents per gallon on methanol, commonly called wood alcohol, if itis imported for fuel use.

title: SENATE DEBATES CAMPAIGN FUND
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Despite the double threat of a filibuster and a Presidential veto, the Senate began today what is expected to be a protracted debate over a major election reform bill that would finance the 1976 Presidential and Congressional campaigns

title: The Case for Tax Cuts
description: Administration economists are striving to give reassurance that real Gross National Productwhich now is expected to show a drop of 4 per cent or more in the first quarter of 1974will flatten out in the second quarter and start to recover in the second half of the year, enough to redeem President Nixon's pledge that there will be no recession this year.

title: Committee Bids Suffolk Start Purchase Plan to Save Farms
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 26 The Suffolk County Agricultural Advisory Committee urged the county administration today to go ahead as soon as possible with its proposed program of acquiring farmland, and suggested guidelines for the $45million project.

title: Sherwin Case Prosecutor Heads State's Crime Unit
description: TRENTON, March 26Matthew P. Boylan, a prominent 41yearold New Jersey trial lawyer who two years ago was named special state prosecutor in the bribery trial of then Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin, was named today as director of the Criminal Justice Division in the State Attorney General's office.

title: Jersey G.O.P. Assembly Leader Seeks Congressional Nomination
description: TRENTON, March 26 Thomas H. Kean, the Assembly Republican minority leader, announced his candidacy for the G.O.P. Congressional nomination in central New Jersey's Fifth District today with a call to fellow Republicans to confront the issues of Watergate and inflation squarely.

title: Annual Playoff Ticket Fever Hits New Highs
description: Ticket fever  an annual bug that infects the Knick and Ranger fan at playoff timeis rising again. The prescription Is costly.

title: Red Smith
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26Up to 8:30 tonight, the men who own Ken Norton were threatening to keep their fighter out of the ring with George Foreman, heavyweight champion of the world. For the sake of their man's health, they shouldn't have changed their minds. Reluctantly accepting the referee Foreman's manager demanded, they sent Norton out to be smashed down three times and clubbed senseless in exactly five minutes of fighting.

title: About New York
description: Jane, can you look this way? the photographer said, and Jane Fonda said, Yeah, sure, and looked. Miss Fonda is the La Pasionaria of the antiwar movement, but up close she is indistinguishable from the girl next door. She was with her husband, Tom Hayden. He looks like Huckleberry Finn.

title: HANS GISEVIUS, 68, ANTINAZI, IS DEAD
description: GENEVA, March 26Hans Bernd Gisevius, an antiNazi German police official who was a leading prosecution witness at the Nuremberg war crime trials, died of a heart attack on Feb. 23 in West Germany, according to a family announcement today. He was 68 years old.

title: STUDENT UNREST MOUNTS IN BRAZIL
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 26  Many Brazilian university students have taken advantage of the recent change in governments to embark upon increased protests.

title: Pakistan, Under Bhutto, Is Entering a New Stage
description: RAWALPINDI, Pikistan, March 25The Prime Minister of Pakistan and the 70 million people he leads so exuberantly and so emphatically are entering a new and eventually decisive stage in their connected destinies. They have seen the future and now they will see whether it works.

title: Cubs to Open Season With 5 New Regulars
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 26Since the Chicago Cubs are one of the two oldest major league baseball teams in the known cosmos (the Cincinnati Reds are the other), it is of more than routine significance to note that they are entering a new era

title: 84Day Tax Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
Tkaczuk Rejoins Rangers in Time for Bruins Tonight
SENATE WON'T GET NITZE NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Paul H. Nitze, a Democrat, will not be nominated as Assistant Secretary of Defense because of opposition to him from conservatives in the Senate. Another man will shortly be proposed for the position.

title: Philadelphia Names U.S. Aide To Study Alleged Police Graft
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26Walter M. Phillips Jr., an Assistant United States Attorney in New York, was named today special prosecutor in an investigation of alleged police corruption in this city.

title: After the Oil Embargo
description: KENSINGTON, Calif.During the winter, when Americans endured bitter cold and parked in long lines at the few gasoline stations that remained open, production of domestic crude oil and naturalgas liquids was running at a reasonable level, imports of oil products averaged 2.8 million barrels a day, and crude oil imports were up 11 per cent from the previous winter.

title: Nixon Autographs Book
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)  President Nixon autographed today a copy of a new book by Col. Robinson Risner, who was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for seven years. Colonel Risner gave the President a copy of his book, Passing of the Night, during a call at the White House Oval Office with Senator and Mrs. Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma.

title: RAILRATE REFORM URGED BY BRINEGAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters)Secretary of Transportation Claude Brinegar urged Congress today to reform the regulations affecting railroad freight rates so the railroads could operate more efficiently.

title: ICELAND TELLS U.S. OF PLAN ON TROOPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26A State Department spokesman said today that the Government of Iceland had advised the United States in general terms of a proposal that calls for all 3,300 American servicemen in that country to leave by mid1976.

title: DEATH PENALTY VETO FAILS IN HARRISBURG
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 26 (AP)The State Legislature restored the death penalty today by overriding Gov. Milton J Shapp's veto of a capital pun ishment bill.

title: Akiyama Conducts, Hines Sings Boris In a Fine Concert
description: The Atiterican Symphony led of its Carnegie Hall concert on Monday night with Barber's Second Essay and the Suite from Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier  two pieces that an orchestra plays when it wants to show itself off.

title: 3 REFINERS TOLD TO REDUCE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The Federal Energy Office said today that it had issued orders directing three oil refiners to make price reductions totaling about $44million.

title: Eschenbach Recital Off
description: Christoph Eschenbach, the German pianist, has influenza and has been forced to cancel the recital he was to have given tonight at Carnegie Hall. Ticket refunds may be obtained at the Carnegie Hall box office.

title: 90 Reported Killed In Burmese Battles Near Thai Border
description: RANGOON, Burma, March 126, (UPI)  The Government said yesterday that 90 persons were killed and more than 160 wounded in fighting last week between Government forces and rebels in southeast Burma.

title: Annual Playoff Ticket Fever Hits New Highs
description: Ticket fever  an annual bug that infects the Knick and Ranger fan at playoff timeis rising again. The prescription is costly,

title: Welfare Rent Ceiling Plan Put Off by State to July 1
description: A new statewide policy of ceilings on welfare rents that was to go into effect next Monday has been delayed until July 1, it was announced yesterday by Abe Lavine, State Commissioner of Social Services.

title: Honda in Arabian Venture
description: TOKYO, March 26 (UPI) The Honda Motor Company will set up a subsidiary in Saudi Arabia in a joint venture with a Saudi Arabian auto company, Honda officials said today. Honda representatives will visit Jidda, Saudi Arabia, in April for one month to study the project with the Ahdullah Hashim Enterprise, a leading Arabian car dealer, according to industry sources. The sources said Honda plans to establish a factory to make Honda dream motorcycles with an initial annual output of 5,000 motorcycles.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne signed legislation yesterday increasing the state urban aid program by 50 per cent to $36.7million. The money will be distributed to the 24 cities and townships that have participated in the program since it was expanded in 1971 from the original $12million plan for the six biggest New Jersey cities.

title: Nixon Aide Cites Examples of TV Networks News Distortion
description: A White House aide, amplifying President Nixon's running criticism of television network news, yesterday cited a number of subtle and sophisticated techniques by which he said, the networks and other media damaged and distorted the public perception of what was occurring in Government.

title: TERMS OF WAGE BILL FIXED BY CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)  Senate and House conferees agreed today on the terms of a bill raising the minimum wage from $1.60 to $2.30 an hour in stages and bringing seven million more workers under its coverage.

title: F.T.C. Urges U.S Monitoring of Energy Industry
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)A Federal Trade Commission staff study said today that energy production is apparently no more monopolistic than any other industry, but competition is dwindling.

title: I.R.S. Expects to Step Up Tax Audits
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, says that the number of tax returns for 1973 that his agency will audit this year will be materially greater than in recent years.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ELIZABETH, March 26There is only one New Jersey high school that can boast of two basketball players who scored 2,000 points It's doubtful that few fans could name it.

title: Nets Have Two Goals For Finale
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 26The New York Nets take their four game winning streak into their last regular American Basketball Association game of the season tomorrow night at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS EVIDENCE SEIZURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Supreme Court ruled today that the police may seize without a search warrant the clothing of a criminal suspect 10 hours after he has been lawfully arrested and use it as evidence against him.

title: Contract Awards
description: The United States Steel Corporation signed letter of intent yesterday with the Fauji, Foundation of Pakistan to build a $135million fertilizer plant in the Rahimyar District of Punjab Province. The plant will produce 550,000 tons of urea fertilizer when it is completed in late 1977. United States aid funds are expected to cover some $90million in foreign exchange costs. The Fauji Foundation is a national trust administered by former military officers for the welfare of exservicemen.

title: Phnom Penh's Drive
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 26 (Reuters)  Widespread fighting was reported in Cambodia today, as Government forces pressed a twopronged assault on the town of Phsar Oudong, held by Communistled insurgents since March 18.

title: Market Place: Insiders Offer Investing Clues
description: Buying and selling stocks by corporate insiders have long been an object fascination for Wall Street. After. all, the insider is by definition an officer, director or large shareowner, and the implication is that he has degree of sophistication about his company and its prospects.

title: Quietly, Central Park Advances as Landmark
description: There was no acrimony, no shoutingnot even controversyin a most unusual public hearing before the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday on whether Central Park should be designated a scenic landmark. It took a procession of politicians, architects, conservationists and concerned citizens four hours to say it, but everyone agreed the park should receive the designation.

title: Chavez Would Curb Baycott in Exchange For Labor Support
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)The leader of the United Farm Workers, Cesar Chavez, said today he would curtail present secondary boycott if the A.F.L. C.I.O. would support a nationwide boycott of grapes and lettuce.

title: The Question of Stockpiling Grain Debated in Senate
description: WASHINGTON Should the United States, in bumper crop years, stockpile wheat, feed grains, and soybeans as insurance, in poor crop years, against famine abroad and skyrocketing grain prices at home?

title: BANK STOCK PLANS SCORED BY EXCHANGE
description: Lowcost purchase of stock through more than 65 banks was vigorously opposed here yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: GARRISON NOT GUILTY OF U.S. TAX EVASION
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP)New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison was found not guilty of income tax evasion today by a United States District Court jury.

title: A.T. &
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reduced its telephone rates to Honduras yesterday and plans to cut them to El Salvador April 5. In a rate filing with the Federal Communications Commission, A. T. & T.'s Long Lines department said annual savings on calls to Honduras would amount to $240,000 to $500,000 to El Salvador.

title: Laborites Illusion of Stability
description: LONDON, March 26  With a glass of wellwatered brandy beside him, Denis Healey, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, stood before a crowded House of Commons today to give the British the good news and the bad for the coming months. In a 20,000 word budget speech, he struck a variety of somber notes, mentioning his own mood of trepidation, the country's gram) economic crisis and the threat of political and social strains. He also hit just about everybody in the country with higher taxes that will send up income taxes as well as prices of cigarettes, Scotch, beer, gasoline, electricity, rail fares, postage and chocolate candy, News Analysis

title: When in Doubt, Smile!
description: There are fashions in diplomacy these days as there are in the latest Paris dresses, and the current fashion among world leaders is the official smile. Whatever else the great men wear, it seems they must wear a smile for the photographersand the greater their differences, the wider their smiles.

title: People in Sports
description: Tommie Agee became the second star of the 1969 Miracle Mets to be dropped by another club in two days, when the Los Angeles Dodgers gave him his unconditional release yesterday. The 31yearold Agee was acquired in an offseason deal that sent Pete Richert, a pitcher, to St. Louis. Agee had only three hits in 20 times at bat in eight spring training games with the Dodgers. Ron Swoboda, a former Met, was dropped by the Atlanta Braves Monday.

title: Black Woman Loses Post at State Dept. To a G.O.P. Activist
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Barbara M. Watson, the first black woman to attain a rank equivalent to Assistant Secretary of State, has been removed by the White House as administrator of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

title: DeBusschere's Special Stamp Goes on Big Victory for Knicks
Befriended by Couple, Man Steals $3,500 From Them
description: A 30yearold man who accepted the hospitality of a 70yearold man and his wife has pleaded guilty to stealing $3,500 of the couple's possessions. Howard Johnson of 17 West 127th Street, pleaded guilty before Justice Isidore Dollinger in Supreme Court in the Bronx. The judge set April 24 for sentencing.

title: African Facility Will Research Diseases
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26  The World Health Organization plans to establish a research center in central Africa aimed at preventing and treating tropical diseases that affect hundreds of millions of people.

title: Beame Appoints New Judge
description: Julian S. Greenspun, a 40yearold Brooklyn lawyer, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Beame to serve as a judge of the Civil Court in Kings County. Judge Greenspun replaces Leonard E. Yoswein, who resigned when he was appointed by the Mayor to serve as Commissioner of the Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance Judge Greenspun will receive $36,451 a year.

title: HAY ON BENCH FOR BROWNSTEIN
description: I don't want to send a guy to jail for seven years it he didn't do anything, Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein admonished an assistant district attorney yesterday after a defendant who had agreed to plead guilty to a robbery charge told the court he had not committed the crime.

title: Loeb, Nephew of Lehman, Seeks G.O.P. Nomination for House
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 26John L. Loeb Jr., an investment banker and nephew of the late Gov. Herbert Lehman, announced today his candidacy for the Republican nomination in the 24th Congressional District, now held by Ogden R. Reid.

title: Notes, on People
description: King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of the Belgians went to Brussels Central Station yesterday to make a bit of history. They welcomed President Gustav Heinemann of West Germany, on an official visit, the first by a German head of state since 1910. The resumption of such visits had taken so long because of the bitterness in Belgium over German occupation of that country in the two World Wars.

title: Stock Prices Show Rise As Trading Pace Gains
Stunned Swoboda Mulls Future, Or Lack of It
Milk CoOp's Report Finds Abuses in Campaign Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 26A report on political spending by Associated Milk! Producers, Inc., prepared at the request of its own officers, indicates broad pattern of irregularities involving both Republicans and Democrats over a long period.

title: CHANGE ON DC10 CALLED OPTIONAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 26A Federal official said today that he understood that a gentlemen's agreement between the Government and the plane's builder had sidetracked the issuance of a mandatory requirement for a design change that might have prevented the March 3 crash of a DC10 jumbo jet airliner near Paris.

title: Head of Landfill Concern Hails Ruling on OutofState Dumping
description: KEARNY, March 26  The director of one of the largest sanitary landfill operations in New Jersey. praised a Superior Court decision today overturning a law banning the dumping of outofstate garbage There is no garbage crisis, he said. We have plenty of land in New Jersey for New York refuse.

title: Bloodbath in Uganda
description: It is not likely that the outside world will know for many months exactly what happened in Uganda over last weekend, but the postscript is tragically familiar. Gen. Idi Amin evidently is using the incident to carry out yet another round of summary executions Ugandan army officers whom he suspects of doubtful loyalty to his brutal dictatorship.

title: Paul Freeman, 70, Dead; Former I.B.M. Executive
description: Paul M. Freeman, a former executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, died yesterday at Boca Raton Community Hospital. Boca Raton, Fla. He was. 70 years old and lived on Deer Knoll Road, in Mount Kisco, N. Y., and in Boca Raton.

title: HOUSE PANEL GETS JURY'S NIXON DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Attorneys for the House Judiciary Committee received today a briefcase of evidence relating to President Nixon's role in the Watergate scandal.

title: The Court Package
description: Shards of court reform bills are strewn about the state Legislature in Albany; the main interest of the lawmakers seems to be to prevent them from ever being put together in a comprehensive package aimed at depoliticizing the courts.

title: Waltrip Is Ready to Make Mark as Top Auto Racer
description: Darrel Waltrip hasn't won any big races lately, but in motor sports these days, the big race isn't to the swiftest car, but to the handsomest driver.

title: Lawyer's Rothko Sale Advice Assailed
description: Ernest L. Dial, whose legal advice led to the sale and consignment by executors of the late Mark Rothko of 800 of his paintings to Marlborough Gallery shortly after his death, was challenged in Surrogate's Court yesterday to justify that advice.

title: OTB Aide Concedes Heavy Wagers Don't Necessarily Mean Fixed Race
description: Heavy wagering on certain superfecta combinations doesn't necessarily mean the race is fixed, a vice president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation conceded yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: GRAINS, SOYBEANS SHOW PRICE SHIFT
description: In a dramatic turnabout just before the close, grain and soy bean prices were bid up from their lows in active trading yesterday on Midwest commodity exchanges.

title: Monetary Group Will Meet on Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 26International monetary officials will begin a threeday session here tomorrow and are expected to deal with the issue of international rules for handling floating currency exchange rates.

title: Killer Gets 5 to 15 Years In 30Cent Fatal Holdup
description: A 22yearold Queens man was sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison yesterday for a robberymurder in which 30 cents was taken from the victim, 20yearold Navy veteran.

title: Natural Gas Search Set
description: CHICAGO, March 26 (UPI)The Amoco Production Company and the Cities Service Gas Company of Oklahoma City announced agreement today on threeyear search for natural gas on more than one million acres in southern Wyoming. Amoco is the exploration and production subsidiary of Standard Oil of Indiana. The agreement, announced in Denver also was released in Chicago by the Standard headquarters.

title: BRITISH STEEL PLANS MAJOR PRICE RISES
description: The stateowned British Steel Corporation said today it was introducing price increases effective day after tomorrow.

title: In Troubled Ethiopia, Eritreans Press Separatist Drive
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia (AP) Fire code words are enough to bring a guerrilla leader out of hiding, here: Your Uncle Ibrahim sends regards.

title: Bade Precision Team Takes Title In Spring Nationals Tourney
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 26A new Precision Team, donning mantle of the disbanded Precision Team that won three national titles in recent years, captured the men's team title at the American Contract Bridge LeaguO's Spring Nationals here last night.

title: PRICES STRONGER IN BOND MARKET
Recital
description: Diane Walsh, a 23yearold pianist with contestwinning fingers, gave an impressive debut recital Monday night at Hunter College Playhouse. Miss Walsh, who earned her appearance by competing in the Young Concert Artists International Auditions last spring, played a brilliantly clear recital, which worked to the special advantage of Clementi's Sonata in F sharp.minor, a Mozartean work in which each note could have been held up and admired like a small pearl.

title: Pro Track Circuit Sets Japan Meet
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP)A Japanese television network and the International Track Association have announced a twoday professional track meet to be held April 6 and 7 in Japan, costing more than $300,000.

title: LAND DEVELOPER TO MAKE REFUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Government moved today to prohibit deceptive practices by a major interstate land company and to provide some consumers with either partial refunds or new lots,

title: Who's Spoking Whose Wheel?
description: PARISOne curious aspect of the continuing superpower negotiation is that neither the United States nor the Soviet Union is exactly sure how strong it is visavis the other. Thus it is not always certain what is uppermost in the minds of each party at any particular phase of their colloquy.

title: HOWARD WEINSTEIN
description: Howard Weinstein, a director of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, 666 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at the Albert Einstein Hospital, the Bronx. He was 48 years old and lived at 7 Surrey Close, White Plains.

title: Butte, Mont.: Inland Port City Without Ships, Harbors or ,Rivers But With Containers and Customs
description: BUTTE, Mont.Two weeks ago it was an African antelope that was said. to have supernatural powers. A few days before that some rhinoceros parts arrived along with a couple of Mongolian sheep and a very strange shipment from the Fiji Islands.

title: INTEGRATION STEP IS URGED BY CLARK
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark said yesterday that he intended to ask the State Board of Regents, of which he is a member, to appoint a threemember commission to supersede the Board of Education here for the specific purpose of desegregating the schools of New York City.

title: WATERGATE TAPES USED TO QUESTION DEAN TESTIMONY
description: The defense in the Mitchell Stans trial used Watergate tapes yesterday to impugn the testimony of John W. Dean 3d. This made for a daylong strutgle, as fierce in its way as a prizefight, between the witness and lawyers for the defense.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters)United States reserve assets rose $78million in February to $14.64billion, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: Justices Void California Election Fee
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 States cannot keep the poor from running for public office by charging candidates filing fees without any alternative means of getting on the ballot, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: New Paltz Students Stage Office SitIn To Protest Policies
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., March 26About 1,000 students at the State University college here occupied the ninestory administration building today, protesting against what a spokesman described as the trend back to more traditional methods.

title: Radio
SUNDAY PLAN GETS STILL MORE RIDERS
description: The Sunday halffare program of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority continued to lure additional riders onto its mass transit facilities last weekend even as open gasoline pumps and good driving weather caused motorists to travel the region's highways in larger numbers.

title: Santa Fe Dividend Raised
description: The directors of Santa Fe Industries Inc., yesterday raised the quarterly dividend by cents a share, to 45 cents. It is payable June 1 to stockholders of record May 10, 1974.

title: Norton: I Should Have Boxed
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26 (AP)"The plan was to go out and box, said Ken Norton after his loss to George Foreman tonight, but it didn't work out that way.

title: Walter Thurston, Former Envoy In the Americas, Is Dead at 79
description: ORANGE, Va.,March 26 (AP) Walter Thurston, former Ambassador to Mexico, Bolivia and El Salvador, died Sunday Lt his cattle farm near here. He was 79 years old.

title: $100Million Outlay Is Deferred by Ford
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threemonth delay in putting into effect a new policy of welfare rent ceilings from next Monday until July 1 was announced by Abe Laving, Social Services Commissioner of New York State. He said the delay was to give time to weigh the impact of unforeseen increases in heating fuel and utility costs vacancy decontrols in the city; cut off of Federal housing aid; general inflation and rising construction costs.

title: A HEARING CALLED ON CITY U. TENURE
description: The Board of Higher Education's controversial tenure policies for City University faculty members will be reexamined at a public hearing on April 10, the board announced yesterday.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON SCHOOL BUSING FOR NEGRO; $30Million Is Cut From Aic to Poor Children in StateCity's Loss $23Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The House of Representatives voted today to prohibit Federal courts from ordering longdistance busing of children to end school segregation.

title: Most of $9Billion State Budget Is Voted as Republicans Prevail
description: ALBANY, March 26  After more than seven hours of oftenacrimonious debate, the Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature pushed through the bulk of Governor Wilson's $9.3billion budget for the new fiscal year, which begins Monday.

title: KURD AUTONOMY DECREED BY IRAQ
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 26 (Reuters)  The Iraqi Government announced tonight that it had issued decrees placing into effect the plan for selfrule that it proclaimed March 11 for the Kurdish minority in the mountainous northern region of the country.

title: GUINAN IS GLOOMY ON TRANSIT TALKS
description: Matthew Guinan, president of the Transport Workers Union said yesterday that the contract dispute with the Transit Authority was so serious that it was time that Mayor Beame and Governor Wilson got into the situation.

title: 2 NAMED REGENTS IN BITTER DEBATE
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, March 27After a bitter debate late last night, the Assembly appoined two new members to the debate Board of Regents, includ ing the board's second woman member.

title: Killian Presses Fight for Hartford's Gubernatorial Delegates
description: HARTFORD, March 26Attorney General Robert K. Killian opened a storefront headquarters on Washington Street here yesterday in his bid to win delegates to the state Democratic convention in the Hartford primary on May 23. Mr. Killian must win in Hartford if he is to remain in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Guru Brings Composers New Voice
description: Pandit Pran Nath, who is completing his current appearances in this city with concerts tonight and Sunday morning at the Open Mind, 66 Greene Street, it not just another of the many excellent Indian musicians who have visited America in recent years. Mr. Pran Nath has become the principal musical guru to a growing number of young American composers.

title: Jersey G.O.P. Assembly Leader Seeks Congressional Nomination
description: TRENTON, March 26Thomas H. Kean, the Assembly Republican minority leader, announced his candidacy for the G.O.P. Congressional nomination in central New Jersey's Fifth District today with a call to fellow Repubicans to confront the issues of Watergate and inflation squarely.

title: U.S. OILLEASE SHIFT URGED BY F.P.C. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)  A Federal Power Commission official said today that Government policy had discouraged small independent companies from competing for offshore oil and gas leases.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON SCHOOL BUSING FOR INTEGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The House of Representatives voted today to prohibit Federal courts from ordering longdistance busing of children to end school segregation.

title: Stars Defeat Kings, Retain Playoff Hope
Chief of Complaint Bureau Named
description: The appointment of Richard B. Lowe 3d to be chief of the Complaint Bureau was announced yesterday by Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: TWO ARE ACCUSED OF BILKING POOR
description: An executive of a food sei vice and his cousin, a bank loan officer, were indicted her yesterday on charges of having fraudulently arranged bang loans for lowincome investor who allegedly were then swind led out of their capital in franchise pyramiding scheme.

title: NEWS COUNCIL SET TO STUDY CHARGES
description: The National News Council announced yesterday that it would study complaints against The New York Times News Seryice, ABCTV and certain television networks.

title: SENATE UNIT ACTS TO END CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Senate Banking Committee disapproved today an extension of wageprice control authority, making it probable that controls will expire as scheduled at midnight April 30 on all sectors of the economy except petroleum products.

title: Boy, 7, Is Found Dead In Abandoned Building
description: A 7yearold boy, missing since last Friday afternoon, was found slain yesterday in a vacant, boarded up house in Flushing, Queens, two doors away from his home.

title: Schnelker Joins Dolphins
description: MIAMI, March 26 (AP)Bob Schnelker, a former tight end for the New York Giants, has been named an assistant coach of the Miami Dolphins, champions of the National Football League.

title: PAN AM'S DEFICIT WIDENS IN MONTH
description: Higher fuel prices and rising operating costs continued to plague Pan American World Airways and Eastern Airlines as their deficits widened in February, they reported yesterday. Northwest Airlines had profit increase, helped by capital gain.

title: BELGIUM PROPOSES 36% OIL PRICE RISE
description: BRUSSELS, March 26The caretaker coalition Government of Belgium offered today the country's oil industry a 36 per cent rise in retail oil prices in an effort to avoid threatening fuel shortages.

title: Henry Fonda Is Embodiment of Darrow
WATERGATE TAPES USED TO QUESTION DEAN TESTIMONY
description: The defense in the MitchellStans trial used Watergate tapes yesterday to impugn the testimony of John W. Dean 3d. This made for a daylong struggle, as fierce in its way as prizefight, between the witness and lawyers for the defense.

title: Controller Beame's Expertise May Haunt Mayor Beame as He Tries to Close Budget Gap
description: The fiscal expertise that Abraham D. Beame used to display so casually in the day; when he kept the city's budget books and John V. Lindsay sat in the Mayor's office might be coming back to haunt Mr. Beame now that he is the Mayor. He finished a gloomfilled exposition of the city's current budget troubles the other dayhe says a $1.5billion gap looms and the politicians in his audience were leaving Gracie Mansion.

title: Condon, Physicist, Dies
description: Dr. Edward U. Condon, the physicist who had a major role in World War II atomic bomb and radar programs, died yesterday. Page 46.

title: Kissinger, Brezhnev Confer for 2d Day; Mideast Discussed
description: MOSCOW, March 26 Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger, meeting for a second day at the Kremlin, dwelt today on approaches to a settlement in the Middle East, an area that has lately been a source of strain in SovietAmerican relations.

title: Gross Rests Defense After Jury Hears Partner Testify From Bed
description: NEWARK, March 26A law partner of Nelson G. Gross made a dramatic courtroom appearance today to support defense testimony in the trial of the former state Republican chairman for alleged conspiracy to conceal campaign funds in 1969.

title: Taxi Fleet Owners, Reporting Losses, Ask 15% Fare Rise
description: The owner of taxicab fleets in the city asked yesterday for a 15.5 per cent fare increase, contending they were suffering severe financial losses because of increased gasoline prices and labor costs.

title: Antiques Shopping, of Sorts, in a 57,000Barrel Crude Oil Tank
$3Million Hughes Plan to See Movies
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26Howard R. Hughes paid $3.65million for a television station in Las Vegas so he could watch old Western and aviation movies in the hours before dawn, the man who sold the station told a Federal trial jury here today.

title: Carey, Starting His Drive, Calls Wilson Nixon's Man
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday, charging that Governor Wilson was tied irrevocably by financial obligation and poltical ambition to Nelson Rockefeller and Richard Nixon.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., March 26 (AP)The sale of the Texas Rangers for $10million seemed likely, but Bob Short, the Rangers owner, failed today to give either one of two groups bidding for the American League Baseball franchise his immediate Messing. A DallasFort Worth group met today, then announced papers were being prepared for final sale of the club. Brad Corbett of Fort Worth is the head the group.

title: The Time Is Now
description: Now is the time for a full and fundamental cleansing of the nation's outmoded, corrupt system of financing public elections with private money. Now is the time to break the stranglehold of wealthy individuals and selfseeking interest groups over the nation's politics. Now is the time to bring into the open sunlight of public responsibility a system halfpublicly regulated and halfsecret. If Congress cannot reform the nation's politics in this sordid year of Watergate, when will there be more opportune time?

title: Long Beach Names Manager
description: LONG BEACH, L.I. March 26 (UPI)  The Long Beach.' City Council today named Richard J. Bowen of Andover, Mass., as the new City Manager. His most recent posts were City Manager of Portsmouth N.H., and Town Manager, of Andover His salary will be about $30000 a year.

title: Ruth Levine Wed to S. A. Chadsey
description: Miss Ruth Levine, manager of the china, glass, silver and gifts department at Bloomingdale's in New York, was married yesterday evening in South Orange, N.J., to Stanley Albert Chadsey, a certified public accountant and an account officer with the First National City Bank in New York.

title: THIEU TO STEP UP LAND ALLOTMENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26 (UPI)  President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that he had ordered an acceleration of the South Vietnamese program of distributing land to prospective farmers.

title: Yugoslays and Italians Rekindle Trieste Dispute
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26A territorial dispute that brought Italy and Yugoslavia to the brink of war in the decade following World War II has been rekindled, and the name Trieste is again firing Yugoslav hearts with fighting fervor.

title: MRS. ROBERT ISAAC
description: Mrs. Lucile Martin Isaac, for 45 years a trustee of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. She was 81 years old, the widow of Robert Isaac, an investment banker. In recent years she had lived at the Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue at 69th Street.

title: 200 ON L.I. OPPOSE HOUSING FOR AGED
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 26Strong opposition to a plan to build 172 apartment units forthe elderly and poor in east Massapequa was voiced as 200 residents of the Town of Oyster Bay attended a public hearing here this morning and tonight.

title: Foreman Retains Title by Stopping Norton in 2:00 of Second Round
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26  With a brutal barrage of punches that reduced the controversy over the nationality of the referee to an academic debate, George Foreman registered a knockout of Ken Norton after 2 minutes of the second round tonight in their world heavyweight title fight.

title: F.B.I. SAYS 3 PLOTTED MIDWEST ABDUCTION
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 26 (AP)The F.B.I. says the kidnapping of a banker's wife near here recently was planned by three men during a nightlong beerdrinking session.

title: Superdome Bonds Go Unsold
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP)The Louisiana Superdome tried and failed today to sell $139.9million in bonds to refinance the massive stadium currently under construction. Herman J.Kohlmeyer Sr., financial adviser the stadium commission, said no bids were received because of the unfavorable nature of the bond market. The commission voted to readvertise for bids at a new date, hoping for a more favorable market.

title: Electronics Executives Stress Export Markets
description: An electronics industry leader complained here yesterday that Japan, by maintaining many limits on investment by American companies, continues to operate as though she were an undeveloped nation in need of special protection,

title: Tyco Laboratories Is Seeking Simplex CableWire Company
description: Tyco Laboratories said it would pay $24.25 cash for each of the 907,823 shares outstanding of the Simplex Cable and Wire Company. The offer came to a total of more than $22million.

title: Pope, Stricken by Illness, Cancels Weekly Audience
description: ROME, March 26The Vatican said today that Pope Paul VI was not well and had been advised by his doctor to cancel his weekly general audience tomorrow.

title: '75 Playoff Causes Stir In N.C.A.A.
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 26 North Carolina State's 76.64 victory over Marquette for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship Monday night was an anticlimax to the Wolfpack's semifinal triumph over the University of California Los Angeles, on Saturday. It also marked the end of the current format for this N.C.A.A. tournament and appeared to start an argument over how the 32 teams will he selected for the 1975 championship.

title: Papal Aide Speaks to Jewish Council
description: The Most Rev. Jean Jadot, tte representative of Pope Paul VI in this country, declared last night that dialogue between Christians and Jews has entered a new stage marked by sober and serious consideration of interfaith problems.

title: PRICE RISE SEEN IN BAUXITE TALKS
New Paltz Students Stale Office SitIn To Protest Policies
description: NEW PALTZ N. Y., March 26About 1,000 students at the State University college here occupied the ninestory administration building today, protesting against what a spokesman described as the trend back to more traditional methods.

title: BASQUIN'S TALENTS AS PIANIST THRIVE
description: When Peter Basquin made his New York recital debut in Alice Tully Hall three years ago, he was an experienced pianist, which showed in the perfection and apparent ease of his playing. At the advanced age of 30, he was back in Tully Hall on Monday night for another recital, giving the same kind of beautifully poised performances as :before, but with some added ;personal touches here and there.

title: Competing for Securities
description: Just when it seemed to be moving into the clear, the drive to promote open competition in the nation's securities markets is running into new resistance on Capitol Hill. Early this month the Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved comprehensive reform legislation to create a national central market system and eliminate fixed commission rates and other longenshrined anticompetitive practices. But floor action is now stalled pending consideration of a related measure which could give a Federal regulatory agency the authority to close down the socalled third market, the increasingly pop ular facility for trading listed stocks off the exchanges.

title: Books of The Times
description: FAULKNER. A Biography. By Joseph Btotner. 2,115 pages. Illustrated. Random House. Two volumes. Boxed. $25.

title: Milk CoOp s Report Finds Abuses in Campaign Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 26A report on political spending by Associated Milk Producers, Inc., prepared at the request of its own officers, indicates al broad pattern of irregularities involving both Republicans and Democrats over a long period.

title: Israeli Styles Grace Mayor's Mansion
description: It was the first, and quite possibly the last, benefit fashion show at Gracie Mansion, presided over by the Mayor's wife. Not that Mary Beame has anything against fashion. She's quite fascinated by it. In fact, she asked Ohrbach's to send her the white spring coat she admired at the fashion show she went to at the store the day before.

title: TWO ARE ACCUSED OF BILKING POOR
description: An executive of a food service and his cousin, a, bank loan officer, were indicted here yesterday on charges of having fraudulently arranged bank loans for lowincome investors who allegedly were then swindled out of their capital in franchise pyramiding scheme.

title: Kissinger,Breziinev Confer for 2d Day; Mideast Is Discussed
description: MOSCOW, March 26 Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger, meeting for a second day at the Kremlin, dwelt today on approaches to a settlement in the Middle East, an area that has lately been a source of strain in SovietAmerican relations.

title: People and Business
description: Harold S. Geneen, chairman and chief executive officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, holds the No. 1 position in corporate executive compensation  as indicated by the annual meeting proxy statements that have been distributed thus farwith a 1973 total income of $814,299. This marked a raise of $19 a week over his salary and bonus from the giant conglomerate in 1972.

title: S.B.A. Says Fourth Of Its Offices Have Serious Problems
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Nearly, onefourth of the Small Business Administration offices have serious problems, the agency has told Congress.

title: Tanner Victor; Nastase Upset
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., March 26 (AP)Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Term., placing his fast first serve perfectly, upset secondseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden today, 57, 63, 75, in the first round of the $50,000 Desert tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis circuit event.

title: Buckley Mail 31 Against View on Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Senator James L. Buckley of New York said today that he had received more than 10,000 letters since urging President Nixon to resign and that most of them had denounced his suggestion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jack Sable, the State Human Rights Commissioner, ruled that the Long Island Rail Road's 5foot, 7inch minimum height requirement for trainmen and engineers would bar about 95 per cent of all women and therefore was discriminatory and illegal. The challenge to the railroad's policy was made last year by Carol Wagner, a 5foot Manhattan French teacher who argued that she was denied a job of trainman because she was a woman. Spokesmen for the railroad had said Miss Wagner's height would pose safety hazards.

title: New Jersey Will Lift OddEven Fuel Rules
description: TRENTON, March 27Government Byrne announced yesterday that he would suspend New Jersey's mandatory oddeven gasoline allocation regulations effective Monday.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
Saxbe Says a Nixon Voice Is Up to the Rodino Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that it was entirely up to the House Judiciary Committee to decide whether to allow the White House to take an active role in the House impeachment inquiry.

title: Trial Ordered in Abduction
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 27 (AP)A housing contractor, James W. Johnson, 35 years old, was bound over yesterday for trial in Federal District Court, but his bond was reduced from $100,000 to $50,000. He and two other men are accused of violating the Hobbs Act in the abduction of Eunice Kronholm, the wife of a South St. Paul bank president, for $200,000 ransom. The act prohibits extortion from a business engaged in interstate commerce.

title: Animals Get Film Safeguard
description: A resolution to abolish inhumane treatment of animals in films, was adopted yesterday by the board of directors of the Motion Picture Association of America. The resolution came after Jack Valenti, president of the Association at 522 Fifth Avenue, had met March 14 with representatives of the Fund for Animals, the Humane Society of the United States and the American Humane Society, who were protesting the treatment of some animals in films.

title: Jury's Nixon Data Opened By Rodino and Hutchinson
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Two senior members of the House impeachment inquiry began examining grand jury evidence today on President Nixon's role in the Watergate scandal.

title: F. W. WOOLWORTH POSTS NEW HIGH
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, the nation's largest retail variety chain, fared better last year than most other merchandisers, It reported yesterday sharp increases to records for its 1973 sales and earnings.

title: Saints Halt Knights
description: ST. PAUL March 27 (AP) Murray Heatley scored twice and added an assist tonight as the Minnesota Fighting Saints won their third straight W.H.A. game, by defeating the Jersey Knights, 6.4. Mike Walton added his 54th goal of the season and 113th point to stay seven ahead of Andre LaCroix of Jersey in their race for the W.H.A. scoring crown. LaCroix had one assist.

title: Photo of Allende on Last Day Wins Prize for Chilean
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 27 (UPI)An unidentified Chilean won the grand prize today in the annual World Press Photo Contest here for a picture of President Salvador Allende Gossens taken on the day he died in a military coup.

title: Emigrants From Philippines Jam Into Little Manila in Honolulu and Find Life Difficult
description: HONOLULU, March 27For reasons that are visually obvious, the seedy KalihiPalawa section of downtown Honolulu is often called Little Manila.

title: Syrian Criticism of Egypt Splits Arabs'
description: TUNIS, March 27Differences between Syria and Egypt over peace with Israel have split a conference of ministers of the 21nation Arab League here that opened on Monday in a show of solidarity and optimism.

title: BAKER SAYS REPORT ON C.I.A. IS FINISHED
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. told newsmen today that he had completed an investigation into the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement with the Watergate scandal and forwarded it to the Senate Armed Services and Appropriations Committees for study.

title: Connecticut Nuclear Plant Closed to Fix Vibrations
description: HADDAM, Conn, March 27 (AP)  The Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant will be shut down for about three weeks to determine the cause of turbine vibrations, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities said today.

title: U.S. Sees 8% Drop For Crops in Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)Soviet crop production in 1974 probably will drop about 8 per cent from last year's record, but Russia probably will reduce its grain imports sharply and may return to its traditional role of a net grain exporter, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Blazers Win Draft Rights To Walton on a Coin Toss
description: The Portland Trail Blazers won yesterday the National Basketball Association draft rights to Bill Walton, the heralded University of California Los Angeles, 6foot11inch center.

title: Drills Sing in Park as Museum Flexes Wings
Cook Says Chat With Stans Led to Shift in Vesco Suit
Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester. day was: 82024

title: Pickpocket to Wear Mittens
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP)Superior Court Judge Richard Hayden has sentenced Joseph Buell, a professional pickpocket, to wear mittens on his hands every time he goes out in public for five years. Before Mr. Buell is placed on the mittenwearing probation, he must spend a year in county jail.

title: BENJAMIN GORDON, ECONOMIC ADVISER
description: Benjamin H. Gordon, who retired in 1957 after 15 years as an economic consultant in the New York regional office of the United States Department of Commerce, died Tuesday at his home, 162 West 56th Street. He was 88 years old.

title: Appraisal Week Lures Thousands to Parke Bernet
Bridge: 32 Teams in Second Round Of Vanderbilt Knockout Play
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 27The Vanderbilt knockout team championship went into the second round of play here this afternoon, with 32 teams battling for survival in the most prestigious event at the American Contract Bridge League. There were no upsets in the first round yesterday, but some are likely today.

title: Merrill Offers a CutRate Plan
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., in a move it said was designed to bring the small investor back to the stock market, disclosed here yesterday that it was introducing a new planfor those who want itthat would drastically reduce commission rates on small orders.

title: Failure in the House
description: Once again the House of Representatives, following its own baser instincts and President Nixon's bad advice, has tied the albatross of a mischievous antibusing amendment around the neck of a good education bill. By placing politics ahead of principles, the House has jeopardized chances for speedy enactment of a measure whose delay will make effective fiscal planning by the nation's schools and colleges virtually impossible.

title: Syrian Criticism of Egypt Splits Arabs Conference
description: TUNIS, March 27Differences between Syria and Egypt over peace with Israel have split a conference of ministers of the 21nation Arab League here that opened on Monday in a show of solidarity and optimism.

title: Yankees Pass Up Their. Chance to  Sign Aparicio
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 27Can the Yankees find happiness by signing 39goingon40yearold shortstop who has played 18 years and 2,559 games in the majors and earns $104,000.

title: Essex Jail Guard Tells of Pressure for Political Gifts
Joseph P. Bailey, Leader In Typographical Union
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 27 (AP)Joseph P. Bailey, third vice president and, a member of the executive council of the International Typographical Union, died yesterday after a stroke. He was 70 years old.

title: Nixon Weighs Release Of'73 Income  Tax Data
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)President Nixon has not yet decided whether to make public his Federal income tax return of 1973, Ronald L. Ziegler, his press secretary, said today.

title: Appraisal Week Lures Thousands to Parke Bernet
description: The elegant Sotheby Parke Bernet auction house, normally the market place for the aristocracy of the art world, looked just like a flea market yesterdaywhich is almost what it was.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 27 (UPI)Indiana favored to take its seventh straight National Collegiate swimming championship in the competition beginning here tomorrow. More than 500 athletes from 92 schools will take part in the threeday event. The chief threats to Indiana are expected to be Southern California, Tennessee and Washington. The Trojans have finished second four times in the Hoosiers streak.

title: HAMILTON
description: Chico Hamilton has always been a drummer with a theatrical, moodsetting concept of drumming. Sometimes he has been exotic.(as in his Blue Sands), sometimes subtly supportive (as in his groups of more than a decade ago that featured guitar and cello). But with the explosive young sextet he is leading this week at Mikell's, Columbus Avenue at 97th Street, Mr. Hamilton is openly and exuberantly swinging.

title: Law on CarRepair Lien Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: TRENTON, March 27 (UPI)A 1915 state law that allowed auto repair shops to place a ien on a car until the owner paid the bill was declared unconstitutional today by the United States District Court.

title: Veto of Death Penalty Bill Is Upheld in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, March 27 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate sustained today Gov. Francis W. Sargent's veto of a bill restoring the death penalty.

title: House Panel Votes Tribes Role In Environment for Strip Mines
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The House Interior Committee voted overwhelmingly today te give Indian tribes, whose reservaitons in the Far West contain large amounts of undeveloped, stripmineable coal, virtual sovereignty over the environmental standards to be imposed upon a number of major mineral corporations that have a vast stake in future coal mining operations there.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Moscow's Little Hints
description: MOSCOW, March 27As Andrei A. Gromyko walked into Spaso House today for a lunch given by Secretary of State Kissinger, the newsstarved American correspondents inside the American Ambassador's residence called out to the Soviet Foreign Minister, How are the talks going?

title: Hole Rallies Shy Dawn to $18.40 Triumph in the Searching Stakes
description: Shy Dawn gave her trainer, Woody. Sedlacek, two thrills at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3yearold Kentucky bred, owned by Jacques Wimpfhelmer, won the first running of the Searching under a brilliant ride by Michael Hole, and the performance so pleased Sedlacek that he said, I must see this race again right away on the rerun.

title: Family Friend Charged in Boy's Death
description: A 20yearold man from Flushing, Queens, was charged yesterday in the slaying of 7yearold boy whose body was found Tuesday in a boardedup house in the neighborhood where they both lived.

title: Warnings on the Use of XRays Are Held Ignored Over 25 Years
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 27A leading health scientist said here today that very little had been accomplished by his warnings over the last quartercentury that Americans were receiving needless, harmful overdoses of radiation from diagnostic Xrays.

title: Seaver Shapes Up, Beauchamp Is Cut
First Soviet Stationary Satellite
description: The Soviet Union launched its first synchronous satellite yesterday, the type that remains stationary in the sky above a particular spot on earth.

title: Everglades Fires Put Out
description: THE EVERGLADES, Fla,, March 27 (AP)Forestry Service firefighters relaxed for the first time in weeks today after extinguishing the last of a rash of arsonset Everglades fires.

title: Wind, Fog Puts Off Ski World Series
description: RENO, March 27 (AP)Strong winds and fog at the Mount Rose resort forced the postponement today of the first men's giant slalom in the World Series of Skiing. The race was rescheduled for tomorrow before the women's giant slalom.

title: Chicago Papers Up to 15c
description: CHICAGO, March 27 (UPI)All four daily newspapers in Chicago announced today they were raising their newsstand prices from 10 cents to 15 cents, effective April 1. The papers are The Tribune, SunTimes. Daily News and Today.

title: HENRY L. ENGEL
description: Henry L. Engel, former president of Bernhard Ulmann Company, textile manufacturer of Long Island City, Queens, who retired in 1967 after 57 years with the company, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 1095 Park Avenue.

title: Revson Service Today
description: The body of Peter Revson, who was killed Friday in an auto race in South Africa, was flown back to the United States yesterday. Services for the 35yearold driver will be held at noon today at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 30th street. Burial will be in Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: Eased Curbs on Navel Oranges Asked
description: WASHINGTON, March 27In another thrust at what he (regards as an inflationary Government hunt policy, John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, disclosed today that he had been trying to persuade Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz to ease restrictions on the marketing of navel oranges.

title: Compromise Plan Offered by S. E. C. On3dMarketDeals
description: WASHINGTON, March 27;The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Treasury Department offered a compromise proposal today to head, off a Senate floor fight over a New York Stock Exchange plan to prohibit thirdmarket trading in listed securities.

title: Pathet Lao Joins in a Force For Security of Vientiane
description: VIENTIANE, Laos. March 27 (AP)The Laotian Government today transferred full responsibility for the military security of Vientiane to a joint military command with the Pathet Lao.

title: House Votes New Funding For Veterans School Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)The House voted without dissent today to authorize argent supplemental funding for educational benefits to veterans.

title: Approval of 3 New Law Schools Urged
About the Mets..
description: Willie Mays, the silent man of the Mets spring, will not accompany the team north next week. He will stay in St. Petersburg and help coach the minor leagues at the Mets complex, then will rejoin the varsity in New York on April 9 for the home opener.... Casey Stengel ended one week of sideline chatter and comment and flew home to Glendale, Calif.... Both Cleon Jones and Rusty Staub, and their sore throwing shoulders, made the starting lineup against Pittsburgh. Jones contributed a single and double but did no hard throwing from left field.... The Pirates have fewer roster problems than the Mets, largely because they cut eight men a week ago. They're down to 31 now and must eliminate another six to reach the openingday limit of 25.

title: People and Business
description: David Merrick, the Broadway and Hollywood producer, has sharply increased his holdings in the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, leading to strong reports that he may. be planning a tender offer or proxy fight for the film producer and distributor.

title: 4 CourtReform Bills Win Approval in State Senate
description: ALBANY, March 27A series of four court reorganization measures that include provisions for the appointment of judges of the Court of Appeals and the creation of a Commission on Judicial Conduct were passed today by the +State Senate.

title: Trudeau and Premiers Reach Interim Accord on Oil Prices
description: OTTAWA, March 27After months of hard bargaining, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Canada's provincial premiers agreed today on an interim solution to the country's regional dispute over the domestic price of oil,

title: Hanoi Aide, in Cuba, Says U.S. Infiltrates Soldiers in Disguise
description: HAVANA, March 27 (Reuters) The North Vietnamese Premier, Pham Van Dong, has accused the United States of infiltrating soldiers dressed as civilians into South Vietnam.

title: Champagne and Morels for Those Who Finish a Coat
description: If someone regularly gets morels from Wisconsin and teaches sewing classes in New York, how about bringing mushrooms and neophyte seamstresses together?

title: Seattle Voters Reject Plan To Lift Marijuana Penalty
description: SEATTLE, March 27Voters have rejected, 55,287 to 25,027, a proposal that would have made Seattle the first major American city to lift criminal penalties for private possession of 40 grams of marijuana or less.

title: Notes on People
description: A retired Washington builder, Myron Davy, has paid $300,000 to buy the Washington suburban home of Spiro T. Agnew, the former Vice President. The Agnews, who bought the place 15 months ago for $190,000, have 90 days to vacate; they are expected to move out of the house in Kellwood, Md., next month. They were said to be looking for a new home that would cost no more than $100,000.

title: Alternative Plan on H.R.A. Is Offered
description: The city's Human Resources Administrator, James R. Dumpson, announced yesterday proposals for realignment of his agency, rather than the dismantling Mayor Beanie called for in appointing him last January.

title: MRS. VANDEN HEUVEL
description: Mrs. Alberta vanden Heuvel, mother of William J. vanden Heuvel, former chairman of the City Board of Correction, died yesterday at her home, 83 Alexander Avenue, Nutley, N. J. She was 84 years old and the widow of Joost vanden Heuvel, who died in 1957.

title: People in Sports
description: Brian Oldfield, the 6foot5inch, 270pound world professional indoor shotput recordholder (70 feet 10 inches), signed a contract with the New York Stars of the fledgling World Football League yesterday.

title: Rangers Bow. Despite 2 Tkaczuk Goals
KURD SEES THREAT OF BIG WAR IN IRAQ
description: BEYZI, Iraq, March 27 (AP) Gen. Mustafa alBarzani, leader of Iraq's rebellious Kurdish minority, said today that his tribesmen and Iraqi GovI ernment troops face the possibility of allout war.

title: MOZAMBIQUE CRASH REPORTED TO KILL 60
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 27 (Reuters)  Sixty people were believed to have been burned to death today in a headon collision between two trains near the Mozambique capital of Lourenco Marques, according to reliable reports reaching here.

title: Nixon Says Republicans Who Back Him Can Win
description: WASHINGTON, March 27President Nixon told a Republimn fundraising dinner tonight that candidates who support this Administration will have strong case to take to the people this fall.

title: ARTHUR BROWER, PHOTOGRAPHER, 58
description: Arthur Brower, assistant supervisor of the newsroom photo laboratory of The New York Times, died yesterday after having suffered a heart attack while at work. He was 58 years old and lived at 78 Glen Road in Yonkers.

title: Chauveron Flew South, And Took the Cafe Along
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla.When we first arrived on the food scene in New York some 25 years ago, there were only four or five luxury restaurants in Manhattan of genuine substance and international repute. There was no La Caravelle, no La Grenouille, no Lutece, no La COte Basque, no Four Seasons.

title: Red Smith
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 27On the hotel elevator a man asked: What is the area of Zaire?

title: Nixon Says Republicans Who Back Him Can Win
description: IMASHINGTON, March 27President Nixon told a Republican fundraising dinner tonight that candidates who support this Administration will have a strong case to take to the people this fall.

title: COURT TO OVERSEE 2 BRONX BUILDINGS
description: In what housing officials here yesterday called a precedentseqing decision, a Housing Court judge has placed two Bronx apartment buildings under court supervisionone permanently and one for a yearto assure that future violations are speedily corrected.

title: People and Business
description: David Merrick, the Broadway and Hollywood producer, has sharply increased his holdings in the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, leading to strong reports that he may. be planning a tender offer or proxy fight for the film producer and distributor.

title: A Lavish Gatsby Loses Book s Spirit
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A task force of police and fire officials, and inspectors from the Sanitation, Consumer Affairs and Buildings Departments descended on auto body shops in the Elmhurst and Corona sections of Queens yesterday morning and issued summonses for numerous violations.

title: PITH END ARMS MID AID FOR CHILE
description: LONDON, March 27Britain announced today that she would sell no more arms to Chile and would suspend economic aid.

title: Nets Win To Clinch East Title
Kuh Lists Plans to Streamline His Office
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh issued a 14page Progress Report to the People of New York County yesterday in which he described efforts by his office to develop increased public confidence in law enforcement.

title: Swift Killing of Tainted Chickens Pushed in South
description: FOREST, Miss., March 27More than 35,000 chickens were gassed to death and buried here today as state and Federal agricultural and health authorities pushed to complete the destruction of some four million broilers contaminated by a cancerinducing insecticide.

title: SHELLING CONTINUES ON THE GOLAN FRONT
description: TEL AVIV, March 27 (Reuters)An artillery duel erupted along the Golan Heights front today for the 16th successive day, and a military spokesman here said a United Nations observation post in the Israeliheld area was damaged.

title: DR. DONALD WRIGHT, TAUGHT AT BROOKLYN
description: Dr. Donald Decker Wright, professor Of chemistry at Brooklyn College, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived on Midwood Street in Brooklyn.

title: CHASE BANK LIFTS PRIMELOAN RATE
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that was raising, effective today, its minimum interest rate on corporate loans to 9 per cent from 9 per cent, a rate that has been in effect only a week. This increase In the prime rate, the Chase said, came in response to a continued sharp rise in other shortterm money market rates.

title: Louisiana Pacific And Sierra Begin Acquisition Talks
description: Merger talks have begun betreen two companies in the forest products field, Sierra Pacific Industries and the Louisiana Pacific Corporation, the companies disclosed yesterday.

title: City Presses Plans For Convention Hall Despite Challenges
description: The city is pressing forward with plans for a $200million convention hall on the Hudson River west of Times Square in the face of sustained challenges from opponents.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
Flooding in Brazil Said to Destroy City And Take High Toll
Ceausescu Is Slated to Get Added Powers Next Week
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 27 (AP)Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, will officially named President of the country next week with the added power to make decisions without consulting the State Council.

title: Beef Industry Stunned by U.S. Hamburger Decision
description: The beeg indsutry was stunned yesterday by a small first step by the Administration to stave off possible economic ruin among cattle feedlot operators.

title: Seats of Influence
description: Members of the general public have been waiting in line for as long as four hours to obtain seats at the trial of former Nixon Cabinet members John N. Mitchell and Maurice Stans. On Monday when John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel and star witness in the case, began his testimony, those who had kept this long vigil discovered on entering the courtroom that all but 28 seats had been preempted by relatives and friends Judge Lee P. Gagliardi and of lawyers on both sides as well as by other attorneys and individuals who have influence with courthouse officials. These favored persons were admitted to the courtroom through a back door, the judge's entrance.

title: Ashe, Layer, Kodes Gain In Tourney
Giants Accentuate Youth, But Pitching Is Uncertain
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March If their pitching holds up, said one of baseball's most knowledgeable scouts, they can really be something, because they have many people who can really do a lot of things.

title: Surplus in U.S. Trade Shrinks
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The United States trade surplus diminished again in February as higher oil prices more than offset some decline in the volume of oil imported, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PRICE OF GOLD SLIPS TO $174 IN EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS. March 27 (UPI)Gold prices retreated on European bullion exchanges today. The dollar improved in Frankfurt but continued to slip in Paris, London and Zurich.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (Reuters)The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose 1.8 per cent in February following a 1.2 per cent gain in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Auto Makers Shift 74 Spending Plans
description: DETROIT, March 27The energy crisis and the consumers switch to small cars has caused the four United States auto companies to make wholesale changes in their multibillion dollar capital spending plans for 1974.

title: Surplus in U.S. Trade Shrinks
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The United States trade surplus diminished again in Febru, ary as higher oil prices more than offset some decline in the volume of oil imported, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: First Mortgage Expecting No Kassuba Loan Losses
description: First Mortgage Investors, one of the principal creditors of Walter J. Kassuba, one of the major apartment developers in the United States, announced yesterday that it expected little or no loss resulting from the Kassuba loans.

title: Paris Removes Chief Of Agency Accused Of Spying on Press
description: PARIS, March 27 (Reuters)The Government announced today the removal of the chief of France's counterespionage agency, which has been accused of planting secret microphones in the offices of the satirical paper, Le Canard Enchaine

title: Big South Vietnamese Convoy Ambushed in Central Highlands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 27 (UPI)  Vietcong forces ambushed a 66truck Government military convoy in the Central Highlands today, destroying or immobilizing at least half the vehicles, military sources said.

title: Emminger Disputes View On Oil Price Rise Impact
description: WASHINGTON, March, 27A leading European Economic official sharply disputed today several commonly held views about the impact of the explosion of oil prices on the world economy, including the view that the price increase heightens the danger of a world recession.

title: TV: Oscar Time Is Cue to Open Movie Floodgate
description: It's Oscar time, and movie fever has settled on broadcasting. Next Tuesday's Academy Awards will be carried on National Broadcasting Company stations, but that hasn't stopped the network's competitors from trying to wriggle into the act.

title: MEDIATORS PRESS FOR TRANSIT PACE
description: With time growing short in the city's critical transit negotiations, a threeman mediation panel scheduled a meeting for this afternoon with Mayor Beame to report on the status of the talks and the problems in getting a settlement before the 5 AM, Monday deadline.

title: Bridge:32 Teams in Second Round Of Vanderbilt Knockout Play
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 27The Vanderbilt knockout team championship went into the second round of play here this afternoon, with 32 teams battling for survival in the most prestigious event at the American Contract Bridge League. There were no upsets in the first round yesterday, but some are likely today.

title: TOT QUALTERS DIES; STAGE ACTRESS, 79
description: Tot Qualters, a musicalcomedy actress of a generation ago, died in her sleep yesterday in the Great Northern Hotel, 118 West 57th Street. Today would have been her 80th birthday.

title: Mrs. King Serves Ace in Behalf of Ballgirls
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King scored another victory last night, but it came away from the tennis court.

title: CONTROLS ENDED IN COAL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (Reuters)  The Cost of Living Council removed today wage and price controls from the coal industry in exchange for pledge from most of the larger producers that they would raise production substantially and limit certain price increases.

title: Schrafft's Restaurant Closing After 44 Years
description: After 44 years of operation in the Chrysler Building, Schrafft's Restaurant will close its doors for good tomorrow.

title: Rebels in Ethiopia Seize Asmara for Second Time
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 27 (AP)  Rebels have again seized control off Asmara and a group of military officers told Ethiopians today that the armed forces would protect civilians from mass killing.

title: Chancellor Turns Tables and Caters to 50 Star Pupils in Salute to Youth
