description: High school marching bands marched, madrigal singers sang, cheerleaders cheered and Chancellor Irving Anker carried around a tray of roast beef sandwiches yesterday as the Board of Education honored 50 students for achievement in scholarship, community participation, leadership and creativity.

title: Truth in Lying
description: WASHINGTONIf you take an oath to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, and then you proceed deliberately to deceive your questioner with tricky evasions, misleading halftruths and unresponsive answersare you guilty of perjury?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Victor Perlo's March 1 letter asked questions we want to answer.

title: Stepping Off the Gas
description: The speed demons were back in action on the highways over the weekendthe first in which gasoline was easily availableproving their machismo by overtaking the enemy in the cars ahead of them. Anyone obeying the sensible fiftymileanhour limit on New York City parkways found himself eating gas fumes and even getting glares of superiority from speeders.

title: King Serves Ace In Behalf of Ballgirls
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King scored another victory last night, butit came away from the tennis court.

title: Public Financing Of Elections Wins Key Test in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A proposal to finance Presidential and Congressional election campaigns with public tax funds won on a key test vote in the Senate today.

title: Small Investor Turns to Gold
description: ZURICH, SwitzerlandSwiss bankers report that the small investor in Western European countries has started buying gold in substantial quantities a development that they say is triggering the rapid rise in bullion prices.

title: East German Team Triumphs in Soccer
description: BERLIN, March 27 (UPI)A 13th minute goal by a midfielder, Joachim Streich, gave East Germany a 10 victory over Czechoslovakia today in a World Soccer Cup tryout. A crowd of 55,000 packed Dresden's stadium. Sixteen countries will compete in the World Cup playoffs in Germany next summer.

title: F.T.C. Nears Point Of Requiring Data By Line of Business
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had taken the nexttofinal step necessary before putting into effect its controversial new lineofbusiness reporting requirement for the nation's 500 largest manufacturing cornpanies.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: IRVINGTON, March 27The New Jersey allstate b4sketball players had been presented their awards, Lou Carneseeca had finished his speech and John Celentano had been presented his award as senior of the year.

title: COUNTRY'S HISTORY INSPIRES CHORALE
description: As the nation's bicentennial approaches, historical programs of American music are increasing in number, and since this country had hardly any formal instrumental music during the first century of its existence, most of these programs are of vocal music.

title: Main British Union Group Supports Laborite Budget
description: LONDON, March 27Britain's main labor organization, representing some 9.5 million workers, gave an initial endorsement today to the budget announced yesterday by the new Cabinet of Prime Minister Wilson.

title: Prices Increased By Wheeling Steel For Varied Goods
description: PITTSBURGH, March 27 (AP)  The WheelingPittsburgh Steer Corporation increased prices.today on a wide variety of steel products used in the construction, manufacturing, Automotive, and fuel industries. The increases, effective immediately, cover tinmill products, hot dipped galvanized products, and heamless carbon and alloy specialty tubing.

title: Dtente: The Balance Sheet
description: Dtente has had a bad press of late on both sides of the fence that was once called the Iron Curtain. A national weekly writes of Dtente: End of Illusions. A Soviet general states that political dtente cannot be durable and irreversible if the arms race continues. On the other hand, the President and Secretary of State inform us that dtente serves the purpose of avoiding nuclear war.

title: MAGMA FIGHTS U.S. ON PRIORITY ACTION
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said late yesterday that its subsidiary, the Magma Copper Company, had filed suit in the United States District Court in the District of Columbia seeking to have declared illegal a recent Government action that placed domestic primary producerrefined copper under the defense priority system.

title: House Panel Says DC10's Flew Without Change Vital to Safety,
description: WASHINGTON, March 27For three to 11, months after the nearcrash of a DC10 in Jane, 1972, most of the 39 DC10's previously produced remained in regular passenger service even though they lacked a vital cargo door design change recommended by the plane's builder, a House committee disclosed today.

title: KISSINGER ENDS 3 DAYS OF TALKS BREZEINEV
description: MOSCOW, March 27Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger completed three days of talks tonight with both sides pointing toward achieving concrete agreements during President Nixon's expected visit here in June.

title: Ballet: Pas Espagnol
description: Benjamin Harkarvy's Grand Pas Espagnol, which last night returned to the Joffrey Ballet repertory at the City Center 55th Street Theater, is an endearing example of timetraveling and a pleasant example of ballet spoof rather than ballet russe. Not that it is meant to be funnynot one bit of it. But it is meant to be affectionately moved from Spanish dance reality.

title: JUNTA'S GRIP FELT IN CHILEAN SLUM
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March  A dozen people lined up side the home of the neighborhood council president in a shantytown in Lo Hermida, a sprawling slum of wooden shacks and unpaved alleys eastern Santiago.

title: SUBWAY WORKMEN FLEE TUNNEL BLAZE
description: Two dozen workmen were evacuated safely yesterday after a fire broke out in a subway tunnel under construction in the Jamaica section of Queens and thick, gray smoke filled the 1,000footlong shaft.

title: WALSTON SEEKING A REORGANIZATION
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., which quit the stock brokerage business voluntarily on Jan. 21, filed for reorganization yesterday under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Under this statute, the present management, headed by Walter E. Auch, president, will continue in possession of the concern's assets until it can reach settlement with creditors.

title: Maine Made Sense
description: FIVE ISLANDS, Me.  People kept telling me I had guts to move to Maine. Frankly, I thought I had common sense, for I wanted to play where I understood the rules of the game.

title: ENERGY BILL TALKS HALT IN DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Negotiations between the Administration and Democratic Congressional leaders for a new emergency energy bill broke down tonight, raising questions about the ability of the Administration and Congress to collaborate successfully on a wider range of energy meaures.

title: Beef Brochette Dinners Recalled by Food Agency
description: WASHINGTON, March 271 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration announced today, the recall of frozen beef brochette dinners, possibly containing contaminated mushrooms, that were sold through Air Force commissaries.

title: Contract Awards
description: Mapco, Inc., said yesterday it had signed longterm contracts to supply coal to two utilities. The coal would come from Mapco's Martiki mine now being developed in Martin County, Ky. It is valued at about $600million. The agreements call for shipment of 2 million tonsayear over a 20year period. The utilities were not identified. The mine has proven recoverable reserves of about 70 million Lions. The agreements provide for full cost escalation and a yearly reopener to implement market. price adjustments,

title: Consumer Notes
description: Although the Food and Drug Administration, after a twoyear study, refused to remove vaginal sprays from the market, a consumer group in Rochester feels they should not be sold, and it has persuaded some major retail outlets in that city to take the products off their shelves.

title: ANGRY EXCHANGE IN ROTHKO CASE
description: Lawyers in the Mark Rothko estate ease; exchanged angry words and one threatened to! hale another before a bar association grievance, committee on ethics charges in Surrogates Court yesterday.

title: Senegal Frees ExPremier Jailed in Plot Case
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 27 (Agence FrancePresse)A former Senegalese Premier, Mamadou Dia, and two members of his Cabinet were released from jail today with 14 other political detainees.

title: 2 School Trustees Prepare to Oust 45 In Queens District
description: Two trustees, acting on be half of the central Board of Education, superseded the District 26 Comunity School Board in Queens yesterday and pre pared to dismiss 38 teachers and seven supervisors.

title: Britain on a Tightrope
description: The budget presented by the new Labor Government had to be tailored to reflect the hard facts of Britain's economic outlook as well as the political arithmetic the House of Commons. It was thus a neutral package, aimed at reassuring those forces at home and abroad on which the economy heavily depends while making some gestures toward the minority Government's own supporters and the program they advocated in the February election.

title: SAUDI PRODUCTION OF OIL INCREASED
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 27Saudi Arabia has authorized the Arabian American Oil Company to produce 8.5 million barrels a day next month, according to official sources.

title: DEFENSE OF GROSS ASSAILS IMMUNITY
description: NEWARK, March 27De fense counsel for Nelson G. Gross charged today that the United States Attorney's office had paid for cooperation it building its campaign tram case against the former state Republican chairman by offering witnesses immunity from prosecution or promising there help in obtaining light sentences for their own misdeeds

title: DOWNSTATE GETS A MEDICAL DEAN
description: Dr. Leonard Laster, a top official of the National Research Council and a former policy maker for the President's Office of Science and Technology, was named yesterday to be vice president for academic and clinical affairs and dean of the College of Medicine at the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins in Ruby
description: LOUGHBOROUGH, England, March 27 (AP)The touring rugby football team from the University of California, Los Angeles, defeated the English collegiate champion, Loughborough College, 196, today.

title: GEORGE HACKL JR., 69, OF EXCHANGE BOARD
description: George F. Hackl Jr., a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died Tuesday at his home, 251 Bayard Lane, Princeton, N. J. He was 69 years old and lived also in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: And You Are A Lawyer?
description: John Dean was being crossexamined, and defense counsel Peter Fleming showed the traditional scorn for witness who has peached on his old chums. Wasn't Mr. Dean hoping benefit from his cooperation? Mr. Fleming spoke the word with distaste.

title: Stage: Nowhere to Run
12 Food Establishments Listed As Violators of the Health Code
Market Place: Rivals Assess Merrill's Plan
description: Before he went on stage yehterday morning, Donald T. Regan, the boss at Merrill Lynch, was asked by a reporter: How do you feel?

title: Raymond Brandt, Bureau Chief Of PostDispatch in Capital, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Raymond P. Brandt, chief of the Washington bureau of The St. Louis PostDispatch from 1934 to 1961 and later a contributing editor, died today in Georgetown University Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: 76ers Top Celtics In Finale
COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Gasoline Output Up In  Week but Slipped Below 1973 Period
description: WASHINGTON; March 27 (AP)The American Petroleum Institute reported today that total estimated gasoline production, aviation and motor, for the latest week amounted to 6,022,000 barrels a day, in the previous week and 6,191,000 barrels a day a year ago.

title: U, S. VICE CONSUL MISSING IN MEXICO
Bonn to Provide $2.4Billion To Offset U.S. Troop Costs
description: BONN, March 27 (Reuters)The West German Government agreed today to contribute over $2.4billion to offset United States foreignexchange costs in stationing troops here, informed Government sources said.

title: Stage: Hawthorne Story
description: Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Minister's Black Veil is a strange mystical tale about a 19thcentury New England minister who suddenly and inexplicably starts wearing a veil over his face. At first his parishioners regard him as an eccentric, but soon a feeling of awe and dread creeps over them. The minister becomes the symbolic embodiment of their guilt, conscience and mortification.

title: Dowdy Loses Bid for Parole
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (Reuters)  The United States Board of Parole announced today that it had denied a request for parole from former Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, who is serving a sixmonth sentence for perjury. Mr. Dowdy, 62 years old, was convicted. Dec. 31, 1971, of accepting a $25,000 bribe to kelp block a Federal investigation of a construction company. His sentence is to end June 27.

title: U.S. VICE CONSUL MISSING IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, March 27United States and Mexican officials announced today that 31yearold John Patterson, a United States vice consul stationed in northwest Mexico, disappeared last Friday and was presumed kidnapped.

title: Egypt Said to Agree to Remove Unauthorized Guns Along Canal
description: CAIRO, March 27Informed sources said today that Egypt had agreed to pull back any artillery from the east bank of the Suez Canal that had been placed there in violation of the EgyptianIsraeli agreement on troop disengagement.

title: Getting Down to Work in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 27The 1974 legislative session began last night.

title: U.S. Moves a Step Closer To Ties With East Germany
description: BONN, March 27The United States came a step closer to establishing relations with East Germany when the Government in East Berlin showed a State Department delegation what it considered reasonable property for a United States mission, according to officials here.

title: Chris Evert Wins After Shaky Start
description: After having been blitzed in the opening set, Chris Evert recovered for a 23, 61, 62 victory over Mrs. Mary Ann Beattie last night in the $60,000 women's national indoor tennis championship at Felt Forum.

title: SCHOOL STRIKE ENDS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 (UPI)The American Federation of Teachers, which earlier in the day rejected an agreement to end the 20day city school strike, reversed itself tonight and voted to accept the pact.

title: MORE CARE URGED FOR THE RETARDED
description: Dr. June J. Christmas, City Commissioner of Mental Health and Retardation, and representatives of voluntary groups called yesterday for increased care for the retarded, emphasizing at the same time that they try to prevent indiscriminate release of the retarded from state institutions unless there is provision for their care.

title: SWISS REUNION SET BY SOLZIENITSYNS
description: MOSCOW, March 27Mrs. Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn announced today that although it was excruciatingly painful to leave her Russian homeland, she and her family would join her husband in Switzerland Friday.

title: Hoopla Over  Gatsby' A Night to Look Jazzy
description: The Great Gatsby, which in recent weeks has replaced Watergate as the No. 1 topic of gossip on the chic cocktail circuit, opened last night. Finally.

title: Mariner 10 Will Visit Mercury Twice
description: PASADENA, March 27Thanks to a chance remark of an Italian visitor, scientists are planning for the eventual return of Mariner 10 to Mercury. The spacecraft, now plunging toward the planet at 24,000 miles an hour, will return six months from now for another close look.

title: RUTGERS RIOTERS FACE CIVIL ACTION
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 27  Rutgers University today warned students that future campus disruptions that constituted a significant and substantial violation of state law automatically would be referred to public prosecutors for prosecution.

title: Chess: Is He Who Hesitates Lost, Or Does Haste Make Waste?
More Spilled Milk
description: Money is the mother's milk of politics, a veteran political operator once observed. A report on its past political activities commissioned by the present board of directors of Associated Milk Producers, Inc. (A.M.P.I.), a major milk cooperative, shows that milk money has run in secret rivers to both parties and through illegal channels.

title: DUNLOP AGAIN ASKS WAGEPRICE POWERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, urged again today that Congress continue authority for wage and price controls over the health and construction industries.

title: Fight on TV Saturday
description: The world heavyweight title fight in which George Foreman knocked out Ken Norton will be shown on tape on Wide World of Sports, the American Broadcasting Company's television program starting at 5 P.M. Saturday.

title: NIXON AIDE HINTS SOME OF 42 TAPES MAY NOT EXIST
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A White House official left open today the passibility that some of the 42 tape recordings sought by the House Judiciary Committee might not exist.

title: Advertising: Victors From West
description: Although it wasn't billed as such, the cocktail party suite of the Biltmore Hotel last evening in a 10thfloor could well have been a victory party for Eisaman, Johns & Laws, the Los Angeles agency that beat out some highpowered New York shops for the Ballentine's Scotch whisky account last summer.

title: HOROVITZ LET GO BY CITY COLLEGE
description: Israel Horovitz, the playwright, has resigned from $19,000ayear position in City College's English department for falsely stating that he had a degree from Harvard.

title: Nadjari Will Insist Brownstein Waive Immunity on Testimony
description: The state's special prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, will insist on an unconditional waiver of immunity from State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein of Brooklyn and will press for his removal if the justice refuses, sources close to the case said yesterday.

title: Giants Accentuate Youth, But Pitching Is Uncertain
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27 If their pitching holds up, said one of baseball's most knowledgeable scouts, they can really be something, because they have so many people who can really do a lot of things.

title: MRS. C. E. WHITEHOUSE
description: Mrs. Narcissa Pillow Martin Whitehouse, widow of Clifford E. Whitehouse, a building contractor, died at her home Amherst, Mass., on Monday the age of 94. Earlier, she had been the widow of Col. Russell Reeder, an Army officer, who died in 1942.

title: Eduardo Santos, ExPresident Of Colombia, a Publisher, Dies
U.S. URGED TO ACT ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A House subcommittee called on the Nixon Administration today to pay greater attention to the violation of human rights in foreign countries.

title: COURT TO OVERSEE 2 BRONX BUILDINGS
description: In what housing officials here yeaterday called a precedent setting decision, a Housing Court judge has placed two Bronx apartment buildings under court supervisionone permanently and one for a yearto assure that future violations are speedily corrected.

title: Alcina Is Given in the New Way of Doing Handel
An Amateur Who Beats The Pros
description: Bonnie Proctor is a substitute teacher at Lehighton, Pa. But in the show ring, she's a frontline performer. Although an amateur, she competes weekend after weekend success fully against the professional handlers.

title: Raisin (9) Leads Tony Nominee List
Dow Corning Caulks to Rise
description: The Dow Corning Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices on several lines of consumer products, including silicone rubber caulks and sealers, beginning April 15. Increase forthe major product category, bathtub caulks and household sealers, will average about 10 per cent.

title: West Germany Sells Steel Mill to China
description: PEKING, March 27 (Reuters)  A West German consortium has sold China a coldstrip steel rolling mill for $200million, said to be the biggest single deal ever made between the two countries.

title: Stockholders Sue Gulf Aides Over Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A stockholder suit asking more than $1million in damages personally against officers of the Gulf Oil Corporation was filed today by a public interest law firm as an outgrowth of an illegal political campaign contribution in 1972. officers had not yet seen the lawsuit and had no immediate comment.

title: Screen
MARKET IN BONDS QUIET AND STEADY
description: Trading remained quiet and prices mostly steady yesterday in the bond markets, where two $100 million offerings, one corporate and one taxexempt, were marketed with what appeared to be good initial responses. The Government market, between two special Treasury offerings, closed on a steady note, with prices little changed. Earlier in the day, Government issues had shown some gains, which at one point added up to 10/32ds in the new 7s, due 1981, for example.

title: Whalers Win in W.H.A.
description: BOSTON, March 27 (AP)Al Karlander and Mike Byers each scored two goals and John French had five assists as the New England Whalers won, 71, from the Los Angeles Sharks in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: STUDY ON MEADOWS CITES GARBAGEFUEL
description: LYNDHURST, March 27 (AP) Most of the garbage dumped daily in New Jersey's Hackensack Meadowlands could be converted into fuel, according to a new proposal released by a state agency today.

title: Music
description: Zitta Finkelstein is one of those beautifully schooled pianists who play spectacularly well but seem more obsessed by the instrument than by the music available to it. The Rumanianborn musician's recital at the Grace Rainey. Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday night left little doubt as to her keyboard agility, particularly when she attacked and largely subdued Mussorgsky's infamously difficult Pictures at Exhibition.

title: KISSINGER ENDS 3 DAYS OF TALKS WITH BREDINEV
description: MOSCOW, March 27Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary State Kissinger completed three days of talks tonight with both sides pointing toward achieving concrete agreements during President Nixon's expected visit here in June.

title: 50 Girls Join 175 Boys at Tryout for Little League
description: Young feminism, dressed mainly in sweatshirts and blue jeans, was out in force in Hoboken yesterday as more than 50 girls registered to play Little League baseball.

title: SCHOOL AID BILL PASSED BY ROUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The House pass Al today multibilliondollar bill that would establish the framework for Federal aid to grade schools and high schools over the next four years.

title: CrisisRidden Italians Feel They Merit Better
description: ROME, March 27Beset by grave economic troubles, ballooning inflation, proliferating scandals and recurrent labor unrest, Italians are worried about the stability of their governmental system.

title: EDMUND W. REEVE
description: Edmund W. Reeve, who retired in 1962 as assistant manager of the Chimney Division of M. W. Kellogg Company, engineering and construction concern, died Tuesday in The Pine Acres Nursing Home; Madison, N. J. His age was 80.

title: NIXON AIDE HINTS SOME OF 42 TAPES MAY NOT EXIST
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 A White House official left open today the possibility that some of the 42 tape recordings sought by the House Judiciary Committee might not exist.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joanne D. Chesimard, a 26yearold alleged Black Liberation Army figure who is awaiting trial in New BrunsWick on charges of killing a New Jersey state trooper last May underwent a regular monthly medical examination yesterday in Middlesex County Jail in New Brunswick. Dr. William Ainslee, a local specialist acting for the state, and Dr. Ernest Garrett of Newark, chosen by Mrs. Chesimard, were reported to have found the condition of Mrs. Chesimard, who is pregnant, normal and satisfactory. The woman was originally a codefendant in the murder trial with Clark E. Squire, 36, but her case was severed from the proceedings when her pregnancy was discovered earlier this year. Mr. Squire was found guilty of the trooper's murder and was sentenced to life in prison earlier this month. Mrs. Chesimard is scheduled to be tried when her Condition permits.

title: Louisiana Pacific And Sierra Begin Acquisition Talks
description: Merger talks have begun between two companies in the forest products field, Sierra Pacific Industries and the Louisiana Pacific Corporation, the companies disclosed yesterday.

title: Aid in Arrests Praised
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 President Nixon today, personally congratulated a television news cameraman, William Roy Anderson, who rammed a car that was fleeing after bank robbery in Memphis on March 18. In the ceremony at the White House Attorney General William Saxbe and Clarence Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, joined in saluting Mr. Anderson, whose action led to the arrest of the suspected robbers.

title: Cook Says Chat With Stans Led to Shift in Vesco Suit; ExS.E.C. Aide Testifies Paragraph Was Changed in Attempt to Conceal $200,000 Gift to Nixon Drive
description: A former official of the Securities and Exchange Commission testified yesterday that during a lull in a goose hunt he was crouched in a Texas rice field with Maurice H. Stans and that the two men then had their first conversation about the commission's investigation of Robert L. Vesco.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LATE HARVEY GROSBECK. By Gilbert Millstein. 285 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: Approval of 3 New Law Schools Urged
description: The State Education Department has recommended approval of new law schools proposed by City University, Yeshiva University and the University of Rochester.

title: ENERGY BILL TALKS DISPUTE; HALT IN
description: WASHINGTON March 27 Negotiations between the Administration and Democratic Congressional leaders for a new emergency energy bill broke down tonight, raising questions about the ability of the Administration and Congress to collaborate successfully on a wider range of energy meaures.

title: Essex Jail Guard Tells of Pressure For Political Gifts
description: NEWARK, March 27 guard at the Essex County Jail here said today that he and other guards were constantly pressured to make political contributions while on the job.

title: Public Financing Of Elections Wins Key Test in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A proposal to finance Presidential and Congressional election campaigns with public tax funds won on a key test vote in the Senate today.

title: Doubled Aramco Profit Disclosed
Drills Sind in Park as Museum Flexes Wings
description: Victorious in the battle against foes of its expansion plans, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is moving full speed ahead with its $50million to $60million building program, initiated during the museum's centennial celebration in 1970 and then delayed by 18 months of litigation.

title: 1400 Here Attend Heated Debate On Jewish Seminary Expansion
description: Jewish Theological Seminary's proposal to build a multipurpose facility on the site of two apartment buildings on 120th and 121st Streets between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue was debated heatedly last night at an open meeting of Community Board 9 More than 400 Morningside Heights residents attended,

title: Homosexual Church Backed
description: PROVIDENCE, R. 1., March 127 (AP)  The Metropolitan (Community Church of Greater Providence, organized to minister to homosexuals, received affiliated status with the Rhode rsland State Council of Churches yesterday.

title: BAKER SAYS REPORT ON IS FINISHED
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. told newsmen today that he had completed an investigation into the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement with the Watergate scandal and forwarded it to the Senate Armed Services and Appropriations Committees for study.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: For Elephant Fanciers of All Agesthe Circus Opens Tonight
description: For about 50 years now, Ray Moreauwho prefers to be called Sabuhas spent his vacations with elephants, and this spring is no exception. Yesterday, attired in black and looking like a trim if aging tap dancer, he strolled along West 33d Street with 18 elephants, headed for Madison Square Garden.

title: Byrne Supports Girls in Little League
description: TRENTON, March 27Governor Byrne, who has more daughters than sons, said today that he believed qualified girls should be allowed to play Little League baseball or any other sport they can play.

title: RISE IN FOOD COST IN APRIL FORESEEN
description: Food prices will begin to rise again next month, according to the barometer of the city government's advance wholesale buying for hospitals, prisons and other institutions.

title: NIXON IS ASSAILED ON GROUND RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Senator Harold E. Hughes declared today that the Senate Armed Services Committee had developed evidence strongly suggesting that President Nixon violated the law by permitting secret ground operations inside Laos and Cambodia.

title: Film: Conrack, Story of a Teacher
FRANK SMITH DIES; INVESTMENT AIDE
description: Frank Boatner Smith, board chairman of the Acron Corporation, manufacturer of security systems in Lakewood, N. J. Seaside Park, N. J., He was 48 years old. An autopsy is planned to determine the cause of death.

title: Artist Here Charged In Kidnapping Threats
description: A Staten Island man described as an unemployed artist was released on $500 bail yesterday after his arrest by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a charge of mailing kidnapping threats to officials of various museums in the greater New York area.

title: Chris Evert Wins After Shaky Start
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M.

title: Court TightensLimit On School Spending
description: ALBANY, March 27The State Court of Appeals today declared unconstitutional the first of a series of recent state laws that allow three large cities and 65 school districts in small cities to pay for the Cost of schoolemploye pensions with funds raised outside their legal taxing limits.

title: BRIBERY ADMITTED IN DEAL IN ILLINOIS
description: CHICAGO, March 27 (AP)A former president of an Arkansas auto license stamping company has pleaded guilty to paying an $80,000 bribe to Paul Powell, the late Illinois Secretary of State, J. Patrick Stolz, 50 years old, of Conway, Ark., was placed on three years probation yesterday by the United States District Court, fined $30,000 and ordered to pay the Illinois treasury $80,000 in restitution.

title: Byrne Declares  Qualified Girls Should Play Little League Ball
description: TRENTON, March 27Governor Byrne, who has more laughters than sons, said tolay that he believed qualified ;iris should be allowed to play Littie League baseball or any )they sport they can play.

title: Personal Finance
description: Lawyers convene in Yugoslavia. Doctors gather in Atlantic City. Insurers meet in Las Vegas.

title: Nadjari to Insist That Brownstein Waive Immunity
description: The state's special prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, will insist on an unconditional waiver of immunity from State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein of Brooklyn and will press for his removal the justice refuses, sources close to the case said yesterday.

title: Federal Jury Begins Its Deliberations In Campaign Fraud Case Against Gross
description: NEWARK, March 28The campaign fraud case against Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, went to the jury this evening after a trial that lasted nearly five weeks and included the testimony of 28 witnesses.

title: Schlesinger Says Nixon Can't Be Coerced on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that if the Soviet Union believed that itcould take advantage of President Nixon's difficulties over Watergate to obtain concessions on a strategic arms agreement it would soon be disabused of this notion.

title: CRABIEL TESTIFIED TO EVADING LAW
description: TRENTON, March 28  Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, the reputed target of a state grand jury investigation of alleged highway construction fraud in New Jersey, once testified that he helped a prime contractor on a $5.4million interstate highway construction job to circumvent a state law.

title: 3 SIGN UP FOR SPACE IN PLANNED CENTER
description: Wrangling over the planned New York City Convention and Exposition Center continued yesterday as Mayor Beame received letters of intent from three national trade shows that had agreed to take space in the 560,000squarefoot facility on the Hudson River.

title: The Real Honors
description: President Nixon has proclaimed today as Vietnam Veterans Day because a year ago the last American combat soldier departed from that country of casualties. The most appropriate ceremonies. to mark the occasion would be action in Washington to give these veterans improved rights. Educational benefits and job opportunities are the real honors the men who served seek and deserve.

title: SAMUEL ROSKIN
description: Samuel Roskin, founder and board chairman of Roskin Distributors, Inc., in East Hartford, Conn., which represents some 300 manufacturers of varied merchandise, died of cancer Tuesday in Miami Beach, where he had been on vacation. He was 83 years old and lived at 30 Norwood Road in West Hartford.

title: Attorney General's First Watergate Intervention Is Scored by Ervin
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Attorney General William B. Saxbe has asked the United States Court of Appeals here to sustain President Nixon's refusal to turn over five White House tape recordings to the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Choice for Navy Operations Chief James Lemuel Holloway 3d
description: Adm. James L. Holloway 3d, named yesterday by President Nixon to succeed Adm, Elmo R. Zumwalt as Chief of Naval Operations, is an officer who, his associates say, 18 unlikely to originate reforms as his predecessor did but who will solidify the liberalizing changes, already accomplished. The 52yearold admiral now serves as Vice Chief of Naval Operations, a position he assumed last May as Admiral Zumwalt's choice. The two have worked closely as a team Although Admiral Holloway is not known to stand on protocol and is sehooled in the concepts of a modern Navy, he is generally thought to be more traditional than his predecssor.

title: The Police Director of Newark Is Temporarily Lieutenant Again
description: NEWARK, March 28  The city's Police Director, Edward L. Kerr, today is accepting a substantial pay cut for the next three months as he returns to the rank of lieutenant, to take the State Civil Service examination for promotion to police taPtain on the city's force.

title: Early Files Depict a Grim but Familiar City
description: Newly discovered records of the city coroner going back to 1784 draw a grim picture of deadly violence and drug abuse familiar to New Yorkers nearly two centuries later.

title: 2 Prototypes of Bus of Future Delivered to Desert Test Area
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28They rolled out the socalled bus of the future todaythe first new bus design in this country in more than 15 years, the result of a threeyear, $26million Federal effort to create a new kind of bus that can lure motorists from their, cars.

title: COOK SAYS HANS TOLD HIM HE LIED TOME INJURY
description: George Bradford Cook testified yesterday that Maurice H. Stans informed him at a meeting in the White House mess hall that he had lied to the grand jury investigating the MitchellStans case.

title: Crushed Rock Kills Three
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 28 (AP)Three men died yesterday when they were buried beneath tons of crushed rock (Gypsum a storage tank at the Kaiser Gypsum Company quarry here. The victims were identified as Francis Frazier, 34 years old; Alfred Bullard, 26, and Steven Clemmons, 24, all of Jacksonville.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COUNTRY STYLE Tranquillity is not. Manhattan's watchword, but there are a few, very few, cases of it One is a patch of park surrounding a beautiful old country home on Manhattan's highest piece of land The house is the MorrisJumel Mansion, a Georgianstyle relic built in 1765 at Edgecombe Avenue and West 160th Street, a block or so east of Amsterdam Avenue (WA 38008) It was put up by the Morris family before the Revolution as a rural retreat far from the rigors of New York City where the family lived on Stone Street In 1810, the Jumel family bought and refurbished it.

title: Lawyer Says Rothko Executors Acted Against the Artist's Heirs
description: Executors of the Mark Rothko estate acted against the welfare of the late artist's children when they negotiated a contract to sell and consign 800 Rothko paintings to Marlborough Gallery, it was charged in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

title: Doesn't stand on Protocol
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, a businessman and former treasurer of the Democratic state committee said yesterday that he had been endorsed by Matthew J. Troy Jr. the Queens Democratic chairman, for the United States Senate nomination.

title: BRITON IN COURT IN ROYAL AMBUSH
description: LONDON, March 28 Ian Ball, the man charged in last week's kidnapping attempt on Princess Anne, was described by his lawyer today as mentally

title: First Anniversary Of Exit From War To Be Noted Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 28A nationwide Observance of Vietnam Veterans Day will be held tomorrow, with the principal activities scheduled here.

title: One's a MediumSized Madhouse, the Other Even Madder
Brownstein to Waive Immunity; Vows Cooperation With Nadjari
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein said yesterday that he had decided to sign a waiver of immunity in the investigation being conducted by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjarri.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $933million up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $860million. Total retail store sales were about $9.697billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $9.092billion.

title: Key Aide at City College Is Returning to Teaching
description: A vice provost of City College has resigned to return to teaching, and he warned that those charged with finding his successor should withstand pressures brought by ethnic or political groups.

title: Austria May Call Parliament To Name Acting Presidents
description: VIENNA, March 28 (Reuters) The Austrian Government said tonight that a special ses; sion of Parliament might be summoned to elect a presidential troika to act for President Franz Jonas, who is gravely

title: High Vatican Aide Arrives in Havana For Negotiations
description: HAVANA, March 28 (Reuters) Msgr. Agostino Casaroli, special envoy of Pope Paul, has arrived here for talks with Cuban church and government officials.

title: McDowell Is Disbelieving Candidate For Yankees'
Chase Delays Opening British Money Shops
description: LONDON, March 28 (AP)Chase Manhattan bank has decided to delay plans to open money shops in Britain specializing in consumer finance, a bank spokesman said here today.

title: City College Unveils Arts Center Plan
description: City College announced yesterday that construction of its new $5.3million Aaron Davis Hall, which will house the school's Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts, will begin this winter and will be completed by the fall of 1976.

title: Nicklaus And Barber Share Lead
Art: Medici Twilight Shines in Detroit
description: DETROIT. March 28 In the museum world, it is commonplace to speak of rarities, but it is a little less common to come up with them, especially on a grand scale. But this, happily, is what the Detroit Institute of Arts has done with resplendent success in the exhibition called The Twilight of the Medici: Late Baroque Art in Florence, 16701743, which opened in Detroit this week.

title: Guilty in Police Killing
description: A jury in the Bronx convicted Robert Hayes, reputed to be a member of the Black Liberation Army, of the murder of a transit policeman last June. Page 27.

title: Senate Panel Is Urged to Speed Securities Action
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The chairmen of the New York and American Stock Exchanges urged the Senate Securities subcommittee today to speed legislation confining transactions in listed securities to the national stock exchanges.

title: Record Bid for Oil Leases in Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 28 (AP)Oilmen offered a record of $2.16billion today for the right to drill oil and gas wells, farther out in the Gulf of Mexico than ever before, but many of the deepwater tracts were passed over.

title: Ceausescu Is President
description: BUCHAREST, March 28 (AP)  The Rumanian National Assembly elected Nicolae Ceauthe Communist party leader, to the post of President today, giving him absolute power. In his acceptance speech, Mr. Ceausescu said that he would do all he could to keep Stalinist illegalities out of Rumanian socialism.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17 billion tonmiles, 7.3 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 533,810 cars, 4.3 per cent above last year.

title: Medicare Fraud Admitted
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 28 (AP)Dr. William Kozin of Springfield pleaded guilty in United States District Court yesterday to 10 counts of Medicare fraud. Sentencing was sett for April 23.

title: The VietnamVeteran Blues
description: On March 29, 1973a year ago todaythe last American prisoner of war returned from North Vietnam. Recently, President Nixon proclaimed today Vietnam Veterans Day, marking the first anniversary of that homecoming.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company shut off service to the National Socialist White Peoples party, which had been offering recorded hate messages against Jews and blacks.

title: Notes on People
description: Marion H. Smoak will soon step down as Chief of Protocol of the State Department and be succeeded by Henry E. Catto Jr., a wealthy Texas Republican who is the soninlaw of Oveta Culp Hobby, publisher of The Houston Post and former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Newcombe Advances In Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, March 28 (AP) Topseeded John Newcombe continued his domination in the World Championship Tennis tour's Blue Group by defeating Charlie Pasarell, 16, 76, 64, tonight to move into the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Peachtree Corners Classic.

title: Coast Paper Raises Price
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 28 (AP)The Sacramento Bee will increase its street price from 10 cents to 15 cents daily and from 35 cents to 50 cents on Sunday, effective April 1, because of rising costs. Home delivery and mail subscription prices would also be increased, the paper said in announcement today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Consumer food prices in the New York metropolitan area rose by 3.4 per cent in February, a United States Labor Department official said.

title: Saudi Oil Revenues Fueling Expansion
description: RIYADH, Saudia Arabia, March 28The anteroom of Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYamani's offices at the cool, modern Ministry of Petroleum here is filled these days with Western.European and Japanese oil representatives trying to line up contracts or just to get a clear idea of how Saudi Arabia plans to market her oil in the future.

title: A Time For Waiting
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Henry Kissinger is returning from Moscow without the agreement he sought on the control of strategic arms, hut at least he avoided an open break.vith the Soviet leaders and preserved the possibility of a Nixon visit to the Kremlin this summer.

title: UPJOHN CO. CLARIFIES ANTIBIOTICS STATUS
description: The Upjohn Company issued yesterday at its headquarters at Kalamazoo, Mich., a state ment seeking to put down a revived interest in the financial community in two major antibiotics.

title: Westchester Assemblyman Quits Congressional Race
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 28  Assemblyman J. Edward Meyer, a Republican turned Democrat, withdrew today from the race for the Congressional seat being vacated by Ogden R. Reid, who is seeking the gubernatorial nomination.

title: People in Sports
description: The National Football League stole the new World Football League's biggest plum yesterday when David Jaynes, the allAmerica quarterback from the University of Kansas, signed with the Kansas City Chiefs. Jaynes had been the W.F.L.'s top draft choice.

title: $14MILLION READY FOR 74 ELECTIONS
LOTTERY NUMBERS March 28, 1974
description: New York205129

title: BRINCO WILL SELL POWER PROJECT
description: OTTAWA, March 28  After protracted and complex negotiations in Canada and London, the foreign operators of a huge hydroelectric power project in Labrador have agreed to sell the enterprise to the government of Newfoundland for $160million.

title: Senate Bars Moves Weakening Public Financing of Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Senate turned back today renewed attempts to scale down the proposed use of public tax funds to finance Presidential and Congressional election campaigns.

title: United Gas in Name Change
description: Stockholders of United Gas, Inc., voted yesterday at a spe. clal meeting at Houston to change the company's name to Entex, Inc. The company said it hoped to complete the name change by May 1.

title: OIL ROLE IN IRAN TRACED TO DULLES
description: WASHINGTON, March 28A Senate subcommittee was told by an oil executive today that five major United States oil companies began joint production in Iran in 1954 as part of an international consortium solely because Washington thought such a step was necessary to prevent Iran from falling under Soviet influence.

title: Idaho Five Gets Coach
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, March 28 (AP)Jim Jarvis, former head coach at Spokane Falls Community College, has been hired as the University of Idaho's head basketball coach.

title: I.R.S. SEEKS DATA ON CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: CHICAGO, March 28 (Reuters)United States tax authorities have subpoenaed records of 30 banks in Chicago and five in New York into which W. Clement Stone, one of the wealthiest men in the United States funneled more than $5million in campaign gifts, The Chicago Tribune said tonight.

title: Transit Employe Is Killed By IRT Train in Bronx
description: A 52yearold Transit Authority foreman was killed last night when he was struck by a northbound IRT train in a tunnel south of the 149th StreetGrand Concourse station in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Aluminum Prices Are Raised
description: Only hours after the Cost of Living Council freed the aluminum industry from wage and price controls yesterday, major producers of the important metal advanced their prices to 31.5 cents a pound, from 29 cents. This was the maximum level approved by the council in return for a commitment by major producers to limit their increases over the next six months.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Colonialism, subcommittee on Pacific Ocean Territories  10:30 A.M.

title: Schools Are Tinderboxes as Korean Dissent Mounts
description: SEOUL, South KoreaStudents starting the new semester at South Korea's leading universities are in a militant mood of resentment against President Park Chung Hee.

title: DOLLAR SLIPS AGAIN AS GOLD HOLDS FIRM
description: BRUSSELS, March 28 (UPI)  The dollar sagged further on European money markets today as gold prices held steady.

title: Stock Market Slumps
description: Concern of investors over higher interest rates sent the stock market yesterday into its biggest decline in almost two months. The DowJones industrial average slumped 16.82 points. After the market closed, the Bankers Trust Company announced it was raising its prime lending rate by half a point to 91 per cent. Details on Page 47.

title: A Crabiel Deposition Told of Evading Law
description: TRENTON, March 28  Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, the reputed target of a state grand jury investigation of alleged highway construction fraud in New Jersey, once I testified that he helped a prime contractor on a $5.4million interstate highway construction jab to, circumvent a state law.

title: Specter of Watergate at U.S.Soviet Talks
description: MOSCOW, March 28  For the first time in two years, the Watergate affair has had some discernible impact on important SovietAmerican negotiations. During Secretary of State Kissinger's talks here with Leonid I. Brezhnev, each side went out of its way to assure the other that, despite Mr. Nixon's Watergate troubles, it was still committed to impioving relations, regardless of personalities.

title: Wedding Held Here For Miss Seymour
description: Miss Mary Seymour, daughter of Mrs. James Christine of Loretto, Pa., and the late Raymond J. Seymour, was married here yesterday to James H. Manges, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Co., investment bankers. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace S. Manges of New York.

title: Rate Up to 9% Demand Rise for Loans Cited
PAUL CORNELL DIES; AD AGENCY FOUNDER
description: Paul Lincoln Cornell, a forTier advertising executive who in 193637 was chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, died yesterday at his home, Aglin Farms, Washington, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: EDWARD J. CHURCHILL
description: Edward J. Churchill, who retired in the early nineteensixties as chairman and chief executive officer of Donahue & Coe, Inc., a former advertising agency here, died Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz., at the age of 81.

title: KISSINGER FAILS TO SWAY MOSCOW ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington tonight after failing in. three days of talks in Moscow to achieve the conceptual breakthrough he had hoped would lead soon to a new SovietAmerican agreement on strategic arms limitations.

title: 5Acre Bronx Site Bought For New Calvary Hospital
description: Cardinal Cooke said yesterday that Calvary Hospital in the Bronx would expand its facilities to double the number of poor, terminally ill cancer patients it can service.

title: INFANT SURVIVING AFTER ABDUCTION
description: HACKETTSTOWN, March 28 An 8monthold baby girl was doing well at Hackettstown Community Hospital today, after being abducted from her crib last night, tied up in a green trash bag and left behind a church, half a block from her home on Main Street.

title: Leaders In East To Battle Squires In A.B.A. Game
A Marschallin in Depth
description: It has been five seasons since Christa Ludwig first took on the role of the Marschallin in Der Rosenkavalier at the Metropolitan Opera, and in that time her conception of the character has matured considerably. In her excellent Columbia recording issued three years ago, one still heard suggestions of the easy, bittersweet sentimentality that is all some Marschallins find in the part.

title: Mrs. King, Miss Wade Net Victors
Allied Chemical Elects President
description: David H. Bradford Jr. has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Allied Chemical Corporation. He succeeds Frederick L. Bissinger, who was appointed to the new post of vice chairman.

title: Communist Losses In Attack on Camp Put at 84 by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28 (AP)More than 500 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers attacked a South Vietnamese camp 35 miles northwest of Saigon and held parts of it for more than 24 hours before the 300man  garrison drove them off this morning, the South Vietnamese command reported.

title: Tax Hassle Delays Flight by Foreman
description: Venezuela finally found somebody yesterday who could stop George Foreman: its tax collectors.

title: Convicted Sailor Missing
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., March 28 (AP)A sailor convicted of setting a fire that caused $7.5million damage, to the aircraft carrier Forrestal was still missing today. from the Portsmouth I Navy prison, Navy officials said. Seaman Apprentice Jeffrey C. Allison and two other prisoners disappeared Monday night, the officials said.

title: Wife of Abducted Consul Awaits Word
description: MEXICO CITY, March 28United States officials said today that the wife of a missing United States vice consul had made every possible effort to follow the instructions contained in a ransom note but that she had received no further word from her husband or his captors.

title: Democrats to Rebut Nixon
description: The Democratic party's response to President Nixon's radio speech on education last Saturday will be carried tomorrow by the three major radio networks. The American Broadcasting Company and The National Broadcasting Company said the Democratic spokesman on their networks would be Representative John Brademas of Indiana, whose speech will be on at 12:07 P.M. on A.B.C. and 3:05 P.M. on N.B.C. The Columbia Broadcasting System said that Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island would be the speaker on its network, at 12:07 P.M

title: Oil Reserve Drop Seen; Study Excludes 73 Gains
REPUTED MOBSTER FOUND DEAD IN CAR
description: A reputed organizedcrime figure once charged with the murder of a restaurant owner who was a key witness in an investigation into an alleged extortion operation in Queens was found slain in the trunk of a car yesterday.

title: 2 Who Streaked at Vatican Are Given Time to Reflect
description: ROME, March 28  Three! Americans, all in their early 20's, were tried here today for streaking in St. Peter's Square.

title: A DISSIDENT TRIES TO MEET KISSINGER
description: MOSCOW, March 28Valery Panov, the 34yearold Kirov Ballet dancer, attempted to contact Secretary of State Kissinger here this week but his ap proach was reportedly rejected by Mr. Kissinger's aides.

title: Specter of Watergate at U.S.Soviet Talks
description: MOSCOW, March 28 For the first time in two years, the Watergate affair has had some discernible impact on important SovietAmerican negotiations.

title: Rockets Win And Tie for Playoff Spot
REVERSAL SOUGHT OF LEAD DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz, in an action apparently without precedent asked the Tariff Commission today to reopen, reconsider and reverse its decision of last January that would lead higher import duties on lead metal from Canada and Australia under the antidumping law.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF 10TH TIME IN ROW
Sports News Briefs
description: LIVERPOOL, England, March 28 (UPI)Raymond Guest, former United States Ambassador to Ireland, win be hoping the third time will be lucky Saturday when his L'Escargot runs in the $93,240 Grand National Steeplechase over the testing Aintree course. L'Escargot, trained by David Moore in Ireland and ridden by Tommy Carberry of Ireland, is the only transAtlantic challenger for the $60,240 first prize.

title: ALBANY APPROVES RAILTRANSIT BILL
ELTON M'NEIL
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 28 (AP)Elton McNeil, a child psychologist, died yesterday in St. Joseph Mercy Hospital after a heart attack. He was 50 years old.

title: Naber Wins FreeStyle As Kinsella Places Last
White House Says Court Was Told 10 of Nixon's Talks Aren't on Tape
description: WASHINGTON, March 28A White House spokesman said today that it was a matter of court record that at least 10 of the 42 Presidential conversations reportedly sought by the House Judiciary Committee had never been recorded. However, he would not say whether others also were not on tape.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)Prices of natural gas and electricity will triple over the next few years unless inflation is brought under control, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission predicted today.

title: Schlesinger Says Nixon Can't Be Coerced on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger. said today that if the Soviet Union believed that it could take advantage of Presdent Nixon's difficulties over Watergate to obtain concessions on a strategic arms agreement it would soon be disabused of this notion.

title: Dr. Clark Links White Exodus To a Lag in School Integration
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and educator, said yesterday that the exodus of white families from New York City over the last two decades had resulted from too little"rather than too much school desegregation in the city.

title: WARREN W. HOWARD, N.A.A.C.P. AIDE, 49
description: Warren W. Howard, special assistant for program to the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital, after having suffered a cerebral hemorrhage at his desk Wednesday. He was 49 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Energy Shortage Both Favoring and Hampering Improvements in Nation's Environment
description: Six months of energy short age have paradoxically boa dented and strengthened slowed down and speeded up the nation's drive for environmental quality.

title: About New York Life's Little Twists
description: On a recent Thursday night, Dr. Harold Dundy left his office on Eastern Park way in Brooklyn got into a cab, and was driven off to Brooklyn College, where he joined his wife at a party.

title: Col. Eric Barron Dies at 76; A Port Authority Engineer
description: Col. Eric S. Barron, Engineers Corps Reserve, retired, and former senior resident engineer of the Port of New York Authority at its Hoboken piers, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 76 years old and had lived in Malverne, L. I.

title: U.S.Soviet Communique on BrezhnevKissinger Talk
description: MOSCOW, March 28 (AP) Following is the text of the joint United StatesSoviet communique on the visit of Secretary of State Kissinger:

title: One Man,  Vote
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Many of the defects of democracy arise from the principle of one, man, one yote. If all men were in fact not only created equal but also remained equalin ability, intelligence, judgment and wisdomthen granting each man an equal voice in government would be the soundest basis of achieving justice for all.

title: U.S.Soviet Arms Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Reports from Moscow suggest that Secretary of State Kissinger and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, were not able to agree on a formula move ahead on the limitation of strategic arms, but the precise nature of the problem remains uncertain at this stage. What is known is the nature of the differences that persisted up to the time of Mr. Kissinger's Moscow trip.

title: LIBBY WANTS TO CUT FROZEN FOODS LINE
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby, a leading packer of canned and frozen foods which is 56 per centowned by Nestle Alimentano, S. A., said yesterday that it was seeking ways to reduce the size of its frozen food operations. The company said it had entered into negotiations with several companies interested in the frozen food products marketed by the Chicagobased company. Among them are the Winter Garden Freezer Company, Inc., of Belles, Tenn., and Citrus Central, Inc., of Orlando, Fla., both of which have had business relationships with Libby over many years.

title: Cambodian Rebels Seize Pagoda Area After Intense Siege
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 28 (AP)  Insurgents occupied a besieged temple compound north of here today after Government forces and refugees evacuated it in confusion and panic, military and diplomatic sources said.

title: City Transit Talks Pivot On Critical Issue: Money
description: The threeman panel of mediators in the city transit dispute reported to Mayor Beame yesterday that the bargaining was progressing but that difficult economic issues remained to be resolved.

title: Teachers Turn a New Leaf and Use Fewer Texts
description: When Susan Kroll begat teaching five years ago, shi did what she thought ever good teacher was supposec to do. She gave each of hei students a pile of textbooks one for each subject. Now however, she seldom gives her sixthgraders textbooks for any subject.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 41yearold man who was charged with murder but was released without bail last December in a controversial decision by Judge Bruce McM. Wright in the City Criminal Court, has been acquitted of a reduced charge of simple assault in the case.

title: MOSCOW REJECTS PEKING'S CHARGES
description: MOSCOW, March 28The Soviet Union today rejected Chinese charges that a Soviet Army helicopter had recently been sent over Chinese territory on an espionage mission and demanded that Peking return the craft and its threeman crew at once.

title: Wood, Field &
description: Last Wednesday, at Central Park's rowing lake off 72d Street, an organization that seeks to gather the anglers of the nation into a unified political force was launched.

title: Pressure on the Fare
description: No element in the skyrocketing cost of living has more direct impact on the economic viability of New York City than the size of the subway and bus fare. The passage by the State Legislature yesterday of Governor Wilson's transportation packagewith no restructuring to expand the $70 million in promised state operating subsidymakes plainer than ever the fateful nature the negotiations to be concluded this weekend for a new transit wage agreement.

title: Drop in Index Is the Biggest in 2 Months
SECURITY PERIL SEEN IN INFORMATION CURB
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)The Pentagon asked Congress today not to restrict its right to check the backgrounds of prospective employes.

title: CONGRESS RAISES MINIMUM WAGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Congress cleared today and sent to President Nixon legislation that would increase the Federal mininium wage for most workers, by 25 per cent to $2 ar hour this spring.

title: When the Businessmen Sing, Money Isn't on Their Minds
description: Every Monday, Robert Bushnell Jr., a 36yearold Wall Street stockbroker, changes from his Brooks Brothers, pinstripes into a natty blue blazer and Tartan plaid slacks and heads uptown to sing for his supper.

title: ...Mideast Barometer
description: The pace of Middle East diplomacy in the coming weeks may provide a clearer signal of the prospects for superpower dtente than did the unilluminating communiqu in Moscow. If Mr. Kissinger was unable to gain Soviet supportor at least absence of oppositionfor his ongoing mediation effort between Israel and Syria, the whole American peacemaking initiative could be in for sharp and sudden setback.

title: Ruling Lets Graham Rent Arizona State U. Stadium
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28The Arizona Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the evangelist Billy Graham may rent a state university stadium.

title: Big Board Seat Sold
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $85,000, down $5,000 from the previous sale on March 6. The current market price is $75,000 bid and $95,000 ask.

title: Crushed Rock Kills Three
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 28 (AP)Three men died yesterday when they were buried beneath tons of crushed rock in a storage tank at the Kaiser Gypsum Company quarry here. The victims were identified as Francis Frazier, 34 years old; Alfred Bullard, 26, and Steven Clemmons, 24, all of Jacksonville.

title: Major Realignment Urged In Bronx Hospital Service
description: A report by the staff of the city's Health and Hospital Corporation proposed yesterday a major realignment of hospital services in the Bronx to cope with the growing problem of unused hospital beds there.

title: Paper Shifts Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) The Washington StarNews will start publishing its Saturday edition as a morning newspaper instead of an evening paper beginning May 18, John H. Kauffman, StarNews president, announced today.

title: ALBANY APPROVES RAILTRANSIT BILL
description: ALBANY, March 28  Both houses of the Legislature today passed a threepronged measure to help preserve the state's rail and masstransportation systems. It provides for authorizing a referendum on a $250million bond issue for longrange rail road revitalization and also provides for a $100million state subsidy for masstransit opera tions to hold down fares and $30million for immediate help to rescue rail lines.

title: I.C.C. Ends Inquiry on Moore Charges
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday refused to hold an open hearing oh allegations of misconduct committed by William H. Moore, former president of the Penn Central and three other unidentified former officials of the road.

title: E.P.A. to Seek a Voluntary Ban On Use of Gas Linked to Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would ask pesticide makers voluntarily to stop using an aerosol propellant gas vinyl chloride, that has been linked to a rare form of liver cancer.

title: Brownstein Decides To Waive Immunity
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein said yesterday that he had decided to sign a waiver of immunity in the investigation being conducted by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Secretary of the Treasury George Shultz, on announcing his intention of leaving the Administration, made a number of statements which, even discounting for the normally selfserving tendencies of such ceremonies, should not be allowed to stand.

title: U.S. Record Falls In N.C.A.A. Swim
Reputed Black Army Member Guilty in Police Murder
description: Robert Hayes, reputed to be a member of the Black Liberation Army, was found guilty yesterday of murder and robbery in the shooting of a transit patrolman last June.

title: TV Networks Seek to Avoid Streaking Incidents
description: Without formal advice from top management, directors of live television programs and special events for the networks have put themselves on an alert for streakers, fearing that television might present a new frontier for nude runners determined to reach a larger audience.

title: KISSINGER FAILS TO SWAY MOSCOW ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington tonight after failing in three days of talks in Moscow to achieve the conceptual breakthrough he had hoped would lead soon to a new SovietAmerican agreement on strategic arms limi. tations.

title: Whalers Win Division
description: BOSTON, March 28 (AP) The New England Whalers won their second straight East Division championship with a 32 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: Stock Market Slumps
description: Concern of investors over higher interest rates sent the stock market yesterday into its biggest decline in almost two month's. The DowJones industrial average slumped 16.82 points. After the market closed, the Bankers Trust Company announced it was raising its prime lending rate by half a point to 9 per cent. Details on Page 47.

title: LOUIS ROUSSELOT, SURGEON, 70, DIES
description: Dr. Louis M. Rousselot, a prominent New York surgeon who was former Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health and Environment and special assistant with the National Institutes of Health, died yesterday of an aneurysm while vacationing in Puerto Rico. He was 70 years old and had lived in Englewood, N. J., before moving to Washington.

title: COUNCIL DROPS BID ON ECOLOGICAL DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)The Nixon Administration told Congress today that it would not ask for legislation waiving environmental impact statements for energy projects.

title: Saving in Power Reported For Con Edison Customers
description: Reductions in the use of electricity, natural gas and steam saved an equivalent of 210,000 barrels of oil in the week ended last Sunday, according to preliminary figures released by Consolidated Edison yesterday.

title: Share Offer Not Extended By Twentieth CenturyFox
description: The hoard of directors of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation has decided not to extend its offer to purchase up to 2 million shares of its outstanding common stock at $8.50 each. A spokesman for the company said the offer expired at 5 P.M. yesterday.

title: Del Monte Sees Food Price Rise as Profit Gains
U.S. Car Plants Cut Production 37.2%
description: DETROIT, March 28American auto plants will build 588,138 cars in March, down 348,1470, or 37.2 per cent, from the 936,604 cars produced in March, 1973.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation said yesterday it was negotiating contracts for construction of six supertankers on the Gulf Coast. The ships, which would weigh 400,000 tons each, would be the first built in that area. Todd is asking for a price of $130million for each tanker with Exxon International, the Zapata Corporation and the Central Gulf Steamship Company. They would be built at Galveston.

title: COOK SAYS SPANS TOLD HIM HE LIED TO THE GRAND JURY
description: George Bradford Cook testified yesterday that Maurice H. Stans informed him at a meeting in the White House mess hall that he had lied to the grand jury investigating the MitchellStans case.

title: Advertising: Spokane Expo 74
description: Except for the old part, King Cole lives up to his advance billing. He's not only merry soul, but he's also pleasant, smart, hardworking, the father of eight and the best known booster of Spokane, Wash., which he calls the absolute center of Outdoorland, U.S.A.

title: Families Called Victims of Child Cancer
description: ST AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 27An intensive study of 40 families with leukemic children has shown that only one in 10 families emerges from the experience without serious disruption of the family unit, Stanford University social worker reported here today.

title: ZOUHEIR KUZBARI, 50, U.N. AIDE SINCE 1951
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28  Zouheir Kuzbari, an official in the political affairs department of the United Nations, died yesterday at the age of 50.

title: How Much Integration?
description: After having been invited to do so by. Richard Nixon in a radio address, the House of Representatives has voted once again to prohibit the Federal courts from ordering schoolchildren bused to overcome racial segregation. Other measures of this kind have been defeated in the Senate, and even if this one isn't, it is almost certain to be held unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When deaths occur in other sports, even in other auto races, howls of protest usually develop. But when a Grand Prix driver is killed, somehow he's a romantic martyr for the automotive industry. Peter Revson was killed a week ago on the Kyalami track outside Johannesburg, South Africa, when his black Shadow racing car crashed and burned during practice. Yesterday, there was a long line of black limousines on Lexington Avenue outside the Unitarian Church of All Souls after the funeral of America's most successful Grand Prix driver in recent years. At the service were about 500 people, mostly sleek men and elegant women dressed in black. They sat in white wooden pews or stood along pale pink walls and listened to eulogies by George Lysie, roger penske ana Leon Mandel, mice rut his friends. But only a few days before his death, Peter Revson completed what is now his own eulogy. He approved the manuscript for his book, Speed With Style, in collaboration with Leon Mandel, the publisher of Autoweek magazine.

title: Britten Opera Among 6 New Stagings Planned by Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present four new productions next season as well as two.., productions that are scheduled to be introduced during the coming June Festival, the company announced yesterday. The four new stagings are Benjamin Britten's Death in Venice, Janacek's Jenufa, Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov and Rossini's The Siege of Corinth. The June productions are Bartok's Bluebeard's Castle and Puccini's Gianni Schicchi.

title: KLEIDENST TALK WITH LIDDY CITED
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif March 28Former Attorne deneral Richard G. Kleindiens has reportedly told the Federl Bureau of Investigation that has no explanation for havin withheld from Federal prosectors for nearly a year informs tion that would have linke John N. Mitchell's name wit the five men arrested in the Watergate breakin.

title: British Brokerage Firm Fails as Stocks Decline
description: LONDON, March 28  The plunging British stock market claimed its first brokerage house victim today when Mitton, Butler, Priest & Co., mediumsized firm, said it could not meet its obligations.

title: WEICKER DISCLOSES 1971 BREAKIN PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)  Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, made public tonight a memorandum written on White House stationery in 1971 to the then Presidential counsel, John W. Dean 3d, discussing the possibility of a breakin at a Washington research organization.

title: Late Goal Ties Hawks For Sabres
Guilty in Police Killing
description: A jury in the Bronx convicted Robert Hayes, reputed to be a member of the Black Liberation Army, of the murder of a transit policeman last June. Page 27.

title: BYRNE STAFF LOSES FREE COFFEE BREAK
description: TRENTON, March 28 (AP)  Governor Byrne has stopped supplying free coffee to his staff, and most employes of the executive office, rather than. pay a dime a cup as he requested, have been buying their coffee in the State House cafeteria or setting up their own, coffeebrewing operations.

title: DR. DONALD WRIGHT, TAUGHT AT BROOKLYN
description: Dr. Donald Decker Wright, professor of chemistry at Brooklyn College, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived on Midwood Street in Brooklyn.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS March 28, 1974
description: Tickets matching only the last number become eligible for the millionaire semifinal drawing to he held later.

title: Two Officials in China Criticized By Posters in Provincial Capital
description: PEKING, March 28 (Reuters) A political storm In a province capital has generated open attacks on party chiefs and officials for the first time in China's current masscriticism campaign, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Sadat Goes to Yugoslavia For Talks and 3Day Visit
description: PULA, Yugoslavia, March 28 President Anwar elSadat of Egypt arrived here today for a relaxed, threeday visit with President Tito of Yugoslavia.,

title: Subscription Prices At Met Opera Raised
description: Ticket prices will be higher next season for most Metropolitan Opera subscribers. Prices for seats have been raised, with the percentage of increase depending upon location.

title: End Jailings in Strikes, TaylorLaw Panel Urges
description: ALBANY; March 28  An Assembly committee today recommended basic changes in the state's Taylor Law, including an end to jail terms for union leaders involved in illegal strikes and a threeyear experiment in binding arbitration in negotiations with policemen's and firemen's unions.

title: Copper Prices Hit Highs; Penny Bill Is Due Today
description: Although fewer people bother to pick up pennies they find in the street today, the onecent coin has never before been worth more in terms of metal value because of the record prices for copper on world markets.

title: MRS. CHARLES J. VION
description: Mrs. Gertrude Cavanaugh Vion, who retired March 10 as a member of the state's Workmen's Compensation Board after service since 1961, died of leukemia in Roosevelt Hospital yesterday, She was 63 years old, and had recently moved to Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Syria Links Palestinian Issue to an Israeli Truce
description: TUNIS, March 28  Syria served notice today that she would demand Israel's recognition of Palestinian national rights as a condition for truce agreement in the Golan Heights sector of the Middle East front.

title: Revson Is Eulogized as Racer By Friends at Services Here
description: With all the glitter he had spent his life trying to escape, Peter Revson was buried yesterday.

title: The Wrong Questions
description: In abandoning Its questionnaire about the racial attitudes of elementary school pupils and their parents, the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare has sensibly acknowledged the legitimate objections by the city's Board of Education.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EAST ORANGE, March 28The tennis Battle of the sexes is going to be carried a step further at Upsala College in a tournament starting Saturday pairing some of the outstanding men and women players of the Eastern area. Among them are Marilyn Aschner, who ranks No. 1, and Tom King, Upsala's No. 1, who has won 24 straight singles matches.

title: Bridge:
The Liner France, Running at a Loss, Is to End Service
description: PARIS, March 28  The France, biggest in a vanishing fleet of world passenger liners and for the last dozen years the sparkling symbol of this country's graces, is to be taken out of service, probably within the next six weeks.

title: India Ending TakeOver Of Distribution of Wheat
description: NEW DELHI, March 28 The Indian Government, fright ened about a lag in food production and tensions in the nation, decided tonight to scrap its controversial yearold takeover of wheat distribution.

title: Transit Users Prepare for the Worst
description: Remembering the chaos created here by the 12day transit strike of 1966 many large companies  especially bankshave begun making plans for geting their employes to and from work.

title: End Jailings in Strikes, TaylorLaw Panel Urges
description: ALBANY, March 28  An Assembly committee today recommended basic changes in the state's Taylor Law, including an end to jail terms for union leaders involved in illegal strikes and a threeyear experiment in binding arbitration In negotiations with policemen's and firemen's unions.

title: Dorothy Fields, Lyricist, Dies; Wrote 400 Songs in 50 Years
The Liner Fraitce, Ranning at a Loss, Is to End Service
description: PARIS, March 28  The France, biggest in a vanishing fleet of world passenger liners and for the last dozen years the sparkling symbol of this country's graces, is to be taken out of service, probably within the next six weeks.

title: Islanders Lose
Books of The Times
description: Lincoln Steffens was a man of immense personal appeal, we are assured time and again in this new biography by Justin Kaplan, author of the NationalBookAwardwinning study Mr. Clemens and Mark Twain. A,firstborn adored by his mother, Steffens went through life feeling like Freud's proverbial conquering hero, and all who came into contact with himwhether corrupt political bosses like the leaders of New York City's Tammany Hall or aspiring young journalists like Walter Lippmann and John Reedfelt the urge in his presence to worship and confess.
