I tell him what I see and think, wrote Reed while still a student at Harvard, and it comes back beautiful, full of meaning. And women adores Steffens too, if the testimony of his three wives (one of whom he never married and another of whom he married, divorced and then continued living with) is valid evidence.

title: Paper Company Executive And Wife Die Within Week
description: Harold S. Foley, formerly vice chairman of the MacMillan Bloedel & Powell River Company, a major Canadian newsprint manufacturer, died March 21 at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia. Five days later, on Tuesday, his widow, Mrs. Frances Burrowes Foley, died, apparently of a heart attack, on an airplane bound for New York. Mr. Folek was 73 years old and Mrs. Foley was 71.

title: Mansfield Asserts'Votes Are There To Impeach Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The Senate majority leader Mike Mansfield, said today that President Nixon's dilatory tactics had stirred increased resentment among many members of Congress, and that the votes are there in the House of Representatives to impeach him, The Washington Post reported.

title: Loss of French Liner Blow to New York Port
description: The impending withdrawal of the luxury liner France is expected to have an unfavorable impact on the Port of New York.

title: MRS. JOHN T. REMEY, AN EARLY AVIATOR, 81
description: Mrs, John Terry Remey, a pioneer woman aviator, died yesterday at her home, 136 East 79th Street, at the age of 81.

title: CHARGES REDUCED BY PAINE, WEBBER
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's largest Wall Street financial institutions, yesterday became the second major brokerage firm to offer reduced rates to the small investor.

title: Harrelson, Jones Scuffle: It Was Just a NoHitter
76 Meet Filing Deadline For Elections in Newark
description: NEWARK, March 28A total of 76 candidates met the filing deadline today for the May 14 race for Mayor and nine Council seats. Six of those candidates, including Kenneth A. Gibson, the incumbent, and State Senator Anthony Imperiale, seek the post of Mayor.

title: Prices Decline in the Bond Markets
description: Pikes declined in the bond markets yesterday where, despite continuing upward pressure on rates, several new offerings attracted favorable initial receptions.

title: Mariner 10 to Fly Close to Mercury Today
description: PASADENA Calif., March 28 From early scanning of the planet Mercury by the approaching Mariner 10 spacecraft, scientists believe that the closeup images of the planet to be received tomorrow afternoon will be some of the great space spectaculars of the century. Its closest approach tomorrow, within 460 miles, will be at 4:46 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: MICHAEL HALPERIN, LAWYER IN THEATER
description: Michael Halperin, a lawyer with wellknown theatrical personalities among his clients, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South.

title: Some With Skill, Some Without, They All Crowd the Crafts Fair
description: Well before noon yesterday  when the crafts show opened  the lobby was already crowded with people waiting to buy tickets. By 3 P.M., about 2,500 people had streamed into the New York Coliseum and up to the third floor to look, buy and participate, at the second annual Craft Materials and Eduipment Show.

title: Ethiopian Rebels End Occupation of City
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 28 (AP)  Rebel troops today ended a threeday occupation of Asmara, Ethiopia's second largest city, but mounting civil unrest and the threat of clashes between rival military units have virtually paralyzed Emperor Haile Selassie's foundering Government,

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Ga., March 28 (UPI)  Al McQuire, Mar quette basketball coach, said today he thought the rules should be changed so that offensive rebounds would have to be passed out to prevent complete dominance by big men. McGuire, here to address a dinner after taking his team to the National Collegiate final before losing North Carolina State, said it was only a matter of time before somebody gets to 7footers.

title: N.B.A. Champions To Meet Ballets At Garden
Streaking Legalized, Calendar Permitting
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, March 28 (AP)The Mayor of this Ocean County community has proclaimed a time for streaking Feb. 29, except in leap years, and the sixth week of March.

title: ENVIRONMENT BILL CLEARS A HURDLE
description: TRENTON, March 23  A highly controversial measure enable New Jersey Citizens file private sults against polluters of the environment cleared its first new legislative hurdle today.

title: MURDER SUSPECT IS CLEARED IN CASE
description: A 41yearold man who was charged with a murder but released without bail last December in a controversial decision by Judge Bruce McM. Wright of the City Criminal Court has been acquitted of a reduced charge of simple assault in the case.

title: 55 Carters Are Charged With Brooklyn Monopoly
8% Notes of Treasury Are Sold at Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The results on the United States 8 per cent Treasury notes (series H1976) auctioned today were as follows:

title: Soviet Shadows...
description: The news from Moscow is somber. Little or no progress has been achieved by Secretary of State Kissinger's visit on a new strategic arms limitation treaty (SALT), on mutual force reductions in Central Europe, on trade and emigration issues or on the Mideast peace negotiations. Watergate, for the first time, evidently has begun to play an important part in Soviet calculations, as has the intensified questioning on both sides about the value of the Soviet American relationship.

title: Ashe Downs Kodes; Tanner Also Gains
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., March 28 (AP)  Topseeded Arthur Ashe overcame an openingset loss to oust Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 36, 63, 64, today in the Desert Classic tenths tournament.

title: PRISONERS N PLEA FOR MISS HEARST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 Two jailed members of the group that calls itself the Symbionese Liberation Army urged today the safe return of Patricia Hearst, who was kidnapped Feb. 4.

title: U.S. Coolness on Accords Baffling Western Europe
description: BONN, March 28West European diplomats were baffled by the notification this week that the United States was no longer interested in obtaining any new written definition of AmericanEuropean relationships.

title: Italy Charges 24 In Major Smuggling Of Heroin Into U.S.
description: ROME, March 28A coin laundry in a Roman suburb was the cover for the operations center of a Mafia ring that had been smuggling large shipments of heroin to the United States, court officials say.

title: Dutch Labor Party Gains in Elections; Oil Stand Credited
description: THE HAGUE, March 28The Dutch Labor party of Premier Joop den Uyl scored gains in nationwide provincial elections yesterday, and its success was generally credited today to his strong leadership during the oil crisis.

title: A.M.A. IS ASSAILED BY H.E.W. OFFICIAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Sharp disagreement between the Government and the American Medical Association on how to assure highquality medical care erupted in public today.

title: 18 COUNTRIES JOIN IN PLEDGE ON AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The industrial countries that provide 95 per cent of the world's foreign aid to the poorer countries have pledged that they will not reduce their aid programs because of the impact of steeply higher oil prices.

title: We Don't Want a Strike, T. W. U. Asserts
description: The Transport Workers Union, battling against a Monday strike deadline for its more than 35,000 local bus and subway workers, said yesterday that the negotiations for major gains were the most difficult in its 40year history because of the very tight money situation now.

title: Stage: Public Theater's TheKilldeer
Transit Talks Intensify
description: Negotiations aimed at heading off a transit strike threatened for Monday intensified, but crucial wage issues have not been resolved. Page 29.

title: ARTHUR H. RUDERMAN
description: Arthur H. Ruderman, treasurer and cofounder of Olin of New York, Inc., parent company of Olins RentaCar, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Middletown, Conn., Wednesday. He was 59 years old and lived at 14205 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: Stein Sees Economic Lag Limited to Energy Area
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today that the latest statistics indicated that the decline in the economy had been limited to sectors, such as automobiles, affected by the energy shortage and had not spread.

title: The XRated World of William Copley
description: Despite the cautionary notices that some viewers might find the subject matter offensive, the exhibition of Xrated paintings and drawings by William Copley (officially known as Coply) now on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, is rather soft in its treatment of hardcore pornographic situations. True, the rambunctious couples and trios, are all pictured in flagrante delicto of some form or other. But Copleys draftsmanshipa kind of comicbook modern inspired by the dada mastersis generally so indifferent to anatomy (with the exception of a few privileged parts) that his women are more apt to look mangled rather than manhandlld. His interest in bright color and bold patterns  usually beautifully managedis apt to prove distracting as well. The results are too artful to be libidinous, let alone lascivi

title: Bhutto and Mrs. rs. Gandhi: A Comparison
MRS. THOMAS TOMMANEY
description: Mrs. Marguerite Dougherty Tommaney, a retired deputy collector of the Internal Revenue Service and the wife of Thomas Tommaney, political journalist, died yesterday in the New York Infirmary. She was 76 years old and lived at 372 Central Park West.

title: Foreman Is Still Stalled In Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 29 (AP)George Foreman and Ken Norton went sightseeing and rested in their hotels today while attorneys in two countries sought to unravel a tax snarl that has prevented the boxers from leaving Venezuela.

title: 7% FARE RISE BACKED ON ATLANTIC FLIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (Reuters)The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized a 7 per cent increase in passenger fares today for North Atlantic flights.

title: New Jersey Sports His Canadian Pitch
Business Briefs
description: BURBANK, Calif., March 29 (Reuters)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today it had reached agreement with its 24 lending banks to provide a supplemental $75 million line of credit in addition to the $650million provided in its 1971 credit agreement, The financing arrangement is subject to approval by the Emergency Loan Guar'antee Board.

title: Gross Is Convicted Of All 5 Charges In Campaign Fraud
description: NEWARK, March 29  Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was convicted today on five tax fraud and perjury counts that stemmed from is activities as chairman of the 1969 gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill,

title: WILLIAM A. COLEMAN
description: William A. Coleman, director of media relations for the Maryknoll Fathers in Ossininf;, N. Y., died Thursday at his home, 450 Pelham Road, New Rochelle, N. Y. His age was 60.

title: First Major Change Made In Color TV Tube by RCA

description: The Schrafft's on the ground floor of the Chrysler Building has been a landmark of 42d Street for almost 45 years.

title: Books of The Times
description: LOCKED ROOMS AND OPEN DOORS, Diaries and Letters of Anne Morrow Lindbergh, 1933.35. 352 pages. Illustrated, A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book, Harcourt Brace Jovanovtch.

title: Desert Protection Needed
description: Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton has announced plans to give greater protection to three outstanding Federal wildlife refuges in the deserts Of the Southwest.

title: Precision Shooting Offsets a40Point Effort by Hayes
WILLIAM HASSELMAN
description: William Ponningh Hasselman, former Chief Trade Commissioner of the Netherlands and from 1960 to 1966 his country's Consul General in Los Angeles, died yesterday after a long illness at Largo, Fla., where he made his home. His age was 73.

title: People and Business
description: Norton Simon, the investor, and Norton Simon, Inc., the company he founded but is no longer associated with, are two names being mentioned these days in connection with the reported plans of David Merrick, the producer, to make his weight felt at Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation.

title: Sarajevo Hails Assassin but Debates Ethics of Deed
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, March 24With plans going forward for a new movie about the 1914 assassination that brought permanent fame to this ancient and picturesque town, some Sarajevo citizens are wrestling once again with the moral issues of political killing. It was an assassination here on June 28, 1914the victims were Archduke Franz Ferdinand, heir to the AustroHungarian throne, and his wife, Sophie  that precipitated World War

title: Biltmore Shoeshine Man Since 1913, Now Near 90 Is Forced to Retire as Barbershop Closes
BARAKA HEADING NEW LABOR GROUP
description: NEWARK, March 29Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, is. heading a movement to establish a new labor I organization in the city because of the traditional unresponsiveness of labor unions as they relate to black and poor people.

title: RESERVES OFF 6% FOR NATURAL GAS
description: Proved reserves of natural gas in the United States dropped by 6 per cent in 1973, the American Gas Association reported yesterday. This marked the fifth decline in the last six years and dropped proved reserves to their lowest levels since 1957.

title: Dance Team From India Charming
description: Kathak is a classical dance style from India that is rarely seen here, and it was enterprising of the Asia Society to go out of its way to bring Blrju Maharaj, reputedly the greatest exponent of Kathak, to the United States from India for a special tour.

title: Britain No Longer Foreign Tax Haven
description: LONDON, March 29  Turmoil erupted in the foreign business community here today in response to Britain's demise as an international tax haven following the presentation of the labor Government budget.

title: Mrs. Vic Damone's Death Listed as Probable Suicide
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29 (Reuters)The.Coroner's Oftice here today listed probable suicide as the cause of death of the actress Judy Rawlins, 36 years old, a former wife of the singer Vic Damone. Miss Rawlins was found dead in her home here yesterday.

title: Cargo of Beef Stolen
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 29 (AP)  Gaylord L. Espich of Fort Wayne, a truck driver, told the Federal Bureau of Investigation that thieves had stolen his tractortrailer containing 36,781 pounds of beef, valued at $45,000, from a Toledo truck stop. Agents said the empty rig was found this morning at the Willis Day Industrial Park south of Toledo.

title: Oilers Beat Saints, 31
description: ST. PAUL, March 29 (AP) Goals by Bob Sheehan, Ron Anderson and Blair MacDonald led the Edmonton Oilers to a 31 World Hockey Association victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Grant in Semifinal Of Junior Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 29Michael Grant, the topseeded player, advanced to the semifinal round of eighth annual Concord junior invitation tennis tournament today at the Concord Hotel. Grant eliminated Doug Hull of Mountain Lakes, N.J., 62, 60.

title: Bank Robber Is Given 15 Years; Nothing Added for Escape Try
description: A convicted bank robber, one of three who tried to escape from Federal Detention Headquarters in lower Manhattan a week ago, was sentenced to 15 years in prison yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Rockland democratic Chief Backs Samuels'
description: The head of the Democratic party in Rockland County endorsed Howard J. Samuels for governor yesterday.

title: Visits by Jobert and Eban Set Up To Aid FrenchIsraeli Relations
description: JERUSALEM, March 29 (AP)  The foreign ministers of Israel and France will exchange visits this year in an effort to soothe the strained relations between the two countries, government officials disclosed today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 29 (AP)The East, with Marvin Barnes, Len Elmore and Billy Knight, is favored to defeat the West tomorrow in the coaches national college allstar basketball game. The East leads the series, 74, an'd trying for its fifth victory in the last six games. The contest will be seen on Channel 11 in New York at 4 P.M. Bill Walton and Keith Wilkes of the University of California, Los Angeles; Kevin Stacom of Providence and Tom McMillen of Maryland turned down offers to play in the game. Barnes, a 6foot9inch Providence star, averaged 22.1 points and 18,7 rebounds a game this season. Elmore, also 69, teamed with McMillen to lead Maryland to national ranking the last two seasons. Knight, a hometown 66 product, led an unheralded Pittsburgh team to national prominence.

title: Transit Talks Intensify
description: Negotiations aimed at heading off a transit strike threatened for Monday intensified, but crucial wage issues have not been resolved, Page 29.

title: REGENTS PUT OFF CLARK'S REQUEST
description: ALBANY, March 29  The State Board of Regents today deferred action for a month on a resolution by Dr. Kenneth B. Clark asking, the appointment of a special commission to supersede the New York City Board of Education for the purpose of desegregating the city's schools.

title: HUMPHREY BELIEVES IMPEACHMENT LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today supported Senator Mike Mansfield's assessment that there are enough votes in the House of Representatives to impeach President Nixon.

title: Bay State Loses Candidate
description: BOSTON, March 29 (AP) Peter Fuller, a Boston automobile dealer who had planned to run as an independent for Governor, said today that he had decided not to enter the race'Mr. Fuller's father, Alvin Fuller'was Governor in the 1920's.

title: WHITE HOUSE YIELDS DATA SUBPOENAED BY JAWORSKI IN POLITICALGIFT INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The White House agreed today to surrender all the materials 'subpoenaed March 15 by the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS 8 IN CAMPUS DEATHS AT KENT STATE U.
description: CLEVELAND, March 29A Federal grand jury today indicted one present member and seven former members of the National Guard of Ohio on charges of violating the civil rights of four Kent State University students who were shot to death and nine others who were wounded.

title: SWEDEN SAYS SAIGON SABOTAGES ACCORD
description: STOCKHOLM, March 29The Swedish Government charged today that the Paris agreement on Vietnam was being sabotaged by the Saigon Government and its supporters abroad.

title: Yale's Bar Gives In
description: NEW HAVEN, March 29Mory's, the legendary darkpaneled restaurant here celebrated in song by generations of male Yale University students and faculty members, today gave up its threeyear fight to exclude women.

title: Incredulous Bank Teller Foils WouldBe Robber
description: A man handed a note and a paper bag to a teller in the branch of the Greater New York Savings Bank at 90 Broad Street at Stone Street in the financial area at 1:25 P.M. It read:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fiveyear extension of rent stabilization for 275,000 Mt :York City apartments, most of them built since 1947, was signed into law by Mayor Beame in City Hall yesterday. Rent stabilization, applying mostly to buildings built between 1947 and 1969, when the law was adopted, differs front sent control, which applies to one million older apartnierits. Under stabilization, the maximum annual rent increases are based on a study of the cost of operating ipaiiments. The current limits are 6.5 per cent for a oneyear renewal lease, 8.5 per cent for a twoyear renewal lease and 10.5 per cent for a threeyear renewal lease.

title: Park Service Fees Backed
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill expanding the authority of the Park Service and the Forest Service to charge fees for use of campgrounds and picnic sites.

title: Newcombe Is Defeated By Stockton
description: ATLANTA, March (AP) Dick Stockton, returning to the tour after a threeweek layoff, upset topseeded John Newcombe, 76, 64, tonight and advanced to the semifinals of a $50,000 World Championship Tennis Blue Group tournament.

title: 2 Jews Reported Arrested In Soviet Emigration Case
description: MOSCOW, March 29 (UPI) Two young Jews from Moldavia were arrested today when they tried to go to the Communist party central committee building to submit a complaint, Jewish sources said.

title: A Fresh Look, in Photos, at Japan
description: The spectacle of a traditional way of life suddenly subjected to swift and shattering change may bring in Its wake a terrifying burden of political problems and social conundrums, but it is also likely to be a fertile inspiration to artists who bring the requisite combination of curiosity and detachment to the study of its special characteristics. Under the pressure of such change, the past as well as the present acquires a new. vividness. Where everything is in question, everything may be looked at with a fresh eye. Indeed, the act of serious observation may at times be the only mode of moral discipline attainable.

title: U.S. Air Units Based in Thailand To Be Cut by Third in New Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Defense Department anflounced today that nearly onethird of the United States Air Force units stationed in Thailand would be withdrawn in the

title: Wife of U.S. Diplomat in Mexico Begs for Word From Abductors
description: HERMOSILLO, Mexico, March 29The wife of the United States diplomat who was kidnapped a week ago in this northwest Mexican city today urgently appealed to her husband's captors to make contact with her.

title: Judger Entry 25 in Flamingo Today
description: MIAMI, March 29  On paper, the powerful entry of Judger and Cannonade figures. to finish first and second in the Flamingo Stakes tomorrow and go on to Churchill Downs as the heavy favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 4.

title: WHITE HOUSE YIELDS DATA SUBPOENAED BY JAWORSKI IN POLITICALGIFT INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The White House agreed today to surrender all the materials subpoenaed March 15 by the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski.

title: MRS. ROBERT GOELLER
description: Mrs. Mattie E. Goeller, who was an actress on the musicalcomedy stage as Shirley Sherman in the early nineteentwenties, died Thursday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Her age was 76, and she lived in Mamaroneck, N. Y.

title: Dayan Gives Formal Proposals For a Syrian Pact to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Defense Minister Moshe Dayar today gave Secretary of Stab Kissinger Israel's formal pro'posals for troop separation with Syria, opening the latest stage In the efforts to achieve Middle East settlement.

title: DR. S. R. MARDASHEV
description: MOSCOW, March 29 (Reuters)  Dr. Sergei R. Mardashev, vice president of the Soviet Academy of Medical Sciences and a leading cancer researcher, has died in Moscow at the age of 68, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported tonight.

title: Nixon,Said to Reject Amending His Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Nixon's tax lawyers have rejected any, suggestion that he voluntarily amend. his returns and pay additional taxes, and have asked to argue their case before an investigating Congressional committee, sources close to the inquiry said today.

title: A FastPaced Circus
description: The circus this year rushes forward like the wind. Such fast pacing not only tightened the bulging package of humans and animals that Spilled into Madison Square Garden on Thursday night,'but also added snap and sparkle, even a flavor of spontaneity, and made 21/2 hours seem shorternot an easy feat for a mammoth juggernaut called Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey. Is it the Greatest Show on Earth?

title: Cook Concedes More Lies Relating to Vesco Inquiry
STUDY FINDS RISKS IN DIALYSIS CARE
description: BOSTON, March 29 (AP)Researchers have reported thataccelerated hardening of the arteries and increased heart disease have been found to be major risks to longterm survival of patients using artificial kidney dialysis.

title: Burning of Coal by Con Ed Banned After Tomorrow
description: The Consolidated Edison Company will not be allowed to burn coal after tomorrow, the city's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday.

title: POPE CAUTIONS U.N ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: ROME, March 29Pope Paul VI, in a stern message to United Nations officials, reaffirmed his unyielding stand on birth control today.

title: BAN LIFTED ON GAS TO NEW CUSTOMERS
description: NEWARK, March 29 (AP)The State Public Utility Commission today temporarily removed a ban against new naturalgas customers for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. The ban was put into effect last Oct. 12.

title: Conviction Upset in Death Of a Marine Here in 1971
description: The 1971 manslaughter con Mr, Maynard has had three trials. The first ended in a hung jury, the second in a mistrial and the third in his conviction. He was found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree and received a 10to20year sentence, viction of Wiliam A. Maynard the Greenwich Village shotgun slaying of a marine sergeant was set aside yesteron the ground that the District Attorney had suppressed information.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Figures in Shubert Case
description: Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, one of those accused yesterday of obtaining funds illicitly from the Shubert Estate, was head of the Shubert theater empire from 1962 to 1972. He is a grandnephew of the founding Shubert Brothers, J. J., Sam and te the e. His father, Lawrence Shubert Lawrence Sr., was the son of a Shubert sister and the gen. eral manager of the Shubert theaters in Philadelphia.

title: Solzhenitsyn, Clutching a Bouquet, Greets His Tired Family in Zurich
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, March 29Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was reunited with his tired family today after more than sin weeks alone in forced exile.,

title: Mrs. Suparb Yossundara, Active With World Bank
description: Mrs..Suparb Yossundara, director of the Bank of Thailand and a Member of the Thai National Legislative Assembly,. died in Bangkok on Tuesday at the age of 53.

title: Austrian Captures Cup Skiing Title
description: CASPOGGIO, Italy, March 29 (UPI)  Klaus Heidegger of Austria turned in a swift second run today to capture the Vanoni Trophy men's special slalom in the final European Cup Ski event of the season. Christian WittDoering, a teammate, captured the cup title.

title: State Weighing New Rules For Local School Boards
description: TRENTON, March 29  The State Board of Education is considering changes that would greatly restrict the right of local boards to plan construction and determine policies.

title: West Germans Expect Economic Gains
description: BONN, March 29West Ger man officials have shaken off the pessimism engendered by the oil crisis last fall, and now expect growth of more than 2 per cent in the economy this year, Economics Minister Hans Friedrichs told parliament toay.

title: American Woman Reporter Knifed to Death in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 28 (AP)Claudia Ross, a 27yearold American reporter for the Bangkok Post, was stabbed to death today by a man who broke Info her bedroom, the newspaper said.

title: Nixon Hails Veterans Efforts in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)  President Nixon said today that the Americans who served in Vietnam could be proud that the American effort was in good conscience, honorably undertaken and honorably ended.

title: Wheaton College Tuition Up
description: NORTON. Mass., March 29 (AP)  A $350 tiution hose at Wheaton College will increase the annual fee for the 197475 academic year to $4,880, the college said today.

title: Space Hall of Fame Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)Senators Pete V. Domenii, a Republican, and Joseph M. flontoya, a Democrat of New ple7:ico have introduced a bill to authorize transfer or loan of space artifacts to the projected International Space Hail of rame at Alamogordo, N. M. 2he bill would seek the artifacts from the Defense Department and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Delivering Mail Like Men, Maybe better
description: CORAM, L,I.  Five days a weekand sometimes sixor sevenJanet Russell gets up at 5 AM., prepares breakfast for her husband and four children, packs the children off to school, dons a mail carrier's uniform and drives to the United States Post Office here. From 7 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., Mrs. Russell hauls mail from door to door and farm to farm in this lonely, still rural part of Suffolk County.

title: WAIT URGED IN AID FOR EAST EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Senator Adlai E. Stevenson, Democrat of Illinois, asked the ExportImport Batik today to cease all further credits to the Soviet Union and other countries of Eastern Europe pending Congressional action on legislation to extend the life of the bank beyond its scheduled expiration date of June 30.

title: 5 Westerners Seeking Oil Are Captured in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 29 (AP)Guerrillas seeking independence for the northernmost Ethiopian province of Eritrea have captured three Americans and two Canadians exploring for oil, informed sources said today.

title: Jersey Court Acts
description: TRENTON, March 29The State Superior Court ruled today that girls must be permitted to play Little League baseball along with boys in New Jersey.

title: 32 Senators Back Resolution Opposing Panama Canal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (Reuters)Nearly a third of the Senatealmost enough to block a treatytoday publicly opposed giving sovereignty over the Panama Canal to the Panamanian Government.

title: SOVIET HOPEFUL ON ARMS ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, March 29  The Soviet Union today brushed aside pessimistic Western press appraisal of Secretary of State Kissinger's mission to Moscow and asserted that a new accord on strategicarms Iimitation can be worked out by the time of President Nixon's visit here in late June.

title: EDWARD L. CONNOLLY
description: Edward L. Connolly, executive vice president of the 34th StreetMidtown Association, died Thursday night at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth, N. J. He was 70 years old and lived at 457 Westminster Avenue, Elizabeth.

title: FRANCOISE ROSAY ACTRESS, 82, DIES
description: PARIS, March 29Frangoise Rosay, the actress, who played in more than 100 French, British, American and German movies during a 61year career, died here yesterday at the age of 82.

title: Shell Oil Cuts Gasoline Prices by 1.8c
description: The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it had reduced its wholesale gasoline prices by 1.8 cents a gallon; effective immediately.

title: Justice at Kent State
description: By handing down indictments against one present and seven former members of the Ohio National Guard unit whose gunfire killed four students and wounded nine others at Kent State University in 1970, a Federal grand jury has gone a long way toward expunging a dismal chapter in the annals of he judicial system.

title: FUTURES PRICES RISE FOR CATTLE
Shubert Executives Are Sued by State
description: Two of the three top executives of the Shubert theatrical ; and realestate empire and some L members of the family, were f accused yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of ; obtaining millions of dollars from the Shubert estate with claims that were grossly excessive, unjustified and unreasonable.

title: Rising Rates of Interest Push Stock Prices Down

Contract Awards
description: The LTV Aerospace Corporation has received $28.1million addition to an Army contract for Lance bombardment missiles.

title: Cook Concedes More Lies Relating to Vesco Inquiry
description: George Bradford. Cook, one of the Government's chief witnesses, admitted yesterday at the Mitchell.Stans trial that he had lied under oath on three occasions to the grand jury that investigated this case and twice to Congressional committees.

title: Decision on Balk Lines Due Monday
description: MIAMI, March 29The fate of those little white lines that make most pitchers see red will be decided Monday, and it's very likely they'll be rubbed out.

title: CONTROLS LIFTED FROM AEROSPACE
Transit Talks Spread Over Four Floors
description: Much of four floors of the Americana Hotel have been taken over for this weekend's grand finale of the transit negottationstwo for labor and two for management.

title: Campus Notes
description: Urbia, a journal published by the Urban Affairs Institute at Jersey City State College, has made its debut with an issue in which Theodore W. Kheel, the New York labor lawyer, accuses the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey of being selfserving, selfaggrandizing and generally uninterested in consumer rights.

title: Transit Negotiators Intensifying Talks
description: Negotiations aimed at heading off a transit strike on Monday were intensified yesterday, but both sides indicated that the crucial bargaining on wage and costofliving issues might not come until tomorrow night.

title: People in Sports
description: John Shumate, Notre Dame's AllAmerican center, has decided to join the pro basketball ranks and pass up his final season of eligibility at Notre Dame that his experience and knowledge of the game will be a positive force in Duke basketball.

title: Mr. Rodino Goes for a Ride
description: WASHINGTON, March 29One.day the President telephoned Peter Rodino. Listen, he said, if we're going to make that trip to.Impeachment,. let's get on with it. I'm sick ancl tired of waiting.

title: Georgia Leve Wed to C. P. Kimball
description: Miss Georgia Foster Leve, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Arthur Leve of New York, was married here yesterday evening to Charles Porter Kimball, of West Palm Beach, Fla., and New York. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Porter Kimball of Monte Carlo, Monaco.

title: 4 Meehan Dances Are Full of Verve And Translucency
description: Nancy Meehan's way with movement is an extremely fluid one. She deploys her dancers with the verve and translucency of an abstract painter splashing colors on a canvas. She presented her company in four dances Thursday evening at the Theater of the Riverside church.

title: White House Compliance
description: In announcing its willingness to surrender the materials sought by Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski, the WhiteHouse has once again stepped back from the brink of constitutional confrontation. This latest move toward accommodation gains significance as a followup to President Nixon's earlier decision not to contest a Federal court order turning the Watergate grand jury's special report on Mr. Nixon over to the House Judiciary Committee for use in its impeachment study.

title: A Top Israeli Links Golan Pullback to Egyptian Talks
description: TEL AVIV, March 29Israel's principal objective in pursuing a disengagement of troops on the Syrian front is to make it possible to carry forward peace negotiations with Egypt, the Government's chief spokesman said today.

title: WESTBURY MAYOR ACCUSED OF GRAFT
description: MINEOLA, LI., March 29 Patrick Buffalino, the Mayor of the Village of Westbury for the last nine years and a deputy commissioner of the Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs, was arrested today on charges of grand larceny and bribery.

title: Five East Germans Win
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, March 29 (AP)East Germans won all five events today at the opening of the threeday Japan indoor swimming championships. Kornelia Ender won the 100meter butterfly in 1 minute 5.9 seconds; Renate Vogel took the 200meter breaststroke in 2:45.3 and the men's winners were Roger Pytel, 400meter freestyle, 4:15.4; Hartmut Flockner, 100  meter butterfly, 0:57.9 and Roland Matthes, 200meter backstroke, 2:08.7.

title: Bridge: Most of the Favored Teams  Survive Tourney's 3d Round
Elusive Court Reform
description: ALBANY, March 29In the midst of still another heavy year of good government theorizing and legislative bate over court reform, two changes have clearly emerged in courts so far.

title: Mercury Found to Have Magnetic Field
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 29 Mariner 10 zoomed in today for the first closeup look at the planet Mercury and sent back television pictures showing an intensely cratermarked surface gouged, torn and blasted by space debris and 4.6 billion years of proximity to the sun.

title: TARIFFS RAISED O BAIL BEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)President Nixon issued a proclamation today raising tariff duties on many imported radial ball bearings and declar: ing their American manufacturers and workers to be eligible for special aid.

title: U.S. Taxes on Aliens Same as for Citizens
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Aliens residing in the United States, regardless of their country of citizenship, are taxed in the same way as American citizens residing in this country. Salary, investment income and all other forms of income are subject to the same taxes as are imposed on United States citizens.

title: TITO SAID TO WARN SADAT OVER UNITY
description: BRIONI ISLAND, Yugoslavia, March 29  President Tito of Yugoslavia has pointedly reproached President Anwar elSadat of Egypt ror his negotiations with the United States toward, resolving the Middle East crisis, sources close to the Yugoslav Government disclosed today.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS 8 IN CAMPUS DEAR AT KENT STATE U
Shubert Executives Are Sued by State
description: Two of the three top executives of the Shubert theatrical and realestate empire and some members of the family were accused yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of obtaining millions of dollars from the Shubert estate with claiins that were grossly excessive, unjustified And unreaionable.

title: Courting Tree Felled After 5Day Protest
description: BRANFORD, Conn., March 29 A 75foot copper beech tree was felled early this morning after one protester was arrested for trespassing and three young boys were forcibly removed from the tree.

title: Bid to Legalize Marijuana Fails to Get on Coast Ballot
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29 California's Secretary of State, Edmund G. Brown Jr., announced today that a proposed initiative to abolish all criminal penalties for possession and use of marijuana by adults had failed to qualify for the general election ballot in November.

title: ARABS SAID TO FAVOR HIGHER PRICE FOR OIL
description: OTTAWA, March 29All of the Arab oilproducing nations except Saudi Arabia want to increase the price of oil in July, the secretary general of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today.

title: Unexpected Snow Snarls Traffic Here
description: Spring suffered an unexpected setback yesterday with the arrival of several inches of snow, to the chagrin of thousands of city and suburban motorists who were caught with their guard down and their snow tires off.

title: Cole Takes Shot Lead on 66 for 134
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 29 The southwesterly wind that prevails in these parts dame out of hiding today and shook up the scoring in the Second round of the Greater New Orleans open, It also shook up the standing, producing a new leader and moving yesterdye's firstround leaders down into the pack.

title: Exxon Aide Hits Profit Critics
Gift Papers, or, How. a Writer Lost Out in the TaxDeduction Game
Market Place: Viewing Virtues Of 2 Blue Chips
description: For the last couple of days, two of this nation's mightiest corporations American Telephone and General Motors  have been trading at virtually the same stock price.

title: Anker and Board of District 26 Reach Pact Lasting 95 Minutes
description: The City School Chancellor Irving Anker, and the Community School Board in District 26 yesterday announced an agreement for settling their

title: Fixed Money Rates Put Off Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 International officials charged with negotiating world monetary reform formally buried today a return to fixed currency exchange rates for the indefinite future. They agreed on a short list of items that could usefully be negotiated for application in the interim system of floating exchange rates.

title: Prices Drop Again on Amex and OTC
WINE TALK; Buying German Vintages? Here's a Basic Rule
description: Someone came up with good basic rule for buying German wines these days, to wit: Buy 1971's; buy the Spatleses and the Ausleses. And that's it.

title: Jersey Court Acts
description: TRENTON, March 29The State Superior Court ruled today that girls must be permitted to play Little League baseball along with boys in New Jersey.

title: People in Sports
description: John Shumate, Notre Dame's AllAmerica center, has decided to join the pro basketball ranks and pass up his final season of eligibility at Notre Dame.

title: Layer and Dibbs Advance
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., March 29 (AP)Rod Laver defeated Dennis Ralston, 75, 63, today and gained the semifinuals of the $60,000 Desert Tennis Classic.

title: The Filler in the SandWich
description: PARISThank heavens there has been a simmering down in the temperature of the transAtlantic stewpot but that doesn't mean the argument has therefore ended. The only new understanding implied is that it is perhaps wise for the United States and France to trust each other more, without seek. ing'to tie down every last comma of a commitment in signed agreements.

title: Burning of coal  by Con Ed Banned After Tomorrow
description: The Consolidated Edison Company will not be allowed to burn coal after tomorrow, the city's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT uide
description: SPRING PRICE Whether you play golf or chess or jazz guitar, when what you do doesn't seem to match what you have in mind, it's time to go to the pro for clinical advice.. Now, for you guitar pluckers, there's the Jazz Guitar Workshop tomorrow from 4 P.M. to 7 or 8 under the tutelage of the nimble  fingered Chuck Wayne and Joe Puma.

title: Yale's Bar Gives In
description: NEW HAVEN, March 29Mory's, the legendary darkpaneled restaurant here celebrated in song by generations of male Yale University students and faculty members, today gave up its threeyear fight to exclude women.

title: Ehrlichman Reported Set To Drop Wilson as Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, March 29John D. Ehrlichman, concerned about a potential conflict of interest with It R. Haldeman, his former White House colleague, has decided to drop John J. Wilson as his lawyer for the Watergate coverup trials, sources close to the case disclosed today,

title: JOE STECHER, 80, DIES CHAMPION WRESTLER
description: ST. CLOUD, Minn., March 29 (AP)Joe Stecher, a former world heavyweight wrestling champion, died at Veterans Hospital here this week. He was 80 years old.

title: Brazilians in Flooded City Recall Scenes of Horror
description: TUBARAO, Brazil, March 29 Thick layers of mud and debris shroud this onceprosperous agricultural center, which was hardest hit in last week end's countrywide floods.

title: E.P.A. ACTS TO HALT DUMPING IN LAKE
Mrs. King, Misses Casals and Evert Gain
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King had a dream the other night, but it wasn't about Bobby Riggs.

title: Farewell to Controls?
description: The Senate Banking Committee has voted to let wageprice contrOls die April 30. But it would be irresponsible for Congress and the Administration to bail out of all controls when the economydespite a decline in real output is suffering the most severe and prolonged spell of inflation in American peacetime history. Indeed, inflation has been accelerating: consumer prices have climbed at an annual rate of 12 per cent and wholesale prices at a rate of nearly 30 per cent in the past three months.

title: Civil Rights Protector John Stanley Pottinger
description: CLEVELAND, March 29Shortly after John Stanley Pottinger was appointed an assistant attorney general in charge of the Civil Rights Division a year ago he began to get letters from people asking him to reopen the Kent State investigation.

title: LAYOFFS OF 14,200 ANNOUNCED BY FORD
description: DEARBORN, Mich., March 29 (AP)The Ford Company will idle 14,200 workers at nine plants for one or two weeks next Month in a new round of production cutbacks, spokesmen said today.

title: Squash Racquets Tourney Opens
description: Te City Athletic Club open squash racquets doubles tournament got under way last night with five firstround matches. Barry Binns and Mike Downer defeated Larry Heath and Jay Unas, 815, 159, 1817, 1513, while Dan Spinac and Khalid Mir beat Vic Elmaleh and Dave Linden 157, 1511, 1513.

title: Erving, Gale Star Virinia Coach, Player Ejected
Unexpected Snow Snarls Traffic Here
description: Spring suffered an unexpected setback yesterday with the arrival of several inches of snow, to the chagrin of thousands of city and suburban motorists who were caught with their guard down and their snow tires off.

title: F.C.C. Delays Change in WATS Rates
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission today postponed from April 1 to July 1 the effective date of proposed, changes in Wide Area Tele1 phone Service (WATS) rates by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: JURY OF 12 SELECTED IN TRIAL OF BOYLE
description: MEDIA Pa., March 29 (AP)A jury of nine men and three women was completed today to try W. A. Boyle, former head of the United Mine Workers, in the Yabonski murders case. The jury, and two alternates, will be sequestered during the ,trial of the 72yearold Mr. Boyle. Testimony begins Monday and is expected to take about three weeks.

title: Mercury Found to Have Magnetic Field
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 29 Mariner 10 zoomed in today for the first closeup look at the planet Mercury. and sent back television pictures showing an intensely cratermarked surface gouged, torn and blasted by space debris and 4.6. billion years of proximity to the sun.

title: Music: Schuller's Gala
description: Whatever else it may be, Gunther Schuller's Gala Music, which the New York Philharmonic played at Thursday night's subscription concert under Erich Leinsdorf's direction, is not gala. Subtitled Concerto for Orchestra, the fourmovement work seems to celebrate chiefly the composer's talent for manipulating musical materials at great length and to small point.

title: MORE BANKS RAISE RATES FOR LOANS
description: More major banks raised their rates on corporate loans yesterday, but shortterm interest rates in the money market dropped sharply for the first time in weeks.

title: Days Inns Rides BudgetMotel Trend
description: ATLANTACecil Day first learned about renting rooms to people as a rangy, rawboned kid growing up a poor preacher's son in Macon, Ga.

title: PRICES DROP BY 4% IN FARM PRODUCTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)Prices of raw farm prodcuts dropped four per cent from Feb. 15 to March 15, the first decline in four months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Prove Out Set to Show 1973 Success Was No Fluke
Gross is Convicted Of All 5 Charges In Campaign Fraud
description: NEWARK, March 29  Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was convicted today on five tax fraud and perjury counts that stemmed from his activities as chairman of the 1969 gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill.

title: Quake in Aleutians
description: PALMER, Alaska, March 29 (UPI)  An earthquake with a magnitude of 5.3 on the Richter scale shook Kodiak Island in the Aleutians today, but no damage was reported, according to the Palmer Observatory.

title: NELSON CHOWENHILL
description: The Rev. Nelson Le Roy Chowenhill, who was rector of Grace Episcopal Church in Hartford from 1954 to 1970 and had previously been rector of the Holyrood Episcopal Church, 715 West 179th Street, died Wednesday at Orange Park, Fla. His age was 70.

title: Growth Pains Hit Brazil's Car Makers
Sadat Says Soviet Misinformed Him OnSyrian Stand Early in Mideast War
description: CAIRO, March 29President Anwar elSadat said in an interview published here today that the Soviet Ambassador had incorrectly told him shortly after the Middle East war erupted last Oct. 6 that Syria was requesting an immediate ceasefire.

title: 4 Break Church Windows
description: Four youths swinging sticks and pipes smashed 23 5footby8foot stainedglass windows on the four front doors of St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church in Bellerose, Queens, last night, causing an estimated $1,200 in damage.

title: Extra Day to Register Cars
description: ALBANY, March.,29 (UPI) The State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, Arnold R. Fisher, reminded motorists today that all driver licenses and vehicle registrations scheduled to expire In March will remain valid through midnight Monday, April 1, The oneday extension was authorized because the last day of March falls on a Sunday.

title: Harness Manager Named
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 29 (AP)Art Johnson of El Paso, Tex., is the new general manager of the Pocono Downs Harness track, it was announced today. Johnson, 47 years old, formerly was associated with thoroughbred tracks in New Mexico.

title: PAUL D. SCHREIBER
description: Paul D. Schreiber, who retired in 1953 as superintendent of schools in Port Washington, L. I., died Thursday in the Fox Memorial Hospital, Oneonta, N. Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Britain No Longer Foreign Tax Haven
description: LONDON, March 29  Turmoil erupted in the foreign business community here today in response to Britain's demise as an international tax haven following the presentation of the Labor Government budget.

title: Britain, France Disagree on Concorde
description: PARIS, March 29  British and French ministers failed to agree today at a breefing. on the future of the Concorde supersonic airliner.

title: Reported Crime Rose 5% in 73; Saxbe Sees Nixon on Remedies
Stennis Assailant Is Sentenced To Three 1Oto30Year Terms
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)  One of three men charged with shooting and robbing Senator John C. Stennis was sentenced today to three concurrent. 10to:30year prison terms.

title: Screen: The Red Train
Nixon Said to Reject 4mending His Taxes
Ethiopia at the Brink
description: Nearly a decade ago a young Ethiopian Cabinet minister spoke eloquently to an American visitor in Addis Ababa of the necessity for modernization and reform the ancient kingdom. The last great service Haile Selassie could perform for his country, the minister said, would be to pave the way for essential reform, including the political machinery required to manage the difficult transition to representative government after the Emperor's death.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Water Company has received approval to increase annual bills by an average of $13 a customer. The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners in Newark granted the company, the second largest water and sewer operator in the state, inereases for it 118,000 residential and business customers in parts of Middlesex, Ocean, Monmouth, Warren, Atlantic, Hunterdon, Cape May and Burlington counties.

title: Vice President and Provost Is Selected at City College
description: Dr. Robert E. Marshak, City College president, yesterday announced that he had selected Dr. Egon Brenner to be provost and vice president for academic affairs of City College, effective Monday.

title: Rothkos'
description: Gerald Dickler, lawyer for one of Mark Rothko two children, moved in Surrogate's Court yesterday for immediate replacement of three executors of Mr. Rothko's will.

title: Notes on People Eugene Rostow to Plan New Law School
description: Dr. Eugene V. Rostow, former dean of the Yale Law .School and a former high official in the State Department, has been named director of planning for the Touro School of Law, which is scheduled to begin operations here in September, 1975.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los Angeles  Jose Luis del Campo, 129 pounds, Guadalajara, Mexico, outpointed Alberto Reyes, 129, 10 rounds.

title: Vanderbilt U Acts to End Suit By C.B S Against News Archive
description: Vanderbilt University, which maintains the only known national archives of the evening newscasts of all three television networks, has moved In court to dismiss the complaint of the Columbia Broadcasting System that the Archive infringes on C.B.S. copyrights.

title: LIVES PROLONGED LEUKEMIA TEST
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 27British researchers have succeeded In prolonging the lives of adults suffering from rapidly fatal form of leukemia by treating them with tuberculosis vaccine and dead tumor cells from other leukemic patients.

title: Mets Crush Pirates, 115, With 17 Hits
Sports News Briefs
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 29 (AP)The East, with Marvin Barnes, Len Elmore and Billy Knight, is favored to defeat the West tomorrow in the coaches national college allstar basketball game. The East leads the series, 74, and trying for its fifth victory in the last six games. The contest will be seen on Channel 11 in New York at 4 P.M. Bill Walton and Keith Wilkes of the University of California, Los Angeles; Kevin Stacom of Providence and Tom McMillen of Maryland turned down offers to play in the game. Barnes, a 6foot9inch Providence star, averaged 22.1 points and 18.7 rebounds a game this season. Elmore, also 69, teamed with McMillen to lead Maryland to national ranking the last two seasons. Knight, a hometown 66 product, led an unheralded Pittsburgh team to national prominence.

title: Hayes Unstoppable Before, After
description: Elvin Hayes set two official records last night with his 40 points, but the Capital Bullets center may also have set an unofficial mark for the fastest exit from a losers dressing room.

title: Decision on Balk Lines Due Monday
description: MIAMI, March 29The fate of those little white lines that make most pitchers see red will be decided Monday, and it's very likely they'll be rubbed out,

title: SOVIET HOPEFUL ON ARMS ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, March 29  The Soviet Union today brushed aside pessimistic Western press appraisal of Secretary of State Kissinger's mission to Moscow and asserted that a new accord art strategicarms limitation can be worked out by the time of President Nixon's visit here in late June.

title: JOHN LYMAN BISHOP, EAST ASIA SCHOLAR
description: Dr. John Lyman Bishop, lecturer on East Asian studies at Harvard University, died Sunday in Boston, where he lived. He was 60 years old and also lived in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Headliners
description: W. A. (Crony) Boyle, the former United Mine Workers president, has gone on trial for murder in Pennsylvania, charged with instigating a conspiracy to execute Joseph A. Yablonski, and his wife and daughter. Mr. Yablonski, Mr. Boyle's opponent in a disputed 1969 union election, was found shot to death a few weeks after the election. Mr. Boyle has been stripped of his union presidency, has attempted suicide, and has been sentenced to three years in prison for violating campaign financing laws. He still faces Federal charges of conspiring to violate Mr. Yablonski's civil rights.

title: These Mysteries Are Tantalizing
description: THERE has often been something distinctly embarrassing for me about exhibitions of primitive art, especially the best ones. No doubt this has owed mainly to the spottiness of my knowledge in these areas. Like many another uninformed viewer, I tend to spend almost more time scanning wall labels and catalogue prefaces, grasping for straws of illumination, than looking at the works themselves. Beyond that, however, there is another discomfort, a, kind of awe in face of the powerful but inaccessible.

title: Watergate &
description: The struggle between President Richard Nixon and those who are investigating him turned sharply last week from legal debate and political maneuver to the matter of hard evidencethe material the investigators already have, what the President is and is not prepared to yield and what, in the end, it will all prove.

title: Where the Elite Meet To Eat in Opelousas
description: TIRED of New Orleans's aggressively touristic color and glutted with the weight of its spicy French sauces, I asked a huge rednosed man standing at, the marble counter of the Acme Oyster House on Iberville Street where I could find food more typical of the rest of Louisiana, together with some interesting countryside. The man turned out to be Bill Dodd, former Lieutenant Governor during the last years of the bizarre gubernatorial reign of Huey P. Long's brother, Earl. He had strolled in earlier, waved to my friend and me and seemed approachable. But he answered my question by first demonstrating how to make a sauce for raw oysters.

title: Woodbine Residents Reflect
description: WOODBINE  Every Saturday morning, a small group of aging men and women, all descendants of those who came here 80 years ago to escape persecution in Russia, gather in the Brotherhood Synagogue to recite prayers for the dead.

title: Ann Robinson Peake Is the Bride of Robert Dunham Nostrand
description: Miss Ann Robinson Peake and Robert Dunham Nos trend, 1973 graduates of the University of Denver, were married yesterday in St, Mar tin's Episcopal Church, Houston. The Rev. Dr, James Thomas Bagby and the Rev. Robert Johnson officiated.

title: News Summary and Index
Yanks Win, Lyle Tagged For 4 Runs
Design
description: When Charles and Jane Prussack decided to move back to the city from Long Island, they insisted that the living be as easy in the city as in the suburbs. They asked architects Stanley and Laurie Maurer to turn the top two floors of their brownstone on the upper West Side into two duplex rental apartments and to remodel the bottom three floors into a childproof triplex for themselves and their four children Amy, 13, Victor, 11, and Toby. and Louis, 9 (they're twins). The Prussacks left nothing to chance. They tested everything, the architects reported, cracking eggs, spilling milk, squeezing lemons over it, scratching it. Among the ownerapproved choices were slate floors, Formicasurfaced cabinets, industrial carpeting and highgloss paint for walls and woodwork. Along with practicality, the Prussacks wanted drama and elegance. This was provided by an imaginative use of space as sculpture. The eye is both startled and beguiled by stark geometrical forms that not only delineate areas, but also provide exciting transitions between them.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Will consumers stand for the higher prices for clothing expected when price controls are lifted at the end of April?

title: Kissinger Weds Nancy Maginnes
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Henry A. Kissinger married Nancy Maginnes this afternoon in Arlington, Va., and the couple immediately flew to Acapulco for a Mexican honeymoon.

title: Little League Girls Drill Quietly Here
description: There is no grass at P.S. 173, where spring training has started for the first Little League girls team in Manhattan. There have been no demonstrations at the school at Fort Washington Avenue and 174th Street. Few persons are even aware that the embattled Little League has started a separate division for girls this year.

title: Westminster Group Seeks Funds for a Hall of Fame
Nixon Broadcasts Today On Veterans Affairs
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 30 (AP)President Nixon will deliver a live nationwide radio broadcast on veterans affairs at 1:07 P.M. tomorrow, the Florida White House announced today.

title: World News Briers
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 30 (AP) A bomb was thrown into a crowded bar in a Protestant section here today, killing two persons and injuring 15, the police reported.

title: Norton Gets OutForeman Boxed In
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 30Ken Norton left Venezuela today after paying $80,000 in income tax, but the heavyweight champion George Foreman, had to remain behind because his payment of $300,000 came too late for the issuance of tax clearances.

title: Hanoi Reported to Send Civilians South
description: SAIGON, S out h Vietnam, March 30  Recent American and South Vietnamese intelligence reports indicate that Hanoi has begun sending thousands of young civilian men and women from North Vietnam into the South as part of a program aimed at establishing farms and populating areas under Vietcong control.

title: BOCES Leaders Contested in Nassau
description: WESTBURYThe role local school boards play in policymaking decisions of the Nassau County Board of Cooperative Educational Services is at Issue in tomorrow's hotly contested election for two positions on the ninemember BOCES board.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Plant lettuce, onion sets, beets, spinach, peas... Plant cosmos, California poppy, bachelor buttons, sweet alyssum and sweet pea.... Buy shade trees and deciduous shrubs for planting now Send soil samples for testing.... Lime the lawn if needed.... Seed bare spots.... Use 2, 4.D to kill broadleaved weeds.

title: News of the Screen
description: The late Tom Mix, a cowboy star long before John Wayne began chasing Hollywood rustlers, is now slated to be the subject of a 20th CenturyFox feature film as well as of a book to be published by Delacorte Press. Both book and screen adaptation are to be written by Darryl Pontcsan, whose novels, The Last Detail and Cinderella Liberty were turned into recent films.

title: Anne Crichton Seawell Wed to A.B.Robinson Jr.
description: Miss Anne Crichton Seawell, daughter of William T. Seawell, chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, and Mrs. Seawell of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Adam Benjamin Robinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Pine Bluff, Ark.

title: The National Interest
description: The agenda in the case of Richard M. Nixon has narrowed down to.one simple proposition: The House Judiciary Committee is under constitutional duty determine and transmit to the full House its findings on whether the evidence already in its hands and that still to be obtained constitute cause to impeach the President. No action must be taken that might debase these proceedings or jeopardize the public's faith in their fairness.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: MAME, directed by Gene Saks from a screenplay by Paul Zindel and starring Lucille Ball, Beatrice Arthur and Robert Preston, got 7 mixed reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Rex Reed, News; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Judith Crist, New York; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; William Wolf, Cue) and 14 negative (Kathleen Carroll, News; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Molly Haskell, Village Voice; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV, Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; John Simon, Esquire; Pauline Kael, New Yorker; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World; Frank Rich, New Times; Jay Cocks, Time; Gene Shalit, NBC; Archer Winston, Post).

title: The World
description: As open bickering threatened the Middle, East partnership of Egypt and the Soviet Union, the first hesitant steps have been taken in Washington toward implementing Secretary of State Kissinger's formula for achieving a ceasefire between Israel and Syria.

title: Better, Not Bigger
description: So far has the quiet revolution against growth advanced in the United States that an important city has just set the precedent of fixing a ceiling for its own population. Since it already has more people than that limit allows, St. Petersburg, Fla., has told 25,000 residents most recent arrivalsto pack up and go elsewhere.

title: KISSINGER TERMS DAYAN PROPOSAL ON GOLAN USEFUL
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Secretary of State Kissinger wound up two days of talks with the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, today and expressed confidence that he would bring about a troopseparation agreement between Israel and Syria on the Golan Heights.

title: WARRULES TALKS lc CLOSE IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, March 30An international conference convened by Switzerland to modernize the rules of war completed the first of two sessions this week with the United States delegation expressing regret that little progress had been achieved.

title: Unbundling
description: It was a disappointingly modest reform, yet a wave of anguish swept across the securities industry last week on news that the nation's largest brokerage ii.m, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., was reducing its commission charges for the smallest investors.

title: Any Pact Will Put Pressure on Fare
description: Any settlement in the transit negotiations now under way will add millions of dollars to the cost of running the city's subways and buses and put new pressure on the 35cent fare.

title: They've Turned Gatsby to Goo
description: THEY were careless people, Tom and Daisy, says Nick Carraway, the narrator, near the end of F. Scott Fitzgerald's finest novel, The Great Gatsby. They smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made....

title: Pastorates Barred To the Graduates Of Dissident School
description: ST. LOUIS, March 30The commission responsible for interpreting all bylaws in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod has ruled that graduates of a dissident seminary in exile cannot be appointed pastors,

title: Rhoda Temkin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Temkin of West Orange, N. J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rhoda Beth Temkin, to Raymond Albert Sterling Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Sterling of Washington. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Bernards Township Democrat Faces Test as Foe of Industry
description: BERNARDS TOWNSHIPLast November, when William W. Allen, a Democrat, was elected to the Township Committee, the fivemember governing body here, many people interpreted his victory as a vote against further industrial development.

title: U.N. GETS APPEAL FOR SYRIAN JEWS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30Secretary General Waldheim has been asked to intercede on behalf of the 4,000 Jews living in Syria in an attempt to persuade the Syrian Government to allow them to emigrate.

title: Stamps
description: PETER MAX, who has been to the graphic arts what the Beatles have been to music, has done just about everything except design a stampand, now he has done that too.

title: RULING EXPECTED TO SPUR DRUG ADS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30.A recent Federal court decision is expected to accelerate the national trend toward allowing drug stores to advertise the retail prices of prescription products.

title: Idaho State Cancels Garne, Cites Cost
description: POCATELLO, Idaho (UPI) Idaho State University and the University of South Dakota have canceled their seasonopening football game this fall, citing increased travel costs due to the energy crisis.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Muhammad Ali, who fights George Foreman next in Zaire, shouted up to Foreman in the ring after the heavyweight champion's devastating knockout of Ken Norton: If you behave like that, my African friends will put you in the pot.

title: INVESTING
The Artichoke That Isn't Quite What It Seems to Be
description: MINEOLAThe future of the Jerusalem artichoke is in the hands of the people at DeBole's here.

title: Depth Gives Knicks Edge In Playoffs With Bullets
Oxford, Cambridge Row On the Thames Saturday
description: LONDON, March 30 (AP)  Dave Sawyier, the big Olympic oarsman from Chicago, sets out this week to restore Oxford's tarnished image in the 145yearold university boat race.

title: Social Announcements
description: Kennard and Nancy Mandell (nee Razen) of Wellesley Hills, Masts. announce the birth of Rebecca's sister Meredith Erin on March 17, 1974, The proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Louis Razen of Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Coal Mines Reach Deadline For Obeying Code on Safety
description: WHITEWOOD, Va., March 30 The slowmoving Industrial safety revolution, which began in the coal fields in 1968 after the last great mine disaster, finally came tonight for Rex Hobbs, for the 52 blackfaced white men who toil in his mines, for the families they feed.

title: Miss Thayer Hoffstot Is Engaged to Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Phipps Hoffstot Jr. of Pittsburgh have, announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Thayer Drew Hoffstot, to Edward Robert Untermsn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elvin Ian Unterman of New York and Garrison, N. Y.

title: Transit Situation at a Glance
description: PARTICIPANTSThe public agencies involved in the contract negotiations at the Americana Hotel are the New York City Transit Authority and its subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority. They operate the city's subways and publicly owned bus lines. Both are under the supervision of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency.

title: DEAD INFANT FOUND IN AN ICEBOX AT FIRE
description: The body of a 6monthold baby girl, her eyes and mouth covered with tape was found in a refrigerator in a Brooklyn aparttment last night, according to fire officials. Firemen discovered the body while fighting a onealarm blaze at 164 Albany Avenue in the BedfordfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the officials said.

title: Property Tax Law Scored
description: TRENTON  Stung by a ch4rge by a publicinterest lobby that large banks and corporations are reaping financial windfalls by investing money that they owe in delinquent property taxes, state legislators are looking into the possibility of revising municipal tax structures.

title: Teddy Yarosz Is Dead at 63; Was Middleweight Champion
description: MONACA, Pa March 30 (UPI)Teddy Yarosz, former world's middleweight boxing champion, died of cancer yesterday. He was 63 years old.

title: Carlos Wins Two Events In Track
Reds 52 Choice To Win Pennant
description: RENO, March 30 CAP) Cincinnati is a 5.2 favorite to win the 1974 National League pennant, and Oakland and Baltimore are both 52 choices in the Anierican League race, according to Reno oddmakers.

title: Waiting for theend: On nursing homes
description: A thin, graying woman wanders up and down the corridor of a Michigan nursing home in search of a nurse's aide. Could you help my husband out bed? she asks. He didn't feel well earlier in the day but he'd like to get up now.

title: Lakewood School Head Leaving
description: LAKEWOODSuperintendent of Schools William D. Mackolin, whgse progressive racial, policies made him chief election Issue here, will be leaving soon, but his legacy will remain,

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE NIXON ON SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The Democratic party's spokesmen on education charged today that President Nixon's stance on the education bill had fanned the flames of the busing issue, provoked discord and brought confusion and chaos to thousands of school districts all over America.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY MARCH 31, 1974
description: TOMS RIVER  Ocean County Republicans, still reeling from the first major Democratic victories here more than 150 years, have reorganized their party leadership.State Senator John F. Russo, who is also the Democratic county chairman, is pinning his party's election hopes on his performance and that of two colleagues, Assemblymen John P. Doyle and Daniel F. Newman.

title: CONSUMER LEADER CHARGED IN ITALY
description: ROME, March 30  Italy's small consumer movement is in trouble because its leader is accused of having conspired with oliveoil producers for higher prices and of having blackmailed babyfood manufacturers.

title: OTHER THEATER OPENINGS
description: MY FAT FRIENDTonight, Brooks Atkinson, 6:45. A comedy by Charles Laurence. Starring Lynn Redgrave and George Rose.

title: Dorothy Fields Rites Today
description: A funeral service for Dorothy Fields, the song writer, will be held at 1 P.M. today at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Miss Fields died of a heart attack at her home on Thursday evening. She was 68 years old.

title: Long Island Five Wins
description: PATERSON, N.J., March 30 (AP)Roosevelt, L.I., defeated Paterson, N.J., 4745, to win the seventh annual Junior American Basketball Association national tournament championship today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Having staggered the world by doubling crude oil prices last October and then doubling them again in January, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries (OPEC) has now genet'. ously decided to freeze current prices until July 1, After that, OPEC warns, prices may be raised again if the oilconsuming countries fail to control their inflation. In fact, a major justification given for the October and January increases was to keep oil export prices in line with the rising cost of the goods OPEC states were importing.

title: DOCTOR DECRIES PSYCHIATRIC JAILS
description: Dr, Alfred M. Freedman, president of the American Psychiatric Association, has opened a drive for an International conference of leading psychiatrists and jurists aimed at outlawing the use of psychiatric institutions as jails for political prisoners.

title: Trading a Museum's Treasurea Very Hazardous Business
description: AFTER last year's public airing of the Metropolitan's deaccession policies, one would think that other institutions, no matter how small or how private, would reassess their own procedures. But old habits, like old loves, die hard. And one institution that has not profited from the Met's experience is the Museum of the American Indian.

title: How to find to nursing home
description: (1) Plan ahead. Begin investigating nursing homes immediately if your parent has been hospitalized for a serious illness.

title: S. G. Gorray to Marry Letitia Opulente
description: Dr. BlaIse J. Opulente, academic vice president of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, and Mrs. Opulente of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Letitia Anne Opulente, to Stephen Gerard Gorray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Gorray of Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Colleges Shift to Hard Sell In Recruiting of Students
description: American colleges, faced with financial pressures they have not known since Depression days, are resorting more and more to the hard sell in search of students.

title: Busy Mediators in Transit Talks View Themselves as Catalysts
description: We serve as catalysts, Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, said yesterday of the three mediators in the crucial transit negotiations, which have a strike deadline of 5 A.M. tomorrow.

title: ExExecutives as Consultants
description: The idea is not new, but it seems to be growing. Scores of companies are retaining retired senior executives as consultants at fees that run into six figures.

title: Mrs. Capstick Bride Of James A. Howell
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N. J., yesterday, Mrs. Gwendolyn Willey Capstick, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. F. Parker Willey of South Orange, N. J., became the bride of James Abbott Howell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Brown Howell Jr. of Bay Shore, L. I.

title: Women Were His Heaven and His Hell
description: AUGUST STRINDBERGwhose The Dance of Death opens Thursday at the Beaumont  went to his writing the way we today go to psychiatry. Through his art, the Swedish playwright wanted to confront himself, and his enormous body of work contains the most turbulent and the most detailed case history in dramatic literature. A restless experimenter, Strindberg was always in search of new forms through which to free his own psychic demons. Constantly shifting allegiance, struggling first with women and then with God, rejecting the one as he accepted the other, changing idols from Nietzsche to Swedenborg, Strindberg sought and, thankfully, for the sake of drama, never found an Absolute.

title: Two Taxi Drivers Are Slain in Cabs In Brooklyn, Bronx
description: Two taxicab drivers were killed, one in Brooklyn on Fri day night and the other in the Bronx yesterday. Although the police said that the killings apparently were unrelated, it was thought that in each instance the killers were passengers who refused to pay their fares.

title: Ford Calls Campaign Unit An Arrogant, Elite Guard
description: CHICAGO, March 30Vice President Ford, in a speech here today to cheering Republican leaders, sharply attacked the Committee for the Reelection of the President as an arrogant, elite guard of political adolescents.

title: Bartlett Leber Will Be Bride Of Bruce Hyde
description: The engagement of Miss Bartlett Fenton Leber to Bruce Geoffrey Hyde of South Hero, Vt., eon of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Yetter Hyde of Burlington, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Leber 2d of Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a concerned person who has examined the report on the renovation of the Custom House ["A $25Million Renovation of Custom House Studied, March 17], I would like to urge those responsible for the project to consider the report's architectural conclusions with extreme care.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 22yearold woman from Hackettstown, N.J., was arraigned on a charge of assault with intent to kill her 8monthold girl in a case first thought to be an abduction.

title: Two novels
description: The Senator From Slaughter County

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In the world of organized sport, women are gradually breaking down the sex barriers: They're competing against men in horse racing (and winning regularly), track, motorboat racing, surfing and horseshoes. At some high schools, girls are eligible for varsity football. Now, girls in the 8to12yearold set are knocking hard on the boys only door of Little League baseball.

title: Actress Makes Streets Stage
description: Geraldine Fitzgerald, whose acting credits over a 40year career have ranged from Hollywood films to Shakespearean tragedies, held a Brooklyn audience rapt last weekend with readings from that most nostalgic of novels, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn.

title: Police, Businesses and the City Get Ready for Strike
description: The Police Department yesterday prepared its forces around the city to deal with massive traffic problems anticipated if the bus and subway workers strike tomorrow.

title: Problem for Willie Smith: Slow Down to Run Faster
description: Willie Smith, an unbeaten Long Island high school sprinter who broke two national indoor records earlier this month, is being groomed for the outdoor track season by a coach who wants to slow him down.

title: City Appointees Paid by Con Ed To Check Utility's Street Work
description: Every month, Consolidated Edison gets from the city's Transportation Administration a list of 13 to 15 inspectors who stipposedly check on the utility's street repairs, according to a Utility spokesman. In turn, he paid, Con Edison delivers a $666 check each month for each inspector to the agency's offices at 40 Worth Street.

title: Movie Mailbag
