description: To THE EDITOR:

title: So Young Conductors Can Advance
description: A GOOD deal has apparently been happening to the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra since it acquired Sergiu Comissiona as its music director, and New Yorkers will have a chance to judge for themselves when the ensemble plays a concert in Carnegie Hall on May 10. Among other things, however, Comissiona has initiated a Young Conductors Competition, to be held in July. The Rumanianborn music director was himself helped in his career by being a prizewinner in such a competition in Besancon, France, in 1955. He feels that it is one of the few ways in which young American conductors can get ahead, and so he has added his effort to the meager contest opportunities in this country. Part of the prize will be a cash award of $2,000, and those Interested should write immediately to Mrs. Ann Goldberg, Baltimore Symphony, 120 West Mount Royal Avenue, Baltimore, Md. 21201.

title: Epilogue
description: For Elizabeth J. McCormack, the transition from the secular world to the lay world has been completed. Miss McCormack, the President of Manhattanville College, and a nun until her resignation from religious order last January, will join the Rockefeller Brothers Fund in June as special assistant to its president in the area of higher education. After 30 years as a nun, Miss McCormack resigned from the Society of the Sacred Heart because of a fundamental disagreement with the order over the nature of religious life and the diversification of the order's major focus, education, into other areas, such as community living.

title: Mets Lose As McGraw Is Starter
The Wonderland Of Lewis Carroll
description: ROSLYNA collection designed to demonstrate the variety of the works of Lewis Carroll, best known as the author of Alice in Wonderland, Through the Looking Glass and The Hunting of the Snark, will go on display tomorrow at the HewlettWoodmere Library.

title: Kevin Sullivan Fiance Of Miss Amy L. Phillips
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Lewis Phillips of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy Lee Phillips, to Kevin P. Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Sullivan Jr. of Southampton, L. I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Seminar Planned on Moral Issues
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThree New Jersey adult schools and Rutgers University have scheduled a weekend seminar on The Moral Dilemmas of the 1970's. It will be held May 4 and 5 at the Rutgers Center for Continuing Education on the Douglas College campus.

title: Con Edison's Money Problems Are Serious and May Get Worse
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has some of the most serious financial and operating difficulties of any utility in the nation, according to state and regulatory officials, Wall Street analysts and present and former employes of the corporation. And they say there is every Indication the problems are likely to become worse before they improve.

title: Morris Democrats Acquiring Strength
description: MORRISTOWNA change is taking place in Morris County politics. After scores of years of Republican, domination, Democrats are becoming a. force to be reckoned with, and the Republicans, recognizing recent Democratic inroads, are taking steps to offer new faces in this year's countywide elections.

title: Letters
description: No pretense

title: Potato Farming Is Rising In Cost
description: RIVERHEAD  It will cost Long Island's potato farmers nearly 30 per cent more to raise their crop this year  if they can get the supplies they need,

title: Stockton Reaches Net Final
description: ATLANTA, March 30 (AP) Dickie Stockson overcame Ross Case ofAustralia, 6.3, 67, 6.2, and Jiri Hrebec of Czechoslovakia downed Geoff Masters of Australia, 26, 64, 64, in the semifinals of a $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Cost Spurt Coming Out in the Wash
description: The apartmenthouse laundry room is not what it used to be.

title: Future Social Events
description: Here Comes Hank Chapin With Madrigal and Bach April 1Hank Chapin, son of Schuyler Chapin, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is in town with his battered brown valise, clown makeup and a multifaceted show of mime and music called the Suitcase Circus. He plays and sings everything, ineluding folk songs, on five instruments ranging from dulcimer to the cello. No piano? Too bad, his mother is the former Elizabeth Steinway. Hank is aided by two fellow mimes, John Tyson and Katherine Tyson, and by members of the new All Souls Opera Company, the beneficiary of the evening. The place Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street, 8 P.M. Donation, $3, at the door.

title: City to Hear Views On Douglaston Mall
description: A large community turnout is expected on Tuesday when the city's Board of Standards and Appeals hears arguments on a 15store shopping mall that has been proposed for a 4.5acre site along Northern Boulevard in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Conductor's Award to Foss
description: Lukas Foss, conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonia and the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, last night received the $1,000 Alice M. Ditson Conductor's Award for 1974 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Rigs That Drillers Swear By
description: Twenty years ago this spring an ungainly, squat steel box, measuring 150 by 90 feet and sporting a tall lattice steel tower, was sunk into 25 feet of water in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: 5 Discussion Panels Set For P.H.A. Forum Here
description: The 18th annual educetidnal forum for members of the equestrian set will be held tomorrow at the. Belmont Plaza Hotel. It is sponsored by the Professional Horsemen's Association of America. The event is scheduled to get un der way at 2:30 P.M. and run until 10:30 P.M. with a break for dinner. Joseph A. Vanoric of Pound. Ridge, N.Y., is the chairman of the forum.

title: The Challenge of Planting in the Shade
description: SOME gardens have the wonderful advantage of being just right for growing plants in the shade. Though people are often more aware of sunloving than shadeloving plants, it is a wonder that more gardeners are not won over to the challenge of developing a shady garden.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THERE'S an old joke about Gertrude Stein who once wrote a poem about a rose. It said that Miss Stein had worried about inflation, she would have written, A dollar is a quarter is dime.... Today, price inflation is indeed the worry of the hour.

title: Television This Week
They May Reveal a Great Deal About Mr. Nixon's Role
description: WASHINGTONOnce again, it has come down to a set of White House tapes in the effort to determine the truth about Watergate. Only this time it is not the Special Prosecutor seeking evidence about President Nixon's associates. Now it is the House Judiciary Committee seeking evidence about the President.

title: Bridge
description: A famous authority on the game once stated that defense is the hardest part of the game. Great defenders, he suggested, are very much rarer than great dummyplayers or great bidders. Although this is an arguable thesis, it is certainly true that the average player is less skilled in defense than in other areas: the problems are of a varied nature, and the literature available to the student is very limited.

title: Pistons Top Bulls, 9788, In Playoff
The Very Clever Kissinger: Momentum Is Only Part of It
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Henry Kissinger's unorthodox approach to diplomacy has statesmen and foreign officers around the world awed and confounded, dazzled and indignant, admiring and fearful. They admit that he seems to have been remarkably successful, but they are beginning to ask how real are his successes. They wonder how long he can go on involving himself personally in all negotiations without gradually exhausting his influence. And Europeans are pondering, how reliable is the American commitment to Europe after the shock treatment recently delivered by President Nixon and Mr. Kissinger.

title: India Criticized for Abandoning Wheat TakeOver
description: NEW DELHI, March 30An ideological storm broke today in the aftermath of the Indian Government's decision to scrap its takeover of wheat distribution.

title: 51 Dundee Marmalade Wins Westchester by a Nose
description: Dundee Marmalade, Alfred Vanderbilt's steady going campaigner, won the first stakes of his career by taking the $54,900 Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Opposing such sturdy opposition as the Hobeau Farm's Prove Out and the Buckland Farm's Torsion, Dundee Marmalade splashed through to a nose success over Sigmund Sommer's Infuriator.

title: The Nation
description: John W. Dean 3d, the smoothfaced former White House counsel whose scheduled appearance at the MitchellStans trial had cast its shadow across the first three somnolent weeks of the courtroom proceedings, has now given his testimony, and he has fully lived up to his advance billing as the Government's star witness.

title: Roselinn Catalano Plans August Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Catalano of Muttontown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roselinn Joy Catalano, to Peter Joseph Lesniewski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Lesniewski of Port Richmond, S.I. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Miss Sweet Has Nuptials
description: Miss BeckyLee Sweet and Richard Thomas O'Connor of New York were married yesterday afternoon in the Fox Chapel Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh, where the Rev. James M. Dix and the Rev. Harold E, Towne performed the ceremony.

title: He Likes to Be Liked, and Still Have His Way
description: PARISEgyptian President Anwar elSadat is pursuing toward the United States what the French call la politique du sourire"the politics of ingratiation. In a remarkable contrast to the style of his predecessor, Gamal Abdel Nasser, he is heaping encomiums on Secretary of State Kissinger and President Nixon as though determined to embarrass them into fulfilling his ends. It is no secret that Mr. Kissinger has promised Mr. Sadat to achieve substantial Israeli withdrawal. So far, he has delivered only a thin strip of sand on the Suez Canal's east bank. Whether he can prevail on the Israelis to disgorge the remainder of the Sinai and the other Arab territories remains to be seen, but Mr. Sadat is banking all on Mr. Kissinger's word.

title: Mary Trageser Of Boston Bank To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Trageser of Chapel Hill, N. C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Lyrze Trageser of Boston, to Matthew Thomas Birmingham 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Birmingham Jr. of Norwalk, Conn., and Cavendish, Vt. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Memories of a Boy Trout Fishing
description: When I was a boy, the anticipation of the trout season was the sweetest time of year, sweeter, even than Christmas. It was later, much later, that the color and smell of autumn would wrench and wring my heart with its indescribable aura of fulfillment and loss.

title: The Region/ Continued
description: WASHINGTON  The politics of mass transit is as serpentine as the winding route of the I.R.T. express from Pelham Parkway in the Bronx to Utica Avenue in Brooklyn.Similarly, the designation of masstransit routes and the formulation of schedules also reflect political considerations, according to the White House position, The Administration held that masstransit operating subsidies would merely make the unions tougher, the riders more demanding and the costs excessive, because the Federal Government would be picking up the tab.

title: Bushongo, $19.20, Captures Flamingo
description: MIAMI, March 30  The road to the Kentucky Derby passed through Hialeah Park today and a surprise traveler named Bushongo reached a milestone on it with an upset victory in the $128,800 Flamingo Stakes.

title: Televised Trial on Capitol Hill?
description: WASHINGTON, March 90 A few weeks ago, it was a good bet around here that there would be no resignation by the President, no impeachment, and no clear exoneration. In short, an indecisive mess. The outlook was that the Judiciary Committee of the House would vote for impeachment but fail to get a majOrity on the floor to send the President to the Senate for trial. But that was a few weeks ago.

title: A Wife's Story of Her Love and Loss
description: EAST HAMPTON  When Barbara Mahoney was asked why she wrote A Sensitive, Passionate Man, a highly personal account of her life with an alcoholic husband, she paused contemplatively. The words came slowly, almost painfully.

title: Those April Showers
description: April is the traditionally showery month, and many ecstatic words have been written about those showers. Not all those words have been realistic, however.

title: Newark Boys Chorus Seeks Funds
description: NEWARK  The Newark Boys Chorus, which won critical and popular acclaim during a sevenstate concert tour of the South, returned home recently and found the wolf at the door.

title: Education Bill Has Passed the House
description: WASHINGTONThe House of Representatives last week passed a fouryear, multibilliondollar education measure whose most notable feature was a provision that would effectively end busing of school children for desegregation purposes.

title: A Student's Guide Aids Rural Planners
description: CLINTON  The persistent interest of a law student and a little help from the Ford Foundation are providing what is now a largely rural area with model landuse and environmentalcontrol ordinances before it is too late.

title: Weicker Backs Meskill as Judge Despite Bar Group's Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Senator Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, has apparently decided to fight for the nomination of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill to a Federal judgeship despite the indicated opposition of the American Bar Association.

title: The Other Team Cheers Mitchell's Prosecutor
description: If John A. Lowe, a member of the prosecution team at the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans tires of the law, he has an invitation of sorts to try professional football.

title: Book Ends
description: Middletown. If you've been wondering whether the energy shortage has affected reading habitsthe assumption being that people are huddling close to the hearth with a good bookone way of finding out is to call up Leon Jones, head librarian of the Muncie, Ind. (Middletown) Public Library. Well, the quick answer to the question is no, it hasn't. Apparently they haven't had much of an energy crisis out in Indiana. On the other hand, Mr. Jones said, there has been a significant increase in adult reading over the last two or three years. (We'll take any trend we can get.) This was accompanied by a decline in juvenile use of the library, attributable to the fact that there are fewer children in Muncie these days and also to the increased resources available in the schools. Other trends: the library is using more paperbacks than ever and the circulation of audiovisual materials has shot up markedly. The library hasn't been bothered by censorship groups, although the city's porn bookstore was closed by the police. It :s now back in business because the court threw the case out. (Like many states Indiana is struggling to write new obscenity law.)

title: 18,000 Bring $4Million To Gallery for Appraisal
description: More than 18,000 people brought an estimated $4milt lion worth of artwork to he appraised to the Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries during the last four days, as the gallery's Heirloom Discovery Weeks ended last night.

title: Hearing Set on Efforts to Protect Carmans River
description: BELLPORT  Plans to include the Carmans River in the State Wild, Scenic and Recreational Rivers Act will be discussed at an open meeting here on Friday at 8 P.M. at the Bellport Middle School auditorium. A bill intended to preserve the river and adjacent wet lands has been introduced into the Legislature at Albany by Senator Leon E. Giuffreda, Republican of Centereach.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: Reid Lists $511,923 in Contributions to Campaign
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid, In the latest move by a Democratic gubernatorial candidate to open his finances to public scrutiny, disclosed yesterday that up to the end of February he had received $511,923.30 in contributions and loans to his campaign and had spent $470,232.12 of that sum..

title: Kelley Puts His Mark On the F.B.I.
description: The tour of the Federal Bureau of Investigation still leaves every 15 minutes and still features exhibits on The Crime of the CenturyThe Case of the A Bomb Spies (Julius and Ethel Rosenberg) and The Sinister Hand of Soviet Espionage (Colonel Rudolph Abel)". The Ten Most Wanted List still includes six student radicals. A few weeks ago the F.B.I. admitted keeping a subversive file on, and opening a criminal investigation of, a 16yearold high school girl: from Chester, N. J., because a mail cover revealed her as a letter writer to the Socialist Workers party (for a Jtchool project, as It turned out).

title: They didn't come here to solve anything: They came here
description: About 20 years ago, somebody gave me a season ticket to the Poetry Center, and I used to go week after week. I was just quietly in my hole, writing and wanting to be a writer, and yearned for that stage, the promise that it held for this enameled future I would dream about. So when I was finally invited to read, it meantit was an anointment.

title: Central Rape Reports Urged
description: TRENTONIn a move designed to encourage women to report alleged rape to the police, a South Jersey legislator has proposed the creation of countywide lawenforcement agencies that would be modeled after a similar unit in New York City.

title: Ziegenfuss in W.T.T.
description: HONOLULU, March 30 (AP)Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego has signed to play with the Hawaii Leis of World Team Tennis, the team said today. Ross Case of Australia joined the team three weeks ago.

title: Photography
Why Shylock Should Not Be Censored
description: PROTESTS by Jewish organizations over the recent presentation of The Merchant of Venice by the American Broadcasting Company once again raise the old questions: Is Shakespeare's portrayal of Shylock a negative stereotype of the Jew and thus an incitement to antiSemitism? And if so, should it be kept off the air?

title: Action by Judge In Jersey Raises Issue of Court's Role in Zoning
description: HACKENSACK, N. J.A decision by a Superior Court judge to retain his own planning consultants in a zoning case appears to have touched off an argument over judicial prerogatives in community housing policy.

title: A Farewell to Defense Colleagues
description: Following are excepts from an open letter that the writer has distributed to his former defense Establishment colleagues. He resigned Friday from his position as chief of the reconnaissance and mapping branch of the Rome, N. Y., Air Development Center, an Air Force researchanddevelopment laboratory.

title: nome Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH fire extinguishers are not required by law in private residences (they are required in boats and commercial establishments) many safetyconscious homeowners and apartment dwellers do have one or more extinguishers strategically located throughout the house because they realize that these can often be an invaluable aid in stopping small fires before they reach dangerous proportions.

title: Soviet Plans the World's Biggest Conventional Explosion to Build Power Darn
description: The Soviet Union has announced plans for the world's largest conventional explosion to lay the dam for a major waterpower project in a remote river gorge of Central Asia.

title: Measuring Business Schools
description: A new way of measuring the prestige of the nation's top business schools has been devised, and all you need is a very long yardstick.

title: Streaker
description: People who question the health of free enterprise in this country are no doubt reassured whenever a new fad appears, For it seems that one never passes without numerous entrepreneurs trying to cash in.

title: ETHIOPIA CLASHES SAID TO KILL lb
The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win 52,500. Tickets, with the live numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25 Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50

title: Criminals At Large
description: How far back does a book have to go to be classified as a historical novel? Here's THE BIG KISSOFF OF 1944 by Andrew Bergman (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $6.95), and it takes place in those preatomic days when there was only a war on and the world was simple. Thirty years backand it feels like a century ago. Bergman, who knows the privateeye genre in its straitjacketed orthodoxy out of Black Mask through Hammett and the others, has created his own specimen named Jack LeVine, and LeVine is not out to break any trails.

title: LOUIS S. ISAACSON
description: Louis S. Isaacson, an international tax lawyer with the WarnerLambert Pharmaceutical Company, was killed in a twocar accident in Franklin Township, N. J., on Friday evening. He was alone in his car. The driver of the other car, also alone, was unhurt.

title: From Lilliput to Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOKMuseum workers were understandably apprehensive. After years in storage, they were awaiting delivery of 15 roomsfull of delicate period furnishingsQueen Anne secretaries, handpainted murals, inlaid cabinets, handcarved moldings and handwrought chandelierseach a masterpiece of its kind.

title: Air Bags: Subject of Hot Debate
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration ruled the other day that air bags, or some passive restraint system, must be installed as safety equipment for all new 1977 cars. This seems to open the way for a boom for air bag manufacturers. Or does it?

title: Music in Review
description: Guitar recitals generally follow a chronological pattern, beginning with the obligatory Renaissance dances, continuing relentlessly through the Baroque and concluding with the inevitable VillaLobos etude.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CAMDEN, S. C., March 30 (AP)Breaking Dawn, 6yearold gelding owned by Michael Walsh, won the 42d Carolina Cup steeplechase today in an accidentmarred race in which Athenian Idol, last year's champion, broke his neck on the second jump.

title: U.S. ENERGY STUDY STRESSES BALANCE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The nation needs to start deciding now what its energy policies for the longterm future will be and needs to decide not only where the supplies of energy are coming from but how much more demand for energy should be permitted to develop.

title: Lincoln Steffens
description: When The Autobiography of Lincoln Steffens appeared in 1931, it was a happy coincidence for Steffens and for the many confused liberals who were ripe for conversion to something, anything, more positive than the collapse of American values represented just then by Herbert Hoover's America. Steffens's always charming, fascinatingly episodic life, as he told it, could not have been exposed at a more opportune time for the many American liberals and wouldbe radicals who were wondering what to think of life in America and of their own lives in particularin the face of so many reversals.

title: No innocents in this jungle
description: When George V. Higgins's first novel, The Friends of Eddie Coyle, made its debut two years ago, it was clear that Higgins had broken new ground in tapping the perennial lodestone of crime novels. Higgins, then Assistant U. S. Attorney for the District of Massachusetts, displayed unique virtuosity in exploiting an uncanny ear for the argot of the underworld. His ability to capture its textures and rhythms in fiction without losing authenticity immediately established him as an impressive chronicler of the life style and mores of the smalltime hoodlum for whom crime is the only thing that does pay. Moreover, for those of us who are aficionados of the genre it was a rare example of a member of the law and order establishment probing without pious conclusions or clinical transparency the behavioral and mental sets of the petty thief and murderer.

title: The Black Book
description: This is a history book to browse through, wondering at our beauty and our stupidity. There is in it an 1833 handbill for The Public Sale of Negroes, and later a selection of recipes for love potions and hex breakers and voodoo aphrodisiacs. There are birth records of slaves owned by blacks and sheet music for old coon songs.

title: Miss Flinkman Will Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Flinkman of Merlon Station, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Beth Flinkman, to Dr. David, R. Cooper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Cooper of Westbury, L.I.

title: Pop
description: IN the 20thcentury search for life, American Bloods have been bound by the spirit of a common legend: willful flight from the pastoral South.

title: New Chief Steward Cautions Indy 500 Drivers
description: Tom Binford has given notice that he will be a tough chief steward at the Indianapolis 500. He has warned drivers that if they are not lined up properly for the start, they won't get the green flag. If anybody is out of position we will have them on for another lap end another if necessaryuntil they are right, said the man who replaced the con troversial Harlan Fengler this year as boss of the big race.

title: SHOP TALK
description: PARSIPPANYAllen Morgan, president of Taxidermy Unlimited, is an avid outdoersman and evironmentalist, and se, he contends, are most of his customers. There are more of them this year than last because, as game becomes scarcer, hunters are more Inclined to preserve fine specimens.

title: 2 New Planners Set Aims
description: New York City's two largest boroughs, both in terms of population and physical size, will Install new planning directors tomorrow and each of the new appointees intends to make his primary concern the people, not the real estate, in his respective domain.

title: Dr. Elena Schmidt Wed to Dentist
description: Dr. Elena Caryn Schmidt and Dr. David James Zegarelli were married in the Community Presbyterian Church in Mountainside, N. J., yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Elmer A. Talcott, assisted by the Rev. Richard Scannell, Catholic chaplain at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center here.

title: Julia Davis Rewed to William Adams
description: Mrs. Julia Davis Healy of Princeton, N.J., who as Julia Davis is the author of historical novels, children's books and The Anvil, an offBroadway play, was remarried yesterday noon to William McMillan Adams of Canaan, N.Y., 41 years after their divorce.

title: What's White Flight?; By Tom Wicker
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark flew in the face of conventional wisdom when he charged in an extensive report that white flight from New York City had been caused by too little. rather than too much school desegregation. But there is much logic in his position, which is supported by some evidence on white flight recently gathered from Pasadena and other cities in California.

title: Offshore, the Oil Hunt Gets Tough
description: There is not much chance of finding a big enough oil patch to relieve world dependence on the Middle East, the exploration manager of a large oil company said recently, but you can be sure that if one is found it will be under water.

title: Squash Racquets Seeded Team Bows
description: Gordon Anderson and Craig Benson of Toronto upset the third seeded team of Vic Neiderhoffer and Pedro Bacallao of New York yesterday in the open squash racquets doubles championship.

title: Mrs. King, Miss Evert Reach Net Final
description: It will be Mrs. Billie Jean King against Chris Evert today for the $14,000 first prize in the women's national indoor tennis championships.

title: Laurelton Owners ally to Attract Buyers
description: They came, they saw, they munched hamantash. They were even offered a free membership in a synagogue if they bought a house. And the homes they inspected were some of the best buys in New York City: Prewar Tudors, capes and colonials for $33,000 and up.

title: Trade and the Soviet Jews
description: WASHINGTONThe Trade Reform Act of 1973 began as an effort to negotiate lower tariff barriers among Western industrialized nations and Japan. It was soon transformed into a platform for confrontation between skeptics of dtente and the Nixon Administration, and it launched a debate on some of the basic issues of foreign policy.

title: WILSON PICKS PANEL ON TEACHERS PACTS
description: Governor Wilson announced on Friday the appointment of an 11member task force to study alternate ways of resolving negotiations between teachers and local school boards when the Taylor Law provisions have been exhausted.

title: EDWARD B. BENEDICT, SURGEON, DIES AT 77
description: Dr. Edward B. Benedict, who developed the operating gastroscope and received the first Rudolf Schindler award from the American Gastroscopy Society, of which he was a former president, died Thursday at his home in Chestnut Hill, Mass, His age was 77.

title: Princeton Loses, 217
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 30Johns Hopkins captain, Rick Kowalchuk, scored three goals to pace his lacrosse team to a 217 victory over Princeton in the Tigers home opener at Poe Field today. John Hopkins now has a 31 wonlost record. Princeton stands 11.

title: A Land Developer Agrees To Disclose Data to Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The GAC Corporation arranged with the Department of Housing and Urban Development this week to offer complete financial disclosures and development plans to its customers.

title: Albany Moves to Allow Homeowners to Buy Abandoned Spur
description: ALBANYThe State Legislature stepped in last week to settle a longsimmering controversy between the Long Island Rail Road and a group of Queens homeowners.

title: What's Doing in the DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
description: LA ROMANAA still largely unknown resort of exquisite beauty, La Romana dozes quietly in the sun in a sugarmill town of the same name, 1 1/2hours driving time east of Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. Perhaps more than any other resort, La Romans demonstrates that this Caribbean country, after many years of political strife and turmoil, is finally waking up to tourism. The awakening has been slow, but as a result, the Dominican Republic still has miles and miles of unspoiled beaches and a lush, untrammeled mountain range. La Romana started as a small guest house for executives of the Gulf & Western Company, which owns the sugar mill, and grew into one of the loveliest resorts in the entire Caribbean. Facilities today include a golf course by the sea, tennis courts, a stable for horseback riding, and equipment for bicycling, skeet shooting, sailing and, of course, swimming. The resort has 120 rooms, and service is topnotch with rates starting at $45 per room, double occupancy, modified American plan. As another indication of the Dominican Republic's awakening to tourism, the Government is currently building two major resorts and an international airport on the remote north coast. These are scheduled to be completed later this year.

title: TUNISIA PUTS OFF UNION WITH LIBYA
description: TUNIS, March 30The proposed merger between Tunisia and Libya, which startled the world in January, is now a dead letter in the view of knowledgeable political and diplomatic sources here.

title: Mrs. Becker Has Son
description: A son was born here to Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Becker of Roslyn, L. I., on March 19 in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Becker is the former Miss Barbara Florman, daughter of Mayor Marvin George Florman of the Village of Kensington, Great Neck, L. I., and Mrs. Florman. The child has been named Richard Evan.

title: MARINER TO HUNT MERCURY MOONS
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 30 Looking back over its shoulder as it recedes from Mercury, the space craft Mariner 10 is scheduled to begin tomorrow a search for possible moons in orbit around that planet.

title: 1920's Woman Star Held Greatest Ever inTennis
DOCTOR DECRIES PSYCHIATRIC JAILS
description: Dr. Alfred M. Freedman, the president of the. American Psychiatric Association, has opened a drive for an international conference of leading psychiatrists and jurists aimed at outlawing the use of psychiatric institutions as jails for political prisoners.

title: Ellen Leslie Wed To Joseph Cohen
description: Miss Ellen Ann Leslie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Leslie of Woodmere, L, I., was married in Cedarhurst, L. I., last evening to Joseph Alan Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cohen of Troy, N.Y. Rabbi Emeritus Edward T. Sandrow of Temple Bethel performed the ceremony in the temple.

title: News of the Stage
description: Tonescopade, a new musical by Robert Ackerman based on the works of Eugene Tonesco, will open at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, on April 25 under the producing banner of Kermit Bloomgarden and Roger Ailes, cosponsors of the Off Broadway hit, The Hot L Baltimore.

title: Millions of Elderly Suffer As Cost of Living Mounts
description: CHICAGO, March 30 Mrs. Estelle Gilder is a 64yearold Phoenix widow who has decided to leave all of her electric lights off permanently to save some money.

title: Shoemaker Scores 100th In,$100,000 Stakes Race
Udall Accuses Nixon of Sacrificing the Environment to Politics
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A leading Congressional conservationist charged tonight that President Nixon was sacrificing environmental values to impeachment politics and was fostering a disastrous reassertion of the old, discredited naturaf, resource policies of a different age.

title: Emergency Service Begun by Dentists
description: LONG BRANCHThe MonmouthOcean County Dental Society has instituted a 24hour emergency telephone service for the benefit of Monmouth and Ocean County residents.

title: Compromise Keeps Youth Center Open
description: BELVIDERECompromise has prevented the scheduled closing tomorrow of Warren County's monthold, $500,000 juvenile detention and rehabilitation center.

title: Dr. Girija Mookerjee Is Dead; Indian Educator and Author
description: Dr. Girija Kanta Mookerjee, Indian diplomat, educator and author, died last night in Lenox Hill Hospital, after having suffered a heart attack while lecturing before the Association of Indians in America here. He was 68 years old and lived in New Delhi.

title: Fashion
description: Vicky Ifrah would like to be as tall and willowy asa model, but she's only 5 feet 3. So she wears shoes with the highest platforms and heels she can walk on. She insists on welltailored pants that fit across the hips, grow wider toward the hern, and are long enough to hide the shoes. The result is a leggy look. Born in Morocco of French parents, Vicky has a preference for French clothes. Her taste is simple but definite: no frills, no fuss, nothing that overpowers her small frame. For a special evening, she might wear a long skirt with a blouse, but not a formal evening dress. And never a short skirt or a big skirtshe isn't ready to give up those stilts and be short again.

title: Nixon to Seek a Cut in Welfare Funds
description: REY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 30President Nixon said today that he would ask Congress to cut $800million in current welfare appropriations, citing what he called the first major drop in the nation's welfare rolls in a number of years.

title: Doctor Sues U.S. Over Drug Charges
description: A Manhattan doctor and his Wife who operated a private methadone treatment program for drug addicts have sued Federal lawenforcement officials for $4.5million for allegedly haVing falsely described them as the largest suppliers of illicit amphetamines on the East Coast.

title: Leila Pile Bride of John de Bruyne
description: Miss Leila Helene Pile, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Pile Jr. of Brookville, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Adrian de Bruyne, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman A. de Bruyne of Cambridge, England, and Princeton, N. J. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell performed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Sarah Smoot, F. B. Ingraham Have L.I. Bridal
description: Miss Sarah McJilton Smoot, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. William S. Smoot of Laurel Hollow, L. I., and Thomas Island, Me., was married yesterday to Frederic Beach. Ingraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ingraham of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and Lynne, N. H.

title: EndorsementBan End Helping Conservatives
description: With Watergate, inflation and the energy crisis combining to threaten their usual electoral majorities, Suffolk Republicans have ended a threeyearold arrangement with the county's Democrats not to deal with minor parties and are currently negotiating crossendorsements with the Conservative party.

title: Rough Play Sets Tone in Net Victory
Freshman Rowing Goes to St. John's
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., March 30St. John's freshman eightoared crew upset Iona and New York State Maritime College today in the opening event of the Pelham Manor regatta staged by the New York Rowing Association.

title: Mexicans Expect Abducted U.S. Aide To Be Freed Soon
Martha Nolte Is Wed to Frank Cash
description: Miss Martha Shaw Nolte, who is in her first year at the Medical College of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday noon to Frank Joseph Cash, a consulting engineer with the Macro Corporation of Fort Washington. Pa. The Very Rev, Michael J. Campbell performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Media, Pa.

title: French Inflation Spurs Wide Unrest
description: PARIS, March 30Anger at the rising cost of living and the failure of purchasing power to keep up has provoked one of the most serious outbreaks of labor unrest in this country since the uprisings of May and June, 1968.

title: Where Has All the Protest Gone? To Television; The small screen, traditionally the medium for safe entertainment, has grown bolder, while movies have become more cautious
description: ALTHOUGH most American movies have always been designed as escapist fantasies, Hollywood has also produced.a substantial number of hardhitting, topical films dealing with controversial social issues. This muckraking tradition goes back to early Warners exposes like I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang, and continues through such films as Fury, You Only Live Once, The Grapes of Wrath, The Snake Pit, On the Waterfront, Rebel Without a Cause, Blackboard Jungle, Twelve Angry Men, I Want to Live, right up to Easy Rider and Medium Cool. Many these social dramas have dated badly, but over the years they gave American movies a measure of urgency, and a vital connection with the world outside the theater.

title: ALFRED HART PLAYS FRENCH VIOLIN MUSIC
description: French music for violin was the subject of Alfred Hart's program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. With Frances Bing at the piano, Mr. Hart played Leelair's Sonata in D, Franck's Sonata in A, Chausson's Poeme and the Ysaye arrangement of SaintSaens's ValseCaprice. The remaining work was Ysaye's Sonata No. 4 for unaccompanied violin.

title: Miss Jane Rice Will Be Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Jane Margaret Rice to Henry Kapkana Koyuk has been announced by Mrs. H. Edison Rice of Chappaqua, N.Y., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Joachim Koyuk of Nome, Alaska, and the late Mrs. Teresa Koyuk.

title: LILCO Says Coal Could Lower Bills
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 29The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it could lower electricity bills for its 836,000 customers if it was allowed to burn either coal or oil with a higher sulphur content.

title: Teaching Teachers To Teach
description: The first encounter with a classroom full of children can prove traumatic for young men and women learning to be teachers. Textbooks on education theory don't prepare them for the shock they may feel when first faced with a sixthgrader who can't keep up because he's reading at a thirdgrade level, or for the threat to a teacher's authority the challenges of a precocious 10yearold can pose.

title: Let all who are hungry come and eat
description: The youngest son of the family is the star at the Jewish feast of Seder as he opens this basic celebration of Passover by asking the centuriesold question: Why is this night different from all other nights? Mrs. Baruch Zeger, shown at right, says, For me it is the time of an ingathering of my family and I love it. It's one of the few times I get all my sons together. This coming Saturday evening, there will be, as there have been in the past, 30 or more guests in Mrs. Zeger's home. Among the most honored will be hr sons, Eric Segal, best known as the author of Love Story"; David Segal, a stage arid electrical designer, and Thomas Segal, a business executive. Below is a sampling of dishes that Mrs. Zeger will set forth.

title: Even a housing allowance is no answer to poverty
description: In America, as elsewhere, the welfare state actually two: one for the affluent and one for the poor. Nowhere has this duality been more clearly expressed than in. Federal housing policy. Ever since World War H, the Government has subsidized the affluent so that they could buy homes in the private housing market, but has placed the poor in specially designated projects, notably public housing. Last fall, however, the Nixon Administration proposed a new housing policythe housing allowancewhich would subsidize them so that they could also choose their homes in the private market. The housing allowance is intended for the 34 per cent of the poor who still live in deteriorating or dilapidated units, and would pay them the difference between the cost of private housing and percentage of their income, probably 25, if they move into standard nonslum apartments. Actually, the White House is for only paying the allowance to an experimental 20,000 families in 12 metropolitan areas, and it has not yet explained what kind of legislation it has in mind, except to indicate that the undertaking would cost less than existing profor the poor.

title: Joset Walker's Design for Living
description: FLEMINGTON  Joset Walker combined a French flair for fashion with American simplicity and became one of the famous names in sportswear history. Mrs, Walker, whose clothes were popular in the forties, is now retired to the life of a country gentlewoman in Flemington,

title: Philippine Bus Crash Kills 8
description: MANILA, March 30 (AP)The police said today that eight persons were killed and 11 critically injured yesterday when a bus went off a road and fell into a 400foot ravine 200 miles north of Manila, the official Philippine news agency reported.

title: Karen Nelson, Law Clerk, to Wed
description: Miss Karen Nelson and Kenneth Cameron Moore, 1973 graduates of the Harvard Law School, are planning a June wedding. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Nelson of Bethesda, Md., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Moore of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: SAUDI ARABIA announced she would increase production by 1 million barrels a day to 8.5 million, almost equal to the preembargo level.... Canadian exported is going up by 30 cents a barrel to $6.70... The Venezuelan Government proposes to build a 400,000barreladay refinery in Lowell, Mass.... Shell cut the wholesale price of gasoline by 1.8 cents a gallon.

title: Parent and Child: The special growing pains of a science whiz
description: At the highrise apartment building on East 76th Street where Francis Barany lives, I asked the uniformed doorman to announce me.

title: Belleville: Convenient, Comfortable
description: BELLEVILLEPerched between suburban Nutley to the north and urban Newark to the south, this Essex County community of 37,700 people is a mix of today's social and The Talk economic forces that do not allow of for a clearcut deBelleville scription in terms of residential patterns. On the one hand, the visitor gets a feeling of an industrial town that would like to be known as a suburban community; on the other hand, it is possible to drive through many streets that are purely residential, isolated in a way from the hustle and bustle not far distant.

title: Donna Higier Is Wed To Robert J. Siegel
description: Miss Donna Anne Higier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ross H. Higier of Gloversville, N. Y., was married here last evening to Robert J. Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Siegel of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Edward E. Klein performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Two More Puerto Ricans Get City Posts in Wake of Protest
description: Two city employes of Puerto Rican extraction were appointed by Mayor Beame yesterday to deputy commissionerships in the Departments of Correction and Social Services.

title: Theology is a word game
description: The hunt begins quietly enough with a metaphysical dialogue between a puzzled oyster and an unusually wise stone. It ends gloriously with a theological fireworks display illuminating the streets and houses of the City of God. Oh wow! says Capon. And in between, this witty Episcopal priest, aptly called a pop C. S. Lewis, describes the only hunt that really means anything, the search for the elusive mystery of God's relationship to the world. Along the way he snipes at some lesser targets: imprecise theological language, overwhelming concern with morality  usually somebody else'sbut the real object of the hunt is always running ahead, nipped at the heels by his welltrained pack of thehounds.

title: Soviet Informs Public Of Streaking in West
description: MOSCOW, March 30 (AP) Tass told its readers about streaking for the first time today and concluded that it was a sign of the rebelliousness of young people in crisisplagued capitalistic societies.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Foreign investments in the United States are not strictly a recent phenomenon. In fact, many of them were made before the turn of the century and have become such a part of the American way. of life that today their foreign ownership has been forgotten.

title: Alice, a Musical Parody
description: SOMERSET  Students in the Art Department at Franklin Township High School are preparing Lewis Carroll's Alice for a new and different kind of wonderland. Since January, they have been working on a musical version of Alice In Wonderland, one in which songs of the Beatles will provide the musical score for an adaptation that puts all of Alice's famous adventures in a contemporary, satirical setting.

title: Flyers Beat Bruins, Win Title in West
MARINER TO HUNT MERCURY MOONS
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 30 Looking back over its shoulder as it recedes from Mercury, the space craft Mariner 10 is scheduled to begin tomorrow a search for possible moons in orbit around that planet.

title: Miss Cynthia Tilghman Walker Engaged to Piers L. S. Diacre
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York, East Hampton, L. I., and Hobe Sound, Fla,, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Tilghman Walker, to Piers Louis Sunderland Diacre, son of Kenneth Diacre de Liancourt of Tryall, Jamaica, and Mrs. C. Richard HindsHowell of London.

title: J. G. CAVANAGH 65, EXHAT EXECUTIVE
description: NORWALK, Conn., March 30  The Rev. J. Garvan Cava nagh, who gave up a successful career as a member of the Cavanagh hatmaking family of this city to become a Roman Catholic priest, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: SADAT AND TITO END THEIR TALKS
description: BRIONI ISLAND, Yugoslavia, March 30President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today described reports of rifts in the Arab world and among other nonaligned nations over policy toward the superpowers as so much wishful thinking.

title: ANEW ATTORNEY FOR EHRLICHMAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 30John D. Ehrlichman disclosed today that he had retained William S. Frates of Miami, a lawyer closely associated with Charles G. Rebozo, a confidant of President Nixon, to represent him in the pending Watergate coverup trials.

title: S.U.N.Y. STUDENTS ARE FOUND IN DEBT
description: Twothirds of the seniors of the State University of New York who are from families with annual incomes of $20,000 or less are in debt and facing the prospect of having to repay an average of $2,535 in loans that they have borrowed to pay for their education.

title: Senseless Quarrel
description: For twenty years the flourishing relations between Yugoslavia and Italy have served as dramatic proof that even the most intractable and explosive of international problems can be resolved with patience and goodwill. Now, in fits of petulance that defy rational explanation, Belgrade and Rome are restoking the territorial quarrel that once threatened to ignite greatpower conflict but that they settled, in fact it not in law, in 1954.

title: Aparicio, Cut by Red Sox, Listed on AllStar Ballot
N.Y.U. Wins 11th Crown In Fencing
Feminist Therapy Thrives in Bergen
description: TEANECKFive women psychotherapists in Bergen County have found, much to their delight, that the term feminist is not so big a problem as they thought it would be in this politically conservative area.

title: I.R.S. Providing Tax Aid on Phone
description: NEWARK  The Internal Revenue Service will provide telephone assistance to New Jersey taxpayers every Saturday through April 13.

title: P.S.C. to Weigh Steps To Cut AllElectric Cost
description: ALBANY, March 30 (AP)  The state's Public Service Commission agreed today to consider steps to ease the impact of electricrate increasesup to 129 per cent in some casesfor owners of allelectric homes.

title: Reutemann's Grand Prix: He Dedicates It to Revson
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 30  Carlos Reutemann of Argentina led for the last 68 laps to win the South African Grand Prix auto race today and promptly dedicated his victory to the late Peter Revson.

title: Idle Auto Workers Wait and Worry
And the President Shall Have Cameras Wherever He Goes
description: IN the television medium, no message is guaranteed more rapid access to a mass audience than one being delivered by the President of the United States. This creates problems, long recognized but still not resolved.

title: Aircraft Executive Aided Nixon in 72 After DC10 Mishap
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The president of McDonnell Douglas Corporation donated more than $4,000 to President Nixon's reelection campaign in 1972 while the concern was trying to dissuade the Government from issuing an unfavorable report on the DC10, the McDonnell Douglas jumbo jet.

title: Son to Mrs. Wharton
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Richard Gilbert Wharton of New York and Chicago at Lenox Hill Hospital on March 3. The child has been named Jonathan Leonidas. Dr. Wharton is a legislative agent and liaison representative of the New Jersey School Boards Association in Trenton.

title: Carpets and doormats; The Truth About Stone Hollow; By Zilpha Keatley Snyder. Illustrated by Alton Raible. 211 pp. New York: Atheneum. $6.25.; The Lost Farm; By Jane Louise Curry. Illustrated by Charles Robinson. 137 pp. New York: AtheneumMargaret K. McElderry. $5.25.; The Nargun And the Stars; By Patricia Wrightson. 184 pp. New York: AtheneumMargaret K. McElderry. $5.50. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: Books are always being talked about as if they were rugs, with various strands going in and out of them and over and under. If one looks at writers of fantasy for children with this figure in mind, it's apparent that as weavers they often begin with the same basket of wool: a pair of pink and blue skeins named Susan and Peter or Betsy and Roger, some family strands in a clashing color, some green threads for the country or gray ones for the city, and somewhere in the first chapter a bold swatch that upsets the expected design and begins the queer true pattern of the book. The finished rug may be about as interesting as a doormat or it may indeed be the genuine article, a carpet that flies. Sitting down on that first chapter the reader always hopes to feel the thing tremble and lift beneath

title: Man Held in Market Holdups
description: A man who had been sought for more than two months for questioning by the police in connection with at least 40 supermarket holdups was arrested yesterday at 48th Street and 59th Place in Woodside, Queens. The suspect was identified as Louis Roman, 30 years old, of 4733 57th Place, Woodside. He has a police record of 18 previous arrests.

title: Churchmen Act to Free Chile Detainees
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 30 In their first public act of concern for political prisoners, Chile's major religious leaders have filed a habeascorpus motion in a court of appeals here for 131 people who were arrested and disappeared in the months following the military coup last September.

title: The 1,500gram puzzle
description: One of the most frustrating aspects of contemporary science is the appalling lack of communication. Often specialists in the same discipline cannot meaningfully convey to each other, much less the general public, the essence of their research.

title: George B. Cummings, 84, Dies; Headed Institute of Architects
description: George Bain Cummings, president of the American Institute of Architects in 195556, died Thursday in Binghamton, N. Y., where he lived, after having been injured in a fall on March, 23. He was 84 years old.

title: New Greek Church for Clifton
description: CLIFTONThe new St. George Greek Orthodox Church at 818 Valley Road will be formally dedicated next Saturday.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: A PALMSIZED Super 8 movie camera that measures 6 inches long by a little over 4 inches high and less than 1 inches in width has recently been introduced by Yashica, Inc. with the ability to focus down to 0.7 feet and with through the lens viewing. Called the Electro8 Macro, and featuring an f/1.9 manual, zoom lens (9.30mm), the camera uses two 1.5volt penlight batteries for both the electronic exposure system and the motor drive. It has a magnetic shutter release that enables it to be used for timelapse effects, and carries a list price of about $240.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Bowing to pressure from critics, Governor Byrne has agreed to consider extending public financing to gubernatorial primary campaigns.

title: Derby Field Is Set at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 30 Eight 3yearold thoroughbreds, headed by unbeaten Agitate, are primed to start tomorrow in the 37th running of the Santa Anita Derby.

title: Fighting Over the Future of Controls
description: WASHINGTONThe Senate Banking Committee voted last week to let all price and wage controls expire as scheduled at midnight April 30.

title: A writer's sounds and silences
description: A dark hawk face, harsh, gentle and resolute: I look at the photograph of Tillie Olsen with wonder. Nebraska born; lived most of her life in San Francisco; worked and raised four children, during which time the simplest circumstances for creation did not exist. Nevertheless writing, the, hope of it was the air I breathed, so long as I shall breathe at all.. So she wrote in an essay on writers silences published in the Harvard Advocate, Winter 1973. Tillie Olsen knows those silences intimately, myself so nearly remaining mute and having let writing die over and over again in me.

title: Grand Canyon Dam In 80's Considered By 2 Public Utilities
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30Two public utility companies, one in Los Angeles and the other in Arizona, are giving serious consideration to the idea of building a dam in the Grand Canyon. The dam would be used to meet peak energy demands in the two regions by the early nineteeneighties.

title: Numismatics
Parley Scheduled On Racial Conflict
description: EAST BRUNSWICK  A conference on racial, conflict will be held at the Ramada Inn here Tuesday, beginning at 8:45 A.M. Educators from throughout the state are expected to attend.

title: Shah Selling His Oil To Whom He Pleases
description: KISH ISLAND, Iran, March 27  Suddenly this barren, halfforgotten little island in the Persian Gulf has become a new kind of world power center.

title: Theater
description: Benefits Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Candlde the

title: 3 Democrats Got Heavy Labor Help In House Elections
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Organized labor spent more than $70,000  an unusually large amountin support of the three Democratic candidates who won special elections for House seats in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Ohio this year.

title: Kosher Food for Passover and Aspirin, Too
description: You don't have to be Jewish to like matzoh, says Simon Z. Bell, sales manager of Aron Streit, Inc. But it helps.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: A Proposal to Limit College. Varsity Sports to Seniors
description: To The Editor:

title: TRANSIT PARLEY TURNS TO WAGES AND LIVING COST
description: Crucial negotiations aimed at averting a strike by bus and subway workers tomorrow turned yesterday to the vital wage issue and the unions insistence on protection against future costofliving increases.

title: Fashion Is Quiet Now And Some Designers Say That's Just Fine
description: The wild extravaganzas of the nineteenfifties and the headspinning changes of the sixties have wound down. Fashion in the last few years has maintained a relatively low profile and it's likely to remain that way.

title: Turner Chooses Crew for Cup Trials
description: Ted Turner, who will skipper the America's Cup 12Meter contender Mariner, has announced a crew of 10. They are Dennis Conner of San Diego, Calif.; Robbie Doyle of Mar blehead, Mass.; Rich DuMoulin of Cambridge, Mass.; Bill Adams of Wilton, Conn.; Richy Boyd of Islip, L.I.; Robert Derecktor of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; Conn Findlay of Belmont, Calif.; Carl (Bunky) Helfrich Jr. of Savannah, Ga.; Marty O'Meara of Wethersfield, Conn., and Lagree Van Ness of Benton, Tex.

title: Heart of U.S. Darkness
description: PARISAfter the Moscow Kissinger talks, which suggested a slight sag, what strikes me is that, at a moment when it may exercise more diplomatic influence than ever before in history, the United States is so blatantly faced with a crisis in its own leadership that must be internationally mirrored.

title: Red Smith
description: The calendar on the wall tells a story made hilarious by the scene outside the window. The calendar says tomorrow is April 1, and if that Is so, then this must be the time Mr. Shakespeare was talking about when well apparell'd April on the heel of limping winter treads. April apparell'd in ermine, he must have meant. That whiteness outside the window, that chaste and spotless mantle which the poet Nick Kenny identified with sure taste as God's dandruff gives new meaning to All Fools Day. For the first of April is also the opening day of the trout season in New York.

title: Nixon Signs Bill on Funds For Kin of Dead P.O.W.'s
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 30 (UPI)  President Nixon signed today a bill providing funeral transportation and living expenses for the families of deceased Vietnam prisoners of war and men missing in action in Southeast Asia.

title: The Adventures of OYK 834, Or, How I Moped in Britain
description: WHEN Woody Allen's movie wife leaves him in Play It Again, Sam, she says she wants to be free, she wants to ride a motorcycle through Europe, aitd when I saw this scene I said to myself, Yeah, right, I want to do that, too. I want to ride a motorcycle through Polandl Here I had frittered away practically a halfcentury, of my life without ever looking twiee at a motorcycle and now suddenly this dizzy movie chick struck a brand new chord in me without warning. Poland was just summoned up from my subconscious to make my fancy reach a certain desirable degree of surrealism. It wasn't exactly the real Poland that came to mindI had been there once and it rained and the kielbasa (sausage) had bone chips in it7but the magnetically gloomy Poland of Roman Polanski, the landscape of the film Knife in the Water with all those leaves on all those trees reflecting the light, quaking aspens probably, and all that water with the tiny Polish waves on its surface also reflecting the light, and every once in a while a closeup of a stern face, male or female, under some kind of Polish emotional stress. Bir,Ches? Birches, too, there would be, a Marvelously northern, Ingmar Bergman quantity of birches. And I would shoot, along a blacktopped, wet highway, Wet but not being rained on during my trajectory under protecting, leafy tree branches, a graygreen, misty tunnel, my powerful motorcycle humming

title: Thoeni and Miss Proell Win Series Ski Finals
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 30 (UPI) Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, and Annemarie Proell, the favorites, won the Nations World Series of Skiing today at Heavenly Valley's stormwhipped East Bowl.

title: STUDY OF JUSTICE IN CITY IS SCORED
description: Eighteen months after former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller ordered the State Commission of Investigation to monitor, evaluate and make recommendations about New York City's criminaljustice system, its only public product has been a 21page report on the narcotics courts.

title: Ann F. Lilien Has Nuptials
description: Miss Ann Fleming Lilien and Bruce John Singer were married yesterday afternoon in St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N. J. The Rev. Richard Andersen performed the ceremony.

title: The voice of a prophet is heard on The Street
description: I used to get visist from a 3foot6inch Swiss gentleman in funny green leotards called the Gnome of Zurich. The Gnome predictedand this in the middle 1960'sthat the stock market would wither and the price of gold and silver wood go through the roof. We Gnomes, he said, are skeptics. We stand for disbelief. We are basically cynical about the ability of men to manage their affairs rationally for very long. There would be a race between belief and disbelief, said the Gnome; disbelief took people out of paper currencies and into good old gold. The Gnome should have typed up a book; he would have a best seller now.

title: The Nation
description: It has been almost four years since a state grand jury cleared Ohio National Guard troops in the slaying of four students during antiwar demonstrations at Kent State University, and almost three years since former Attorney General John N. Mitchell dropped a Justice Department investigation of the case.

title: Wall Street Baits a Hook
description: Starting tomorrow, for the first time ever, Wall Street's major firms will offer special reduced rates to small investors in the stock market. But there is a hook in that bait.

title: Trevino Shoots a 67 and Ties Cole at 202 in New Orleans
Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Barbara Milberg Wed
description: In the Cottage of the Hampshire House yesterday evening, Miss Barbara Ellen Milberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Max B. Milberg of Brooklyn and Lauderhill, Fla., became the bride of Dr. Kenneth Leigh Sanders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sanders of Perrine, Fla. Rabbi Eugene J. Sack performed the ceremony. Dr. Milberg is a clinical associate professor of medicine at the Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn.

title: City's Garbage Problem Eased By Dumping Ruling in Jersey
description: The city's garbage prolem was at least temporarily eased by a court's striking down of New Jersey's ban on the dumping of outofstate refuse there. But some officials said the move would delay even further a real solution of what to do with New York's garbage.

title: Miss Mary Katherine Lemon Is Married to Thomas Carhart
description: Miss Mary Katherine Lemon and Thomas Carhart, who expect to graduate in June from Antioch College, were married in the Winnetka (Ill.) Congregational Church yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Paul Allen performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the MidAmerica Club in Chicago.

title: Phyllis Weiner Plans Bridal With Michael Shlorno Miller
description: Dr. Meyer Weiner, a dentist, and Mrs. Weiner of Brookline, Mass. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Weiner, to Michael Shlomo Miller, son of Rabbi Israel Miller, vice president for student affairs at Yeshiva University, and Mrs. Miller of the Bronx, New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Africa Remains Adamant on Pro Ban
description: When Zaire became the first black African nation to qualify for the World Cup finals, soccer observers hoped it would be a major step in getting professionalism off the ground on that continent. But nothing of the sort has happened thus far, and good African players continue along the path of their predecessors, who found the professional door shut completely to the black African player.

title: The Barking Deer
description: Among the Montagnard tribes of Vietnam there is a legend about a deer who was befriended by an eagle and a tiger. But the eagle and the tiger fought so bitterly over who should be the deer's protector, that when they were through, very little remained of the deer to protect. This parable is fleshed out by the story of the village of Buon Yon, a Highland hamlet of strategic value to both the Vietcong and the United States Army in the early 1960's. In telling this story, Jonathan Rubin has written the best novel about the war in Vietnam that I have yet read.

title: 3 PUNS DEVISED FOR SUPERAGENCY
description: Roger Starr, head of the city's Housing and Development Administration, says he will offer Mayor Beame three alternative proposals for carrying out the Mayor's aim of dismantling the controversial housing superagency.

title: Kissinger Said to Offer Halt on New Missile
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Administration officials renort that Secretary of State Kissinger told Soviet leaders in Moscow this week that the United States would be prepared. to halt further deployment of missiles with multiple warheads, as part of a new agreement on limiting offensive nuclear weapons.

title: Rutgers Delays Health Institute Pending U.S. Study
description: proposal to set up an Institute of Public Health at Rutgers University is being delayed for at least several months, until the publication of a Federal study outlining the demand for health administrators and health officers throughout the country.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: For Alger B, (Duke) Chapman Jr., the 42yearold newly appointed chief executive of the big Wall Street concern of Shearson, Hammi & Co., Inc., it is a time of testing.

title: American Restoring a 1699 House in London
description: LONDONA historic 17thcentury house in Battersea, across the Thames from London, that has been attributed to the great English architect Sir Christopher Wren is nearing the end of a painstaking, threeyear restoration. The cost of the endeavor, which is expected to be finished this summer, will be about 120,000, or roughly a third of a million dollars.

title: Dance
Acrostic puzzle
Jeffry Bogatin Marries Susan Rothman
description: Miss Susan Ellen Rothman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rothman of Tenafly, N. J., was married here last evening to Jeffrey Bruce Bogatin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Bogatin of Whitemarsh, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the TerraceRoom of the Plaza by Rabbi Dennis N. Math. He was assisted by Cantor Elliot Levine.

title: Saigon Official Warns of Hanoi Offensive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30  Hoang Duc Nha, one of President Nguyen Van Thieu's closest advisers, charged today that North Vietnam was preparing a general offensive aimed at conquering South Vietnam.

title: Child to Mrs. J. L. Levy
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. James L. Levy of White Plains on March 16 in Beth Israel Hospital. Mrs. Levy is the former Miss Leslie Bernstein. The child, whose father is a real estate appraiser and vice president of the Estates Management Co., is named Laurie Ann.

title: Nancy J. Stetson To Marry in June
description: Miss Nancy J. Stetson and Kenneth A. Remsen, graduates of Middlebury College, plan to be married in June.

title: Cosmic exploration? Passages About Earth; An Exploration of the New Planetary Culture. By William Irwin Thompson. Illustrated. 206 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $6.95.
description: Treating a book like this with less than tenderness is enough to make a reviewer feel like The Grindge Who Stole Christmas. William Irwin Thompson is not so much writing about culture as witnessing to a faith that he has apparently been seeking for years. After spend ing his twenties teaching Humanities at various multiversities, Thompson embarked on what he likes to call my Canadian retreat"that is, he left M.I.T. and took a post at York University in Toronto. There he began to study yoga, to contemplate the limitations of rationaltechnocratic society and sense the possibilities of a cosmic awareness.

title: 2 Towns In Accord To Share Health Aid
description: MADISON TOWNSHIPA contract has been negotiated by Madison and East Bruns wick Townships that will provide for partial regionalization of this community's health services.

title: Chess. In Exchange Sacs, You Lose The Rook Before You Reap
In Cold Print: Jackets &
description: Comes now a new organization called Graphic Artists for SelfPreservation (G.A.S.P.), which consists of some of America's most talented and prolific bookjacket designers, protesting that they are being ripped off. The designers, not the book jackets.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: AbertsonExhibition by members of the Aquarelle Club, watercolorists who paint and evaluate their work together, through the month of April, art gallery, Shelter Rock Public Library, 165 Searington Read. For hours, call (516) CH 87363.

title: Steel Scrap
description: When the nation's steel industry tried to raise prices back in the days of President Kennedy, it found itself under harrowing fire. Now the steel industry is getting in some shots of its own against a new culprit In the Inflationary wars. This time it's the suppliers of steel scrap, who are charging as much as $164 a ton.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the pride of meals and the quality of comparable establishments: Roughly, one star may be translated as fair; two stars as good, three as excellent. and four as superb.

title: Notes: Alaska Is Set For New Gold Rush
description: WITH the price of gold running high on world markets, Alaska is preparing for a new gold rush this summerone composed of tourists who hope to strike it rich while vacationing in the 49th state.

title: OPINION: In 10 Years, Much/Little Has Changed
description: Ten years ago, when the Beatles were together and China was dim, the heavy weight champion of the world was an invincible brute of such charisMatic presence and penetrating stare that sports writers were afraid to ask questions in mass press conferences. Sonny Liston could kill you over a telephone.

title: Patricia Wolf Engaged to Tage Strom
description: Dr. and Mrs. George A. Wolf Jr. of Jericho, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Wolf, to Tage Strom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Halvdan Strom of Esbo, Finland.

title: At the Heart of It Is the Price of Oil, Which Has Quadrupled
description: Like a small bomb triggering a larger one, the October war in the Middle East triggered a larger war: the economic attack by the Arab oilproducing states against the industrialized nations. The oil embargo has largely been lifted, but the consequences of that display of economic power are likely to be longlasting for the world's economy. Western statesmen and money managers are struggling to find the technical answers to questions raised by the oil war.

title: Mrs. Meyer Has Son
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Alan H. Meyer of Long Beach, Calif., on March 15 at the Long Beach Memorial Hospital. The child has been named Edward Alan. His mother, the former Miss Carolyn Houchins, Is a daughter of Edward Houchins of Philadelphia. The child is a grandson also of Dr. and Mrs. Albert H. Meyer of Great Neck, L. I. The child's father is a gastroenterologist at Long Beach Veterans Hospital. den Jr. was best man for his brother.

title: Newark Subway May Grow
description: NEWARK  Multilevel Pennsylvania Station, long active as a commuter and Amtrak rail hub, is being eyed by transit planners for yet another role: The main terminal of an expanded trolleycar network.

title: Hearings Set on New Rates For Downstate Phone Calls
description: Three public hearings are to take place this week on the New York Telephone Company's proposal, announced last Feb, 6, seeking a flat charge for each downstate call plus additional charges for length and distance.

title: Terri Palmer Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James L. Palmer of Lambertville, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Terri Lynne Palmer, to J. Alan Brewster, vice president of urban opinion surveys division of Mathematica, Inc., of Princeton, N. J., and project director of Mathematica's healthinsurance study. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Brewster of Murray Hill, N. J.

title: Music
description: A FEW weeks ago I wrote about Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart Jr., the sweet, shy and ineffectual son of the great composer. In passing I mentioned that Antonio Salieri had been one of the younger Mozart's teachers. Now, by coincidence, Salieri is in the news. Last Friday at the Philadelphia Musical Academy his opera Falstaff received what was most likely its first American performance.

title: What Do You Say To a Naked Prima Donna?
description: My WHOLE life functions on love, knockout soprano Carol Neblett says, tall, gorgeous, redhaired and still shapely though pregnant. I'm a love object and a love subject, she continues unabashedly. Whatever I do on this earth comes from needing to be loved and wanting to return it. I would definitely say I'm sensual.

title: Writing in an Occupied Language
description: The situation of writers and cultural life in Spain is a constant source of critical reflection and profound sadness for Spanish intellectuals. In spite of the major changes that have taken place in Spanish society during the last 15 years,, Spanish writers are faced with the same problems in 1974 as in 1954 and 1964. Unless there is some enormous and unexpected transformation of the present political situation, we writers will find ourselves condemned to the same sad and interminable masochistic trap. Our literary life today. like that of the past 35 years, somewhat resembles Ravel's Bolero. One can't see the end.

title: Drunk on a doctor, treated by drink
description: What do we deny ourselves by not wrecking our lives? Could I wreck mine if I wanted to? Could I want to?

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: American Airlines has subleased its space in the Rolex Building at 665 Fifth Avenue to the Spanish National Tourist Office for 21 years at an aggregate rent of more than $3.6million.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Xoregos Company, California Dancers, Delivers Surprises
description: The Xoregos Performing Company of San Francisco, dance troupe directed by Shela Xoregos, made its local debut Friday night at the American Theater Lab, 219 West 19th Street, for a runthrough tonight. Like many manifestations of California culture, the company was full of surprises.

title: HEARST FIGURES ALTER AMIDES;. 53 Days Since Kidnapping, Father and 2 Prisoners Have Changed Stands
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 Only the status of Patricia Hearst remains unchanged. Even though 53 days have passed since her abduction, she is still being held captive and there is still no indiction as to when she might be released.

title: Blackouts, Homeowners and Portable Generators
description: Last December's ice storm, which left thousands of homeowners in the New York area without electric power, wasn't a disaster for everyone.

title: Kelley Seeks to Sell the F.B.I. Among the Academic Community
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass, March 30J. Edgar Hoover would not have believed his ears. There was the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation modestly asking an audience of Harvard students and profEsors for their ideas to help the F.B.I. adapt to human needs and telling them how he hoped to gain insights about the possibility we are straying a bit from the path.

title: The Yen and the Mark Never the Twain
description: PARISThis is a tale of two currencies: the mark and the yen, products of the defeated powers of World War 11, bestriding the narrow World like two colossuses quarter century later. So strong did these two moneys become that they were dubbed undervalued by the noted economists of the day.

title: James Gay Is Fiance of Miss Oskin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Oskin of Winnetka, Ill., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Louise Oskin, to James Peter Gay,.son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Gay of Roslyn, L. I. The wedding is planned for Oct. 26.

title: 111 Red Rum Wins Again At Aintree
description: AINTREE, England, March 30 (UPI)Red Rum outgained Americanowned L'Escargot by seven lengths today and became the first horse in 38 years to win the grueling Grand National Steeplechase race two straight years.

title: Theater: A Proud Touch of the Poet in Hartford
Beame Aide Working to Strip Health Services Agency
description: For a week before his official appointment as first deputy administrator of the Health Services Administration, Milton Kelsky was busily at work on plans for dismantling the agency.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
C.W. Post Stressing No Need Scholarship
description: BROOKVILLE  A subtle, increasing trend toward offering scholarships at colleges And universities across the nation regardless of the applicant's economic situation, has evoked mixed reactions from administrators and educators. But at Long Island University's C. W. Post campus, at least, the concept is rated a major success.

title: ACADEMIES CRITIC TELLS OF PRESSURE
description: An Air Force captain whose twoyear study of the nation's military academies uncovered alleged violations of Constitutional guarantees said he was being invited to resign froth the service because of the controversy created by the survey.

title: A Taste of India in Newark
description: NEWARK  The sariwrapped Indian women crowd around the front end of the AmericaIndian Traders store at 801 Sanford Avenue, selecting their favorite spices from the labeled shelves.

title: Kissingers Staying At Acapulco Villa Owned by Friend
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 30 (UPI)Secretary of State Kissinger and his bride, Nancy, are staying at a luxurious villa overlooking Acapulco Bay.

title: Gardens
